Zevachim



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All slaughtered offerings that were slaughtered not for their own sake,</b> i.e., during the slaughtering the slaughterer’s intent was to sacrifice a different offering, <b>are fit,</b> and one may continue their sacrificial rites and partake of their meat where that applies. <b>But</b> these offerings <b>did not satisfy the obligation of the owner,</b> who is therefore required to bring another offering. This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all offerings <b>except for the Paschal offering and the sin offering.</b> In those cases, if the owner sacrificed them not for their own sake, they are unfit. But there is a difference between the two exceptions. <b>The Paschal offering</b> is unfit only when sacrificed not for its sake <b>at its</b> appointed <b>time,</b> on the fourteenth day of Nisan after noon, while <b>the sin offering</b> is unfit <b>any time</b> that it is sacrificed not for its sake.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The guilt offering too</b> is unfit when sacrificed not for its sake. According to his opinion, the correct reading of the mishna is: <b>The Paschal offering</b> is unfit only <b>at its</b> appointed <b>time,</b> while <b>the sin offering and the guilt offering</b> are unfit <b>at all times. Rabbi Eliezer said</b> in explanation: <b>The sin offering is brought for</b> performance of <b>a transgression and the guilt offering is brought for</b> performance of <b>a transgression. Just as a sin offering is unfit</b> when sacrificed <b>not for its sake, so too, the guilt offering is unfit</b> when sacrificed <b>not for its sake.</b>
<b>Yosei ben Ḥoni says:</b> Not only are the Paschal offering and the sin offering unfit when slaughtered not for their sake, but also other offerings <b>that are slaughtered for the sake of a Paschal offering and for the sake of a sin offering are unfit.</b>
<b>Shimon, brother of Azarya, says</b> that this is the distinction: With regard to all offerings, if <b>one slaughtered them for the sake of</b> an offering whose level of sanctity is <b>greater than theirs, they are fit;</b> if one slaughtered them <b>for the sake of</b> an offering whose level of sanctity is <b>less than theirs, they are unfit.</b>
<b>How so? Offerings of the most sacred order,</b> e.g., sin offerings and burnt offerings, <b>that one slaughtered for the sake of offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> e.g., peace offerings, <b>are unfit. Offerings of lesser sanctity that one slaughtered for the sake of offerings of the most sacred order are fit.</b> Likewise, there is a distinction between different offerings of lesser sanctity. <b>The firstborn</b> animal <b>and the</b> animal <b>tithe that one slaughtered for the sake of a peace offering are fit,</b> as the sanctity of peace offerings is greater. <b>Peace offerings that one slaughtered for the sake of a firstborn</b> animal <b>or for the sake of</b> an animal <b>tithe are unfit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: All slaughtered offerings that were slaughtered not for their sake are fit, but they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> using the language: <b>But they did not [<i>ella shelo</i>] satisfy</b> the obligation of the owner? <b>Let it teach</b> simply: <b>And they did not [<i>velo</i>] satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b> What does the word: But [<i>ella</i>], add?
The Gemara responds: By adding <b>this</b> word, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the only deficiency with regard to these offerings <b>is that they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner, but they retain their sanctity, and it is</b> still <b>prohibited to deviate</b> from the protocol <b>of their</b> sacrificial process, i.e., the remaining rites must be performed with proper intent.
<b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava, as Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a burnt offering that one slaughtered not for its sake,</b> it is still <b>prohibited to sprinkle its blood</b> on the altar <b>not for its sake.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument</b> to support this statement, and <b>if you wish, cite a verse</b> as proof. The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument:</b> Just <b>because</b> one <b>deviated</b> from protocol <b>in its</b> sacrifice once, i.e., in its slaughter, could it be that <b>he should continue to deviate</b> from protocol <b>in all</b> the rest of the sacrificial rites? One deviation does not justify additional deviations.
And <b>if you wish, cite a verse: “That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do; according to what you have vowed [<i>nadarta</i>] freely [<i>nedava</i>] to the Lord your God,</b> even that which you have promised with your mouth” (Deuteronomy 23:24). The Gemara interprets the words <i>nadarta</i> and <i>nedava</i> exegetically: Can <b>this</b> verse be referring to <b>a gift</b> offering [<b><i>nedava</i></b>]?

Daf 2b

<b>It is</b> already referred to as <b>a vow</b> offering <b>[<i>neder</i>]. Rather,</b> the verse indicates that <b>if you did what you vowed</b> to do, i.e., you sacrificed your vow offering properly, <b>it shall be</b> a satisfactory <b>vow</b> offering; <b>and if</b> you did <b>not</b> sacrifice it properly, <b>it shall be</b> rendered a voluntary <b>gift</b> offering unrelated to the vow, and shall not satisfy the obligation of your vow.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And is it permitted to deviate</b> from protocol <b>in</b> the sacrifice of <b>a gift</b> offering <i>ab initio</i>? Clearly it is not. Evidently, even if one of the sacrificial rites was performed for the sake of sacrificing a different offering, it is still prohibited to perform any of the other sacrificial rites in the incorrect manner.
§ <b>Ravina said to Rav Pappa:</b> Since <b>you were not with us last night within the</b> Shabbat <b>limit of Bei Ḥarmakh,</b> you did not hear <b>that Rava raises a contradiction between</b> two <b>superior</b> mishnaic <b>statements and teaches their</b> resolution.
<b>What</b> are these <b>superior statements? We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>All slaughtered offerings that were slaughtered not for their sake</b> are fit, but they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner. Rava infers: <b>The reason</b> they do not satisfy the obligation of the owner is specifically <b>that</b> they were slaughtered <b>not for their sake. But</b> if offerings were slaughtered <b>without specification</b> of intent, <b>they, as well, satisfied the obligation of the owner. Apparently,</b> if one performs any action <b>without specification</b> of intent, it is <b>also considered as</b> if he performed it expressly <b>for its sake.</b>
<b>And</b> Rava <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 24a): <b>Any bill of divorce that was written not for the sake of</b> the <b>woman</b> in question is <b>not valid. And</b> it is derived from the continuation of that mishna that if a bill of divorce was written <b>without specification</b> as to which woman it is referring, it is <b>also not valid.</b>
<b>And</b> Rava <b>resolves</b> the contradiction: <b>Ordinary slaughtered offerings stand</b> designated <b>for their</b> own <b>sake.</b> From the time that the offering is consecrated, its presumed end is that it will be slaughtered for the type of offering for which is was consecrated. Therefore, even if the one slaughtering it has no particular intention, it is in effect considered slaughtered for its own sake. By contrast, <b>an ordinary wife does not stand</b> designated <b>for divorce.</b> Therefore, a bill of divorce is never presumed to be referring to a given woman unless it is specified explicitly.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that <b>slaughtered offerings are fit</b> and even satisfy the obligation of the owner if slaughtered <b>without specification? If we say</b> it is <b>from that which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>All slaughtered offerings that were slaughtered not for their sake</b> are fit, but these offerings did not satisfy the obligation of the owner, <b>and</b> it <b>does not teach</b> this using the language: All slaughtered offerings <b>that were not slaughtered for their sake</b> are fit, but these offerings did not satisfy the obligation of the owner, this cannot be. One cannot infer from this language that slaughter without specification is valid, since the Mishna <b>also teaches with regard to a bill of divorce: Any bill of divorce that was written not for the sake of the woman is not valid, and it does not teach: That was not written for the sake of the woman is not valid,</b> and it is a given that a bill of divorce written without specification is not valid.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps it is derived <b>from that which we learned</b> in a mishna (13a): <b>How</b> are offerings slaughtered <b>for their sake and</b> then <b>not for their sake?</b> For example, one might slaughter the Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering and</b> then <b>for the sake of a peace offering.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> such an offering is unfit is <b>that he says</b> that he is slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering and</b> then he says that he is slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a peace offering. But</b> if he says that he is slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering, and</b> then slaughters it <b>without specification,</b> it is <b>fit. Apparently,</b> slaughtering an offering <b>without specification is considered as</b> if one slaughtered it <b>for its sake.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps there it is different, as</b> the mishna <b>is saying</b> that <b>anyone who performs</b> an action <b>performs</b> it <b>with</b> his <b>original intent</b> in mind. Therefore, since he specified initially that he was slaughtering the offering for the sake of a Paschal offering, there are no grounds to assume that he then changed his mind. Here, by contrast, he pronounced no initial statement of proper intent.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps this <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from the latter clause</b> of that mishna: How are offerings slaughtered <b>not for their sake and</b> then <b>for their sake?</b> For example, one might slaughter the Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a peace offering and</b> then <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> it is unfit <b>is that he says</b> he is slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a peace offering and</b> then he says he is slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering. But</b> if he started slaughtering it <b>without specification and</b> then slaughtered it <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering,</b> it is <b>fit.</b> Apparently, if one slaughters an offering without specification it still satisfies the obligation of the owner.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps there it is different, as</b> the mishna <b>is saying</b> that <b>his ultimate</b> intent <b>proves</b> the nature <b>of his original</b> intent. Since his ultimate intent was to sacrifice a Paschal offering, that was presumably his original intent as well. Here, by contrast, there is no ultimate expression of proper intent.
<b>Alternatively,</b> it can be explained that even if one’s ultimate intent is not considered proof of his original intent, the mishna still uses the same term in both clauses to preserve symmetry. <b>Since</b> in the former clause the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> using the language: <b>For their sake and</b> then <b>not for their sake,</b> teaching that original intent is considered proof of ultimate intent, the <i>tanna</i> <b>also taught</b> the second clause using the language: <b>Not for their sake and</b> then <b>for their sake.</b> In any event, there is no proof from that mishna that an offering slaughtered without specification satisfies its owner’s obligation.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps this <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from that</b> mishna (46b), which states: <b>The offering is slaughtered for the sake of six matters: For the sake of</b> the particular <b>offering; for the sake of the one sacrificing</b> the offering, i.e., the owner; <b>for the sake of God; for the sake of</b> consumption by the <b>fires</b> of the altar; <b>for the sake of</b> sacrificing it in a manner that gives <b>an aroma;</b> and <b>for the sake of pleasing</b> God. <b>And the sin offering and a guilt offering</b> are slaughtered <b>for the sake of</b> atonement for the <b>sin.</b>
The mishna on 46b continues: <b>Rabbi Yosei said: Even</b> in the case of <b>one who did not have in mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for the sake of</b> any <b>one of these,</b> the offering is <b>fit, since</b> this <b>is a stipulation of the court.</b> The Gemara explains Rabbi Yosei’s opinion: The <b>court stipulated that</b> one <b>should not say</b> that he is slaughtering the offering <b>for its sake, lest he come to say</b> that he is slaughtering it <b>not for its sake.</b> Therefore one should not specify his intent at all.
The Gemara infers: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that if one slaughters an offering <b>without specification</b> it is <b>unfit, would the court arise and stipulate a matter that disqualifies</b> the offering? Clearly, an offering slaughtered without specification is fit and satisfies the obligation of the owner.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to a bill of divorce, from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> if it is written <b>without specification</b> as to which woman it is referring, it is <b>not valid?</b>
<b>If we say</b> it is inferred <b>from that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 24a): In the case of a man who <b>was passing through the marketplace, and</b> he <b>heard scribes</b> who write bills of divorce <b>dictating</b> to their students: The <b>man so-and-so divorces so-and-so from</b> the <b>place</b> of <b>such and such, and</b> the man <b>said: This is my name and that is the name of my wife,</b> and he desires to use this bill for his divorce, this bill is <b>unfit to divorce</b> his wife <b>with it,</b> that is not a proof.
It can be explained: <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>of Rav Pappa. As Rav Pappa says: Here we are dealing with scribes who are wont to practice</b> writing bills of divorce; <b>and</b> this bill of divorce is a draft and <b>was not written for the sake of severance,</b> i.e., divorce, <b>at all.</b> But if a bill of divorce is written to be used for divorce, perhaps it is fit even if written without specifying the woman in question.
<b>Rather,</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the subsequent clause in <b>that</b> mishna:

Daf 3a

<b>Moreover,</b> if a husband <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce with which <b>to divorce his wife but</b> later <b>reconsidered,</b> and <b>a resident of his town found him and said to him: My name is</b> the same <b>as your name, and my wife’s name is</b> the same <b>as your wife’s name,</b> and we reside in the same town; give me the bill of divorce and I will use it, the bill of divorce is <b>unfit</b> for the second man <b>to divorce</b> his wife <b>with it.</b> Evidently, even if the bill of divorce was written to be used for divorce, if it was not written specifically for the given woman it is not valid.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps there it is different, as</b> the bill of divorce <b>was</b> specifically <b>designated</b> For <b>the sake of that</b> man’s <b>divorce,</b> and therefore it is not valid for the second man’s divorce. But a bill of divorce that was written without specification might be valid if written for the sake of divorce.
<b>Rather,</b> derive it <b>from</b> the subsequent clause in <b>that</b> mishna: <b>Moreover,</b> if <b>he has two wives whose names are identical,</b> and he <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>to divorce the older</b> one, and then reconsidered, <b>he may not divorce the younger</b> one <b>with it.</b> Evidently, a bill of divorce must be written specifically to divorce a specific wife.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps there it is different, as</b> the bill of divorce <b>was</b> specifically <b>designated for the sake of the divorce of that</b> other wife.
<b>Rather,</b> derive it <b>from</b> the subsequent clause in <b>that</b> mishna: <b>Moreover,</b> if <b>he said to the scribe [<i>lalavlar</i>]: Write</b> a bill of divorce for one of my two wives who have identical names, <b>and I will</b> use it to <b>divorce whichever</b> one of them <b>that I want,</b> this bill of divorce is <b>unfit to divorce</b> either wife <b>with it.</b> Evidently, it must be written for the divorce of a specific woman.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps there it is different, as there is no</b> retroactive <b>designation.</b> The designation of the bill of divorce cannot be determined retroactively. It cannot be used for either wife because it was possibly written for the sake of the other wife. But a bill of divorce written without specification may be valid.
<b>Rather,</b> derive it <b>from that</b> mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 26a): With regard to a scribe <b>who writes the standard</b> part <b>of [<i>tofesei</i>] bills of divorce</b> in advance, so that when one requests a bill of divorce, he will have to add only the details unique to the case, <b>he must leave</b> empty <b>the place</b> of the name <b>of the man, and the place</b> of the name <b>of the woman, and the place</b> of the names <b>of the witnesses, and the place of the date. And</b> in addition, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> A scribe <b>must also leave the place of</b> the essential phrase: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man,</b> since it must be written for the sake of that specific woman. Evidently, a bill of divorce must be written for a specific husband and wife, and if not it is not valid, even if it was written for the sake of divorce.
§ Ravina continued to inform Rav Pappa of Rava’s statements: Rava <b>further raises another contradiction: Did Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav says</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a burnt offering</b> is <b>unfit,</b> whereas if one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>for the sake of</b> consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> meat, it is <b>fit? Apparently,</b> only improper intent that is <b>of its type,</b> i.e., for the sake of another offering, <b>ruins</b> the offering and renders <b>it</b> unfit, whereas wrong intent that is <b>not of its type,</b> i.e., for the sake of consumption of non-sacred meat, is disregarded and <b>does not ruin it.</b>
<b>And</b> Rava <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the aforementioned mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 24a): <b>Any bill of divorce that was written not for the sake of</b> the <b>woman</b> who is being divorced with it <b>is not valid; and</b> by inference, <b>even</b> if it was written <b>for the sake of a gentile woman,</b> it is <b>not valid.</b> With regard to the matter of divorce, a gentile woman is not of the same type as a Jewish woman, as the <i>halakhot</i> of bills of divorce are irrelevant to her.
<b>And</b> Rava <b>resolves</b> the contradiction: If <b>a bill of divorce</b> is written for the sake of a gentile woman it is not valid, because if you <b>remove</b> the intent for the sake of <b>a gentile woman from it, it is</b> considered to be <b>without specification</b> of the woman who is divorced with it, <b>and</b> a bill of divorce written <b>without specification is not valid.</b> But if <b>sacrificial</b> animals are slaughtered for the sake of consumption of non-sacred meat, they remain fit, since if you <b>remove</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> intent <b>from them, they are</b> considered to be <b>without specification, and</b> offerings slaughtered <b>without specification are fit.</b>
§ <b>And</b> Rava <b>raised another contradiction: Did Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav says</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a burnt offering</b> is <b>unfit,</b> whereas if one <b>slaughtered it for the sake of</b> consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> meat it is <b>fit? Apparently,</b> he holds that only improper intent that is <b>of its type ruins it,</b> whereas wrong intent that is <b>not of its type does not ruin it.</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states with regard to ritually impure carcasses of creeping animals: “And every earthen vessel into <b>whose interior</b> any of them falls, anything that is in its interior shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:33). From the word “interior” it is derived that only food in its interior is rendered impure, <b>but not</b> any food that is in <b>the interior of its interior,</b> i.e., in another vessel within the earthenware vessel. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> not only if the inner vessel is an earthenware vessel; <b>even</b> if it is a metal or wooden <b>vessel,</b> which is purified though <b>rinsing</b> in a ritual bath and is therefore susceptible to impurity from its exterior, it nevertheless <b>protects</b> food that is inside it from being rendered impure. Evidently, even a vessel that is not of the same type serves to nullify the status of the interior of an earthenware vessel.
<b>And</b> Rava <b>resolves</b> the contradiction as follows: A vessel purified through rinsing is actually considered of the same type as an earthenware vessel, since they are both vessels. Concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of impurity, the equivalent of intent with regard to the consumption of non-sacred meat is an item that is not a vessel at all; the Sages <b>rendered non-sacred</b> meat <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> animals <b>like a partition with regard to</b> an earthenware <b>oven: Just as a partition in an oven is not effective at all</b> in preventing the transmission of impurity from one side to the other since it is not a vessel, <b>so too,</b> slaughtering an offering for the consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> meat <b>is not effective at all with regard to</b> rendering <b>sacrificial</b> animals unfit.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 8:1): In the case of <b>an oven that</b> one <b>divided with boards or with curtains, and</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal was found in one place, all</b> of the food in the oven, including that on the other side of the partition, is rendered <b>impure.</b>
The mishna continues: In the case of <b>a round barrel that is broken and plugged up with straw and lowered into the airspace of the oven,</b> if the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> is <b>inside</b> the barrel, <b>the oven</b> is rendered <b>impure.</b> And if the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> is <b>in the oven,</b> the <b>food that is inside</b> the barrel is rendered <b>impure.</b> The broken barrel is not considered a vessel despite its being plugged up with straw, and therefore it does not prevent the transmission of impurity between the creeping animal and the oven. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> the food in the barrel <b>pure.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> My opinion can be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i>: If</b> a barrel or any other partition between some item and a corpse under the same roof <b>protects</b> the item <b>from</b> becoming impure, even though impurity imparted by <b>a corpse</b> is <b>severe</b> in that it lasts seven days, <b>shouldn’t</b> a partition <b>protect</b> food <b>in</b> the airspace of <b>an earthenware vessel</b> from impurity imparted by the carcass of a creeping animal, <b>which is mild</b> by comparison?
The mishna continues: The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> Your inference is <b>not</b> correct.

Daf 3b

<b>If</b> a partition <b>protects</b> an item <b>from</b> impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> which is <b>severe,</b> this is only <b>because</b> such impurity is unique in that it is imparted to that which is in the same tent, i.e., under the same roof, and <b>tents are divided</b> by partitions. If so, <b>should</b> a partition <b>protect</b> food from impurity imparted <b>in an earthenware vessel, which,</b> although <b>mild, is not divided by</b> partitions, like <b>tents</b> are?
The Gemara notes: The comparison between non-sacred meat vis-à-vis offerings and a partition in an earthenware vessel <b>works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that a partition does not prevent transmission of impurity inside an earthenware vessel. But <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who maintains that a partition is effective in an earthenware oven, <b>what can be said?</b> How is this compatible with the principle that an item is not affected by something not of its type?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> agrees with this principle. Yet he <b>says</b> that a partition in an earthenware vessel is effective due to his <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which overrides the principle that an item is not affected by something not of its type.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If that is so,</b> that an <i>a fortiori</i> inference overrides this principle, <b>let us say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>there as well,</b> with regard to a sin offering that was slaughtered for the consumption of non-sacred meat: If slaughtering sacrificial animals for the sake of other <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>desecrates</b> those <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that slaughtering them for the consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> meat desecrates them?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather, the reasoning</b> behind the statement <b>of Rav</b> that a sin offering slaughtered for the consumption of non-sacred meat is fit is not in accordance with this principle at all, but it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. As Rabbi Elazar says: What is the reasoning</b> behind the statement <b>of Rav?</b> The verse: <b>“And they shall not desecrate the sacred items of the children of Israel, which they set apart unto the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 22:15), teaches that only improper intentions for the sake of <b>sacred items,</b> i.e., offerings, <b>desecrate sacred items, but non-sacred</b> intent <b>does not desecrate sacred items.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>Apparently,</b> an inference from <b>a verse</b> can <b>come to rule out</b> a conflicting <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. If so, <b>here too,</b> with regard to a partition in an oven, <b>let</b> the verse “and every earthen vessel into <b>whose interior</b> any of them falls” <b>come to rule out</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that a partition prevents food in an oven from becoming impure.
The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> expression: <b>“Whose interior,”</b> does not indicate that a partition is ineffective, as it <b>is necessary to</b> teach another <i>halakha</i>, namely, that <b>food that one kneaded with clay,</b> covering it from all sides, <b>and put in the airspace of an oven</b> that had the carcass of a creeping animal in it is impure. Because it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the food <b>cannot become impure by touching</b> an impure item, as the clay serves as an interposition, <b>it also cannot become impure</b> by being put <b>in the airspace of</b> an impure oven. The phrase “in whose interior any of them falls” <b>teaches us</b> that the food does contract impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis,</b> who apparently do interpret the verse as teaching that a partition is ineffective in preventing the contracting of impurity in an earthenware vessel, how do they derive that food covered with clay and placed in an impure oven is impure? The Gemara answers: <b>These</b> matters <b>do not need a verse</b> to teach them. Such food has the same status as any other food in an impure oven, and the <i>halakha</i> therefore is self-evident.
§ <b>Rav Yosef bar Ami raises a contradiction</b> between Rav’s statement with regard to <b>deviation</b> with regard to the type <b>of offering,</b> i.e., slaughtering for the sake of a different type of offering, <b>and</b> Rav’s statement with regard to <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> i.e., slaughtering for the sake of someone other than the offering’s owner, <b>and</b> he then <b>resolves</b> the contradiction.
The contradiction is as follows: <b>Did Rav say</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for the sake of</b> another <b>sin offering,</b> i.e., one that the owner is obligated to bring for a different transgression, is <b>fit,</b> but that if one slaughtered it <b>for the sake of a burnt offering</b> it is <b>unfit? Apparently,</b> slaughtering an offering with an improper intention <b>not of its type ruins it;</b> whereas intent that is <b>of its type does not ruin it.</b>
<b>But doesn’t Rav say</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for</b> a person who is not its owner but <b>who</b> nevertheless <b>is obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering</b> is <b>unfit,</b> whereas if one slaughtered it <b>for</b> a person <b>who is obligated</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering,</b> it is <b>fit? Apparently,</b> an improper intention that is <b>of its type ruins</b> the offering, whereas intent <b>not of its type does not ruin it.</b>
<b>And</b> he <b>resolves</b> the contradiction as follows: <b>There,</b> with regard to deviation from the type of offering, <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33). <b>And</b> here <b>a sin offering was slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering,</b> and therefore although it was for the sake of a different sin offering, it remains fit.
<b>Here,</b> concerning deviation with regard to the owner, it <b>is written</b> in the Torah concerning a sin offering: <b>“And he shall be forgiven”</b> (Leviticus 4:26), indicating that specifically <b>he,</b> the owner, <b>but not another</b> person, shall be forgiven. Therefore, if a sin offering is slaughtered for the sake of another person, it is unfit. <b>The other</b> person to whom this is referring is presumably <b>similar to him,</b> the owner of the sin offering, in <b>that he is obligated</b> to make <b>atonement similar to</b> that of the owner. Therefore, if the other person is obligated to bring a burnt offering and not a sin offering, this disqualification does not apply.
§ <b>Rav Ḥaviva raises a contradiction</b> between Rav’s statement concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner and</b> the aforementioned <i>baraita</i> concerning <b>the interior of its interior,</b> i.e., a vessel placed in an earthenware vessel, <b>and resolves</b> the contradiction.
The contradiction is as follows: <b>But did Rav say</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for</b> a person other than its owner but <b>who is</b> also <b>obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering</b> is <b>unfit,</b> whereas if one slaughtered it <b>for</b> a person <b>obligated</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering,</b> it is <b>fit? Apparently,</b> an improper intention that is <b>of its type ruins it,</b> whereas intent that is <b>not of its type does not ruin it.</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if the carcass of a creeping animal is found inside an earthenware vessel, the vessel’s <b>interior</b> is rendered impure <b>but not the interior of its interior,</b> and <b>even a vessel</b> purified through <b>rinsing,</b> if placed in the earthenware vessel, <b>protects</b> food inside it from contracting impurity? Evidently, impurity in the airspace of an earthenware vessel can be contained by something not of its type.
<b>And</b> Rav Ḥaviva <b>resolves</b> the contradiction as follows: The expression: <b>Whose interior [<i>tokho</i>], is written four</b> times. In other words, in the verse: “And every earthen vessel into whose interior [<i>tokho</i>] any of them falls, anything that is in its interior [<i>tokho</i>] shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:33), the word <i>tokho</i> is mentioned twice, and each time, the verse could have written: The interior. Since the possessive: Its, is added to each instance, the verse is interpreted exegetically as though the word interior [<i>tokh</i>] were mentioned four times: <b>Interior [<i>tokh</i>], whose interior [<i>tokho</i>], interior [<i>tokh</i>],</b> and <b>its interior [<i>tokho</i>].</b>
<b>One</b> of these is necessary <b>to</b> teach the matter <b>itself,</b> that an im-pure earthenware vessel imparts impurity to food in its airspace; <b>and one</b> instance is used <b>for a verbal analogy</b> between the two instances of the word interior, from which it is derived that an earthenware vessel itself contracts impurity from impure items in its airspace.
<b>One</b> indicates that <b>the interior</b> airspace <b>of this,</b> i.e., an earthenware vessel, renders food impure, <b>but not the interior of another</b> type of vessel, which imparts impurity only through contact; and <b>the other</b> instance indicates that <b>its interior, but not the interior of its interior,</b> imparts impurity, <b>and</b> that <b>even a vessel</b> purified through <b>rinsing,</b> if placed in the earthenware vessel, <b>protects</b> food inside it from becoming impure. Consequently, it is derived from a verse that inside an earthenware vessel, other vessels not of its type can block the transmission of impurity. Since this halakha is derived from a verse written in that context, there is no reason to assume that a similar <i>halakha</i> would apply to slaughter.

Daf 4a

§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that we require</b> that an offering’s <b>slaughter</b> be performed <b>for its own sake?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “And if his offering is a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of peace offerings”</b> (Leviticus 3:1), teaching <b>that slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>] must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> when the verse states: “A sacrifice of peace offerings,” “a sacrifice of peace offerings” <b>is</b> simply <b>the name of</b> this type of offering, and is not referring to intent of the one slaughtering it.
The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is written</b> in other verses: <b>“Who offers the blood of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:33), and: <b>“Who sprinkles the blood of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:14), <b>and</b> the term: <b>A sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>], is not written,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> in this verse, the term: <b>“A sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>]</b> of peace offerings,” <b>is written, learn from it that</b> the <b>slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>] must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>slaughter</b> must be performed for the sake of the offering being sacrificed. <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> i.e., collecting the blood, conveying it to the altar, and sprinkling it on the altar, must also be performed for the sake of the offering?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from</b> the fact that <b>slaughter</b> must be performed for the sake of the offering that the other sacrificial rites must be performed for the sake of the offering as well, this derivation can be refuted, as slaughter has a unique element of stringency: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about slaughter?</b> It is unique <b>in that with regard to a Paschal offering,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified</b> if it is slaughtered <b>not for the sake of those who eat</b> it. If the Paschal offering is slaughtered for the sake of people who are incapable of eating it, such as one who is too ill to eat, it is disqualified. By contrast, performing other rites with this intent does not disqualify the offering. Therefore, one cannot assume that a <i>halakha</i> that applies to slaughter applies to other rites as well.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, the verse states: “Who sacrifices [<i>hamakriv</i>] the blood of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:33), referring to the one who collects the blood of the offering, as the Gemara will explain. This phrase indicates <b>that</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the Torah only <b>with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>and we would derive from it</b> that <b>slaughter</b> must also be performed for the sake of the offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> such a derivation <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about collection</b> of the blood? It is unique <b>in that it is not valid</b> if performed <b>by a non-priest or a woman,</b> whereas slaughter can be performed by any competent Jew. Therefore, one cannot assume that a <i>halakha</i> that applies to collection applies to slaughter as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>slaughter and collection</b> of the blood must be performed for the sake of the offering. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> applies to the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood as well?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from these</b> rites, i.e., slaughter and collection, that this <i>halakha</i> applies to the sprinkling of the blood as well, this derivation can be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about these</b> rites? They are unique <b>in that</b> for offerings of the most sacred order, it is <b>required</b> that they be performed in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard. <b>And</b> furthermore, these rites <b>are</b> performed <b>in the</b> sacrifice of <b>inner sin offerings</b> as well as standard sin offerings. The sprinkling of the blood on the external altar, by contrast, is performed in all portions of the Temple courtyard, and it is not performed in the sacrifice of inner sin offerings, whose blood is sprinkled only in the Sanctuary.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, the verse states: “Who sprinkles the blood of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:14), indicating <b>that</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to sprinkling, and we would derive from it</b> that it applies to slaughter and collection as well.
The Gemara answers: That would not be sufficient, <b>because</b> such a derivation <b>can be refuted,</b> as sprinkling has a unique element of stringency. <b>What</b> is unique <b>about sprinkling?</b> It is unique <b>in that a non-priest is liable to</b> be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> performing <b>it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>all</b> four rites save <b>conveying</b> the blood to the altar. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this latter rite must also be performed for the sake of the offering?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from all</b> the other rites that conveying the blood must also be performed for the sake of the offering, this derivation can also be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about all of</b> the other rites? They are unique <b>in that</b> each of them is <b>an indispensable rite. Would you say</b> that any requirement that applies to those rites necessarily applies also <b>with regard to conveying</b> the blood, <b>which is dispensable?</b> If an offering is slaughtered by the side of the altar, it is unnecessary to convey its blood to the altar.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall sacrifice [<i>vehikriv</i>] the whole,</b> and make it smoke <b>upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:13), <b>and the Master said</b> that <b>this</b> is referring to <b>conveying</b> the <b>limbs</b> of the offering <b>to the ramp</b> of the altar. <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And</b> Aaron’s sons, the priests, <b>shall present [<i>vehikrivu</i>]</b> the blood” (Leviticus 1:5), that <b>this</b> is referring to the <b>collection of the blood. And</b> one can infer that <b>the Merciful One expresses</b> collection of the blood <b>in the</b> same <b>language</b> used for <b>conveying, to say that you should not exclude conveying from the category of collection</b> of the blood. Therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> of collection apply to conveying.
The Gemara asks further: <b>And we found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the type of <b>offering,</b> i.e., that an offering may not be slaughtered for the sake of a different type of offering. <b>From where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> i.e., that an offering may not be slaughtered for the sake of one who is not the owner?
<b>Rav Pinḥas, son of Rav Ami, says: The verse states</b> with regard to a thanks offering: <b>“And the meat of the sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of his thanksgiving peace offering</b> shall be eaten on the day of his offering” (Leviticus 7:15), apparently indicating <b>that</b> its <b>slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>] must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a thanks offering.</b> And <b>if</b> this language <b>is not</b> needed <b>for the matter of deviation</b> with regard to the type of <b>offering,</b> and in fact it is not, <b>as we</b> already <b>derived</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from there,</b> i.e., the verse cited concerning peace offerings, <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b> It is thereby derived that an offering must be slaughtered for the sake of its owner.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does this</b> verse <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>Isn’t it necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Concerning the phrase <b>“and the meat of the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering,” Abba Ḥanin says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> It <b>comes to teach</b> that <b>a thanks offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a peace offering is fit;</b> whereas <b>a peace offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a thanks offering is unfit. What</b> is the <b>difference between this</b> offering <b>and that</b> offering? <b>A thanks offering is called a peace offering</b> in that verse, <b>but a peace offering is not called a thanks offering.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>We are saying</b> that it is derived <b>from</b> the superfluous term: <b>“Sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>],”</b> that the slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>] must be performed for the sake of the owner. The term “peace offering” teaches Abba Ḥanin’s ruling.
The Gemara disputes this: <b>But</b> the term “sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>]” is <b>still necessary</b> to serve as the source for another halakhic midrash: <b>From where</b> is it derived that the meat of <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering</b> may be eaten only on the day the animal is sacrificed and the following night, like a thanks offering? <b>The verse states:</b> “And the meat of the <b>sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>]</b> of his thanksgiving peace offering shall be eaten on the day of his offering.” The phrase teaches that not only thanks offerings, but any slaughtered offering [<i>zevaḥ</i>] is subject to this time limit unless the Torah specifies otherwise.
The Gemara answers: <b>If that were so,</b> i.e., if the term “sacrifice” indicated only that a sin offering and a guilt offering may be eaten only for the period of time for which a thanks offering may be eaten, <b>let the verse write: And the meat of his thanksgiving peace offering sacrifice. What</b> is indicated by the mention of the word <b>sacrifice</b> before the phrase “his thanksgiving peace offering”? Rather, <b>conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>slaughter</b> must be performed for the sake of the owner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> must also be performed for the sake of the owner?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from slaughter</b> that the other rites must be performed for the sake of the owner as well, this derivation can be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about slaughter?</b> It is unique <b>in that with regard to a Paschal offering,</b> slaughter <b>not for the sake of those who eat</b> it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, whereas performing the other rites not for the sake of the owner does not.
The Gemara answers: A term of <b>slaughter is stated with regard to deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering, and</b> a term of <b>slaughter is stated with regard to deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner. Just as</b> concerning the term <b>slaughter stated with regard to deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering, you did not differentiate between slaughter and</b> the <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> and all four rites must be performed for the sake of the offering, <b>so too,</b> concerning the term <b>slaughter stated with regard to deviation</b> in the context of the <b>owner, you should not differentiate between slaughter and</b> the <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites.</b>
The Gemara counters: This derivation <b>can be refuted: What</b> is unique <b>about deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering,</b> as opposed to deviation with regard to the owner? It is unique with regard to four matters: First, it is unique <b>in that its disqualification concerns</b> the essence of the offering <b>itself. And</b> second, it is unique in that deviation from the type of <b>offering applies to</b> the <b>four</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> whereas performing a rite for the sake of the owner is relevant only to the sprinkling of the blood, which atones for the owner.
<b>And</b> third, it is unique in that deviation from the type of offering <b>applies</b> even <b>after</b> the <b>death</b> of the owner, when the owner’s heir brings the offering, whereas intent for the sake of the owner is irrelevant after the owner has died. <b>And</b> fourth, it is unique in that deviation from the type of offering <b>applies with regard to communal</b> offerings <b>as well as with regard to individual</b> offerings, whereas employing the term owner is irrelevant with regard to communal offerings, which are owned by the public.

Daf 4b

<b>And although two</b> of these distinctions <b>are not precise,</b> the other <b>two are in any event precise</b> distinctions, based upon which a distinction can be drawn.
The Gemara explains why two of the distinctions are not precise: <b>What is different</b> about <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> such <b>that its disqualification does not concern</b> the offering <b>itself?</b> It is that this <b>merely</b> constitutes a change of <b>thought. Deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering is also merely</b> a change of <b>thought;</b> the offering is not physically affected. <b>Rather,</b> this distinction between deviation with regard to the owner and deviation from the type of offering is false; one should claim that if deviation from the type of offering <b>disqualifies it once</b> the one who slaughtered it <b>had</b> that <b>intent, here too, once</b> the one who slaughtered it <b>had intent</b> to deviate from its owner, <b>he disqualified it.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty with the second distinction, the case where the owner died: <b>And according to Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Mari, who says</b> that disqualification by <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner applies</b> even <b>after</b> the owner’s <b>death,</b> there is no distinction in this regard between deviation from the type of offering and deviation with regard to the owner. <b>In any event, there are two</b> remaining distinctions based on which the comparison between a deviation from the type of offering and a deviation with regard to the owner <b>can be refuted.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited to sprinkle the blood for the sake of one other than the owner is derived from a verse. <b>The verse states: “And it shall be accepted for him to atone for him”</b> (Leviticus 1:4), teaching that the sacrificial rite that atones for the owner, namely, the sprinkling of the blood, must be performed specifically for him, <b>and not for another.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does this</b> verse <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? Isn’t <b>it necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the verse: <b>“And it shall be accepted for him to atone for him [<i>alav</i>],” Rabbi Shimon says:</b> This indicates that in a case where one consecrated an animal as an offering and it died or was lost, if it was initially incumbent <b>upon him [<i>alav</i>]</b> to bring an offering, i.e., if he had accepted upon himself a personal obligation to bring an offering, <b>he bears responsibility for it,</b> i.e., he is obligated to bring another offering in its stead. <b>But</b> if it was <b>not</b> incumbent <b>upon him [<i>alav</i>]</b> to bring an offering, i.e., if he consecrated a specific animal without accepting upon himself any personal obligation, <b>he does not bear responsibility for it</b> if it dies or is lost.
<b>And Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: What is the reasoning</b> behind this distinction? <b>Once</b> a person <b>said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring an offering, it is considered <b>as though</b> the offering is <b>loaded upon his shoulders.</b> He does not discharge his obligation until he brings some offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ashi says</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited to sprinkle the blood for the sake of one other than the owner is derived <b>from</b> the phrase <b>“And it shall be accepted for him,”</b> not from the term “for him,” on which the <i>baraita</i> is based.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>slaughter and</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood must be performed for the sake of the owner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>collection</b> of the blood must also be performed for the sake of the owner?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from slaughter and sprinkling</b> that collection must also be performed for the sake of the owner, this derivation can be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about slaughter and sprinkling?</b> They are unique <b>in that</b> each is <b>a rite for which one is liable</b> to be punished with death at the hand of Heaven if he performs it <b>outside</b> the Temple.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that the collection of the blood must also be performed for the sake of the owner <b>is derived from</b> the case of <b>a nazirite’s ram. As it is written: “And he shall offer the ram for a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of peace offerings</b> unto the Lord” (Numbers 6:17), indicating <b>that its offering should be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a peace offering. And if</b> the verse <b>is not</b> necessary for the <b>matter of deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering, as we derived that from there,</b> i.e., the verses cited earlier (4a), <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b> It is thereby derived that its sacrificial rites must be performed for the sake of its owner.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Abba said to Rava,</b> in objection to this derivation: <b>Say</b> that the term: <b>“Shall offer,” is a generalization</b> and: <b>“A sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>],” is a detail.</b> According to the principles of biblical hermeneutics, where there is <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization includes only that which is</b> specified <b>in the detail.</b> Accordingly, <b>slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>], yes,</b> must be performed for the sake of its owner; but <b>no other</b> rite must be performed for the sake of its owner in order for the offering to be fit.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it had been <b>written: Shall offer</b> the ram <b>for peace offerings as a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>],</b> it would be <b>as you say.</b> The clause: Shall offer the ram for peace offerings, would be considered a generalization, and: Sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>], would be a detail. <b>Now that it is written: “Shall offer</b> the ram <b>for a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of peace offerings,”</b> the term “shall offer” is <b>an incomplete generalization,</b> as the term “for a sacrifice” interrupts between “shall offer” and “peace offerings.” <b>And one cannot derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from <b>any incomplete generalization by</b> employing the principle of <b>a generalization and a detail.</b>
<b>Ravina says</b> there is a different answer: <b>Actually, one can derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from verses with incomplete generalizations using the principle of a generalization and a detail. <b>And</b> the reason this <i>halakha</i> applies to other rites besides slaughter is that by adding the term <b>“unto the Lord,”</b> it <b>then makes a generalization.</b>
Before Ravina concluded his interpretation, <b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: But the former generalization is dissimilar to the latter generalization. The former generalization includes</b> only the essential sacrificial <b>actions and nothing more,</b> whereas <b>the latter generalization</b> includes <b>any</b> sacrificial duty <b>unto the Lord, and even pouring</b> the <b>remains</b> of the blood on the base of the altar <b>and burning</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> of the offering on the altar. Ravina responded: <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught generalizations and details in cases like this.</b>
Ravina concludes his explanation: Since the term: “Unto the Lord,” is another generalization, the verse is formulated as <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization,</b> and <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as the</b> mentioned <b>detail,</b> slaughter, is <b>defined</b> as an essential <b>rite and we require</b> that it be performed <b>for the sake of</b> the owner, <b>so too, we require</b> that <b>every</b> essential <b>rite</b> be performed <b>for the sake of</b> the owner.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the verse is referring only to actions similar to the detail, not all of the essential rites are necessarily included. Perhaps it should be derived that <b>just as the</b> mentioned <b>detail,</b> slaughter, is <b>defined</b> as an essential <b>rite, and one is liable</b> to be punished with death at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> performing <b>it outside</b> the Temple, <b>so too, any</b> essential <b>rite</b> for which <b>one is liable</b> to be punished with death at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> performing <b>it outside</b> the Temple is included in the verse. Accordingly, <b>slaughter and sprinkling</b> the blood <b>are</b> included, but <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>and conveying</b> it are <b>not.</b>
<b>Alternatively,</b> it could be derived that <b>just as the</b> item mentioned in the <b>detail</b> is clearly <b>defined</b> as <b>an action that requires</b> performance in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and is</b> performed <b>in the</b> sacrifice of <b>inner sin offerings, so too, any</b> rite <b>that requires</b> performance in the <b>north and is</b> performed <b>in the</b> sacrifice of <b>inner sin offerings</b> is included in the <i>halakha</i>. Accordingly, <b>slaughter and collection are</b> included; <b>sprinkling</b> the blood is <b>not.</b>
The Gemara answers: Both possibilities are equally valid; <b>this</b> derivation <b>can be said and that</b> derivation <b>can be said.</b> Either collection or sprinkling might be included in the <i>halakha</i>. Consequently, <b>they are equal, and</b> therefore <b>both are included.</b> Or according to <b>another version</b> of the Gemara’s answer, they are equal, <b>and</b> therefore <b>each one,</b> i.e., both collection and sprinkling, <b>shall stand in</b> its <b>status.</b>
The Gemara provides an alternative answer: <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that <b>sprinkling is derived from</b> the verse <b>that Rav Ashi</b> cited: “And it shall be accepted for him to atone for him.” Therefore, when the verse states: “And he shall offer the ram for a sacrifice of peace offerings unto the Lord,” indicating the inclusion of rites similar to slaughter, it is apparently referring not to sprinkling but to collection.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a nazirite’s ram</b> must be sacrificed for the sake of its owner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> applies with regard to <b>other peace offerings</b> as well?
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from a nazirite’s ram</b> that all peace offerings must be sacrificed for the sake of their owners, this derivation can be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a nazirite’s ram?</b> It is unique <b>in that there is other blood,</b> i.e., there are other offerings, a sin offering and a burnt offering, that must be brought by a nazirite together <b>with</b> his ram.
The Gemara answers: <b>If that is so,</b> if this <i>halakha</i> is unique to a nazirite’s ram, <b>let</b> the verse <b>write: His peace offerings [<i>shelamav</i>]. What</b> is indicated by writing <b>“peace offerings [<i>shelamim</i>]”?</b> It is written <b>to include all</b> types of <b>peace offerings.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a peace offering</b> must be sacrificed for its own sake and for the sake of its owner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> applies with regard to <b>all other offerings?</b>
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive from a peace offering</b> that all offerings must be sacrificed with these intentions, this derivation can be refuted: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a peace offering?</b> It is unique <b>in that it requires placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>and</b> it is accompanied by <b>libations, and</b> it requires the <b>waving of</b> the <b>breast and</b> the right <b>hind leg</b> by the priest and owner together. No other offering possesses all three of these requirements.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, the verse states: “This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the consecration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings”</b> (Leviticus 7:37). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> all types of offerings <b>with peace offerings,</b> indicating that <b>just as we require</b> the sacrifice of <b>a peace offering</b> to be performed <b>for its sake, both</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner, so too, we require</b> the sacrifice of <b>every</b> type of offering to be performed <b>for its sake, both</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b>
§ Having established the source for the requirement to sacrifice offerings with the rightful owner and the specific type of offering in mind, the Gemara inquires: Why not <b>say</b> that in a case <b>where</b> one <b>slaughtered them not for their sake, they are disqualified?</b> Why, according to the mishna, do they remain fit?
The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do; according to what you have vowed [<i>nadarta</i>]</b> freely [<i>nedava</i>] to the Lord your God, that which you have promised with your mouth” (Deuteronomy 23:24). The Gemara interprets the words <i>nadarta</i> and <i>nedava</i> exegetically: How can the offering mentioned in <b>this</b> verse be <b>a gift</b> offering <b>[<i>nedava</i>]? It is</b> already referred to as <b>a vow</b> offering <b>[<i>neder</i>]. Rather,</b> the verse indicates that <b>if you did what you had vowed</b> to do, i.e., sacrificed your vow offering properly, <b>it shall be</b> a satisfactory <b>vow</b> offering; <b>but if</b> you did <b>not</b> sacrifice it properly, <b>it shall be</b> rendered a voluntary <b>gift</b> offering. Although it does not satisfy the obligation of your vow, it remains a valid offering.
<b>And it was necessary</b> for the Torah to include the verse: <b>“That which has gone out of your lips,” and it was necessary</b> to include the verse: <b>“This is the law.” As, had the Merciful One written</b> in the Torah only the verse: <b>“That which has gone out</b> of your lips,” <b>I would say</b>

Daf 5a

that we <b>do not know what</b> requirement does not disqualify the offering if not fulfilled. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> the verse: <b>This is the law,</b> juxtaposing all offerings with a peace offering, which must be performed for its own sake. <b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> only the verse: <b>This is the law, I would say</b> that offerings sacrificed not for their sake <b>should be disqualified.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> the verse: <b>That which is gone out of your lips,</b> teaching that they are accepted, though they do not satisfy their owners’ obligations.
§ <b>Reish Lakish raised a difficulty while lying on his stomach in the study hall: If</b> offerings that were sacrificed for the sake of the wrong type of offering or someone other than the owner <b>are fit, let them propitiate</b> God, i.e., let them satisfy the obligation of their owners; <b>and if they do not propitiate</b> God, <b>why are they brought</b> as offerings at all?
<b>Rabbi Elazar said to him: We have found</b> a precedent for this <b>in</b> the case of offerings <b>brought after</b> the <b>death</b> of their owners, <b>as they are fit, but they do not propitiate</b> God, as they do not have owners requiring atonement. This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kinnim</i> 2:5): With regard to <b>a woman</b> after childbirth <b>who brought her sin offering and</b> then <b>died,</b> the <b>heirs shall bring her burnt offering.</b> If she brought <b>her burnt offering and</b> then <b>died,</b> the <b>heirs shall not bring her sin offering.</b> Evidently, a burnt offering is sacrificed even if it does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.
Reish Lakish <b>said to him: I concede to you with regard to a burnt offering</b> that it is sacrificed even if it does not satisfy its owner’s obligation, <b>since it is brought</b> even <b>after</b> its owner’s <b>death</b> in the case of the woman who died after bringing her sin offering. But <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>a guilt offering, which</b> is brought for atonement and therefore <b>not brought after</b> its owner’s <b>death,</b> is brought even in a case where it was slaughtered not for its sake and therefore will not satisfy its owner’s obligation?
Rabbi Elazar <b>said to him: Your</b> side of the <b>dispute</b> is written in the mishna <b>next to</b> the opinion that you find difficult. Following the opinion in the mishna (2a) that only a sin offering and a Paschal offering are disqualified if they are slaughtered for the sake of the wrong type of offering, the mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The guilt offering too</b> is unfit when sacrificed not for its sake.
Reish Lakish <b>said</b> in reference to Rabbi Elazar: <b>Is he</b> the one <b>of whom people say</b> that <b>he is a great man? I am referring to the entire mishna,</b> specifically to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, which is the accepted <i>halakha</i>. <b>And you say to me</b> that the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> resolves my difficulty?
<b>Rather, Reish Lakish said: I will introduce a solution to my own</b> difficulty. He then recited the exegesis stated above: The verse states: <b>“That which has gone out of your lips</b> you shall observe and do, <b>etc.”</b> How can <b>this</b> be referring to <b>a gift</b> offering? <b>It is</b> already referred to as <b>a vow</b> offering; <b>and so on, as</b> stated <b>above.</b> In other words, it is derived from a verse that although the offering does not satisfy the obligation of its owner, it is fit to be sacrificed as a gift offering.
<b>Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Abba were sitting, and Abaye was sitting with them. And they were sitting and saying:</b> The case of <b>a guilt offering was difficult for Reish Lakish, as</b> a guilt offering is <b>not brought after</b> the owner’s <b>death, and he adduced the derivation</b> from the verse: <b>“That which has gone out of your lips,”</b> as a solution <b>to it.</b> This resolution is difficult: Why not <b>say</b> that only an offering <b>that is brought for a vow or a gift is brought</b> even in a case where it <b>does not propitiate,</b> since the verse mentions a vow and a gift; but <b>a guilt offering,</b> which is not brought voluntarily, <b>should not be brought at all</b> if it was slaughtered for the sake of the wrong type of offering. How does the verse resolve Reish Lakish’s difficulty?
<b>Abaye said to them:</b> Although <b>Reish Lakish</b> cited that verse, he actually <b>introduced</b> the solution to his difficulty <b>from here: “And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33). It is derived from the word <b>“it”</b> in this verse that if a sin offering is slaughtered <b>for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if it is slaughtered <b>not for its sake,</b> it is <b>unfit. Consequently, other offerings</b> slaughtered <b>not for their sake,</b> including a guilt offering, <b>are fit.</b> And since one <b>might</b> have thought that once they are fit, they also <b>propitiate</b> God, <b>the verse states: “That which has gone out of your lips,”</b> from which it is derived that such an offering does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.
Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Abba asked him: <b>But</b> since the phrase in the verse “that which has gone out of your lips” is referring to offerings <b>brought for a vow or a gift,</b> why not <b>say</b> that only these offerings <b>do not propitiate</b> God even though <b>one must bring</b> them if slaughtered for the sake of the wrong offering, but <b>a guilt offering</b> slaughtered for the sake of the wrong offering <b>propitiates</b> God <b>as well?</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> in response: <b>You cannot say that a guilt offering</b> that was slaughtered for the sake of the wrong offering <b>propitiates</b> God, due to <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from a burnt offering: Just as a burnt offering, which does not atone</b> for a sin as it is brought as a vow or gift offering, still <b>does not propitiate</b> God if it was slaughtered for the sake of the wrong offering, so too, with regard to <b>a guilt offering, which atones</b> for a sin and is therefore treated more stringently, <b>is it not logical that it does not propitiate</b> God?
The Gemara challenges the inference: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is unique <b>in that it is</b> totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar. By contrast, the meat of a guilt offering is eaten by priests. Since in some ways a burnt offering is treated more stringently than a guilt offering, no <i>a fortiori</i> inference can be derived from one to the other.
The Gemara answers: <b>A peace offering can prove</b> that this aspect is not relevant, since it is not totally consumed on the altar, and still if slaughtered for the sake of the wrong offering it does not satisfy its owner’s obligation. The inference can therefore be drawn from a peace offering rather than a burnt offering.
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a peace offering?</b> It is unique <b>in that it requires libations, and the waving of</b> the <b>breast and</b> the right <b>hind leg.</b>
The Gemara answers: If so, <b>a burnt offering can prove</b> the point, since these stringencies do not apply to it. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. At this stage the <i>halakha</i> is derived from a combination of the two sources: <b>The aspect of this</b> case, a burnt offering, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case, the peace offering. <b>And the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are offerings and</b> if one <b>slaughtered them not for their sake, they are fit but they do not propitiate. So too, I shall include a guilt offering</b> in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it is an offering, and</b> therefore if one <b>slaughtered it not for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit but it does not propitiate.</b>
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about their common element,</b> i.e., the common element of a burnt offering and a peace offering? These offerings are unique <b>in that they are</b> brought <b>by</b> the <b>public.</b> There are communal burnt offerings and peace offerings, but there are no communal guilt offerings.
The Gemara responds: <b>A thanks offering can prove</b> the point, since there are no communal thanks offerings, and still a thanks offering slaughtered not for its sake does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.

Daf 5b

The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a thanks offering?</b> It is unique <b>in that it requires</b> a meal offering of forty loaves of <b>bread.</b>
The Gemara answers: If so, <b>a burnt offering and a peace offering can prove</b> the point, as loaves are not brought with them. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. The <i>halakha</i> is derived from a combination of the two sources: <b>The aspect of this</b> case, a burnt offering and a peace offering, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case, a thanks offering, <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are offerings, and</b> if one <b>slaughtered them not for their sake,</b> they are <b>fit but do not propitiate</b> God. <b>So too, I shall include a guilt offering</b> in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it is an offering, and</b> therefore if one <b>slaughtered it not for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit but does not propitiate</b> God.
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about the common element of</b> a thanks offering, a burnt offering, and a peace offering? It is unique in <b>that</b> these offerings <b>are brought</b> either <b>as a vow</b> offering <b>or as a gift</b> offering, whereas a guilt offering is brought only to fulfill an obligation.
<b>Rather, Rava says: The verse: “This is the law</b> of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the consecration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:37), <b>juxtaposes</b> a guilt offering <b>with a peace offering,</b> indicating that <b>just as peace offerings are offerings and</b> if one <b>slaughtered them not for their sake, they are fit but do not propitiate, so too, I shall include a guilt offering, as it is an offering,</b> and therefore if it is slaughtered not for its sake, although it is fit, it does not satisfy the obligation of its owner.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see,</b> i.e., why do you think it is reasonable, <b>that you compared</b> a guilt offering <b>to a peace offering?</b> Why not <b>compare</b> it <b>to a sin offering,</b> which is disqualified in such a case?
The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One excluded</b> all other offerings from the <i>halakha</i> concerning a sin offering in this matter, as derived from the verse: “And slaughter <b>it</b> for a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:33).
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the <i>amora’im</i> who participated in the two following discussions: <b><i>Heh</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>shin</i>; <i>beit</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>reish</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Huna and Rav Naḥman were sitting, and Rav Sheshet was sitting with them. And they were sitting and saying: Reish Lakish raised</b> his <b>difficulty</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, since it is not brought after</b> its owner’s <b>death. Let Rabbi Elazar say to him</b> that <b>a guilt offering is also</b> essentially <b>brought after</b> its owner’s <b>death,</b> since it is sold once it develops a blemish, and the proceeds are used to buy a burnt offering.
<b>Rav Sheshet said to them:</b> This claim can be refuted: <b>What</b> element <b>of a guilt offering is sacrificed</b> after its owner’s death? Only <b>its remainder,</b> i.e., the money from its sale that is used to purchase an animal to be sacrificed. And if so, it is no different from <b>a sin offering, the remainder of which is also sacrificed,</b> and a sin offering itself is entirely disqualified if slaughtered not for its sake.
Rav Huna and Rav Naḥman explained: <b>A sin offering</b> that was slaughtered not for its sake is disqualified <b>even though its remainder is sacrificed,</b> because <b>the Merciful One</b> specifically <b>excludes</b> a sin offering from being a fit offering if sacrificed not for its own sake, as derived from the verse: “And he shall lay his hand upon the head of the goat, and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before the Lord; <b>it</b> is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). The redundant phrase “it is a sin offering” teaches that a sin offering is disqualified if sacrificed not for its own sake.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>also written with regard to a guilt offering:</b> “And the priest shall make them smoke upon the altar for an offering made by fire unto the Lord; <b>it</b> is a guilt offering” (Leviticus 7:5)? Why is a guilt offering not disqualified when it is slaughtered not for its sake?
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is written</b> not with regard to the main sacrificial rites, but with regard to the stage <b>after the burning of the</b> offering’s <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>But with regard to a guilt offering,</b> the term <b>“It</b> is a guilt offering” <b>is stated only after the burning of the sacrificial portions. And</b> since the guilt offering <b>itself</b> is <b>fit</b> even <b>if the sacrificial portions were not burned</b> at all, it is certainly fit if they were burned not for the sake of a guilt offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“It</b> is a guilt offering” to be stated at all? The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>for that which Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says. As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a guilt offering</b> whose owner died or whose transgression was otherwise atoned for, and <b>that was</b> therefore <b>consigned</b> by the court <b>to grazing</b> until it develops a blemish so that it can be sold and the proceeds used to purchase a burnt offering, if, before it developed a blemish, someone <b>slaughtered it without specification</b> of its purpose, it is <b>fit</b> as a burnt offering.
The Gemara infers: If <b>it was consigned</b> to grazing, <b>yes,</b> it is fit as a burnt offering if slaughtered. By inference, if <b>it was not consigned</b> to grazing, it is <b>not</b> fit. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The verse states: “It</b> is a guilt offering,” indicating that <b>it shall</b> remain <b>as it is,</b> i.e., as a guilt offering, unless it is consigned by the court to fulfill another purpose.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman and Rav Sheshet were sitting, and Rav Adda bar Mattana was sitting with them. And they were sitting and saying:</b> In response to <b>that which Rabbi Elazar said</b> to Reish Lakish: <b>We have found</b> a precedent for this situation <b>in</b> the case of offerings that <b>are brought after</b> their owners’ <b>death, as they are fit but they do not propitiate</b> God, <b>let Reish Lakish say to him: These</b> offerings <b>should also be brought and propitiate</b> God with regard to the heirs. Why did Reish Lakish not challenge Rabbi Elazar’s assumption?
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to them:</b> How can the offering of <b>a woman after childbirth</b> propitiate God after her death? <b>If she gave birth, did her children give birth?</b>
<b>Rav Asi objects to this</b> reasoning: <b>And who shall say to us that if</b> a woman <b>has several</b> violations of <b>positive mitzvot</b> for which to atone, <b>she does not atone</b> by means of the burnt offering she brings after childbirth for her purification? Clearly, such offerings can atone for transgressions other than those for which they are brought. <b>And since, when she has several</b> violations of <b>positive mitzvot she atones</b> by means of the offering, <b>so too,</b> if she dies, <b>her heirs atone</b> by this offering for their own violations of positive mitzvot.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> the offering is <b>acquired by</b> the heirs, and this is why it atones for their transgressions? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that if one <b>left his two sons a meal offering and</b> then <b>died,</b> the offering must be <b>sacrificed, and it does not have</b> the status of a meal offering brought in <b>partnership? And if it enters your mind</b> that the offering is <b>acquired by</b> the heirs, it should be considered a meal offering brought in partnership, which is unfit, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: “And when <b>one</b> brings a meal offering unto the Lord” (Leviticus 2:1). The word “one” teaches that two people cannot bring a meal offering together. Clearly, the heirs do not inherit the offering, and if so, it should not atone for their transgressions.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> the offering <b>not acquired by them? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> himself <b>say</b> that if one <b>left his two sons an animal</b> offering <b>and</b> then <b>died,</b> the offering must be <b>sacrificed, and they cannot effect substitution</b> of another animal <b>for it?</b> Even if they declare another animal to be a substitute for it, that animal is not consecrated. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the offering is <b>acquired by them, this is</b> the reason <b>that they cannot effect substitution</b> of another animal <b>for it:</b> It is <b>because they are like partners,</b>

Daf 6a

<b>and partners cannot effect substitution</b> of other animals for their offering. <b>But if you say</b> that it is <b>not acquired by them,</b> and the animal is the property solely of the deceased father, <b>let them also effect substitution</b> on his behalf, as heirs are able to affect substitution for their deceased parents’ offerings.
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as</b> although <b>the verse states: “If he shall at all change [<i>hamer yamir</i>]</b> animal for animal” (Leviticus 27:10), the superfluous word <i>hamer</i> serving <b>to include the heir</b> as one who is able to effect substitution, nevertheless the subject’s singular form teaches that only <b>one</b> heir <b>can effect substitution, but two</b> heirs <b>cannot effect substitution.</b>
<b>Rav Ya’akov of Nehar Pekod objects to this</b> derivation: <b>If that is so,</b> one should say the same <b>with regard to</b> the redemption of the second <b>tithe, as it is written: “And if</b> a man <b>will redeem [<i>gaol yigal</i>]</b> any of his tithe, he shall add to it the fifth part thereof” (Leviticus 27:31), with the superfluous word <i>gaol</i> serving <b>to include the heir</b> as one who must add the one-fifth. <b>So too,</b> it should be derived from the verb’s singular form that if <b>one</b> heir <b>redeems</b> the tithe, he must add one-fifth of its value, <b>but</b> if <b>two</b> heirs <b>redeem</b> it, <b>they do not</b> need to add one-fifth.
