In fact, the <i>halakha</i> is that partners must also add one-fifth.
The Gemara answers: Redemption of the <b>tithe is different, as</b> the <b>father had</b> the ability to redeem the tithe <b>even in partnership</b> with another when alive. Therefore, the heirs can do so as well. By contrast, substitution of an offering cannot be effected by partners.
<b>Rav Asi said to Rav Ashi: But from</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>itself,</b> that two heirs cannot effect substitution of an offering, it can be proven that they acquire the offering of the deceased. <b>Granted, if you say</b> it is <b>acquired by them, this is</b> the reason <b>that one</b> heir, <b>in any event, can effect substitution</b> of another animal for the offering. <b>But if you say</b> it is <b>not acquired by them, how can</b> even one heir <b>effect substitution?</b>
<b>But doesn’t Rabbi Abbahu say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If <b>one consecrates</b> his own animal to atone for someone else and he then redeems it, he <b>adds one-fifth</b> of its value, as he would for any other offering he owned, but if the one for whom it atones redeems it, he need not add one-fifth, since he is not the owner. Nevertheless, only the <b>one for whom</b> the offering <b>atones can render</b> another animal <b>a substitute</b> for it, as in this respect only he is considered its owner. Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement concludes: <b>And</b> if <b>one separates <i>teruma</i> from his</b> own produce <b>to</b> exempt the produce <b>of another</b> from the obligation to have teruma separated from it, <b>the benefit of discretion is his.</b> Only the one who separated the <i>teruma</i> is entitled to determine which priest receives it. Since an heir is able to effect substitution, apparently the offering atones for his transgression. This supports the claim that the heir acquires the offering.
Rav Ashi responds: The offering <b>does not atone</b> for the transgressions of the heirs <b>by</b> its <b>essence,</b> as it was not consecrated for their atonement, and they do not acquire it. Therefore, two heirs of a meal offering can bring it, as explained above. Yet, it <b>does atone</b> for them <b>incidentally [<i>mikkufeya</i>].</b> Therefore, an heir can effect substitution of another animal for it.
§ With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that offerings slaughtered not for their sake are fit to be sacrificed but do not satisfy the obligations of their owners, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: After these offerings are sacrificed, <b>did they atone for</b> the sins for <b>which they came, or did they not atone</b> for them?
<b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said: It stands to reason that they did not atone, as, if it enters your mind</b> that <b>they did atone, for what</b> purpose <b>is</b> the <b>second</b> offering <b>brought?</b> Why is the owner required to bring another offering if the first atoned for his sin?
The Gemara challenges this reasoning: <b>Rather, what</b> is the alternative? That <b>they did not atone?</b> If so, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>is</b> the first offering <b>sacrificed?</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: This</b> is what is <b>difficult for Rav Sheisha,</b> i.e., Rav Sheshet, <b>son of Rav Idi: Granted, if you say</b> that such an offering <b>did not atone,</b> it <b>is brought</b> even when slaughtered <b>not for its sake on the strength of</b> its prior consecration <b>for its sake. And</b> in that case, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>is</b> the <b>second</b> offering <b>brought?</b> It is brought <b>to atone</b> for the sin. <b>But if you say</b> that offerings that were slaughtered not for their sake <b>atoned</b> for the sin, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>is</b> the <b>second</b> offering <b>brought?</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When one brings a burnt offering, which atones for violations of positive mitzvot, <b>does it atone</b> even <b>for</b> a violation of <b>a positive mitzva that</b> one committed <b>after designating</b> the animal as an offering, <b>or does it not atone</b> for such a violation?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Do we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> in this case is <b>just as it is with regard to a sin offering,</b> in that <b>just as a sin offering does</b> atone for a sin <b>that</b> one committed <b>before designation</b> of the animal but does <b>not</b> atone for a sin <b>that</b> one committed <b>after designation, here too,</b> a burnt offering <b>does</b> atone for violations <b>that</b> one committed <b>before designation</b> but does <b>not</b> atone for those committed <b>after designation?</b>
<b>Or, perhaps</b> a burnt offering is <b>not similar to a sin offering, as</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering one must bring one sin offering for each and every sin</b> he commits. <b>But here, since</b> a burnt offering <b>atones</b> even for one who <b>has</b> committed <b>several</b> violations of <b>positive mitzvot,</b> one may claim that <b>it also atones</b> even <b>for</b> the violation of <b>a positive mitzva that</b> one committed <b>after designation</b> of the animal.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And he shall place</b> his hand on the head of the burnt offering, <b>and it shall be accepted</b> for him to atone for him” (Leviticus 1:4). <b>And does placing hands atone</b> for one’s sins? <b>But isn’t atonement</b> achieved <b>only by</b> the sprinkling of <b>the blood, as it is stated: “For it is the blood that makes atonement by reason of the life”</b> (Leviticus 17:11)? <b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “And he shall place…and it shall be accepted</b> for him <b>to atone”?</b> This teaches <b>that if one deemed</b> the ritual of <b>placing hands</b> to be <b>a non-essential mitzva</b> and consequently failed to perform it, <b>the verse ascribes to him</b> blame <b>as though</b> the offering <b>did not atone</b> for his sins; <b>and</b> nevertheless, the offering <b>atoned</b> for his sins.
<b>What,</b> does the final clause of the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> mean <b>that</b> the offer-ing <b>atoned</b> for the violation of any <b>positive mitzva that</b> the owner committed <b>before designation</b> of the animal, but <b>it did not atone for</b> violation of <b>the positive mitzva of placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>as that constitutes</b> a violation of <b>a positive mitzva after designation</b> of the animal? Apparently, a burnt offering does not atone for the violations committed after the animal’s designation.
<b>Rava said</b> in response: <b>You say</b> that <b>the positive mitzva of placing hands</b> is proof? <b>There it is different, since as long as he does not slaughter</b> the offering, <b>he remains</b> obligated <b>to stand and place</b> his <b>hands</b> on its head. He has not yet violated the mitzva. <b>When does</b> the violation of this <b>positive mitzva occur?</b> It occurs <b>after</b> the <b>slaughter,</b> at which point fulfillment of the mitzva is no longer possible. And with regard to a violation committed <b>after</b> the <b>slaughter, we do not raise the dilemma;</b> clearly a burnt offering does not atone for such a violation.
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said to Rava: Say</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that the offering <b>atoned</b> for the transgression of <b>the person,</b>

Daf 6b

but <b>it did not atone</b> for him <b>before Heaven,</b> i.e., it is not accepted by God as a perfect offering.
<b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to the purification process of a leper (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:10): The verse states: <b>“And the rest of the oil that is in</b> the priest’s <b>hand</b> he shall put upon the head of the one that is to be purified, <b>to make atonement for him before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 14:18). This teaches that <b>if</b> the priest <b>placed</b> the oil on the leper’s head, <b>it atoned</b> for him, and he is purified, <b>but if he did not place</b> the oil on his head, <b>it did not atone</b> for him; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says:</b> Placement of the oil on the leper’s head <b>is a non-essential mitzva.</b> Therefore, <b>whether</b> the oil <b>was placed</b> on his head or <b>whether it was not placed</b> on his head, <b>it atoned</b> for him, <b>but</b> the verse <b>ascribes</b> the leper blame <b>as though it did not atone</b> for him.
The Gemara comments: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>As though it did not atone</b> for him? <b>If we say that it is necessary</b> for the leper <b>to bring another offering</b> of oil, <b>didn’t you say</b> that <b>whether</b> the oil <b>was placed</b> on his head or <b>whether it was not placed</b> on his head, <b>it atoned</b> for him? <b>Rather,</b> the meaning of the statement is as follows: <b>It atoned</b> for <b>the person,</b> but <b>did not atone</b> for him <b>before Heaven. Here too,</b> with regard to one who sacrificed an offering without placing hands on its head, the <i>baraita</i> apparently means that the offering <b>atoned</b> for the owner’s transgression, even if it did not atone for him before Heaven.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>There too,</b> with regard to the purification process of a leper, one can explain that the oil atoned for one matter and did not atone for another: It <b>atoned;</b> in other words, the <b>placement</b> of oil on the leper’s right <b>thumb and big toe,</b> which was performed, effected its atonement. But it <b>did not atone,</b> i.e., there still needs to be an atonement effected by <b>placement</b> of oil on <b>the</b> leper’s <b>head,</b> and another <i>log</i> of oil must be brought for the performance of that act.
The Gemara returns to the matter of atonement for transgressions committed after the offering’s designation. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to the communal peace offering of two <b>lambs</b> that accompanies the two loaves on <b><i>Shavuot</i>, for what</b> sin <b>are they brought?</b>
The Gemara interrupts the citation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The</b> two <b>lambs</b> sacrificed on <b><i>Shavuot</i></b> are not brought for a sin; <b>they are peace offerings</b> brought with the annual public offering of two loaves of new wheat. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be emended as follows: <b>For what</b> sin <b>are the goats</b> sacrificed on <b><i>Shavuot</i></b> as a sin offering <b>brought?</b>
Rabbi Shimon answers: They are brought <b>for</b> the <b>defiling of</b> the <b>Temple,</b> by entering it while ritually impure, <b>or</b> for defiling <b>its sacrificial foods,</b> by partaking of them while ritually impure.
Rabbi Shimon continues: Once <b>the blood of</b> the <b>first</b> goat <b>is sprinkled</b> on the altar, thereby atoning for this defilement, <b>for what</b> sin <b>is</b> the <b>second one sacrificed?</b> It is sacrificed <b>for</b> any incident involving <b>impurity that</b> may have <b>occurred between</b> the sacrifice of <b>that</b> first goat <b>and</b> the sacrifice of <b>this</b> second goat. <b>Based on this, say</b> that <b>the Jewish people should have</b> had to <b>sacrifice their offerings at all times and at every moment,</b> as perhaps they sinned in the interim; <b>but the verse spared</b> them of this obligation.
The Gemara infers: <b>And here,</b> where an incident involving impurity occurred between the sacrifice of the two goats, is a case <b>where</b> the <b>positive mitzva</b> of distancing ritually impure people from the Temple was violated <b>after</b> the <b>designation</b> of the offering, as both goats were designated in advance. <b>And</b> nevertheless, the second goat <b>atones</b> for the violation. Evidently, an offering can atone for transgressions committed after its designation.
The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>If</b> both goats were <b>designated simultaneously,</b> this would <b>indeed</b> be evidence to that effect. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> they were <b>designated sequentially,</b> and an incident involving impurity may have occurred between their respective designations.
The Gemara challenges this assertion: <b>But shall we stand and say about the verse</b> mandating these two sin offerings <b>that when it is written, it is written</b> specifically with regard to a case <b>where</b> they are designated <b>sequentially?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> the inference can be rejected for a different reason: <b>Do you say</b> that evidence can be adduced from <b>communal offerings? Communal offerings are different, as</b> the <b>court makes a non-verbal stipulation about them, in accordance with</b> what <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Shmuel says. As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>communal offerings,</b> the slaughtering <b>knife,</b> i.e., the act of slaughter, <b>designates them for what they are.</b> The court stipulates that the second goat be consecrated as it is sacrificed, and it therefore atones for incidents of impurity that occur beforehand. Individual offerings, by contrast, are all designated in advance.
<b>Rav Yosef, son of Rav Shmuel, said to Rav Pappa: But does Rabbi Shimon accept</b> the opinion that <b>the court can make a non-verbal stipulation about</b> communal offerings? <b>Doesn’t Rav Idi bar Avin say</b> that <b>Rav Amram says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to animals designated as <b>daily offerings</b> but <b>which</b> in the end <b>were not necessary for</b> use by <b>the public,</b>

Daf 7a

<b>according to the statement of Rabbi Shimon, they may not be redeemed</b> as long as they are <b>unblemished,</b> since they retain the status of offerings. But <b>according to the statement of the Rabbis, they may be redeemed</b> even when they are <b>unblemished,</b> as the court initially stipulates that if they are not needed they will not assume the status of an offering. Apparently Rabbi Shimon does not accept the notion that the court can stipulate that there be a delay in the consecration of communal offerings, and the <i>baraita</i> can be adduced as evidence that offerings atone for transgressions committed after their designation as offerings.
<b>And furthermore,</b> continued Rav Yosef, son of Rav Shmuel, one can otherwise infer from the goats sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i> that an offering can atone for transgressions committed after designation; as <b>Rabbi Yirmeya asked Rabbi Zeira:</b> If the <b>goats</b> sacrificed on <b><i>Shavuot</i></b> were slaughtered simultaneously and <b>their blood was collected in two cups, and the blood of</b> the <b>first</b> goat <b>was sprinkled, for what</b> sin <b>is</b> the <b>second</b> goat <b>brought?</b> There was no time in the interim for other transgressions to occur. Rabbi Zeira answered: It atones <b>for</b> any incident involving <b>impurity that occurred between the sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>of that</b> first goat <b>and</b> the sprinkling of the blood of <b>this</b> second goat.
One can infer: Rabbi Yirmeya <b>raised the dilemma only</b> about whether or not an offering atones for the violation of <b>a positive mitzva</b> committed <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter</b> and before the sprinkling of the blood. <b>But</b> with regard to the violation of <b>a positive mitzva that</b> one committed <b>after</b> the <b>designation</b> of the offering, before its slaughter, <b>he did not raise the dilemma.</b> Apparently, it was obvious to him that the offering atones for such a violation.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Yirmeya’s dilemma was also with regard to the violations committed after designation. He phrased his question to apply to violations committed after slaughter because <b>he was saying:</b> Even <b>if you say</b> that an offering atones for violations committed after designation, does it atone for those violations committed after slaughter? It may be that neither issue was clear to him.
§ <b>It was stated</b> with regard to <b>a thanks offering that</b> one <b>slaughtered for the sake of another’s thanks offering: Rabba says</b> that it is <b>fit</b> and satisfies its owner’s obligation, and <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> it is <b>unfit</b> in this regard.
<b>Rabba says</b> it is <b>fit</b> because the <b>thanks offering was slaughtered for the sake of a thanks offering. Rav Ḥisda says</b> it is <b>unfit</b> because <b>it must be slaughtered for the sake of his own peace offering.</b>
<b>Rabba said: From where do I say</b> that it is fit? It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And the meat of the sacrifice of his thanksgiving peace offering</b>…<b>on the day that he presents his offering</b> it shall be eaten” (Leviticus 7:15–16). <b>Abba Ḥanin said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> The verse <b>comes to teach</b> that <b>a thanks offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a peace offering</b> is <b>fit,</b> whereas <b>a peace offering that was slaughtered for the sake of a thanks offering</b> is <b>unfit. And what</b> is the <b>difference between this</b> offering <b>and that</b> offering? <b>A thanks offering is called a peace offering</b> in the verse, <b>but a peace offering is not called a thanks offering.</b>
Rabba explains: The <i>baraita</i> indicates that <b>a peace offering</b> that was slaughtered <b>for the sake of a thanks offering</b> is <b>unfit, but a thanks offering</b> that was slaughtered <b>for the sake of</b> some other <b>thanks offering</b> is <b>fit. What, is it not</b> referring to the thanks offering <b>of another,</b> teaching that it satisfies its owner’s obligation?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is referring to another thanks offering <b>of his own,</b> which he designated to give thanks for another incident of deliverance.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if one slaughtered his thanks offering for the sake of <b>another’s</b> thanks offering, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it <b>unfit,</b> i.e., it does it not satisfy the owner’s obligation? If so, <b>rather than teaching</b> that <b>a peace offering</b> slaughtered <b>for the sake of a thanks offering</b> is <b>unfit, let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> that <b>a thanks offering</b> that was slaughtered <b>for the sake of</b> another’s <b>thanks offering</b> is unfit, <b>and</b> one could infer that <b>all the more so a peace offering</b> slaughtered <b>for the sake of a thanks offering</b> is unfit.
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to specify a case where <b>a peace offering</b> was slaughtered <b>for the sake of his own thanks offering.</b> Otherwise, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since a thanks offering is called a peace offering, a peace offering is called a thanks offering as well, and</b> therefore <b>when one slaughters</b> a peace offering <b>for the sake of a thanks offering it should be fit.</b> Therefore the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
§ <b>Rava says: A sin offering that one slaughtered for the sake of</b> another <b>sin offering</b> he was obligated to bring is <b>fit;</b> but if one slaughtered it <b>for the sake of a burnt offering</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this distinction? <b>The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33), <b>and</b> therefore, as long as the <b>sin offering was slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering,</b> even another sin offering, it is fit. But if it was slaughtered <b>for the sake of a burnt offering</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
<b>And Rava says: A sin offering that one slaughtered for</b> a person other than its owner, but <b>who</b> nevertheless was <b>obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering,</b> is <b>unfit.</b> But if one slaughtered it <b>for</b> one <b>who</b> was <b>obligated</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering,</b> it is <b>fit.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this distinction? The Torah states: <b>“And he shall be forgiven”</b> (Leviticus 4:26), indicating that it must be specifically <b>he,</b> the owner, <b>who</b> shall be forgiven, <b>and not another</b> person. <b>The other</b> person to whom this is referring, with regard to whom the offering is disqualified, is presumably <b>similar to</b> the owner <b>in</b> that <b>he is</b> also <b>obligated</b> to achieve <b>atonement similar to</b> the owner’s by bringing a sin offering. Whereas if the other person is obligated to bring a burnt offering, and not a sin offering, this disqualification does not apply.
<b>And Rava says: A sin offering that one slaughtered for</b> a person <b>who is not obligated</b> to bring <b>anything</b> is <b>unfit, as there is no person among the Jewish people who is not obligated</b> to bring an offering for violating <b>a positive mitzva.</b> Therefore, the one for whom he slaughtered the offering is considered one who was obligated to bring a sin offering.
<b>And Rava says</b> that <b>a sin offering atones for those obligated</b> to bring a burnt offering for violating <b>a positive mitzva, due to an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If a sin offering <b>atones for those who are liable</b> for transgressions for which one receives <b>excision from the World-to-Come</b> if he performs them intentionally, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that it atones <b>for those liable</b> for failing to fulfill <b>a positive mitzva?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> the violation of a positive mitzva <b>is of the same type as</b> the sins atoned for by a sin offering? <b>But doesn’t Rava say</b> that <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered for</b> a person other than its owner but <b>who</b> was <b>obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering</b> is <b>unfit,</b> but if it was slaughtered <b>for</b> a person <b>who is obligated</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering,</b> it is <b>fit,</b> as he is not obligated to provide a similar atonement? Given that burnt offerings atone for violations of positive mitzvot, apparently such atonement is of a different type than atonement for the transgression of prohibitions.

Daf 7b

The Gemara answers: A sin offering <b>does not atone</b> for violating a positive mitzva <b>by</b> its <b>essence,</b> since prohibitions and positive mitzvot are not of the same type, but it <b>atones</b> for it <b>incidentally.</b>
<b>And Rava says:</b> As for <b>a burnt offering that one slaughtered not for its sake, it is</b> still <b>prohibited to sprinkle its blood not for its sake.</b>
Why is this so? <b>If you wish, cite a verse;</b> and <b>if you wish, propose a logical argument.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you wish, cite a verse: “That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe</b> and do; according to what you have vowed freely to the Lord your God, even that which you have promised with your mouth” (Deuteronomy 23:24). The derivation from this verse was explained in 2a. <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument:</b> Just <b>because</b> one <b>deviated</b> from protocol <b>in its</b> slaughter, shall he continue to deviate from protocol in the rest of the sacrificial process? This is <b>as</b> it was stated at <b>the beginning of the chapter</b> (2a).
<b>And Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a burnt offering that is brought</b> by its owner’s heirs <b>after</b> his <b>death,</b> if one <b>slaughtered it with a deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering,</b> i.e., for the sake of another type of offering, it is <b>unfit,</b> i.e., it does not satisfy the owner’s obligation, and the heirs must therefore bring another offering. But if it was slaughtered <b>with a deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> i.e., for the sake of another person, it is <b>fit, as</b> the offering <b>has no</b> legal <b>owner after</b> the owner’s <b>death.</b>
<b>And Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ami, says</b> that an offering <b>has an owner after</b> its owner’s <b>death,</b> specifically, the heir. <b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ami: Is the Master saying</b> that an offering <b>actually has an owner after</b> its owner’s <b>death, and</b> that if it was slaughtered for the sake of the wrong owner, the heir <b>must bring another burnt offering,</b> contrary to the opinion of Rava? <b>Or perhaps</b> the Master is merely saying <b>that if</b> the heir <b>has several</b> violations of <b>positive mitzvot,</b> the offering <b>atones</b> for them, but still if it was slaughtered for the sake of the wrong owner, the heir is not required to bring another offering.
Rav Pineḥas <b>said to him: I am saying</b> that the heir is <b>actually</b> the owner, and if the offering was slaughtered for someone else, he must bring another offering.
<b>And Rava says: A burnt offering is a gift [<i>doron</i>]</b> to God; its essential purpose is not atonement. Rava supports his assertion: <b>What are the circumstances</b> under which a burnt offering atones for violating a positive mitzva? <b>If</b> one brings a burnt offering <b>without repentance</b> for his transgression, he may not sacrifice it at all, as <b>“the sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination”</b> (Proverbs 21:27). <b>And if there is repentance, isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if one <b>violates a positive mitzva and repents,</b> God <b>forgives him before he</b> even <b>moves from</b> his place? If so, why is he required to bring an offering? <b>Rather, conclude from it</b> that a burnt offering <b>is a gift</b> that one brings in order to appease God even after he is forgiven.
The Gemara states <b>a mnemonic</b> for this series of statements by Rava: <b>A sin offering atones for who, a burnt offering after a gift.</b>
<b>This</b> last statement of Rava <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon said: For what</b> purpose <b>is a sin offering brought?</b> The Gemara interrupts: <b>For what</b> purpose <b>is it brought?</b> Is it not brought <b>to atone</b> for a transgression? <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Shimon clearly meant: <b>For what</b> reason <b>is it brought before a burnt offering</b> in all circumstances where both are brought? Rabbi Shimon answered: It is comparable <b>to an advocate [<i>lifraklit</i>] who enters</b> before the king to convince him to pardon the defendant. Once the <b>advocate has appeased</b> the king, the <b>gift is brought in after him.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that all offerings are fit even if slaughtered not for their sake, <b>except for the Paschal offering and the sin offering.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a Paschal offering</b> is required to be slaughtered for its sake?
The Gemara answers: It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “Observe the month of the spring and offer [<i>ve’asita</i>] the Paschal offering”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:1), teaching <b>that all of the actions [<i>asiyyotav</i>] of</b> the Paschal offering, all of its sacrificial rites, must be performed <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>Paschal offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering</b> is prohibited. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner</b> is also prohibited?
The Gemara answers that this is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And you shall say: It is the sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of</b> the Lord’s <b>Passover”</b> (Exodus 12:27), which indicates <b>that</b> the <b>slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>] must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>Paschal offering. If</b> the verse <b>is not</b> necessary in order <b>to</b> derive <b>the matter</b> of <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering,</b> as that <i>halakha</i> is derived from Deuteronomy 16:1, <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source <b>for</b> the <b>mitzva</b> to sacrifice the Paschal offering for its sake and for the sake of its owner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that these intentions are <b>indispensable</b> and, if lacking, disqualify the offering?
The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “And you shall sacrifice [<i>vezavaḥta</i>] the Paschal offering unto the Lord, your God,</b> of the flock and the herd” (Deuteronomy 16:2). By repeating the mitzva to sacrifice the Paschal offering for its sake and for the sake of its owner, the Torah indicates that these two intentions are both indispensable to the sacrificial process.
<b>Rav Safra objects to this: Does this</b> verse: <b>“And you shall sacrifice,” come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>It is necessary for</b> the statement <b>of Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a leftover Paschal offering,</b> an animal consecrated but not ultimately sacrificed on Passover eve, <b>is sacrificed as a peace offering</b> afterward? It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: “And you shall sacrifice the Passover offering unto the Lord, your God, of the flock and the herd.”</b> The verse is difficult: <b>But isn’t a Paschal offering brought only from the lambs and from the goats? From here</b> it is derived <b>that a leftover Paschal offering should be</b> sacrificed <b>as</b> an offering <b>brought</b> both <b>from the flock and from the herd. And what is that?</b> It is <b>a peace offering.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Safra says</b> that the verses should be expounded as follows: The verse <b>“And you shall sacrifice the Paschal offering”</b> teaches the statement <b>of Rav Naḥman,</b> that a leftover Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace offering. The verse: <b>“Observe the month of the spring</b> and offer the Paschal offering” (Deuteronomy 16:1), teaches that there is <b>a mitzva</b> to sacrifice the Paschal offering without <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering.</b> The verse: <b>“And you shall say:</b> It is <b>the sacrifice of</b> the Lord’s <b>Passover”</b> (Exodus 12:27), teaches that there is <b>a mitzva</b> to slaughter it without <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b> The term <b>“it is”</b> in the latter verse teaches that <b>both here and there,</b> i.e., with regard to both the offering and the owner, proper intent is <b>indispensable.</b>
Rav Safra continues: <b>And we found</b> a source for <b>slaughter. From where do we</b> derive that <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> must also be performed for the sake of the owner or the offering is disqualified? <b>Since</b> the Torah <b>revealed</b> that this intention is indispensable to the proper slaughter of the Paschal offering, it thereby <b>revealed</b> that it is critical to proper performance of the other rites as well.
<b>Rav Ashi says: We do not say</b> that <b>since</b> the Torah <b>revealed</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is indispensable to slaughter, it thereby <b>revealed</b> that it is indispensable to the other rites as well. <b>Rather, from where do we</b> derive that it is indispensable to the other sacrificial <b>rites?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “This is the law of the burnt offering, and of the meal offering,</b> and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the consecration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:37), indicating that all offerings must, like a peace offering, be sacrificed for their own sake.
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the verse: <b>“In the day that he commanded the children of Israel to present their offerings”</b> (Leviticus 7:38), <b>this</b> word, i.e., “offerings,” is referring to the <b>firstborn</b> animal, the animal <b>tithe, and</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> which are not mentioned in the previous verse.
<b>The text juxtaposes</b> all types of offerings mentioned in both verses <b>with a peace offering,</b> indicating that <b>just as</b> one who sacrifices <b>a peace offering is required</b> to do so with the proper intent, <b>both</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> from the <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> and in addition, the <i>halakha</i> of proper intent is only <b>as a mitzva,</b> not as an indispensable requirement, <b>so too,</b> in the case of <b>any</b> type of offering that must have proper intent, <b>both</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> from the <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of proper intent is only <b>as a mitzva.</b> Therefore, the mitzva <i>ab initio</i> is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a peace offering; and those verses mentioned earlier repeat the <i>halakha</i> to teach that it is indispensable with regard to slaughter.
<b>And</b> the juxtaposition of the peace offering with the Paschal offering indicates that a Paschal offering is <b>similar to a peace offering</b> in another respect: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a peace offering, you did not distinguish between slaughter and</b> the <b>other rites with regard to</b> the <b>mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i> of proper intent, <b>so too, with regard to</b> the <b>Paschal offering, do not distinguish between slaughter and</b> the <b>other</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that proper intent is <b>indispensable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather,</b> since the indispensability of proper intent with regard to the Paschal offering is derived from its juxtaposition with the peace offering, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“it is”</b> to be written in Exodus 12:27? What is derived from there?
The Gemara answers: This is written to teach that this requirement is indispensable only in the case of a Paschal offering, and not in the case of a guilt offering. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Concerning</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> the term <b>“it is” is stated with regard to slaughter</b> in Exodus 12:27 <b>to</b> teach that intent for the owner is <b>indispensable. But</b> concerning <b>a guilt offering,</b> the term <b>“it is” is stated only after</b> the verse mentions <b>the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions, and</b> since a guilt offering <b>itself</b> is <b>fit</b> even <b>when its portions were not burned</b> on the altar at all, intent for the sake of the owner at this point is certainly not indispensable.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that if <b>a sin offering</b> is sacrificed for the sake of the wrong type of offering or one other than its owner, it is disqualified? The Gemara answers: It is derived from this verse, <b>as it is written: “And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33), teaching <b>that</b> the <b>slaughter must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source with regard to <b>slaughter. From where do we</b> derive this with regard to <b>collection</b> of the blood? The Gemara answers: It is derived from this verse, <b>as it is written:</b>

Daf 8a

<b>“And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25), teaching <b>that</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And we found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>slaughter and collection</b> must be performed for the sake of a sin offering. <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood? The Gemara answers: It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “And the priest shall make atonement for him concerning his sin”</b> (Leviticus 4:26), teaching <b>that</b> the <b>atonement must be</b> effected <b>for the sake of a sin offering,</b> as atonement is effected by the sprinkling of the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the prohibition against <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering. From where do we</b> derive the prohibition against <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner?</b> The Gemara answers: The aforementioned <b>verse states:</b> “And the priest shall make atonement <b>for him,”</b> indicating that the intent must be <b>for him, and not for another.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source <b>for</b> the <b>mitzva</b> to sprinkle the blood for the sake of the owner <i>ab initio</i>. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is <b>indispensable</b> and disqualifies the offering if not fulfilled? The Gemara answers: It is <b>as Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says</b> with regard to the sin offering of a nazirite: Since the verse could have simply stated: <b>Sin offering,</b> but instead stated: <b>“His sin offering”</b> (Numbers 6:16), it is inferred that the offering must be sacrificed for his, the owner’s, sake. <b>Here too,</b> since the verse could have simply stated <b>“sin,”</b> but states <b>“his sin,”</b> one infers that if the blood of the sin offering is not sprinkled for the sake of its owner, it is disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <b>mitzva of</b> sacrificing a sin offering without <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and</b> with regard to <b>sprinkling</b> its blood without <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner</b> concerning <b>both</b> its <b>mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i> <b>and</b> its <b>indispensability. From where do we</b> derive that performing <b>all</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> without <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering is an indispensable</b> requirement, <b>and</b> that performing <b>all other rites,</b> besides sprinkling the blood, without <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner is both a mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i> <b>and indispensable?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yona says: It is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>the sin offering of a nazirite; as it is written</b> concerning a nazirite: <b>“And the priest shall bring them before the Lord, and shall offer [<i>ve’asa</i>] his sin offering, and his burnt offering”</b> (Numbers 6:16). The verse teaches <b>that all of its</b> sacrificial <b>actions [<i>asiyyotav</i>] must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that a sin offering must be sacrificed without <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering,</b> and that this requirement is indispensable. <b>From where do we</b> derive that sacrificing it without <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner</b> is also indispensable, even in rites other than the sprinkling of the blood?
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says:</b> Since the verse concerning a nazirite could have simply stated: <b>Sin offering,</b> but instead states: <b>“His sin offering,”</b> one infers that the offering must be sacrificed for the owner’s sake.
<b>Ravina objects to this: If that is so, what do you interpret</b> from the fact that the same verse could have stated: <b>Burnt offering,</b> but instead states: <b>“His burnt offering”?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Ravina, what do you interpret</b> from the subsequent verse: “The priest shall offer also his meal offering and his libation” (Numbers 6:17)? Why does Ravina not mention that this verse could have stated: <b>Meal offering,</b> but instead states: <b>“His meal offering,”</b> and that it could have stated: <b>Libation,</b> but instead states: <b>“His libation”?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> language <b>is necessary;</b> it is just like the phrase: <b>“Their meal offering and their libations,”</b> which is mentioned many times in the portion of the Festival offerings (e.g., Numbers 29:37). It teaches that the meal offerings and libations that are brought with the additional animal offerings of the Festivals can be sacrificed even <b>at night</b> after the offering is brought. The phrase: <b>“Their meal offering and their libations,”</b> also teaches that they may be brought <b>even on the following day.</b> Likewise here, when stated with regard to a nazirite, the phrase teaches that they may be brought at night or the day after the offering is sacrificed. <b>But</b> there remains a difficulty: <b>What do you interpret</b> from the fact that the verse could have stated: <b>Burnt offering,</b> but instead states: <b>“His burnt offering”?</b>
The Gemara raises an additional objection to the derivation from a nazirite’s sin offering: <b>And furthermore, can</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a standard sin offering and of a nazirite’s sin offering <b>be derived from one another?</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for a transgression, e.g., eating forbidden <b>fat, cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a nazirite’s sin offering,</b> due to the unique element of stringency of the latter, <b>since there is other blood,</b> i.e., other offerings are brought, <b>with it.</b> Likewise, the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a nazirite’s sin offering cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offer-ing</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat,</b> due to the unique element of stringency of the latter, <b>since</b> it atones for a transgression punishable by <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>].</b>
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> These <i>halakhot</i> are <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the sin offering of a leper; as it is written: “And the priest shall offer [<i>ve’asa</i>] the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:19), teaching <b>that all</b> sacrificial <b>actions of [<i>asiyyotav</i>]</b> a sin offering <b>must be</b> performed <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b>
<b>And we found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that a sin offering must be sacrificed without <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering,</b> and that this is indispensable. <b>From where do we</b> derive that sacrificing a sin offering without <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner</b> is also indispensable? <b>The verse states: “And make atonement for the one that is to be purified</b> of his impurity” (Leviticus 14:19), indicating that the sin offering must be sacrificed <b>for</b> the sake of <b>this</b> person <b>who is being purified, and not for another</b> person <b>who is to be purified.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But still, can</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a standard sin offering and a leper’s sin offering <b>be derived from one another?</b> This comparison is also problematic. The <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a leper’s sin offering, since there is other blood</b> that is brought <b>with</b> the latter, i.e., a burnt offering and a guilt offering; and the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a leper’s sin offering cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat, since</b> the latter atones for a transgression punishable by <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: Indeed, the <i>halakhot</i> of a sin offering <b>cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>one</b> other type of sin offering alone. But one can <b>derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>one</b> type of sin offering <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the other <b>two.</b> The verses concerning a standard sin offering, that of a leper, and that of a nazirite all contain elements that indicate that the offering must be sacrificed for its own sake. Two of them together are sufficient to teach that this <i>halakha</i> applies to the third case. The third case is therefore apparently extraneous, and it is understood to teach that proper intent in this regard is indispensable for all the offering’s rites.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to which</b> type of sin offering <b>should</b> the Torah <b>not have written</b> this <i>halakha</i>, i.e., which of the three cases should be regarded as the extraneous case? If you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> it <b>with regard to a sin offering</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other sin offerings, i.e., those of a nazirite and a leper, this can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> other sin offerings? They are notable <b>in that there is other blood</b> brought <b>with them.</b> Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> should apply only to similar sin offerings.
If you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> it <b>with regard to a nazirite’s sin offering, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other sin offerings, those of a leper and a sinner, this can also be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> other sin offerings? They are notable <b>in that</b> one <b>does not have</b> the option of obtaining an exemption through <b>a request</b> to a halakhic authority. A nazirite, by contrast, can request of a halakhic authority to dissolve his vow of naziriteship, thereby nullifying his obligation.
If you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> it <b>with regard to a leper’s sin offering, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other sin offerings, those of a nazirite and a sinner, this can also be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> other sin offerings? They are notable <b>in that they cannot be brought</b> from doves instead of sheep if the owner is <b>poor,</b> unlike a leper’s sin offering (see Leviticus 14:21). Therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> of these different sin offerings cannot be derived from one another.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is derived from that which <b>the verse states: “This is the law of the burnt offering, and of the meal offering,</b> and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the consecration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:37). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> a sin offering <b>with a peace offering,</b> indicating that <b>just as</b> for <b>a peace offering we require</b> intent <b>for its sake, as a mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>both</b> concerning the <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner, so too,</b> for <b>a sin offering we require</b> intent <b>for its sake as a mitzva, both</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> from the type of <b>offering and</b> concerning <b>deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner.</b>
<b>Therefore,</b> the <b>mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i> is derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a peace offering; and those verses</b> mentioned earlier, from which this requirement is derived with regard to each type of sin offering separately, repeat the <i>halakha</i> <b>to</b> teach that it is <b>indispensable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And we found</b> a source for these <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <b>a sin offering</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat, as it is written with regard to it:</b> “And slaughter it <b>for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33), indicating that it must be slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering. Likewise, sources for this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the sin offerings of a nazirite and a leper have also been cited.

Daf 8b

<b>From where do we</b> derive these <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <b>a sin offering</b> brought <b>for idol worship,</b> which has unique <i>halakhot</i>, as detailed in Numbers 15:27–31, and with regard to which the term: For a sin offering, is not written? Likewise, from where do we derive them with regard to the sin offerings that are brought <b>for</b> the <b>hearing</b> of <b>the voice, and</b> for <b>an utterance of the lips, and</b> for the <b>defiling of</b> the <b>Temple or its sacrificial</b> foods, which also have unique <i>halakhot</i> (Leviticus 5:1–13), and <b>with regard to which</b> the term: For a sin offering, <b>is not written</b> either?
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>a sin offering</b> brought <b>for idol worship,</b> these <i>halakhot</i> are <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for eating forbidden <b>fat, as</b> idol worship is also punishable by <b><i>karet</i>, similar to</b> consumption of forbidden fat. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all these</b> other sin offerings, which are brought for transgressions not punishable by <i>karet</i>, these <i>halakhot</i> <b>are derived by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of the aforementioned three sources, namely, a standard sin offering, the sin offering of a nazirite, and the sin offering of a leper.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> When <b>a Paschal offering</b> is sacrificed <b>at its</b> appointed <b>time,</b> on Passover eve after noon, if it is sacrificed <b>for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake,</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> as stated in the mishna. <b>And</b> when an offering consecrated as a Paschal offering is sacrificed <b>during the rest of the days of the year,</b> if it is sacrificed <b>for its sake,</b> it is <b>unfit;</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the <i>amora’im</i> mentioned in this discussion: <b><i>Shin</i>, <i>lamed</i>, <i>vav</i>; <i>kuf</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>alef</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>tzadi</i>, <i>nun</i>; <i>mem</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>reish</i>; <i>beit</i>, <i>tzadi</i>, <i>alef</i>; <i>beit</i>, <i>alef</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived, i.e., that if a Paschal offering is sacrificed during the rest of the year it is fit if sacrificed not for its sake? <b>Shmuel’s father says: The verse states: “And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings unto the Lord is of the flock”</b> (Leviticus 3:6), indicating that an offering <b>that is brought</b> only <b>from the flock will be a sacrifice of peace offerings.</b> The Paschal offering fulfills this criterion.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Say</b> that if it is sacrificed for the sake of <b>a peace offering, yes,</b> it is fit, but if it is sacrificed for the sake of <b>some other</b> offering, it is <b>not</b> fit. <b>Rabbi Ila says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The redundant expression <b>“for a sacrifice”</b> in Leviticus 3:6 is stated <b>to include any</b> type of <b>sacrifice.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say</b> that a Paschal offering <b>should be</b> rendered <b>as any</b> offering for <b>which</b> one <b>slaughters</b> it; for example, if it is slaughtered for the sake of a burnt offering, it should be rendered a burnt offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the phrase: <b>For peace offerings and a sacrifice, was written</b> in the verse, it would be <b>as you say. Now that it is written: “For a sacrifice of peace offerings,”</b> it indicates that <b>for whatever</b> type of offering one <b>slaughters it, it will be a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>Say</b> that: <b>“For a sacrifice,”</b> is <b>a generalization</b> and: <b>“Of peace offerings,”</b> is <b>a detail,</b> and according to the principles of biblical hermeneutics, wherever there is <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization includes only that which is</b> specified <b>in the detail.</b> Accordingly, if the offering is sacrificed for the sake of <b>a peace offering, yes,</b> it is fit; but if it is sacrificed for the sake of <b>another</b> offering, it is <b>not</b> fit.
The Gemara answers: With the term: <b>“Unto the Lord,”</b> the verse <b>then generalized</b> again. Therefore, the verse is formulated as a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, as the Gemara will explain.
<b>Rav Ya’akov of Nehar Pekod objects to this</b> suggestion: <b>But the latter generalization is dissimilar to the former generalization. The former generalization:</b> “For a sacrifice,” <b>includes</b> only <b>slaughtered offerings and nothing more,</b> whereas <b>the latter generalization: “Unto the Lord,”</b> includes <b>any</b> offering <b>unto the Lord. And</b> accordingly, <b>even</b> if the Paschal offering was sacrificed <b>for</b> the sake of <b>bird</b> offerings, <b>or even for</b> the sake of <b>meal offerings,</b> it should be fit, as these are brought “unto the Lord.”
The Gemara responds to this objection: <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught generalizations and details</b> even in examples <b>like this case.</b>
The Gemara explains: Since “unto the Lord” is a second generalization, the verse is formulated as <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization,</b> and <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail</b> are clearly <b>defined as</b> a case where a Paschal offering was sacrificed <b>not for its own sake, and</b> nevertheless it is <b>fit, so too,</b> in <b>any</b> case <b>where it</b> was sacrificed <b>not for its sake but</b> for the sake of another offering, it is <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the verse is referring only to actions similar to the detail, then <b>just as</b> the items mentioned in <b>the detail</b> are clearly <b>defined</b> as a peace offering, which is <b>a matter that is brought as a vow</b> offering <b>or as a gift</b> offering, <b>so too,</b> a Paschal offering should be fit only if it was sacrificed for the sake of <b>any</b> offering <b>that is brought as a vow</b> offering <b>or as a gift</b> offering. Accordingly, if it was sacrificed for the sake of <b>a burnt offering or a peace offering, yes,</b> it is fit, as these are brought as a vow offering or as a gift offering; but if it was sacrificed for the sake of <b>a sin offering or a guilt offering,</b> it is <b>not</b> fit, as these are not brought as a vow offering or as a gift offering.
The Gemara therefore rejects the exegetical method of generalizations and details in favor of that of amplifications and restrictions: <b>Rather,</b> the term: <b>“For a sacrifice,” is</b> not a generalization, but <b>an amplification,</b> which includes any type of offering. Therefore, if a Paschal offering is sacrificed for the sake of any type of offering during the rest of the year, it is fit.
The Gemara challenges: If so, <b>say</b> that it adds that a Paschal offering <b>should be</b> rendered <b>as any</b> offering for <b>which</b> one <b>slaughters</b> it. Why does Shmuel’s father interpret that it is rendered a peace offering specifically?
<b>Rabbi Avin says:</b>

Daf 9a

<b>Offerings that are eaten,</b> in this case the Paschal offering, <b>are diverted</b> when slaughtered not for their sake <b>to</b> serve as other types of <b>offerings that are eaten,</b> such as peace offerings. <b>But offerings that are eaten are not diverted to</b> serve as <b>offerings that are not eaten,</b> such as burnt offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering are not eaten?</b> Why does a Paschal offering receive the status of a peace offering and not that of a sin offering or a guilt offering, which are eaten by the priests?
<b>Rather,</b> the answer should be emended: <b>Offerings that are eaten by every</b> Jewish <b>person are diverted to</b> serve as <b>offerings eaten by every</b> Jewish <b>person,</b> i.e., peace offerings. <b>But offerings eaten by every</b> Jewish <b>person are not diverted to</b> serve as <b>offerings not eaten by every</b> Jewish <b>person,</b> i.e., sin offerings and guilt offerings, which are eaten only by priests.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Avin, says</b> that there is a different answer: <b>Offerings of lesser sanctity are diverted to</b> serve as <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> i.e., peace offerings. <b>But offerings of lesser sanctity are not diverted to</b> serve as <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> i.e., burnt offerings, sin offerings, or guilt offerings.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rabbi Savriyu, objects to this</b> answer: If so, <b>say</b> that if one <b>slaughtered</b> a Paschal offering <b>for the sake of</b> the animal <b>tithe, let it be</b> rendered animal <b>tithe,</b> which, like a Paschal offering, is an offering of lesser sanctity. The Gemara adds: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> does it matter, practically speaking, that a Paschal offering has been rendered an animal tithe rather than a peace offering? It matters <b>because</b> if it is rendered an animal tithe, <b>it should not require libations. And</b> furthermore, if one sells it, he <b>should be flogged for</b> transgressing the prohibition: <b>“It shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:33), which applies to the animal tithe even after its slaughter.
The Gemara responds: <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the animal tithe: <b>“The tenth shall be sacred”</b> (Leviticus 27:32). The definite article indicates that <b>this,</b> the tenth animal, is the <b>tithe, but another</b> animal slaughtered for its sake is <b>not a tithe.</b>
The Gemara challenges: Still, <b>say</b> that if one <b>slaughtered</b> a Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a firstborn</b> animal, <b>let it be</b> rendered <b>like a firstborn.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> does it matter, practically speaking, that it has been rendered a firstborn rather than a peace offering? It matters <b>because</b> if it is rendered a firstborn, <b>it should not require libations. Also,</b> this means <b>that one should give it to the priests.</b>
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>a firstborn too,</b> the verse states: “That you shall set apart [<i>veha’avarta</i>] unto the Lord all that opens the womb” (Exodus 13:12). Since with regard to the animal tithe it is stated: “Whatever passes [<i>ya’avor</i>] under the rod, the tenth shall be holy” (Leviticus 27:32), it is <b>derived</b> by verbal analogy between the <b>passing [<i>avara</i>]</b> stated with regard to a firstborn and the <b>passing [<i>avara</i>]</b> stated with regard to the animal <b>tithe</b> that a Paschal offering cannot become a firstborn either.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But say</b> that if one <b>slaughtered</b> a Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a substitute, let it be</b> rendered <b>a substitute.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> does it matter, practically speaking, that it has been rendered a substitute rather than a peace offering? The one who slaughtered it <b>should be flogged for</b> transgressing the prohibition of effecting substitution. <b>Also,</b> its sale <b>should be determined to</b> violate the prohibition: <b>“It shall not be sold or redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:28).
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, says:</b> It is derived from that which <b>the verse states</b> with regard to substitution: <b>“Then both it and that for which it is changed</b> shall be sacred” (Leviticus 27:33). The verse teaches that only <b>it,</b> the animal substituted, is <b>a substitute, but another</b> animal is <b>not a substitute.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But say</b> that if one <b>slaughtered</b> a Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a thanks offering, let it be</b> rendered <b>like a thanks offering.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> does it practically matter that it has been rendered a thanks offering rather than a peace offering? If so, <b>it should require</b> a meal offering of forty loaves of <b>bread.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Is there anything,</b> i.e., any situation, comparable to this suggestion <b>that a Paschal offering itself does not require bread, but its leftover,</b> an animal consecrated as a Paschal offering but ultimately not sacrificed on Passover eve, <b>requires bread</b> when slaughtered not for its sake? Such a suggestion is implausible.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, now</b> that a leftover Paschal offering slaughtered for the sake of a peace offering becomes a peace offering, this objection can <b>also</b> be raised: <b>Is there anything</b> comparable to the suggestion <b>that a Paschal offering itself does not require libations, but its leftover requires libations</b> as a peace offering?
The Gemara explains its answer: <b>This</b> is what <b>we are saying: Is there anything</b> comparable to the suggestion <b>that the leftover of a thanks offering itself does not require bread, but</b> the <b>leftover</b> of an offering <b>from</b> some <b>other</b> category <b>requires bread?</b>
§ It was taught that the verse: “And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings unto the Lord is of the flock” (Leviticus 3:6), teaches that a Paschal offering sacrificed not on Passover eve is rendered a peace offering if sacrificed not for its sake. <b>Rav Yeimar, son of Rav Hillel, objects to this: But from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> this verse <b>is written with regard to a leftover Paschal offering? Perhaps it is written with regard to a leftover guilt offering;</b> a guilt offering is also brought only from the flock.
<b>Rava says: The verse states: “And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings</b> unto the Lord <b>is of [<i>min</i>] the flock,”</b> where the term “<i>min</i>” indicates <b>that is</b> brought <b>equally from all</b> species of the <b>flock,</b> i.e., from both sheep and goats. A guilt offering, by contrast, is brought only from rams, i.e., male sheep.
<b>Rabbi Avin bar Ḥiyya, and some say Rabbi Avin bar Kahana, objects to this: You say everywhere</b> that the word <b>“<i>min</i>”</b> is stated <b>to exclude</b> items, <b>but here</b> you claim that the word <b>“<i>min</i>”</b> is stated <b>to include</b> all species of the flock? You should say the opposite: The verse indicates an offering that is brought only from some species of the flock, i.e., a guilt offering.
<b>Rabbi Mani says: Here too,</b> the word <b>“<i>min</i>”</b> is stated <b>to exclude</b> certain categories of the flock, <b>as</b> a Paschal offering <b>is not brought</b> from an animal that is <b>in its second year, and is not brought from</b> the <b>female</b> animals of the flock.
The Gemara cites another objection. <b>Rav Ḥana of Baghdad objects to this: How can you say that when this</b> verse <b>is written, it is written with regard to a leftover Paschal offering? But from</b> that <b>which is written</b> in the subsequent verses: <b>“If</b> he brings <b>a lamb”</b> (Leviticus 3:7), and <b>“if</b> his offering is <b>a goat”</b> (Leviticus 3:12), one learns <b>by inference that</b> the passage is <b>not written with regard to a leftover Paschal offering;</b> the Torah states elsewhere, in Exodus 12:5, that a Paschal offering is brought from both lambs and goats, and it is unnecessary to teach this again in Leviticus.
The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> verses <b>are necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The word <b>“lamb”</b> is written <b>to include the Paschal offering in</b> the requirement that the <b>tail</b> be offered on the altar, which is written subsequently with regard to a peace offering (Leviticus 3:9), since this <i>halakha</i> is not mentioned in the verses concerning the Paschal offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “If</b> he brings <b>a lamb,”</b> it is <b>to include in all the mitzvot of peace offerings a Paschal offering whose</b> first <b>year has passed</b> and is therefore too old to be sacrificed as a Paschal offering, <b>and peace offerings brought due to a Paschal offering.</b> Specifically, this indicates <b>that they require placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>libations, and the waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh. And when</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And <b>if</b> his offering is a <b>goat,” it interrupted the</b> previous <b>matter</b> and <b>taught that the</b> sacrificing of <b>a goat does not require</b> that the <b>tail</b> be burned on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But is it derived from here</b> that a Paschal offering that is too old to be sacrificed as a Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace offering? <b>It is derived from</b> the verse <b>that Shmuel’s father</b> cites, <b>as Shmuel’s father says:</b> The verse: <b>“And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings</b> unto the Lord <b>is of the flock”</b> (Leviticus 3:6), teaches that an offering <b>that is brought</b> only <b>from the flock,</b> i.e., the Paschal offering, <b>will be a sacrifice of peace offerings.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>But</b> even without the <i>baraita</i>, Shmuel’s father’s statement is <b>still</b> superfluous, as that <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived from that which Rav Naḥman</b> says that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says. As Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a leftover Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace offering? As it is stated: “And you shall sacrifice the Passover offering unto the Lord, your God, of the flock and the herd”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:2). Why is the herd mentioned? <b>But isn’t a Paschal offering brought only from the lambs and from the goats? Rather,</b> it is derived <b>from here that a leftover Paschal offering should be</b> sacrificed as an offering <b>brought</b> both <b>from the flock and from the herd. And what is that?</b> It is <b>a peace offering.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> none of these derivations are superfluous, as <b>three verses are written</b> that teach the <i>halakha</i> that a Paschal offering that is sacrificed not on Passover eve is sacrificed as a peace offering.

Daf 9b

<b>One</b> verse teaches this <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice, Passover eve, <b>has passed, and its</b> first <b>year has</b> also <b>passed,</b> disqualifying it for sacrifice as a Paschal offering. <b>And one</b> verse teaches the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice <b>has passed, but not its</b> first <b>year. And</b> the third <b>one</b> teaches a case where <b>neither its time</b> of sacrifice <b>nor its</b> first <b>year has passed,</b> but it was sacrificed before Passover eve.
<b>And</b> all these verses <b>are necessary. As, had the Merciful One written</b> only <b>one</b> of the verses, <b>I would say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>where</b> both <b>its</b> first <b>year and its time</b> of sacrifice <b>have passed.</b> Only such a Paschal offering should be sacrificed as a peace offering, <b>as it was completely rejected from</b> its status as <b>a Paschal offering. But</b> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice <b>has passed, but its</b> first <b>year</b> has <b>not</b> passed, in <b>which</b> case it is still <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed as a Paschal offering on the <b>second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, I would say</b> that it is <b>not</b> sacrificed as a peace offering.
<b>And had the Merciful One written</b> only <b>these two</b> verses, one might assume that only these Paschal offerings are sacrificed as peace offerings, <b>as they were</b> both <b>rejected from their status</b> as Paschal offerings. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where neither its time</b> of sacrifice <b>nor its</b> first <b>year have passed,</b> in <b>which</b> case it is still <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed as <b>a Paschal offering</b> on Passover eve, <b>I would say</b> that it is <b>not</b> sacrificed as a peace offering. Therefore, all three verses <b>are necessary.</b>
§ <b>Rav says in the name of Mavog: A sin offering that</b> one <b>slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering of Nahshon,</b> i.e., a sin offering similar to those brought by the princes during the dedication of the Tabernacle (see Numbers, chapter 7), not to atone for a sin but as a gift, is <b>fit</b> and satisfies its owner’s obligation; <b>as the verse states: “This is the law of the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:18), indicating that there is <b>one law for all the sin offerings.</b>
<b>Rava sat and stated this <i>halakha</i></b> of Mavog. <b>Rav Mesharshiyya raised an objection to Rava</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake</b> but for the sake of another type of meal offering <b>are fit, and satisfied the obligation of the owner,</b> in contrast to animal offerings, which if slaughtered not for their sake do not satisfy their owners’ obligations.
This is <b>because meal offerings are not similar to slaughtered offerings. As, if one removes a handful</b> from a meal offering prepared in a shallow <b>pan for the sake of</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan,</b> his intention is demonstrably incorrect, as <b>its</b> mode of <b>preparation proves that it is</b> a meal offering prepared in a shallow <b>pan.</b> Likewise, if one removes a handful from <b>a dry</b> meal offering <b>for the sake of</b> a meal offering <b>mixed</b> with oil, his intention is demonstrably incorrect, as <b>its</b> mode of <b>preparation proves that it is a dry</b> meal offering. The demonstrably incorrect nature of the intention prevents it from affecting the status of the meal offering in any way.
<b>But with regard to slaughtered offerings this is not so.</b> There is <b>one</b> mode of <b>slaughter for all of</b> the offerings, <b>one</b> mode of <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>for all of them,</b> and <b>one</b> mode of <b>sprinkling for all of them.</b> Therefore, improper intention affects the status of the offering; if a rite is performed for the sake of the wrong type of offering, the offering does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.
Rav Mesharshiyya inferred from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The reason</b> a meal offering satisfies its owner’s obligation even when one removed a handful for the sake of another type of meal offering <b>is that its</b> mode of <b>preparation proves</b> its true nature. <b>But</b> if <b>its</b> mode of <b>preparation does not prove</b> its nature, it does <b>not</b> satisfy its owner’s obligation. <b>Why</b> not? If Mavog’s derivation is correct, <b>let us say</b> likewise that the verse: <b>“This is the law of the meal offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:7), indicates that there is <b>one law for all of the meal offerings,</b> regardless of their mode of preparation.
<b>Rather, if</b> Mavog’s statement <b>was stated, it was stated like this: Rav says in the name of Mavog: A sin offering that one slaughtered on the condition that Nahshon,</b> the prince of Judah, <b>be atoned for by it is fit;</b> this is not considered a change of owner, as <b>there is no atonement for the dead.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if this was Mavog’s statement, why did he mention Nahshon? <b>Let him state</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference to <b>a dead</b> person <b>in general.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement of Mavog <b>teaches us</b> that <b>the reason</b> for the fitness of a sin offering slaughtered for the atonement of Nahshon <b>is that he is dead. Consequently,</b> if it was slaughtered for the sake of <b>a living</b> person obligated to bring a sin offering <b>similar to</b> that of <b>Nahshon,</b> it is <b>unfit. And what is that?</b> It is <b>a nazirite’s sin offering or a leper’s sin offering,</b> which are brought not to atone for a sin but to become ritually pure. Consequently, if one sacrifices a standard sin offering for the sake of one obligated to bring the sin offering of a nazirite or a leper, it is considered a change of owner, and the offering is unfit.
The Gemara counters: Why is the offering disqualified? <b>These</b> sin offerings of a nazirite and a leper <b>are</b> equivalent to <b>burnt offerings,</b> since they are not brought for atonement. Sacrificing a sin offering for the sake of one obligated to bring a burnt offering is not considered deviation with regard to the owner and does not disqualify it (see 3b).
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, if</b> Mavog’s statement <b>was stated, it was stated like this: Rav says in the name of Mavog: A sin offering that one slaughtered for one who is obligated to bring a sin offering similar to</b> that of <b>Nahshon</b> is <b>fit; Nahshon’s sin offering is</b> equivalent to <b>a burnt offering.</b>
<b>There is</b> one <b>who says</b> that <b>Rav says in the name of Mavog: A sin offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering of Nahshon</b> is <b>unfit.</b> This is because <b>a sin offering of Nahshon is</b> equivalent to <b>a burnt offering,</b> and he is therefore considered to have deviated from the type of offering.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> why did Mavog mention a sin offering of Nahshon, which one cannot bring at all? <b>Let him say</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a nazirite’s sin offering and a leper’s sin offering,</b> which are also equivalent to burnt offerings. The Gemara explains: Mavog <b>cited the primary sin offering,</b> the first case of an individual sin offering recorded in the Bible.
§ <b>Rav says: A sin offering</b> brought for consuming forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering</b> brought for consuming <b>blood,</b> or <b>for the sake of a sin offering</b> brought for engaging in <b>idol worship, is fit;</b> it is not considered deviation from the type of offering.
But if it was slaughtered <b>for the sake of a nazirite’s sin offering,</b> or <b>for the sake of a leper’s sin offering,</b> it is <b>unfit; these</b> sin offer-ings <b>are</b> equivalent to <b>burnt offerings,</b> as they are not brought for atonement.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for consuming forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering</b> brought <b>for</b> the <b>defiling of</b> the <b>Temple or its sacrificial</b> foods, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that the offering is fit, as the latter type of sin offering atones for a transgression punishable by <b><i>karet</i></b> when committed intentionally, <b>similar to</b> the transgression of consuming forbidden fat?
<b>Or perhaps</b> is it unfit, as a sin offering brought for defiling the Temple is a sliding-scale sin offering, the contents of which vary with the financial situation of the transgressor (see Leviticus 5:3–13), and <b>not a set</b> sin offering, which is always an animal, <b>like</b> a sin offering brought for consuming forbidden fat?
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, teaches</b> a version of Rav’s statement according to which in <b>all of</b> the cases he mentioned, including one where the sin offering was slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering brought for consuming blood or for engaging in idol worship, the offering is <b>unfit. What is the reason?</b> It is derived from the verse: <b>“And slaughter it [<i>otah</i>] for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33), that a sin offering must be slaughtered <b>for the sake of that [<i>otah</i>] sin offering,</b> and no other.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava: How do you teach Rava’s dilemma?</b> Rava appears to assume that if one slaughters a sin offering for the sake of some other types of sin offering it remains fit. How is this compatible with your version of Rav’s statement, according to which slaughter for the sake of any other type of sin offering disqualifies it?
Rav Aḥa <b>said to him: We teach</b> Rava’s dilemma <b>with regard to deviation</b> with regard to the <b>owner</b> rather than from the type of offering. <b>And this is how we teach it:</b> First, <b>Rava says: A sin offering</b> brought for consuming forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for</b> the sake of one <b>who is obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering</b> for consuming <b>blood, or</b> for the sake of one who is obligated to bring <b>a sin offering</b> for engaging in <b>idol worship,</b> is <b>unfit.</b> Since the other person is also obligated to bring a sin offering, this is considered deviation with regard to the owner. But if it was slaughtered <b>for one who is obligated</b> to bring <b>a nazirite’s sin offering or a leper’s sin offering,</b> it is <b>fit,</b> as these sin offerings are not brought for atonement. Deviation with regard to the owner disqualifies an offering only if the other owner is obligated to bring a similar offering.
<b>And</b> then <b>we pose the dilemma like this: Rava raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>a sin offering</b> brought for consuming forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for</b> the sake of <b>one who is obligated</b> to bring <b>a sin offering for</b> the <b>defiling of</b> the <b>Temple or its sacrificial</b> foods, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that the offering is unfit, as the one who defiled the Temple or its sacrificial foods is obligated to bring a sin offering for a transgression punishable by <b><i>karet</i>, similar to</b> the transgression of the owner? <b>Or perhaps</b> it remains fit, as a sin offering brought for defiling the Temple is <b>not a set</b> sin offering <b>like</b> a sin offering brought for consuming forbidden fat?
The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> a sin offering <b>for its sake</b> with intent <b>to sprinkle its blood not for its sake</b> but for the sake of another type of offering, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the offering is <b>unfit, and Reish Lakish says</b> it is <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> as in his opinion <b>one can have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite,</b> i.e., one can disqualify an offering by performing one rite with improper intent about a subsequent rite that he has not yet performed. <b>And we derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from intent of <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., intent while performing one of the main rites to consume the offering after the appointed time, which disqualifies the offering.
<b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that it is <b>fit,</b> as in his opinion <b>one cannot have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite, and we do not derive</b> <i>halakhot</i> with regard to deviation from the type of offering <b>from intent of <i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish each <b>follow [<i>ve’azdu</i>] their</b> general line of <b>reasoning</b> in this matter; <b>as it was stated:</b>

Daf 10a

With regard to <b>one who slaughters an animal in order to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, or</b> in order <b>to burn its</b> forbidden <b>fat for idol worship, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Deriving benefit from the animal is <b>prohibited,</b> as it is considered an offering to idol worship, even if ultimately its blood was not sprinkled or its fat burned to that effect. This is because <b>one can have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite;</b> idolatrous intent while slaughtering the animal renders it forbidden, even if the intention pertains not to the slaughter itself but to the sprinkling of the blood or the burning of the forbidden fat. <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>piggul</i>, as <b>we derive</b> <i>halakhot</i> of idol worship, which are applicable even <b>outside</b> the Temple, <b>from</b> <i>halakhot</i> concerning intent that apply <b>inside</b> the Temple.
<b>Reish Lakish says:</b> Deriving benefit from the animal is <b>permitted. One cannot have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite, and we do not derive</b> <i>halakhot</i> applicable <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> <i>halakhot</i> that apply <b>inside</b> the Temple.
