Although both disputes are essentially the same, each is necessary. <b>And if</b> the Sages <b>had taught us</b> the dispute only <b>with regard to that</b> issue, namely, an animal slaughtered with idolatrous intent, one would have reasoned that <b>Reish Lakish says</b> his opinion only <b>with regard to that</b> issue, as he maintains that <i>halakhot</i> applicable outside the Temple are not derived from <i>halakhot</i> applicable only inside the Temple. <b>But</b> with regard to an offering that was slaughtered with the intention of sprinkling its blood not for its sake, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that it is disqualified, as <i>halakhot</i> applicable <b>inside</b> the Temple can be derived <b>from</b> other <i>halakhot</i> applicable <b>inside</b> the Temple.
<b>And if</b> the Sages <b>had taught us</b> the dispute only with regard to <b>this</b> issue, namely, an offering that was slaughtered with the intention of sprinkling its blood not for its sake, one might claim that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> his opinion only <b>with regard to this</b> issue, which concerns <i>halakhot</i> applicable inside the Temple. <b>But with regard to that</b> issue, an animal that was slaughtered with idolatrous intent, one would <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> that <i>halakhot</i> applicable outside the Temple are not derived from <i>halakhot</i> applicable only inside the Temple. Therefore, both statements <b>are necessary.</b>
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said: Rav Yirmeya responds</b> to this dispute by eliciting evidence <b>to support</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan; and Rabbi Ila</b> elicits evidence <b>to support</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish.</b>
Rav Dimi elaborated: <b>Rav Yirmeya</b> elicits evidence <b>to support</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>Just as in</b> the <b>case</b> of improper intent with regard to the offering’s time, <b>where if</b> the one slaughtering the offering <b>said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> it is <b>fit,</b> and nevertheless, if he <b>slaughtered it in order to sprinkle its blood beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> so too, in the <b>case</b> of deviation from the type of offering, <b>where</b> even <b>if he said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>not for its sake,</b> it is <b>unfit, isn’t it logical that</b> if <b>he slaughtered it in order to sprinkle its blood not for its sake, it should be unfit?</b>
<b>Rava bar Ahilai objects to this</b> inference: One cannot claim that deviation from the type of offering is a more severe transgression than intent to consume it or sprinkle its blood beyond its designated time, since the latter has its own element of stringency. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> intent <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> one who eats the meat of such an offering is liable to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>,</b> whereas one who eats the meat of an offering disqualified due to deviation from the type of offering is not.
<b>Rather, Rava bar Ahilai says:</b> Rav Yirmeya was actually referring to improper intent with regard to the offering’s designated area, since consumption of an offering thereby disqualified is not punishable by <i>karet</i>. And <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying: Just as</b> in the <b>case</b> of improper intent with regard to the offering’s designated area, <b>where if</b> the one slaughtering the offering <b>said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, it is fit,</b> and nevertheless, if he <b>slaughtered it in order to sprinkle its blood outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> so too, in the <b>case</b> of deviation from the type of offering, <b>where</b> even <b>if he said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>not for its sake, it is unfit, isn’t it logical that</b> if <b>he slaughtered it in order to sprinkle its blood not for its sake, it should be unfit?</b>
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this</b> inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> intent to sprinkle the blood <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the disqualification <b>applies to all slaughtered offerings. Can you say</b> that the same <i>halakhot</i> govern the disqualification of an offering sacrificed <b>not for its sake, which applies only to a Paschal offering and a sin offering?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says: This</b> is what Rav Yirmeya <b>is saying: Just as in</b> the <b>case</b> of deviation with regard to the owner, <b>where, if</b> the one slaughtering the offering <b>said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>for the sake of so-and-so, it is fit,</b> and nevertheless, if he slaughtered it in order <b>to sprinkle its blood for the sake of so-and-so,</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> so too, in the <b>case</b> of deviation from the type of offering, <b>where</b> even <b>if he said: I am hereby slaughtering</b> it <b>not for its sake, it is unfit, isn’t it logical that</b> if <b>he slaughtered it in order to sprinkle its blood not for its sake, it should be unfit?</b> The opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan is supported by this logical line of reasoning.
<b>Rabbi Ila</b> elicits evidence <b>to support</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> that performance of one rite with improper intent with regard to another rite is of no consequence: The Torah <b>should not have stated</b> the requirement of sacrificing an offering for its own sake <b>with regard to sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>and</b> rather <b>should have</b> let one <b>derive</b> it <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <b>common</b> element <b>of</b> two other rites, <b>from slaughter and collection</b> of the blood. If so, <b>for what <i>halakha</i> does the Merciful One write</b> this redundant requirement? It is in order <b>to say that one cannot have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this</b> derivation: <b>But perhaps</b> the requirement is written to teach the opposite, <b>that one can have intention from</b> one <b>rite to</b> affect another <b>rite.</b> A redundant requirement should expand, not reduce, the scope of actions that can disqualify the offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>If that were so, let the verse remain silent with regard to</b> sprinkling the blood for the sake of the offering, <b>and one could derive</b> that one can have intention from one rite to affect another rite <b>from Rav Ashi’s</b> aforementioned <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. The verse must be meant to counteract that inference and teach that one cannot have intention from one rite to affect another rite.
<b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>would refute</b> Rabbi Ila’s proof <b>like this:</b> It is necessary for the Torah to state the requirement with regard to sprinkling. It cannot be derived from the cases of slaughter and collection of the blood, since these two share an element of stringency that sprinkling lacks. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these?</b> They are notable <b>in that</b> in offerings of the most sacred order <b>they must</b> be performed in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>they are</b> performed <b>in the</b> sacrifice of <b>inner sin offerings</b> as well as external sin offerings, unlike the sprinkling of the blood on the external altar.
<b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, Reish Lakish, would respond that <b>now, in any event, we stand</b> in a discussion <b>with regard to peace offerings,</b> since the requirement of sacrifice for the offering’s sake is derived from the verses concerning peace offerings. Peace offerings are neither offerings of the most sacred order nor inner sin offerings, and therefore the elements of stringency mentioned above are irrelevant.
A parallel dispute <b>was stated:</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> a sin offering <b>for its sake</b> but with intent <b>to sprinkle its blood not for its sake, Rav Naḥman says</b> that the offering is <b>unfit,</b> and <b>Rabba says</b> that it is <b>fit. And Rabba retracted his</b> opinion, and conceded <b>to Rav Naḥman, due to Rav Ashi’s <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The guilt offering, too,</b> is unfit when sacrificed not for its sake. With regard to this <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said: A sin offering is brought for</b> committing <b>a transgression and a guilt offering is brought for</b> committing <b>a transgression. Just as a sin offering</b> sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> is <b>unfit, so too, a guilt offering</b> sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> is <b>unfit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> The inference is <b>not</b> valid. <b>If you say</b> this <b>with regard to a sin offering, whose blood</b> is sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line that encircles the altar, should you necessarily say the same with regard to a guilt offering, whose blood is sprinkled below that line, like most animal offerings?
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: A Paschal offering can prove</b> the point, <b>as its blood is</b> sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line, <b>and</b> nevertheless, if one <b>slaughtered it not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> A Paschal offering cannot serve as the source either, since it possesses a unique element of stringency. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a Paschal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that its</b> designated <b>time is fixed.</b> A guilt offering does not have a fixed time.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: A sin offering can prove</b> the point, as it does not have a fixed time, and nevertheless, it is disqualified if sacrificed not for its sake.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b>

Daf 10b

<b>I return</b> to my previous claim that a sin offering is unique since its blood is sprinkled above the red line. The discussion is going <b>around [<i>ḥalila</i>]</b> in circles.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer then presented a different logical inference: With regard to a sin offering,</b> the word <b>“it” is stated concerning slaughter,</b> in the verse: “And slaughter it in the place where they kill the burnt offering before the Lord; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). The word “it” teaches that if <b>it</b> is sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit. And</b> similarly, <b>with regard to a Paschal offering,</b> the word <b>“it” is stated concerning slaughter [<i>zeviḥa</i>],</b> in the verse: “It is the sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of the Lord’s Passover” (Exodus 12:27). Here, the word “it” teaches that if <b>it</b> is sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
And the word <b>“it” is stated with regard to a guilt offering as well,</b> in the verse: “It is a guilt offering” (Leviticus 7:5). Here too, say that the word “it” teaches that if <b>it</b> is sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: With regard to a sin offering,</b> the word <b>“it” is stated concerning slaughter,</b> teaching that if <b>it</b> is sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> it is <b>fit,</b> but if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit. With regard to a Paschal offering</b> too, the word <b>“it” is stated concerning slaughter,</b> likewise teaching that if <b>it</b> is sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> it is <b>fit,</b> but if it is sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> it is <b>unfit. But with regard to a guilt offering,</b> the word <b>“it” is stated only after the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions. And</b> since the offering <b>itself is fit</b> even if the <b>sacrificial portions were not burned</b> at all, it is certainly fit if they were burned not for the sake of a guilt offering.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him:</b> A sin offering and a guilt offering are juxtaposed in the verse that <b>states: “As is the sin offering, so is the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:7). The verse teaches that <b>just as a sin offering</b> sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> is <b>unfit, so too, a guilt offering</b> sacrificed <b>not for its sake</b> is <b>unfit.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: I return</b> to my previous claim, that a sin offering is unique since its blood is sprinkled above the red line. The discussion is going <b>around</b> in circles. The Gemara asks: <b>And let the derivation revert</b> to its starting point, <b>and let</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>derive</b> the point <b>by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of the two sources, a sin offering and a Paschal offering. Together they can prove that a guilt offering sacrificed not for its sake is also unfit, since they share no element of stringency that the latter lacks.
The Gemara answers: Even such a derivation is not valid, <b>as it can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> A sin offering and a Paschal offering are notable <b>in that they</b> both <b>have an element of <i>karet</i>.</b> A sin offering is brought for a transgression punishable by <i>karet</i> when committed intentionally, and one who refrains intentionally from bringing a Paschal offering is liable to be punished with <i>karet</i>. A guilt offering, by contrast, has no element of <i>karet</i>.
§ The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> Your comparison of a guilt offering to a sin offering is <b>not</b> valid. <b>If you say</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a sin offering, whose blood is</b> sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line, should you necessarily say the same with regard to a guilt offering, whose blood is sprinkled below that line? The Gemara challenges: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>say to him</b> another refutation: Your comparison is <b>not</b> valid, as <b>if you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a sin offering, whose blood enters the innermost sanctum,</b> i.e., the Holy of Holies, on Yom Kippur, must the same be said for a guilt offering, whose blood never enters the innermost sanctum?
The Gemara answers: <b>We are stating</b> a comparison of a guilt offering to a sin offering specifically <b>with regard to the external sin offerings,</b> whose blood does not enter the innermost sanctum.
The Gemara counters: If so, Rabbi Yehoshua could have refuted the comparison by pointing out another difference between a sin offering and a guilt offering, <b>as, if the blood of</b> an external sin offering <b>enters the innermost sanctum,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> This is not so in the case of the blood of a guilt offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>a guilt offering</b> whose blood enters the innermost sanctum is <b>also</b> disqualified.
The Gemara counters: Rabbi Yehoshua could have pointed out another distinction, <b>as</b> a sin offering <b>atones for</b> transgressions for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i></b> if he committed them intentionally.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer derives the <i>halakha</i> specifically <b>from a sin offering</b> brought <b>for hearing the voice,</b> i.e., for falsely taking an oath that one is unable to testify in another’s case. This transgression is not punishable by <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara counters: Rabbi Yehoshua could have pointed out another distinction, <b>that</b> the blood of a sin offering <b>requires four placements</b> on the altar, whereas the blood of a guilt offering requires only two.
The Gemara answers: Perhaps Rabbi Eliezer holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who says</b> that <b>the blood</b> of almost <b>all</b> offerings <b>requires four placements.</b>
The Gemara counters: Rabbi Yehoshua could have pointed out another distinction, <b>that</b> a sin offering’s blood <b>requires</b> placement <b>on</b> all <b>four corners</b> of the altar, whereas the blood of a guilt offering, even according to Rabbi Yishmael, is sprinkled on only two corners.
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> why didn’t Rabbi Yehoshua mention other distinctions between a sin offering and a guilt offering? <b>Isn’t there</b> the requirement that a priest place a sin offering’s blood on the altar with his <b>finger? Isn’t there</b> the requirement to place a sin offering’s blood on the <b>corner</b> of the altar? And even according to the opinion that it is not placed on the corner itself, <b>isn’t there</b> the requirement to place it on <b>the edge of</b> the corner? None of these requirements pertain to any offering other than a sin offering. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>mentioned one of two</b> or <b>three</b> valid <b>claims</b> at his disposal.
§ <b>The Master says: Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> Your comparison is <b>not</b> valid. <b>If you say</b> this with regard to a sin offering, whose blood is sprinkled above the red line, should you necessarily say the same with regard to a guilt offering, whose blood is sprinkled below that line? The Gemara challenges: <b>Let Rabbi Eliezer say to him: The blood of a guilt offering is also</b> sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line, since Rabbi Eliezer holds that the <i>halakhot</i> of a guilt offering and a sin offering are parallel.
<b>Abaye said: You cannot say</b> that <b>the blood of a guilt offering is</b> presented <b>above</b> the red line, due to <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a burnt offering, which is</b> treated stringently in that it is totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar, <b>its blood</b> is presented <b>below</b> the red line, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that in the case of <b>a guilt offering, which is not</b> totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar, its blood is presented below the red line?
The Gemara rejects the inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it does not atone</b> for a sin, unlike a guilt offering. Perhaps this is why its blood is presented below the red line.
The Gemara answers: <b>A bird sin offering can prove</b> the point, as it atones for a sin, and still its blood is presented below the red line.
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a bird sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it is not a type of offering</b> that is <b>slaughtered;</b> it is killed by pinching the nape of its neck. Perhaps this is why its blood is presented below the red line.
The Gemara answers: If so, <b>a burnt offering can prove</b> the point, since it is slaughtered, and its blood is still presented below the red line. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> is derived from a combination of the <i>halakhot</i> of a burnt offering and a bird sin offering: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are offerings of the most sacred order, and their blood is</b> presented <b>below</b> the red line. <b>So too, I shall include a guilt offering</b> in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it is an offering of the most sacred order, and</b> therefore <b>its blood is</b> presented <b>below</b> the red line.
<b>Rava of Parzakya said to Rav Ashi: Let</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>refute</b> this inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about the common element of</b> the two cases? It is notable <b>in that neither</b> a burnt offering nor a bird sin offering <b>has a fixed</b> value. Need <b>you say</b> that the same <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to a guilt offering, which has a fixed</b> value of two silver shekels (see Leviticus 5:15)?
<b>Rather, this is Rabbi Eliezer’s reason</b> for not claiming that the blood of a guilt offering is presented below the red line: <b>As the verse states</b> with regard to the presenting of the blood of a sin offering: <b>“The priest who offers it”</b> (Leviticus 6:19). The word “it” indicates that <b>its blood</b> is presented <b>above</b> the red line, <b>but the blood of another</b> slaughtered offering is <b>not</b> presented <b>above</b> the red line.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if Rabbi Eliezer accepts that the word “it” indicates exclusivity, <b>let him also say</b> that the verse: “And slaughter <b>it</b> for a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:33), teaches that only <b>a sin offering is fit</b> if slaughtered <b>for its sake,</b> and <b>unfit</b> if slaughtered <b>not for its sake. Consequently, other slaughtered offerings, whether</b> slaughtered <b>for their sake or not for their sake, are fit.</b> Why then does Rabbi Eliezer deem a guilt offering unfit if slaughtered not for its sake?
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> instance of the word <b>“it”</b> does <b>not</b> indicate that the <i>halakha</i> applies <b>specifically</b> to a sin offering and to no other offerings, <b>as</b> the Torah <b>excludes</b> the <b>Paschal offering</b> from such a generalization. A Paschal offering is certainly disqualified if sacrificed not for its sake.
The Gemara counters: If so, <b>here too,</b> with regard to the presenting of the blood above the red line, one must say the word “it” does <b>not</b> indicate that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>specifically</b> to a sin offering and no other offerings, <b>as</b> the Torah <b>excludes a bird burnt offering</b> from such a generalization. The blood of a bird burnt offering is presented above the red line.
The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to</b> offerings that require <b>slaughter, in any event,</b> the Torah <b>excluded nothing</b> from the generalization. Bird offerings are irrelevant, as they are killed by the pinching of the nape.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that even the blood of a bird burnt offering is presented in a manner different from that of a sin offering. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> suggestion? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says: This place</b> where the blood of a sin offering is presented is <b>discrete, and that place</b> where the blood of a bird burnt offering is presented is <b>discrete.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The blood</b> that must be placed on <b>the lower</b> half of the altar <b>is placed</b> anywhere <b>from the red [<i>hasikra</i>] line and below, and</b> the blood that must be placed on <b>the upper</b> half is placed anywhere <b>from the red line and above. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to a bird burnt offering. But</b> the placement of the blood of <b>an animal sin offering is itself performed only on the actual corner</b> of the altar.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (81b): <b>As Rabbi Akiva would say: Any blood that</b> should have been sprinkled on the external altar but instead <b>entered to atone in the Sanctuary</b> is <b>unfit. And the Rabbis say:</b> That is the <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to the blood of <b>a sin offering. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The halakhic status of <b>a guilt offering</b> is <b>also</b> like that of a sin offering, <b>as it is stated: “As is the sin offering, so is the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:7).
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> is understandable, <b>as he states the reason</b> for his opinion. <b>But what is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
<b>Rava said: You cannot say</b> that <b>the blood of a guilt offering that entered into</b> the Sanctuary is <b>disqualified,</b> due to <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering: Just as</b>

Daf 11a

with regard to <b>a burnt offering, which is</b> totally <b>consumed</b> by the fire on the altar, nevertheless, even if <b>its blood enters into</b> the Sanctuary it is <b>fit,</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, which is not</b> entirely <b>consumed</b> on the altar, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that even if its blood enters the Sanctuary it remains fit?
The Gemara refutes this inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it does not atone</b> for a sin. Perhaps this is why its blood is not disqualified if it enters the sanctuary.
The Gemara responds: <b>The meal offering of a sinner can prove</b> the point, as it is not disqualified by entering the Sanctuary, even though it atones for a sin.
The Gemara interjects: <b>But let us say</b> that <b>a bird sin offering can prove</b> the point, as it too atones for a sin but is not disqualified by entering the Sanctuary. This case is more similar to that of a guilt offering, as a bird has blood, unlike a meal offering. The Gemara answers: It is not certain that <b>a bird sin offering</b> is not disqualified by entering the Sanctuary; this <b>is a dilemma</b> raised <b>by Rabbi Avin.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But let us refute</b> the above response as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sinner’s meal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it is not a type of slaughtered offering.</b>
The Gemara answers: If so, <b>a burnt offering can prove</b> the point, since it is a slaughtered offering, and still if its blood enters the Sanctuary, it is not disqualified. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. The <i>halakha</i> is derived from the <i>halakhot</i> of a burnt offering and a sinner’s meal offering: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are offerings of the most sacred order, and</b> if they <b>enter into</b> the Sanctuary <b>they are</b> still <b>fit. So too, I shall include a guilt offering</b> and infer that <b>since it is</b> also <b>an offering of the most sacred order,</b> if <b>its blood enters into</b> the Sanctuary it is still <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rava of Barnish said to Rav Ashi: But let us refute</b> this inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that neither</b> a burnt offering nor a sinner’s meal offering <b>has a fixed</b> value. <b>Should you say</b> the same <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to a guilt offering, which has a fixed</b> value?
<b>Rather, this is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis: As the verse states:</b> “And any sin offering, any of <b>whose blood</b> is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). The term “whose blood” teaches that <b>the blood of this</b> offering, i.e., a sin offering, <b>and not the blood of another</b> offering, is disqualified in this manner.
<b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Eliezer, interpret this term? He derives from it that only <b>its blood</b> is disqualified by entering the Sanctuary, <b>but not its flesh.</b>
<b>And</b> from where do <b>the other</b> Rabbis derive that the flesh of a sin offering is not disqualified by entering the Sanctuary? They maintain that both <i>halakhot</i> are derived from this term, as the verse could have simply stated: <b>Blood,</b> but stated: <b>“Whose blood.”</b> The redundancy excludes not only the flesh, but also other offerings.
<b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Eliezer, <b>does not interpret</b> the redundancy indicated by the change from: <b>Blood,</b> to: <b>“Whose blood,”</b> to be significant. Once the word blood is mentioned, it is grammatically necessary for the verse to state “whose blood.”
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of the dispute in the mishna between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis. <b>Granted, according to the Rabbis, who say</b> that <b>a guilt offering that one slaughtered not for its sake</b> is <b>fit, that is why a meal offering is juxtaposed with a sin offering,</b> and <b>a meal offering</b> is also juxtaposed <b>with a guilt offering.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The verse states with regard to a meal offering: <b>“It is most sacred, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:10), teaching that <b>a meal offering of a sinner is like a sin offering. Therefore,</b> if one <b>removed its handful not for its sake,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> And the verse also teaches that <b>a voluntary meal offering is like a guilt offering. Therefore,</b> if one <b>removed its handful not for its sake,</b> it is still <b>fit.</b> This accords with the opinion of the Rabbis, that a guilt offering slaughtered not for its sake is fit.
<b>But according to Rabbi Eliezer, for what <i>halakha</i> is a meal offering juxtaposed with a sin offering, and a meal offering</b> juxtaposed <b>with a guilt offering?</b>
The Gemara answers: They are juxtaposed <b>to</b> teach <b>the other</b> <i>halakha</i> derived <b>by Rabbi Shimon</b> from this verse; <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Menaḥot</i> 26a): If the handful of a meal offering is conveyed to the altar <b>not in a service vessel,</b> the offering is <b>unfit. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
<b>And Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon? The verse states</b> with regard to a meal offering: <b>“It is most sacred, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering,”</b> teaching that if a priest <b>comes to perform</b> its sacrificial rites <b>by hand, he must perform</b> them <b>with</b> his <b>right</b> hand, <b>like</b> one performs the rites of <b>a sin offering.</b> And if he performs them <b>with a vessel, he may perform</b> them <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>like</b> one performs the rites of <b>a guilt offering,</b> since Rabbi Shimon maintains this is permitted in the case of a guilt offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> himself, <b>does he expound this verse for this</b> purpose, concerning one who if one removes its handful not for its sake, <b>and expound it for that</b> purpose, concerning conveying the handful with one’s hand?
The Gemara answers: <b>The verse comes mainly to</b> teach <b>that which Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> explained. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>that a meal offering of a sinner</b> whose handful was removed <b>not for its sake</b> is <b>unfit is</b> due to <b>another reason: What is the reason a sin offering</b> sacrificed not for its sake is disqualified? The reason is <b>that</b> the word <b>“it” is written with regard to it</b> in the verse: “It is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). Since the word <b>“it” is also written with regard to the meal offering of a sinner,</b> in the verse: “For it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:11), the same applies in that case.
In the mishna, Rabbi Eliezer cites the verse: “As is the sin offering, so is the guilt offering” (Leviticus 7:7), as a source for his opinion. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the Rabbis, for what <i>halakha</i> is a guilt offering juxtaposed with a sin offering?</b> The Gemara answers: They are juxtaposed <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as a sin offering requires placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>so too, a guilt offering requires placing hands</b> on the head of the offering.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Yosef ben Ḥoni says:</b> Other offerings <b>that are slaughtered</b> for the sake of a Paschal offering or a sin offering are unfit. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Yosef ben Ḥoni and Rabbi Eliezer said the same thing,</b> i.e., Rabbi Eliezer agrees with Yosef ben Ḥoni.
<b>Rabba says:</b> Although they agree that other offerings slaughtered for the sake of a Paschal offering are unfit, <b>they disagree with regard to other</b> offerings slaughtered <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b> Whereas Yosef ben Ḥoni holds that they are unfit, Rabbi Eliezer maintains that they are fit.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a Paschal offering whose</b> first <b>year has passed,</b> and it must therefore be sacrificed as a peace offering, <b>and one slaughtered it at its</b> designated <b>time</b> on Passover eve <b>for its own sake</b> as a Paschal offering, <b>and likewise,</b> if <b>one slaughtered other</b> offerings <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering at its</b> designated <b>time,</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree as to the status of the offering. <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>unfit, and Rabbi Yehoshua deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: If, during the rest of the days of the year, when</b> a Paschal offering <b>is not fit</b> if it is slaughtered <b>for its own sake,</b> nevertheless, <b>other</b> offerings that are slaughtered <b>for its sake are fit,</b> then <b>at its</b> designated <b>time, when</b> a Paschal offering <b>is fit</b> if it is slaughtered <b>for its own sake, isn’t it logical that other</b> offerings slaughtered <b>for its sake should be fit?</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: Or conversely, just as during the rest of the days of the year, when</b> a Paschal offering <b>is not fit</b> if it is slaughtered <b>for its own sake, it is fit</b> if slaughtered <b>for the sake of other</b> offerings, so too, <b>at its</b> designated <b>time, when it is fit</b> if slaughtered <b>for its own sake, isn’t it logical that it should be fit</b> if slaughtered <b>for the sake of other</b> offerings? <b>And</b> accordingly, <b>a Paschal offering</b> slaughtered <b>not for its own sake on</b> the <b>fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>should be deemed fit,</b> which contradicts the <i>halakha</i>. Clearly, this line of reasoning leads to incorrect conclusions.
Furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer refuted Rabbi Yehoshua’s logic as follows: <b>And do you say this</b> derivation? <b>What</b> does it matter <b>to me</b> that <b>other</b> offerings slaughtered <b>during the rest of the days of the year for the sake of</b> a Paschal offering <b>are deemed fit? After all,</b> a Paschal offering slaughtered <b>for the sake of other</b> offerings <b>is</b> also <b>fit. But</b> must you say that <b>other</b> offerings slaughtered <b>at its</b> designated <b>time for its sake should be deemed fit? After all,</b> at its designated time, a Paschal offering slaughtered <b>for the sake of other</b> offerings <b>is unfit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: If,</b> as you maintain, other offerings slaughtered on Passover eve for the sake of a Paschal offering are disqualified, <b>you have diminished the force</b> of the requirement that <b>a Paschal offering</b> be sacrificed for its own sake, <b>and you have given</b> more <b>force to</b> the requirement that <b>a peace offering</b> be sacrificed for its own sake. A Paschal offering sacrificed at the proper time, i.e., during the rest of the year, for the sake of a peace offering, is fit, whereas a peace offering sacrificed on Passover eve for the sake of a Paschal offering is unfit.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer then presented a different logical inference: We find</b> that <b>a leftover Paschal offering,</b> an animal consecrated as a Paschal offering but ultimately not sacrificed on Passover eve, is <b>brought</b> as <b>a peace offering; but a leftover peace offering,</b> one bought with money left over from funds dedicated toward the acquisition of a peace offering, is <b>not brought</b> as <b>a Paschal offering.</b> A Paschal offering is a potential peace offering, but a peace offering is not a potential Paschal offering.
<b>And</b> if so, one may infer <i>a fortiori</i>: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a Paschal offering, whose leftover</b> offering <b>is brought</b> as <b>a peace offering,</b> and nevertheless, if one <b>slaughtered it at its</b> designated <b>time for the sake of a peace offering</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> so too, with regard to <b>a peace offering, whose leftover</b> offering <b>is not brought</b> as <b>a Paschal offering, if</b> one <b>slaughtered</b> it <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering at its</b> designated <b>time, isn’t it logical that</b> it <b>should be unfit?</b>

Daf 11b

<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> This inference is not valid, as <b>we find</b> that <b>a leftover sin offering,</b> e.g., one bought with money left over from funds dedicated to the acquisition of a sin offering, <b>is brought</b> as <b>a burnt offering,</b> whereas <b>a leftover burnt offering is not brought</b> as <b>a sin offering.</b>
<b>And</b> according to Rabbi Eliezer’s logic, one should derive <i>a fortiori</i>: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering, whose leftover is brought</b> as <b>a burnt offering,</b> nevertheless, if one <b>slaughtered it for the sake of a burnt offering</b> it is <b>unfit,</b> so too, with regard to <b>a burnt offering, whose leftover is not brought</b> as <b>a sin offering,</b> if one <b>slaughtered it for the sake of a sin offering, isn’t it logical that it should be unfit?</b> Yet, the <i>halakha</i> is that a burnt offering slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering is fit.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: No, if you said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a sin offering,</b> that another offering sacrificed for its sake is fit, this is only <b>because</b> a sin offering <b>is fit</b> when sacrificed <b>for its sake all year long. Shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a Paschal offering, which is fit</b> when sacrificed <b>for its sake only at its</b> designated <b>time? Since</b> a Paschal offering <b>is unfit</b> when sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> during the rest of the year, <b>it is logical that other</b> offerings <b>should be disqualified</b> when sacrificed <b>for its sake</b> at its designated time.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Shimon, brother of Azarya, says</b> that this is the distinction: With regard to all offerings, if one slaughtered them for the sake of an offering whose sanctity is greater than theirs, they are fit; if one slaughtered them for the sake of an offering whose sanctity is less than theirs, they are unfit.
<b>Rav Ashi teaches in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan, and Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, teaches</b> the same statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Yannai: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Shimon, brother of Azarya?</b> It is derived from that <b>which the verse states: “And they shall not profane the holy things of the children of Israel, which they will set apart [<i>yarimu</i>] unto the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 22:15). The verse is interpreted not as a prohibition but as a halakhic axiom, teaching that offerings <b>are not profaned,</b> i.e., disqualified, <b>by</b> sacrifice for the sake of offerings whose sanctity is <b>more elevated [<i>muram</i>] than theirs; they are profaned</b> only <b>by</b> sacrifice for the sake of offerings whose sanctity is <b>less than theirs.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does that</b> verse <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>But isn’t it necessary for Shmuel’s</b> derivation? <b>As Shmuel says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who eats untithed produce is</b> liable <b>to</b> be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven? <b>As it is stated: “And they shall not profane the holy things of the children of Israel, which they will set apart unto the Lord.”</b> The term: “Will set apart,” indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of</b> holy items <b>that are to be set apart in the future,</b> i.e., untithed produce, which includes the portion designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>].
The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> if <b>the verse</b> taught only one <i>halakha</i>, the <i>halakha</i> of Shimon, brother of Azarya, it <b>should have written: Which they have set apart. What</b> is the reason the verse states: <b>“Which they will set apart,”</b> in the future tense? <b>Conclude from it</b> that the verse teaches <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i>: An offering sacrificed for the sake of an offering of greater sanctity is fit, and consumption of untithed produce is punishable by death at the hand of Heaven.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> According to Shimon, brother of Azaria, who says that less sacred offerings sacrificed for the sake of more sacred offerings are fit, perhaps they <b>are fit but do not propitiate</b> God, i.e., they do not fulfill the owner’s obligation, as the Rabbis hold. If so, <b>when</b> Shimon, brother of Azaria, <b>disagrees</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> in the mishna, <b>he disagrees</b> only <b>with regard to one</b> matter, i.e., that more sacred offerings sacrificed for the sake of less sacred ones are disqualified altogether. <b>Alternatively, perhaps</b> Shimon, brother of Azaria, holds that if less sacred offerings are sacrificed for the sake of more sacred offerings they are both <b>fit and propitiate</b> God, <b>and they disagree</b> with the Rabbis <b>about two</b> matters.
<b>Abaye, and some say Rabbi Zerika, said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof that they do not satisfy the owners’ obligation: Shimon, brother of Azarya, elaborated on his opinion in the mishna: <b>A firstborn</b> animal <b>and the</b> animal <b>tithe that one slaughtered for the sake of peace offerings are fit,</b> as the sanctity of peace offerings is greater. <b>Peace offerings that one slaughtered for the sake of a firstborn</b> animal <b>or for the sake of</b> the animal <b>tithe are unfit.</b>
<b>And if it enters your mind</b> that offerings sacrificed for the sake of offerings of greater sanctity are both <b>fit and propitiate</b> God, <b>is a firstborn</b> an offering that <b>propitiates?</b> Sacrificing a firstborn does not serve to propitiate God; <b>rather,</b> conclude that such offerings <b>are fit but do not propitiate. And</b> one can infer that <b>since</b> in <b>the latter clause they are fit but do not propitiate,</b> in <b>the former clause as well,</b> concerning all offerings of lesser sanctity slaughtered for the sake of offerings of the most sacred order, <b>they are fit but do not propitiate.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b> Perhaps Shimon, brother of Azarya, holds that offerings of lesser sanctity slaughtered for the sake of offerings of the most sacred order propitiate God, but a firstborn animal and animal tithe slaughtered for the sake of peace offerings do not propitiate God.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what is</b> the latter clause concerning a firstborn and animal tithe <b>teaching us,</b> if not that no offerings of lesser sanctity propitiate God when sacrificed for the sake of offerings of greater sanctity? How is the clause not redundant? <b>Does it teach us</b> an example of offerings of <b>higher</b> sanctity <b>and</b> offerings of <b>lower</b> sanctity? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> such an example in the former clause, which teaches: <b>How so? Offerings of the most sacred order that one slaughtered for the sake of offerings of lesser sanctity</b> are unfit; offerings of lesser sanctity slaughtered for the sake of offerings of the most sacred order are fit.
The Gemara answers: It is stated <b>lest you say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> of offerings of <b>higher</b> sanctity <b>and</b> offerings of <b>lower</b> sanctity <b>applies only</b> when the difference is between <b>offerings of the most sacred order and offerings of lesser sanctity, but</b> with regard to offerings of <b>lesser</b> sanctity <b>and</b> other offerings of <b>lesser</b> sanctity this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply, as they are all considered to possess the same level of sanctity. Therefore the mishna adds the example of a firstborn animal and animal tithe slaughtered for the sake of peace offerings, to clarify that one can distinguish between different offerings of lesser sanctity as well.
The Gemara raises an objection to this answer: <b>We</b> already <b>learn this as well,</b> in another mishna (89a): The <b>peace offering precedes</b> sacrifice of <b>the firstborn because</b> the peace offering <b>requires placement</b> of its blood twice so as to be visible on <b>four</b> sides of the altar, <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>libations, and waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh</b> by the priest and the owner, none of which is required for the firstborn.
The Gemara answers: The <b>primary</b> mention of the distinction is in <b>this</b> mishna; <b>that</b> mishna <b>cites it incidentally,</b> in discussing the order of precedence of offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the Paschal offering that one slaughtered</b> on the <b>morning of</b> the <b>fourteenth</b> of Nisan, the day when the Paschal offering should be slaughtered in the afternoon, if he did so <b>not for its sake, Rabbi Yehoshua deems it fit as though it were slaughtered on the thirteenth</b> of Nisan. An animal consecrated as a Paschal offering that was slaughtered not at its designated time for the sake of a different offering is fit for sacrifice as a peace offering. <b>Ben Beteira deems it unfit as though it were slaughtered</b> in the <b>afternoon</b> of the fourteenth.
<b>Shimon ben Azzai said: I received</b> a tradition <b>from seventy-two elders,</b> as the Sanhedrin deliberated and decided <b>on the day that they installed Rabbi Elazar</b> ben Azarya <b>at</b> the head of <b>the yeshiva</b> and ruled <b>that all the slaughtered offerings that are eaten that were slaughtered not for their sake are fit, but</b> these offerings <b>did not satisfy the obligation of the owner, except for the Paschal offering and the sin offering.</b> Based on that version, <b>ben Azzai added</b> to the <i>halakha</i> cited in the first mishna <b>only the burnt offering,</b> which is not eaten, <b>and the Rabbis</b> disagreed and <b>did not concede to him.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says: With regard to a Paschal offering that one slaughtered</b> on the <b>morning of</b> the <b>fourteenth</b> of Nisan <b>for its sake, ben Beteira would deem</b> it <b>fit, as</b> he held that <b>the entire day,</b> not only the afternoon, <b>is its</b> designated <b>time.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is the reason the mishna states that according to ben Beteira, a Paschal offering slaughtered on the morning of the fourteenth is considered <b>as though</b> it were slaughtered in the afternoon? This language seems to indicate that it does not have the same status as a Paschal offering actually slaughtered in the afternoon.
The Gemara responds: <b>Since Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> the term: <b>As though</b> it were slaughtered on the thirteenth, ben Beteira <b>also says</b> the term: <b>As though</b> it were slaughtered in the afternoon. But in fact he maintains that there is no difference between a Paschal offering slaughtered on the morning of the fourteenth and one slaughtered in the afternoon.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, rather than disagreeing</b> in the mishna <b>with regard to</b> a Paschal offering that was slaughtered on the morning of the fourteenth <b>not for its sake, let them disagree with regard to</b> one slaughtered <b>for its sake;</b> ben Beteira holds that it is fit, and Rabbi Yehoshua holds that it is unfit.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the mishna were to write only that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> a Paschal offering slaughtered <b>for its sake, I would say: But in</b> a case where it was slaughtered <b>not for its sake, Rabbi Yehoshua concedes to ben Beteira</b> that it is disqualified, even though it was slaughtered in the morning, <b>since</b> at least <b>part of</b> the day, the afternoon, is <b>fit</b> for its sacrifice as a Paschal offering. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that they disagree with regard to this case as well.
The Gemara asks: How can ben Beteira claim that a Paschal offering may be slaughtered in the morning? <b>But isn’t it written:</b> “And the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall slaughter it <b>in the afternoon [<i>bein ha’arbayim</i>]”</b> (Exodus 12:6)?
<b>Ulla, son of Rav Ilai, says:</b> Ben Beteira interprets the phrase <i>bein ha’arbayim</i> literally: <b>Between two evenings,</b> i.e., between the eve of the fourteenth and the night after the fourteenth. Accordingly, the Paschal offering may be sacrificed all day long.
The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the <b>daily offering, concerning which it is written:</b> “The one lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer <b><i>bein ha’arbayim</i>”</b> (Numbers 28:4), is <b>the entire day fit</b> for sacrifice <b>also?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There, since it is written: “The one lamb you shall offer in the morning,” by inference,</b> the term <b><i>bein ha’arbayim</i></b> is referring to the <b>actual afternoon.</b>
The Gemara counters: <b>Say</b> that <b>one</b> of the lambs should be sacrificed <b>in the morning,</b> and <b>the other</b> one can be sacrificed <b>all day.</b> Why is it evident from the requirement that one be sacrificed in the morning that the other must sacrificed in the afternoon?
The Gemara answers: The clause <b>“One</b> lamb you shall offer <b>in the morning”</b> indicates that <b>two</b> lambs are <b>not</b> sacrificed <b>in the morning;</b> the other must perforce be sacrificed in the afternoon.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the <b>lamps</b> of the Candelabrum, one should say the same, <b>as it is written:</b> “And when Aaron lights the lamps <b><i>bein ha’arbayim</i>”</b> (Exodus 30:8). Is <b>the entire day fit</b> for lighting <b>also,</b> according to the opinion of ben Beteira?
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as it is written:</b> “To burn <b>from evening to morning”</b> (Exodus 27:21). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>“from evening to morning”</b> indicates that you must <b>allocate</b> the Candelabrum <b>its measure</b> of oil so <b>that it will burn from evening until morning. Alternatively,</b> the same verse can be interpreted as follows: <b>Only this rite is valid from evening until morning,</b> since all other rites must be performed during the day. Therefore, the Candelabrum is lit only at the end of the day.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the <b>incense,</b> one should say likewise, <b>as it is written with regard to it: “<i>Bein ha’arbayim</i></b> he shall burn it” (Exodus 30:8). Is <b>the entire day also fit</b> for burning the incense according to the opinion of ben Beteira?
The Gemara answers: The <b>incense is different,</b>

Daf 12a

<b>as it is juxtaposed with</b> the lighting of the <b>lamps</b> (see Exodus 30:8). Evidently, it is burned in the afternoon as well.
The Gemara asks: Just as it is written explicitly that the Candelabrum must be lit in the evening, <b>there too,</b> with regard to a Paschal offering, <b>it is written: “There you shall sacrifice the Passover offering at evening”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:6). How can ben Beteira claim that it may be sacrificed all day long?
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes to</b> teach a different <i>halakha</i>, that a certain <b>item should be</b> sacrificed <b>after</b> another item. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the order of precedence between the Paschal offering and the daily afternoon offering: <b>An item,</b> i.e., the Paschal offering, <b>with regard to which</b> both the expressions: <b>“In the evening,” and: “<i>Bein ha’arbayim</i>,”</b> are <b>stated, should be</b> sacrificed <b>after an item,</b> the daily afternoon offering, <b>with regard to which only “<i>bein ha’arbayim</i>” is stated.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But is there anything</b> comparable to ben Beteira’s suggestion, <b>that if one slaughters it in the morning, you say</b> that <b>it is its</b> designated <b>time</b> and it is fit; <b>but when afternoon comes, you say</b> that the <b>item should be</b> sacrificed only <b>after</b> the daily afternoon offering?
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> there is a precedent; <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one did not recite the additional prayers of Shabbat, the New Moon, or a Festival, which should be recited in the morning, until it is time for the afternoon prayer, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that he should first <b>recite the afternoon prayer, and recite the additional prayers thereafter.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the term <b>“<i>bein ha’arbayim</i>”</b> is referring to the entire day, as ben Beteira maintains, <b>why do I</b> need those instances of the expression <b>that</b> are <b>written with regard to</b> burning <b>incense and</b> lighting the <b>lamps,</b> which are not performed all day?
<b>Furthermore,</b> this interpretation of the opinion of ben Beteira is difficult, as <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>responded on behalf of ben Beteira to the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> that a Paschal offering slaughtered not for its sake on the morning of the fourteenth of Nisan is fit, as though it were slaughtered on the thirteenth: <b>No, if you said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the <b>thirteenth, as no part of</b> the day is <b>fit</b> for sacrificing the Paschal offering, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the <b>fourteenth, part of which</b> is <b>fit</b> for sacrificing the Paschal offering? Since it can be sacrificed in the afternoon of the fourteenth, if it is slaughtered in the morning not for its sake, it is disqualified.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And if it is so</b> that a Paschal offering can be sacrificed throughout the day of the fourteenth, <b>all of it is fit,</b> not only part of it.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Oshaya’s interpretation of ben Beteira’s opinion is rejected. Instead, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: With regard to a Paschal offering that one slaughtered on the fourteenth in the morning, ben Beteira would deem</b> it <b>unfit, whether</b> it was slaughtered <b>for its sake or not for its sake.</b> It is unfit even if it was slaughtered not for its sake, <b>since part of</b> the day is <b>fit</b> for its sacrifice as a Paschal offering.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu ridiculed [<i>megaddef</i> ]</b> this interpretation: <b>If so, how can you find a fit Paschal offering according to ben Beteira? If</b> its owner <b>designated</b> an animal <b>now,</b> on the morning of the fourteenth, as a Paschal offering, <b>it is disqualified from the outset,</b> as it cannot be sacrificed at all, either for its sake or not for its sake. <b>And</b> even <b>if</b> its owner <b>designated it the previous day,</b> when it was fit to be sacrificed not for its sake, <b>it was fit and</b> then <b>disqualified</b> the next morning, when it was no longer fit to be sacrificed until the afternoon. Once an offering is disqualified, it can no longer become fit.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Abbahu says: Let</b> the Paschal offering <b>be</b> fit when it is designated on the fourteenth <b>after noon,</b> when it may already be sacrificed as a Paschal offering.
<b>Abaye says: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is fit if designated <b>in the morning,</b> as an offering is <b>not</b> disqualified due to the fact that it is an offering <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived if its time will arrive <b>on that same day.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is fit if designated <b>from</b> the previous <b>night,</b> as an offering that was designated at <b>night</b> and may be sacrificed the following day is <b>not</b> considered an offering <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, <b>as it is taught in the school of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> Although an animal is unfit for sacrifice until its eighth day, on the <b>night</b> before its <b>eighth</b> day it may already <b>enter the den to be tithed.</b>
<b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Appetoriki, as Rabbi Appetoriki raises a contradiction: It is written:</b> “When a bull or a sheep or a goat is born, <b>then it shall be seven days with its mother”</b> (Leviticus 22:27); <b>consequently,</b> on the following <b>night,</b> i.e., the night before the eighth day, <b>it is fit</b> for sacrifice. <b>And it is written</b> subsequently in that verse: <b>“But from the eighth day and on it may be accepted</b> for an offering made by fire unto the Lord”; <b>consequently,</b> on the previous <b>night,</b> i.e., the night before the eighth day, <b>it is not</b> yet <b>fit.</b>
<b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? At <b>night</b> it is fit <b>for consecration, and</b> the following <b>day</b> it is fit <b>for effecting acceptance,</b> i.e., for sacrifice. Apparently, an offering that may be sacrificed the following day can be consecrated the previous night, even though it may not be sacrificed at night, and it is not considered an offering whose time has not yet arrived.
§ Rabbi Abbahu presumes that an animal consecrated before it may be sacrificed is disqualified. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Abbahu: Shall we say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan holds</b> that consecrated <b>animals</b> that cannot be sacrificed at any given moment <b>are disqualified</b> from ever being sacrificed?
Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: Yes, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>an animal belonging to two partners,</b> if one of them <b>consecrated</b> the <b>half of it</b> that belongs to him, <b>and then purchased</b> the other <b>half of it</b> from his partner <b>and consecrated it, it is consecrated,</b> despite the fact that it was consecrated piecemeal. <b>But it may not be sacrificed,</b> since when he first consecrated it, the consecration did not extend to his partner’s half. Since the animal was not fit to be sacrificed then, it is disqualified permanently.
<b>But</b> as it is consecrated now, it can <b>render</b> consecrated as <b>a substitute</b> a non-sacred animal that is exchanged for it. If the owner substitutes a non-sacred animal for this one, the second animal becomes consecrated as well. <b>And</b> yet <b>its substitute is like it;</b> it too is consecrated but cannot be sacrificed.
<b>And</b> one can <b>conclude three</b> points <b>from</b> this statement: <b>Conclude from it</b> that <b>animals</b> that cannot be sacrificed <b>are</b> permanently <b>disqualified; and conclude from it</b> that <b>disqualification from the outset,</b> i.e., from the time the offering is consecrated, <b>is</b> permanent <b>disqualification; and conclude from it</b> that

Daf 12b

<b>there is</b> permanent <b>disqualification</b> even <b>in</b> a case where the animal possesses sanctity that inheres in its <b>monetary</b> value, rather than inherent sanctity.
§ <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat and designated an offering</b> to atone for the transgression, <b>and</b> then <b>apostatized,</b> thereby disqualifying himself from bringing an offering, <b>and</b> later <b>recanted</b> his apostasy, <b>since</b> the offering was already <b>disqualified, it shall be disqualified</b> permanently.
<b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat and designated an offering</b> to atone for his transgression, <b>and</b> then <b>became an imbecile,</b> who is unfit to bring an offering, <b>and</b> then <b>again became</b> halakhically <b>competent, since</b> the offering was already <b>disqualified, it shall be disqualified</b> permanently.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> both statements <b>are necessary. As, if</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>had taught us</b> only <b>the first</b> statement, concerning an apostate, one might have reasoned that the offering is permanently disqualified <b>because he disqualified himself by</b> his own <b>action, but here,</b> in the case of one who became an imbecile, <b>where he was disqualified</b> through a process that occurs <b>by itself,</b> when he becomes competent again he may bring his sacrifice, as it is <b>considered as</b> though he were <b>asleep.</b> If one designated an offering and fell asleep, this certainly does not disqualify it.
<b>And if</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>had taught us</b> only the statement <b>here,</b> with regard to one who became an imbecile, one might have reasoned that the offering is permanently disqualified <b>because it is not in his power to return</b> to competence, <b>but here,</b> in the case of an apostate, <b>since it is in his power to recant</b> his apostasy, <b>I would say</b> that the offering is <b>not</b> permanently disqualified. Therefore, both statements are <b>necessary.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat and designated an offering</b> for the transgression, <b>and</b> then the <b>court ruled that</b> the type of <b>fat</b> he ate is <b>permitted,</b> thereby rendering the offering unnecessary, <b>and</b> the court subsequently <b>retracted</b> its ruling, in this case, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is</b> the offering permanently <b>disqualified, or is it not</b> permanently <b>disqualified?</b>
<b>A certain elder [<i>hahu sava</i>] said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>When Rabbi Yoḥanan introduced</b> the topic of permanently <b>disqualified</b> offerings, <b>he introduced</b> it <b>with this</b> case. <b>What is the reason? There,</b> in the case of one who apostatized or became an imbecile, although <b>the person was disqualified,</b> the <b>offering</b> itself <b>was not disqualified.</b> Consequently, it is less evident that the offering will be disqualified permanently. But <b>here,</b> in a case where the court ruled that the fat is permitted, the <b>offering</b> itself <b>was also disqualified,</b> as it was rendered unnecessary. Therefore, this is a more obvious example.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Shimon ben Azzai said: I received</b> a tradition <b>from seventy-two elders [<i>zaken</i>]</b> that all slaughtered offerings that are eaten, if slaughtered not for their sake, are fit. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need to <b>teach</b> the phrase <b>seventy-two</b> elders using the singular form: <b><i>Zaken</i>,</b> rather than the plural form: <i>Zekenim</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Because they all maintained one opinion,</b> i.e., they all agreed with this <i>halakha</i>.
The mishna continues: <b>Ben Azzai added only the burnt offering</b> to the sin offering and the Paschal offering, which are mentioned in the first mishna as disqualified when sacrificed not for their sake.
<b>Rav Huna said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of ben Azzai?</b> The verse states: <b>“It is a burnt offering, an offering made by fire, of a pleasing aroma unto the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 1:13). The word <b>“it”</b> teaches that if it is sacrificed <b>for its sake,</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if sacrificed <b>not for its sake,</b> it is <b>unfit.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t the word <b>“it” written with regard to a guilt offering as well,</b> in the verse: “It is a guilt offering” (Leviticus 7:5)? Nevertheless, a guilt offering sacrificed not for its sake is not disqualified.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is written after the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar. Since the offering is fit even if these portions are not burned at all, it is certainly fit if they are burned not for the sake of a guilt offering.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t <b>this</b> mention of the word “it” with regard to a burnt offering <b>also written after the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar?
The Gemara answers: The word <b>“it” is written</b> with regard to a burnt offering in <b>two</b> places, both in Leviticus 1:13 and in Exodus 29:18. Although both are written after the burning of the portions consumed on the altar, one of them is superfluous, and is therefore interpreted in reference to the main sacrificial rites, performed before the burning of the portions. The verse therefore teaches that the offering is fit only if these rites are performed for its sake.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to a guilt offering as well,</b> isn’t the word <b>“it” written</b> in <b>two</b> places, Leviticus 5:9 and Leviticus 7:5?
<b>Rather, ben Azzai derives</b> his <i>halakha</i> not from a verse, but <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering, which is not</b> totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar but partially eaten by priests, if <b>one slaughtered it not for its sake</b> it is <b>disqualified,</b> so too, with regard to <b>a burnt offering, which is</b> treated more strictly in that it is totally <b>consumed</b> on the altar, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that if it is slaughtered not for its sake it is disqualified?
The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones</b> for sin, in contrast to a burnt offering, which is not brought for atonement. Therefore, only a sin offering is disqualified when sacrificed not for its sake.
The Gemara suggests: <b>A Paschal offering can prove</b> the point, as it is not brought for atonement, yet it is disqualified if sacrificed not for its sake.
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a Paschal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that its time is set</b> at Passover eve, in contrast to a burnt offering, which does not have a designated time.
The Gemara suggests: If so, <b>a sin offering can prove</b> the point, since it has no set time. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. The <i>halakha</i> is derived from the common element of the two sources: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are offerings, and</b> if one <b>slaughtered them not for their sake,</b> they are <b>disqualified. So too, I shall include a burnt offering</b> in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it is an offering, and</b> therefore if one <b>slaughtered it not for its sake,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable in <b>that they</b> both <b>have an element of <i>karet</i>.</b> A sin offering is brought for a transgression punishable by <i>karet</i> when committed intentionally, and one who refrains intentionally from bringing a Paschal offering is liable to be punished with <i>karet</i>. A burnt offering does not have an element of <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>Ben Azzai</b>

Daf 13a

<b>does not refute</b> the inference by citing a common <b>element of <i>karet</i>,</b> as the elements of <i>karet</i> in a sin offering and in a Paschal offering are not parallel.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let it be derived</b> from this inference that <b>a guilt offering</b> is <b>also</b> disqualified if sacrificed not for its sake.
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>a guilt offering,</b> ben Azzai <b>refutes</b> the inference as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about the common element of</b> a sin offering and a Paschal offering? It is notable <b>in that there are communal</b> offerings <b>as well as individual</b> offerings of these types, as well as communal burnt offerings, whereas there is no communal guilt offering.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that actually, ben Azzai <b>also refutes</b> the entire inference, because a sin offering and a Paschal offering uniquely share <b>an element of <i>karet</i>. And</b> the reason <b>ben Azzai</b> maintains that a burnt offering sacrificed not for its sake is disqualified is that <b>he learned it</b> as <b>a tradition. And</b> as for the fact <b>that Rav Huna cites an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, he does not believe it to be the true source for ben Azzai’s <i>halakha</i>; <b>he said it only to sharpen</b> the minds of <b>his students with it,</b> challenging them to refute it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the Paschal offering and the sin offering, where one slaughtered them not for their sake,</b> or where he <b>collected</b> their blood in a vessel, <b>conveyed</b> this blood to the altar, <b>or sprinkled</b> this blood on the altar <b>not for their sake, or</b> where he performed one of these sacrificial rites <b>for their sake and not for their sake, or not for their sake and for their sake,</b> in all these cases the offerings <b>are unfit.</b>
<b>How</b> are these rites performed <b>for their sake and not for their sake?</b> In a case where one slaughtered the Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a Paschal offering and for the sake of a peace offering.</b> How are these rites performed <b>not for their sake and for their sake?</b> In a case where one slaughtered the Paschal offering <b>for the sake of a peace offering and for the sake of a Paschal offering.</b>
The offering is unfit <b>because a slaughtered offering is disqualified</b> due to prohibited intent <b>in four matters: In</b> the performance of the sacrificial rites of <b>slaughtering</b> the animal, <b>in collecting</b> the blood, <b>in conveying</b> the blood, <b>and in sprinkling</b> the blood.
<b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the offering <b>fit</b> if the prohibited intent was <b>during</b> the rite of <b>conveying</b> the blood, <b>as he would say: It is impossible</b> to sacrifice an offering <b>without slaughtering</b> the animal, <b>or without collection</b> of the blood, <b>or without sprinkling</b> the blood, <b>but it is possible</b> to sacrifice an offering <b>without conveying</b> the blood to the altar. How so? If one <b>slaughters</b> the animal <b>alongside the altar and sprinkles</b> the blood, the blood does not need to be conveyed. Therefore, the rite of conveying the blood is not significant enough to cause the offering to be disqualified due to prohibited intent while performing it.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>one who conveys</b> the blood <b>in a situation where he is required to convey</b> it, prohibited <b>intent</b> while conveying it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. If he conveys the blood <b>in a situation where he is not required to convey</b> it, prohibited <b>intent</b> while conveying it <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a slaughtered offering is disqualified due to prohibited intent while performing four rites, including collection of the blood. The Gemara asks: <b>And does collection</b> of the blood with prohibited intent <b>disqualify</b> the offering?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And</b> the sons of Aaron, the priests, <b>shall present</b> the blood” (Leviticus 1:5); <b>this</b> is referring to <b>collection of the blood. Do you say</b> it is referring to <b>collection of the blood, or is it</b> referring to <b>only sprinkling</b> the blood? <b>When it states</b> immediately afterward: <b>“And sprinkle</b> the blood roundabout against the altar,” <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>is thereby stated.</b> If so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of: <b>“And</b> the sons of Aaron, the priests, <b>shall present”? This</b> is referring to <b>collection of the blood.</b> And the phrase <b>“the sons of Aaron, the priests”</b> teaches <b>that</b> collection of the blood <b>must be</b> performed <b>by a fit priest,</b> i.e., one who has no blemish and who was not disqualified due to flawed lineage, <b>and</b> that he must do so while he is wearing priestly <b>service vestments.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Akiva said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that collection</b> of the blood <b>may be</b> performed <b>only by a fit priest and</b> while he is wearing <b>service vestments?</b> The expression <b>“the sons of Aaron” is stated here</b> in the verse in Leviticus, <b>and it is stated there: “These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the priests that were anointed,</b> whom he consecrated to minister in the priest’s office” (Numbers 3:3). <b>Just as there,</b> in the verse in Numbers, it mentions the word “priests” <b>with regard to fit priests,</b> i.e., Aaron’s sons, <b>and with regard to</b> priests who were consecrated to serve by being dressed with <b>service vestments</b> (see Exodus 29:30), <b>so too here,</b> the reference is <b>to a fit priest and with regard to</b> one who is wearing <b>service vestments.</b>
<b>Rabbi Tarfon said: I will bury my sons if I did not hear</b> a <i>halakha</i> from my teachers <b>discerning a distinction between collection</b> of <b>and sprinkling</b> the blood, <b>but I cannot explicate</b> the distinction, as I do not remember what it was.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Akiva said: I will explicate:</b> With regard to <b>collection,</b> the Torah <b>does not render intent like action.</b> Collecting the blood with prohibited intent does not disqualify the offering. But with regard to <b>sprinkling,</b> the Torah <b>does render intent like action.</b> Furthermore, if one <b>collected</b> the blood <b>outside</b> the Temple, <b>he is not liable</b> to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>.</b> But if one <b>sprinkled</b> the blood <b>outside</b> the Temple, <b>he is punished</b> with <b><i>karet</i>.</b> Moreover, if those who are <b>unfit</b> for the Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood, <b>they are not liable for</b> that action. But if those who are <b>unfit</b> for the Temple service <b>sprinkled</b> the blood, <b>they are liable</b> to receive the penalty of death at the hand of Heaven <b>for that</b> action.
<b>Rabbi Tarfon said to him</b> excitedly: I take an oath by <b>the</b> Temple <b>service</b> that <b>you have</b> not <b>deviated left or right</b> from what I heard from my teachers. <b>I</b> myself <b>heard</b> them <b>and I cannot explicate</b> what they taught, whereas <b>you teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> on your own <b>in concurrence with the <i>halakha</i></b> I heard. <b>He said to</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>using this language: Akiva, anyone who leaves you is like one who leaves his life.</b> In any event, Rabbi Akiva’s statement in the <i>baraita</i> apparently contradicts the mishna with regard to the matter of whether the collection of the blood with prohibited intent disqualifies the offering.
<b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>not difficult.</b> The <i>baraita</i> <b>here</b> is referring <b>to intent of <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., intent to consume or burn the offering after its appointed time. The mishna <b>there</b> is referring <b>to intent not for the sake of</b> the offering.
The Gemara adds: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches that a slaughtered offering is disqualified</b> in this manner, <b>and it does not teach</b> that an offering <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i></b> in this manner. Apparently, the mishna is referring to intent that merely disqualifies the offering without rendering it <i>piggul</i>, one who partakes of which is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from</b> the mishna’s language that this interpretation is correct.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does intent of <i>piggul</i> during</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>not disqualify</b> the offering?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>intent</b> to consume an offering after its designated time <b>is effective</b> to render the offering <i>piggul</i> <b>only</b> when one has that intent <b>during sprinkling. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include slaughter and collection</b> of the blood in this <i>halakha</i>? <b>The verse states: “And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings is at all eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted,</b> neither shall it be imputed to the one who offers it; it shall be an abhorred thing [<i>piggul</i> ]” (Leviticus 7:18). As derived on 29a, the verse is referring to performance of the sacrificial rites with intent to consume the offering after its designated time. The phrase “is at all eaten” teaches that <b>the verse speaks of matters that lead to consumption,</b> i.e., those sacrificial rites that enable consumption of the offering, including slaughter of the animal and collecting the blood.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even</b> the <b>pouring of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar, after its sprinkling, <b>and</b> the <b>burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “On the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be imputed to the one who offers it”</b> (Leviticus 7:18). The phrase “the one who offers it” indicates the sprinkling of the blood. <b>Sprinkling was included</b> in the general category of rites that enable consumption. <b>And for what</b> purpose <b>was it singled out? To compare</b> other <i>halakhot</i> <b>to it,</b> i.e., <b>to say to you: Just as sprinkling is unique, as it is a rite and</b> if not performed <b>it prevents atonement, so too, any rite</b> that <b>prevents atonement</b> if not performed is included in the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i>. <b>Pouring</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood <b>and burning</b> the <b>sacrificial portions are</b> therefore <b>excluded, as they do not prevent atonement</b> if not performed. Evidently, intent of <i>piggul</i> applies to the collection of the blood, contrary to Rava’s resolution of the contradiction between the mishna and the <i>baraita</i>.

Daf 13b

The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement of Rava, that intent of <i>piggul</i> does not apply to collection, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the one slaughtering the offering <b>says: I am hereby slaughtering</b> this offering <b>in order to collect its blood tomorrow.</b> Because the collection of the blood is not considered consumption, such intent does not render the offering <i>piggul</i>. <b>That</b> statement of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the one collecting the blood <b>says: I am hereby collecting its blood in order to pour</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar <b>tomorrow.</b> Since pouring the remains is considered consumption of the blood on the altar, such intent renders the offering <i>piggul</i>.
<b>One of the Sages said to Rava: And does</b> prohibited <b>intent with regard to</b> the <b>pouring of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood <b>and</b> the <b>burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions not disqualify</b> the offering, as this explanation of the <i>baraita</i> seems to indicate?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>only</b> prohibited <b>intent with regard to consumption of the meat is effective</b> to render the offering <i>piggul</i>. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> the <b>pouring of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood <b>and</b> the <b>burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions? The verse states: “And if</b> any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings <b>is at all eaten [<i>he’akhol ye’akhel</i> ]</b> on the third day, it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 7:18). It is derived from the repeated verb that <b>the verse speaks of two</b> types of <b>consumption: One is consumption</b> of the meat <b>by man,</b> i.e., by the priests or the owner of the offering, <b>and</b> the other <b>one is consumption</b> of the blood and the sacrificial portions <b>on the altar.</b>
The Gemara answers: It is <b>not difficult.
