This</b> case, where intent renders the offering <i>piggul</i>, is <b>where</b> the one sprinkling the blood <b>says: I am hereby sprinkling</b> the blood <b>in order to pour</b> the <b>remainder tomorrow.</b> Since sprinkling the blood is necessary for atonement, if it is performed with the intent that consumption occur beyond its designated time, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>. <b>That</b> case, where intent does not render the offering <i>piggul</i>, is <b>where he says: I am hereby pouring</b> the <b>remainder in order to burn</b> the <b>sacrificial portions tomorrow.</b> Although burning the portions is considered consumption, pouring the remainder of the blood is not indispensable for atonement, and therefore the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
§ <b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: I heard that with regard to an inner sin offering,</b> whose blood is sprinkled on the curtain separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies, <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood in order to sprinkle it, if he does so with the intent of burning the offering on the altar the following day, <b>renders</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>Ilfa heard</b> this statement and <b>said it before Rav Padda.</b> Rav Padda <b>said</b> in response: <b>Did we derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i></b> with regard to all offerings <b>from anything but a peace offering?</b> The source for the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> is the verse stated with regard to peace offerings (Leviticus 7:18). Therefore, <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>a peace offering,</b> prohibited intent while <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood to sprinkle it on the altar <b>does not render it <i>piggul</i>,</b> as there is no requirement to sprinkle the blood of a peace offering with one’s finger rather than the containing vessel, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> prohibited intent while <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood <b>does not render it <i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But are all</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>piggul</i> <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a peace offering? If</b> that is so, then <b>just as</b> sacrifice of <b>a peace offering not for its sake does not preclude</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> as it is still fit, <b>so too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be that sacrifice of <b>a sin offering not for its sake does not preclude</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> In fact, the <i>halakha</i> is that a sin offering sacrificed not for its sake cannot become <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rather, what have you to say</b> to explain this <i>halakha</i>? You must say that it is <b>derived from an amplification of the verse. Here too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that prohibited intent while dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering renders it <i>piggul</i> is <b>derived from an amplification of the verse.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: I heard in this upper story that</b> prohibited intent while <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood of an inner sin offering <b>renders</b> it <b><i>piggul</i>. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish wondered [<i>tahei</i>] at this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>Did</b> the Sages <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i> from anything but a peace offering? Just as</b> with regard to <b>a peace offering,</b> prohibited intent while <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood <b>does not render it <i>piggul</i>, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be that prohibited intent while <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood <b>does not render it <i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>But are all</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>piggul</i> <b>derived from</b> those of <b>a peace offering? If</b> so, <b>just as</b> sacrifice of <b>a peace offering not for its sake does not preclude</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, so too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be that sacrifice of <b>a sin offering not for its sake does not preclude</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Indeed, all</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>piggul</i>, even this one, <b>are derived from a peace offering. Since in</b> the case of <b>a peace offering,</b> intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area disqualifies</b> it, <b>and in</b> the case of <b>a sin offering,</b> sacrifice <b>not for its sake disqualifies</b> it, one can infer that <b>just as</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, which disqualifies a peace offering, precludes</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, so too,</b> sacrifice <b>not for its sake, which disqualifies a sin offering, precludes its</b> being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> By contrast, dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering with intent to consume it after its designated time does not render it <i>piggul</i>, as there is no parallel <i>halakha</i> with regard to a peace offering.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> This inference is <b>inherently disjointed: What</b> is notable <b>about</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, which disqualifies a peace offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> its disqualification <b>applies to all slaughtered offerings.</b> This is why it precludes the offering from becoming <i>piggul</i>. Need <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to</b> disqualification by sacrifice <b>not for its sake, which applies only to a Paschal offering and a sin offering?</b>
<b>Rather, what have you to say</b> to explain this derivation? One must say that it is not based on a case-to-case comparison, but on a principle that is derived from a peace offering, namely: Any <b>matter that disqualifies</b> a peace offering, e.g., intent to consume it outside its designated area, <b>precludes its</b> being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> and any <b>matter that prevents</b> atonement if not performed <b>renders</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> if performed with intent to consume it beyond its designated time.
One infers therefore that <b>here too,</b> with regard to an inner sin offering, any <b>matter that disqualifies it,</b> e.g., sacrifice not for its sake, <b>precludes</b> its being rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> and any <b>matter that prevents</b> atonement if not performed <b>renders it <i>piggul</i></b> if it is performed with intent to consume it beyond its designated time. Accordingly, dipping one’s finger in the blood with intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time renders it <i>piggul</i>, as this rite is indispensable.
<b>Rav Mari says: We learn</b> in a mishna <b>as well</b> that dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering with intent to consume it beyond its designated time renders the offering <i>piggul</i> (<i>Menaḥot</i> 12a): <b>This is the principle:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who removes a handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>or</b> who <b>places</b> the handful <b>in a vessel, or who conveys</b> the handful to the altar, <b>or who burns</b> it on the altar, if he does so with intent that the offering will be consumed after its designated time the offering is <i>piggul</i>.
Since the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>piggul</i> are derived from those of a peace offering, one can ask: <b>Granted,</b> the one who <b>removes</b> a handful of a meal offering can render the offering <i>piggul</i>, as he <b>is</b> considered equivalent to the one who <b>slaughters</b> a peace offering. Just as the blood is the essential part of an animal offering, and it is removed by slaughter, so too, the handful of a meal offering is its essential part. Likewise, the one who <b>conveys</b> the handful <b>is</b> equivalent to the one who <b>conveys</b> the blood of a peace offering, and the one who <b>burns</b> the handful <b>is</b> equivalent to the one who <b>sprinkles</b> the blood <b>too. But</b> to <b>what is</b> the one who <b>places</b> the handful <b>in a vessel</b> equivalent? From where is it derived that he, too, can render the offering <i>piggul</i>?
<b>If we say that</b> placing the handful in a vessel is <b>comparable to collection</b> of the blood, as both rites involve placing the essential part of the offering in a vessel, one may respond: <b>Are</b> these rites actually <b>comparable? There,</b> in the case of a peace offering, the collection of the blood is performed passively. The blood spills into the vessel <b>by itself. Here,</b> in the case of a meal offering, the priest <b>takes</b> the handful himself <b>and places</b> it in a vessel. Clearly, placing the handful in a vessel is not equivalent to any specific rite in the sacrifice of a peace offering.
<b>Rather, since it is not sufficient</b> for the handful to be sacrificed <b>without</b> first <b>placing</b> it in a service vessel, <b>it is, perforce, an important rite.</b> One who performs it can therefore render the offering <i>piggul</i> like those who perform other essential rites. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering, although it has no equivalent in the sacrifice of a peace offering, <b>since it is not sufficient</b> if the priest <b>does not perform it, it is perforce</b> considered part of the <b>conveying</b> of the blood, and the priest can render the offering <i>piggul</i> while performing it.
The Gemara responds: <b>No, actually,</b> placing the handful in a vessel is <b>comparable to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood. <b>And</b> despite the distinction <b>that you say,</b> namely, that <b>here,</b> in the case of a peace offering, the blood spills <b>by itself,</b> while <b>there,</b> in the case of a meal offering, the priest <b>takes</b> the handful himself <b>and places</b> it in the vessel, nevertheless, <b>since</b> both <b>this</b> rite <b>and that</b> rite involve <b>placement</b> of the essential part of the offering in <b>a vessel,</b> they are equivalent. <b>What</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the blood spills into the vessel <b>by itself,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the priest <b>takes</b> the handful himself <b>and places</b> it in the vessel? By contrast, dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering has no equivalent in a peace offering. Therefore, <i>piggul</i> does not apply to it.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the principle that dipping one’s finger in the blood is considered part of conveying it to the curtain is <b>the subject of</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to</b> an inner <b>sin offering, dipping</b> one’s <b>finger</b> in the blood with intent that it be consumed beyond its designated time <b>renders it <i>piggul</i>. And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: Dipping one’s finger in the blood with intent that it be consumed beyond its designated time <b>does not render</b> it <b><i>piggul</i>, and neither does</b> slaughtering the animal with the intent to dip his finger in the blood the next day <b>render</b> it <b><i>piggul</i>. What, is it not</b> that this matter <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> both <i>tanna’im</i> agree that dipping one’s finger in the blood of an inner sin offering is part of conveying it to the curtain. Rather, <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that a priest can render the offering <i>piggul</i> while dipping his finger in its blood, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> in the mishna (13a), who hold that one can render the offering <i>piggul</i> while conveying the blood to the altar. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states the opposite, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> in the mishna, who holds that one cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i> while conveying the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the latter <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, why</b> is it referring <b>specifically</b> to <b>dipping</b> one’s <b>finger? Doesn’t he say</b>

Daf 14a

that <b>any</b> offering <b>whose</b> blood <b>is not</b> sprinkled <b>on the external altar like a peace offering is not subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>piggul</i>?</b> If so, <i>piggul</i> does not apply to inner sin offerings at all.
<b>Rather,</b> both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis; and</b> the apparent contradiction between them is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that maintains that one cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i> while dipping his finger in the blood is referring <b>to the external sin offerings,</b> since dipping one’s finger in order to sprinkle the blood on the external altar is not considered an essential rite. <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that maintains that one can render the offering <i>piggul</i> while performing this rite is referring <b>to the inner sin offerings.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that one cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i> while dipping his finger in the blood of <b>the external sin offerings?</b> The statement: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger in the blood” (Leviticus 4:6), <b>is not written with regard to</b> these offerings. Since it is clearly not an essential rite, why was it necessary for the <i>baraita</i> to teach that improper intent while performing it cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i>?
The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to teach this, as otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since it is written</b> with regard to an external sin offering: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take</b> of the blood of the sin offering with his finger” (Leviticus 4:34), <b>and</b> therefore <b>if a monkey comes</b> and <b>places</b> blood <b>on the hand of</b> the priest the priest <b>must take</b> blood from the vessel <b>again</b> to perform the mitzva as stated in the verse, <b>it is considered as though</b> the statement: <b>And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger in the blood, <b>is written</b> with regard to an external sin offering as well.
Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that dipping one’s finger in the blood of an external sin offering is an inessential rite and one cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i> while performing it. As it is <b>for this</b> reason that the phrase: <b>And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger in the blood, <b>is not written</b> with regard to this offering, but rather: And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, <b>which indicates this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that the priest must actively take the blood in his hand, <b>and</b> also <b>indicates that</b> <i>halakha</i>, that dipping one’s finger in the blood is not an essential rite and cannot render the offering <i>piggul</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the offering <b>fit</b> if the prohibited intent was <b>during</b> the rite of <b>conveying</b> the blood to the altar. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Rabbi Shimon concedes that</b> prohibited <b>intent during the conveying of</b> the blood of <b>the inner sin offerings disqualifies them, since</b> with regard to those offerings, it is <b>an indispensable rite.</b> Because the blood must be sprinkled inside the Sanctuary and the offering cannot be slaughtered inside the Sanctuary, conveying the blood into the Sanctuary is always necessary for such offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon say</b> that with regard to <b>any</b> offering <b>whose</b> blood <b>is not</b> sprinkled <b>on the external altar like a peace offering, one is not liable</b> to be punished with <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it, due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>?</b> In other words, the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> does not apply to inner sin offerings at all.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says:</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>concedes</b> that although intent to consume an inner sin offering after its designated time does not render it <i>piggul</i>, it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, <b>due to an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> sacrifice <b>not for its sake, which is valid in</b> the case of <b>a peace offering,</b> is nevertheless <b>not valid in</b> the case of <b>a sin offering,</b> as stated in the mishna (2a), so too, <b>isn’t it logical that</b> sacrifice with intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, which disqualifies peace offerings, should disqualify sin offerings?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And we found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that intent to consume an inner sin offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time</b> disqualifies it according to Rabbi Shimon. <b>From where do we</b> derive that intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> also disqualifies it?
<b>If</b> we derive it <b>from</b> the case of intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> one may respond: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it can render an offering <i>piggul</i>, for partaking of which one is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>If</b> we derive it <b>from</b> the case of intent <b>not for its sake,</b> one may respond: What is notable about sacrifice not for its sake? It is notable <b>in that</b> this disqualification <b>applies</b> even <b>to</b> sacrifice on a private <b>altar</b> during the era when such altars were permitted. By contrast, intent to consume the offering outside its designated area is irrelevant to sacrifice on a private altar, which has no designated area.
The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to what</b> offering <b>does</b> disqualification due to intent <b>not for its sake apply?</b> It applies <b>to a Paschal offering and a sin offering.</b> Since <b>a Paschal offering and a sin offering may not be sacrificed on</b> a private <b>altar,</b> this factor is irrelevant. One may therefore derive from the case of intent not for its sake that intent to consume the offering outside its designated area disqualifies it.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>it is</b> derived from the <b>juxtaposition</b> of the <i>halakha</i> of intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time with the <i>halakha</i> of intent to consume it outside its designated area. The verse states: “And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings is at all eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be imputed to the one who offers it; it shall be an abhorred thing [<i>piggul</i>]” (Leviticus 7:18). <b>This</b> statement: “On the <b>third</b> day, it shall not be accepted,” is referring to intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time;</b> and <b>this</b> seemingly superfluous statement: “Neither shall it be imputed to the one who offers it; it shall be <b><i>piggul</i>,”</b> is referring to intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b> Such juxtaposition indicates that there are parallel <i>halakhot</i> in the two cases even if they are dissimilar.
§ <b>Rava says: If you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>his son</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>who says</b> that the area <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar</b> is considered part of the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard, the only place where a sin offering may be slaughtered, he must also hold that prohibited <b>intent while conveying</b> the blood of <b>the inner sin offerings is effective</b> to disqualify them <b>only from the doorway of the Entrance Hall inward.</b> Prohibited intent before the priest reaches the doorway of the Entrance Hall does not disqualify the offering, as conveying the blood to the doorway is not necessary; the offering could have been slaughtered at the doorway in the first place.
<b>And if you say</b> that Rabbi Shimon <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that the <b>interior of the Temple courtyard sanctifies</b> offerings, i.e., that offerings can be sacrificed on the courtyard floor as if it were part of the altar, prohibited <b>intent while conveying</b> the <b>removed bowls</b> of frankincense from the table in the Sanctuary to burn them on the external altar <b>is effective</b> to disqualify them <b>only</b> while <b>conveying</b> them <b>from the doorway of the Sanctuary outward</b> to the Entrance Hall. Since the table can be placed anywhere in the Sanctuary, conveying the bowls of frankincense in the Sanctuary itself is unnecessary, and once the priest exits the Entrance Hall to the Temple courtyard, the frankincense could theoretically be burned immediately.
Rava continues: <b>And if you say</b> that Rabbi Shimon also <b>holds</b> that <b>the sanctity of the Sanctuary and the Entrance Hall are one</b> and the same, and the table can be placed in the Entrance Hall as well, prohibited <b>intent is effective only</b> while conveying the frankincense <b>from the doorway of the Entrance Hall outward,</b> i.e., in the doorway of the Entrance Hall itself.
<b>And if you say</b> that he also <b>holds</b> that <b>inside the doorway is</b> considered <b>like inside</b> the Entrance Hall, then the table can be placed in the doorway too, and prohibited <b>intent is not effective</b> while conveying the frankincense <b>even one step. Rather,</b> it is effective only during the moment when the frankincense is taken out of the doorway to the courtyard, the time it takes the priest <b>to stretch out his hand</b> to place the bowls on the courtyard floor.
<b>And if you say</b> that he also <b>holds</b> that <b>conveying</b> an offering <b>not by foot is not considered conveying,</b> prohibited <b>intent is not effective at all</b> while conveying the bowls of frankincense.
§ <b>Abaye said to Rav Ḥisda’s interpreter: Ask Rav Ḥisda</b> for me: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a non-priest conveying</b> the blood? Is the offering disqualified, as in a case where a non-priest performs any other sacrificial rite that may performed only by priests?
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him:</b> The offering remains <b>fit, and a verse supports my</b> ruling: <b>“And they slaughtered the Paschal offering, and the priests sprinkled the blood, which they received of their hand, and the Levites flayed them”</b> (II Chronicles 35:11). Apparently, priests are required only for the sprinkling of the blood on the altar and later rites. Just as slaughter may be performed by non-priests, so can the collection and conveying of the blood be performed by them.
<b>Rav Sheshet raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a non-priest, or an acute mourner,</b>

Daf 14b

<b>a drunk</b> priest, <b>or a blemished</b> priest performs the rites of <b>collection, conveying</b> or <b>sprinkling</b> the blood, the offering is <b>disqualified. And likewise,</b> it is disqualified if a priest performs any of these rites while <b>sitting. And</b> this is <b>likewise</b> the <i>halakha</i> if a priest performs any of these rites with his <b>left</b> hand. The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rav Ḥisda’s ruling; if a non-priest conveys the blood, it is disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥisda state a verse</b> as proof that the offering is not disqualified? The verse states that the priests sprinkled the blood after receiving it from non-priests.
The Gemara answers: The verse described a case <b>where</b> the non-priests <b>served as a bench [<i>itztaba</i>].</b> The priests would give the blood to the non-priests to hold it for them and would then take it and sprinkle the blood. The non-priests would not convey the blood to the altar.
<b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both say</b> that the case of <b>a non-priest conveying</b> the blood is subject to <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis.</b> According to <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that <b>a dispensable rite is not</b> classified as a true <b>rite</b> and therefore does not disqualify the offering if performed with prohibited intent, the offering is <b>fit</b> even if the conveying of the blood is performed <b>by a non-priest. According to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that a dispensable rite is classified as a true rite, the conveying of the blood is <b>not valid</b> if performed by a non-priest.
<b>Abaye said to him: But</b> what about <b>slaughter, which is an indispensable rite, and</b> yet the offering is <b>fit</b> even if it is performed <b>by a non-priest? He said to</b> Abaye: <b>Slaughter,</b> though indispensable, <b>is not</b> classified as a sacrificial <b>rite</b> at all. Therefore it need not be performed by a priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is it not? But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If the <b>slaughter of</b> a red <b>heifer</b> is performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> it is <b>not valid? And Rav said about this</b> <i>halakha</i>: It is derived from the phrases: <b>“Elazar</b> the priest” (Numbers 19:3), <b>and: “Statute”</b> (Numbers 19:2), which <b>are written with regard to</b> the red heifer. The mention of Elazar indicates that slaughter must be performed by a priest, and the term “statute” indicates that one may not deviate from any of the details of the service as delineated in the verses. If one does, the heifer is disqualified.
The Gemara answers: The red <b>heifer is different, as it is</b> not an offering; it has the sanctity of items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> that govern its service therefore differ from those of offerings proper.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>this not</b> prove the point <b>all the more?</b> If slaughtering an animal <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance is</b> tantamount to a sacrificial <b>rite,</b> can slaughtering <b>offerings,</b> which are sacrificed on the <b>altar, not be</b> considered a sacrificial <b>rite?</b>
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The slaughter of a red heifer is considered <b>just as it is in</b> the case of <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks, which</b> are deemed ritually pure or impure by a priest. Although this is <b>not</b> a sacrificial <b>rite,</b> it still <b>requires</b> a member of the <b>priesthood</b> to perform it. Therefore, the requirement that the red heifer be slaughtered by a priest does not prove that it is classified as a sacrificial rite.
The Gemara further challenges the premise of Rabba and Rav Yosef that a dispensable rite can be performed by a non-priest: <b>But</b> what about <b>conveying</b> the <b>limbs</b> of the offering <b>to the ramp, which is a dispensable rite,</b> as the offering can be slaughtered next to the ramp? <b>And</b> nevertheless, if it is performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, as it is written: “And the priest shall sacrifice the whole, and make it smoke upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:13); <b>and the Master says: This</b> is referring to <b>conveying</b> the <b>limbs to the ramp.</b>
The Gemara answers: In a case <b>where</b> the verse explicitly <b>revealed</b> that a rite must be performed by a priest, it <b>revealed</b> it; <b>but</b> in a case <b>where</b> the Torah <b>did not reveal</b> it, it <b>did not reveal</b> it. With regard to conveying the blood, the Torah does not state explicitly that a priest is required.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But is it not all the more so</b> obvious? <b>Just as conveying the limbs to the ramp requires</b> that the conveyor be a member of the <b>priesthood,</b> even though it <b>does not prevent atonement</b> if not performed at all, since atonement was already effected by sprinkling the blood, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that concerning <b>conveying</b> the <b>blood</b> and sprinkling it on the altar, <b>where</b> the failure to convey it and sprinkle it on the altar <b>prevents atonement,</b> it must be that the conveyor be a member of the priesthood? This difficulty remains unresolved.
<b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> In a case where <b>conveying</b> the blood is performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, even according to Rabbi Shimon.</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is <b>conveying</b> the blood <b>not by foot</b> but rather by passing it by hand to another priest <b>considered conveying, or is it not considered conveying?</b> Can the rite be performed in this manner?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> evidence from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And likewise,</b> if the priest collected, conveyed, or sprinkled the blood while <b>sitting, and likewise,</b> if he performed any of these rites with his <b>left</b> hand, the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> Since only sitting is listed, one <b>consequently</b> infers that if the priest conveyed the blood while <b>standing</b> but in a manner <b>similar to sitting,</b> i.e., by outstretching his hand without walking, the offering is <b>fit.</b> Evidently, conveying the blood does not require walking.
The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>Perhaps</b> when the <i>baraita</i> states: <b>Sitting,</b> it is referring to one who conveys the blood by moving toward the altar while sitting on the ground in such a manner <b>that he rubs</b> himself against the floor of the courtyard as he pulls himself forward. If so, the parallel case of <b>standing</b> in a manner <b>similar to sitting</b> is a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>moves</b> forward <b>a bit.</b> Perhaps if he does not move at all and merely outstretches his hand, the rite is not valid.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 64a): <b>An Israelite would slaughter</b> the Paschal offering, <b>and a priest would collect</b> the blood. The priests would be lined up from the place where the lamb was slaughtered until the altar. The priest who collected the blood would immediately <b>hand it to another</b> priest standing next to him, <b>and the other</b> priest would pass it <b>to another,</b> and so forth, until it would reach the altar. Evidently, the blood can be passed from hand to hand; it need not be conveyed by foot.
The Gemara answers: <b>There, too,</b> the priests <b>would move a bit</b> with their feet while passing the blood forward. The Gemara asks: <b>But what is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us</b> in this description, if not that the blood need not be conveyed by foot? The Gemara answers: It teaches that: <b>“In the multitude of people is the king’s glory”</b> (Proverbs 14:28). It honors God when the Temple service is performed by a multitude of priests.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another resolution from a mishna (32a): If a priest who is <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood in a vessel <b>and gave</b> it <b>to an unfit</b> individual standing next to the altar, that individual <b>should return</b> it <b>to the fit</b> priest, so that he may perform a complete act of conveying the blood to the altar. Evidently, the blood must be conveyed to the altar by foot. If conveying by hand were valid, another priest could simply take the blood from the unfit person and complete the conveying of the blood to the altar.
The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>Say</b> that the wording of the mishna should be emended; instead of stating that the unfit person should return the vessel to the fit priest, it should state that <b>the fit</b> priest, even another priest, <b>should then receive it</b> from the unfit person. If so, the mishna proves nothing about conveying by hand.
<b>It was stated: Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Conveying</b> the blood <b>not by foot is not considered conveying.</b>

Daf 15a

The Gemara asks: If the blood was conveyed by hand, is it <b>possible to correct it</b> by conveying it again properly, <b>or</b> is it <b>not possible to correct it,</b> and the offering is disqualified permanently?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the aforementioned mishna: If a priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood in a vessel <b>and gave</b> the vessel <b>to an unfit</b> person standing next to the altar, the latter <b>should return</b> it <b>to the fit</b> priest. Apparently, even after the blood is conveyed in an inappropriate manner, it can be corrected.
<b>And though</b> one can <b>indeed</b> explain <b>that the fit</b> priest <b>should then receive it</b> from him, as posited above, <b>if it enters your mind</b> that if the blood is conveyed incorrectly it is <b>not possible to correct it,</b> the offering <b>was</b> already <b>disqualified</b> when the priest gave the blood to the unfit person. Taking it back is of no consequence.
The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>Do you maintain that</b> this is referring to a case where the <b>non-priest is standing inside,</b> between the fit priest and the altar? <b>No,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the <b>non-priest is standing outside,</b> farther away from the altar than the priest. Therefore, when the priest gave him the blood, he was not conveying it toward the altar at all; he was moving it farther away from the altar.
<b>It was stated: Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Conveying</b> the blood <b>not by foot</b> renders the offering <b>unfit. Apparently, it is not possible to correct it,</b> as otherwise Rabbi Yoḥanan would have merely stated that it is not considered conveying, as in his earlier statement (14b).
<b>Rav Naḥman raised an objection to Ulla</b> from a mishna (32a): If the blood <b>spilled from the vessel onto the floor and one collected it</b> from the floor, it is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice. Apparently, although spilling the blood on the floor constitutes a not valid conveying toward the altar, it can still be corrected after the fact.
The Gemara explains: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the blood that spilled <b>went outward,</b> i.e., away from the altar, so it did not constitute conveying at all.
The Gemara asks: Can spilled blood <b>go outward</b> and <b>not come inward?</b> Clearly, spilled blood spreads to all sides. The Gemara answers: It is a case where the blood spilled <b>on an inclined plane,</b> and it therefore spilled only outward, away from the altar. And <b>if you wish, say</b> instead that it spilled <b>into a hole</b> in the ground, so it did not spread in any direction. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is a case <b>where</b> the blood is <b>thick,</b> so it did not spread in all directions.
The Gemara asks: <b>But did the <i>tanna</i> go to all that trouble [<i>ikhpal</i></b>] just <b>to teach us all these</b> unlikely cases? <b>And furthermore, rather than teaching in another chapter</b> (see 25a) that if the blood <b>spilled</b> from the animal’s neck <b>onto the floor and one collected it</b> in a vessel from the floor it is <b>unfit, let</b> the mishna <b>teach a distinction within</b> the case where the blood spilled from the vessel <b>itself: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that the blood is fit, <b>said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the spilled blood <b>went outward,</b> away from the altar, <b>but</b> if it <b>came inward</b> it is <b>unfit.</b> The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation;</b> if the blood is conveyed in a not valid manner, it can be corrected.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> The <b>dispute</b> in the mishna (13a) between <b>Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis</b> as to whether improper intent while conveying the blood disqualifies the offering is only with regard to <b>conveying</b> the blood <b>not by foot. With regard to greater conveying,</b> i.e., conveying the blood by moving the feet, <b>everyone agrees that</b> if one performs it with prohibited intent, the offering is <b>unfit. When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to lesser conveying,</b> i.e., conveying the blood by hand without moving the feet, in a case where the offering was slaughtered next to the altar.
<b>They laughed at</b> this statement <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, saying: <b>But</b> if so, one encounters difficulty with regard to <b>a bird sin offering, which</b> is killed through pinching its nape on the altar and whose blood is sprinkled directly from its neck. It is known that if one sprinkled its blood with prohibited <b>intent,</b> the offering is <b>unfit.</b> And <b>according to Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that prohibited intent while conveying the blood by hand does not disqualify the offering, <b>how can you find these</b> circumstances? <b>If</b> the priest <b>has</b> prohibited <b>intent with regard to</b> the offering <b>before</b> the <b>blood comes out</b> of the bird, this intent <b>is nothing,</b> since his waving it is like conveying by hand. <b>And if</b> he has such intent <b>after the blood came out, its mitzva was</b> already <b>performed,</b> as the blood already reached the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the difficulty? Perhaps</b> the offering is disqualified due to prohibited intent <b>from</b> the moment the blood <b>leaves</b> the bird <b>until</b> the moment <b>it reaches the altar.</b>
This is <b>as Rabbi Yirmeya asked Rabbi Zeira:</b> If the priest <b>was sprinkling</b> the blood, <b>and the hand of the one sprinkling was severed before</b> the <b>blood reached the airspace of the altar, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the sprinkling not valid since it was performed by a blemished priest, or is it valid because the blood left the bird before he was blemished? <b>And</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>not valid. What is the reason? We require</b> that the verse: <b>“And sprinkle</b> of the blood” (Leviticus 4:6), be fulfilled in the same manner as the verse that follows it: <b>“And</b> the priest shall <b>place</b> of the blood upon the corners of the altar” (Leviticus 4:7), namely, that the blood reach the altar. Therefore, the blood can be disqualified anytime until it reaches the altar, whether through the priest becoming blemished or through prohibited intent.
<b>When Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, came from the study hall, they said: This is</b> the reason for <b>the laughter</b> of the scholars of Eretz Yisrael: <b>With regard to greater conveying,</b> i.e., conveying by foot, can one say Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis <b>do not disagree?</b> Clearly, <b>when they disagree</b> in the mishna, <b>they disagree with regard to greater conveying,</b> as Rabbi Shimon reasons that conveying is a dispensable rite. Only conveying by foot is dispensable, since even if the offering is slaughtered next to the altar, the priest will need to move its blood somewhat with his hand.
<b>Rather,</b> the statement under discussion should be emended to say: <b>With regard to lesser conveying,</b> i.e., conveying the blood by hand, <b>everyone agrees that it does not disqualify</b> the offering due to prohibited intent. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to greater conveying,</b> i.e., conveying the blood for a distance by foot. Rabbi Shimon holds that improper intent even then does not disqualify the offering, as the rite is dispensable, and the Rabbis maintain that it does disqualify it.
§ If <b>a non-priest conveyed</b> the blood to the altar, <b>and a priest returned it</b> to its original location, <b>and</b> a priest then <b>conveyed it again</b> to the altar, <b>the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Yannai disagree with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i>. <b>One says</b> that the offering is <b>fit, and one says</b> it is <b>unfit.</b> This is because one <b>Sage holds</b> that if the blood is conveyed improperly, it is <b>possible to correct it, and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that it is <b>not possible to correct it.</b>
If <b>a priest conveyed it</b> to the altar, <b>and</b> then <b>returned it, and a non-priest</b> then <b>conveyed it again, Rav Shimi bar Ashi says: According to the statement of the one who deems</b> the offering <b>fit</b> in the previous case, where a non-priest conveyed it the first time and a priest conveyed it the second time, in this case the offering is <b>unfit,</b> as a non-priest conveyed it the second time. <b>According to the statement of the one who deems</b> the offering <b>unfit</b> in the previous case, as a non-priest conveyed it the first time, in this case, where a priest conveyed it the first time, <b>he deems</b> the offering <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rava says: Even according to the statement of the one who deems</b> the offering <b>unfit</b> in a case where a non-priest conveyed it the first time, it is <b>unfit</b> in this case as well, where a priest conveyed it the first time and a non-priest conveyed it the second time. <b>What is the reason? Because</b> after the blood is returned to its original location, <b>it is necessary</b>

Daf 15b

<b>to bring it</b> again. Therefore, the second conveying must also be performed by a priest.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rav Ashi: This</b> is what <b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti said</b> when he stated <b>that it is necessary to bring</b> the blood to the altar again, and that therefore the second conveying is considered a sacrificial rite and must be performed by a priest: He meant that this principle is subject to <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.</b>
This is <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna (13a): <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>one who conveys</b> the blood <b>in a situation where he is required to convey</b> it, prohibited <b>intent</b> while conveying it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. If he conveys the blood <b>in a situation where he is not required to convey</b> it, prohibited <b>intent</b> while conveying it <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering.
<b>And Rava says: All</b> of the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>concede</b> that if one <b>collected</b> the blood <b>outside,</b> i.e., at a distance from the altar, <b>and he brought it inside,</b> close to the altar, <b>that is</b> considered <b>necessary conveying.</b> If one <b>collected it inside and took it outside, that is</b> considered <b>unnecessary conveying.</b>
<b>They disagree only</b> with regard to a case <b>where he brought it in and took it out again.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that since <b>it is necessary to bring it</b> back to the altar, it is considered necessary conveying, and prohibited intent while performing it disqualifies the offering. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that since the rite of conveying to the altar was already performed, <b>it is not considered conveying that is necessary for the</b> sacrificial <b>service,</b> and prohibited intent while performing it does not disqualify the offering. Apparently, the same dispute applies to a case where a non-priest conveyed the blood the second time.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rava’s interpretation from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>one who conveys</b> the blood <b>in a situation where he is required to convey</b> it, prohibited <b>intent</b> while conveying it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. <b>How so?</b> If one <b>collected</b> the blood <b>outside,</b> at a distance from the altar, <b>and he brought it inside,</b> close to the altar, <b>that is</b> considered <b>necessary conveying.</b> If one <b>collected it inside and took it outside, that is</b> considered <b>unnecessary conveying. And consequently,</b> one infers that if <b>he brought it in again, it is</b> considered <b>necessary conveying</b> even according to Rabbi Eliezer.
Rava <b>said to him: If this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught,</b> and I cannot disagree with it.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all slaughtered offerings,</b> if the one <b>who collected their blood</b> was <b>a non-priest;</b> or a priest who was <b>an acute mourner,</b> i.e., one whose relative has died and has not yet been buried; or <b>one</b> who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed; <b>or one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, e.g., a <i>zav</i> or leper after the seventh day of the purification process; <b>or</b> a priest <b>lacking</b> the requisite priestly <b>vestments;</b> or one <b>who did not wash his hands and feet</b> from the water in the Basin prior to performing the Temple service; or <b>an uncircumcised</b> priest; or <b>a ritually impure</b> priest; or if the one who collected the blood was <b>sitting;</b> or if he was <b>standing</b> not on the floor of the Temple but <b>upon vessels,</b> or <b>upon an animal,</b> or <b>upon the feet of another,</b> he has <b>disqualified</b> the offering.
If <b>he collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, he <b>disqualified</b> the blood for offering. In this last case, <b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a non-priest</b> who performs sacrificial rites disqualifies an offering? <b>As Levi teaches:</b> The verse states: <b>“Speak to Aaron and to his sons, that they separate themselves from the sacred items of the children of Israel [<i>benei Yisrael</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 22:2). Levi continues: <b>“The children of Israel”</b> serves <b>to exclude what</b> from the prohibition against sacrificing an offering in a state of impurity? <b>If we say</b> that it serves <b>to exclude</b> the offerings of <b>women,</b> and the verse states “<i>benei</i>” in the masculine to indicate sons but not daughters, is it conceivable that <b>an offering of women is sacrificed in</b> a state of <b>impurity?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps it serves <b>to exclude</b> offerings of <b>gentiles. Now,</b> if the <b>frontplate</b> of the High Priest, which normally effects acceptance for offerings of Jews sacrificed in a state of impurity, <b>does not effect acceptance</b> for the offerings of gentiles, <b>as the Master said: And with regard to</b> an offering of <b>gentiles, whether</b> it was offered in a state of impurity <b>unintentionally or intentionally, it was not accepted;</b> can it be, then, that such an offering <b>is sacrificed in</b> a state of <b>impurity</b> <i>ab initio</i>?
<b>Rather, this</b> is what the verse <b>is saying,</b> i.e., it should be read in the following manner: <b>That they separate themselves from the sacred items; the children of Israel, and that they not profane</b> My holy name. That is, the verse states that they, the priests, must separate themselves from the sacred items when they are ritually impure, and that the children of Israel must separate themselves from performing the sacrificial rites, so that they will not profane, i.e., disqualify, the offerings.
A <i>tanna</i> of the <b>school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of a non-priest who performs the sacrificial rites <b>is derived via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a blemished</b> priest: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a blemished</b> priest, <b>who may partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> he has nevertheless <b>desecrated</b> the service,

Daf 16a

then with regard to <b>a non-priest, who may not partake</b> of the meat of offerings of the most sacred order, <b>is it not right that if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service?
The Gemara rejects the inference: One cannot draw an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from a blemished priest, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>a blemished</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah <b>rendered</b> an animal that <b>is sacrificed like</b> the priest who <b>sacrifices</b> it, i.e., both blemished animals and blemished priests are disqualified. Since there is an added element of stringency with regard to the case of a blemished priest, one cannot draw an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from it.
The Gemara suggests: The case of <b>an impure</b> priest <b>will prove</b> that this is no reason to reject the <i>a fortiori</i> inference. While an animal and the priest are not equated with regard to ritual impurity, as an animal cannot become impure while alive but a priest can, an impure priest desecrates the service. The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>an impure</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> an impure priest <b>imparts impurity</b> to others.
The Gemara responds: <b>A blemished</b> priest <b>will prove</b> that this is no reason to reject the inference, as he cannot impart his blemish to others. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. Therefore, one may derive the <i>halakha</i> of a non-priest from the combination of the case of a blemished priest and that of an impure priest: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case, <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element</b> is <b>that they are prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites <b>and if they performed</b> these <b>rites they have desecrated</b> the service. Therefore, <b>I will also include a non-priest, who is prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites, <b>and</b> conclude that <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> a non-priest <b>is prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites? <b>If</b> it is derived <b>from</b> the verse: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, <b>that they separate themselves</b> from the sacred items of the children of Israel, and that they not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2), then the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is unnecessary, since <b>profanation itself is writ-ten in</b> the verse. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that it is derived <b>from</b> the verse: “Keep the charge of the Tent of Meeting, whatever the service of the Tent may be; <b>but a common man shall not draw close to you”</b> (Numbers 18:4).
The Gemara asks: Still, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference drawn from the cases of a blemished priest and an impure priest <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> a blemished priest and an impure priest <b>were not permitted</b> to perform sacrificial rites <b>on</b> a private <b>altar</b> during times when there was no Temple or permanent Tabernacle. Since it was permitted for non-priests to perform rites on private altars, perhaps non-priests do not desecrate the sacrificial rites performed in the Temple.
The Gemara responds: <b>Do not say</b> that the case of <b>an impure</b> priest <b>will prove</b> the <i>a fortiori</i> inference with the case of a blemished priest; <b>rather, say</b> that the case of <b>an acute mourner will prove</b> it, as it is prohibited for him to perform the service and, if he were to perform it, he would desecrate it. This, too, is rejected: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>an acute mourner?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> he <b>is prohibited from</b> partaking of second <b>tithe,</b> whereas a non-priest may partake of second tithe. The Gemara responds: <b>A blemished</b> priest <b>will prove</b> the inference, as he may partake of second tithe.
<b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case. <b>Their common element</b> is <b>that they are prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites <i>ab initio</i>, and they desecrate the service if they do so. Therefore, with regard to a non-priest, who is prohibited from performing sacrificial rites, if he performed sacrificial rites he has desecrated the service.
The Gemara asks: <b>Here, too, let one refute</b> the inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> both an acute mourner and a blemished priest <b>were not permitted</b> to perform sacrificial rites <b>on</b> a private <b>altar,</b> unlike a non-priest. <b>Rav Samma, son of Rava, objects to this: And who shall say to us that an acute mourner</b> was <b>prohibited</b> from performing rites <b>on</b> a private <b>altar? Perhaps</b> it was <b>permitted</b> for him to perform the rites <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b>
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that a non-priest desecrates the service <b>is derived</b> by <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of a priest who performed sacrificial rites while <b>sitting: Just as</b> with regard to a priest who was <b>sitting, who may partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service, then with regard to <b>a non-priest, who may not partake</b> of the meat of offerings of the most sacred order, <b>is it not right that if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>a sitting</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> one who sits <b>is disqualified from bearing witness,</b> as witnesses must stand when testifying. Since there is an added aspect of stringency with regard to the case of a sitting priest, one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a non-priest from it. The Gemara responds: Learn instead <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sitting Torah scholar,</b> as the court may allow a Torah scholar to sit while testifying.
The Gemara challenges: Still, one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> from this, as <b>what</b> is notable about <b>the category of a sitting</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> generally speaking, one who sits <b>is disqualified from bearing witness,</b> even though there are exceptions. The Gemara responds: <b>The category of a sitting</b> priest <b>cannot refute</b> the derivation. One can refute a derivation only from concrete cases, not general concepts. <b>And</b> even <b>if you say it can refute</b> the derivation, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a non-priest <b>can be derived from</b> the case of <b>a sitting</b> priest <b>and from one of those</b> other cases, i.e., a blemished priest, an impure priest, or an acute mourner, all of whom may testify.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> one who is <b>sitting is fit</b> to perform sacrificial rites <b>on</b> a private <b>altar?</b> If he is not, one can refute the common element in the same manner as above. The Gemara responds: <b>The verse states:</b> “The Lord separated the tribe of Levi to bear the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord, <b>to stand before the Lord to minister to Him”</b> (Deuteronomy 10:8). The verse indicates that the sacrificial rites must be performed while standing only <b>before the Lord,</b> i.e., in the Temple, where the Divine Presence resides, <b>and not before</b> a private <b>altar,</b> which is a mere place of worship.
§ The mishna teaches that rites performed by <b>an acute mourner</b> are disqualified. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to a High Priest who is an acute mourner: <b>“And he shall not leave the Sanctuary, and he will not profane</b> the Sanctuary of his God” (Leviticus 21:12). One can infer: <b>But</b> any <b>other</b> ordinary priest <b>who did not leave</b> the Sanctuary while he was an acute mourner and continued to perform the service <b>has desecrated</b> the rites he performed.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> One can derive it <b>from here</b> instead: When Moses asked Aaron why the sin offering that was sacrificed on the day that Nadav and Avihu died was burned and not eaten, he suspected that Aaron’s other sons, Eleazar and Itamar, had sacrificed the sin offering while acute mourners, which disqualified it and forced them to burn it. Aaron responded to Moses: “This day have <b>they offered</b> their sin offering?” (Leviticus 10:19). Rather, <b>I offered</b> it. As High Priest, I do not desecrate the Temple service even when I am an acute mourner; I burned it only because, as acute mourners, my sons and I are prohibited from partaking of the meat. Rabbi Elazar continues: <b>By inference,</b> one can derive <b>that if they had offered</b> the sin offering they would have disqualified it, and it would have been <b>proper</b> that <b>it was burned.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar does not say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And he shall not leave the Sanctuary”?</b> The Gemara responds: He could have <b>said to you: Is it written: But</b> any <b>other</b> ordinary priest <b>that did not leave</b> the Sanctuary <b>has desecrated</b> the rites he performed? It is only an inference, and so it is not conclusive.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> Sage, who derives it from the verse: “And he shall not leave the Sanctuary,” <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not say</b> to derive it <b>from</b> the verse: “This day have <b>they offered</b> their sin offering?” The Gemara responds: He <b>holds</b> that the sin offering <b>was burned because</b> it became <b>ritually impure,</b> not because Aaron and his sons were acute mourners.
A <i>tanna</i> of the <b>school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a blemished</b> priest: <b>And just as</b>

Daf 16b

with regard to <b>a blemished</b> priest, <b>who may partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service, then with regard to <b>an acute mourner, who may not partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>is it not right that if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service?
The Gemara rejects the inference: One cannot derive this <i>halakha</i> from the case of a blemished priest, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a blemished</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah <b>rendered</b> animals that <b>are sacrificed like</b> the priests who <b>sacrifice</b> them. Since this stringency does not exist with regard to acute mourning, perhaps an acute mourner may perform sacrificial rites as well.
The Gemara responds: The case of <b>a non-priest will prove</b> that this is no reason to reject the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, since there is no equivalence between priest and sacrifice in this regard, yet a non-priest desecrates the service. The Gemara rejects this as well: One cannot cite a proof from the case of a non-priest, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>a non-priest?</b> It is notable <b>in that he has no remedy,</b> i.e., a non-priest may never perform the sacrificial rites. By contrast, an acute mourner will eventually become permitted to perform the service.
The Gemara responds: <b>A blemished</b> priest <b>will prove</b> that this is no reason to reject the inference, as even though the priest may perform the service if the blemish is healed, he desecrates the service so long as he remains blemished. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. Therefore, one learns the <i>halakha</i> from the combination of the cases of a blemished priest and a non-priest: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case, <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case. <b>Their common element is that they are prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites, <b>and if they performed</b> such <b>rites they have desecrated</b> the service. Therefore, <b>I will also include an acute mourner, who is prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites, <b>and</b> conclude that <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Where is</b> an acute mourner <b>prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites, as asserted in the inference? <b>If we say</b> that it is derived <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And he shall not leave the Sanctuary,</b> and he will not profane the Sanctuary of his God” (Leviticus 21:12), then the above <i>a fortiori</i> inference is unnecessary, since <b>profanation itself is written in</b> the verse. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that it is derived <b>from</b> the verse: “This day have <b>they offered</b> their sin offering?” (Leviticus 10:19), <b>and</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that the sin offering brought by Aaron <b>was burned because</b> Aaron and his sons were in <b>acute mourning.</b>
The Gemara challenges: The inference from the common element of the cases of a blemished priest and a non-priest <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>its general prohibition was permitted.</b> There is an exception to the prohibition against an acute mourner performing the Temple service, namely the High Priest, who may perform the sacrificial rites while an acute mourner.
The Gemara responds: The case of <b>an impure</b> priest <b>will prove</b> that this is no reason to reject the inference, as there is an exception to the prohibition against performing the service while impure, namely that the prohibition against performing the Temple service in a state of impurity is permitted in cases involving the public, yet an impure priest desecrates the service.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>an impure</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that he imparts impurity</b> to others. Perhaps it is only for this reason that an impure priest desecrates the service. The Gemara responds: <b>Those</b> other cases, i.e., a blemished priest and a non-priest, <b>will prove</b> that this does not reject the inference, since they do not impart their status to others. <b>And the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. Therefore, one can derive the <i>halakha</i> from the combination of the cases of an impure priest, a blemished priest, and a non-priest: The aspect of this case is not like the aspect of that case; <b>their common element is that they are prohibited</b> from performing sacrificial rites and they desecrate the service. Therefore, I will also conclude that since an acute mourner is prohibited from performing sacrificial rites, he desecrates the service.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let one refute</b> this as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that its general prohibition was not permitted,</b> even <b>in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering.</b> By contrast, a High Priest in acute mourning may perform rites even for individual offerings. The Gemara responds: <b>The category of impurity, at least, is permitted</b> in the case of communal offerings. Therefore, one cannot claim that an impure priest, a non-priest, and a blemished priest all share a lack of exemptions.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to an acute mourner <b>is derived by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a sitting</b> priest: <b>And just as</b> with regard to <b>a sitting</b> priest, <b>who may partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service, then with regard to <b>an acute mourner, who may not partake</b> of the meat of offerings, <b>is it not right that if he performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites he has desecrated</b> the service?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the case of <b>a sitting</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> one who sits <b>is disqualified from bear-ing witness,</b> as witnesses must stand when testifying. The Gemara responds: Learn instead <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sitting Torah scholar,</b> as the court may allow a Torah scholar to sit while testifying.
The Gemara challenges: Still, one cannot derive from this, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about the category of a sitting</b> priest? It is notable <b>in that</b> generally speaking, one who sits <b>is disqualified from bearing witness,</b> even though there are exceptions. The Gemara responds: <b>The category of a sitting</b> priest <b>cannot refute</b> the derivation. One can refute a derivation only from concrete cases, not general concepts. <b>And</b> even <b>if you say it can refute</b> the derivation, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a non-priest <b>can be derived from</b> the case of <b>a sitting</b> priest <b>and from one of those</b> other cases, i.e., a non-priest, an impure priest, or a blemished priest, through their common element.
§ The mishna teaches that if <b>an acute mourner</b> collects the blood of an offering, the offering is <b>disqualified. Rava says: They taught</b> this <b>only with regard to an individual’s offering. But with regard to a communal offering,</b> a rite performed by an acute mourner does <b>effect acceptance.</b> One can derive this by <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from ritual impurity.</b>
<b>Just as</b> the prohibition against performing rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity, whose general prohibition was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering,</b> as no individual offering may be sacrificed in a state of impurity, <b>was</b> nevertheless <b>permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary [<i>hedyot</i>]</b> priest performing rites <b>for a communal offering,</b> as communal offerings may be sacrificed by an impure priest when necessary; then so too, with regard to the prohibition against performing rites while in a period of <b>acute mourning, whose general prohibition was permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering,</b> as the High Priest may perform all rites while an acute mourner, <b>is it not right that</b> this prohibition <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering?</b>
<b>Rava bar Ahilai objects to this:</b> On the contrary, if such an inference can be made, then perhaps one can make the following mistaken inference: The performance of rites in a state of <b>acute mourning should not be permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering, by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> the prohibition against performing rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering, was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering;</b> then so too, with regard to the prohibition against performing the rites during a period of <b>acute mourning,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering, is it not right that</b> this prohibition <b>should not be permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering?</b>
<b>And</b> similarly, one may claim: The performance of rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity should be permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering, by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> the prohibition against performing rites in a state of <b>acute mourning,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering,</b> still <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering;</b> then so too, with regard to the prohibition against performing the rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering, is it not right that</b> this prohibition <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering?</b>
<b>And</b> similarly, one may claim: The performance of rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity should not be permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering, by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> the prohibition against performing rites in a state of <b>acute mourning,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual’s offering,</b> still <b>was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering;</b> then so too, with regard to the prohibition against performing the rites in a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> whose general prohibition <b>was not permitted in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest</b> performing rites <b>for an individual offering, is it not right that</b> this prohibition <b>should not be permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary priest</b> performing rites <b>for a communal offering?</b>
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for recalling the above rejections of Rava bar Ahilai: <b>And should not be permitted, and should not be permitted, acute mourning, and ritual impurity, ritual impurity, individual, and individual, communal.</b>

Daf 17a

<b>Rather,</b> one <b>can derive this</b> way <b>and</b> one <b>can derive that</b> way. Since these derivations contradict one another, <b>each and every</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>shall stand in its place</b> and not modify the other by <i>a fortiori</i> inference.
§ The mishna teaches that sacrificial rites performed by <b>one who immersed that day</b> are disqualified. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: It is derived <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Simai says: From where</b> in the Torah is the <b>allusion</b> with regard <b>to</b> a priest <b>who immersed that day, that if he performed</b> the Temple <b>service he desecrated</b> that service? It is derived from a verse, as <b>the verse states: “They shall be sacred to their God and they shall not desecrate</b> the name of their God” (Leviticus 21:6).
<b>If</b> this verse <b>is not</b> written with regard to the <b>matter of an impure</b> priest who performed the Temple service, <b>as</b> that <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived for us from</b> the verse: <b>“That they separate themselves</b> from the sacred items of the children of Israel” (Leviticus 22:2), then <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of</b> a priest <b>who immersed that day</b> who performed the Temple service. Although he is no longer impure in every sense, the priest remains impure in the sense that he is prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i> and sacrificial food, and from entering the Temple.
The Gemara asks: Why must the verse be applied to the matter of one who immersed that day? <b>Say</b> that one should <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of one who creates a bald spot</b> upon his head <b>or to</b> the matter of <b>one who destroys</b> his <b>beard,</b> as these matters are discussed in the preceding verse.
The Gemara responds: This verse is already used to indicate another <i>halakha</i> relating to one who immersed that day: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that if one who immersed that day performed</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> he is liable to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven? <b>As</b> it is <b>derived</b> by verbal analogy between <b>profanation</b> mentioned in this context and <b>profanation from <i>teruma</i>,</b> as the verse states in this context: “And not profane the name of their God” (Leviticus 21:6), and the verse states with regard to <i>teruma</i>: “Lest they bear sin for it, and die therein, if they profane it” (Leviticus 22:9). It can be inferred from this verbal analogy that one <b>who disqualifies <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., one who immersed that day, <b>profanes</b> the Temple <b>service,</b> and one <b>who does not disqualify <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., one who creates a bald spot or one who destroys his beard, <b>does not profane</b> the <b>service.</b>
§ <b>Rabba said: Why do I</b> need <b>that</b> which <b>the Merciful One wrote,</b> i.e., that <b>an impure</b> priest, <b>and one who immersed that day, and one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering all disqualify the rites they perform? Wouldn’t it have been enough to teach the <i>halakha</i> in only one case?
Rabba explains: All three <b>are necessary, as</b> in each case there is a stringency not present in the others. Therefore, <b>had the Merciful One written</b> only that <b>an impure</b> priest desecrates the service, one might say that this is <b>because he imparts impurity</b> to others, and since the other two cases do not, one cannot derive them from the case of an impure priest. And had the Merciful One written the <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to one who immersed that day,</b> then the case of <b>one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering <b>could not be derived from it, since</b> the former <b>is unfit to</b> partake of <b><i>teruma</i></b> while the latter is not. And had the Merciful One written the <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, then the case of <b>one who immersed that day could not be derived from it, since</b> only the former <b>has not yet</b> performed a necessary <b>action,</b> while one who immersed that day must simply wait for nightfall in order to become fully pure.
The Gemara asks: Still, why are all three necessary? Granted, <b>from one</b> of these cases the other two <b>cannot be derived,</b> but <b>let one be derived from</b> the other <b>two.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> of the three <b>should the Merciful One not write?</b> If one suggests: <b>Let</b> the Merciful One <b>not write</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to one who has not yet</b> brought an <b>atonement</b> offering <b>and derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other two, an impure priest and one who immersed that day, one can reply: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these?</b> They are notable <b>in that they are unfit to</b> partake of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Since one who has not yet brought an atonement offering may partake of <i>teruma</i>, perhaps he does not disqualify rites he performs.
<b>Rather,</b> say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to one who immersed that day and derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other two, an impure priest and one who has not yet brought an atonement offering. <b>As, what can you</b> say to <b>refute</b> this? One cannot reply: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these;</b> they are notable <b>since they have not yet</b> performed a necessary <b>action,</b> because <b>ultimately their impurity,</b> i.e., the impurity of one who has not yet brought an atonement offering, <b>is weak</b> when compared to one who immersed that day, and relatively speaking, one who has not yet brought an atonement offering is not considered to be lacking the performance of an action.

Daf 17b

The Gemara responds: Rabba <b>holds</b> that <b>a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>] who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering is still <b>considered</b> to have the impure status of <b>a <i>zav</i>.</b> The impurity of one who has immersed but has not yet brought an atonement offering is therefore considered stronger than that of one who immersed that day but requires no atonement.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> the matter of whether <b>a <i>zav</i> who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering is still <b>considered a <i>zav</i> is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>an acute mourner or one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering <b>burned</b> the red heifer, it is <b>fit. Yosef the Babylonian says:</b> If <b>an acute mourner</b> burned it, it is <b>fit,</b> but if <b>one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering burned it, it is <b>disqualified. What, is it not that they disagree with regard to this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Yosef the Babylonian, <b>holds</b> that <b>a <i>zav</i> who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering <b>is considered</b> a full-fledged <b><i>zav</i></b> and therefore disqualifies the red heifer, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that a <i>zav</i> who has not yet brought an atonement offering <b>is not considered a <i>zav</i>,</b> but is instead considered like one who immersed that day, who is fit to burn the red heifer?
The Gemara responds: <b>No, everyone</b> agrees that he <b>is considered a <i>zav</i>, and here</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to this</b> matter, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the rite of the red heifer: <b>“And the pure person shall sprinkle”</b> the water of purification (Numbers 19:19). The preceding verse already states that the one performing the service must be ritually pure. Therefore, by stating “pure” this verse emphasizes that he needs be pure enough only to perform the rite of the red heifer specifically. <b>By inference,</b> one derives <b>that he</b> may <b>be impure</b> in some way that disqualifies him for other rites. This <b>teaches that one who immersed that day is fit</b> to participate <b>in</b> the rite of the red <b>heifer.</b>
The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree as to the extent of this <i>halakha</i>: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that it is referring to any state of <b>impurity</b> mentioned <b>in the entire Torah,</b> i.e., anyone who immersed that day due to any impurity may participate in the rite of the red heifer. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Yosef the Babylonian, <b>holds</b> that it is referring specifically to one who was in the state of <b>impurity</b> mentioned <b>in this passage,</b> i.e., impurity contracted from a corpse, which the red heifer purifies.
<b>Therefore,</b> according to Yosef the Babylonian, with regard to <b>an acute mourner and one who immersed that day</b> after becoming <b>impure</b> due to contact with the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, since</b> they <b>are</b> treated more <b>leniently, they are derived <i>a fortiori</i> from</b> the case of <b>one who immersed that day</b> to remove impurity contracted from <b>a corpse,</b> and they are fit to participate in the rite of the red heifer. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>who</b> is treated more <b>stringently, since</b> his <b>impurity emerges onto him from his body</b> rather than being imparted from without, one does <b>not</b> derive that he is fit to participate in the rite of the red heifer.
§ The mishna teaches that a priest <b>lacking</b> the requisite priestly <b>vestments</b> disqualifies the rites he performs. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Avuh says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and</b> some <b>determined it</b> to be stated <b>in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: As the verse states: “And you shall gird them with belts, Aaron and his sons, and bind mitres on them; and they shall have the priesthood by a perpetual statute”</b> (Exodus 29:9).
