If</b> it is such <b>that a cow can kneel and drink from it,</b> it is considered water and should be fit <b>even to</b> complete the measure of <b>a quarter</b><i>-log</i> for ritual washing of the hands. <b>And if a cow cannot kneel and drink from it, it should not even</b> be fit to <b>complete</b> the requisite measure for <b>a ritual bath.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> say that it means <b>to exclude red gnats</b> that originate and grow in water. This, too, is difficult, as <b>even by themselves</b> they may constitute the entire measure of the ritual bath, not only to complete a deficient measure of water; <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> With regard to <b>anything that originates in the water, one may immerse in it,</b> since it is considered as though it were water. <b>And Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says: One may immerse</b> even <b>in</b> liquefied <b>fish eye</b> of sufficient volume.
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The statement of Reish Lakish means <b>to exclude</b> a case where <b>one added a <i>se’a</i> and removed a <i>se’a</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 7:2): In the case of <b>a ritual bath that contains</b> the minimum measure of <b>exactly forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water, and <b>one added a <i>se’a</i></b> of liquid other than water, <b>and</b> then <b>removed a <i>se’a</i></b> of the mixture, the ritual bath remains <b>fit.</b> The added liquid is considered nullified in the forty <i>se’a</i> of water, so that when one <i>se’a</i> of the mixture is removed, there still remain the requisite forty <i>se’a</i> of fit water. <b>And Rav Yehuda bar Sheila says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>up to the greater part</b> of the measure of the ritual bath. Adding and removing such a liquid to the requisite measure for washing of the hands renders the water unfit.
<b>Rav Pappa says: If one drilled in</b> the wall of a ritual bath, and the sides of the hole can hold <b>a quarter</b><i>-log</i> of liquid, <b>one may immerse</b> small vessels such as <b>needles and hooks in</b> the hole, even though it constitutes a space separate from the ritual bath, <b>since</b> the fitness of the water in the hole <b>derives from the fitness of</b> the water in <b>the ritual bath.</b> This <i>halakha</i> is parallel to the one discussed with regard to the Basin.
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says: Water of a ritual bath is fit to</b> be used as <b>water of</b> the <b>Basin.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> the water in the Basin <b>does not</b> need to be <b>flowing water,</b> i.e., spring water? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse indicates that the innards of an offering must be washed: <b>“With water”</b> (Leviticus 1:9), <b>and not with wine; “with water,” and not with</b> wine <b>mixed</b> with water; <b>“with water,” to include other</b> types of <b>water,</b> even those that are not spring water. <b>And</b> it can be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> that <b>the water</b> used <b>for</b> the <b>Basin</b> may be used to wash the innards. <b>What</b> is the basis of the <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that <b>the water</b> used <b>for the Basin</b> may also be used? Is it <b>not that it is</b> from a source of <b>flowing water</b> and therefore obviously fit for washing the innards?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is based on the fact <b>that</b> the water used for the Basin is <b>sanctified</b> for the service. The Gemara asks: <b>But is sanctified</b> water <b>preferable,</b> given that the Torah stipulates simply “water”? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Shmuel teach:</b> The word <b>“water”</b> used in the verse denotes specifically water <b>whose</b> name <b>has no modifier;</b>

Daf 22b

<b>excluded is water of</b> the <b>Basin, which has a modifier</b> in its name? <b>Rather,</b> since the <i>baraita</i> cannot be referring to the water of the Basin itself, as it is unfit for washing the innards, <b>is it not</b> referring to water <b>that is fit to</b> be <b>water of</b> the <b>Basin? Apparently,</b> the only reason such water could be preferable is because it <b>is flowing water.</b>
The Gemara responds: The issue <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>the water of</b> the <b>Basin, Rabbi Yishmael says: It</b> must be <b>spring water,</b> i.e., flowing water, <b>and the Rabbis say: It</b> may be <b>another</b> type of <b>water.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that a priest who is <b>uncircumcised</b> disqualifies sacrificial rites he performs. The Gemara elaborates: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rav Ḥisda says: We did not learn this matter from the Torah of Moses, our teacher;</b> rather, <b>we learned</b> it <b>from the words of</b> the prophet <b>Ezekiel, son of Buzi: “No stranger, uncircumcised in heart or uncircumcised in flesh, shall enter into My Sanctuary to serve Me”</b> (Ezekiel 44:9).
<b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that he desecrates</b> the <b>service</b> after the fact? <b>As it is written: “In that you have brought in strangers, uncircumcised in heart or uncircumcised in flesh, to be in My Sanctuary, to profane My house”</b> (Ezekiel 44:7).
<b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states <b>“stranger”;</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that this is referring to <b>an actual stranger,</b> i.e., a gentile. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Uncircumcised in heart,”</b> to indicate that it is referring to a priest rather than a gentile. <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Stranger”?</b> It is referring to one <b>whose actions are</b> considered <b>estranged from his Father in Heaven,</b> i.e., an apostate, who sins regularly. <b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>one uncircumcised in heart</b> is unfit to serve; <b>from where</b> is it derived that <b>one uncircumcised in flesh</b> is unfit as well? <b>The verse states: “Or uncircumcised in flesh.”</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> both phrases in the verse <b>are necessary. As, had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“Uncircumcised in flesh,”</b> one might think that only he is unfit <b>because he is disgusting</b> in that he possesses a foreskin, <b>but</b> concerning <b>one uncircumcised in heart, who is not disgusting, I will say</b> that he is <b>not</b> unfit. <b>And had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> only that one <b>uncircumcised in heart</b> is unfit, one might think that only he is unfit, <b>because his heart is not</b> directed <b>toward Heaven, but one uncircumcised in flesh, whose heart is</b> directed <b>toward Heaven, I will say</b> that he is <b>not</b> unfit. Therefore, both phrases <b>are necessary.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that a ritually <b>impure</b> priest is <b>unfit</b> for Temple service and disqualifies rites he performs. <b>The Elders of the South said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to one who became <b>impure due to</b> contact with the carcass of <b>a creeping animal. But</b> with regard to a priest who became <b>impure due to</b> contact with <b>a corpse, since he can effect acceptance</b> of his rites <b>for communal</b> offerings <i>ab initio</i> if the majority of the community has contracted impurity from a corpse, <b>he can effect acceptance</b> of his rites <b>for individual</b> offerings <b>as well</b> after the fact.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let</b> it <b>be derived</b> that <b>one impure due to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> can also effect acceptance for communal offerings in cases of communal impurity <i>ab initio</i>, and for individual offerings after the fact, <b>by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from one impure due to a corpse: Just as</b> a priest who is <b>impure due to a corpse, who requires sprinkling</b> of the water containing the ashes of the red heifer on the <b>third and seventh</b> day to be purified, still <b>effects acceptance,</b> then with regard to <b>one</b> who is <b>impure due to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal, who does not require sprinkling</b> on the <b>third and seventh</b> day, <b>is it not right that he</b> should also <b>effect acceptance?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>The Elders of the South hold</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>those who effect atonement</b> is <b>like those who achieve atonement: Just as</b> with regard to <b>those who achieve atonement</b> through communal offerings, i.e., the community, only if a majority is <b>impure due to a corpse may</b> the offering be sacrificed in a state of impurity, but if they are <b>impure due to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> it may <b>not, so too</b> with regard to <b>those who effect atonement,</b> i.e., the priests, if they serve when they are <b>impure due to a corpse, yes,</b> their service achieves atonement, but if they serve when they are <b>impure due to the carcass of a creeping animal,</b> it does <b>not.</b>
The response of the Gemara assumes that communal offerings may not be brought when the majority of the community is impure due to a creeping animal. The Gemara therefore asks: <b>What do</b> the Elders of the South <b>hold</b> with regard to the Paschal offering? <b>If they hold</b> that <b>one may not slaughter</b> it <b>nor sprinkle</b> its blood on the altar <b>for</b> an owner who is <b>impure due to a creeping animal,</b> even though he can immerse and become pure in time to eat the offering that night, then one may ask: <b>Why can’t</b> the <b>community perform</b> communal offerings <b>in</b> such a state of <b>impurity? Isn’t</b> it a principle that for <b>any</b> impurity <b>for which an individual</b> may not sacrifice the Paschal offering and <b>is deferred</b> to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, the <b>community may perform</b> its offerings <b>in</b> such a state of <b>impurity?</b>
<b>Rather, they</b> must <b>hold</b> that <b>one may slaughter</b> the Paschal offering <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>for</b> an owner who is <b>impure due to a creeping animal.</b> Accordingly, the community may not offer the Paschal offering in such a state of impurity.
<b>Ulla says: Reish Lakish shouted [<i>teka</i>] to</b> the Elders <b>of the South: But which power is greater</b> to overcome impurity with respect to offerings, <b>the power of those who effect atonement,</b> i.e., the priests, <b>or the power of those who achieve atonement,</b> the offerings’ owners? Since the Elders of the South hold that the Paschal offering may be sacrificed for an owner who is impure due to a creeping animal, while a priest who is similarly impure may not sacrifice any offering, <b>you must say</b> that <b>the power of those who achieve atonement</b> is greater.
If so, your initial statement that a priest who contracted impurity from a corpse can effect acceptance for individual offerings can be refuted <i>a fortiori</i>: <b>And just as in a case where</b> the <b>owner became impure due to a creeping animal,</b> he <b>may send his offerings</b> for sacrifice, and yet <b>a priest who became impure due to a creeping animal cannot effect acceptance,</b> then in <b>a case where the owner became impure due to a corpse, where he may not send his offerings</b> for sacrifice, <b>is it not right that a priest who became impure due to a corpse cannot effect acceptance?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>The Elders of the South hold</b> that an owner who is <b>impure due to a corpse may also send his offerings,</b> even though he will not be able to partake of his Paschal offering. Therefore, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference does not stand.
The Gemara protests: <b>But isn’t it written: “If any man of you or of your generations shall be impure</b> by reason of a dead body, or be in a journey afar off, <b>he shall perform the Paschal offering</b> to the Lord. <b>In the second month</b> on the fourteenth day at dusk they shall perform it” (Numbers 9:10–11)? Apparently, one impure due to a corpse in the first month must defer his Paschal offering to the second month. The Gemara responds: The verse intends this <b>as a mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i>. But if he sends his offering in the first month, it is accepted, and he is not required to sacrifice a Paschal offering in the second month.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written:</b> “And if the household be too little for a lamb, then shall he and his neighbor next to his house take one according to the number of the souls; <b>a man,</b>

Daf 23a

<b>according to his eating,</b> you shall make your count for the lamb” (Exodus 12:4)? This teaches that one may bring the Paschal offering only if he is able to partake of it. The Gemara responds: This requirement is also meant <b>as a mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i>; it does not disqualify the offering if not fulfilled.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is this requirement <b>not indispensable</b> even after the fact? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the phrase <b>“according to the number of the souls” teaches that the Paschal offering may be slaughtered only for those who registered for it</b> in advance. If the Paschal offering was <b>slaughtered for</b> individuals <b>who did not register for it,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>it would</b> only <b>be like transgressing a mitzva,</b> but the offering would not be disqualified. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall make your count”; the verse repeats</b> the issue of counting <b>to</b> stress that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>indispensable,</b> and if one slaughters the offering for one who is not registered, it is disqualified. The Gemara concludes: <b>And those who eat</b> the offering <b>are juxtaposed to those registered</b> for it, as the verse states: “According to the number of the souls; a man, according to his eating.” Accordingly, if one slaughters the Paschal offering for one who cannot partake of it, the offering is disqualified.
The Gemara responds: <b>The Elders of the South do not juxtapose</b> the phrases, i.e., they do not interpret the verse’s juxtaposition of the two phrases as significant. The Gemara asks: <b>But even if they do not juxtapose</b> the phrases, <b>there is a refutation to</b> their statement <b>from this</b> inference <b>as well: And just as in a case where the owner became impure due to a creeping animal, where he may send his offerings</b> for sacrifice <b><i>ab initio</i>, a priest who became impure due to a creeping animal</b> nevertheless <b>cannot effect acceptance,</b> then in <b>a case where the owner became impure due to a corpse, where he may not send his offerings <i>ab initio</i>, is it not right that a priest who became impure due to a corpse cannot effect acceptance?</b>
Furthermore, the Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 80b): <b>As</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that with regard to <b>a nazirite and one who performs</b> the rite of the <b>Paschal offering, the frontplate effects acceptance for</b> offerings sacrificed in a state of <b>impurity of</b> the <b>blood, but the frontplate does not effect acceptance for</b> offerings sacrificed in a state of <b>impurity of the body</b> of the individual bringing it.
The Gemara continues: <b>To what</b> impurity is it referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring <b>to impurity due to a creeping animal, didn’t you say</b> above that according to the Elders of the South, <b>one may slaughter</b> the Paschal offering <b>and sprinkle</b> its blood <b>for</b> an owner who is in a state of <b>impurity due to a creeping animal? Rather,</b> it must be referring to <b>impurity due to a corpse, and</b> the mishna <b>teaches: The frontplate does not effect acceptance. Evidently,</b> if the <b>owner became impure due to a corpse, he may not send his offerings</b> for sacrifice, contrary to the opinion ascribed to the Elders of the South.
The Gemara responds: <b>No, if the owner became impure due to a corpse,</b> the frontplate <b>indeed</b> effects acceptance for the offering. The mishna is not referring to the owners of the offerings at all; rather, <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the officiating <b>priest became impure due to a creeping animal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If it became known after the offering was brought that he had <b>contracted ritual impurity</b> imparted <b>in the depths,</b> i.e., a source of impurity that had been unknown at the time, <b>the frontplate effects acceptance</b> for the offering. This clause cannot be reconciled with the suggested interpretation of the mishna, since <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: They stated</b> this <i>halakha</i> of <b>impurity</b> imparted <b>in the depths only with regard to</b> impurity due to <b>a corpse.</b> Now, when he says that it applies only <b>to</b> impurity due to <b>a corpse,</b> he means <b>to exclude what?</b> Does he <b>not</b> mean <b>to exclude impurity</b> imparted by the carcass of <b>a creeping animal in the depths?</b> If so, the mishna cannot be referring to impurity due to a creeping animal.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya means <b>to exclude impurity</b> imparted <b>by</b> a gonorrhea-like <b>discharge [<i>ziva</i>] in the depths.</b> Impurity due to the corpse of a creeping animal, by contrast, is within the scope of the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how is one to understand <b>this dilemma that Rami bar Ḥama raises:</b> With regard to <b>a priest who effects acceptance for the offerings of</b> the nazirite and the Paschal offering, <b>was impurity</b> imparted <b>in the depths permitted for him or was impurity</b> imparted <b>in the depths not permitted for him?</b> According to the Elders of the South, why not <b>resolve</b> the dilemma and conclude <b>that impurity</b> imparted <b>in the depths was permitted for him, since</b> they hold that <b>we interpret</b> the mishna <b>here</b> as referring <b>to</b> an impure <b>priest?</b>
The Gemara responds: The premise of this dilemma <b>of Rami bar Ḥama certainly disagrees</b> with the opinion of the Elders of the South, and Rami bar Ḥama does not interpret the mishna in this manner.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a verse written about the frontplate: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, <b>and Aaron shall bear the sin committed with the sacred</b> items, which the children of Israel shall consecrate, even all their sacred gifts; and it shall be always upon his forehead, that they may be accepted before God” (Exodus 28:38). <b>And</b> the Sages expounded: <b>Which sin does</b> Aaron <b>bear?</b>

Daf 23b

<b>If</b> the verse means that he bears <b>the sin of <i>piggul</i>, it is already stated:</b> “And if any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted, <b>neither shall it be credited</b> to he who offers it” (Leviticus 7:18). <b>If</b> he bears <b>the sin of <i>notar</i>, it is already stated</b> in the same verse: <b>“It shall not be accepted.”</b>
Rather, the frontplate <b>bears only the sin of impurity, whose general prohibition was permitted in</b> cases involving <b>the pub-lic.</b> The verse indicates that the frontplate effects acceptance for individual offerings sacrificed in a state of ritual impurity.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is the <b>impurity</b> borne by the frontplate? <b>If we say</b> that it effects acceptance <b>for impurity due to a creeping animal, where</b> does one find that the general prohibition was <b>permitted</b> in cases involving the public? <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring to <b>impurity due to a corpse. And</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where the owner</b> of the offerings <b>became impure from a corpse? Evidently,</b> if <b>the owner became impure from a corpse, he may send his offerings</b> for sacrifice, as the frontplate effects acceptance for them.
<b>And to what</b> offering is this statement referring? <b>If</b> it is referring <b>to</b> the offering of <b>a nazirite,</b> doesn’t <b>the Merciful One state: “And if any man die</b> very suddenly <b>beside him,</b> and he defile his consecrated head” (Numbers 6:9)? The passage indicates that even if a nazirite contracts impurity against his will, he still cannot bring his offerings until he is pure. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring <b>to one who performs</b> the rite of the <b>Paschal offering.</b> This proves the claim of the Elders of the South that one who is impure due to a corpse may send his Paschal offering for sacrifice.
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the statement is referring <b>to</b> impurity due to <b>a creeping animal,</b> not due to a corpse. <b>And</b> although the general prohibition with regard to impurity due to a creeping animal was not permitted in cases involving the public, nevertheless, one finds that <b>the category of impurity in general</b> was permitted in such cases.
The Gemara notes: <b>And some infer</b> the opposite <b>and derive like this:</b> The verse states of the frontplate: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron shall bear the sin committed with the sacred items” (Exodus 28:38). That is, it <b>does</b> bear <b>the iniquity of the sacred items,</b> but it does <b>not</b> bear <b>the iniquity of those who consecrate</b> or sacrifice them, i.e., the owners of the offering or the priests involved in its sacrifice. And to <b>what impurity</b> is this verse referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to <b>impurity</b> due to <b>a creeping animal, is</b> such impurity <b>permitted in</b> cases involving the <b>public? Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>impurity</b> due to <b>a corpse, and</b> the verse indicates that the frontplate <b>does</b> bear <b>the iniquity of</b> the <b>sacred items</b> but does <b>not</b> bear <b>the iniquity of those who consecrate</b> them? This refutes the opinion of the Elders of the South that owners who are impure due to a corpse may send their offerings.
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the verse is referring to <b>impurity due to a creeping animal, and</b> although the general prohibition with regard to impurity due to a creeping animal was not permitted in cases involving the public, <b>the category of impurity in general</b> was permitted in such cases.
§ The mishna teaches that a priest who is <b>sitting</b> disqualifies the rites that he performs. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says: The verse states</b> with regard to the priests: “For the Lord your God has chosen him out of all your tribes, <b>to stand to minister”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:5). The verse indicates that <b>I have chosen him for standing and not for sitting.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: “To stand to minister,”</b> indicates that there is <b>a mitzva</b> to perform the service while standing. <b>When it says:</b> “Then he shall minister in the name of the Lord his God, as all his brethren the Levites do, <b>who stand</b> there before the Lord” (Deuteronomy 18:7), <b>the verse repeats</b> the matter <b>to invalidate</b> rites that are performed while not standing.
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: Now, one who is sitting is considered like a non-priest and desecrates</b> the <b>service.</b> Therefore, <b>I will say: Just as a non-priest</b> who performs a rite is liable <b>to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, <b>so too one who is sitting</b> should be liable <b>to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven. If so, <b>why is it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>But one who is uncircumcised, an acute mourner,</b> and <b>one who is sitting are not</b> liable <b>to</b> receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven if they performed rites; <b>rather,</b> they simply transgress <b>a prohibition?</b>
The Gemara responds: That is taught <b>because</b> the case of a priest <b>lacking</b> the requisite priestly <b>vestments and</b> that of <b>one whose hands and feet are not washed are two verses that come as one,</b> as the verse states explicitly for each case that if they perform rites they are liable to receive death at the hand of Heaven.

Daf 24a

<b>And any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common aspect to similar cases. Therefore, one cannot assume that analogous prohibitions carry penalty of death at the hand of Heaven as well.
<b>And</b> even <b>according to the one who says</b> that they do <b>teach</b> their common aspect, the prohibition against service by <b>those who drank wine</b> also contains explicit mention of death at the hand of Heaven and <b>constitutes a third</b> verse. <b>And all agree</b> that <b>three</b> verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common aspect.
§ The mishna teaches that one who is <b>standing upon vessels,</b> or <b>upon an animal,</b> or <b>upon the feet of another,</b> is <b>unfit</b> to perform rites. The Gemara elaborates: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? This is derived <b>as</b> the Sage <b>from the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Since the floor</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>sanctifies</b> the priest to perform the service, <b>and service vessels,</b> i.e., priestly vestments, also <b>sanctify</b> him, one may draw a comparison between the two: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>service vessels, nothing may interpose between</b> the priest <b>and</b> the <b>service vessel, so too</b> with regard to the <b>floor, nothing may interpose between</b> the priest <b>and the floor.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> each of the three cases mentioned in the mishna is <b>necessary. As, had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only that <b>a vessel</b> interposes between the priest’s feet and the floor, one might have thought that this is only <b>because it is not a type of flesh, but</b> with regard to <b>an animal, which is a type of flesh, I will say</b> that it <b>does not</b> constitute an interposition. <b>And had it taught us</b> only that <b>an animal</b> interposes, one might have thought that this is only <b>because it is not of the human species, but another</b> person, <b>who is human, I will say</b> that he does <b>not</b> interpose. Therefore, each is <b>necessary.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If <b>one of</b> the priest’s <b>feet</b> was <b>on a vessel and one of his feet</b> was <b>on the floor,</b> or if <b>one of his feet</b> was <b>on a stone and one of his feet</b> was <b>on the floor,</b> one <b>sees: Any</b> case <b>where, were the vessel to be removed or the stone removed, he</b> would still be <b>able to stand on one foot and perform rites, his service</b> is <b>valid. But if</b> he would <b>not</b> be able to stand on one foot, <b>his service</b> is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ami raises a dilemma:</b> If one of <b>the stone</b> tiles of the Temple floor <b>came loose</b> and began to wobble, <b>and</b> the priest <b>stood on it, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Do not raise the dilemma</b> with regard to a case <b>where he does not intend to attach</b> the stone to the floor again, <b>as it certainly interposes</b> in such a case, since it is considered an item separate from the Temple. Rather, <b>when you raise this dilemma,</b> do so with regard to a case <b>where he intends to attach it</b> again. In such a case, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Does one say that <b>since he intends to attach it, it is considered like that which is</b> already <b>attached? Or perhaps now, at least, it is disconnected,</b> and it is considered a separate item.
<b>Rabba Zuti raises this dilemma like this: Rabbi Ami raises a dilemma:</b> If one of <b>the stone</b> tiles <b>was uprooted and</b> the priest <b>stood in its</b> empty <b>place, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara interjects: <b>What is the dilemma he is raising?</b> Perhaps this is the dilemma: <b>When</b> King <b>David sanctified</b> the site of the Temple, <b>did he sanctify</b> the <b>upper</b> level of the <b>floor</b> but nothing underneath it, <b>or perhaps he sanctified</b> it <b>to the depths of the earth? But</b> if this is the dilemma, <b>let him raise the dilemma</b> with regard to <b>the entire Temple courtyard,</b> i.e., what is the <i>halakha</i> if the entire floor is removed?
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> it is <b>obvious to him that</b> King David <b>sanctified</b> the site of the Temple <b>to the depths of the earth, and this is the dilemma that he raised:</b> When a priest stands on an unfinished part of the Temple floor, <b>is this</b> a normal <b>manner of ministration, or is this not</b> a normal <b>manner of ministration?</b> Concerning the dilemma itself, the Gemara responds: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: If the priest <b>collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the service is <b>disqualified, and Rabbi Shimon deems it fit. The Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it upon the corners of the altar” (Leviticus 4:25). The conjunction of the term <b>“with his finger”</b> and the term <b>“and</b> the priest <b>shall take” teaches that</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>may be</b> performed <b>only with</b> the <b>right</b> hand, since the word “finger” in the context of priesthood is always referring to the right hand. Likewise, the phrase <b>“with his finger and put it” teaches that</b> the <b>placing</b> of the blood <b>may be</b> performed <b>only with</b> the <b>right</b> hand.
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: But is</b> the word: <b>Hand, stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood? <b>Rather,</b> the verse states only: <b>“With his finger and put it,”</b> teaching <b>that</b> the <b>placing</b> of the blood <b>may be</b> performed <b>only with</b> the <b>right</b> hand. <b>Since</b> the word: <b>Hand, is not stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, even if <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> as for <b>Rabbi Shimon, whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, his opinion is difficult. <b>If he holds</b> that one derives <b>a verbal analogy</b> from the passage discussing a leper (Leviticus, chapter 14), which indicates that all references to hands and fingers mean specifically the right hand, then even <b>if</b> the word: <b>Hand, is not stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>what of it?</b> In any event, the word “finger” is stated. <b>And if he does not hold</b> that one derives this <b>verbal analogy,</b> then even <b>if</b> the word: <b>Hand, were stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>what of it?</b> The word would have no significance.
<b>Rav Yehuda says: Actually, he does not hold</b> that one derives this <b>verbal analogy. And this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying: But is</b> the phrase: <b>Right hand, stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood? Rather, <b>since</b> the phrase: <b>Right hand, is not stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, even if <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rabba said to him: If so,</b> then <b>even</b> the rite of <b>placing</b> the blood should be valid when performed with the left hand, since the phrase: Right hand, does not appear with regard to it <b>as well. And furthermore, does Rabbi Shimon</b> really <b>not hold</b> that one derives this <b>verbal analogy? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In <b>every instance</b> in the Torah <b>that</b> the word <b>“hand” is stated,</b> the verse <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to the <b>right</b> hand, and whenever the verse mentions <b>“finger,”</b> it <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to a finger of the <b>right</b> hand?
<b>Rather, Rava says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>holds</b> that one derives this <b>verbal analogy, and this</b> is what he <b>is saying: But is</b> the word: <b>Hand, stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood? <b>Since</b> the word: <b>Hand, is not stated with regard to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>but</b> the word <b>“finger”</b> is stated, <b>and collection cannot</b> be performed <b>with a finger</b> alone, one must conclude that the word “finger” must actually be referring to the placing of the blood. Therefore, while the placing of the blood must be performed with the right hand, if <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rav Samma, son of Rav Ashi, said to Ravina:</b> But <b>it is possible to fashion</b> a small <b>handle for the rim of</b> the <b>bowl,</b> and one could then hold the bowl with his finger <b>and collect</b> the blood <b>in it.</b> If so, it is possible for one to collect the blood with only his finger.
<b>Rather, Abaye says:</b>

Daf 24b

<b>They disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>a verse is interpreted</b> based on juxtaposition to the language <b>preceding it and</b> to the language <b>following it.</b> According to Rabbi Shimon, a verse is interpreted only based on the language following it. Therefore, when the verse states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put it upon the corners of the altar,” the word “finger” is referring only to the placing of the blood and not its collection. The Rabbis hold that the verse is also interpreted based on the language preceding it. Accordingly, they require that both rites be performed with the right hand.
<b>Abaye says: This</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, diverges from</b> the opinion <b>of his father, and it diverges from</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis: As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says:</b> In <b>every instance</b> in the Torah <b>that</b> the word <b>“finger” is stated with regard to collection</b> of the blood and not with regard to placing of the blood on the altar, if the priest <b>deviated</b> from the proper method <b>of collection</b> and performed it with the left hand, the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> but if he deviated from the proper method <b>of placing</b> the blood, the offering remains <b>fit. And</b> in <b>every instance that</b> the word <b>“finger” is stated</b> only <b>with regard to placing</b> the blood, if the priest <b>deviated</b> from the proper method <b>of placing,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> but if he deviated from the proper method <b>of collection,</b> the offering remains <b>fit.</b>
<b>And where is</b> the word <b>“finger” stated</b> only <b>with regard to placing? As it is written: “And you shall take of the blood of the bullock and put it upon the corners of the altar with your finger”</b> (Exodus 29:12). <b>And he holds</b> that <b>a verse is interpreted</b> based on juxtaposition to the language immediately <b>preceding it and not</b> to the language <b>before that</b> which immediately <b>precedes it, nor</b> to the language <b>following it.</b>
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In <b>every instance</b> in the Torah <b>that it is stated</b> that an action is performed with <b>a finger and</b> by members of the <b>priesthood,</b> it may be performed <b>only</b> with the <b>right</b> hand.
The Gemara comments: It might <b>enter our mind</b> to say that this means that <b>we require both</b> a finger and the priesthood to be stated together in the verse in order to mandate use of the right hand, e.g., <b>as it is written: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger”</b> (Leviticus 4:25). <b>And</b> the fact that this verse is referring to a finger from his right hand <b>is derived from a leper, as it is written: “And the priest shall dip his right finger”</b> (Leviticus 14:16). This cannot be correct, <b>as</b> there is the verse that addresses <b>the removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>in which only</b> the <b>priesthood is written, and</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Menaḥot</i> 6a): If one <b>removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the meal offering is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> This statement means that if the verse mentions <b>either a finger or</b> the <b>priesthood,</b> only the right hand may be used.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: But this is contradicted by the verse discussing <b>the conveyance of</b> the <b>limbs</b> of the daily burnt offering <b>to the ramp</b> of the altar, <b>as priesthood is written with regard to it, as it is written: “And the priest shall sacrifice the whole</b> and make it smoke <b>upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:13), <b>and the Master said</b> that <b>this</b> verse is referring to the <b>conveyance of</b> the <b>limbs to the ramp. And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 31b): When the priest conveys the limbs to the ramp, <b>the foot of</b> the <b>right</b> side of the offering is carried <b>in the left</b> hand <b>of</b> the priest, <b>and the place of its skin,</b> i.e., the side of the limb covered in skin, is held facing <b>outward.</b> Clearly, use of the left hand does not disqualify the conveyance of the limbs.
The Gemara responds: <b>When we say</b> that if the verse states <b>either finger or priesthood</b> then the left hand is disqualified, this is only <b>with regard to a matter that precludes atonement,</b> i.e., a rite whose performance is indispensable to the atonement, <b>similar to</b> the sprinkling of the oil on the <b>leper</b> (see Leviticus 14:16). The conveyance of the limbs, by contrast, is not indispensable to atonement.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there the <b>collection</b> of the blood in a service vessel, <b>about which priesthood is written and</b> which <b>is a matter that precludes atonement? And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the blood is <b>disqualified</b> for offering, <b>and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Shimon requires</b> that <b>both</b> matters appear in the verse, i.e., both finger and priesthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rabbi Shimon</b> really <b>require both? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In <b>every instance</b> in the Torah <b>that</b> the word <b>“hand” is stated,</b> the verse <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to the <b>right</b> hand, and whenever the verse mentions <b>“finger,”</b> it <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to a finger of the <b>right</b> hand?
The Gemara responds: According to Rabbi Shimon, if the verse mentions only <b>“finger,”</b> then it <b>does not require</b> a mention of the <b>priesthood</b> as well for the limitation to apply. But if the verse mentions only the <b>priesthood,</b> it <b>requires</b> a mention of <b>“finger”</b> for the limitation to apply.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to Rabbi Shimon, if the mention of the priesthood alone does not suffice to disqualify the right hand, then <b>why do I</b> need the superfluous reference to <b>a priest</b> with regard to the collection of the blood? After all, the verse already states that the collection must be performed by the sons of Aaron. The Gemara responds: The additional mention of the priesthood indicates that the priests must perform the collection of the blood <b>in their priestly state,</b> i.e., while wearing the priestly vestments.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>concerning which only</b> the <b>priesthood is written</b> in the verse, <b>and we learned:</b> If <b>one sprinkled</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand it is <b>disqualified; and Rabbi Shimon does not disagree</b> with this ruling, indicating that Rabbi Shimon holds that a mention of the priesthood does not require a mention of “finger”?
<b>Abaye says: He disagrees</b> with this ruling <b>in a <i>baraita</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, it is <b>disqualified, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b> Additionally, if <b>one sprinkled</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, it is <b>disqualified, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But that which Rava says</b> with regard to the superfluous phrases in the passage discussing a leper: One derives a verbal analogy between <b>“hand”</b> and <b>“hand”</b> mentioned with regard <b>to the removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering, to indicate that the latter must also be performed with the right hand. Additionally, one derives a verbal analogy between <b>“foot”</b> and <b>“foot”</b> mentioned with regard <b>to</b> the <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> ritual. And one derives a verbal analogy between <b>“ear”</b> and <b>“ear”</b> mentioned with regard <b>to</b> the <b>piercing</b> of a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl. One may ask: <b>Why do I</b> need the first analogy? The requirement that the handful be removed with the right hand can be <b>derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> above, since priesthood is mentioned in the verse describing it.
The Gemara responds: Both derivations are necessary, <b>one for</b> the removal of the <b>handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>and one for the sanctification of</b> the <b>handful,</b> i.e., placing it into a second service vessel. Both must be performed with the right hand.

Daf 25a

The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Shimon, who does not require sanctification of</b> the <b>handful, or according to the one who says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon also requires</b> the <b>sanctification of</b> the <b>handful</b> but that <b>he deems</b> the sanctification <b>fit</b> when performed <b>with</b> the <b>left</b> hand, <b>why do I</b> need the verbal analogy <b>of Rava</b> between <b>“hand”</b> and <b>“hand”?</b>
<b>If</b> one suggests that it is necessary <b>to</b> indicate that the <b>removal of</b> the <b>handful itself</b> must be performed with the right hand, this cannot be, since that is <b>derived from</b> the verse cited by <b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya. As Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: What is the reason that Rabbi Shimon</b> does not require that the handful be sanctified in a service vessel? <b>As the verse states</b> with regard to the meal offering: <b>“It is most holy, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:10).
The verse compares the meal offering to a sin offering and a guilt offering. Therefore, if the priest <b>comes to perform</b> the burning of the handful <b>with</b> his <b>hand,</b> then <b>he performs it with</b> his <b>right</b> hand, <b>like a sin offering,</b> whose blood is sprinkled by hand. And if he <b>comes to perform it with a vessel,</b> i.e., if he first sanctifies the handful in a service vessel, then <b>he</b> may <b>perform it with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>like a guilt offering,</b> whose blood is sprinkled from a vessel. Since the removal of the handful is performed by hand, the verse indicates that it must be performed with the right hand, and the verbal analogy is unnecessary.
The Gemara responds: The verbal analogy <b>is necessary only for the handful of a meal offering of a sinner,</b> to teach that it must be removed with the right hand. It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Shimon says</b> that this offering does not require oil and frankincense <b>so that his offering will not be of superior</b> quality, perhaps <b>when he removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, which is an inferior manner, <b>it should be fit as well.</b> The verbal analogy therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the handful must always be removed with the right hand, even in the case of the meal offering of a sinner.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>the blood spilled on the floor</b> before the priest managed to collect it into a vessel, <b>and</b> the priest then <b>collected it</b> from the floor into a vessel, it is <b>disqualified.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“And the anointed priest shall take from the blood of the bull [<i>middam happar</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 4:5). This means that the priest shall take <b>from the blood of the soul,</b> i.e., the blood that flows from the place of slaughter as the animal dies, <b>but not from the blood of the skin,</b> which bleeds out when the skin is cut before the slaughter, <b>nor from the blood of exudate,</b> i.e., that exudes from the neck of the animal after the initial spurt of its slaughter concludes.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: When the verse states: <b>“From the blood of the bull,”</b> it should be interpreted as if it is written: <b>He shall collect the blood from the bull,</b> i.e., if the blood spills onto the floor before it is collected in a service vessel, it is disqualified. <b>As, if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that <b>“from the blood of the bull”</b> should be interpreted <b>as it is written,</b> i.e., that <b>“from the blood”</b> means that the priest may collect <b>even</b> only <b>a portion of the blood,</b> that is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rav say: One who slaughters</b> the offering <b>must collect all the blood of</b> the <b>bull, as it is stated: “And all the blood of the bull he shall pour out</b> on the base of the altar” (Leviticus 4:7)? The verse emphasizes that the priest must pour all the blood of the bull, which is possible only if he has collected all of it.
<b>Rather, “from the blood of the bull”</b> means that the priest <b>shall collect</b> the <b>blood from the bull. And</b> this Sage <b>holds</b> that the Sages <b>subtract and add and interpret homiletically,</b> i.e., one may take a letter from one word, insert it into a second word, and explain the phrase in that manner. In this case, the <i>mem</i> of <i>middam</i> is added to <i>happar</i>, so that the verse is interpreted as though it states: <i>Dam mehappar</i>, meaning: Blood from the bull.
§ The Gemara turns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: One who slaughters</b> the offering <b>must collect all the blood of</b> the <b>bull, as it is stated: “And all the blood of the bull he shall pour out</b> on the base of the altar.” The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> this verse <b>written with regard to the remainder</b> of the blood that is poured onto the base of the altar after the sprinkling? How, then, can a <i>halakha</i> with regard to the collection of the blood be derived from it?
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> this verse <b>is not</b> referring <b>to the matter of the remainder</b> of the blood after sprinkling, <b>as not all of the blood is</b> present for that rite since some of it has already been sprinkled, <b>apply it</b> instead to <b>the matter of collection</b> of the blood from the animal.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One who slaughters</b> the offering <b>must hold the knife up</b> after slaughter, so that blood that is on the knife does not fall into the service vessel, <b>as it is stated: “And</b> the anointed priest <b>shall take from the blood of the bull,”</b> i.e., <b>and not from</b> a mixture of <b>the blood of the bull and something else,</b> such as the blood from the knife.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with what does he wipe</b> the <b>blood</b> from the <b>knife? Abaye says:</b> He wipes it <b>with the rim of</b> the <b>bowl</b> used to collect the blood, <b>as it is written</b> of the bowls used to collect the blood: <b>“Atoning-bowls [<i>keforei</i>] of gold”</b> (Ezra 1:10). The root <i>kaf</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>reish</i> can also mean to wipe.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says: One who slaughters</b> the offering <b>must place</b>

Daf 25b

the <b>veins</b> of the offering <b>into the vessel,</b> so that all the blood will empty into it. <b>It was also stated: Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b>veins must see the airspace of</b> the <b>vessel.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Asi raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If the priest <b>was collecting</b> the blood, <b>and the bottom of the bowl broke before</b> the <b>blood reached the</b> bowl’s <b>airspace, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is blood that enters the <b>airspace</b> of a bowl <b>that will not ultimately</b> allow it <b>to settle</b> inside nevertheless <b>considered as</b> though it <b>settled</b> inside the vessel, so that when it spills through the break it is considered to have already been collected in the bowl? If so, it remains fit for sprinkling. <b>Or</b> is it <b>not considered as</b> though it <b>settled,</b> but is instead considered to have spilled directly from the animal’s neck onto the floor, and is therefore disqualified?
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: You learned</b> the answer in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a barrel that is placed under a pipe</b> to catch water running from it, both the <b>water that</b> has already flowed <b>inside</b> the barrel <b>and</b> that <b>which is</b> still <b>outside it</b> but about to fall in are <b>unfit</b> to be used as water of purification, which purify one who contracts impurity from a corpse. The water of purification must be flowing water, and all of this water is considered to have been collected in the barrel. But if one <b>joined the mouth of</b> the barrel <b>to the pipe,</b> the <b>water that is inside</b> the barrel is <b>unfit, but</b> water <b>that is</b> still <b>outside it</b> is <b>fit,</b> even though it will ultimately fall in, since it is still in the pipe and is not considered to be above the airspace of the barrel. One can infer from the <i>baraita</i> that all liquid that enters the airspace of a vessel is considered to have been collected in it.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What is this</b> comparison? Rabbi Asi <b>raises a dilemma before</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to a case where an item enters the <b>airspace</b> of a vessel <b>that will not ultimately</b> allow it <b>to settle</b> inside, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>resolves</b> the dilemma by citing a case where the item enters the <b>airspace</b> of a vessel <b>that will ultimately</b> allow it <b>to settle</b> inside.
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Asi <b>raises two dilemmas before</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: First, what is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an item that will not come to rest in the vessel? Second, <b>if you say</b> that an item that enters the <b>airspace</b> of a vessel <b>that will not ultimately</b> allow it <b>to settle</b> inside is <b>not considered as</b> though it <b>settled</b> inside the vessel, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an item that entered the <b>airspace</b> of a vessel <b>that will ultimately</b> allow it <b>to settle</b> inside?
The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Yosef teaches</b> the exchange in <b>this</b> manner, i.e., as recounted. <b>Rav Kahana teaches</b> it as follows: Rabbi Asi <b>raised the dilemma before</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to <b>a barrel,</b> asking whether the water in its airspace is fit to be used for the water of purification, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>resolved</b> the dilemma <b>for him</b> by citing the <i>baraita</i> mentioning <b>a barrel,</b> with which he was unfamiliar.
<b>Rabba teaches</b> the exchange as follows: Rabbi Asi <b>raised the dilemma before</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to <b>a barrel, and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>resolved</b> the dilemma <b>for him</b> by citing the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a bowl</b> used to collect the blood in the Temple, saying: <b>Do you not concede with regard to the bowl that it is impossible to</b> collect the blood in <b>it without a stream</b> of blood flowing through the air from animal’s neck? If the air above the bowl is not considered part of the bowl, the blood would be considered to have entered the bowl from the air above rather than directly from the animal’s neck, and all collected blood would be unfit. Therefore, the airspace must be considered part of the bowl, and the same holds for the barrel with regard to the water of purification.
The Gemara adds: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Para</i> 6:4) with regard to sanctifying the water of purification: If one <b>placed his hand or his foot or vegetable leaves in order</b> to allow flowing <b>water to pass</b> through them <b>to</b> the <b>barrel,</b> the water is <b>disqualified.</b> But if the water passed through <b>leaves of reeds or leaves of nuts,</b> the water remains <b>fit. This is the principle:</b> If the water passes through <b>an item that is susceptible to impurity,</b> it is <b>disqualified;</b> if it passes through <b>an item that is not susceptible to impurity,</b> it is <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Abba: The verse states: “Nevertheless a fountain or a cistern wherein is a gathering of water shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 11:36). The verse indicates that <b>their being must be by way of purity,</b> i.e., the gathering of the water must not be accomplished by way of items susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Since this mishna states that water that flows over one’s hand through the air into the barrel is disqualified, <b>that is to say</b> that the <b>airspace</b> above <b>a vessel</b> is <b>considered as</b> though it were part of the <b>vessel</b> itself. If it were not, the water would not be considered to have flowed directly from the hand to the vessel, but rather from the air above the vessel. Since air is not susceptible to impurity, the water would not be disqualified.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: But perhaps</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the water <b>flows weakly</b> straight from the hand into the vessel itself, since the hand is situated directly on the edge of the vessel, with no air separating them? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <b>said to him: Imbecile, we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>In order</b> to allow flowing <b>water to pass</b> through them <b>to</b> the <b>barrel.</b> This indicates that the water is traveling in a stream and will pass through the air before reaching the barrel.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This mishna</b> concerning the barrel <b>was taught from the testimony of Rabbi Tzadok, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 7:4): <b>Rabbi Tzadok testified with regard to rivulets that one diverted</b> by way of a pipe made <b>with leaves of nuts that</b> their water is <b>fit</b> to be used as water of purification. <b>This was an incident in</b> the town of <b>Ohalya, and</b> an account of the <b>incident came before the Sages in the Chamber of Hewn Stone</b> in the Temple, <b>and they deemed</b> the water <b>fit.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> In the case of <b>one who slits the ear of the bull</b> with the knife after slaughter, creating a blemish, <b>and thereafter collected its blood</b> from the neck, the offering is <b>disqualified, as it is stated: “And</b> the anointed priest <b>shall take from the blood of the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:5). By referring to the animal as a bull even after its slaughter, the verse indicates that the <b>bull</b> must be at the time of collection of the blood as <b>it already was</b> before slaughter, without a blemish.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> since the verse is referring to such an offering; <b>from where do we</b> derive that the same holds for <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b>
<b>Rava says: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the Paschal offering, an offering of lesser sanctity: The verse states: <b>“A lamb without blemish, a male of the first year</b> it shall be for you” (Exodus 12:5), indicating <b>that it shall be unblemished and in its</b> first <b>year at the time of slaughter. From where</b> is it derived that it must also be without blemish <b>at</b> the time of <b>collection</b> of the blood, <b>at</b> the time of <b>conveying</b> the blood to the altar, and <b>at</b> the time of the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood? <b>The verse states: “It shall be,”</b> emphasizing that <b>all its happenings shall be only</b> when it is <b>unblemished and in its</b> first <b>year.</b>
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> this from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>any of the</b> types of <b>offerings that</b> are mentioned <b>in the Torah from which there remains</b> either <b>an olive-bulk of flesh or an olive-bulk of fat,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the priest <b>sprinkles the blood</b> of that offering. Apparently, one may sprinkle the blood even if much of the offering is damaged or missing.
The Gemara responds: <b>Interpret</b> the verse as referring only <b>to</b> the requirement that the animal be <b>in its</b> first <b>year</b> until after the sprinkling. It may have a blemish at the time of sprinkling.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But is there any</b> case <b>where</b> the animal is <b>in its</b> first <b>year at the time of slaughter,</b> but <b>at the time of conveying</b> the blood to the altar <b>and sprinkling</b> the blood it is <b>in its second</b> year?
<b>Rava says: That is to say</b> that <b>hours disqualify sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., one measures the age of the offering from the exact time of its birth. It is therefore possible that the animal reaches its second year between its slaughter and the conveying of its blood to the altar.
§ <b>Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> In a case where the animal is standing <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>but its legs</b> are planted <b>outside</b> it, if one <b>severed</b> its legs <b>and thereafter slaughtered</b> it, the offering is <b>fit,</b> since all the blood collected in the bowl is from the portion of the animal standing in the courtyard.

Daf 26a

But if he <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>and thereafter severed</b> its legs, the offering is <b>disqualified</b> because some of the blood collected is from the legs, which are outside the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: If he <b>severed</b> its legs <b>and thereafter slaughtered</b> it, is the offering <b>fit?</b> But isn’t <b>he sacrificing a blemished</b> animal? <b>Rather, say:</b> If one slaughtered the animal while it stood wholly in the courtyard, and afterward its legs moved beyond the edge of the courtyard, and then he <b>severed</b> its legs <b>and thereafter collected</b> the blood, the offering is <b>fit.</b> But if he <b>collected</b> the blood <b>and thereafter severed</b> the animal’s legs, the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> since the blood from the legs is mixed with the other blood of the animal.
The Gemara challenges: If he <b>severed</b> its legs <b>and thereafter collected</b> the blood, is the offering <b>fit? But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say:</b> If one <b>slits the ear of a firstborn</b> animal with the knife after slaughter, creating a blemish, <b>and thereafter collected its blood</b> from the neck, the offering is <b>disqualified, as it is stated: “And</b> the anointed priest <b>shall take from the blood of the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:5)? The verse indicates that the <b>bull</b> must be at the time of collection of the blood as <b>it already was</b> before slaughter, without a blemish.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Avimi says:</b> Rabbi Ami is not referring to a case where one severs the entire leg. Rather, one <b>cuts</b> the flesh <b>of the limb until he reaches the bone,</b> leaving the bone intact. This is not considered a blemish, and the animal remains fit for sacrifice.
The Gemara suggests: Given that if he <b>collected</b> the blood <b>and thereafter severed</b> the animal’s legs, the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> perhaps <b>you</b> can <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>blood absorbed in the limbs</b> of an animal <b>is</b> considered <b>blood,</b> such that it disqualifies the offering because this blood left the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps</b> the offering is disqualified <b>because of</b> the animal’s <b>fat</b> that is mixed with the blood in the legs. This is considered to be like meat of the offering that has left the Temple courtyard, which also disqualifies the offering.
The Gemara suggests: If so, perhaps <b>you</b> can <b>conclude</b> another <i>halakha</i> <b>from it:</b> In the case of <b>meat of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the <b>blood,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> even though the meat of such offerings may be eaten outside the Temple after the blood has been sprinkled.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>halakha</i> was stated only <b>with regard to offerings of the most sacred order,</b> whose meat must be eaten inside the Temple courtyard. It proves nothing about offerings of lesser sanctity.
The Gemara suggests: Come and hear a proof from that which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, their slaughter is in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>and collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north.</b> If one <b>stood in the south and extended his hand into the north and slaughtered</b> the offering there, <b>his slaughter</b> is <b>valid.</b> If he <b>collected</b> the blood in a similar manner, <b>his collection</b> is <b>not valid.</b> If <b>he inserted his head and most of his</b> body into the north of the courtyard and collected the blood there, it is <b>as if his entire</b> body <b>entered</b> the north. If he slaughtered the animal and it then <b>convulsed and left</b> the north <b>to the south and</b> then <b>returned</b> to the north, it remains <b>fit.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, their slaughter is</b> anywhere <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is anywhere <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard. If one <b>stood outside and inserted his hand into</b> the courtyard <b>and slaughtered</b> the offering there, <b>his slaughter</b> is <b>valid.</b> If he <b>collected</b> the blood in a similar manner, <b>his collection</b> is <b>not valid. And</b> if he <b>inserted his head and most of his</b> body into the courtyard and collected the blood, it is <b>as if he had not entered</b> it at all. If he slaughtered the animal and it then <b>convulsed and left to the outside</b> of the courtyard <b>and returned,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that in cases of <b>meat of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the <b>blood,</b> the offerings <b>are disqualified.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> the <b>tail,</b> the <b>diaphragm, and</b> the <b>two kidneys</b> of offerings of lesser sanctity, which are all burned on the altar. Since these portions are never meant to leave the Temple courtyard, they are disqualified if they leave even momentarily. It may still be that the remaining meat of such offerings is not disqualified.
§ <b>Shmuel’s father raised a dilemma before Shmuel:</b> If the offering was standing <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and its legs</b> were <b>outside, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May one slaughter it?
Shmuel <b>said to him: It is written: “That they may bring them to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 17:5), indicating that the offering may not be slaughtered <b>unless all of it is inside.</b>
His father asked him further: If one <b>suspended</b> the animal in the air <b>and slaughtered</b> it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>valid.</b> His father <b>said to him: You are mistaken. We require</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> occur <b>on</b> the <b>side</b> of the altar (see Leviticus 1:11), <b>and</b> this is <b>not</b> considered to fulfill that requirement.
His father asked him further: If the one slaughtering the animal <b>was suspended</b> in the air <b>and slaughtered</b> the offering while it was on the ground, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>not valid.</b> His father <b>said to him: You are mistaken.</b> We require only that the <b>slaughter</b> occur <b>on</b> the <b>side</b> of the altar, <b>but not</b> that the <b>one who slaughters</b> be <b>on</b> the <b>side</b> of the altar.
His father asked him further: If the priest <b>was suspended</b> in the air <b>and collected</b> the blood of the offering in that position, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>valid.</b> His father <b>said to him: You are mistaken. This is not</b> a normal <b>manner of ministration.</b>
His father asked him further: If the priest <b>suspended</b> the offering in the air after slaughter <b>and collected</b> its blood, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>not valid.</b> His father <b>said to him: You are mistaken.</b> We require only that the <b>slaughter</b> occur <b>on</b> the <b>side</b> of the altar, <b>but not</b> that <b>collection</b> of the blood occur <b>on</b> the <b>side</b> of the altar.
<b>Abaye said: With regard to offerings of the most sacred order,</b> in <b>all of</b> those cases the offerings <b>are disqualified, except for</b> the case where one <b>was suspended</b> in the air <b>and slaughtered</b> the animal. <b>With regard to offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> in <b>all of</b> those cases the offerings <b>are fit, except for</b> the case where the priest <b>was suspended</b> in the air <b>and collected</b> the blood.
<b>Rava said: What is different</b> about a case where one <b>suspended</b> the animal <b>and collected</b> the blood of an <b>offering of lesser sanctity,</b> such <b>that</b> the offering is <b>fit?</b> Perhaps it is <b>because the air inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>is considered</b> to be <b>inside</b> the courtyard for purposes of the service. But if so, then <b>with regard to offerings of the most sacred order as well,</b> let one say that <b>air</b> in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>is considered</b> to be in the <b>north</b> for purposes of the service.
<b>Rather, Rava says: Both with regard to offerings of the most sacred order and with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> they <b>are fit</b> in all of those cases <b>except</b> where one <b>suspended</b> the animal <b>and slaughtered</b> it <b>in</b> the case of <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> because the Torah mandates that such offerings be slaughtered on the side of the altar. And the offerings are also disqualified where the priest <b>was suspended</b> in the air <b>and collected</b> the blood, <b>both with regard to offerings of the most sacred order and with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> since this is not a normal manner of ministration.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> If the priest was <b>inside and his fringes,</b> i.e., his hair, were <b>outside,</b> and he collected the blood, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Did you not say</b> that the verse: <b>“That they may bring them to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 17:5), indicates that an offering may not be slaughtered <b>unless all of it comes inside? Here, too,</b> the verse states with regard to the priests: <b>“When they go into the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Exodus 28:43), indicating that the priest may not perform rites <b>unless all of him comes into the Tent of Meeting.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the priest <b>placed</b> the blood <b>upon the ramp</b> leading up to the altar, or if he placed it on the wall of the altar in an area <b>that</b> is <b>not opposite the base</b> of the altar, i.e., in those parts of the altar where there is no foundation; or if <b>he placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line that runs along the middle of the altar, e.g., the blood of a burnt offering, <b>above</b> the red line, <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line, e.g., the blood of a sin offering, <b>below</b> the red line; <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., on the golden altar or in the Holy of Holies, <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary on the external altar, <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, in all these cases the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> Nevertheless, <b>there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of these offerings.

Daf 26b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Shmuel says:</b> When the mishna states that the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> it means that the <b>meat</b> is unfit for consumption. <b>But</b> the <b>owner</b> of the offering has <b>achieved atonement</b> through it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>as the verse states</b> with regard to the blood: <b>“And I have given it to you upon the altar to atone</b> for your souls” (Leviticus 17:11), from which it is derived that <b>once the blood reaches</b> any location on <b>the altar,</b> the <b>owner</b> of the offering has <b>achieved atonement.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> the <b>meat</b> should be fit for consumption <b>as well.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The verse states “to atone,”</b> emphasizing that <b>I have given it</b> to you <b>for atonement and for nothing else,</b> e.g., consumption of the meat.
The Gemara notes: <b>Apparently,</b> Shmuel <b>holds</b> that blood sprinkled <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place is considered as</b> though it were sprinkled in <b>its</b> proper <b>place.</b> But <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>in another chapter</b> (32a): If an unfit person <b>placed</b> the blood <b>upon the ramp,</b> or on the wall of the altar <b>that</b> is <b>not opposite the base</b> of the altar; or if <b>he placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line; <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>or</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, then <b>if there is blood of the soul</b> that remains in the animal, <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>should collect</b> the blood <b>again</b> and sprinkle it on the altar.
The Gemara continues: <b>And if</b> it would <b>enter your mind</b> to say <b>that</b> blood sprinkled <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place</b> is considered <b>as</b> though it were sprinkled in <b>its</b> proper <b>place, why do I</b> need <b>the fit</b> priest to <b>collect</b> the blood <b>again</b> and sprinkle it? <b>And if you would say</b> that although the first sprinkling already effected atonement, the second sprinkling is necessary <b>to permit the meat</b> of the offering <b>for consumption, is there</b> such a concept as <b>a sprinkling that does not</b> itself <b>effect atonement and</b> yet <b>permits</b> the <b>meat for consumption?</b> Rather, one must conclude that the first sprinkling did not effect atonement at all, since it was not sprinkled in its proper place.
The Gemara responds: <b>If a fit</b> priest <b>had</b> initially <b>placed</b> the blood improperly, the sprinkling would <b>indeed</b> have effected atonement after the fact and there would not be another sprinkling. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where an unfit</b> person <b>placed</b> the blood, so that it did not effect atonement at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the mishna is dealing with a case where an unfit person placed the blood initially, then the offering <b>should be rejected</b> permanently, <b>as we learned</b> in the same mishna: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all</b> unfit people <b>who collected</b> the blood with the intent to offer it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, if there is blood of the soul</b> that remains in the animal, <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>should collect</b> the blood <b>again</b> and sprinkle it on the altar. Since the mishna states this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to collection of the blood, one can infer that specifically if an unfit person <b>collected</b> the blood with improper intent, a fit priest can <b>indeed</b> collect the blood again, but if they <b>sprinkled</b> the blood with improper intent he <b>cannot. What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because</b> the offering <b>is rejected</b> permanently when an unfit person sprinkles its blood?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the offering is rejected <b>because it is disqualified by</b> the improper <b>intent</b> of the person sprinkling the blood, not because that person is unfit.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then improper intent with regard to <b>collection</b> of the blood should disqualify the offering <b>as well. And furthermore, does intent disqualify</b> offerings in such cases? <b>But doesn’t Rava say: Intent is effective</b> to disqualify an offer-ing <b>only</b> when it is expressed <b>by one who is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service, and with regard to an item that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service, and in a place that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service?</b> Here, the one collecting the blood is unfit.
The Gemara responds: <b>Do not say</b> that one infers from the mishna that if an unfit person <b>sprinkled</b> the blood with improper intent a fit priest <b>cannot</b> collect it again. <b>Rather, say</b> that one infers that if an unfit person <b>slaughtered</b> the offering with improper intent the mistake <b>cannot</b> be rectified. Slaughter is valid if performed by one unfit for the Temple service, and therefore an unfit person’s improper intent is effective to disqualify the offering. By contrast, collection and sprinkling of the blood must be performed by a fit priest. Consequently, an unfit person’s intent with regard to those rites does not disqualify the offering.
The Gemara asks: According to this interpretation, <b>what is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us?</b> Can it mean to teach only <b>that</b> improper <b>intent</b> by an unfit person during slaughter <b>disqualifies</b> the offering? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this in the same mishna (31b), which states: With regard to all those who are unfit for Temple service who slaughtered an offering, their slaughter is valid, and <b>therefore, these</b> unfit people <b>disqualify</b> the offering <b>with</b> improper <b>intent.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us: That</b> one who is unfit can disqualify the offering only during its slaughter, but <b>from</b> the rite of <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>onward</b> the <b>intent</b> of an unfit person <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>like that which Rava</b> says: Intent is effective to disqualify an offering only when expressed by one who is fit for the service in question.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one slaughtered an offering and <b>had intent to place</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, or to place the blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, and he had intent to do so <b>immediately,</b> i.e., on the same day, the offering remains <b>fit.</b> Therefore, if <b>he subsequently had intent</b> when performing the other rites

Daf 27a

to burn or eat the offering or sprinkle its blood <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b> But if he had intent to perform one of those actions <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> then it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b>
If he had intent to sprinkle the blood improperly <b>the next day,</b> beyond the permitted time, then the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> Nevertheless, it is not rendered <i>piggul</i>, because he also had intent to sprinkle the blood improperly. Therefore, if <b>he subsequently had intent</b> to sacrifice the offering or consume its meat, <b>whether beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> it is <b>disqualified and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it,</b> because an offering can be rendered <i>piggul</i> only if it would have otherwise been fit.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if</b> blood sprinkled <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place</b> is considered <b>as</b> though it were sprinkled in <b>its</b> proper <b>place,</b> then in <b>this</b> case above, where he had intent to sprinkle the blood improperly the next day, is the offering merely <b>disqualified?</b> Since <b>it is</b> considered as though he had intent to sprinkle the blood properly the next day, shouldn’t the offering be rendered <b><i>piggul</i>?</b>
<b>Mar Zutra said:</b> Intent with regard to <b>sprinkling that permits</b> the <b>meat for consumption</b> can <b>cause</b> the offering <b>to</b> become <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> Intent with regard to <b>sprinkling that does not render</b> the <b>meat permitted for consumption does not cause</b> it <b>to</b> become <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> Even Shmuel concedes that although the owner achieves atonement, if the blood is sprinkled in an improper place the meat may not be consumed. Accordingly, this offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Mar Zutra: From where do you</b> derive <b>this?</b> Mar Zutra replied: I derive it from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And if any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten</b> on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be credited to he who offers it, <b>it shall be <i>piggul</i>”</b> (Leviticus 7:18). The verse indicates that only an offering <b>whose</b> intent of <b><i>piggul</i></b> alone <b>caused it</b> to be disqualified is considered <i>piggul</i>. <b>Excluded is this</b> case, <b>whose</b> intent of <b><i>piggul</i></b> alone <b>did not cause it</b> to be disqualified; <b>rather, the prohibition of something else,</b> i.e., the intent to sprinkle the blood in an improper location, <b>caused it</b> to be disqualified.
The Gemara challenges: But <b>if so,</b> i.e., if blood applied not in its proper place is considered as though it were applied in its proper place, and the intent to sprinkle the blood the next day does not render the offering <i>piggul</i>, then <b>it should not even be disqualified</b> due to such an intention. Why, then, does the <i>baraita</i> rule that it is disqualified?
