<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> In general, intent to perform the rites of an offering beyond its designated time disqualifies the offering, even when it does not render it <i>piggul</i>, <b>just as is</b> the case <b>with regard to the intent to leave</b> portions of the offering for the next day, as taught in a mishna in the next chapter (35b), <b>and according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> there, that intent to leave the blood until the next day rather than sprinkling it on the altar disqualifies the offering even though it does not render it <i>piggul</i>.
§ The Gemara cites additional opinions with regard to the statement of the mishna that blood misapplied on the altar disqualifies the offering. <b>Reish Lakish says: Actually,</b> when the mishna states that the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> this is to be taken <b>literally,</b> i.e., that the owner does not even achieve atonement through it. <b>And</b> nevertheless, blood sprinkled <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place is considered as</b> though it were sprinkled in <b>its</b> proper <b>place,</b> and it effects atonement. <b>And</b> the apparent contradiction between these two claims is <b>not difficult: Here, where</b> misapplication of the blood effects atonement, it is a case <b>where he placed</b> it <b>in silence,</b> i.e., without specific intent; <b>there,</b> in the mishna, it is a case <b>where he placed</b> it <b>with a statement,</b> i.e., intent to consume the offering beyond its appointed time.
Since Reish Lakish agrees with the statement of Shmuel that blood applied not in its proper place is considered as though it were applied in its proper place, the Gemara poses the same difficulties to the statement of Reish Lakish as posed above to Shmuel: <b>We learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one slaughtered an offering and <b>had intent to place</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, or to place the blood that is to be placed <b>above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, etc., <b>until</b> the response of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: <b>Just as is</b> the case <b>with regard to the intent to leave</b> portions of the offering for the next day, <b>and according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, etc.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Both <b>here and there,</b> i.e., in the mishna here as well as in the mishna in the next chapter (32a), it is a case <b>where he placed</b> the blood <b>in silence. And</b> the mishna here rules that the offering is completely disqualified because blood applied <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place is not considered as</b> though it were applied in <b>its</b> proper <b>place. And that</b> mishna in the next chapter, which states that the blood may be collected and sprinkled again, is referring to a case <b>where there is blood of the soul</b> left in the animal to sprinkle again, while <b>this</b> mishna is referring to a case <b>where there is no blood of the soul</b> left.
The Gemara challenges: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that if the blood was misapplied on the altar, the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of the meat. <b>Granted, according to Reish Lakish,</b> who explains that the mishna is referring to one who expresses intent to sacrifice or consume the offering beyond its designated time, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: Disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it,</b> to stress that although one sprinkled the blood with intent of <i>piggul</i>, since the sprinkling was performed improperly, his intent does not render the offering <i>piggul</i>, and one who partakes of it is not liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
<b>But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who explains that the mishna is referring to a case where the blood was sprinkled with no specific intent, of <b>what</b> necessity is the clause: <b>There is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it?</b> Since the offering is disqualified because the blood was placed not in its proper place, and there was no intent of <i>piggul</i>, why would one think that there should be liability for <i>karet</i>? The Gemara responds: Indeed, this clause is <b>difficult</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Shmuel,</b> of <b>what</b> necessity is the clause: <b>There is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: If one placed</b> the blood improperly <b>with intent</b> that would otherwise render the offering <i>piggul</i>, the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it,</b> because such sprinkling would not have permitted the meat for consumption.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, if</b> blood sprinkled <b>not in its</b> proper <b>place is not considered as</b> though it were sprinkled in <b>its</b> proper <b>place, it should be as if it spilled from the</b> service <b>vessel onto the floor, and let</b> the priest <b>gather it up</b> and sprinkle it again properly. Why, then, does the mishna rule that it is disqualified?
The Gemara responds: The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says: He may not gather it up. As Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All concede with regard to</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>that</b> if <b>one placed it above</b> the red line, and likewise with regard to the blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the red line if one <b>placed it below</b> the red line, <b>not in accordance with</b> the procedure dictated by <b>its mitzva,</b> e.g., with the left hand or with improper intent, <b>he may not gather it up</b> again. <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>that one placed below</b> the red line, and blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the red line <b>that one placed above</b> the red line, <b>as Rabbi Yosei says: He may not gather it up, and Rabbi Shimon says: He may gather it up.</b>

Daf 27b

<b>And our mishna is in accordance with the statement of the one who says: He may not gather it up.</b>
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> says that <b>Avimi says: Everyone concedes with regard to</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>that</b> if <b>one placed it above</b> the red line <b>he may not gather it up</b> again. <b>And all the more so with regard to the</b> blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>that one placed below</b> the red line, <b>since the blood</b> placed <b>above</b> the red line will eventually run down the side of the altar and <b>reach below</b> the red line. <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>that one placed outside</b> on the external altar, or blood that is to be placed <b>outside that one placed inside, as Rabbi Yosei says: He may gather it up,</b> as though it had spilled on the floor, <b>and Rabbi Shimon says: He may not gather it up,</b> because the blood was nevertheless placed on an altar.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: We learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>as well</b> that if the blood is misapplied on the altar it may not be gathered, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the verse states: <b>“This</b> is the law of the burnt offering: <b>It is that which goes up [<i>ha’ola</i>]</b> on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2), from which it is derived that a disqualified offering that ascended upon the altar shall not descend from it. <b>These</b> terms, i.e., “this,” “it,” and “that,” <b>are</b> three terms of <b>exclusion,</b> which serve <b>to exclude</b> three cases of disqualified offerings from this <i>halakha</i>: An offering that <b>was slaughtered at night,</b> one <b>whose blood was spilled, and</b> one <b>whose blood emerged outside the curtains,</b> i.e., the Temple courtyard. In these cases, even <b>if</b> the offering <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall descend.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> From the term <b>“burnt offering [<i>ola</i>]” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a fit burnt offering</b> shall not descend. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>includes</b> an offering <b>that was slaughtered at night, or</b> one <b>whose blood was spilled, or</b> one <b>whose blood emerged outside the curtains, or</b> one <b>that was left overnight, or</b> one <b>that left</b> the courtyard, <b>or</b> one <b>that</b> became <b>impure, or</b> one <b>that was slaughtered</b> with intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, or</b> an offering for <b>which an unfit</b> person <b>collected and sprinkled its blood, or</b> a case where <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> it, <b>or</b> where <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> it, <b>or</b> where <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>outside</b> on the external altar, <b>or</b> where <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> it, <b>or a Paschal offering or a sin offering that one slaughtered not for their sake? From where</b> is it derived that if these offerings ascended they shall not descend?
<b>The verse states: “The law of the burnt offering [<i>ha’ola</i>],”</b> literally: That which goes up. The verse <b>included</b> under <b>one law all</b> items <b>that ascend</b> upon the altar, teaching <b>that if they ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even an animal that copulated with a person, or an animal that was the object of bestiality, or</b> an animal <b>that was set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>or</b> an animal <b>that was worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>or</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as <b>the price</b> of a dog, <b>or</b> an animal born of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds, or</b> an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, or</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section. The verse</b> therefore <b>states: “This,”</b> to exclude these animals from the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> as the reason <b>to include</b> the former cases <b>and to exclude</b> the latter ones? The Gemara responds: <b>I include these</b> former cases, <b>whose disqualification occurred in sanctity,</b> i.e., in the course of the Temple service, <b>and I exclude these</b> latter cases, <b>whose disqualification did not occur in sanctity</b> and were disqualified as offerings from the outset.
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak continues: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that if <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> it, <b>or</b> if <b>one placed</b> the blood that is to be placed <b>above</b> the red line <b>below</b> it, the offering does not descend from the altar. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda does not disagree,</b> even though he holds that if the blood spilled on the ground the offering descends from the altar. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because</b> even if the blood was misapplied, <b>the altar has absorbed</b> the blood and it is not considered to have been spilled on the floor? <b>Conclude from it</b> that if blood was misapplied on the altar, the priest <b>may not gather it up</b> again, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
§ Pursuant to the discussion of disqualified offerings that do not descend from the external altar, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The inner altar,</b> i.e., the golden altar inside the Sanctuary, <b>sanctifies disqualified</b> offerings such that if they ascended onto it, they do not descend.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this statement <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learn</b> this in the above <i>baraita</i>: If one placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary outside on the external altar, or if one placed the blood that is to be placed outside the Sanctuary inside it, on the golden altar, the offering does not descend.
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> one were to learn the <i>halakha</i> only <b>from there, I would say: This matter</b> applies only to <b>blood</b> mistakenly placed on the golden altar, <b>as it is fit to</b> be placed on that altar in certain contexts, i.e., the blood of the bull and goat sin offerings on Yom Kippur; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>which is not fit to</b> be placed on the golden altar in any context, <b>I will say</b> that it is <b>not</b> sanctified when placed on it. Rabbi Eliezer therefore <b>teaches us</b> that even a handful from a meal offering does not descend from it.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>strange incense,</b> i.e., incense that it is prohibited to burn on the golden altar, <b>ascended onto the altar, it shall descend, as only the external altar sanctifies disqualified</b> offerings that are <b>suited for it.</b> One can infer that the <b>external</b> altar <b>does</b> sanctify disqualified offerings, but the <b>inner</b> altar does <b>not.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Answer like this:</b> The <i>baraita</i> means that if <b>strange incense ascended onto the external altar, it shall descend, as the external altar sanctifies only disqualified</b> offerings <b>that are suited for it. But the inner</b> altar sanctifies everything, <b>whether it is suited for it or it is not suited for it. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>This,</b> the external altar, is considered part of the <b>floor,</b> since it is fixed to the floor of the Temple, <b>and that,</b> the inner altar, is considered <b>a service vessel</b> with a higher level of sanctity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who slaughters the offering</b> with intent <b>to sprinkle its blood outside</b> the Temple <b>or</b> to sprinkle <b>part of its blood outside</b> the Temple, <b>to burn its sacrificial portions outside</b> the Temple <b>or</b> to burn <b>part of its sacrificial portions outside</b> the Temple, <b>to partake of its meat outside</b> the Temple <b>or</b> to partake of <b>an olive-bulk of its meat outside</b> the Temple, <b>or to partake of an olive-bulk of the skin of the tail outside</b> the Temple, in all of these cases the offering is <b>disqualified, and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of it.
But if one had intent <b>to sprinkle its blood the next day</b> or <b>part of its blood the next day, to burn its sacrificial portions the next day or</b> to burn <b>part of its sacrificial portions the next day, to partake of its meat the next day or</b> to partake of <b>an olive-bulk of its meat the next day, or to partake of an olive-bulk of the skin of the tail the next day,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The students <b>assumed</b> that <b>the skin of the tail</b>

Daf 28a

<b>is considered as</b> though it were part of the <b>tail</b> itself. The tail of a sheep sacrificed as a peace offering is burned on the altar rather than eaten. <b>But</b> if so, one who slaughters the sheep with intent to consume the skin of its tail the next day <b>has intent</b> to shift its consumption <b>from consumption by</b> the <b>altar,</b> i.e., burning the offering, <b>to</b> consumption by <b>a person.</b> Since intent to consume part of an offering beyond its designated time renders an offering <i>piggul</i> only if that part is intended for human consumption, why does the mishna rule that such an offering is <i>piggul</i>?
<b>Shmuel says:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says: One can have intent</b> to shift an item’s consumption <b>from consumption by</b> the <b>altar to consumption by a person, or from consumption by a person to consumption by</b> the <b>altar,</b> and the offering will still be rendered <i>piggul</i>.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (35a): In a case of <b>one who slaughters the offering</b> with intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, or <b>to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not burn</b> it on the altar, beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, the offering is <b>fit. And Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>unfit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with which</b> opinion <b>did you interpret</b> the mishna here? You interpreted it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> But if so, <b>say the latter clause,</b> i.e., the next mishna (29b): <b>This is the principle: Anyone who slaughters</b> the animal, <b>or who collects</b> the blood, <b>or who conveys</b> the blood, <b>or who sprinkles</b> the blood with the intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>burns</b> it on the altar, beyond its designated time, renders it <i>piggul</i>.
One can infer that intent to partake of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it <b>does</b> render it <i>piggul</i>, while intent to partake of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it does <b>not</b> render it <i>piggul</i>. In this clause, <b>we arrive at</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Can it be that <b>the first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> while <b>the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: Yes.</b> That is how one must understand the mishna.
<b>Rav Huna says: The skin of</b> the <b>tail is not considered as</b> though it were the <b>tail</b> itself. Unlike the tail itself, its skin is consumed. Consequently, both this mishna and the next can be understood in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis. <b>Rava said: What is the reasoning of Rav Huna?</b> As the verse states: “And he shall present of the sacrifice of peace offerings an offering made by fire unto the Lord: <b>The fat thereof, the fat tail”</b> (Leviticus 3:9), indicating that the priest must offer the fat of the tail on the altar, <b>but not the skin of the tail.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: Actually, the skin of the tail is considered as</b> though it were the <b>tail</b> itself, and it is burned on the altar. <b>And here,</b> in the mishna, <b>we are dealing with the tail of a kid,</b> which is not burned on the altar but is consumed. Accordingly, intent to consume it outside its designated time renders it <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara notes: <b>All of them,</b> Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda, <b>do not say as Shmuel</b> says, since <b>they do not</b> wish to <b>interpret</b> that <b>the first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer and the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> And Shmuel and Rav Ḥisda <b>do not say as Rav Huna</b> says, since <b>they heard</b> that the <b>skin of</b> the <b>tail is considered as</b> though it were the <b>tail</b> itself.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Shmuel and Rav Huna <b>do not say as Rav Ḥisda</b> says, that the mishna is referring to the tail of a kid? The Gemara responds that they reason: According to Rav Ḥisda, <b>what is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us</b> by referring specifically to the skin of the tail? Does it mean to teach simply that the <b>skin of</b> the <b>tail is considered</b> edible, <b>like</b> the <b>tail</b> itself? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this in another mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 122a): <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose skin</b> has a halakhic status <b>like</b> that of <b>their meat,</b> since it is soft and edible: The <b>skin beneath the tail.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Ḥisda,</b> how would he respond? The Gemara answers: The reference here to the skin of the tail <b>was necessary,</b> as given only the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥullin</i>, it might <b>enter your mind to say: This matter,</b> the equation between the skin of the tail and the tail itself, applies only <b>with regard to the matter of ritual impurity, as</b> the skin of the tail is <b>soft</b> and edible, and it is therefore <b>counted</b> as part of the tail. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the matter of the Temple service, <b>I will say</b> that the verse states with regard to the gifts to which members of the priesthood are entitled: <b>“As a consecrated portion”</b> (Numbers 18:8), <b>to</b> indicate that they must be eaten in <b>greatness, in the way that the kings eat. And</b> since <b>kings do not generally eat</b> the skin of the tail, <b>I will say</b> that it is <b>not</b> considered an eaten portion of the offering. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that it is nevertheless considered like the tail itself.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who slaughters a burnt offering</b> with intent <b>to burn an olive-bulk of</b> the <b>skin beneath the tail outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> renders the offering <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of the offering. If his intent is to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating <b>it.</b> This is the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Elazar ben Yehuda of Avelim says in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, and so Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda of Kefar Ikos would say in the name of Rabbi Shimon: Whether</b> the <b>hide of the hooves</b> of <b>small livestock, or</b> the <b>skin of the head of a young calf, or</b> the <b>skin beneath the tail, or any</b> of the skins <b>that the Sages listed with regard to ritual impurity</b> under the heading: <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose skin</b> has a halakhic status <b>like</b> that of <b>their meat,</b> which means <b>to include the skin of the womb,</b> if one has intent to burn one of them <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it,</b> and if one’s intent is to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> he renders it <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b>
One can infer from the <i>baraita</i> that only with regard to <b>a burnt offering, yes,</b> the skin of the tail is burned on the altar like the tail itself. <b>But</b> with regard to another <b>offering,</b> this is <b>not</b> the <i>halakha</i>. <b>Granted, according to Rav Huna,</b> who holds that the skin of the tail of a peace offering is not considered as though it were the tail itself, and it is eaten rather than burned, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> about <b>a burnt offering</b> specifically, as all portions of a burnt offering are burned, even those that are eaten in the case of other offerings. <b>But according to Rav Ḥisda,</b> who holds that the skin of the tail is burned together with the tail, <b>why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> about <b>a burnt offering?</b> If the skin of the tail is always considered as though it were the tail itself, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> about any <b>offering.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda</b> could have <b>said to you: If you wish, say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to the tail of a kid,</b> which is never burned on the altar except in the case of a burnt offering. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that one should emend the text of the <i>baraita</i> to <b>teach:</b> One who slaughters any <b>offering,</b> etc.
§ The mishna states that if one intends to consume the meat or sprinkle the blood outside its designated area, the offering is <b>disqualified, and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of it. If one intends to do so beyond its designated time, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>, and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for burning or partaking of it. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Shmuel says: Two verses are written.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> these verses? <b>Rabba said:</b> Shmuel is referring to two phrases from the verse: “And if any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be credited to he who offers it; it shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18). The Sages taught that this verse is referring not to offerings actually eaten on the third day, but to one who performs one of the sacrificial rites with intent to eat the offering beyond its designated time. Now, when the verse states: “And if any of the flesh…be at all eaten on the <b>third</b> day,” <b>this is</b> referring to intent to consume the meat <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time.</b>
When the verse states: “It shall be <b><i>piggul</i>,” this is</b> referring to one who has intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b> And when the verse states: <b>“And the soul that eats of it</b> shall bear his iniquity,” i.e., shall be liable to receive <i>karet</i>, “of it” indicates that only <b>one</b> of the above disqualifications carries the penalty of <i>karet</i> for one who partakes of it, <b>but not two</b> of them. And <b>this</b> included case <b>is</b> intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, to the exclusion of</b> intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> which carries no such penalty.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> the opposite, that when the verse states: <b>“And the soul that eats of it</b> shall bear his iniquity,” <b>this is</b> referring to intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, to the exclusion of</b> intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>It stands to reason</b> that intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time</b> is the <b>preferable</b> candidate to carry the punishment of <i>karet</i>, <b>as</b> the verse <b>opened with it.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary,</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> is <b>preferable, as</b> the clause that teaches liability for <i>karet</i> is <b>adjacent to it.</b>
<b>Rather, Abaye said: When Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi came,</b> he said that <b>Rav says:</b> Shmuel was actually referring to two separate verses. And he <b>relied on that which the <i>tanna</i> taught:</b> The verse is seemingly redundant <b>when it states:</b> “And if it be eaten at all on the <b>third</b> day, it is <i>piggul</i>; it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 19:7), <b>in the</b> Torah <b>portion</b> that begins: <b>“You shall be holy”</b> (Leviticus 19:2), <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this, <b>since it is already stated: “And if any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten on the third day</b>…it shall be <i>piggul</i>” (Leviticus 7:18).

Daf 28b

Therefore, <b>if</b> the verse <b>is not</b> referring <b>to the matter</b> of intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, apply it to the matter of</b> intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area. And</b> as for the punishment of <i>karet</i>, <b>the Merciful One restricted</b> it to the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>,</b> i.e., actually partaking of the offering beyond its designated time, as the verse states: <b>“But whoever eats it shall bear his iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 19:8). This indicates that one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for partaking of <i>notar</i>, <b>to the exclusion of</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> instead that when the verse states: <b>“But whoever eats it shall bear his iniquity,” this is</b> referring to intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, and</b> the verse serves <b>to exclude <i>notar</i> from</b> the penalty of <b><i>karet</i>?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>It stands to reason</b> that <b><i>notar</i> should be interpreted as</b> carrying the penalty of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> because this would allow one <b>to derive</b> by way of verbal analogy between <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity”</b> stated with regard <b>to</b> the case of intent to consume the meat <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> that the punishment of <i>karet</i> applies to the latter as well. The verbal analogy would be apt <b>since</b> one prohibition <b>is similar to</b> the other <b>in</b> that they share features that form the acronym <b><i>zayin</i>, <i>beit</i>:</b> Both concern the offering’s designated time [<i>zeman</i>], and both are applicable to an offering sacrificed on a private altar [<i>bama</i>].
The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary,</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area should be interpreted as</b> carrying the penalty of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> because this would allow one <b>to derive</b> by way of verbal analogy between <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity”</b> stated with regard <b>to</b> the case of intent to consume the meat <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> that the punishment of <i>karet</i> applies to the latter as well. The verbal analogy would still be apt <b>since</b> one prohibition <b>is similar to</b> the other <b>in</b> that both share features that form the acronym <b><i>mikdash</i>:</b> Both concern intent [<i>maḥashava</i>]; both disqualify the entire offering even if one had intent with regard to only part [<i>ketzat</i>] of it; both occur while collecting or sprinkling the offering’s blood [<i>dam</i>]; and with regard to both the verse contains an extraneous mention of the third [<i>shelishi</i>] day.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>Zavdi bar Levi taught: It is derived</b> that the prohibition of <i>notar</i> carries the penalty of <i>karet</i> by way of verbal analogy between <b>“sacred”</b> and <b>“sacred.” It is written here:</b> “But whoever eats it shall bear his iniquity, because <b>he has profaned the sacred item of the Lord; and</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from his people” (Leviticus 19:8). <b>And it is written there:</b> “And if any of the flesh of the consecration, or of the bread, remain until the morning, <b>then you shall burn the remainder [<i>notar</i>] with fire;</b> it shall not be eaten, because it is sacred” (Exodus 29:34). <b>Just as</b> the verse <b>there</b> is referring to <b><i>notar</i>, so too,</b> there verse <b>here</b> is referring to <b><i>notar</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> consequently, when <b>the Merciful One restricted</b> the penalty of <i>karet</i> <b>to</b> the prohibition of eating <b><i>notar</i>,</b> as the verse states: <b>“But whoever eats it shall bear his iniquity,”</b> this restriction serves <b>to exclude</b> the case of intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area from</b> the penalty of <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara returns to the initial assumption that the statement of Shmuel is referring to two verses: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to conclude <b>that the long verse</b> (Leviticus 7:18) is referring <b>to</b> intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and</b> that the verse that mentions the <b>third</b> day (Leviticus 19:7) <b>in the</b> Torah <b>portion</b> that begins: <b>“You shall be holy,”</b> is referring to intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area? I</b> might just as well <b>reverse</b> the two.
The Gemara responds: <b>It stands to reason</b> that <b>the long</b> verse is referring <b>to</b> intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, as</b> this allows for one to <b>derive</b> by way of verbal analogy between <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity” from <i>notar</i></b> that an offering sacrificed with such intent carries the penalty of <i>karet</i>. The verbal analogy is apt <b>since</b> one prohibition <b>is similar to</b> the other <b>in</b> that both share the features mentioned above that form the acronym: <b><i>Zayin</i>, <i>beit</i>.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary,</b> it stands to reason that <b>the long</b> verse is referring <b>to</b> intent to consume the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, and</b> that the verse that mentions the <b>third</b> day <b>in</b> the Torah portion that begins: <b>“You shall be holy,”</b> is referring <b>to</b> intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time.</b> This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the latter intent is <b>similar to</b> <i>notar</i> in that both prohibitions share the features mentioned above that form the acronym: <i>Zayin</i>, <i>beit</i>, and it is therefore reasonable that the Torah <b>juxtaposed</b> the two in adjacent verses. <b>And</b> if so, when the verse states with regard to <i>notar</i>: “But whoever eats it shall bear his iniquity,” this <b>excludes</b> intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time from the penalty of <i>karet</i>.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> One must accept the original interpretation of Shmuel’s statement, that <b>all of</b> these <i>halakhot</i> with regard to intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time or outside its designated area <b>are derived from the long verse. As it is written:</b> “If any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be credited to he who offers it; it shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18). When the verse states: <b>“Be at all eaten [<i>he’akhol ye’akhel</i>],”</b> using a doubled verb, <b>the verse speaks of</b> intent with regard to <b>two consumptions, one consumption by a person, and one consumption by</b> the <b>altar,</b> i.e., burning the offering. Improper intent with regard to either of these acts renders the offering <i>piggul</i>.
The phrase <b>“any of the flesh of his peace offerings”</b> indicates that <b>just as a peace offering</b> possesses that which <b>renders <i>piggul</i> and</b> that which <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., the blood, which renders the offering <i>piggul</i> through one’s intent with regard to its rites, and the meat, which is rendered <i>piggul</i> through such intent, <b>so too</b> the verse is referring to <b>all</b> offerings that possess that which <b>renders</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i> and</b> that which <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b>
The term “on the <b>third</b> day” indicates that the verse is referring to intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> as peace offerings may be eaten for only two days.
The phrase <b>“it shall not be accepted”</b> indicates that an offering is deemed <i>piggul</i> following the stage of the service at which it would have otherwise effected atonement. Therefore, <b>like the acceptance of a fit</b> offering, <b>so</b> is <b>the acceptance of a disqualified</b> offering, <b>and just as the acceptance of a fit</b> offering does not occur <b>until one sacrifices all its permitting factors,</b> i.e., one sprinkles the blood properly, <b>so too the acceptance of a disqualified</b> offering does not occur <b>until one sacrifices all its permitting factors.</b>
The term <b>“he who offers”</b> indicates that <i>piggul</i> <b>is disqualified at</b> the time of <b>offering,</b> due to improper intent, <b>and it is not disqualified on the third</b> day literally. And when the verse states <b>“it,”</b> this indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of</b> a disqualification of the <b>offering</b> only, <b>but it is not speaking of</b> the <b>priest,</b> who is not disqualified from the priesthood through such intent.
The phrase <b>“neither shall it be credited [<i>yeḥashev</i>]”</b>

Daf 29a

indicates that to render an offering <i>piggul</i>, the priest <b>does not mix other</b> improper <b>intentions [<i>maḥashavot</i>] with</b> intent of <i>piggul</i>. If he has more than one type of improper intent, the offering is disqualified, but it is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
When the verse states: <b>“<i>Piggul</i>,” this is</b> referring to an offering that one had intent to consume <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
And since the verse states: <b>“It shall be,”</b> and not: They shall be, this <b>teaches that</b> intent to consume half an olive-bulk beyond its designated time and intent to consume half an olive-bulk outside its designated area <b>join together with one another</b> to constitute the minimum measure required to disqualify the offering.
Finally, when the verse states: <b>“And the soul that eats of it</b> shall bear his iniquity,” the term “of it” indicates that only <b>one</b> of the above disqualifications carries the penalty of <i>karet</i>, <b>but not two</b> of them. <b>And which is this?</b> It is intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, as</b> one <b>derives</b> by way of verbal analogy between <b>“iniquity”</b> and <b>“iniquity” from <i>notar</i></b> (Leviticus 19:8), that “bear his iniquity” means that one is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. The comparison is apt <b>since</b> <i>notar</i> <b>is similar to</b> intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time <b>in</b> that both prohibitions share the features mentioned above that form the acronym: <b><i>Zayin</i>, <i>beit</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: According to your</b> opinion, in <b>what</b> way do <b>you interpret</b> the reference to the <b>third</b> day (Leviticus 19:7) <b>in the</b> Torah <b>portion</b> that begins: <b>“You shall be holy”?</b> Rava responded: <b>That</b> verse is <b>necessary to</b> teach <b>that</b> a given <b>location</b> is considered to be outside the offering’s designated area only if it <b>is</b> so <b>in three ways,</b> i.e., outside the permitted limits <b>of</b> the <b>blood, of</b> the <b>meat, and of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions.</b>
The Gemara asks: Why not <b>let me derive</b> that <i>halakha</i> <b>from the first verse:</b> “And <b>if</b> any of the flesh of his peace offerings <b>be at all eaten</b> on the third day” (Leviticus 7:18), <b>since the Merciful One expresses</b> that verse as well <b>with the term “third”?</b> Since Rava derives the disqualification of intent to consume an offering outside its designated area from this verse, why not let him derive this <i>halakha</i> from the verse as well?
<b>Rav Ashi said: I stated</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Mattana,</b> and <b>he said to me: If</b> one were to derive this <i>halakha</i> only <b>from there</b> (Leviticus 7:18), <b>I would say:</b> The term <b>“third”</b> is <b>a detail,</b> and the term <b>“<i>piggul</i>”</b> is <b>a generalization, and</b> whenever a detail is followed by a generalization, <b>the generalization becomes an addition to the detail, and</b> consequently, all <b>other areas are included</b> as well. The additional verse <b>teaches us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> includes only those areas that are outside in three ways.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to the verse: <b>“And if any of the flesh of his peace offerings be at all eaten</b> on the third day, it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 7:18): <b>Rabbi Eliezer said: Bend your ear to hear</b> the true meaning of the verse: <b>The verse is speaking of one who intends to partake of his offering on the third day. Or</b> perhaps it is referring <b>only to</b> one <b>who</b> actually <b>partakes of his offering on the third day,</b> per the straightforward meaning of the verse? But that cannot be; would <b>you say</b> that <b>after</b> the offering <b>is fit</b> for the first two days, <b>it should then be disqualified</b> retroactively by being eaten on the third day?
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to him: Yes,</b> it could be disqualified retroactively. After all, <b>we find with regard to a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>], or a woman who experiences a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period [<i>zava</i>], or a woman who observes</b> a clean <b>day for a day</b> when she experiences a discharge, <b>that they</b> all <b>have the presumptive status of purity</b> after immersing. <b>But once they have seen</b> another discharge the same day, <b>they have negated</b> this status retroactively, and everything they had touched after immersing becomes impure. Therefore, <b>you as well should not be surprised about this</b> offering consumed beyond its designated time, <b>that even though it was rendered fit, it may then be disqualified</b> retroactively.
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him: But</b> the same verse <b>says: “He who offers</b> it,” indicating that the offering <b>is disqualified at the time of</b> its <b>offering, and it is not disqualified on the third</b> day. <b>Or</b> perhaps when the verse <b>says: “He who offers</b> it,” <b>this</b> is referring <b>only</b> to <b>the priest who sacrifices</b> the offering, indicating that he is disqualified. But if so, it would have been enough for the verse to state: He who offers shall not be credited. Therefore, <b>when it states</b> instead: “Neither shall it be credited to he who offers <b>it,”</b> this indicates that the verse <b>is speaking of the offering, and it is not speaking of the priest.</b>
<b>Ben Azzai says: Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “It”?</b> It is necessary <b>because</b> elsewhere <b>it is stated:</b> “When you shall vow a vow to the Lord your God, <b>you shall not delay paying it;</b> for the Lord your God will require it from you, and it will be sin in you” (Deuteronomy 23:22). One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> one who <b>is late</b> in fulfilling <b>his vow</b> is included <b>in: “It shall not be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 7:18). Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It,”</b> to indicate that <b>it,</b> an offering rendered <i>piggul</i>, <b>is</b> included <b>in</b> the <i>halakha</i> of: <b>“It shall not be accepted,” but</b> the animal of <b>one who is late</b> in fulfilling <b>his vow is not</b> included <b>in</b> the <i>halakha</i> of: <b>“It shall not be accepted.”</b>
<b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> One can conclude that the verse (Leviticus 7:18) is referring to improper intention rather than improper consumption from the phrase <b>“neither shall it be credited [<i>yeḥashev</i>],”</b> which indicates that the offering <b>is disqualified by</b> improper <b>intention [<i>maḥashava</i>], and it is not disqualified</b> by consumption <b>on the third</b> day.
The Gemara asks: <b>And ben Azzai,</b> who interprets the term “it” as excluding vows that were fulfilled late, <b>from where does he</b> derive <b>that the verse is speaking of</b> the <b>offering and not of</b> the <b>priest?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>If you wish, say</b> that <b>he derives it from</b> the statement <b>of <i>Aḥerim</i></b> that the verse rules out disqualification on the third day itself. This would be necessary only if the verse is referring to the offering and not the priest. <b>Or, if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is written: “They shall not be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 22:25), <b>and: “It shall not be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 7:18), it is evident that the verse <b>is</b> referring to <b>an offering,</b> which may be accepted or may not be accepted.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to the statement of <b>ben Azzai</b> that one derives from the word “it” that <b>it,</b> i.e., <i>piggul</i>, is included <b>in</b> the <i>halakha</i> of: <b>“It shall not be accepted,” but</b> the animal of one who <b>is late</b> in fulfilling <b>his vow is not</b> included <b>in</b> the <i>halakha</i> of: <b>“It shall not be accepted,”</b> is this <i>halakha</i> <b>derived from here? It is derived from</b> the statement <b>of <i>Aḥerim</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a firstborn</b> animal <b>whose</b> first <b>year passed,</b> during which time it ought to have been sacrificed, <b>should be</b>

Daf 29b

<b>like disqualified consecrated</b> animals, <b>and it should be disqualified</b> from being sacrificed, as though it had developed a blemish.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God,</b> in the place which He shall choose to place His name there, <b>the tithe of your grain,</b> of your wine, and of your oil, and the firstborns of your herds, and of your flocks” (Deuteronomy 14:23). The verse <b>juxtaposes a firstborn</b> animal <b>to</b> the <b>tithe</b> of grain to indicate that <b>just as</b> the <b>tithe is not disqualified</b> by being kept over <b>from</b> one <b>year to the next</b> (see Deuteronomy 14:28), <b>so too a firstborn</b> animal <b>is not disqualified</b> by being kept over <b>from</b> one <b>year to the next.</b> If so, one already derives from this verse that an offering is not disqualified even if it is brought late.
The Gemara responds: Nevertheless, the verse cited by ben Azzai <b>was necessary,</b> as without it, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this matter</b> applies only to <b>a firstborn, which is not for acceptance,</b> i.e., it does not serve to atone for any sin and is merely a gift for the priest, <b>but</b> with regard to other <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that are for acceptance, say</b> that <b>they shall not effect acceptance</b> when brought late. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that even these others are not disqualified when brought late.
The Gemara asks further: <b>But still,</b> isn’t this <i>halakha</i> <b>derived from</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>elsewhere:</b> The verse states: “When you shall vow a vow to the Lord your God, you shall not delay paying it; for the Lord your God will require it from you; <b>and it will be sin in you”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:22), indicating that there is sin in you, <b>but</b> there is <b>no sin in your offering,</b> and therefore it is not disqualified due to the delay?
The Gemara responds: <b>Ben Azzai requires that</b> verse to teach a different <i>halakha</i>: The phrase <b>“and it will be sin in you”</b> indicates that there will be sin in you, <b>but</b> there will <b>not</b> be <b>sin in your wife.</b> It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Elazar said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> who said: <b>A man’s wife does not die unless</b> his creditors <b>ask him for money</b> that he owes <b>and he does not have</b> it, <b>as it is stated: “If you do not have with what to pay, why should he take away your bed from under you?”</b> (Proverbs 22:27); therefore, one’s wife <b>also dies for this transgression of</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not delay,</b> since one has failed to fulfill his commitment. Consequently, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that the sin is imputed to him alone.
§ The <i>baraita</i> stated that <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> The phrase “neither shall it be credited” indicates that the offering <b>is disqualified by</b> improper <b>intention, and it is not disqualified</b> by consumption beyond its designated time <b>on the third</b> day. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who derives this <i>halakha</i> from a different source, <b>what does he do with</b> the phrase <b>“neither shall it be credited”?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>He requires it for</b> that <b>which Rabbi Yannai</b> says, <b>as Rabbi Yannai says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to intentions that they displace one another,</b> i.e., that an additional improper intention prevents the offering from being rendered <i>piggul</i>? <b>As it is stated: “Neither shall it be credited [<i>yeḥashev</i>],”</b> indicating that an offering is rendered piggul only if the priest does <b>not mix other</b> improper <b>intentions [<i>maḥashavot</i>] with</b> intent of <i>piggul</i>.
<b>And Rav Mari teaches</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who has</b> improper <b>intentions with regard to sacrificial</b> animals <b>is flogged</b> like one who transgressed a prohibition? <b>The verse states: “Neither shall it be credited [<i>lo yeḥashev</i>],”</b> i.e., one reads the verse as if it states: One shall not have improper intention [<i>lo y’ḥashev</i>].
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Mari:</b> But <b>it is a prohibition that does not involve an action, and</b> the principle is that <b>for</b> transgressing <b>any prohibition that does not involve an action one is not flogged.</b> Rav Mari <b>said to him: It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says: For</b> transgressing <b>a prohibition that does not involve an action one is flogged.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>This is the principle:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who slaughters</b> the animal, <b>or who collects</b> the blood, <b>or who conveys</b> the blood, <b>or who sprinkles</b> the blood, with intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, e.g., the meat of the offering, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>burns</b> it on the altar, if his intent was to partake of or to burn the measure of <b>an olive-bulk outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b> If his intent was to do so <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it, provided that the permitting factor,</b> the blood, <b>is sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>in silence</b> with no specific intent, and <b>he collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn or partake of the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> it with intent to burn or partake of the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and he collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood <b>in silence; or</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>and collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn or partake of the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, that is</b> the case <b>where</b> one <b>sacrifices the permitting factor in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> and <b>he collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and <b>collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area; or</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>and collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> these are cases in which the permitting factor is not sacrificed in accordance with the mitzva.
Similarly, in the case of <b>the Paschal offering and the sin offering that one slaughtered not for their sake, and</b> one <b>collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering or sin offering with intent to burn it or partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and <b>he collected and conveyed and sprinkled</b> the blood <b>not for their sake; or that one slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering or sin offering <b>and collected and conveyed and sprinkled their blood not for their sake, that is</b> the case of an offering <b>whose permitting factor is not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
If one performed one of the sacrificial rites with the intent <b>to eat an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, or <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>half an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, the offering is <b>disqualified and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>this is the principle:</b> In <b>any</b> case <b>where the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it. And if the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it. And the Rabbis say:</b> In both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, the offering is <b>disqualified and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b> If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk</b> and <b>to burn half an olive-bulk</b> not at the appropriate time or in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>fit because eating and burning do not join together.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the disagreement between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis concerning a case where one has intent with regard to both time and area, <b>Ilfa says:</b> There is <b>a disagreement</b> only <b>with regard to two</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> i.e., where each intent was held during a different rite, <b>but</b> if both were held <b>in</b> the course of <b>one rite, all agree</b> that <b>it constitutes a combination of intentions,</b> and the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even</b> if the intentions were both held <b>in</b> the course of <b>one rite,</b> there is still <b>a disagreement.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the mishna is understandable <b>according to Ilfa, since the first clause</b> of the mishna: If one slaughtered the animal in silence with no specific intent and collected…beyond its designated time, etc., is referring to different intentions held <b>in</b> the course of <b>two</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> one can assume that <b>the latter clause</b> is referring <b>to two rites as well. But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> could it be that <b>the first clause</b> is referring <b>to two rites, and the latter clause</b> is referring <b>to</b> only <b>one rite?</b>

Daf 30a

The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> it can be explained that <b>the first clause</b> is referring <b>to two</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> while <b>the latter clause,</b> i.e., the disagreement between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, applies <b>to both one rite and two rites.</b>
The Gemara suggests a proof: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>this is the principle: If the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it. Granted, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who says that the disagreement applies even to one rite, <b>this</b> is the reason <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: This is the principle,</b> indicating that the principle is broad. <b>But according to Ilfa, what</b> is added by the phrase: <b>This is the principle?</b> The Gemara responds: This indeed poses <b>a difficulty</b> to the opinion of Ilfa.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Temura</i> 25b): If one had two animals standing before him, one a burnt offering and one a peace offering, and he said with regard to another non-sacred animal of his: <b>This</b> animal <b>is hereby the substitute of</b> the <b>burnt offering, the substitute of</b> the <b>peace offering,</b> then <b>that</b> animal <b>is the substitute of</b> the <b>burnt offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei said: If that was his intent from the outset,</b> i.e., his intent was that this animal be the substitute of both a burnt offering and a peace offering, <b>since it is impossible to produce two designations simultaneously</b> and one designation must precede the other, <b>his statement is effective,</b> and the animal is the substitute of both a burnt offering and a peace offering. <b>But if</b> it was only <b>after he said: This</b> animal <b>is hereby the substitute of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> that <b>he reconsidered and said: This</b> animal <b>is hereby the substitute of</b> the <b>peace offering,</b> then <b>that</b> animal <b>is the substitute of a burnt offering</b> alone.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If one expressed the two intentions simultaneously and said: <b>This is hereby the substitute of a burnt offering and a peace offering, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Additionally, if one specified his intention <b>to split</b> the animal between a burnt offering and a peace offering, but mentioned the burnt offering first, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Abaye said: In this</b> case, <b>Rabbi Meir certainly concedes</b> that both types of sanctity apply to the animal. <b>Rava said: It is still a disagreement;</b> Rabbi Meir still holds in this case that since he mentioned the burnt offering first, only that sanctity applies to the animal.
<b>Rava said to Abaye: According to your</b> opinion, <b>as you say</b> that <b>in this</b> case <b>Rabbi Meir certainly concedes,</b> one may raise an objection from the mishna, which describes a case where one performs <b>slaughter</b> with intent to eat one olive-bulk of the offering beyond its time and one olive-bulk outside its area, <b>which is comparable to</b> a case where one says: <b>To split,</b> since both intentions are held during the singular act of slaughter. <b>And</b> nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that one attends only to the first statement, renders the animal <i>piggul</i>.
Abaye <b>said to him: Do you hold</b> that <b>slaughter is</b> considered to have been performed <b>only at</b> its <b>end,</b> such that it takes effect in a single instant? Actually, <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished progressively, <b>from beginning to end, and our mishna</b> is referring to a case <b>where one says:</b> I slaughter the <b>first <i>siman</i>,</b> the gullet or the windpipe, with intent to consume the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and the <b>second <i>siman</i></b> with intent to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what about the <b>removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering with intent to eat one olive-bulk beyond its time and one outside of its area, <b>which is comparable to</b> a case where one says: <b>To split,</b> since both intentions are held during the removal, <b>and</b> nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with regard to it in tractate <i>Menaḥot</i> (12a)?
The Gemara responds: Since the mishna does not state such a dispute explicitly, one can say that their disagreement is not with regard to the removal of the handful but with regard to the burning of the two permitting factors of the meal offering, the handful and the frankincense. Accordingly, <b>there too,</b> the case is such <b>that</b> the priest <b>burned the handful of</b> the <b>meal offering</b> with intent to eat it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and he burned <b>the handful of frankincense</b> with intent to eat the meal offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
The Gemara persists: <b>But</b> what about <b>the handful from a meal offering of a sinner, which has no frankincense with it, and</b> still Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree?</b>
The Gemara responds: In that case <b>they do not disagree. Rav Ashi says:</b> Even <b>if you say</b> that <b>they disagree</b> in that case, one may say that <b>they disagree</b> specifically <b>with regard to</b> a case where the priest had different intentions during his <b>steps</b> toward the altar while holding the handful. Consequently, even this rite is divisible into separate parts.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi</b> would <b>teach in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye</b> that in a case where one explicitly mentions both intentions at once, Rabbi Meir concedes that both sanctities apply to the animal. <b>Rav Huna bar Natan</b> would <b>teach in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava</b> that even in such a case, Rabbi Meir considers only the first sanctity mentioned.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> When <b>Rabbi Meir</b> said that if one says: This animal is hereby the substitute of a burnt offering, the substitute of a peace offering, then the animal is the substitute of a burnt offering, he <b>said this according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that in general, the <i>halakha</i> is to <b>attend</b> only to the <b>first statement.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>this is the principle: If the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b>

Daf 30b

<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Dimi: <b>But doesn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> say that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: When you consider their</b> opinions, <b>Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei do not disagree with one another,</b> i.e., neither holds that one attends only to the first statement?
Rav Dimi objected: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>they do not disagree? But don’t they disagree</b> explicitly in the mishna cited earlier? Abaye <b>said to him: They disagree where they disagree,</b> i.e., that specific case, <b>but they do not disagree where they do not disagree,</b> i.e., the underlying principle. Accordingly, one must understand the basis of their dispute in another manner.
This is <b>as Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All,</b> i.e., Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yosei, <b>concede that</b> in a case <b>where one says: Let this</b> sanctity of a burnt offering <b>take effect and afterward let that</b> sanctity of a peace offering <b>take effect, everyone agrees</b> that the sanctity of a peace offering <b>does not take effect,</b> because the sanctity of the burnt offering took effect first. Likewise, if one said: <b>This</b> sanctity <b>shall not take effect unless that</b> sanctity <b>applies, everyone agrees</b> that the sanctity of a peace offering <b>takes effect</b> as well.
<b>They disagree</b> with regard to a case <b>where one says:</b> This animal is hereby <b>a substitute for a burnt offering, a substitute for a peace offering. Rabbi Meir holds: Since</b> if he wanted both sanctities to take effect, <b>he should have said: A substitute for a burnt offering and a peace offering, but he said</b> instead: <b>A substitute for a burnt offering, a substitute for a peace offering, learn from</b> his language that he originally intended for it to be a burnt offering, and he then <b>retracted</b> his first intention.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei</b> holds that <b>if he</b> had <b>said: A substitute for a burnt offering and a peace offering, I would say</b> that he means that <b>half</b> the animal should be <b>a substitute for a burnt offering and half a substitute for a peace offering. He therefore says: A substitute for a burnt offering, a substitute for a peace offering; that is to say that all of it is a burnt offering and all of it is a peace offering.</b> In any event, according to this explanation, Rabbi Meir does not necessarily hold that one attends only to the first statement.
Rav Dimi <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>He,</b> Rabba bar bar Ḥana, <b>says</b> that <b>they do not disagree, but I say</b> that <b>they disagree,</b> and Rabbi Meir holds that one attends only to the first statement, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in the mishna.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the mishna itself: <b>Ulla</b> said, <b>and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Oshaya</b> who <b>said: Perhaps our colleagues, the Babylonians, know</b> whether <b>we learn</b> the language of the improper intention in the mishna as: I hereby slaughter the animal with intent to consume <b>an olive-bulk</b> beyond its designated time, <b>an olive-bulk</b> outside its designated area, <b>or we learn: An olive-bulk</b> beyond its designated time <b>and an olive-bulk</b> outside its designated area?
The Gemara elaborates: Perhaps <b>we learn: An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk,</b> and it is only in this case that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with the Rabbis. <b>But</b> if one said: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it constitutes a combination of intentions,</b> and the animal is not rendered <i>piggul</i>. <b>Or perhaps we learn: An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk, where according to Rabbi Yehuda</b> each term <b>constitutes a separate</b> term despite the use of the conjunction: And, and he holds that one attends only to the first statement, <b>and all the more so</b> if one said: <b>An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that <b>dilemma which Levi raised before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: If <b>one had intent to consume an olive-bulk the next day outside</b> its designated area, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: This</b> is an excellent <b>question.</b> The answer is that even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that this <b>constitutes a combination of intentions</b> and that the animal is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>said before him:</b> How is this an excellent question; <b>is it not our mishna?</b> As we learned in the mishna: If one expressed intent <b>to eat an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, or <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>half an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, the offering is <b>disqualified and there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> burning or partaking of <b>it.</b> Rabbi Yehuda disagrees only with regard to these cases; <b>but</b> in <b>another</b> case, it could easily be inferred that he concedes that <b>it constitutes a combination of intentions.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him:</b> Levi <b>asked me a matter of wisdom, and you say our mishna. For you, whom I taught two</b> phrasings of the mishna, both: An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk, and: An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk, the question is <b>not difficult,</b> since my omission of this other case allows you to infer its <i>halakha</i>.
<b>For him, whom I taught only one</b> phrasing, <b>and</b> who <b>heard the Rabbis reciting two,</b> the question is excellent, since Levi <b>thought:</b> Perhaps <b>my</b> phrasing is <b>exact, and their</b> additional phrasing <b>constitutes a combination of intentions</b> according to all opinions. <b>Or perhaps their</b> phrasing is <b>exact, and my</b> phrasing <b>omitted</b> this case. <b>And</b> if <b>my</b> phrasing <b>omitted this</b> case, perhaps <b>their</b> phrasing <b>also omitted that</b> other case, even though it is subject to disagreement.
The Gemara asks: <b>And which</b> phrasing <b>did</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>teach</b> Levi? <b>If we say</b> that <b>he taught him: An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk,</b> i.e., that Rabbi Yehuda still holds the terms to be distinct despite the conjunction, <b>this is not an omission,</b> since one can infer <i>a fortiori</i> that the same applies to: An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>he taught him: An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk,</b> so that it was unclear to Levi what the <i>halakha</i> would be if one used the conjunction: And.
The Gemara asks: If so, why did Levi raise the dilemma with regard to the phrasing: The next day outside? <b>Let him raise the dilemma</b> with regard to the phrasing: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara responds: Levi <b>thought: I will raise one dilemma before him so as to learn two</b> <i>halakhot</i>. <b>As, if I ask</b> only with regard to: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk, it will work out well if he says to me</b> that Rabbi Yehuda concedes that they constitute one <b>general</b> term, as this would apply <b>all the more so</b> if one said: <b>An olive-bulk the next day outside,</b> which is even more unified. <b>But if he says to me</b> that each term constitutes <b>a separate</b> term according to Rabbi Yehuda, then <b>I will still</b> need to <b>raise the dilemma</b> with regard to the case of: <b>An olive-bulk the next day outside.</b> I will therefore inquire with regard to the latter case.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, now too, it works out well if he says to him</b> that Rabbi Yehuda maintains that the wording: <b>An olive-bulk the next day outside,</b> is constituted of <b>separate</b> terms, as this would apply <b>all the more so</b> if one said: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk,</b> which is less unified. <b>But if he says to him</b> that it is one <b>general</b> term according to Rabbi Yehuda, then <b>he will still</b> need to <b>raise the dilemma</b> with regard to the case of: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi answered in <b>this</b> manner, i.e., that Rabbi Yehuda concedes that: An olive-bulk the next day outside, is considered one term, he would unwittingly provide the answer to the other question as well. As, if Rabbi Yehuda had also conceded with regard to: An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would <b>become angry</b> with Levi for asking the wrong question and say:

Daf 31a

<b>Now</b> that Rabbi Yehuda concedes that even: <b>An olive-bulk and an olive-bulk,</b> is one <b>general</b> term, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to inquire with regard to: <b>An olive-bulk the next day outside?</b>
The Gemara presents <b>another version</b> of this discussion: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi might say that if Rabbi Yehuda maintains that even when one says: <b>An olive-bulk the next day outside,</b> each term is considered <b>separate, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to inquire with regard to: <b>An olive-bulk, an olive-bulk?</b>
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If one had intent to eat <b>half an olive-</b>bulk <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, half an olive-</b>bulk <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, and</b> another <b>half an olive-</b>bulk <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, Rava says:</b> In such a case, <b>the <i>piggul</i></b>: <b>“Awaked as one asleep”</b> (Psalms 78:65), i.e., since one had intent to consume two halves of an olive-bulk beyond their designated time, these intentions are joined together. The middle thought is disregarded, since it constitutes only half the requisite measure, and the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>. <b>And Rav Hamnuna says: It constitutes a combination of</b> improper <b>intentions.</b> The middle thought, although itself insufficient to disqualify the offering, is sufficient to interfere with the intention to consume it beyond its time, and the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rava said: From where,</b> i.e., based on what, <b>do I state</b> my ruling? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 1:5): <b>An egg-bulk of food</b> with <b>first-</b>degree impurity <b>and an egg-bulk of food</b> with second-degree impurity <b>that one mixed together</b> are collectively considered to have <b>first-</b>degree impurity. If one <b>separated them</b> into two portions, each containing a homogenous mixture, <b>this</b> portion is considered to have <b>second-</b>degree impurity <b>and that</b> portion is considered to have <b>second-</b>degree impurity. Since neither of them contains the requisite amount of food with first-degree impurity, each mixture settles to the lower level of impurity between the two foods. Rava reasoned: <b>But</b> if one <b>mixed them again,</b> they revert to <b>be</b> of <b>first-</b>degree impurity.
<b>From where</b> do I know this? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of that mishna <b>teaches:</b> If <b>this</b> portion <b>fell by itself and that</b> portion fell <b>by itself onto a loaf of <i>teruma</i>, it disqualifies it,</b> as would any food with second-degree impurity. But it does not render it impure, since only foods with first-degree impurity impart impurity to other foods. But if <b>they both fell simultaneously</b> onto the loaf, <b>they render it</b> a food with <b>second</b>-degree impurity. Evidently, although the first-degree impurity lay dormant for lack of a requisite measure, it resurfaces when the rest of the measure is added, despite the fact that each portion was previously considered to have second-degree impurity. The <i>halakha</i> would be the same in the case of intent to consume the offering beyond its designated time, i.e., the intent to consume half an olive-bulk outside its area does not interfere with the intent of <i>piggul</i>.
<b>And Rav Hamnuna says:</b> The cases are different. <b>There,</b> in the case of ritual impurity, <b>there is</b> a requisite <b>measure</b> present at the outset, which is divided and then recombined. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the offering, <b>there is no</b> requisite <b>measure</b> present at the outset to render it <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rav Hamnuna said: From where do I say</b> my opinion? <b>As we learned</b> in another mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 17b): <b>The food that became ritually impure</b> through contact <b>with a primary source of ritual impurity,</b> thereby assuming first-degree impurity, <b>and</b> the food <b>that became ritually impure</b> through contact <b>with a derivative source of ritual impurity,</b> thereby assuming second-degree impurity, <b>join together</b> to constitute the requisite measure of an egg-bulk <b>to impart impurity in accordance with the</b> more <b>lenient of the two,</b> i.e., as a food of second-degree impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> that they retain second-degree impurity <b>even if one makes up</b> the requisite measure <b>again?</b> If so, it can be inferred that the first-degree impurity is lost, and it does not lie dormant or resurface. Here as well, the latter intent of <i>piggul</i> cannot restore the initial intent of <i>piggul</i>, as the intent to consume half an olive-bulk outside its area interfered.
The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna is referring specifically to a case <b>where one does not complete</b> the requisite measure <b>again.</b>
The Gemara presents similar cases: <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said:</b> If one had intent to eat <b>half an olive-bulk outside its</b> designated <b>area, and half an olive-bulk beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and</b> then another <b>half an olive-bulk beyond its</b> designated <b>time, bar Kappara teaches</b> that the offering is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> since the <b>half an olive-bulk</b> with regard to the area <b>is not effective</b> to interfere <b>where</b> the intent with regard to the time concerns a whole <b>olive-bulk.</b>
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he stated</b> a different formulation: If one had intent to eat <b>half an olive-bulk beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and</b> then another <b>half an olive-bulk beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and</b> then <b>half an olive-bulk outside its</b> designated <b>area, bar Kappara teaches</b> that the offering is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> since the <b>half an olive-bulk is not effective</b> to interfere <b>where</b> the intent of <i>piggul</i> concerns a whole <b>olive-bulk.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in this</b> manner: If one had intent to eat <b>half an olive-bulk beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and</b> then intended with regard to a whole <b>olive-bulk</b> to eat <b>half of it outside its</b> designated <b>area and half of it beyond its</b> designated <b>time, bar Kappara teaches</b> that the offering is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> because the <b>half an olive-bulk is not effective</b> to interfere <b>where</b> the intent of <i>piggul</i> concerns a whole <b>olive-bulk.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> If one <b>had intent that dogs would eat</b> the offering <b>the next day,</b> it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, as it is written: “And the dogs shall eat Jezebel in the portion of Jezreel”</b> (II Kings 9:10). The verse indicates that consumption by dogs is considered eating.
<b>Rabbi Ami objects to this: If that is so,</b> then if one <b>had intent that</b> non-sacred <b>fire would consume it the next day, as it is written: “A fire not blown shall consume him”</b> (Job 20:26), <b>this too</b> should be <b><i>piggul</i>. And if you would say</b> that this is <b>indeed</b> so, that is difficult: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> not at the appropriate time or in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>fit because eating and burning do not join together?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If one expressed</b> his intention to burn the offering <b>in terms of consumption,</b> it would <b>indeed</b> join together with intention to eat. But in the mishna <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where he expressed it in terms of burning.</b> The two intentions do not join together <b>since terms of consumption and terms of burning are discrete</b> entities.
§ <b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>one had intent that two people</b> would collectively <b>eat an olive-bulk, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we follow</b> the <b>intent,</b> in <b>which</b> case <b>there is</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> of an olive-bulk? <b>Or do we follow those who eat, and neither</b> eats the requisite <b>measure?</b>
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> beyond the designated time or outside the designated area, the offering is <b>fit because eating and burning do not join together.</b>

Daf 31b
