It can be inferred <b>that</b> if one had intent <b>to eat and to eat</b> in a manner <b>similar to</b> a case of intent <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk <b>and to burn</b> half an olive-bulk; Abaye interjects: <b>And what are the circumstances</b> of such a case? It is a case <b>with two people,</b> i.e., where each one will consume half an olive-bulk. Abaye continues with the conclusion of his statement: Then the two halves <b>join together.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from it</b> that this is so.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>had intent to eat an olive-bulk in more than</b> the period of time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we equate</b> the consumption of offerings <b>to the consumption of the Most High,</b> i.e., the burning of offerings on the altar, for which there is no maximum allotted time? <b>Or do we equate it to the consumption of an ordinary</b> person, for whom consumption slower than this rate is not considered eating?
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> not at the appropriate time or in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>fit because eating and burning do not join together.</b> One may infer that the <b>reason</b> the offering is fit is that he had intent <b>to eat and to burn</b> the offering. <b>But</b> if he had intent <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk at the normal rate <b>and to eat</b> half an olive-bulk in the time it takes to burn half an olive-bulk, the two would <b>join together. But</b> the <b>burning</b> of an olive-bulk of an offering can take <b>more than</b> the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. It therefore seems that there is no upper limit on the time in which one is considered to have consumed an offering.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna is referring to intent to burn half an olive-bulk <b>in a large fire,</b> which can consume it in the time it takes to eat a half-loaf of bread. Accordingly, one may draw the inference only with regard to a case where his intent was to consume the halves of an olive-bulk within this time.
§ The mishna teaches: If one slaughtered the animal with intent <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> not at the appropriate time or in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>fit.</b> The Gemara infers: The <b>reason that</b> the two halves of an olive-bulk do not join together is because his intent was <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk <b>and to burn</b> half an olive-bulk. <b>But</b> if his intent was <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk of the meat <b>and to eat</b> half an olive-bulk of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, then the halves do <b>join together</b> and disqualify the offering, as both intentions concern eating.
The Gemara notes an apparent contradiction: <b>But the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If one’s intent was <b>to partake</b> of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, beyond its designated time, his intent <b>joins together</b> to disqualify the offering. One can infer that only if his intent was to partake of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, <b>does</b> his intent join together, but if his intent was to partake of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not</b> to partake of it, then it does <b>not</b> join together.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> latter clause? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says: One can have intent</b> to shift an item’s consumption <b>from consumption by a person to consumption by</b> the <b>altar, or from consumption by</b> the <b>altar to consumption by a person. As we learned</b> in another mishna (35a): In the case of <b>one who slaughters the offering</b> with intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not</b> to partake of it, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not burn</b> it on the altar, beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, the offering is <b>fit, and Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>unfit.</b>
<b>Abaye says: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the latter clause is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. And do not say</b> that one should infer from the mishna <b>that</b> if his intent was <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk of an item normally consumed <b>and to eat</b> half an olive-bulk of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, then the offering is disqualified. <b>Rather, say</b> that one infers <b>that</b> if his intent was <b>to eat</b> half an olive-bulk <b>and to eat</b> another half an olive-bulk, both halves from <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, then the halves join together to disqualify the offering.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>what</b> is this latter clause <b>teaching us? If it teaches us</b> that two half olive-bulks from <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, join together, one can already <b>learn</b> this <b>from the first clause</b> of the mishna: If one has intent to consume <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> One can infer <b>that</b> if his intent was to eat the first <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> the offering would be rendered <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>But if</b> one will say that this term teaches its literal meaning, that intentions <b>to eat and to burn</b> two halves of an olive-bulk do not join together, one can already <b>learn</b> this <b>from the inference</b> drawn above <b>from the first clause</b> of the mishna, namely that intent <b>to partake</b> of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it <b>does</b> disqualify the offering, but intent to partake of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it does <b>not.</b> By extension, intent to consume half an olive-bulk of such an item does not join to disqualify the offering.
<b>Now,</b> consider the following: <b>And just as</b> if when one has intent <b>to partake</b> of an item normally eaten <b>and to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, his intentions <b>do not join together,</b> even though both intentions concern consumption, <b>is it necessary</b> for the mishna to teach that intentions <b>to consume and to burn</b> do not join together? The last clause therefore seems unnecessary.
The Gemara responds: It <b>was necessary</b> for the mishna to explicitly address the case where one had intent <b>to eat and to burn,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that it <b>is</b> only <b>there,</b> where one’s intentions are referring solely to consumption, that they do not join together, <b>since he has intent</b> to act in a way that is <b>not</b> consistent with <b>its</b> typical <b>manner</b> and consume an item not normally consumed. <b>But here, where</b> his intent is to both eat and burn the offering, such that <b>with regard to this</b> half he intends to act <b>in</b> a way consistent with <b>its</b> typical <b>manner, and with regard to that</b> half he intends to act <b>in</b> a way consistent with <b>its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>they should join together.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that intentions to eat and to burn do not join together.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all</b> those <b>who are unfit</b> for Temple service <b>who slaughtered</b> an offering, <b>their slaughter is valid, as the slaughter</b> of an offering <b>is valid</b> <i>ab initio</i> when performed even <b>by non-priests, by women, by</b> Canaanite <b>slaves, and by ritually impure</b> individuals. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even with</b> regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, provided that the ritually impure will not touch the flesh</b> of the slaughtered animal, thereby rendering it impure. <b>Therefore,</b> these unfit individuals can <b>disqualify</b> the offering <b>with</b> prohibited <b>intent,</b> e.g., if one of them intended to partake of the offering beyond its designated time or outside its designated area.

Daf 32a

<b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them,</b> in a case <b>where they collected the blood</b> with the intent to offer it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, if there is blood of the soul</b> that remains in the animal, <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>should again collect</b> the blood and sprinkle it on the altar.
If <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood in a vessel <b>and gave</b> the vessel <b>to an unfit</b> person, that person <b>should return</b> it <b>to the fit</b> priest. If the priest <b>collected</b> the blood in a vessel <b>in his right</b> hand <b>and moved</b> it <b>to his left</b> hand, <b>he should return</b> it <b>to his right</b> hand. If the priest <b>collected</b> the blood <b>in a sacred vessel and placed it in a non-sacred vessel, he should return</b> the blood <b>to a sacred vessel.</b> If the blood <b>spilled from the vessel onto the floor and he gathered it</b> from the floor, it is <b>valid.</b>
If an unfit person <b>placed</b> the blood <b>upon the ramp</b> or on the wall of the altar <b>that</b> is <b>not opposite the base</b> of the altar, or if <b>he placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, <b>or</b> if he placed the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>or the</b> blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, then <b>if there is blood of the soul</b> that remains in the animal, <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>should again collect</b> the blood and sprinkle it on the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the use of the past tense in the mishna: With regard to all those who are unfit for Temple service who <b>slaughtered,</b> that <b>after the fact, yes,</b> the slaughter is valid. But <b><i>ab initio</i>, no,</b> those who are unfit may not slaughter an offering.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from what was taught in the halakhic midrash <i>Torat Kohanim</i>: The verse states with regard to a burnt offering: <b>“And he shall slaughter</b> the bull before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:5). The fact that the verse does not stipulate that a priest must slaughter the offering teaches that <b>slaughter is valid</b> if performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> as stated in the mishna: <b>As the</b> sacrificial rite of <b>slaughter is valid</b> when performed <b>by non-priests, by women, by</b> Canaanite <b>slaves, and by ritually impure</b> individuals, <b>and even with</b> regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order. Or</b> perhaps the term “and he shall slaughter” in the verse is referring <b>only</b> to slaughter <b>by priests?</b>
<b>You</b> can <b>say</b> in response: <b>From where did you come</b> to the idea that the verse is referring only to a priest? It is <b>from the fact that it is stated</b> to Aaron: <b>“And you and your sons with you shall keep your priesthood in everything that pertains to the altar”</b> (Numbers 18:7).
One <b>might</b> have thought that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even with</b> regard to <b>slaughter,</b> that only priests are fit to slaughter an offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall slaughter the bull before the Lord, and</b> Aaron’s sons, the priests, <b>shall present [<i>vehikrivu</i>]</b> the blood” (Leviticus 1:5), from which it is inferred that specifically <b>from</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>and onward</b> it is <b>a mitzva</b> exclusively <b>of the priesthood.</b> This <b>teaches about the</b> rite of <b>slaughter that it is valid</b> <i>ab initio</i> if performed <b>by any person.</b> This contradicts the inference from the mishna that slaughter of an offering by a non-priest is valid only after the fact.
The Gemara answers: <b>The same is true that even <i>ab initio</i> as well</b> it is permitted for those unfit for Temple service to slaughter an offering, <b>but because</b> the mishna <b>wants to teach</b> with regard to the <b>ritually impure that</b> they may <b>not</b> slaughter an offering <b><i>ab initio</i></b> due to a rabbinic <b>decree lest they touch the flesh</b> and render it ritually impure, therefore the mishna <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> with the expression in the past tense: <b>Who slaughtered,</b> i.e., after the fact.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> individual who performed the slaughter, is it <b>permitted</b> even <b>after the fact? And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from what is taught in the halakhic midrash: The Torah states two consecutive directives: <b>“And he shall place</b> his hand upon the head of the burnt offering…<b>And he shall slaughter</b> the bull before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:4–5). This juxtaposition indicates that both directives are referring to the same individual, which teaches that <b>just as placing hands</b> on the head of an offering may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals, <b>so too,</b> the <b>slaughter</b> may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals. The Gemara answers: <b>By rabbinic law,</b> an impure person is prohibited from slaughtering an offering lest he touch the flesh of the offering, but by Torah law the slaughter is valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>placing hands</b> that it can be performed only by those who are ritually pure even by Torah law? It is <b>that it is written: “Before the Lord,”</b> which is referring to the Temple courtyard, and an impure person may not enter the Temple courtyard. With regard to <b>slaughter as well, isn’t it written: “Before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 1:5)? How can a ritually impure person enter the Temple courtyard to slaughter an offering? The Gemara answers: It is <b>possible,</b> in a case <b>where he fashions a long knife,</b> stands outside the Temple courtyard, <b>and slaughters</b> the offering that is inside the courtyard.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>placing hands also, it is possible,</b> in a case <b>where he inserts his hands</b> into the Temple courtyard <b>and places</b> them on the head of the offering. The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>a partial entry,</b> in which only a part of the body enters the Temple courtyard, <b>is called entry.</b> Therefore, an impure individual may not insert even part of his body, such as his hands, into the Temple courtyard.
<b>Rav Ḥisda taught the</b> <i>baraita</i> in the <b>opposite</b> manner: <b>“And he shall place</b> his hand upon the head of the burnt offering…<b>and he shall slaughter</b> the bull” (Leviticus 1:4–5), teaches that <b>just as slaughter</b> may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals, <b>so too, placing hands</b> may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>slaughter</b> that it may be performed only by those who are ritually pure? It is <b>that it is written</b> with regard to it: <b>“Before the Lord,”</b> which refers to the Temple courtyard, and a ritually impure person may not enter the Temple courtyard.

Daf 32b

With regard to <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an offering <b>as well, it is written: “Before the Lord.”</b> The Gemara answers that <b>it is possible,</b> in a case <b>where he inserts his hands</b> into the Temple courtyard <b>and places</b> them on the head of the offering while he remains outside. The Gemara asks: But with regard to <b>slaughter also,</b> it is <b>possible,</b> in a case <b>where he fashions a long knife and slaughters</b> the animal while standing outside the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Shimon HaTimni,</b> who holds that the one who slaughters an offering must stand inside the Temple courtyard. This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that when the verse states: <b>“And he shall slaughter the bull before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 1:5),it teaches that the bull must be inside the Temple courtyard, <b>but the slaughterer</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>“before the Lord.”</b> Therefore, he may stand outside the Temple courtyard and slaughter the offering that is inside. <b>Shimon HaTimni says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the hands of</b> the <b>slaughterer must be</b> farther <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>than the</b> animal that is <b>slaughtered? The verse states: “And he shall slaughter the bull before the Lord,”</b> which teaches that the <b>slaughterer of the bull must be before the Lord.</b>
§ Apropos the question of whether partial entry into the Temple courtyard is considered entry, <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says: A ritually impure</b> individual <b>who inserted his hand inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>is flogged</b> for transgressing the prohibition of entering the Temple while impure, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to the impurity of a woman who gave birth: <b>“Every consecrated item she shall not touch,</b> and to the Temple she shall not come, until the days of her purification are complete” (Leviticus 12:4). The verse <b>juxtaposes entry</b> into the courtyard <b>to touching</b> a sacred item. <b>Just as touching with</b> even <b>a part</b> of the body <b>is considered touching, so too, entry with part</b> of the body <b>is considered entry.</b>
<b>Rav Hoshaya raised an objection to Ulla</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: There is the case of <b>a leper whose eighth</b> day, on which he becomes ritually pure from his leprosy and performs the final stages of his purification process, <b>occurs on Passover eve,</b> such that it would be possible to bring his offerings and be fit to partake of the Paschal offering that evening. <b>And he experienced a seminal emission on that day</b> before he performed the final stages of his purification process, rendering him ritually impure and prohibited from entering the Temple. <b>And he</b> then <b>immersed</b> himself in a ritual bath. The question is whether he may come to the gate of the Temple courtyard, which is necessary to complete his purification process and terminate his status as a leper.
<b>The Sages said: Although</b> any <b>other</b> individual who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed <b>may not enter</b> the Temple mount until nightfall, <b>this</b> one <b>may enter.</b> The reason is that <b>it is better</b> for <b>a positive mitzva that has</b> a punishment of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., the bringing of the Paschal offering, to <b>come and override a positive mitzva for which there is no</b> liability to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., the mitzva to remove individuals who are ritually impure from the Temple courtyard, than have the positive mitzva that has a punishment of <i>karet</i> not be performed.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law, there is not even a positive mitzva</b> that restricts from entering the Temple courtyard one who has immersed that day and will become pure only upon nightfall, <b>as it is stated: “And Jehoshaphat stood in the congregation of Judea and Jerusalem, in the House of the Lord, before the new courtyard”</b> (II Chronicles 20:5). <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>“the new courtyard”? Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This is referring to the place <b>in which they innovated many matters and said</b> that <b>one who immersed that day may not enter the camp of the Levites,</b> which in Jerusalem includes the entire Temple Mount. This indicates that the prohibition is of rabbinic origin, and by Torah law it is permitted for him to enter.
Rav Hoshaya concludes his objection: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>partial entry</b> into the courtyard <b>is considered entry, how</b> does the leper who immersed himself that day <b>insert his hands</b> into the courtyard <b>so that</b> his right <b>thumb and big toe</b> will become purified? In this situation, both <b>this</b> mitzva to eat of the Paschal offering <b>and that</b> mitzva for an impure person to not enter the courtyard <b>are</b> each <b>a positive mitzva for which there is</b> liability to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as someone who immersed himself that day who enters the Temple courtyard is liable to be punished with <i>karet</i>.
Ulla <b>said to</b> Rabbi Hoshaya: A proof to my opinion can be brought <b>from your</b> own <b>burden,</b> i.e., from the question you asked. <b>A leper is different,</b> as the Torah permitted him to insert his right thumb and big toe into the courtyard in order to become purified despite the fact that he has not yet brought an atonement offering to complete the purification process, and <b>since he was permitted</b> to partially enter the courtyard <b>for</b> purification from <b>his leprosy, he was</b> also <b>permitted</b> with regard to his impurity due <b>to his seminal emission.</b> Nevertheless, a partial entry into the courtyard is in fact considered an entry.
Based on Ulla’s previous comment, <b>Rav Yosef said: Ulla holds</b> that if <b>most of</b> the Jewish people were <b><i>zavim</i></b> on Passover eve, and were therefore prohibited from sacrificing the Paschal offering while impure, <b>and</b> then <b>they became ritually impure due to a corpse,</b> which allows them to sacrifice the Paschal offering despite their impurity as they are a majority of the Jewish people, <b>since they are permitted</b> to sacrifice the offering <b>with regard to their impurity</b> due to a corpse, <b>they are</b> also <b>permitted with regard to their <i>ziva</i>.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: Are</b> the cases <b>comparable?</b> With regard to a leper who experienced a seminal emission, he was already permitted to partially enter the courtyard despite his initial impurity. There-fore, the subsequent impurity does not prohibit him from entering. By contrast, the <i>zavim</i> were originally prevented from sacrificing the Paschal offering. Therefore, even if he would be <b>permitted</b> to enter the courtyard despite becoming <b>impure</b> due to a corpse, he would <b>not</b> be <b>permitted</b> to enter due to the <b><i>ziva</i></b> that was previously present.
Furthermore, Abaye <b>said to him: Perhaps this</b> is what <b>the Master is saying:</b> If <b>most of</b> the Jewish people were initially <b>ritually impure due to a corpse, and they</b> subsequently <b>became <i>zavim</i>, since they are permitted with regard to their impurity</b> due to a corpse, <b>they are permitted with regard to their <i>ziva</i></b> as well. Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Yes,</b> that was what I meant.
The Gemara asks: <b>But still,</b> this is <b>not comparable</b> to the case of Ulla, since with regard to <b>a leper, it is</b> with total <b>permission</b> that he is allowed partial entry into the courtyard. And <b>since it was permitted</b> with regard to one impurity, <b>it was permitted</b> with regard to a second impurity. But the <b>ritual impurity</b> with regard to the sacrificing of the Paschal offering <b>is</b> only <b>overridden,</b> and there is not a total permission. Perhaps <b>with regard to this,</b> i.e., ritual impurity due to a corpse, <b>it is overridden,</b> but <b>with regard to that,</b> i.e., the impurity of <i>ziva</i>, <b>it is not overridden.</b>
<b>Rava said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is</b> more <b>reasonable.</b> With regard to <b>a leper, it is</b> with specific <b>permission</b> that he was allowed by the Torah to insert his right thumb and big toe into the courtyard in order to become purified despite his ritual impurity, which was not granted for other impurities. Therefore, perhaps only <b>with regard to this</b> impurity <b>it is permitted, but with regard to that</b> impurity, i.e., due to a seminal emission, <b>it is not permitted.</b> But with regard to <b>ritual impurity,</b> since <b>it is overridden</b> in the case of ritual impurity due to a corpse, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if there is <b>one</b> impurity that is <b>overridden,</b> and <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if there are <b>two</b> impurities that are <b>overridden?</b>

Daf 33a

The Gemara comments: It can be derived <b>by inference that both</b> Abaye and Rava <b>hold</b> that <b>impurity is overridden in</b> cases involving the <b>public</b> and is not entirely permitted.
The Gemara returns to discussing Ulla’s statement that partial entry of a ritually impure individual is considered entry: <b>Let us say</b> that a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nega’im</i> 8:10) <b>supports</b> Ulla’s opinion: Concerning <b>all the</b> cases of <b>placing hands that were there</b> in the Temple, <b>I say about them</b> that the principle: <b>Immediately</b> following the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on the head of an offering is its <b>slaughter,</b> is applied, meaning that these acts must take place uninterruptedly and in the same location.
This is so <b>except for this</b> case of a leper who places hands on his guilt offering, <b>which was</b> done <b>in</b> the threshold of the <b>Nicanor Gate</b> and not in the Temple courtyard where the guilt offering was slaughtered. The reason for this is <b>that a leper cannot enter</b> the courtyard <b>until they sprinkle from the blood of his sin offering and from the blood of his guilt offering</b> on the altar <b>on his behalf.</b> The Gemara explains the proof: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>partial entry is not considered entry, let him insert his hands and place</b> them on the head of the offering, and the offering should then be slaughtered in that location next to the gate.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> There is no proof from here, as in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that the northern side of the courtyard in which it is permitted to slaughter offerings of the most sacred order, which includes a guilt offering, includes only the area to the north of the altar and not the entire northern section of the courtyard. This area is <b>far north</b> of the entrance to the courtyard, i.e., more than twenty-two cubits away. Consequently, even if the leper were to insert his hands into the courtyard and place them on the head of his guilt offering, it would not be permitted to slaughter it there.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let an opening [<i>pishpash</i>] be made</b> in the northern courtyard wall facing the altar, where the leper can insert his hands. The Gemara explains: <b>Abaye and Rava both say</b> that such structural changes cannot be made to the Temple, since the verse states with regard to the Temple construction: <b>“All in writing, as the Lord has made me wise by His hand upon me, even all the works of this pattern”</b> (I Chronicles 28:19).
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosef said</b> another explanation as to why the leper cannot insert his hands into the courtyard and place them on the head of the offering: <b>Anyone who places hands</b> on the head of an offering must <b>insert his head and most of his</b> body into the courtyard. <b>What is the reason? We require</b> placing hands with <b>all</b> of <b>his force. Therefore,</b> it is <b>not possible</b> for the leper to perform the placing of his hands properly without entering the courtyard, and the placing of hands on the offering is done instead in the threshold of the Nicanor Gate.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> does the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>placing hands</b> on the head of <b>a guilt offering of a leper</b> is <b>by Torah law, and</b> the principle that <b>immediately</b> following the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on the head of an offering must be its <b>slaughter</b> is also <b>by Torah law, let</b> the leper <b>openly insert</b> his hands into the courtyard <b>and place</b> them on the head of the offering, <b>as the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that he must do so.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana says:</b> In principle that should be done. But the prohibition against the leper entering the courtyard is a rabbinic <b>decree,</b> due to the concern that <b>perhaps he will increase</b> his <b>steps,</b> enter the courtyard more than is necessary, and be liable for entering there in a state of impurity. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana says</b> that <b>placing hands</b> on the head of <b>a guilt offering of a leper</b> is indeed <b>by Torah law, but</b> the requirement that <b>immediately</b> following the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> is the <b>slaughter</b> is <b>not by Torah law.</b> Therefore, he places hands on the offering outside of the courtyard.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> cited previously (32a): The verse states: <b>“And he shall place</b> his hand upon the head of the burnt offering…<b>And he shall slaughter</b> the bull” (Leviticus 1:4–5). <b>Just as placing hands</b> may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals, <b>so too,</b> the <b>slaughter</b> may be performed only <b>by ritually pure</b> individuals. <b>And if you say</b> that the requirement that placing hands must immediately precede the slaughter is <b>not by Torah law,</b> then <b>with regard to ritually impure</b> individuals <b>you also find</b> that placing hands may be performed, since they can do so outside the courtyard.
<b>Rather, reverse</b> it and say that <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the <b>guilt offering of a leper</b> is <b>not by Torah law,</b> and therefore the leper must do so outside the courtyard, <b>but</b> with regard to offerings that require placing of hands by Torah law, the requirement that <b>immediately</b> following the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> must be the <b>slaughter</b> is <b>by Torah law.</b>

Daf 33b

The Gemara returns to Ulla’s statement in the name of Reish Lakish (32b) that an impure individual who inserted his hand into the Temple courtyard is flogged, as partial entry is considered entry. An objection was then raised from the case of the leper, where he is not liable to be punished with <i>karet</i> for partial entry, and Ulla offered one answer. <b>Ravina says</b> that there is another answer: It <b>was stated</b> only <b>with regard to lashes,</b> teaching that one is flogged for partially entering the courtyard while ritually impure. Reish Lakish agrees that there is no punishment of <i>karet</i> for partial entry as there is for a full entry.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that the statement of Reish Lakish with regard to this verse <b>was stated with regard to a ritually impure</b> individual <b>who touched sacrificial</b> food, and not with regard to partial entry into the courtyard, as Ulla had said.
This is <b>as it was stated:</b> There is an amoraic dispute with regard to <b>an impure person who touched sacrificial</b> food. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged.</b> The Gemara elaborates. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged,</b> as it is written: <b>“Every consecrated item she shall not touch”</b> (Leviticus 12:4). <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged,</b> as <b>that</b> verse <b>is written with regard to</b> touching <b>the portion of the produce designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>].</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>Reish Lakish</b> actually hold that <b>this verse comes to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>He requires this</b> verse to teach <b>a prohibition for</b> a ritually impure person <b>who eats sacrificial meat. As it was stated: From where</b> is <b>the prohibition for</b> a ritually impure person <b>who eats sacrificial meat</b> derived? <b>Reish Lakish says</b> it is derived from the verse: <b>“Every consecrated item she shall not touch,”</b> which the Gemara will explain is referring to eating.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The Sage <b>Bardela teaches</b> that this prohibition is <b>derived from</b> a verbal analogy of the term <b>“his impu-rity [<i>tumato</i>]”</b> written with regard to one who eats sacrificial meat while impure (Leviticus 7:20), and the term <b>“his impurity [<i>tumato</i>]”</b> written with regard to one who <b>enters</b> the <b>Temple</b> while impure (Numbers 19:13). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to entering the Temple while impure, the Torah <b>prescribed</b> the <b>punishment</b> of <i>karet</i> <b>and</b> also explicitly <b>prohibited</b> doing so, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to eating sacrificial meat while impure, the Torah <b>prescribed</b> the <b>punishment</b> of <i>karet</i> <b>and</b> also explicitly <b>prohibited</b> doing so. Clearly, Reish Lakish understood this verse as referring to eating sacrificial meat, not merely touching it.
The Gemara answers: Reish Lakish holds that both can be derived from Leviticus 12:4. The prohibition with regard to <b>a ritually impure</b> individual <b>who touched sacrificial</b> food is derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One expressed</b> this prohibition <b>with a term of touching,</b> while <b>the prohibition with regard to one who eats</b> sacrificial food while impure is derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Torah <b>juxtaposed</b> the prohibition of eating <b>sacrificial</b> food while impure <b>to</b> the prohibition of entering the <b>Temple</b> while impure in the verse: “Every consecrated item she shall not touch, and to the Temple she shall not come” (Leviticus 12:4).
The Gemara comments: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish.</b> It is written: <b>“Every consecrated item she shall not touch”;</b> this is <b>a prohibition for</b> an impure person who <b>eats</b> sacrificial food. <b>Do you say</b> that it is <b>a prohibition for</b> an impure person who <b>eats</b> sacrificial food, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> a prohibition <b>for</b> an impure person who <b>touches</b> sacrificial food?
<b>The verse states: “Every consecrated item she shall not touch, and to the Temple she shall not come”</b> (Leviticus 12:4). The verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the matter pertaining to <b>sacrificial</b> food <b>to</b> the matter of entering the <b>Temple</b> while ritually impure. <b>Just as</b> entering the <b>Temple</b> is <b>a matter</b> that entails a punishment <b>that involves</b>

Daf 34a

<b>the taking of a life,</b> i.e., <i>karet</i>, <b>so too,</b> the <b>matter</b> pertaining to <b>sacrificial</b> food entails a punishment <b>that involves the taking of a life.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>And if</b> the prohibition is <b>with regard to touching</b> sacrificial food, <b>is there</b> a punishment that entails <b>the taking of a life? Rather,</b> the prohibition is <b>with regard to eating.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> this verse is <b>still necessary for</b> Reish Lakish to teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a ritually impure</b> person <b>who ate sacrificial meat before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood of the offering on the altar, when the meat is not yet permitted. <b>As it was stated:</b> With regard to <b>an impure</b> individual <b>who ate sacrificial meat before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged</b> for doing so, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged,</b> as it is written: <b>“Every consecrated item she shall not touch,”</b> without limiting the prohibition to a specific time, indicating that it <b>is no different</b> if one eats the sacrificial meat <b>prior to sprinkling</b> the blood, <b>and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one does so <b>after sprinkling</b> the blood. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged, as</b> the Sage <b>Bardela teaches</b> that the prohibition <b>is derived</b> by means of the verbal analogy cited before, as the verse states <b>“his impurity”</b> with regard to an impure person who eats sacrificial food, and states <b>“his impurity”</b> with regard to an impure person entering the Temple. <b>And when</b> “his impurity” <b>is written,</b> it is with regard to partaking of sacrificial meat <b>after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood (see Leviticus 7:20).
The Gemara answers for Reish Lakish: <b>If so,</b> that the verse was referring only to partaking of sacrificial meat after the sprinkling of the blood, <b>let the verse say: A consecrated item</b> she shall not touch. <b>What</b> is the reason for using the phrase <b>“every consecrated item”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it,</b> i.e., it also includes not eating sacrificial meat before the sprinkling of the blood.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself:</b> With regard to <b>an impure</b> individual <b>who ate sacrificial meat before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged</b> for doing so, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged. Abaye says:</b> This <b>dispute</b> applies <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>impurity of the body</b> of the one who eats the meat, <b>but with regard to impurity of the flesh</b> itself, i.e., if the sacrificial meat was ritually impure, <b>all agree</b> that he is <b>flogged.</b>
This is <b>as the verse states:</b> “And the flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire; and the flesh, every one that is pure may eat the flesh” (Leviticus 7:19). The Sages derived that the extra term <b>“and the flesh”</b> serves <b>to include wood and frankincense, which are not fit for consumption, and even so the verse included them</b> as being susceptible to impurity, and one who eats them while he is impure is flogged. Therefore, sacrificial meat before the sprinkling of the blood, which is fit for consumption, is certainly included in the prohibition.
<b>And Rava says:</b> This <b>dispute</b> applies <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>impurity of the body, but with regard to impurity of the meat all agree</b> that <b>he is not flogged. What is the reason? Since</b> one <b>does not apply to</b> meat before the sprinkling of the blood the verse: “But the soul that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings of the Lord, <b>having his impurity upon him,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from his people” (Leviticus 7:20), which is referring to meat after the sprinkling of the blood, so too, one <b>does not apply to it</b> the prohibition: <b>“And the flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 7:19).
The Gemara challenges the statement of Rava: <b>But doesn’t the Master say</b> that the term <b>“and the flesh”</b> serves <b>to include wood and frankincense</b> that became impure as items that are forbidden to be eaten, despite the fact that they are not fit for consumption? Certainly, then, sacrificial flesh before the sprinkling of the blood should also be included in the category of items forbidden to be eaten.
The Gemara answers: <b>What are we dealing with here,</b> that one would be liable for eating wood and frankincense that are impure? It is a case <b>where</b> the wood and frankincense <b>were sanctified in a vessel,</b> and the reason for the liability is <b>that</b> they are then <b>considered like</b> an item for <b>which all of its permitting factors were sacrificed,</b> such as flesh after the sprinkling of the blood, and only then is one liable for eating it while impure.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 10a): With regard to <b>anything that has permitting factors,</b> i.e., rites that must be performed or items that must be sacrificed before the meat of the offering may be eaten, such as the meat of an offering that is permitted to be eaten by the sprinkling of the blood; one is liable for eating it while impure <b>from</b> the time <b>that its permitting factors were sacrificed.</b> With regard to <b>anything that does not have permitting factors,</b> such as the handful removed from a meal offering and the frankincense, which themselves render the rest of the meal offering permitted for consumption, one is liable for eating it while impure <b>from</b> the time <b>it is sanctified in a vessel.</b>
§ <b>It was stated:</b> In the case of <b>one who offers up the limbs of a non-kosher animal upon the altar, Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>flogged</b> for doing so, while <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He is not flogged.</b> The Gemara explains the logic for each opinion: <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>flogged,</b> because there is a positive mitzva to sacrifice an offering from the herd and the flock (see Leviticus 1:2), which are kosher animals. Therefore, it can be inferred that <b>a kosher</b> animal, <b>yes,</b> one may sacrifice, but <b>a non-kosher</b> animal one may <b>not</b> sacrifice, <b>and</b> one who transgresses <b>a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> is <b>flogged for it. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> One is <b>not flogged for it,</b> as one who transgresses <b>a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> is <b>not flogged for it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Reish Lakish from a <i>baraita</i> cited in <i>Torat Kohanim</i>: “Whatsoever parts the hoof, and is wholly cloven-footed, and chews the cud, among the beasts, <b>that may you eat”</b> (Leviticus 11:3). One can infer: <b>But</b> you may <b>not</b> eat <b>a non-kosher animal; and a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva</b> has the status of <b>a positive mitzva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: I will explain</b> it <b>to you: With regard to</b> one who sacrifices the <b>limbs of a non-kosher animal</b> upon the altar, <b>everyone agrees</b> that he is not flogged, as he violates only a positive mitzva. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> one who sacrifices a kosher <b>undomesticated animal</b> on the altar, <b>and it was stated like this: Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He transgresses a positive mitzva. Reish Lakish says: He does not transgress anything.</b>
The Gemara explains their reasoning: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He transgresses a positive mitzva,</b> since the Torah commanded that <b>a domesticated animal, yes,</b> should be sacrificed, from which it can be inferred that <b>an undomesticated animal</b> may <b>not</b> be sacrificed, and a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva has the status of a positive mitzva. <b>Reish Lakish says: He does not transgress anything,</b> since <b>that</b> verse which instructs one to sacrifice offerings from the herd and the flock is referring <b>to</b> the optimal manner of fulfilling the <b>mitzva,</b> but if he sacrificed an undomesticated animal, he has not transgressed the mitzva.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Had</b> the verse (Leviticus 1:2) <b>stated</b> only: When any man of you brings <b>an offering to the Lord, animals [<i>behema</i>]</b>, <b>I would say</b> that even <b>an undomesticated animal</b> is included <b>in the category of an animal [<i>behema</i>], like that</b> which <b>is stated: “These are the animals [<i>behema</i>] that you may eat: The ox, the sheep, and the goat, the deer, and the gazelle,</b> and the fallow deer, and the wild goat, and the oryx, and the aurochs, and the mountain sheep” (Deuteronomy 14:4–5), and, for example, the deer and gazelle are undomesticated animals. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “From animals, from the <b>cattle and</b> from the <b>flock”</b> (Leviticus 1:2), which indicates that God says: <b>I have told you</b> to bring offerings from the <b>cattle and</b> the <b>flock, but not an undomesticated animal.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that one should <b>not bring</b> an undomesticated animal <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but if</b> one <b>did bring</b> it, it is <b>valid,</b> and <b>to what is this comparable? To a student whose teacher says to him: Bring me wheat, and</b> the student <b>brought him wheat and barley.</b> In this case, <b>it is not as</b> though the student is <b>disobeying the statement of</b> the teacher; <b>rather,</b> he is merely <b>adding to his statement, and</b> that should be <b>valid.</b>
Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> again: “From the <b>cattle”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), <b>and:</b> “From the <b>flock”</b> (Leviticus 1:10), to reiterate that God says: <b>I have told you</b> to bring offerings from the <b>cattle and</b> the <b>flock, but not an undomesticated animal. To what is this comparable? To a student whose teacher told him: Bring me only wheat, and</b> the student <b>brought him wheat and barley. It is not as</b> though the student is <b>adding to the statement of</b> the teacher; <b>rather, it is as</b> though <b>he is disobeying his statement,</b> since his teacher instructed him to bring only wheat. Consequently, one who sacrifices an undomesticated animal does not merely add to a mitzva of the Torah, but also violates a prohibition,

Daf 34b

<b>and</b> the offering is therefore <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of them,</b> in a case <b>where they collected</b> the blood with the intent to offer it beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, if there is blood of the soul that remains in the animal, the priest fit for Temple service should again collect the blood and sprinkle it on the altar. <b>Reish Lakish asked Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If an individual <b>unfit</b> for Temple service presented the blood, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood that remains in the animal? Does the fact <b>that he</b> presented some blood <b>render</b> the rest of it <b>a remainder</b> and no longer fit to be presented, or perhaps the presenting performed by an unfit individual is not considered valid, and therefore a priest fit for Temple service may present the blood again?
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> A not valid presenting <b>does not render</b> the rest of the blood <b>a remainder unless</b> it is a case where a priest fit for Temple service presented the blood with the intent to offer it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, since</b> it is only in that case that the presenting of the blood <b>effects acceptance,</b> i.e., it is considered a valid presenting, <b>with regard to</b> rendering the offering <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its designated time.
<b>Rav Zevid teaches</b> the matter in <b>this</b> way: <b>Reish Lakish asked Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> Concerning <b>a cup</b> of <b>disqualified</b> blood, e.g., one which had been taken out of the Temple courtyard and was then nevertheless presented on the altar, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to it <b>rendering</b> the remaining blood <b>a remainder</b> and unfit to be presented? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> In the case of <b>an unfit</b> individual who <b>himself</b> presented the blood, <b>what do you hold</b> to be the <i>halakha</i>? <b>If an unfit</b> individual who presented the blood <b>renders</b> the remaining blood <b>a remainder,</b> then <b>a cup</b> of <b>disqualified</b> blood should <b>also render</b> the remaining blood <b>a remainder. If an unfit</b> individual does <b>not render</b> the remaining blood <b>a remainder,</b> then <b>a cup</b> of <b>disqualified</b> blood should <b>also not render</b> the remaining blood <b>a remainder.</b>
<b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti teaches</b> the discussion <b>this</b> way: <b>Abaye asked Rabba:</b> If the blood was collected in more than one cup and the presenting of the blood on the corners of the altar was performed with one <b>cup, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does the cup <b>render</b> the blood of <b>the other</b> cup <b>rejected,</b> and it is therefore poured into the drain running through the Temple courtyard, <b>or</b> does it render it <b>a remainder,</b> which is poured on the base of the altar?
Rabba <b>said to him:</b> This is <b>a dispute between Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, and the Rabbis. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the remainder of the blood of the external sin offering: In the verse <b>above,</b> discussing the sin offering of a <i>Nasi</i>, <b>it states:</b> “And <b>he shall pour its blood</b> out at the base of the altar of the burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:25). In the verse <b>below,</b> discussing the sin offering of an individual, <b>it states: “And he shall pour all its blood</b> out at the base of the altar” (Leviticus 4:30).
The discrepancy between the first verse and the second verse, which contains the additional term “all,” is explained as follows: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a sin offering which</b> the priest <b>collected its blood in four cups and placed one placement</b> of blood onto the altar <b>from this</b> cup, <b>and one placement</b> of blood <b>from that</b> cup, and likewise for all four corners of the altar, <b>that</b> the remainder of blood from <b>all</b> the cups <b>are poured</b> out <b>onto the base</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “And he shall pour all its blood.”</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that if <b>he placed four placements</b> of blood of the sin offering <b>from one cup,</b> the blood in <b>all</b> the rest of the cups <b>should be poured onto the base</b> of the altar. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> he shall pour <b>its blood,”</b> and not all of its blood. <b>How so?</b> Only <b>that</b> blood in the cup from which blood was properly presented on the altar <b>is poured onto the base</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> the rest of the cups of blood are rejected and <b>are poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a sin offering which</b> the priest <b>collected its blood in four cups and</b> then <b>placed four placements from one cup, that</b> the blood from <b>all</b> the cups <b>are poured</b> out <b>onto the base</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “And he shall pour all its blood.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written: “And he shall pour its blood,”</b> which indicates that not all of the blood is poured? <b>Rav Ashi said: That</b> verse serves <b>to exclude</b> the <b>remainder that is in the throat of</b> the <b>animal</b> that was never collected in a vessel to be presented, which is not poured onto the base of the altar but into the Temple courtyard drain.
§ The mishna discussed three similar cases: If <b>the</b> priest <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood in a vessel <b>and gave</b> the vessel <b>to an unfit</b> person, that person should return it to the fit priest. If the priest collected the blood in a vessel in his right hand and moved it to his left hand, he should return it to his right hand. If the priest collected the blood in a sacred vessel and placed it in a non-sacred vessel, he should return the blood to a sacred vessel.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it was <b>necessary</b> to mention all of these cases, <b>as had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only the case where he gave the blood to <b>an unfit</b> individual, <b>I would say: What</b> does the term: <b>Unfit,</b> mean? It means <b>an impure</b> priest, who is not completely unfit, <b>as</b> he <b>is fit for communal service</b> in the Temple when the priests or the entire community are impure, and that is why the blood is not disqualified; <b>but</b> if the priest moved the blood to his <b>left</b> hand, which under no circumstances may be used to perform the rite of collecting and carrying the blood, it is <b>no</b> longer valid.
<b>And had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only with regard to moving the blood to his <b>left</b> hand that he should return it to his right hand and present it, one would assume that the reason is <b>that</b> the left hand <b>has validity on Yom Kippur,</b> since the High Priest carries the spoon of incense with his left hand, <b>but</b> if he poured the blood into <b>a non-sacred vessel</b> then it is <b>not</b> valid.
<b>And had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only with regard to <b>a non-sacred vessel</b> that the blood is not disqualified, one could suggest that perhaps it is <b>because</b> the vessels <b>are suitable to be consecrated, but</b> with regard to <b>these,</b> i.e., an unfit individual and the left hand, which have no possibility of becoming fit for service, <b>say</b> that the blood does <b>not</b> remain valid. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for all of the cases to be mentioned.
§ The Gemara questions the actual <i>halakha</i>: <b>But let</b> the blood <b>be</b> considered <b>rejected</b> when placed in the hand of the unfit individual, the left hand, or the non-sacred vessel. <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: This is</b> what <b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti says in the name of Rava:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian, who does not</b> subscribe to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>rejection,</b> but holds that a sacrifice that was rejected temporarily is not rejected entirely.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian says:</b> In the event that the scapegoat of Yom Kippur was lost, <b>even</b> if the <b>blood</b> of its partner that is sacrificed to God has already been collected <b>in the cup,</b> the blood is not rejected, but rather <b>he brings</b> another scapegoat as <b>its counterpart, and pairs it with</b> the goat that has already been slaughtered, and the blood is sprinkled.
<b>Rav Ashi says</b> that there is another explanation to the mishna: <b>Anything that is in his power</b> to rectify <b>is not</b> considered <b>rejected,</b> as in these cases where he can simply return the blood to its proper place.
<b>Rav Shaya said:</b> It <b>is reasonable</b> to explain the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ashi,</b> as <b>whom have you heard who accepts</b> the reasoning of <b>rejection?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 62a): <b>And furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> If <b>the blood</b> of the goat sacrificed to God <b>spilled</b> from the cup before it was sprinkled, <b>the scapegoat</b> is left to <b>die.</b> Similarly, if <b>the scapegoat died, the blood</b> of the goat sacrificed to God <b>should be spilled,</b> and two other goats are used. Consequently, Rabbi Yehuda holds that the scapegoat, or in the opposite case, the blood of the goat to be sacrificed to God, is totally rejected.
<b>And</b> yet, <b>we have heard that</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>says: Anything that is in his power</b> to rectify <b>is not rejected. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A priest <b>would fill one cup with blood of the</b> many Paschal offerings brought that day that was now <b>mixed</b> together on the floor <b>and</b> then <b>sprinkle it</b> with <b>a single sprinkling against the base</b> of the altar. <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that although the blood originally spilled from the cup, <b>anything that is in his power</b> to rectify <b>is not rejected.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from it</b> that it is so.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A priest <b>would fill one cup with the mixed blood,</b> so <b>that if one of</b> the cups with the collected blood of one of the Paschal offerings <b>were to spill,</b> it would be <b>found that this</b> cup of the mixed blood that was sprinkled <b>would render</b> the sacrifice <b>valid.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yehuda: But</b> the mixed blood <b>was not collected in a vessel.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do</b> the Rabbis <b>know</b> that the blood was not collected in a vessel? Perhaps it was collected and it spilled out. <b>Rather,</b> this is what they are saying: <b>Perhaps it was not collected in a vessel.</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to them:</b>

Daf 35a

<b>I too said</b> that the blood should be sprinkled <b>only when it was collected in a vessel.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But he,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>himself, from where did he know</b> if the blood was indeed collected? The Gemara answers: He relies on the fact that <b>priests are vigilant,</b> and perform their service properly and collect all of the blood. <b>But they work swiftly, and</b> the blood therefore <b>spills</b> from the cup.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t blood of exudate,</b> which is unfit to be sprinkled upon the altar, <b>mixed with</b> the blood of the soul on the floor? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> that <b>blood of exudate is considered blood.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Blood of exudate</b> is <b>subject to a prohibition,</b> and one who consumes it receives lashes. This is not as severe as consuming blood of the soul, the blood that spurts out of an animal as it is being slaughtered, for which one is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One who consumes blood of exudate is liable <b>to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as this blood is treated as proper blood.
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda concedes with regard to atonement that</b> presenting blood of exudate <b>does not effect atonement, as it is stated:</b> “For the soul of the flesh is in the blood; and I have given it to you upon the altar to make atonement for your souls; <b>for it is the blood</b> that makes atonement by reason <b>of the soul”</b> (Leviticus 17:11).
This verse indicates that <b>blood with which the soul leaves</b> the animal, i.e., that spurts immediately upon slaughter, <b>is called blood;</b> but blood <b>with which the soul does not leave</b> the animal, i.e., blood of exudate, <b>is not called blood.</b> If so, even according to Rabbi Yehuda, blood of exudate is unfit for presenting upon the altar, and collecting blood from the floor should therefore be ineffective.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Blood does not nullify blood.</b> Therefore, the blood in the cup that is fit for sprinkling on the altar is not nullified by the blood of exudate, and the entire mixture may be sprinkled on the altar.
The Gemara cites the continuation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>According to your statement</b> that the mixed blood on the floor may not be used, <b>why do they plug</b> the drain of <b>the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> on Passover eve and not allow the blood to flow out through it? The Rabbis <b>said to him: It is</b> a source of <b>praise for the sons of Aaron that they should walk in blood up to their ankles,</b> thereby demonstrating their love for the Temple service.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the <b>blood is an interposition</b> between the feet of the priests and the floor of the Temple, and this should invalidate the service. The Gemara explains: The blood <b>is moist and is</b> therefore <b>not an interposition, as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>blood, ink, honey, and milk,</b> when they are <b>dry they interpose,</b> but when they are <b>moist they do not interpose.</b>
The Gemara asks further: <b>But don’t their garments become soiled? And we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a priest’s <b>garments were soiled and he performed</b> a Temple <b>rite</b> while wearing them, <b>his rite is disqualified. And if you would say that they raised</b> their garments so that they would stay clean, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “And the priest shall put on <b>his</b> linen <b>garment [<i>middo</i></b> <i>vad</i>]” (Leviticus 6:3). The term <i>middo</i>, literally, his measure, teaches that his garment must be <b>according to his measure [<i>kemiddato</i>],</b> i.e., <b>that it should not be</b> too <b>short and that it should not be</b> too <b>long.</b> If the priest raises his garment, it will no longer be exactly his size. The Gemara answers that the priests would walk in the blood only <b>while carrying the</b> sacrificial <b>limbs to the ramp</b> of the altar, <b>which is not</b> actually <b>a rite,</b> but only preparation for a rite.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it <b>not</b> one of the rites? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And the priest shall bring it all</b> and burn it upon the altar” (Leviticus 1:13); <b>this is</b> referring to <b>the carrying of the limbs to the ramp? Rather,</b> the priests would walk in the blood only <b>while carrying wood to the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar, <b>which is not a rite.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the floor of the Temple was full of blood; <b>how did they walk to</b> perform <b>the</b> actual <b>rites</b> without soiling their garments? The Gemara answers: <b>They would walk on platforms</b> raised above the floor, so that the blood would not reach their garments.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters an offering</b> with the intent <b>to eat,</b> beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, e.g., the portions of the offering consumed on the altar, <b>or</b> with the intent <b>to burn,</b> beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not burn</b> it on the altar, e.g., the meat of the offering, the offering is <b>fit, and Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>unfit.</b>
One who slaughters an offering with the intent <b>to eat,</b> beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>partake</b> of it, <b>or</b> with the intent <b>to burn,</b> beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>burn</b> it on the altar, but his intent was to partake or burn <b>less than an olive-bulk,</b> the offering is <b>fit.</b> If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, the offering is <b>fit, because eating and burning do not join together.</b>
In the case of <b>one who slaughters an offering</b> with the intent <b>to eat, beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, an olive-bulk from the hide, or from the gravy, or from the spices</b> that amass at the bottom of the pot together with small amounts of meat, <b>or from a tendon in the neck, or from the bones, or from the tendons, or from the horns, or from the hooves,</b> the offering is <b>fit and one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for it,</b> neither <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> if the sacrificial rites were performed with the intent to partake of the offering beyond its designated time, <b>nor</b> due to the prohibition of <b>leftover</b> meat beyond the designated time, <b>nor</b> due to the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b>
In the case of <b>one who slaughters sacrificial</b> female animals with the intent <b>to eat</b> the <b>fetus</b> of those animals <b>or</b> their <b>placenta outside</b> the designated area, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> Likewise, in the case of <b>one who pinches doves,</b> i.e., slaughters them for sacrifice by cutting the napes of their necks with his fingernail, with the intent <b>to eat their eggs</b> that are still in their bodies <b>outside</b> the designated area, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> This is because the fetus, the placenta, and the eggs are not considered part of the body of the animal or the bird.
For the same reason, one who consumes <b>the milk of sacrificial</b> female animals <b>or the eggs of doves is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> it, neither <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, nor</b> due to the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, nor</b> due to the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If one <b>renders an offering <i>piggul</i></b> by slaughtering it with the intent to partake of it beyond its designated time, its <b>fetus is rendered <i>piggul</i></b> as well, and one who eats it is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. But if he intended to partake <b>of the fetus</b> beyond its designated time, <b>the offering has not been rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> Likewise, if <b>he rendered</b> a bird offering <b><i>piggul</i> by</b> having intent to partake of <b>a tendon in the neck,</b> which is edible, beyond its designated time, then <b>the crop</b> of the bird <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i></b> as well, although it is not considered an item that is usually eaten, since there are people who eat it. But if he intended to partake <b>of the crop</b> beyond its designated time, then <b>a tendon in the neck is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b>
If <b>he rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., had improper intent <b>by</b> intending to burn <b>the sacrificial portions</b> that are consumed on the altar beyond their designated time, then <b>the</b> rest of the <b>bulls are rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> Therefore, if one partakes of their meat, he is liable to receive <i>karet</i> due to the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>. But if he intended to partake <b>of</b> the rest of <b>the bulls</b> beyond their designated time, since <i>piggul</i> does not apply to them, as they are not destined to be consumed on the altar or to be eaten, <b>the sacrificial portions</b> that are consumed on the altar <b>are not rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>sup-ports</b> the opinion of Rabbi Elazar: <b>And</b> even those who hold that <i>piggul</i> applies to the bulls that are burned <b>agree that if he intended to partake of the bulls or</b> to <b>burn them</b> beyond their designated time <b>he did not do anything.</b> This is because these bulls are not eaten or burned on the altar, and intentions can render an offering <i>piggul</i> only in the cases of offerings that are eaten or burned on the altar. The Gemara infers: <b>What, is it not</b> possible to infer <b>that</b> if <b>he intended with regard to the sacrificial portions</b> of the bulls that are consumed on the altar to burn them beyond their designated time, the <b>bulls are rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> which is in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Elazar? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b>

Daf 35b

derive instead as follows: <b>But</b> if <b>he intended, with regard to the sacrificial portions</b> of the bulls, to burn them beyond their designated time, the <b>sacrificial portions themselves are rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating them. The flesh of the bulls is never rendered <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 9a): In the case of the <b>bulls that are burned and</b> the <b>goats that are burned,</b> one who derives benefit <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>from</b> the time <b>that they were consecrated.</b> Once <b>they were slaughtered, they are susceptible to being rendered disqualified</b> for sacrifice <b>through</b> contact with <b>one who immersed that day, and through</b> contact with <b>one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>and through</b> being <b>left overnight</b> without the requirements of the offering having been fulfilled.
The Gemara derives: <b>What, is it not</b> referring to the <b>flesh</b> being <b>left overnight,</b> which would render it not valid? <b>And conclude from</b> the mishna that <b>since</b> the flesh <b>is rendered disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight,</b> the flesh is also <b>rendered disqualified</b> by the <b>intention</b> to burn the sacrificial portions the next day, i.e., it is subject to <i>piggul</i>, which is in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Elazar.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>leaving overnight</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> of the offering, not the flesh. Likewise, only the sacrificial portions are rendered <i>piggul</i> by intent to eat them after their designated time. The Gemara asks: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches:</b> One who derives benefit <b>from all of them by the place of the ashes</b> where they are burned is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>until the flesh is</b> completely <b>scorched, it may be inferred that the first clause</b> of the mishna is also referring to the <b>flesh</b> being <b>left overnight.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is. The first clause</b> is referring to the <b>sacrificial portions</b> that are consumed on the altar, <b>and the latter clause</b> is referring to the <b>flesh.</b>
<b>Rabba raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And these</b> are portions of the offering <b>that do not render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i>, and they do not become <i>piggul</i>:</b> The <b>wool that is on the head of</b> the <b>lambs,</b> the <b>hair that is in the beard of</b> the <b>goats, the hide, the gravy, the spices</b> that amass at the bottom of the pot together with small amounts of meat, <b>a tendon in the neck, the crop, the bones, the tendons, the horns, the hooves, the fetus, the placenta, the milk of sacrificial</b> animals, <b>and the eggs of doves.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>All of these do not render</b> other items <b><i>piggul</i></b> in the case of intent to consume them after their designated time, <b>and they are not rendered <i>piggul</i>, and one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for them,</b> neither <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> nor the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, nor</b> the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure. And one who offers up</b> one <b>of these outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt,</b> since they are not fit to be sacrificed on the altar.
Rabba explains: <b>What,</b> does the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> mean that all of these items <b>do not render the offering <i>piggul</i></b> if one intends to partake of them beyond the designated time, <b>and they are</b> also <b>not rendered <i>piggul</i> due to</b> the rest of the <b>offering</b> having been rendered <i>piggul</i>? This includes the fetus and placenta, and is therefore not in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Elazar that the rest of the offering does render them <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it means, that <b>they do not render the offering <i>piggul</i>, and they are not rendered <i>piggul</i> due to themselves</b> if one had intent to partake of them beyond the designated time. But such intent with regard to the offering can render them <i>piggul</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> concerning <b>that which is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause: All of these do not render</b> other items <b><i>piggul</i> and they are not rendered <i>piggul</i>, why do I also</b> need <b>this?</b> Doesn’t it teach that they are not rendered <i>piggul</i> due to the rest of the offering?
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning</b> that the additional statement is necessary, then with regard to that which it says a third time: <b>One is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> them <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, why do I also</b> need <b>this? Rather,</b> the third statement does not teach an additional <i>halakha</i>, but <b>since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> that one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> due to violating the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i> and</b> the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure, he taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>piggul</i></b> as well.
<b>Here too,</b> it can be explained similarly: <b>Since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>one who offers up</b> one <b>of these</b> items <b>outside</b> the Temple is exempt, <b>he also taught: And all of these do not render</b> other items <b><i>piggul</i> and they are not rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> It may be that the rest of the offering does in fact render them <i>piggul</i>, as Rabbi Elazar stated.
<b>Rava says: We learn</b> in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Elazar in the mishna <b>as well: One who slaughters sacrificial</b> female animals with the intent <b>to eat</b> the <b>fetus</b> of those animals <b>or</b> their <b>placenta outside</b> their designated area <b>has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>. And one who pinches doves,</b> i.e., slaughters them for sacrifice by cutting the napes of their necks with his fingernail, with the intent <b>to eat their eggs</b> that are still in their bodies <b>outside</b> their designated area, <b>has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>And then it is taught:</b> One who consumes <b>the milk of sacrificial</b> female animals <b>or the eggs of doves is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> it <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> nor due to the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, nor</b> due to the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure. But</b> it can be inferred that one who partakes of the <b>fetus or placenta,</b> which are not mentioned, is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> due to the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rather, isn’t</b> it correct to <b>conclude from</b> the mishna that <b>here,</b> they are rendered <i>piggul</i> <b>due to the offering,</b> and <b>there, due to themselves,</b> i.e., if he had improper intent concerning them, then they are not rendered <i>piggul</i>. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> the mishna that it is so.
§ The <i>baraita</i> cited by Rabba is now discussed in a different context: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (84a) that if disqualified offerings are nevertheless brought upon the altar, they are removed, <b>and blemished</b> animals are also included in this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Akiva deems blemished</b> animals <b>fit,</b> and if they were brought upon the altar they are not removed.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Akiva deemed fit only</b> an animal with a blemish <b>on the cornea of the eye</b> and similar blemishes that are not noticeable, <b>since they are valid in</b> the case of <b>birds. And</b> in addition, this <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that its consecration preceded its blemish,</b> i.e., when the animal was consecrated it was still entirely fit.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says: And Rabbi Akiva concedes with regard to a female burnt offering</b> that was brought upon the altar <b>that</b> since a burnt offering may be only a male animal, <b>it is comparable to</b> a case <b>where its blemish preceded its consecration,</b> since the disqualifying factor was there from the outset. Therefore, if it was brought upon the altar it must be removed.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises an objection</b> to this from the <i>baraita</i> cited by Rabba: <b>One who offers up</b> one <b>of these outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt,</b> as they are not fit to be sacrificed on the altar. <b>But</b> it can be inferred that if he were to sacrifice <b>from</b> the flesh of the <b>mother of</b> one of <b>these</b> outside the Temple, he would be <b>liable. And how can you find these</b> circumstances? It is only <b>in</b> the case of <b>a female burnt offering.</b> This is because with regard to a peace offering, which may also be from a female animal, its flesh is not burned on the altar but is eaten. Therefore, there would be no liability for sacrificing it outside the Temple.
Rabbi Zeira explains his objection: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> with regard to <b>a female burnt offering</b> that <b>if it ascended</b> onto the altar <b>it does not descend,</b> in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? It <b>is</b> that of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> This is because one is liable for sacrificing any offering outside the Temple that may be sacrificed on the altar, including one that was brought upon the altar inappropriately but is not removed. <b>But if you say</b> that with regard to a female burnt offering <b>if it ascended</b> the altar <b>it</b> must <b>descend,</b> and it entirely lacks the status of an offering fit to be sacrificed on the altar, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>?
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the inference should be as follows: <b>One who offers up</b> one <b>of those</b> items <b>outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt, but</b> if he sacrificed <b>from the sacrificial portions of</b> the <b>mother of</b> one of <b>these,</b> he is <b>liable.</b> This <i>halakha</i> can apply to both a sin offering and a peace offering, for which a female may be brought and whose sacrificial portions are burned on the altar.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i> with the term: <b>Of</b> one of <b>these,</b> indicating that it is referring to one who sacrifices the flesh, and not the sacrificial portions alone. <b>And</b> the case of <b>their mother</b> is <b>similar to</b> that of <b>them,</b> and is therefore referring to sacrificing the flesh of the mother outside the Temple, and not the sacrificial portions. <b>Rather, say</b> as follows: <b>One who offers up</b> part <b>of their sacrificial portions outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt, but</b> one who offered up some <b>of the sacrificial portions of</b> the <b>mother of</b> one of <b>these</b> is <b>liable.</b>
