<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one slaughters</b> the animal <b>in order to leave its blood or its sacrificial portions for the next day, or to remove them outside</b> the designated area, but not in order to sacrifice them the next day, <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> the offering <b>unfit, and the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>fit.</b> In the case of one who slaughters the animal <b>in order to place</b> the blood <b>upon the ramp</b> or on the wall of the altar <b>that</b> is <b>not opposite the base</b> of the altar, <b>or</b> in order <b>to place</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, <b>or</b> to place the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, <b>or</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b>

Daf 36a

<b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>or</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary; and likewise, if he slaughtered the animal with the intent <b>that ritually impure</b> people <b>will partake of it,</b> or <b>that ritually impure</b> people <b>will sacrifice it,</b> or <b>that uncircumcised</b> people <b>will partake of it, or that uncircumcised</b> people <b>will sacrifice it;</b> and likewise, with regard to the Paschal offering, if he had intent during the slaughter <b>to break the bones of the Paschal offering,</b> or <b>to eat from</b> the meat of the Paschal offering <b>partially roasted, or to mix the blood of</b> an offering <b>with the blood of unfit</b> offerings, in all these cases, although he intended to perform one of these prohibited acts, some of which would render the offering unfit, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
The reason is <b>that intent does not render</b> the offering <b>unfit except in</b> cases of intent to eat or to burn the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time and outside its</b> designated <b>area, and</b> in addition, <b>the Paschal offering and the sin offering</b> are disqualified by intent to sacrifice them <b>not for their sake.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who deems the offering unfit if there was intent to leave it over until the next day or to take it out of its designated area? <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> There are <b>two verses</b> that <b>are written with regard to <i>notar</i>. One verse states: “You shall let nothing of it remain until the morning,</b> and that which remains of it until the morning you shall burn with fire” (Exodus 12:10), <b>and one verse states: “He shall not leave any of it until the morning”</b> (Leviticus 7:15). <b>If</b> the additional verse <b>is not</b> necessary for <b>the matter of</b> the prohibition <b>against leaving</b> it overnight, which is already mentioned by the first verse, <b>apply it to the matter of intent of leaving</b> it overnight, which would therefore be prohibited as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, does this verse come to</b> teach <b>this</b> idea? <b>This</b> verse is <b>necessary for him to</b> derive <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving shall be eaten on the day of his offering; he shall not leave any of it until the morning” (Leviticus 7:15). From the words: <b>“And the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving,” we learned with regard to a thanks offering that it is eaten for a day and a night.</b>
With regard to animals <b>exchanged</b> for thanks offerings, <b>and</b> the <b>offspring</b> of thanks offerings, and the <b>substitutes</b> of thanks offerings, <b>from where</b> is it derived that they too are eaten for only a day and a night? <b>The verse states: “And the flesh [<i>uvesar</i>],”</b> and the additional “and” includes them. With regard to <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering, from where</b> is it derived that they are eaten for only a day and a night? <b>The verse states: “Sacrifice,”</b> to include other types of offerings.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>to include the peace offering of a nazirite,</b> i.e., the ram that a nazirite brings at the close of his term of naziriteship, <b>and the peace offering of Passover? The verse</b> therefore <b>states: “His peace offerings,”</b> in the plural. With regard to <b>the loaves of</b> the <b>thanks offering, and the loaves and wafers that</b> are part <b>of</b> the offering brought by <b>a nazirite, from where</b> is it derived that they are eaten for only a day and a night? <b>The verse states: “His offering.” With regard to all of them I</b> will <b>read</b> the phrase <b>“He shall not leave</b> any of it until the morning” as being applicable. Evidently, this verse is necessary to teach numerous <i>halakhot</i> concerning the allotted time to partake of offerings.
The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse state: And you shall let nothing</b> of it <b>remain</b> until the morning, as stated in the other verse. <b>What</b> is indicated by the phrase <b>“He shall not leave</b> any of it”? <b>If</b> it <b>is not</b> necessary for the <b>matter of</b> the prohibition <b>against leaving</b> it overnight, <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of intent</b> to <b>leave</b> it overnight.
The Gemara now questions the source cited by Rabbi Elazar: <b>This works out well</b> to explain the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to one who had intent <b>to leave</b> the sacrificial portions overnight. But with regard to disqualifying the offering due to one who had intent <b>to remove</b> them from the Temple, <b>what can be said</b> to explain the source of Rabbi Yehuda, as it cannot be derived from these verses?
<b>And furthermore,</b> the statement of Rabbi Elazar can be questioned, as <b>the rationale of Rabbi Yehuda is</b> based on <b>logical reasoning</b> and is not derived from a verse. This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Do you not concede that if he left it over until the next day that it is disqualified? So too,</b> if <b>he intended to leave it over until the next day</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> Clearly, Rabbi Yehuda bases his opinion on logical reasoning, as he equates intent with action. The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, is the rationale of Rabbi Yehuda</b> based on <b>logical reasoning</b> and not derived from the verse? <b>But</b> if so, <b>Rabbi Yehuda should also disagree with regard to all of</b> the other cases in the mishna due to the same reasoning.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>With regard to which</b> case <b>should</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagree?</b> Should he disagree <b>with regard to one who</b> slaughters the offering with intent to <b>break the bones of the Paschal offering, or</b> with intent <b>to partake of</b> the Paschal offering while it is <b>partially roasted?</b> Even had he actually realized such intent, <b>would the offering itself</b> thereby <b>be disqualified?</b> It presumably would not, as the presenting of the blood effects acceptance.
Likewise, if a rite was performed <b>on the condition that ritually impure</b> individuals <b>will partake of it, or that ritually impure</b> individuals <b>will sacrifice it,</b> i.e., burn the sacrificial portions on the altar, <b>would the offering itself be disqualified</b> if such actions occurred? Likewise, if it was done with the intent <b>that uncircumcised</b> individuals <b>will partake of it, or that uncircumcised</b> individuals <b>will sacrifice it, would the offering itself be disqualified</b> if this occurred? The Gemara presents <b>another version</b> of this question: <b>Is it in his</b> power to execute these actions that are contingent upon the will of others?
With regard to a case where one had intent <b>to mix their blood with the blood of unfit</b> offerings, where <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> also does not disagree with the ruling of the mishna that the offering is valid, he conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Blood does not nullify blood.</b> Therefore, even if one would actually mix the two types of blood, it would not be disqualified. Likewise, in cases where one had intent <b>to place</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, or those that are to be placed <b>below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says:</b> Blood <b>that</b> was <b>not</b> placed <b>in its</b> proper <b>place</b> on the altar is <b>also considered</b> to be placed in <b>its</b> proper <b>place,</b> and it effects acceptance of the offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let him disagree with regard to</b> a case of blood that is to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>that</b> was <b>placed outside, and</b> blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>that</b> was <b>placed inside,</b> as the verse explicitly states that an external sin offering whose blood was sprinkled inside is disqualified (see Leviticus 6:23).
The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that in order to disqualify an offering with the intent to perform a rite outside its designated area, <b>we require that</b> the intended <b>place have threefold</b> functionality, i.e., <b>for</b> the presenting of the <b>blood, for</b> the eating of the <b>meat, and for</b> the burning of the <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar, which is true only of the area outside the Temple courtyard, which was valid for these three activities during an era in which it was permitted to sacrifice offerings on private altars. Therefore, intent to present the blood in the Sanctuary, which lacks these three elements, does not disqualify the offering, as the meat and sacrificial portions are never eaten or burned there.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda accept this reasoning</b> that it must be a place of threefold functionality? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the verse states: “You shall not sacrifice to the Lord your God an ox, or a sheep, that has a blemish, even any <b>evil thing”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:1). The verse <b>included here a sin offering that one slaughtered in the south</b> and not on the northern side of the Temple courtyard as required, <b>and</b> likewise <b>a sin offering whose blood entered inside,</b> i.e., it was slaughtered with the intent that its blood would be brought inside the Sanctuary, that they are <b>disqualified.</b> This indicates that an offering slaughtered with improper intent with regard to a place that lacks threefold functionality nevertheless renders the offering not valid.
The Gemara responds: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda not accept</b> the requirement of a place of <b>three</b> functions? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (82a) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> If <b>he brought</b> the blood into the Sanctuary <b>unwittingly,</b> the blood remains <b>fit</b> for presenting, from which it may be inferred: <b>But</b> if he brought it in <b>intentionally,</b> it is <b>unfit. And we maintain</b> that Rabbi Yehuda deems it unfit only <b>where</b> one actually <b>effected atonement,</b> i.e., he presented the blood on the inner altar.
<b>Now,</b> it stands to reason that <b>if there,</b> where one actually <b>brought</b> the blood inside, only <b>if he effected atonement, yes,</b> it is unfit, but <b>if he did not effect atonement</b> it is <b>not</b> unfit, then <b>here, where</b> he merely <b>thought</b> to bring it inside, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that it should be valid? The Gemara answers: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> concerning a place with threefold functionality.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda hold</b> that with regard to <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered in the south,</b>

Daf 36b

the slaughterer <b>would be liable</b> to receive lashes?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that with regard to <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered in the south, he would be liable</b> for it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not sacrifice to the Lord your God an ox, or a sheep,</b> that has a blemish, even <b>any evil thing”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:1), to teach that <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>an evil thing,</b> such as a blemished offering, <b>you deem him liable</b> to receive lashes, <b>but you do not deem him liable for a sin offering that he slaughtered in the south.</b> The Gemara answers: Here too, there are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> and they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Abba says:</b> Although Rabbi Yehuda says that an offering is rendered not valid if it was slaughtered with the intent that its blood would be left over until the next day, <b>Rabbi Yehuda concedes that</b> if the priest subsequently collected, conveyed, or presented the blood with the intent to sacrifice or partake of the offering beyond its designated time, <b>he then establishes</b> the offering <b>as <i>piggul</i>.</b> The intent to leave it overnight does not prevent it from being rendered <i>piggul</i>, in contrast to intent to sacrifice or partake of it outside its designated area, or performing a sacrificial rite of the Paschal offering or a sin offering not for its own sake, which do prevent the offering from subsequently being rendered <i>piggul</i> (see 29b).
<b>Rava says: Know</b> that this is so, <b>as</b> intent to sprinkle the blood the next day, which renders an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> and which inherently includes the intent to leave the blood over until the next day so that he can then sprinkle it, <b>is nothing before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood. And his intent during the slaughter to sprinkle the blood the next day does not render the offering <i>piggul</i> until the blood is sprinkled, <b>and</b> then the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>comes and establishes</b> the offering <b>as <i>piggul</i>.</b> Clearly, the intent to leave the blood over until the next day does not prevent the offering from subsequently being rendered <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara rejects Rava’s proof: <b>But it is not so</b> that this is a valid proof, as <b>there,</b> with regard to standard <i>piggul</i> intent, <b>it is one intent</b> that is established with the sprinkling of the blood. By contrast, <b>here,</b> where he initially had intent to leave the blood until the next day and subsequently had intent to sprinkle it beyond its designated time, there are <b>two</b> separate <b>intents.</b> Therefore, since an improper intent already exists, the offering cannot thereafter be rendered <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rav Huna raised an objection to Rabbi Abba</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one slaughtered an offering with the intent <b>to place</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>below</b> the red line, or to place the blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the red line <b>above</b> the red line, and he had intent to do so <b>immediately,</b> i.e., on the same day, then it is <b>valid,</b> as such intent does not disqualify the offering. If <b>he then had intent</b> to sacrifice the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> it is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i> for it.</b> If he had intent to sacrifice it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> then it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for it.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If one had intent to place the blood that is to be placed above the red line below the red line or vice versa <b>the next day,</b> then it is <b>disqualified,</b> due to his intent to leave it overnight, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. In this case, if <b>he then had intent</b> to sacrifice the same offering <b>either beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> it is <b>disqualified, and there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i> for it.</b> Evidently, intent to leave it overnight prevents the offering from subsequently being rendered <i>piggul</i>. The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abba</b> is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Ravina bar Sila says:</b> If one slaughtered an offering with <b>intent that impure</b> individuals <b>would eat</b> the meat of the offering <b>the next day,</b> one is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> due the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>. Although impure individuals are not fit to partake of the meat, this is nevertheless considered intent to partake of it beyond its designated time. <b>Rava says: Know</b> that this is so, <b>as meat prior to</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood is <b>not fit</b> to be eaten, <b>and when</b> one <b>has</b> improper <b>intent with regard to it,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> Clearly, intent to partake of a forbidden item beyond its designated time renders the offering <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara rejects Rava’s proof: <b>But it is not so,</b> as <b>there,</b> with regard to standard <i>piggul</i> intent, <b>he sprinkles</b> the blood, <b>and</b> the meat <b>is rendered fit</b> to be eaten the next day. By contrast, <b>here,</b> it is <b>not rendered fit</b> to be eaten by impure individuals <b>at all.</b> Therefore, such intent is not considered significant intent to consume the meat after its designated time.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Dimi bar Ḥinnana was wont to say</b> the following <i>halakha</i>: With regard to <b>the meat of a Paschal offering that was not roasted, and the loaves of a thanks offering</b> from <b>which</b> the priests’ portion <b>was not separated,</b> although it is prohibited for them to be eaten, nevertheless <b>one is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> violating the prohibition against eating <b>them</b> in a state of <b>impurity.</b>
<b>Rava said: Know</b> that this is so, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “But the soul that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings that pertain to the Lord, having his impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20). The added words <b>“that pertain to the Lord”</b> serve <b>to include the sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity with regard to impurity,</b> teaching that one who partakes of them while impure is liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
<b>Apparently, even though they are not fit for consumption, one is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> violating the prohibition against eating <b>them</b> in <b>ritual impurity. Here too,</b> with regard to the meat of a Paschal offering that was not roasted, and the loaves of a thanks offering from which the priests’ portion was not separated, <b>even though they are not fit to be eaten, one is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> violating the prohibition against eating <b>them</b> in <b>impurity.</b>
The Gemara rejects Rava’s proof: <b>But it is not so,</b> as <b>there, the sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity</b> that are burned on the altar are at least <b>fit for</b> the <b>Most High,</b> i.e., for the consumption of the altar, and therefore one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating them while ritually impure. This is <b>to the exclusion of the meat of a Paschal offering that was not roasted and</b> the <b>loaves of a thanks offering</b> from <b>which</b> the priests’ portion <b>was not separated, which are not fit</b> at all, <b>not for</b> the <b>Most High, and not for an ordinary</b> person.
The Gemara presents <b>another version</b> of the proof and its rejection: <b>But</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> are <b>not fit,</b> and yet one is liable if he consumes them while impure. The Gemara responds: <b>But it is not so,</b> since <b>these</b> sacrificial portions are <b>fit for their matters, and these,</b> i.e., the meat of a Paschal offering that was not roasted and the loaves of a thanks offering from which the priests’ portion was not separated, <b>are not fit at all.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> With regard to <b>all</b> the offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed on the external altar,</b> even those that require that the blood be sprinkled on two opposite corners of the altar so that it will run down each of its four sides, in a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>placed</b> the blood on the altar <b>with</b> only <b>one placement, he facilitated atonement. And in</b> the case of <b>a sin offering,</b> which requires four placements, one on each of the four corners of the altar, at least <b>two placements</b> are necessary to facilitate atonement. <b>And Beit Hillel say: Even</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> in a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>placed</b> the blood with <b>one placement, he facilitated atonement</b> after the fact.
<b>Therefore,</b> since the priest facilitates atonement with one placement in all cases other than a sin offering according to Beit Shammai, and even in the case of a sin offering according to Beit Hillel, <b>if he placed the first</b> placement <b>in its proper manner, and the second</b> with the intent to eat the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, he facilitated atonement.</b> Since the second placement is not indispensable with regard to achieving atonement, improper intent while performing that rite does not invalidate the offering.
<b>And</b> based on the same reasoning, <b>if he placed the first</b> placement with the intent to eat the offering <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time and</b> he placed <b>the second</b> placement with the intent to eat the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the second of which does not render an offering <i>piggul</i>, the offering is <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering disqualified by improper intention, <b>and one is liable</b> to receive <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>] for its</b> consumption. This is because the intent that accompanied the second placement does not supersede the <i>piggul</i> status of the offering.
All this applies to those offerings whose blood is to be placed on the external altar. But with regard to <b>all</b> the offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed on the inner altar, if</b> the priest <b>omitted</b> even <b>one of the placements, it is as though he did not facilitate atonement. Therefore,</b> if <b>he placed all</b> the placements <b>in their proper manner, and one</b> placement <b>in an improper manner,</b> i.e., with the intent to eat the offering beyond its designated time, the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> as it is lacking one placement; <b>but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of the offering, as the improper intention related to only part of the blood that renders the offering permitted for consumption, and an offering becomes <i>piggul</i> only when the improper intention relates to the entire portion of the offering that renders it permitted for consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> those offerings whose blood is <b>placed on the external altar, that</b> if the priest <b>placed</b> the blood <b>with one placement, he facilitated atonement? The verse states: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27), indicating that a single pouring of blood suffices. The Gemara asks: <b>But does this</b> verse <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> discussing a different matter:

Daf 37a

<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that all</b> the <b>blood</b> that is left over from an offering after the requisite placement <b>requires placement of blood on the base</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27). The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> of the first <i>baraita</i> <b>derives</b> this <b>from</b> the verse cited <b>by Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> with regard to a verse discussing a bird sin offering: <b>“And the rest of the blood shall be squeezed out</b> at the base of the altar; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:9). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state “of the blood,”</b> because the entire verse is talking about the blood, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “of the blood”?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Since we</b> have <b>learned only about</b> those offerings whose blood is <b>placed</b> on the altar with <b>four placements,</b> i.e., outer sin offerings, <b>that they require placement of the</b> leftover <b>blood on the base</b> of the altar, <b>from where</b> is it derived that the same applies to the leftover <b>blood</b> of all the <b>other</b> offerings? <b>The verse states: “And the rest of the blood shall be squeezed out</b> at the base of the altar; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:9). <b>Since</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state “of the blood,”</b> because the entire verse is talking about the blood, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “of the blood”?</b> This <b>teaches that all the</b> leftover <b>blood</b> from all the offerings <b>requires placement of blood on the base</b> of the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But still,</b> does <b>this</b> verse, Deuteronomy 12:27, <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that if a priest placed the blood with one placement, he facilitated atonement? <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> those offerings whose blood is supposed to be <b>placed by</b> means of <b>sprinkling</b> from a certain distance from the altar, <b>that</b> if the priest <b>placed</b> the blood <b>by pouring</b> it from up close <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation? <b>The verse states: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27).
The Gemara answers that the ruling in this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael, while the <i>tanna</i> of the earlier <i>baraita</i> <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says: Sprinkling is not included in pouring, and</b> similarly <b>pouring is not included in sprinkling.</b> Rather, these are separate actions performed under different circumstances, and one does not fulfill his obligation to sprinkle the blood by pouring it. Therefore, the verse is available to him to teach that if a priest placed the blood with one placement, he facilitated atonement.
The Gemara demonstrates that this is the opinion of Rabbi Akiva: This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 121a): If <b>one recited the blessing over the Paschal offering,</b> which is: Who sanctified us with His mitzvot and commanded us to eat the Paschal offering, <b>he has</b> also <b>exempted</b> himself from reciting a blessing over the Festival peace <b>offering,</b> i.e., the peace offering that is eaten together with the Paschal offering. The blessing for the Festival peace offering of the fourteenth of Nisan is: Who sanctified us with His mitzvot and commanded us to eat the offering.
If he recited the blessing over the Festival <b>offering, he has not exempted</b> himself from reciting a blessing over <b>the Paschal offering.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b> Rabbi Yishmael’s reasoning is based on the <i>halakha</i> that the blood of the Paschal offering is poured, while the blood of the Festival offering is sprinkled. He maintains that sprinkling is included in the more general category of pouring, and therefore the blessing over the Paschal offering includes the Festival offering. Pouring is not included in the more limited category of sprinkling, and therefore reciting the blessing over the Festival offering does not exempt one from reciting a blessing over the Paschal offering.
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Akiva says: This</b> blessing <b>does not exempt</b> one from reciting a blessing over <b>that one, and that</b> blessing <b>does not exempt</b> one from reciting a blessing over <b>this one.</b> Sprinkling is not included in pouring, and pouring is not included in sprinkling. Therefore, there is a separate blessing for each offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>Still,</b> does <b>this</b> verse, Deuteronomy 12:27, <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that if a priest placed the blood with one placement he facilitated atonement? That verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: Since it is stated: “But the firstborn of a bull, or the firstborn of a sheep, or the firstborn of a goat,</b> you shall not redeem; they are sacred. You shall sprinkle their blood upon the altar and shall burn their fat for an offering made by fire, for an aroma pleasing to the Lord” (Numbers 18:17), <b>we learned with regard to a firstborn</b> animal, which must be given to a priest to be offered on the altar in the Temple, <b>that it requires placement of</b> its <b>blood and sacrificial portions on the altar. From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and a Paschal offering? The verse states: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27). This verse teaches that all offerings require placement of their blood on the altar.
The Gemara answers that the <i>tanna</i> of the earlier <i>baraita</i>, who derives from Deuteronomy 12:27 the <i>halakha</i> that if a priest placed the blood with one placement he facilitated atonement, <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains that the <i>halakha</i> that the blood and sacrificial parts of an animal tithe offering and a Paschal offering must be placed on the altar is derived from the aforementioned verse concerning a firstborn animal: “You shall sprinkle their blood upon the altar and shall burn their fat for an offering made by fire, for an aroma pleasing to the Lord” (Numbers 18:17).
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: It is not stated</b> in this verse: <b>Its blood, but</b> rather: <b>“Their blood.”</b> Similarly, <b>it is not stated: Its fat, but</b> rather: <b>“Their fat.”</b> The plural form <b>teaches with regard to</b> the <b>firstborn</b> animal, which is mentioned explicitly in the verse, as well as with regard to the animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> which have a level of sanctity similar to that of a firstborn animal, <b>that</b> each <b>requires placement of</b> the <b>blood and sacrificial portions on the altar.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yishmael derive</b> one <i>halakha</i> <b>from this verse and</b> then <b>derive</b> another <i>halakha</i> <b>from this</b> same verse? It was stated earlier that Rabbi Yishmael derives from the verse “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured” that sprinkling is included in pouring, and yet here he derives from that same verse that the blood of an animal tithe offering and that of a Paschal offering must be presented on the altar. The Gemara answers: These are the opinions of <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> each of whom expressed his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
The Gemara raises a question with regard to the disagreement about the interpretation of Numbers 18:17. <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who interprets the entire</b> verse as referring <b>to a firstborn</b> animal, and according to whom the plural form in the verse is referring to three such firstborns, that of a bull, that of a sheep, and that of a goat, <b>this</b> explains that <b>which is written</b> immediately afterward: <b>“And their meat shall be yours”</b> (Numbers 18:18), in the plural, i.e., the meat of these firstborn animals shall be eaten by the priests.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who interprets</b> this verse as referring <b>also to</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and a Paschal offering,</b> there is a difficulty, as an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and a Paschal offering are eaten by their owners,</b> not by the priests. If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“and their meat shall be yours”?</b> The Gemara answers that the plural term “their meat,” is referring not to an animal tithe offering or a Paschal offering, but to different types of firstborns, i.e., <b>both an unblemished</b> animal, whose blood is poured on the altar, <b>and a blemished</b> one, which is not brought as an offering on the altar.

Daf 37b

<b>This</b> verse <b>teaches that a blemished firstborn is given to a priest</b> as a gift, and that he may eat its meat. This is a novel concept, <b>as we have not found in the entire Torah</b> another <i>halakha</i> similar <b>to it,</b> where a blemished offering is given to the priests for consumption.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who interprets this verse differently, from where does he derive this <i>halakha</i> that a blemished firstborn is given to a priest? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the phrase: “As the breast of waving and as the right thigh, <b>it shall be yours”</b> (Numbers 18:18), <b>which is the latter clause</b> of that same verse. The repetition of the phrase “shall be yours” serves to teach that even the meat of a blemished firstborn shall be eaten by the priests.
§ The Gemara raises another question: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who interprets</b> the verse as referring <b>also to</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and a Paschal offering, this is as it is written</b> in the same verse: <b>“You shall not redeem; they are sacred”</b> (Numbers 18:17). The word “they” indicates that only <b>they are sacrificed</b> on the altar, <b>but their substitutes are not sacrificed.</b> In general, if one substitutes a non-sacred animal for one designated as an offering, both the original and the substitute are considered to be consecrated, and they are therefore sacrificed. But if one substitutes a non-sacred animal for a firstborn, an animal tithe offering, or a Paschal offering, the substitute is not sacrificed.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 21a): With regard to <b>the substitute of a firstborn and</b> of an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, both <b>they,</b> the substitutes themselves, <b>and their offspring, and the offspring of their offspring, forever,</b> i.e., for all future generations, <b>are as</b> the <b>firstborn and</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, respectively, <b>and</b> therefore <b>they are eaten in their blemished</b> state <b>by the owners;</b> but unlike the firstborn and the animal tithe offering themselves, they are not sacrificed on the altar.
<b>And</b> likewise with regard to the substitute of a Paschal offering, <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 96b) that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: I</b> have <b>heard</b> two rulings from my teachers: One ruling was <b>that the substitute of a Paschal offering is sacrificed</b> as a peace offering after Passover, <b>and</b> another ruling was that <b>the substitute of a Paschal offering is not offered</b> as a peace offering after Passover; <b>and I cannot explain</b> these apparently contradictory rulings, as I do not remember the circumstances to which each ruling applies. And as will be explained, if the substitution took place after the sacrifice of the Paschal offering, the animal is sacrificed, as it is considered the substitute of a peace offering, whereas if the substitution occurred before the sacrifice of the Paschal offering, it is not sacrificed, as it is the substitute of a Paschal offering. This indicates that the substitute of a Paschal offering is not sacrificed, just like the substitute of a firstborn is not sacrificed.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who interprets the entire</b> verse as dealing <b>with a firstborn, from where does he</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>that the substitute of</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>and</b> of <b>a Paschal offering are not sacrificed?</b> The Gemara answers: With regard to an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>he derives</b> this by means of a verbal analogy between the terms <b>passing,</b> and <b>passing</b> written <b>with regard to a firstborn.</b> Concerning a firstborn it is stated: “And you shall pass [<i>veha’avarta</i>] to the Lord all that opens the womb” (Exodus 13:12), and concerning an animal tithe it is stated: “Of whatever passes [<i>ya’avor</i>] under the rod” (Leviticus 27:32). From this verbal analogy it may be derived that just as the substitute of a firstborn is not sacrificed, so too, the substitute of an animal tithe offering is not sacrificed.
With regard to the <b>Paschal offering,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is not derived through a verbal analogy, but rather this <i>halakha</i> <b>is explicitly written concerning it.</b> The verse referring to peace offerings states: “If he offers a lamb for his offering” (Leviticus 3:7). The Torah could simply have stated: <b>A lamb,</b> and proceed from there to teach the <i>halakhot</i> of a lamb peace offering. If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “If</b> he offers <b>a lamb”?</b> This serves <b>to include the substitute of a Paschal offering</b> that was substituted <b>after</b> the sacrifice of <b>the Paschal offering,</b> teaching <b>that it is sacrificed as a peace offering,</b> since the Paschal offering has the status of a peace offering after that time. One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even before</b> the sacrifice of <b>the Paschal offering the same</b> should apply, i.e., that the substitute of a Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the Paschal offering: “It is the sacrifice of the Lord’s Passover” (Exodus 12:27), which indicates that <b>it,</b> the Paschal offering itself, is sacrificed, but its substitute is not sacrificed.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>all those <i>tanna’im</i> who derive a different exposition from this</b> verse: <b>“And the blood of your offerings shall be poured”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27), <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> that is recorded in the mishna, that with regard to <b>all</b> the offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed on the external altar,</b> in a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>placed</b> the blood on the altar with <b>one placement, he facilitated atonement, from where do they</b> derive this? The Gemara answers: Those <i>tanna’im</i> <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel, who say: Even</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> in a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>placed</b> the blood with <b>one placement, he facilitated atonement</b> after the fact. <b>And they derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> applying to <b>all</b> the other offerings <b>from</b> that which applies to <b>a sin offering.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that Beit Shammai maintain that in the case of <b>a sin offering,</b> which requires four placements, at least <b>two placements</b> are necessary to facilitate atonement, whereas Beit Hillel hold that even in the case of a sin offering one placement suffices. <b>Rav Huna said: What is the reasoning</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Shammai?</b>
He explains: The verse states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, and put it upon the <b>corners</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:25). Subsequently, the verse states: “The priest shall take of its blood with his finger, and put it on the <b>corners</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:30), and an additional verse states: “The priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, and put it on the <b>corners</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:34). As the mini-mum amount justifying the use of the plural form, i.e., in the word “corners,” is two, one may conclude that <b>there are six</b> references to the corners of the altar <b>here. Four</b> of them are mentioned <b>for a mitzva,</b> meaning that the priest should place the blood on all four corners of the altar <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and</b> the other <b>two</b> are mentioned <b>to invalidate</b> the offering if he did not present the blood on at least two corners.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the reasononing for the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel?</b> The Gemara answers: The matter should be understood according to the written consonantal text, i.e., the way in which the words are actually spelled. The word <b>“corners”</b> is written plene, i.e., with a <i>vav</i>, in one of the verses, which means that it must be read in the plural form. In the other two verses, <b>“corners”</b> and <b>“corners”</b> are written deficient, i.e., without a <i>vav</i>, in a way that can be vocalized in the singular form, i.e., as <i>karnat</i>. Therefore, <b>there are four</b> references to corners <b>here. Three</b> of these references are written <b>to</b> indicate the placements of blood are performed only as <b>a mitzva,</b> i.e., they are performed <i>ab initio</i>, and the remaining <b>one</b> is written <b>to</b> indicate that its absence <b>invalidates</b> the offering, i.e., the offering is not valid if the blood was not placed against at least one corner of the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to this explanation of Beit Hillel, why not <b>say</b> that <b>all of them are</b> written <b>for</b> the <b>mitzva</b> and none are to invalidate, i.e., that the blood must be presented on all four corners <i>ab initio</i>, but the offering atones after the fact even if the blood was not presented at all? The Gemara rejects this possibility: <b>We have not found</b> anywhere in the Torah an example of an offering in which <b>atonement</b> can be achieved <b>with no</b> placement of the blood.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this is the reason of Beit Hillel: The vocalized text</b> of the Torah, i.e., the way in which the words of the Torah are pronounced based on the tradition of what vowels the words contain, <b>is effective</b> in determining how the verses are to be expounded. <b>And</b> likewise, <b>the consonantal text</b> of the Torah, i.e., the way in which the words are actually written, <b>is</b> also <b>effective</b> in determining how the verses are to be expounded. The Gemara elaborates: <b>The vocalized text is effective in adding one</b> more corner <b>and the consonantal text is effective in subtracting one</b> corner. Consequently, the verse is interpreted as referring to five corners, four of which are necessary for the mitzva <i>ab initio</i>, and one of which is indispensable after the fact.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if that is so,</b> that this is the proper manner of expounding the verses, consider the case of the phylacteries of the head, about which it is stated: “And <b>for frontlets [<i>totafot</i>]</b> between your eyes” (Exodus 13:16), and: “They shall be <b>for frontlets [<i>totafot</i>]</b> between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 6:8), and subsequently: “They shall be <b>for frontlets [<i>totafot</i>]</b> between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 11:18). The word <i>totafot</i> is written once in plene form, i.e., with a <i>vav</i>, indicating the plural form, and twice in a deficient form, i.e., without a <i>vav</i>, indicating the singular. Accordingly, <b>there are four</b> frontlets <b>here,</b> and from here the Sages derive that the phylacteries of the head consist of four compartments, which together form a cube. Why not say that <b>the vocalized text,</b> read in the plural, <b>is effective,</b> i.e., that it requires six compartments, <b>and</b> likewise, <b>the consonantal text,</b> read in the singular, <b>is effective,</b> i.e., it requires four compartments, and therefore one should be <b>required to prepare five compartments</b> for the phylacteries of the head?
The Gemara answers that Beit Hillel <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that the requirement to have four compartments in the phylacteries of the head is not derived from the number of times that the word <i>totafot</i> is mentioned, but rather from an exposition of the word <i>totafot</i> itself: <b><i>Tot</i> in</b> the <b>Katpi</b> language means <b>two,</b> and <b><i>pat</i> in</b> the <b>Afriki</b> language means <b>two,</b> for a total of four.
The Gemara raises another objection to this method of exposition: <b>If that is so,</b> consider the case of a <i>sukka</i>, about which it is stated: <b>“In <i>sukkot</i> [<i>basukkot</i>]</b> shall you reside seven days; all that are homeborn in Israel shall reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i> [<i>basukkot</i>].</b> So that your future generations will know that I caused the children of Israel to reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i> [<i>basukkot</i>]</b> when I took them out of the land of Egypt: I am the Lord your God” (Leviticus 23:42–43). Two instances of the word <i>basukkot</i> are written in a deficient manner, i.e., without a <i>vav</i>, indicating the singular, and one instance is written in plene form, i.e., with a <i>vav</i>, indicating the plural form. The Sages derived from here that a <i>sukka</i> must have four walls. Why not say that <b>the vocalized text,</b> read in the plural, <b>is effective,</b> requiring six walls, <b>and</b> likewise, <b>the consonantal text,</b> read in the singular, <b>is effective,</b> requiring four walls, and therefore one should be <b>required to build</b> a <i>sukka</i> with <b>five walls?</b>

Daf 38a

The Gemara answers: <b>There, one</b> of the five indicated by the <b>verse is</b> needed <b>entirely for</b> the mitzva <b>itself,</b> i.e., to teach the basic <i>halakha</i> that one must dwell in a <i>sukka</i>. <b>And</b> another <b>one</b> of the five is needed <b>to</b> teach that a <i>sukka</i>, as is indicated by its name, must have <b>a covering [<i>sekhakha</i>].</b> Accordingly, there are three left, alluding to the requirement that a <i>sukka</i> must have three walls. The Gemara adds that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai <b>comes and reduces the</b> size of the <b>third</b> wall, teaching that it need not be complete, <b>and sets</b> its minimum length <b>at</b> only <b>one handbreadth.</b>
The Gemara raises yet another objection: <b>If that is so,</b> that both the vocalized and the consonantal texts are taken into account, consider the case of a woman who gives birth to a female child. Concerning this woman the verse states: “But if she bear a female child, <b>then she shall be impure two weeks [<i>shevu’ayim</i>],</b> as in her menstruation” (Leviticus 12:5). The way that the word is written allows it to be read as <b><i>shivim</i>,</b> seventy. Why not say that <b>the vocalized text</b> of the Torah <b>is effective,</b> teaching us that the woman is ritually impure for fourteen days, <b>and the consonantal text is</b> also <b>effective,</b> teaching us that she is impure for seventy days, and, therefore, <b>she</b> should be <b>required to sit</b> in a state of ritual impurity for <b>forty-two</b> days, which is the halfway point between fourteen and seventy days?
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different,</b> and the consonantal text is disregarded entirely, <b>as it is written: “As in her menstruation,”</b> and a menstruating woman is impure for one week. Evidently, the verse is speaking in terms of weeks, and is not alluding to the number seventy at all.
§ The Gemara further analyzes the opinion of Beit Hillel that even in the case of a sin offering, if the priest placed the blood on the altar with one placement, he facilitated atonement. <b>And a <i>tanna</i> cites</b> proof <b>for this from here,</b> as it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sin offering brought by a king: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:26), and with regard to the goat brought as a sin offering by an ordinary person: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:31), and with regard to the sheep brought as a sin offering by an ordinary person: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:35). The repetition of this term is <b>due to a logical inference.</b>
<b>As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought to say: <b>Could this not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference</b> as follows: It <b>is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is placed <b>below</b> the red line, <b>and</b> it <b>is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is placed <b>above</b> the red line. <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood concerning</b> which it <b>is stated</b> that it is placed <b>below</b> the red line, <b>when</b> the priest <b>placed</b> it on the altar <b>with one placement he facilitated atonement, so too,</b> with regard to the <b>blood concerning</b> which it <b>is stated</b> that it is placed <b>above</b> the red line, <b>when</b> the priest <b>placed</b> it on the altar <b>with one placement he facilitated atonement.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way,</b> turning away from the previous explanation and toward this explanation: It <b>is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is presented <b>on</b> the <b>inner</b> altar, i.e., with regard to a sin offering of the community or of the High Priest; the blood of these offerings is sprinkled on the incense altar that is inside the Sanctuary. <b>And</b> it <b>is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is presented <b>on</b> the <b>external</b> altar, i.e., with regard to the sin offering of an ordinary person, which is offered on the outer altar that is in the courtyard. <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood concerning</b> which it <b>is stated</b> that it is presented <b>on</b> the <b>inner</b> altar, if the priest <b>omitted one of the placements he has done nothing,</b> i.e., the offering is not valid, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>blood concerning</b> which it <b>is stated</b> that it is presented <b>on</b> the <b>external</b> altar, if the priest <b>omitted one of the placements he has done nothing.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the two possibilities: <b>Let us see to which</b> of the two cases the blood of an animal sin offering is more <b>similar.</b> It can be claimed: We <b>derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar, <b>but</b> we <b>do not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>inner</b> altar. <b>Or, go this way: We derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to <b>a sin offering</b> whose blood is to be placed on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to <b>a sin offering</b> whose blood is to be placed on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar. <b>But</b> a sin offering consisting of a bird, <b>which is not a sin offering</b> whose blood is to be placed on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar, <b>cannot serve as proof</b> to the <i>halakha</i> concerning an animal sin offering, whose blood is to be placed on the four corners of the altar.
Since both of the above inferences are reasonable, neither can serve as the source of the <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,”</b> for a total of three times. The verses are interpreted as follows: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he placed only three</b> placements. Subsequently: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he placed only two</b> placements, and then: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he placed only one</b> placement. This interpretation is the source of Beit Hillel’s opinion.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> each of these verses <b>is necessary for itself,</b> to teach that atonement is achieved for each of the sins through its respective sin offering. <b>Rava said: Bar Adda Mari explained</b> this matter <b>to me: The verse states</b> with regard to each of these sin offerings: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement…and he shall be forgiven”</b> (Leviticus 4:26, 31, 35). <b>This is atonement</b> and <b>this is forgiveness;</b> they are one and the same. Since it would have sufficed to say: “And he shall be forgiven,” the superfluous mentions of the phrase: “And the priest shall make atonement,” serve to teach that the priest facilitates atonement even if he has not performed all the placements.
The Gemara asks: But even if these phrases are superfluous, do they necessarily indicate that a priest who omitted placements has nevertheless facilitated atonement? Why not <b>say</b> that these phrases serve to teach that if the priest placed all the placements he facilitated atonement even if the placements were placed in the wrong place? And expound the verses as follows: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he placed</b> the blood on the altar with <b>only three</b> placements <b>above,</b> on the corners of the altar, <b>and one below,</b> on the lower portion of the altar; <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he placed</b> the blood with <b>only two</b> placements <b>above and two below; “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even if he did not place</b> the blood <b>above</b> at all, <b>but</b> only <b>below.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Yitzḥak says: If so,</b> that the priest facilitates atonement even if he placed all the placements below, <b>you have abolished the requirement of four corners</b> that is stated with regard to the sin offering (see, e.g., Leviticus 4:34), as the four corners are on the upper portion of the altar. The Gemara is puzzled by Rav Adda bar Yitzḥak’s claim: <b>But if the Merciful One states</b> that this is so, <b>let</b> this requirement <b>be abolished.</b>
As Rav Adda bar Yitzḥak’s claim was rejected, <b>Rava said</b> there is a different reason why the previous claim cannot be accepted: <b>What is</b> the <b>item that requires three</b> repetitions of “and the priest shall make atonement,” i.e., to what are these verses referring? <b>You must say</b> that <b>these are</b> the <b>corners</b> of the altar. The Torah must teach that the priest facilitates atonement even if he did not place the blood on three of the four corners. But in order for the verses to teach that all four placements can be placed below, the phrase “and the priest shall make atonement” would have to be written four times.
The Gemara asks further: Even so, it is possible to interpret the three repetitions of the phrase “and the priest shall make atonement” as referring to the location of the placements, without abolishing the requirement of corners, as one can <b>say:</b> “And the priest shall make atonement,” even though he placed the blood on the altar with only three placements above and one below; “And the priest shall make atonement,” even though he placed the blood with only two placements above and two below; <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” even though he placed</b> the blood with <b>only one</b> placement <b>above and three below.</b>
The Gemara answers: This entire line of inquiry can be rejected, as <b>we do not find</b> a case involving <b>blood, half of which</b> is placed <b>above</b> the red line <b>and half of which</b> is placed <b>below</b> it. One either places all the blood on the lower half of the altar, as in the case of most offerings, or all of it on the upper half of the altar, as in the case of sin offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there really <b>no</b> case of that sort? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 53b): The High Priest took the blood of the bull into the Holy of Holies and <b>sprinkled from</b> the blood <b>one</b> time <b>upward and</b> then <b>seven</b> times <b>downward?</b> Apparently, part of the blood of an offering can be sprinkled upward, toward the upper part of the Ark Cover, and part can be placed downward, toward the lower part of the Ark Cover.
The Gemara rejects this: That is not a case where half the blood is sprinkled upward and half is sprinkled downward. Instead, that sprinkling was <b>like a <i>matzlif</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>like a <i>matzlif</i>? Rav Yehuda demonstrated</b> with his hand; it means <b>like one who whips.</b> One who whips another does not strike repeatedly in one place but directs one lash beneath the other.
The Gemara further asks: And is there really no case of that sort? But didn’t we learn in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 58b) about the Yom Kippur service: After the High Priest sprinkled blood on the four corners of the incense altar, <b>he sprinkled</b> blood <b>seven times on <i>tohoro</i> of the altar.</b>

Daf 38b

<b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>to</b> the <b>middle</b> of the side <b>of the altar, as people say: Clear noon [<i>tihara</i>],</b> that is the middle <b>of the day?</b> Accordingly, the root <i>tet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>reish</i> denotes the middle; in the one case, the middle of the day, and in the other case, halfway up the altar. Now, since the blood was sprinkled on the altar seven times, inevitably some of the blood landed above the midpoint and some of it landed below the midpoint. <b>Rava bar Sheila said: No,</b> that is not the meaning of <i>tohoro</i>. Rather, <i>tohoro</i> means <b>on the revealed</b> part, i.e., the top, of the altar, <b>as it is written: “Like the very clear [<i>latohar</i>] sky”</b> (Exodus 24:10). <i>Tohoro</i> is referring to the top of the altar when it has been revealed, after the ashes of the incense are cleared and the pure gold is visible.
The Gemara asks again: Is there not a case where some of the blood is presented above the red line and some of it is presented below? <b>But there is</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood, which is poured on the base of the altar even in the case of a sin offering, the main blood of which is placed on the upper portion of the altar. The Gemara answers: The pouring of the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar <b>is not indispensable</b> for atonement. Blood that is indispensable for atonement is in no instance presented half above the red line and half below it.
The Gemara continues this line of questioning: <b>But there is the remainder</b> of the blood <b>of the inner</b> sin offerings, the main blood of which is sprinkled on the inner altar. The remainder of the blood of these offerings is poured on the base of the external altar, and <b>there is one who says</b> that this pouring of the blood is <b>indispensable</b> for atonement. The Gemara explains: When we said that there is no blood, half of which is presented above and half below, <b>we said</b> this <b>with regard to one place,</b> i.e., the same altar. The blood of inner sin offerings is sprinkled on the inner altar, while the remainder of that blood is poured on the base of the external altar. There is no case of blood, half of which is presented above and half of which is presented below on the same altar.
§ The mishna teaches that according to the opinion of Beit Shammai, in the case of a sin offering two placements facilitate atonement, while with regard to other offerings a single placement is sufficient. Beit Hillel disagree and say that even in the case of a sin offering one placement suffices after the fact. With regard to this issue, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Beit Shammai say</b> that <b>two placements in</b> the case of <b>a sin offering, and one</b> placement <b>in</b> the case of other <b>offerings, they render</b> the offering <b>permitted</b> for eating since these actions facilitate atonement after the fact, despite the fact that blood was not placed on all four corners of the altar.
<b>And</b> similarly <b>they render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> That is to say, if the priest placed two placements of the blood of a sin offering or one placement of the blood of any another offering, intending to eat or burn the offering beyond its designated time, the offering is <i>piggul</i>. <b>Beit Hillel say: One</b> placement <b>in</b> the case <b>a sin offering, and</b> likewise <b>one</b> placement <b>in</b> the case of <b>all</b> the other <b>offerings,</b> if done with proper intent, renders the offering <b>permitted</b> for eating <b>and,</b> if done with improper intent, <b>renders</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Oshaya objects to this: If so, let</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>be taught</b> in the fourth chapter of tractate <i>Eduyyot</i> <b>alongside</b> the other rare cases of <b>Beit Shammai’s leniencies and Beit Hillel’s stringencies.</b> According to Beit Hillel, a sin offering is <i>piggul</i> even if the priest intended to partake of it beyond its designated time even while performing a single placement, whereas Beit Shammai maintain that the offering is <i>piggul</i> only if he had this improper intent during two placements.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Oshaya: <b>When</b> this question <b>was</b> initially <b>asked,</b> and the Sages stated their opinions concerning the matter, <b>it was asked with regard to the permission</b> to partake of the sin offering. In other words, the dispute arose as a result of an inquiry into the other relevant <i>halakha</i>, i.e., whether the priests may partake of a sin offering, the blood of which was placed only one time. In this case it is <b>Beit Shammai who are</b> more <b>stringent,</b> as they permit the meat of a sin offering only after two placements have been placed. For this reason, this case was not listed among the other leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Despite the fact that, according to the opinion of Beit Hillel, the last <b>three placements in</b> the case of <b>a sin offering</b> are not indispensable to the atonement, they <b>may not be performed at night,</b> because the blood is invalidated at sunset. <b>And</b> these three placements <b>may be performed after</b> the <b>death</b> of the owner. If the owner of the offering died before any of the blood was placed on the altar, the blood may not be placed, and the offering is burned as a disqualified offering. But if he died after one placement, the priest may perform the other three placements, as he has already facilitated atonement by means of the first placement. <b>And</b> as it is a mitzva to perform these three placements on the altar, <b>one who offers</b> this blood <b>up</b> on an altar <b>outside</b> the Temple is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>, the punishment received by one who offers a sacrifice outside the Temple.
<b>Rav Pappa says: There are some</b> respects in which the blood of the last three placements of a sin offering is treated <b>like</b> the blood presented <b>at the outset,</b> i.e., like the blood of the first placement, <b>and there are some</b> respects in which the blood of the last three placements is treated <b>like</b> the blood presented <b>at the end,</b> i.e., like the remainder of the blood of a sin offering.
Rav Pappa elaborates: With regard to liability for presenting blood <b>outside</b> the Temple, <b>and</b> concerning the prohibition against presenting blood at <b>night,</b> and with regard to the disqualification of <b>a non-priest</b> from presenting blood and his liability for death at the hand of Heaven if he presents blood in the Temple, <b>and</b> with regard to the requirement that the blood that is to be presented must first be placed in <b>a service vessel,</b> and that the blood must be placed on the <b>corner</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> that the placement must be performed with the priest’s <b>finger,</b> and concerning the obligation to <b>launder</b> a garment onto which the blood of a sin offering sprayed, <b>and</b> finally with regard to the requirement of pouring the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar, the last three placements are treated <b>like</b> blood presented at <b>the outset,</b> i.e., like the first placement.
<b>But</b> these last three placements <b>may be performed after</b> the <b>death</b> of the owner; and they do <b>not</b> render the offering <b>permitted</b> for eating, as that was already achieved by means of the first placement; <b>nor</b> do they <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> if during these placements the priest intended to eat or burn the offering beyond its designated time; <b>and</b> similarly, they are <b>not</b> governed by the <i>halakha</i> that if the blood <b>enters inside</b> the Sanctuary the sin offering is disqualified. With regard to all these matters the blood of the last three placements is treated <b>like</b> the blood presented <b>at the end,</b> i.e., like the remainder of the blood of a sin offering.
With regard to the obligation to launder a garment onto which the blood of a sin offering sprayed, <b>Rav Pappa said: From where do I say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies even to the blood of the last three placements? It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (93a): If the blood of a sin offering <b>sprayed</b> directly <b>from the neck</b> of the animal <b>onto a garment,</b> that garment <b>does not require laundering,</b> as the blood had never been received in a vessel. Likewise, if the blood sprayed onto the garment <b>from the corner</b> of the altar after having been placed there, <b>or from the base</b> of the altar after the remainder was poured there, the garment <b>does not require laundering.</b> It may be inferred from here that blood that sprayed from the corner of the altar does not require laundering. <b>But</b> blood that is <b>fit</b> to be placed <b>on the corner,</b> as it has not yet been placed, <b>requires laundering,</b> and the blood of the last three placements is indeed fit to be placed on the corner of the altar.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But according to your reasoning,</b> one can claim in the same manner that it is only blood that sprayed <b>from the base</b> of the altar that <b>does not require laundering; but</b> blood <b>that is fit for the base</b> of the altar, i.e., what remains of the blood after it has been placed on the corners, <b>requires laundering.</b> This is difficult, as <b>it is written:</b> “And <b>when there will be sprinkled [<i>yizze</i>]</b> of its blood upon any garment” (Leviticus 6:20). The future form of the word <i>yizze</i> serves to <b>exclude</b> this blood sprayed onto the garment from the corner of the altar, <b>as it has already been sprinkled.</b>
The Gemara explains: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> ruling? It is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, as we learned</b> in a mishna (110b) that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> With regard to the <b>remainder of the blood</b> of an offering, <b>which</b> was to be poured at the base of the altar, if <b>one presented it outside</b> the Temple, he is <b>liable.</b> Since Rabbi Neḥemya treats the remainder of the blood as blood with regard to liability for a service performed outside the Temple, he also treats the remainder of the blood of a sin offering as blood with regard to laundering. Accordingly, Rav Pappa’s inference from the previously cited mishna is valid only according to Rabbi Neḥemya, but not according to the majority opinion of the Rabbis, who disagree with him.
The Gemara challenges the proof even according to the opinion of Rabbi Neḥemya: <b>Say that you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> ruled in this manner <b>with regard to the offering up</b> of the remainder of the blood outside the Temple, <b>just as</b> is the case <b>with regard to limbs and fats.</b> Even though the offering of the limbs and fats is not indispensable for atonement, one who offers them outside the Temple is liable. But <b>did you</b> also <b>hear him</b> say this <b>with regard to laundering,</b> that one must launder a garment sprayed with the remainder of the blood of a sin offering? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> we also heard Rabbi Neḥemya rule in this manner with regard to laundering.

Daf 39a

<b>And</b> this is as <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>blood that requires</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar, presumably a reference to the remainder of the blood of a sin offering, which must be poured on the base of the altar, it <b>requires laundering; and</b> improper <b>intent is effective with regard to it,</b> i.e., if the priest poured such blood with the intent to partake of the sacrificial meat beyond its designated time, the offering is <i>piggul</i>; <b>and one who offers it up outside</b> the Temple is <b>liable.</b>
<b>And</b> conversely, with regard to <b>blood that is poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain</b> that passed through the Temple and emptied into the Kidron River, which is blood that has been become disqualified, it <b>does not require laundering, and</b> improper <b>intent is not effective with regard to it, and one who offers it up outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara inquires: About <b>whom did you learn that he said</b> that <b>one who offers up</b> the remainder of the blood <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>is liable? It is Rabbi Neḥemya</b> who says this, <b>and he states</b> in this <i>baraita</i> that a garment that was sprayed with such blood <b>requires laundering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> improper <b>intent effective with regard to</b> blood that must be poured on the base of the altar? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> discussing the intent that renders an offering <i>piggul</i>: The possibility of <i>piggul</i> applies only with regard to a service that is indispensable for atonement. This serves to <b>exclude</b> pouring the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the altar <b>and burning</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the altar, actions <b>that are not indispensable for atonement,</b> concerning which the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> improper <b>intent is not effective with regard to them.</b>
Rather, <b>when that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught,</b> stating that blood that requires the base requires laundering, it is not referring to the remainder of the blood after the placements have been completed. Instead, it is referring <b>to</b> the blood that is to be used for the last <b>three placements</b> of the blood <b>of a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> is it correct to describe this blood as <b>requiring</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar? After all, this blood <b>goes to the corner</b> of the altar, not the base. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that this means: Blood that becomes <b>required</b> for the <b>base,</b> i.e., blood that in the end, after the placements are completed, will be poured on the base of the altar. The Gemara further asks: <b>But is</b> improper <b>intent effective with regard to</b> the blood of the last three placements of the blood of a sin offering? <b>Didn’t you say</b> that this blood does <b>not render</b> the offering <b>permitted</b> for eating, <b>nor</b> does it <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, and</b> it is <b>not</b> governed by the <i>halakha</i> that if the blood <b>enters inside</b> the Sanctuary the sin offering is disqualified? With regard to all these matters the blood of the last three placements is treated <b>like</b> the blood presented at <b>the end,</b> i.e., like the remainder of the blood of a sin offering.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather, when that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught,</b> stating that blood requiring the base requires laundering, and improper intent is effective with regard to it, and one who presents of it outside the Temple is liable, it is indeed referring to the remainder of the blood after the placements have been completed. It is stated not with regard to the remainder of the blood of a standard sin offering, but <b>with regard to</b> the remainder of <b>the blood of inner</b> sin offerings, which are brought on the inner altar located inside the Sanctuary.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is the case, <b>with regard to</b> the remainder of <b>the blood of external</b> sin offerings that are brought on the external altar, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is one who presents them outside the Temple <b>exempt?</b> If so, <b>rather than teaching</b> the <i>halakha</i> of disqualified <b>blood that is poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain, let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>within the</b> case of the remainder of the blood <b>itself,</b> in the following manner: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> a case of <b>the blood of</b> sin offerings brought on the <b>inner</b> altar. <b>But in</b> the case of <b>the blood of</b> sin offerings brought on the <b>external</b> altar, one who offers up such an offering outside the Temple is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> could not have made such a distinction, for in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> ruling? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, who says:</b> With regard to the <b>remainder of the blood</b> of a sin offering brought on the external altar, in a case <b>where one presented it outside</b> the Temple, he is <b>liable. And</b> therefore, were the <i>tanna</i> to contrast the <i>halakha</i> of the blood of sin offerings brought on the external altar with that of the blood of sin offerings brought on the inner altar, <b>he would not</b> have been able to <b>teach three</b> rulings of <b>exemptions corresponding to three</b> rulings of <b>liabilities,</b> as Rabbi Neḥemya maintains that even with regard to the remainder of the blood of a sin offering brought on the external altar, if one presents it outside the Temple he is liable. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> preferred to compare the <i>halakhot</i> of the remainder of the blood of inner sin offerings to the disqualified blood that is poured into the Temple courtyard drain, so that he could list three lenient rulings alongside three stringent ones.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the statement of Rav Pappa, that a garment sprayed by blood from the last three placements of the blood of a sin offering requires laundering, and to his proof from the mishna that states that if the blood of a sin offering sprayed onto a garment from the corner of the altar or from the base of the altar, the garment does not require laundering. <b>Ravina says,</b> in answer to the objection raised against Rav Pappa above, that according to Rav Pappa the mishna (93a) should be understood as follows: The term: <b>From the corner,</b> means from the corner, <b>literally,</b> after the blood was placed there, and therefore Rav Pappa could infer from this that blood that is fit to be placed on the corner, including the blood to be used for the last three sprinklings, requires laundering. But the term: <b>From the base</b> of the altar, does not mean from the base, literally. Rather, it means: <b>From</b> blood <b>that is fit for the base</b> of the altar, i.e., from the remainder of the blood, which is to be poured on the base.
<b>Rav Taḥlifa bar Gazza said to Ravina:</b> One can <b>say</b> a different explanation, that both <b>this and that,</b> i.e., the term: From the corner, and the term: From the base, are referring to blood that <b>is fit</b> for the corner or the base, in which case the mishna teaches that a garment sprayed by the blood that was to be used for the last three placements of a sin offering does not require laundering, contrary to the opinion of Rav Pappa. Ravina replied: <b>What is this</b> claim? <b>Now</b> that <b>you say</b> that blood which is <b>fit for the corner</b> does <b>not</b> require laundering, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that the same applies to blood that is merely <b>fit for the base</b> of the altar? That ruling would be unnecessary. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that the term: <b>From the corner,</b> means <b>from the corner, literally,</b> i.e., that the blood has already been placed there, whereas the term: <b>From the base,</b> means <b>from</b> blood <b>that is fit for the base,</b> i.e., from the remainder of the blood, which is to be poured on the base.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>all</b> the offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed on the inner altar,</b> which are the bull and goat of Yom Kippur, the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, the bull for an unwitting communal sin, and the goat for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship, if the priest omitted even one of the placements, it is as though he did not facilitate atonement. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah first discusses the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest and afterward the bull for an unwitting communal sin, concerning which it states: “And he shall do with the bull, as he did with the bull for a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:20). It may be asked: This phrase: <b>“And he shall do…as he did,” what</b> does this <b>come to teach?</b> All the details stated with regard to the first bull, i.e., that of the anointed priest, seem to be stated explicitly with regard to the second bull as well.
Rather, the verse comes <b>to repeat the</b> <i>halakha</i> of the <b>sprinkling of</b> the blood, as though it were written twice with regard to the same bull. This repetition of the <i>halakha</i> indicates that the sprinkling is indispensable, thereby <b>teaching that if</b> the priest <b>omitted one of the placements he has done nothing. I have</b> a derivation <b>only</b> with regard to the <b>seven placements</b> on the Curtain separating between the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies, that they are indispensable, <b>as</b> these seven <b>are indispensable in all cases,</b> as the Gemara will explain (40a). <b>From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to the <b>four placements</b> on the inner altar? <b>The verse states: “So shall he do”</b> (Leviticus 4:20).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The verse states: “And he shall do <b>with the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:20); <b>this</b> alludes to a different bull whose service is similar, namely <b>the bull of Yom Kippur.</b>

Daf 39b

<b>“As he did with the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:20); <b>this</b> is a reference to the <b>bull</b> for an unwitting sin <b>of the anointed priest,</b> teaching that all of the sprinklings of the blood of this bull are also indispensable. <b>“A sin offering”; these are</b> the <b>goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship,</b> teaching that they are offered in the same manner as the bull for an unwitting communal sin, their blood being sprinkled in the Sanctuary and their flesh burned.
