One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include also the goats of the Festivals and the goats</b> sacrificed on the <b>New Moons,</b> which are communal offerings as well, i.e., that their service should be performed inside the Sanctuary like that of the bull for an unwitting communal sin. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “So shall he do <b>with this”</b> (Leviticus 4:20), which indicates that this service is performed only with this animal and not with the goats of the Festivals or the goats of the New Moons.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see to include these</b> goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship <b>and to exclude those</b> goats sacrificed on the Festivals and the New Moons? The Gemara answers: <b>After</b> noting <b>that the verse included</b> some offerings <b>and excluded</b> others, one can say: <b>I include these</b> goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship, <b>as they atone for the known transgression of a mitzva,</b> i.e., idol worship, and therefore they are similar to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, which is brought for an erroneous ruling of the Sanhedrin with regard to a specific mitzva. <b>And I exclude those</b> goats sacrificed on the Festivals and the New Moons, <b>as they do not atone for the known transgression of a mitzva,</b> but rather they atone for the unwitting defilement of the Temple or its sacrificial foods.
The <i>baraita</i> resumes its interpretation of the verse. <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement”;</b> this teaches that atonement is achieved <b>even if</b> the Elders <b>did not place</b> their <b>hands</b> on the head of the bull as they are commanded to do (see Leviticus 4:15). <b>“And</b> they <b>shall be forgiven”;</b> this teaches that atonement is achieved <b>even if</b> the priest <b>did not place</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar, as is required (see Leviticus 4:7).
The Gemara again asks: <b>And</b> as the verse does not specify which aspects of the service are included and which are excluded, <b>what did you see to disqualify</b> the offering <b>in</b> the case of the seven <b>sprinklings;</b> how did you derive that the phrase “And he shall do…as he did” teaches that the seven sprinklings are indispensable? <b>And</b> what did you see <b>to render</b> the offering <b>fit in</b> the absence of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the offering <b>and</b> pouring out the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar, based on the words “And the priest shall make atonement…and they shall be forgiven”?
The Gemara answers: <b>You should say</b> the following logical argument: I <b>disqualify</b> the offering <b>in</b> the absence of the seven <b>sprinklings, as</b> these seven sprinklings <b>are indispensable in all cases,</b> as will be explained (40a), <b>and I render</b> the offering <b>fit in</b> the absence of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the offering <b>and</b> in the absence of the pouring of the <b>remainder</b> of the blood onto the base of the altar, <b>as</b> these <b>are not indispensable in all cases,</b> and therefore it is reasonable to conclude that they are not indispensable here either.

Daf 40a

The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i> in detail. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> a derivation <b>only</b> with regard to the <b>seven placements</b> on the Curtain separating between the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies, that they are indispensable, <b>as</b> these seven <b>are indispensable in all cases.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> are the seven indispensable? <b>Rav Pappa says: In</b> the case of the red <b>heifer</b> (see Numbers 19:2–4), <b>and in</b> the purification process of one afflicted with leprous <b>marks</b> (see Leviticus 14:16).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to the <b>four placements</b> on the inner altar? <b>The verse states: “So shall he do”</b> (Leviticus 4:20). The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>seven placements,</b> that they should be indispensable? If you say that the reason is <b>that</b> the seven placements <b>are written and repeated,</b> by means of the terms “And he shall do…as he did,” which teaches that they are indispensable, I can say that the <b>four placements as well are written and repeated.</b> Why then should their <i>halakha</i> be any different?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> This <b>is necessary only according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that only two placements are written in this chapter, while the other two are derived through a juxtaposition. Consequently, a specific derivation is required for these. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the placements on the inner altar: <b>Above,</b> in the case of the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, the verse <b>states corner</b> in the plural form of <b>corners</b> (see Leviticus 4:7), i.e., it says “corners [<i>karnot</i>],” in the plural, where it could have written corner, in the singular. These are <b>two</b> corners. And <b>below,</b> with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, <b>it</b> again <b>states corner</b> in the plural form of <b>corners</b> (see Leviticus 4:18). Together these amount to <b>four</b> corners. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> This derivation <b>is not necessary, as it states</b> in these same verses: “And he shall put of the blood upon the corners of the altar which is before the Lord, which is <b>in the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 4:18). The superfluous expression “in the Tent of Meeting” teaches that the blood must be placed <b>on all</b> the corners of the altar <b>that are stated with regard to the Tent of Meeting,</b> i.e., on all four corners. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda, what does he do with</b> the phrase <b>“so shall he do,”</b> which Rabbi Shimon interprets as referring to the four placements?
The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yehuda <b>requires</b> this verse <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>As we did not learn</b> with regard <b>to the bull of Yom Kippur that placing hands</b> is required, i.e., that the High Priest must place his hands on this animal before it is slaughtered, <b>and</b> likewise it is not stated that the <b>remainder of</b> its <b>blood</b> must be poured on the base of the altar. <b>From where</b> is it derived that these actions must be performed? <b>The verse states: “So shall he do.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And did we not learn</b> with regard <b>to the bull of Yom Kippur</b> that these requirements apply? <b>But you said</b> earlier in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>“With the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:20); <b>this</b> alludes to the bull of <b>Yom Kippur,</b> which indicates that all the rites performed in connection with the bull for an unwitting communal sin apply also to the bull of Yom Kippur.
The Gemara answers: The derivation from the phrase “so shall he do” <b>was necessary,</b> as it could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this matter,</b> the comparison between the bull for an unwitting communal sin and the bull of Yom Kippur, applies only to <b>a service that is indispensable for atonement,</b> e.g., the sprinkling of the blood. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a service that is not indispensable for atonement,</b> such as placing hands on the head of the animal or pouring out the remainder of the blood, one might <b>say</b> that these actions need <b>not</b> be performed. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us:</b> “So shall he do,” i.e., these services, too, must be performed with the bull of Yom Kippur.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon, what does he do with this</b> phrase: <b>“In the Tent of Meeting,”</b> from which Rabbi Yehuda derives that the blood must be placed on all four corners of the altar? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Shimon <b>requires</b> the phrase <b>“in the Tent of Meeting”</b> to teach <b>that if the roof of the Sanctuary was breached</b> by a hole, the priest <b>would not sprinkle</b> the blood, as it would no longer be called the Tent of Meeting. The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehuda, from where does he derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains that Rabbi Yehuda derives it <b>from</b> the superfluous term <b>“which is</b> in the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7, 18). The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Shimon? <b>He does not interpret</b> the term <b>“which is”</b> as he maintains that this expression is not significant enough to serve as the source of a <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Abaye said: According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda as well,</b> it <b>was necessary</b> to learn from the phrase “so shall he do” that the four placements are indispensable. As it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>just as it is with regard to placing hands and</b> the <b>remainder of the blood, that even though they are written and repeated they are not indispensable,</b> so <b>too,</b> the <b>four placements</b> of blood <b>should not be indispensable.</b> Therefore, the phrase “so shall he do” <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, and the four sprinklings are indeed indispensable.
§ The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>“With the bull”</b> (Leviticus 4:20), <b>this</b> alludes to <b>the bull of Yom Kippur. To what <i>halakha</i></b> does this statement relate? <b>If</b> it serves <b>to</b> teach that all matters stated with regard to the bull of Yom Kippur are <b>indispensable,</b> this is <b>obvious,</b> since the word <b>“statute” is written concerning it:</b> “And this shall be an everlasting statute to you” (Leviticus 16:29), and there is a principle that <i>halakhot</i> described as statutes are indispensable.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This statement <b>is necessary only according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says: When</b> the term <b>“statute” is written</b> concerning the Yom Kippur service, indicating that no details may be altered, it is written only <b>with regard to actions performed in white garments inside</b> the Holy of Holies, e.g., burning the incense and sprinkling the blood, which are the essential services of the day, and it teaches <b>that if</b> the High Priest <b>performed</b> one of the <b>actions before another,</b> i.e., not in the proper order, <b>he has done nothing.</b>
<b>But</b> with regard to <b>those actions performed in white garments outside,</b> in the Sanctuary, if he <b>performed</b> one <b>action before another, what he did is done</b> and he is not required to repeat the rite. Consequently, one might <b>say</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that their order is not indispensable,</b> it may be derived that the <b>sprinklings,</b> i.e., placements, <b>themselves are also not indispensable.</b> Therefore, the term “with the bull” <b>teaches us</b> that the placements are indeed indispensable.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this: And how can you say this,</b> that Rabbi Yehuda derives from here that the placements are indispensable? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse discussing the Yom Kippur service states: <b>“And when he has finished atoning for the Sanctuary”</b> (Leviticus 16:20). This indicates that <b>if he performed the atonement,</b> i.e., the sprinklings, inside the Sanctuary, <b>he has finished</b> the order of the service, even though he has not poured the remainder of the blood on the base of the altar; <b>and if he did not perform the atonement, he has not finished;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said to him: For what</b> reason <b>do we not say: If he finished</b> the entire service, which includes sprinkling the blood in the Sanctuary and pouring the remainder of the blood onto the base of the altar, <b>he has facilitated atonement; and if he did not finish, he has not facilitated atonement?</b> This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda derives from this verse the <i>halakha</i> that the sprinklings in the Sanctuary are indispensable.
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> This reference to the bull of Yom Kippur in the term “with the bull,” <b>is necessary only to</b> apply to the bull of Yom Kippur three <i>halakhot</i> that are derived from that which is stated with regard to the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest: “And the priest shall immerse his finger [<i>et etzba’o</i>] in the blood” (Leviticus 4:6). These <i>halakhot</i> can be summarized in the shortened form: <b><i>Et</i>, blood, and with immersion.</b> The Gemara elaborates: With regard to the word <b><i>et</i>, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says:</b> This word <b>is necessary only to render fit</b>

Daf 40b

service performed by a priest who has <b>a wart</b> or blister <b>on</b> his <b>finger.</b> These are not considered an interposition between his finger and the blood. With regard to the term <b>“in the blood”</b> (Leviticus 4:6), this teaches <b>that the blood</b> in the service vessel <b>must be of a</b> sufficient <b>measure for immersion from the outset.</b> The priest must initially collect in the vessel enough blood for all the sprinklings, rather than adding blood to the vessel for each sprinkling. Finally, the term <b>“and</b> the priest <b>shall immerse</b> his finger in the blood” indicates that there must be enough blood in the vessel such that the priest can immerse his finger in it <b>and not</b> have to <b>wipe</b> the sides of the utensil to collect blood for sprinkling.
The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> it <b>was necessary</b> for the verse to state both these last two terms. It had <b>to write “in the blood,” as had the Merciful One written</b> only <b>“and</b> the priest <b>shall immerse,” I would say</b> that the sprinklings are valid <b>even if there was not</b> a sufficient <b>measure</b> of blood <b>for immersion from the outset,</b> but only enough for a single sprinkling, provided that the priest then added more blood to the vessel for each sprinkling. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes “in the blood”</b> to teach that from the outset there must be enough blood in the vessel for all the sprinklings.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>had the Merciful One written</b> only <b>“in the blood,” I would say</b> that <b>even</b> if there was enough blood in the vessel at the outset it is not necessary that there be enough blood for immersion for the last sprinklings, as the priest can <b>wipe</b> the sides of the utensil to collect blood for sprinkling. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes “and</b> the priest <b>shall immerse.”</b>
The Gemara addresses another apparently superfluous phrase in the same chapter: “And the priest shall put some of the blood upon the corners of <b>the altar of sweet incense</b> before the Lord” (Leviticus 4:7). <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to mention the sweet incense? It would have been enough to identify the altar as being “before the Lord” and one would have understood that the reference is to the inner altar. Rather, this serves to teach <b>that if the altar had not been inaugurated with sweet incense,</b> the priest <b>would not sprinkle</b> blood on it.
The Gemara comments: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa</b> that the superfluous phrase in the passage discussing the bull for an unwitting communal sin alludes to the bull of Yom Kippur in order to teach the three <i>halakhot</i> of <i>et</i>, in the blood, and immersion, from the case of the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, which is also alluded to in that verse. The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>“And he shall do</b> with the bull, <b>as he did</b> with the bull for a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:20). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “with the bull”?</b> This serves <b>to include the bull of Yom Kippur for all that is stated in</b> this <b>matter,</b> i.e., in the passage concerning the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, specifically the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>et</i>, in the blood, and immersion. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rabbi Yishmael said:</b> This inclusion is unnecessary, as these <i>halakhot</i> can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as in a case in which</b> one <b>offering is not equated with</b> another <b>offering</b> of a different type of animal, the Torah <b>equated</b> the <b>actions</b> of sprinkling the blood in one offering <b>with</b> the <b>actions</b> of the blood in the other offering, as will be explained, in <b>a case in which</b> the Torah <b>equated</b> one <b>offering with</b> another <b>offering,</b> i.e., the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest and the bull of Yom Kippur, <b>isn’t it logical that</b> the Torah <b>should equate</b> the <b>actions</b> of sprinkling the blood in the one offering <b>with</b> the <b>actions</b> of the blood in the other offering? Therefore, the derivation by way of a special inclusion is not necessary.
<b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall do with the bull, as he did with the bull for a sin offering”? With regard to the first instance of <b>“with the bull,” this is the bull for an unwitting communal sin.</b> And with regard to the second instance of <b>“with the bull,” this is the bull for</b> an unwitting sin of the <b>anointed priest.</b> And the verse serves to teach that just as in the first case, if the priest omitted one of the sprinklings, he has done nothing, the same is true in the second case.
The Gemara clarifies the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> above: <b>Just as in a case in which</b> one <b>offering is not equated with</b> another <b>offering. What</b> is the meaning of the expression: One <b>offering is not equated with</b> another <b>offering?</b> Which offerings are not brought from the same type of animal, but nevertheless the <i>halakhot</i> governing the sprinkling of their blood are the same?
<b>If we say</b> that Rabbi Yishmael is referring to <b>the bull of Yom Kippur and the goat of Yom Kippur,</b> and from them he derives by way of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that the actions concerning the bull of Yom Kippur are the same as those concerning the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, which are the same animal, this <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> offerings, the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur? They are notable <b>in that their blood enters the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies. This is not so of the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, the blood of which is sprinkled only in the outer area of the Sanctuary.
<b>Rather,</b> say that the reference here is to <b>the bull for an unwitting communal sin and the goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship.</b> But once again this claim <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> offerings? They are notable <b>in that</b> they both <b>atone for the transgressions of a known mitzva,</b> whereas the bull of Yom Kippur atones for unknown transgressions (see <i>Shevuot</i> 2a).
<b>Rather,</b> the reference here is to <b>the bull for an unwitting communal sin and the goat of Yom Kippur, and this</b> is what Rabbi Yishmael <b>is saying: Just as in a case in which</b> one <b>offering is not equated with</b> another <b>offering, as this</b> is <b>a bull and that</b> is <b>a goat,</b> nevertheless the <b>actions</b> of sprinkling the blood in one offering <b>are equated with</b> the <b>actions</b> of the blood in the other offering <b>with regard to that which is written concerning it,</b> in <b>a case in which</b> one <b>offering is equated with</b> another <b>offering,</b> i.e., the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest and the bull of Yom Kippur, <b>as this</b> is <b>a bull and that</b> is <b>a bull, isn’t it logical</b>

Daf 41a

<b>that</b> the <b>actions</b> of sprinkling the blood in one offering <b>are equated with</b> the <b>actions</b> of the blood in the other offering? The blood of the goat of Yom Kippur is sprinkled even inside the Holy of Holies, which is not so concerning the blood of the bull. Nevertheless, with regard to the sprinkling in the Sanctuary, which is common to both, their actions are performed in the same manner, with the blood being sprinkled with a finger on the Curtain and on the corners of the altar.
<b>And</b> by means of this <i>a fortiori</i> inference the case of <b>the bull of Yom Kippur is derived from</b> the case of <b>the bull of</b> an unwitting sin of the <b>anointed priest, with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> summarized by the words <b><i>et</i>, in the blood, and immersion,</b> as they are both bulls. <b>And</b> likewise, the case of <b>the goat of Yom Kippur is derived from</b> the case of <b>the goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship,</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>et</i>, in the blood, and immersion, <b>via</b> this <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference,</b> as they are both goats.
The Gemara asks: How can the <i>halakhot</i> of the goat of Yom Kippur be derived from the goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship? <b>But does a matter derived by juxtaposition,</b> i.e., a <i>halakha</i> that is not written explicitly in the Torah but that is learned by means of a comparison, <b>again teach by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? There is a principle that a <i>halakha</i> derived by juxtaposition with regard to consecrated matters cannot subsequently teach another <i>halakha</i> via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference. The <i>halakhot</i> alluded to by the words <i>et</i>, in the blood, and immersion, are not explicitly stated with regard to the goats of an unwitting communal sin of idol worship. Rather, they are derived from the comparison found in the verse: “And he shall do…as he did” (Leviticus 4:20), which alludes to the goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship and the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest. <b>Rav Pappa said: The school of Rabbi Yishmael maintains</b> that <b>a matter derived by juxtaposition does again teach by <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, even with regard to consecrated matters.
The Gemara continues to analyze the statement of Rabbi Yishmael in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>“With the bull”; this is the bull for an unwitting communal sin.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to derive this case by way of an exposition? <b>This</b> verse <b>itself is written in reference to</b> the bull for an unwitting <b>communal</b> sin. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The derivation is necessary <b>because</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>wants</b> the case of the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin to teach with regard to</b> the burning on the altar of the sacrificial portions, including the <b>diaphragm and</b> the <b>two kidneys,</b> that this obligation applies also <b>to the goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship,</b> despite the fact that this requirement is not stated with regard to them.
Rav Pappa continues: <b>And</b> as the obligation to burn the diaphragm and the two kidneys on the altar is <b>not written with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin itself,</b> but rather it is <b>derived by juxtaposition</b> from the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, in which this requirement is explictly stated (see Leviticus 4:8–9), it <b>was necessary</b> to include the bull for an unwitting communal sin once again with the term <b>“with the bull.”</b>
The Gemara elaborates: This derivation is required in order <b>that it should be as though</b> this <i>halakha</i> of burning the diaphragm and the two kidneys <b>was written with regard to</b> the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself. And</b> in this manner the derivation from this case, teaching the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship, <b>should not be a matter derived by juxtaposition</b> that <b>again teaches by juxtaposition,</b> as such a derivation is not done with regard to consecrated matters.
§ The Gemara comments: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa: “And he shall do</b> with the bull, <b>as he did”</b> (Leviticus 4:20); <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “With the bull”?</b> It is clear that this verse is referring to the bull.
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Because it is stated</b> with regard to the goats for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship: <b>“And they have brought their offering, an offering made by fire to the Lord,</b> and their sin offering before the Lord for their error” (Numbers 15:25), and this verse is interpreted as follows: <b>“Their sin offering”; these are the goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship,</b> alluded to in that passage. <b>“Their error”; this is the bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> which is brought for an inadvertent transgression of the community. The juxtaposition of these offerings in the verse: <b>“Their sin offering…for their error,”</b> indicates that the <b>Torah</b> means to <b>say: Their sin offering is for you like their error,</b> i.e., all the portions consumed on the altar in the case of the bull for an unwitting communal sin are also burned on the altar in the case of the goats for an unwitting sin of idol worship.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the offering brought for <b>their error,</b> i.e., the bull for an unwitting communal sin, <b>from where did you learn</b> this <i>halakha</i>? Was it <b>not via juxtaposition</b> from the bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, as the diaphragm and the two kidneys are not explicitly mentioned with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin? <b>But</b> this is difficult, as <b>does a matter derived via juxtaposition again teach via juxtaposition?</b>
Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall do with the bull, as he did with the bull for a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:20). With regard to the first instance of <b>“with the bull,” this is the bull for an unwitting communal sin.</b> And with regard to the second instance of <b>“with the bull,” this is the bull for</b> an unwitting sin of the <b>anointed priest.</b> Due to this juxtaposition, it is as though the burning of the diaphragm and the two kidneys was explicitly written with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, and therefore the <i>halakha</i> can be taught by juxtaposition with regard to the goats for an unwitting sin of idol worship, as stated by Rav Pappa.
The Gemara analyzes the previous <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> above: <b>“Their sin offering,” these are</b> the <b>goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship,</b> which are juxtaposed in this verse to the bull for an unwitting communal sin. The Gemara asks: But <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>derive this from the earlier verse</b> stated with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, <b>as the Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier (39b): <b>“A sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:20), this serves <b>to include the goats for</b> an unwitting communal sin of <b>idol worship. Rav Pappa said:</b> This derivation <b>was necessary,</b> as if there were only the juxtaposition from Leviticus 4:20, it would <b>enter your mind to say: This matter</b> applies only to the acts of <b>sprinkling, which are written with regard to</b> the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself.</b>

Daf 41b

<b>But</b> with regard to the burning of the <b>diaphragm and</b> the <b>two kidneys, which are not written with regard to</b> the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself,</b> you might <b>say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> should <b>not</b> be derived from it. Therefore, this additional derivation of “their sin offering” <b>teaches us</b> that the two offerings are similar with regard to this detail as well.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: But the <i>tanna</i> said:</b> “With the bull”; this serves to include <b>the bull of Yom Kippur for all that is stated in this matter.</b> This statement indicates that all the details applying to the bull for an unwitting communal sin are extended to the bull of Yom Kippur by means of a single derivation. Rav Pappa responded: This issue <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as <b>the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rav amplifies</b> the <i>halakha</i> through <b>this</b> juxtaposition, whereas <b>the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael does not amplify</b> the <i>halakha</i> through <b>this</b> juxtaposition, but maintains that an additional derivation is necessary with regard to the diaphragm and the two kidneys.
§ The Gemara cites a statement that is related to the above <i>halakhot</i>. <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: For what</b> reason <b>are</b> the <b>diaphragm and</b> the <b>two kidneys stated with regard to</b> the <b>bull</b> for an unwitting sin <b>of the anointed priest, and they are not</b> explicitly <b>stated with regard to</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin?</b> This can be explained by <b>a parable:</b> It can be compared <b>to a flesh-and-blood king who grew angry with his beloved</b> servant for his misdeeds, <b>but spoke little of</b> the servant’s <b>offense due to his</b> great <b>affection</b> for him. Likewise, as the Jewish people are beloved by God, the Torah does not describe their sin offering in detail.
<b>And the school of Rabbi Yishmael</b> further <b>taught: For what</b> reason <b>is it stated:</b> “Before <b>the Curtain of the Sanctuary”</b> (Leviticus 4:6), <b>with regard to the bull</b> for an unwitting sin <b>of the anointed priest, and</b> this <b>is not stated with regard to the bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> where it merely states: “Before the Curtain” (Leviticus 4:17)? This can be explained by <b>a parable:</b> It can be compared <b>to a flesh-and-blood king against whom a province sinned. If a minority of</b> that province <b>sinned,</b> his relationship with <b>his entourage [<i>pamalya</i>] remains,</b> i.e., the king continues to treat his loyal followers in the usual manner. But <b>if the majority of</b> the province <b>sinned,</b> his relationship with <b>his entourage does not remain,</b> and he no longer meets even those who remained devoted to him. Similarly, when the entire people sins, God no longer has the same relationship with them, and it is as though the place where the priest sprinkles the blood is no longer sacred.
§ The mishna teaches that all the placements upon the inner altar are indispensable, and <b>therefore if</b> the High Priest <b>placed all</b> the placements <b>in their proper manner,</b> and one in an improper manner, i.e., with the intent to eat or burn the offering beyond its designated time, the offering is disqualified, but there is no liability for <i>karet</i> for one who partakes of the offering. The Gemara states that <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Menaḥot</i> 16a), with regard to the burning of the handful of a meal offering and the frankincense, both of which render the meal offering permitted for eating: If the priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> and this occurred <b>during</b> the burning of <b>the handful but not during</b> the burning of <b>the frankincense,</b> or <b>during</b> the burning of <b>the frankincense but not during</b> the burning of <b>the handful,</b> i.e., he burned one of them with the intention of eating the remainder of the offering beyond its designated time, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one</b> who eats it is <b>liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: There is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> in this</b> case <b>unless he renders</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during</b> the performance of <b>the entire permitting factor,</b> i.e., the burning of both the handful and the frankincense.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Do not say</b> that the <b>reason of Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that the offering is <i>piggul</i>, is <b>that he holds</b> in general that <b>one renders</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> even if he intended to eat or burn the offering beyond its designated time <b>during</b> the performance of only <b>half a permitting factor. Rather, what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he</b> initially <b>placed the handful</b> of the meal offering on the altar, to burn it, <b>with</b> the improper <b>intention</b> to eat the remainder beyond its designated time, <b>and</b> afterward he placed <b>the frankincense</b> on the altar <b>silently,</b> i.e., without any particular intent. Rabbi Meir <b>holds: Anyone who performs</b> an action <b>performs</b> it <b>with his initial intent.</b> Therefore, his action with the frankincense is considered to have been performed with the same improper intention as his action with the handful.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> does Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish learn that this is the case? He learns it <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches: Therefore, if he placed all</b> the placements <b>in their proper manner and one in an improper manner,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>. Consequently</b> it follows that if he initially placed <b>one</b> placement <b>in an improper manner,</b> with the intent to eat or burn the offering beyond its designated time, <b>and all</b> the other placements <b>in the proper manner,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Whose</b> opinion is this? <b>If we say</b> it is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, don’t the Rabbis</b> explicitly <b>say</b> that <b>one cannot render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> with an improper intention <b>in</b> the performance of only <b>half a permitting factor?</b> Here, the priest placed one placement in the proper manner. <b>Rather,</b> it must represent the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that if he had an improper intention with regard to the handful and not the frankincense the offering is <i>piggul</i>.
<b>And if Rabbi Meir’s reason is that</b> he holds in general that <b>one renders</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> even <b>during</b> the performance of only <b>half a permitting factor, even</b> if the priest acted <b>as it taught</b> in the mishna, the offering should <b>also</b> be <i>piggul</i>, as he had an improper intention during half the permitting <b>factor.</b> Rather, is Rabbi Meir’s reason <b>not because he holds</b> that <b>anyone who performs</b> an action <b>performs</b> it <b>with</b> his <b>initial intent?</b> Consequently, if he placed the first placement with an improper intention, the offering is <i>piggul</i>, and if his intention during the first placement was proper, the offering is not <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Yitzḥak says: Actually,</b> it is possible that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that one cannot render an offering <i>piggul</i> with an improper intention during half a permitting factor. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>In their proper manner,</b> in the context of the mishna? It means <b>in their proper manner with regard to <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., he placed the blood with an intention that renders the offering <i>piggul</i>. The mishna is teaching that although he placed the first placements with an improper intention, one does not say that the last placement, which was placed without any specific intention, was performed with his initial intent.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches: Therefore, if he placed all</b> the placements <b>in their proper manner and one in an improper manner,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which indicates that the offering is disqualified due to the one placement performed improperly, one can learn <b>by inference that</b> the term: <b>In their proper manner, comes to</b> indicate an intention that <b>renders</b> the offering <b>fit,</b> and not an intention that renders it <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rava says:</b> It can still be explained that the term: In their proper manner, is referring to an intention that renders the offering <i>piggul</i>; and <b>what</b> is the meaning of: <b>In an improper manner?</b> This is referring to the intent to eat the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b> This intention serves to disqualify the offering, which means that it is not <i>piggul</i>, as not all its rites have been performed in the proper manner. <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> The term: In an improper manner, in the mishna, means that he placed one placement <b>not for the sake of</b>  the offering being sacrificed, and in the case of a sin offering an intention of this kind disqualifies the offering; therefore, it is not <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, one can learn <b>by inference that when</b> the priest <b>does not perform</b> the last placement with the intent to eat the offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area or not for the sake of</b> the offering, but silently, <b>he becomes liable,</b> as the offering is <i>piggul</i>. This is certainly not in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, as they maintain that one cannot render an offering <i>piggul</i> with an improper intention during half a permitting factor.
The Gemara answers: The wording of the mishna is imprecise, as in fact, even if he placed the last placement silently the offering is not <i>piggul</i>. But <b>since</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>taught</b> in <b>the first clause,</b> with regard to an offering whose blood is placed on the external altar: If he placed the first placement with the intent to eat the offering beyond its designated time and the second placement with the intent to eat it outside its designated area, the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> its consumption, <b>he likewise taught the latter clause,</b> with regard to a sin offering whose blood is placed on the inner altar, in a similar manner, that if he placed the last placement with the intent to eat it outside its designated area or not for the sake of the offering, the offering is <b>disqualified, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> for</b> its consumption. One cannot infer from here that if he placed the last placement without intent the offering is <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i> even when he intends to eat it beyond its designated time only in the first placement, <b>said? In</b> the case of <b>blood that is placed on the external altar,</b> where one placement renders the offering permitted.

Daf 42a

<b>But</b> with regard to the <b>blood placed</b> inside, i.e., in the Holy of Holies, on the Curtain, and <b>on the inner altar, e.g.,</b> the <b>forty-three</b> presentations of the blood <b>of</b> the bull and goat of <b>Yom Kippur, and the eleven</b> presentations of the blood <b>of</b> the <b>bull for</b> an unwitting sin of the <b>anointed priest, and</b> the <b>eleven</b> presentations of the blood <b>of</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> if in those cases the priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, whether during the first</b> set of presentations, <b>whether during the second</b> set, <b>or whether during the third</b> set, i.e., in any of the requisite sets of presentations, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for its</b> consumption. <b>And the Rabbis say: There is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i> unless he</b> had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during</b> the performance of <b>the entire permitting factor.</b>
<b>In any event,</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If the priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, whether during the first</b> set of presentations, <b>whether during the second</b> set, or <b>whether during the third</b> set, <b>and</b> yet Rabbi Meir <b>disputes</b> the ruling of the Rabbis and says that the offering is <i>piggul</i>. If the priest’s intent renders the offering <i>piggul</i> whether it was during the first, second, or third set of presentations, evidently Rabbi Meir’s ruling must be based on the consideration that one can render an offering <i>piggul</i> during half a permitting factor. According to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish’s claim that Rabbi Meir’s reason is that anyone who performs an action performs it with his initial intent, the offering shoud be <i>piggul</i> only if the first set of presentations was performed with an improper intention while the rest were performed silently.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avin says: What are we dealing with here?</b> We are not dealing with a case of a priest who had improper intention in the presentations themselves, where the issue of half a permitting factor is relevent. Rather, we are dealing with a case <b>where</b> he had an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during</b> the act of <b>slaughter.</b> In other words, after presenting the blood of the bull inside the Sanctuary, the rest of the blood spilled, and he had to slaughter another bull so that he could continue with the presentations, this time on the Curtain. The reason for Rabbi Meir’s ruling is <b>that</b> the act of slaughter <b>is one permitting factor,</b> and therefore the priest’s improper intent involved an entire service, not half a permitting factor. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what is the reason for</b> the ruling of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
<b>Rava says: Who are</b> these <b>Rabbis?</b> This <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as we learned</b> in a mishna (109b): With regard to <b>the handful</b> of a meal offering, <b>and the frankincense, and the incense, and the meal offering of priests, and the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, and the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings, in a case <b>where one sacrificed</b> even <b>an olive-bulk from</b> any <b>one of these,</b> which should be sacrificed on the altar, <b>outside</b> the Temple, he is <b>liable,</b> as the burning of an olive-bulk is considered a proper burning. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>exempt unless he sacrifices the whole of</b> any one of these items outside the Temple. This indicates that according to Rabbi Eliezer even when one performs a proper action he is not liable unless he completes the service. The same should apply to the slaughter of different bulls for different sets of presentations; one should be liable only if he rendered each of them <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: How can you explain Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion with regard to the presentation of the blood in this manner? <b>But doesn’t Rava say: And Rabbi Eliezer concedes with regard to blood</b> that even one who sacrifices part of the blood outside the Temple is liable? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 60a) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> If the blood of the bull or goat of Yom Kippur spilled, even if this occurred in the middle of one of the sets of sprinklings, and the High Priest slaughtered another animal, nevertheless, <b>from the place that he interrupted</b> that particular rite, when the blood spilled, <b>there he resumes</b> performance of that rite. In Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, each individual sprinkling in each of these rites is an act in and of itself, and therefore the offering can be rendered <i>piggul</i> through any one of them. This is certainly not the opinion of the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Meir in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish would explain that the <i>baraita</i> does not mean that the priest had an improper intention either during the first set of sprinklings or the second or the third. Instead, this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the High Priest had an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during the first</b> set of sprinklings, in the Holy of Holies, <b>and was silent during the second</b> set of sprinklings, on the Curtain, <b>and again</b> had an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during the third</b> set of sprinklings, on the inner altar. There is a certain novelty in this case according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who maintains that anyone who performs an action performs it with his initial intent.
Rava elaborates: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that when the priest performs the second set of sprinklings <b>he</b> does so <b>with</b> his <b>initial intent,</b> i.e., that which he had at the time of the first set of sprinklings, <b>why do I</b> need him once <b>again</b> to have an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during the third</b> set of sprinklings? Doesn’t his explicit intent during the third set of sprinklings indicate that he did not have this intent during the second set of sprinklings? Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, but rather his silence during the second set is considered a continuation of his initial intent. <b>Rav Ashi objects to this: Is</b> it <b>taught</b> that he was <b>silent</b> during the second set of sprinklings? According to Rava’s interpretation this is the key detail of the case, and yet it is not mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: What are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the High Priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during the first</b> set of sprinklings, in the Holy of Holies, <b>and during the second</b> set, on the Curtain, <b>and during the third,</b> on the corners of the inner altar. But during the fourth set, the sprinklings on the top of the inner altar, he was silent. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> to say that <b>anyone who performs</b> an action <b>performs</b> it <b>with</b> his <b>initial intent, why do I</b> need him once <b>again</b> to have an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during each and every</b> set of sprinklings? Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even so he is considered to have performed all the sprinklings with his initial intent.

Daf 42b

The Gemara raises a difficulty: How can Rav Ashi explain the <i>baraita</i> as referring to a case where the High Priest had an improper intention during the first, second, and third sets of sprinklings? <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach:</b> If the priest had an intention that can render the offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>whether</b> during the first set of presentations, <b>whether</b> during the second set, or whether during the third set? This indicates that he did not have improper intent during all the sprinklings but only in part of them. The Gemara comments: Indeed, this is <b>difficult,</b> as the wording of the <i>baraita</i> does not suit this interpretation.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the <i>baraita</i> that addresses the blood presented inside the Sanctuary. <b>The Master said</b> that if the High Priest had an improper intention in one of the sets of presentations, e.g., inside the Holy of Holies, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for its</b> consumption, despite the fact that he performed the rest of the rite silently. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>one is not liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> unless all the permitting factors</b> of the offering <b>have been sacrificed,</b> i.e., if the whole service is completed, including the presentation of the blood. <b>As the Master said: As</b> is <b>the acceptance of a valid</b> offering, <b>so</b> is <b>the</b> lack of <b>acceptance of a disqualified</b> offering: <b>Just as</b> there is no <b>acceptance of a valid</b> offerning <b>unless all its permitting factors have been sacrificed, so too,</b> there is no lack of <b>acceptance of a disqualified</b> offering, i.e., it is not rendered <i>piggul</i>, <b>unless all its permitting factors have been sacrificed.</b> That is to say, in the absence of one of its permitting factors it does not become <i>piggul</i>.
<b>But</b> here, in the case of the bull or goat of Yom Kippur, <b>since he intended</b> to burn the offering beyond its designated time while he was sprinkling the blood <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies, the sprinkling is <b>not valid,</b> and therefore the High Priest is <b>considered like one who did not sprinkle</b> the blood, as every one of the sprinklings of the blood of an inner sin offering is indispensable. If so, <b>when</b> he <b>sprinkles</b> the blood <b>again</b> later <b>in the Sanctuary,</b> on the Curtain and the inner altar, it is as though <b>he is merely sprinkling water,</b> and not the blood of the offering. Consequently, the permitting factors of the offering have not been sacrificed, and therefore the offering should not be rendered <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rabba says: You find it</b> in a case <b>of four bulls and of four goats.</b> After sprinkling blood inside the Holy of Holies with the intent to burn the offering beyond its designated time, the blood spilled. Since the priest did not use that blood again, the service inside the Holy of Holies was completed, and that permitting factor was performed properly. He then had to slaughter another bull and goat for the other sprinklings inside the Sanctuary, which he again performed with improper intent and again the blood spilled. The same sequence repeated itself in the sprinklings on the inner altar and on the top of the altar. In this manner each permitting factor was performed properly.
<b>Rava said: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that this is a case where there is only <b>one bull and one goat,</b> as the sprinkling <b>effects acceptance with regard to</b> the offering’s status of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> In other words, even though the High Priest sprinkled the blood inside the Holy of Holies with an improper intention, and thereby disqualified the offering, nevertheless, since he completed the service, he is considered as having sacrificed all the permitting factors with regard to <i>piggul</i>.
§ The <i>baraita</i> mentioned that there are <b>forty-three</b> presentations of the blood of the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> otherwise in a different <i>baraita</i>, that there are <b>forty-seven</b> presentations of that blood? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement, that there are forty-three presentations, <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that the High Priest <b>mixes</b> the blood of the bull and the goat before placing it <b>on the corners</b> of the inner altar, rather than placing the blood of each one separately. <b>And that</b> statement, that there are forty-seven presentations, <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that the High Priest <b>does not mix</b> the two types of blood before placing them <b>on the corners,</b> but sprinkles four times from the blood of the bull and another four times from the blood of the goat, and only afterward mixes the blood of the two animals for placement on the top of the altar.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in yet another <i>baraita</i> that there are <b>forty-eight</b> presentations? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement, that there are forty-eight presentations, <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that the pouring of the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the external altar <b>is indispensable,</b> and therefore this act is added to the total. <b>That</b> statement, that there are only forty-seven presentations, <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that the pouring of the <b>remainder</b> of the blood <b>is not indispensable.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish’s understanding of Rabbi Meir’s opinion, that one cannot render an offering <i>piggul</i> with an improper intention during the performance of half a permitting factor, from a <i>baraita</i> discussing <i>piggul</i> of a meal offering, which states: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> i.e., that if the priest had an improper intention during the performance of one of its services, the offering is <i>piggul</i>, despite the fact that he performed the rest of the services silently? When he had the improper intention <b>in the removal of the handful, or in the placement</b> of the handful <b>in</b> a service <b>vessel, or in the walking</b> with the handful to the altar.
<b>But</b> if <b>he came to</b> perform <b>the burning</b> of the handful and the frankincense, and <b>he presented the handful</b> on the altar <b>with</b> an improper <b>intention and the frankincense</b> he presented <b>silently, or he presented the handful silently and the frankincense</b> he presented <b>with</b> an improper <b>intention, Rabbi Meir says:</b> The offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> consuming <b>it. And the Rabbis say: There is no</b> liablility to receive <b><i>karet</i> unless</b> the priest had an improper intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> during</b> the performance of <b>the entire permitting factor.</b>
<b>In any event,</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> Or he presented <b>the handful silently and the frankincense</b> he presented <b>with</b> an improper <b>intention, and</b> yet Rabbi Meir <b>disagrees</b> with the ruling of the Rabbis and says that the offering is <i>piggul</i>. This indicates that the decisive factor according to Rabbi Meir is not that the priest continues his initial intent, but that one can render an offering <i>piggul</i> during the performance of half a permitting factor. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> and explain the <i>baraita</i> as follows: Or he presented the handful silently after <b>he had already presented the frankincense with</b> an improper <b>intention.</b> In this case the offering is <i>piggul</i> because he performed the second action with his initial intent.
The Gemara refutes this interpretation: <b>One</b> counterclaim is <b>that</b> if this is what the <i>baraita</i> is saying, <b>this is</b> exactly the same case as <b>the first clause. And furthermore, isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>And afterward</b> he presented the frankincense with an improper intention. The Gemara states: Indeed, this is <b>difficult</b> for the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who claims that according to Rabbi Meir one cannot render an offering <i>piggul</i> during the performance of half a permitting factor.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are</b> the <b>items for which one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> One is liable to receive <i>karet</i> only if he partakes of an item that was permitted for consumption or for the altar by another item. As for the items listed here, either nothing else renders them permitted for consumption or for the altar, or they themselves render other items permitted. They are as follows: <b>The handful</b> of flour, which permits consumption of the meal offering; <b>the incense,</b> which is burned in its entirety, without another item rendering it permitted for the altar; <b>the frankincense,</b> which is burned together with the handful of the meal offering;

Daf 43a

<b>the meal offering of priests,</b> from which no handful of flour is removed and which is burned in its entirety (see Leviticus 6:16); <b>the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest,</b> which is sacrificed by the High Priest each day, half in the morning and half in the evening; <b>the blood,</b> which permits all the offerings; <b>and the libations that are brought by themselves</b> as a separate offering and do not accompany an animal offering; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> The same <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> with regard to libations <b>that are brought with an animal</b> offering.
With regard to <b>the <i>log</i> of oil</b> that accompanies the guilt offering <b>of</b> a recovered <b>leper, Rabbi Shimon says: One is not liable for</b> consuming <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> because it is not permitted by any other item. <b>And Rabbi Meir says: One is liable for</b> consuming <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, as the blood of the guilt offering</b> of the leper <b>permits its</b> use, as only after the blood’s sacrifice is the oil sprinkled and given to the priests. <b>And</b> the principle is: With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that has permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>The burnt offering, its blood permits its flesh to</b> be burned on <b>the altar and its hide to</b> be used by <b>the priests. The bird burnt offering, its blood permits its flesh</b> and its skin <b>to</b> be burned on <b>the altar. The bird sin offering, its blood permits its meat for</b> consumption by <b>the priests. Bulls that are burned,</b> e.g., the bull for an unwitting communal sin, <b>and goats that are burned,</b> e.g., the goats sacrificed for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship, <b>their blood permits their sacrificial portions to be sacrificed</b> on the altar.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Those bulls and goats are not subject to <i>piggul</i> because their blood is presented in the Sanctuary, and in the case of <b>any</b> offering <b>whose</b> blood <b>is not</b> presented <b>on the external altar like</b> that of <b>a peace offering,</b> with regard to which the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> was stated in the Torah, <b>one is not liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Ulla says:</b> With regard to <b>a handful</b> of a meal offering that is <b><i>piggul</i> that was offered up on the altar, its <i>piggul</i></b> status <b>has left it.</b> His reasoning is as follows: <b>If</b> this handful <b>brings other</b> items <b>to</b> a status of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> with regard to <b>itself</b> is it <b>not all the more so?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Ulla <b>saying?</b> This consideration does not explain why the status of <i>piggul</i> should leave the handful. The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying: If</b> the handful <b>is not accepted,</b> i.e., if its sacrifice is disqualified, <b>how can it bring other</b> items <b>to</b> a status of <b><i>piggul</i>?</b> A meal offering is considered <i>piggul</i> only if its handful is properly sacrificed.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Ulla <b>teaching us? If</b> he is teaching us <b>that one is not liable for</b> eating the handful <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, we learn</b> this in the mishna: <b>These are</b> the <b>items for which one is not liable due to <i>piggul</i>: The handful, the incense, the frankincense, the meal offering of priests, the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings, <b>and the blood.</b> If so, one is not liable for eating the handful even if it was not offered up on the altar.
<b>Rather,</b> Ulla is teaching <b>that if</b> items with <i>piggul</i> status <b>ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend.</b> But this too, <b>we learn</b> in a mishna (84a): With regard to sacrificial flesh <b>that</b> is <b>left</b> overnight, <b>or that emerges</b> from the Temple courtyard, <b>or that is ritually impure, or</b> an offering <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intention of eating the meat <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> thereby acquiring the status of <i>piggul</i>, <b>if</b> any one of these <b>ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Ulla is teaching <b>that if</b> items with <i>piggul</i> status <b>descended</b> from the altar after having been brought up there, <b>they ascend</b> once again. But <b>we also learn</b> in that same mishna (84b) that <b>this</b> is not so: <b>Just as if they ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend, so</b> too, <b>if they descended</b> from the altar <b>they shall not ascend.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> Ulla’s ruling is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where the fire has</b> already <b>taken hold of it,</b> i.e., the handful began to burn before it came down from the altar. Ulla teaches that in such a case the priests should return the handful to the altar, as its <i>piggul</i> status has already left it.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>too, Ulla</b> already <b>said it</b> on <b>another occasion. As Ulla says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> that items that descended from the altar shall not ascend again <b>only where the fire has not taken hold of them, but where the fire has</b> already <b>taken hold of them, they shall ascend.</b> The Gemara explains: Even so, there is a novelty in Ulla’s ruling: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>this matter</b> applies only

Daf 43b

to <b>a limb</b> of an offering, <b>which is</b> all <b>connected</b> together so that it forms a single unit, and one can say that if fire took hold of part of it, all of it is considered the food of the altar, and therefore it is returned to the altar if it came down; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a handful, which</b> consists of <b>separate</b> pieces, perhaps only the part that the fire took hold of is returned to the altar, but as for the rest you might <b>say</b> that it does <b>not</b> ascend again. Therefore, Ulla <b>teaches us</b> that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to the handful as to a limb, i.e., if it descended from the altar after fire already took hold of any part of it, it ascends once again in its entirety to the altar.
<b>Rav Aḥai says:</b> Since the handful is considered one unit, <b>therefore,</b> in the case of <b>this handful of <i>piggul</i>, half of which lies on the ground and half of which was brought up to the</b> wood <b>arrangement</b> on the altar <b>and the fire took hold of it, one brings all of it up</b> to the altar <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>,</b> i.e., offerings that remain after the time allotted for their consumption, <b>and ritually impure</b> flesh, <b>where one brought them up to the altar, their prohibition has left them. Rav Ḥisda said</b> in astonishment: <b>Teacher of this</b> <i>halakha</i>, is the <b>altar a bath of ritual purification</b> that can render an impure item pure? <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where the fire took hold of them,</b> and therefore the item belongs to the altar and the prohibition lapses.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Bisna raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>. <b>Others say:</b> The verse states: “But the soul that eats of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which pertain to the Lord, <b>having his impurity upon him,</b> that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20). Although this can also be read as: Having its impurity upon it, referring to the meat of the peace offerings, the verse in fact is referring to <b>one whose impurity can depart from him,</b> i.e., a person who is currently impure, but can attain a state of ritual purity by immersing in a ritual bath. This serves to <b>exclude</b> the impure <b>flesh</b> of offerings, <b>as its impurity cannot depart from it,</b> since ritually impure flesh cannot be purified. <b>And if it is so</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is correct, the <b>impurity</b> of flesh <b>can</b> in fact <b>depart from it by means of the fire</b> of the altar.
<b>Rava says:</b> When the <i>baraita</i> speaks of an item whose impurity cannot depart from it, <b>we say</b> it is referring to purification <b>by means of a ritual bath,</b> not through any other means. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is</b> the term <b>ritual bath written</b> in the <i>baraita</i>? It speaks only in general terms about impurity that can or cannot depart from an item. <b>Rather, Rav Pappa says:</b> In that verse <b>we are dealing with the meat of peace offerings, which are not fit for sacrificing,</b> as the meat of a peace offering is eaten rather than being burned on the altar. Therefore, bringing it up to the altar does not remove its impurity from it.
<b>Ravina says</b> there is a different answer: Even if the impurity of flesh leaves it when it is brought up to the altar, this verse cannot be referring to the impure meat of peace offerings, as the phrase <b>“having his impurity upon him”</b> is referring to <b>one whose impurity departs from him when he is whole;</b> the term “upon him” indicates that he is in a state of wholeness. This serves to <b>exclude</b> sacrificial <b>flesh,</b> which is <b>an item whose impurity does not depart from it when it is whole, but</b> only <b>when it is deficient,</b> i.e., when fire takes hold of it on the altar.
§ The Gemara proceeds to analyze <b>the</b> matter <b>itself.</b> In the <i>baraita</i> the Rabbis attempt to prove that the verse: “But the soul that eats of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which pertain to the Lord, having his impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20), is referring to a ritually impure person, and not to impure flesh. The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>“Having his impurity upon him”; the verse speaks of impurity of the body</b> of the person, not the impurity of the flesh of the offering.
The question may be raised: <b>Do you say</b> that it is dealing <b>with impurity of the body? Or is it</b> speaking <b>only of impurity of the flesh,</b> as is suggested by the fact that the term for “meat” [<i>basar</i>] is masculine, matching the masculine pronominal suffix attached to the word “impurity,” whereas the word for “soul” [<i>nefesh</i>] is feminine? The answer is that <b>here it is stated:</b> “Having <b>his impurity</b> upon him,” <b>and there it is stated:</b> “Whoever touches the dead, the body of any man that has died, and does not purify himself, he has defiled the Tabernacle of the Lord; and that soul shall be cut off from Israel, because the water of sprinkling was not sprinkled upon him, he shall be impure, <b>his impurity is</b> yet <b>upon him”</b> (Numbers 19:13). <b>Just as there, the verse is speaking of impurity of the body, so too here, the verse is speaking of impurity of the body.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> there is a different proof: <b>Since</b> in this verse (Leviticus 7:20) the <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>are mentioned in the plural</b> form, i.e., “peace offerings,” <b>but</b> the <b>impurity is mentioned in the singular:</b> “Upon him,” evidently <b>the verse is speaking of impurity of the body,</b> and not impurity of the peace offerings. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> there is yet another proof: Since the next verse states: “And when anyone shall touch any impure item…<b>and eat</b> of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:21), this indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of impurity of the body,</b> as will be explained. <b>Others say</b> that the phrase <b>“having his impurity upon him”</b> proves that the reference here is to <b>one whose impurity can depart from him,</b> i.e., a person. This serves to <b>exclude</b> the impure <b>flesh</b> of offerings, <b>as</b> its <b>impurity cannot depart from it.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that the term <b>“and eat”</b> indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of impurity of the body.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is this <b>inferred?</b> How is the meaning of this verse derived from this term, which appears in a different verse? In this connection the Gemara notes that <b>Rava said: Any verse that was not explained by Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi, and any <i>baraita</i> that was not explained by Rav Ze’eiri, was not explained,</b> as these Sages are the most accomplished interpreters of verses and <i>baraitot</i>, respectively.
Rava cites the relevant explanation of the verse referred to by Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>This</b> is what <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi says:</b> The next verse states: “And when anyone shall touch any impure item, whether it is the impurity of man, or an impure animal, or any impure detestable thing, and eat of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which pertain to the Lord, that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:21). The beginning of that verse: “And when anyone shall touch,” and the end of that verse: “That soul shall be cut off,” are in the feminine form, whereas the middle of the verse: “And eat of the meat,” is in the masculine form, and yet it is clear that the verse is speaking of impurity of the body. The same may be said about the previous verse: <b>Since the verse begins in the feminine</b> form <b>and ends in the feminine</b> form, <b>and the masculine</b> form is used <b>in the middle, the verse</b> must be <b>speaking of impurity of the body,</b> despite the change from the feminine to the masculine.
The Gemara cites the <b><i>baraita</i>,</b> alluded to by Rava, through which the interpretative prowess of Rav Ze’eiri is demonstrated. This <i>baraita</i> also discusses the topic of eating consecrated food while in a state of ritual impurity. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> the <b>lenient are stated, why are</b> the <b>stringent stated; and if</b> the <b>stringent</b> are <b>stated, why</b> are the <b>lenient stated? If</b> the <b>lenient were stated and not</b> the <b>stringent, I would say: For the lenient,</b> one is liable to receive lashes <b>for</b> violating <b>a prohibition, and for the stringent,</b> one is liable <b>to</b> be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven. <b>Therefore,</b> the <b>stringent</b> are <b>stated. And if</b> the <b>stringent were stated and</b> the <b>lenient were not stated, I would say:</b> Only <b>for the stringent should one be liable</b> to receive a punishment; <b>but for the lenient, one should be</b> entirely <b>exempt. Therefore,</b> the <b>lenient</b> are <b>stated.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>, the meaning of which is opaque.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> are the <b>lenient, and what</b> are the <b>stringent?</b> It is known that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the broad topic of eating consecrated food in a state of impurity, but its precise meaning requires elucidation. <b>If we say</b> that the <b>lenient</b> is referring to the consumption of second <b>tithe</b> while one is impure, and the <b>stringent</b> is referring to the partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, in a state of impurity, how can the <i>baraita</i> say that had the Torah stated only the prohibition against eating second tithe <b>I would</b> incorrectly <b>have said</b> that one who partakes of <i>teruma</i> is liable to be punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven? <b>Now too, this</b> is the <i>halakha</i>; one who partakes of <i>teruma</i> when he is in a state of impurity is indeed liable <b>to</b> be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven.
<b>And furthermore,</b> is it correct to say: <b>And if</b> the Torah <b>had not stated</b> the stringent case of <i>teruma</i> but only the lenient case of second tithe, and I would learn the <i>halakha</i> in the stringent case from the <i>halakha</i> in the lenient case by way of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>I would</b> then <b>say</b> that the punishment in the stringent case is that <b>of death</b> at the hand of Heaven? This is impossible, as there is a principle with regard to <i>a fortiori</i> inferences that <b>it is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b> In other words, a <i>halakha</i> derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference can be no more stringent than the source from which it is derived. In this instance, if an impure person who eats second tithe is flogged for violating a prohibition, then the punishment for partaking of <i>teruma</i> in a state of impurity, were it not stated in the Torah, could be no more severe than that.
<b>Rather,</b> when the <i>baraita</i> refers to the <b>lenient</b> it is referring to <b>the impurity of</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> while the <b>stringent</b> is referring to <b>the impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> as the Torah discusses both these cases in the context of eating consecrated foods in a state of ritual impurity: “And whoever touches anything that is impure by the dead, or a man whose semen goes from him, or whoever touches any creeping animal” (Leviticus 22:4–5).
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>to what</b> food is this referring? <b>If</b> it is referring to the partaking <b>of <i>teruma</i>,</b> both <b>this</b> one who was rendered impure by the dead <b>and that</b> one who was rendered impure by a creeping animal <b>are</b> liable to be punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven. No matter how he became impure, if he partakes of <i>teruma</i> in a state of ritual impurity he is liable to be punished with death. <b>And furthermore,</b> how can the <i>baraita</i> state: <b>Therefore, the stringent are stated,</b> i.e., to teach <b>that</b> one is liable only to be flogged <b>for</b> violating <b>a prohibition,</b> and not to be punished with death. After all, one who partakes of <i>teruma</i> when impure <b>is</b> in fact liable <b>to</b> be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven. Consequently, the reference to stringent and lenient cannot be referring to the partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to the eating of</b> second <b>tithe,</b> this too is difficult.

Daf 44a

<b>If</b> the <b>stringent</b> case of impurity imparted by a corpse <b>were not stated,</b> but only the lenient case of the impurity of a creeping animal, <b>would I say</b> that the punishment in <b>the stringent</b> case is that <b>of death</b> at the hand of Heaven? <b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of impurity imparted by a corpse would be <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>the impurity of a creeping animal</b> by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>and it is sufficient for</b> the conclusion <b>that emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source,</b> in this case that one is liable to be flogged for the violation of a prohibition, and no more.
<b>Ze’eiri says:</b> Indeed, the <b>lenient</b> case is referring to <b>the impurity of a creeping animal,</b> and the <b>stringent</b> case is referring to <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse. And this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: If the impurity of a creeping animal was stated, and it was stated</b> that one who eats second <b>tithe</b> while impure with such impurity has violated a prohibition <b>and</b> one who partakes of <b><i>teruma</i></b> in that state is liable to be punished with death at the hand of Heaven, <b>and the impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse was not stated</b> in this context, <b>I would say</b> as follows: The <b>lenient</b> level of impurity, that of a creeping animal, <b>with regard to</b> food with <b>lenient</b> <i>halakhot</i>, second tithe, <b>involves</b> the violation of <b>a prohibition, and with regard to</b> food with <b>stringent</b> <i>halakhot</i>, <i>teruma</i>, it involves liability to be punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven.
Ze’eiri continues his explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>lenient</b> level of impurity, that of a creeping animal, <b>with regard to</b> food with <b>stringent</b> <i>halakhot</i>, <i>teruma</i>, involves liability to be punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven, it may be inferred that <b>also</b> in the analogous case of the <b>stringent</b> level of impurity, imparted by a corpse, <b>with regard to</b> food with <b>lenient</b> <i>halakhot</i>, there is liability to be punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven. <b>Therefore, the stringent</b> level of impurity, imparted by a corpse, <b>was stated</b> with regard to second tithe, which has lenient <i>halakhot</i>, to teach that even if one contracted impurity from a corpse, he has violated only a prohibition for eating second tithe, and is not liable to be punished with death at the hand of Heaven.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that has permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The Gemara cites a verse and a related <i>baraita</i>. The verse states: “And if any be at all eaten of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offering on the third day, it shall not be accepted, neither shall it be imputed to him who sacrifices it; it shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18). The <i>baraita</i> first demonstrates that the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> applies not only to a peace offering, with regard to which it is stated in the Torah, but to all offerings.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Or perhaps</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> <b>extends only to</b> an offering that is <b>similar to peace offerings: Just as peace offerings are notable</b> in that <b>they are eaten for two days and one night, so too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> applies to <b>any</b> offering that is <b>eaten for two days and one night.</b>
But as for an offering that <b>is eaten</b> only <b>for one day,</b> i.e., the day the offering is sacrificed, <b>and</b> the following <b>night,</b> e.g., a sin offering, guilt offering, and firstborn offering, <b>from where</b> is it derived that the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> applies to this offering as well? The verse states: <b>“Of the flesh</b> of the sacrifice of his peace offering,” which teaches that the status of <i>piggul</i> can apply to <b>any</b> offering <b>whose remainder</b> of meat <b>is eaten</b> after its sacrificial portions have been offered on the altar. The <i>baraita</i> asks: With regard to <b>a burnt offering, whose remainder</b> of meat <b>is not eaten,</b> as it is burned in its entirety on the altar, <b>from where</b> is this <i>halakha</i> derived? <b>The verse states: “Sacrifice,”</b> which includes any offering that is slaughtered.
