The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include bird</b> offerings, e.g., doves or pigeons, which are not slaughtered but whose napes of their necks are pinched, <b>and meal offerings, until I include</b> even the <b><i>log</i> of oil</b> that accompanies the guilt offering <b>of</b> a recovered <b>leper? The verse states</b> with regard to the consumption of consecrated food in a state of ritual purity: “That they separate themselves from the sacred items of the children of Israel, <b>which they consecrate to Me,</b> and that they do not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2).
The <i>baraita</i> clarifies this derivation: The <i>halakha</i> that the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i></b> applies to all these offerings is <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy of <b>profanation</b> in the context of <i>notar</i>: “And if anything remains until the third day, it shall be burned in fire…and anyone who eats it shall bear his iniquity, because he has profaned the sacred item of the Lord” (Leviticus 19:6–8), and <b>profanation</b> stated in the verse discussing <b>ritual impurity:</b> “And that they do not profane My holy name.” <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b><i>piggul</i></b> applies to all these offerings is subsequently <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy of <b>“iniquity”</b> in the context of <i>piggul</i> and <b>“iniquity”</b> stated in the verse discussing <b><i>notar</i>.</b> With regard to <i>piggul</i>, the verse states: “It shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18), and with regard to <i>notar</i>, it is stated in the aforementioned verse: “And anyone who eats it shall bear his iniquity.”
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>And since</b> the verse <b>eventually includes all items,</b> even meal offerings and the <i>log</i> of oil of a leper, <b>now</b> one can ask: <b>Why does</b> the verse <b>state</b> <i>piggul</i> specifically with regard to <b>peace offerings?</b> The <i>baraita</i> answers: This serves <b>to tell you</b> that the offering must be similar to peace offerings in the following way: <b>Just as peace offerings are notable</b> in <b>that they have permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar, so too,</b> with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that has permitting factors, either for a person or for the altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> specifies: With regard to <b>the burnt offering, its blood renders its flesh permitted to</b> be burned on <b>the altar and its hide</b> to be used <b>by the priests.</b> With regard to <b>the bird burnt offering, its blood renders its flesh</b> and its skin <b>permitted to</b> be burned on <b>the altar.</b> With regard to <b>the bird sin offering, its blood renders its flesh permitted for</b> consumption by <b>the priests.</b> With regard to <b>bulls that are burned,</b> e.g., the bull sacrificed for an unwitting communal transgression, <b>and goats that are burned,</b> e.g., the goat sacrificed for an unwitting communal sin of idol worship, <b>their blood renders their sacrificial portions permitted to be sacrificed</b> on the altar.
<b>And I exclude,</b> via the analogy to peace offerings, <b>the handful</b> of a meal offering, <b>the frankincense, the incense, the meal offering of priests, the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings, <b>and the blood.</b> All these do not have an item that renders them permitted either for a person or for the altar.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the fact that the verse specifies peace offerings as the standard case of <i>piggul</i> teaches: <b>Just as peace offerings are notable</b> in <b>that they have</b> a permitting factor that is sacrificed <b>on the external altar,</b> i.e., their blood, <b>and one is liable for</b> eating <b>them</b> due to violation of the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> has a permitting factor that <b>is</b> sacrificed <b>on the external altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> This serves to <b>exclude bulls that are burned and goats that are burned: Since</b> their blood is <b>not</b> presented <b>on the external altar like peace offerings, one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said:</b> Perhaps the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i> extends only to an offering that is <b>similar to peace offerings: What is this</b> offering that is similar to a peace offering but not included in the category of peace offerings? The Gemara answers: The reference is to <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>which is eaten for two days and one night,</b> as is a peace offering. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>By what</b> hermeneutical principle <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the firstborn offering <b>derived? If</b> it is <b>by</b> the hermeneutical principle of: <b>What do we find</b> with regard to, a principle of inductive reasoning involving a comparison between cases that include similar details, i.e., since the peace offering and firstborn offering are similar with regard to the time designated for their eating, <i>piggul</i> status should apply to each, this <b>can be refuted.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the refutation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about peace offerings?</b> They are notable in <b>that they require placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>libations, and waving of the breast and thigh.</b> None of these apply in the case of a firstborn offering.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <i>piggul</i> status applies to a firstborn offering is derived through the hermeneutical principle of a generalization and a detail and a generalization, <b>from</b> the following verse: <b>“And if any be at all eaten</b> of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings on the third day, it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 7:18). The terms: “And if any” and “be at all eaten” are generalizations, while the words: “The flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offering” constitute a detail. According to the hermeneutical principle of a generalization and a detail and a generalization, in such a case one includes any item that is similar to the detail, and therefore one includes the firstborn offering.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>These two</b> phrases <b>are generalizations that are adjacent to one another,</b> which means that this is not an instance of a generalization and a detail and a generalization, as they are not in that order. <b>Rava said:</b> The hermeneutical principle applies even in this case, <b>as they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: In <b>every place that you find two generalizations that are adjacent to one another, cast</b> the <b>detail</b> that is written afterward <b>between them, and interpret them in</b> the manner of <b>a generalization and a detail</b> and a generalization. Consequently, this verse is considered to state a generalization and a detail and a generalization.
§ The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>Until I include</b> even <b>the <i>log</i> of oil of a leper.</b> The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> ruling? The Gemara answers that <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b><i>log</i> of oil of the leper, one is liable for</b> consuming <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> if the guilt offering that this oil accompanied became <i>piggul</i>; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Say the latter clause: And I exclude the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings, <b>and the blood,</b> as they do not have a permitting factor. Here <b>we arrive at</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who dispute the ruling of Rabbi Meir.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>As it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b>libations of an animal</b> offering, <b>one is liable for</b> consuming <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, as the blood of the offering renders them permitted to be offered</b> on the altar; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him: But a person</b> may <b>bring his offerings today and</b> the accompanying <b>libations from now until</b> even <b>ten days</b> later. Evidently, then, the blood of the offering does not render the libations permitted. Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: I too spoke only about</b> libations that <b>come</b> to be sacrificed together <b>with the offering.</b> If so, the <i>baraita</i> under discussion represents two conflicting opinions.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> ruling, that even the <i>log</i> of oil of a leper is included in the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who</b> agrees with the Rabbis that the libations of an animal offering are not permitted by the blood of the offering. And Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> with regard to the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper</b> that it is not the blood of the guilt offering that renders it permitted; rather, the <b>placements of its</b> oil “before the Lord” (Leviticus 14:16) <b>render</b> the remainder of the oil <b>permitted</b> to be eaten by the priests. <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>placements of its</b> oil <b>render</b> the oil <b>permitted,</b> by the same token the <b>placements of its</b> oil <b>render it <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., if the oil was placed with the intent that the priests should consume its remainder on the following day, one who consumes the oil is liable for consuming <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara cites the source for Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper,</b> one who derives benefit <b>from it</b> is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property if he derives benefit from it at any point after it has been consecrated in a service vessel, <b>until the blood</b> of the leper’s guilt offering <b>is sprinkled.</b> At this stage the oil is permitted to the priests, and therefore the prohibition against misusing property consecrated to the Temple no longer applies to it. Once <b>the blood has been sprinkled, one may not derive benefit</b> from the oil <i>ab initio</i>, by rabbinic law, as it must still be placed on the leper’s right ear, thumb, and big toe. <b>But</b> if one derived benefit from it, he is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse.</b>
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> One who derives benefit from the oil is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property <b>until</b> the priest <b>places its</b> own <b>placements,</b> i.e., until the oil is sprinkled seven times toward the Sanctuary, as these sprinklings render the remainder of the oil permitted to the priests. <b>And</b> the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>agree that consumption</b> of the <i>log</i> of oil is <b>prohibited until</b> the priest <b>places the seven placements,</b> i.e., sprinklings, of oil toward the Sanctuary, <b>and</b> performs the <b>placing</b> of the oil <b>on the</b> leper’s <b>thumb and big toe.</b>
<b>They said this</b> statement <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya</b> in Eretz Yisrael, whereupon <b>he said:</b> Would <b>a great man such as Rav Yosef say such a matter,</b> that the sprinkling of the oil renders the rest of the oil <i>piggul</i>?

Daf 44b

But there is the case of the <b><i>log</i> of oil that is brought by itself,</b> i.e., where the leper brings it after he has sacrificed his offerings. There <b>everyone</b> agrees that <b>its placements render</b> the remainder of the oil <b>permitted to</b> the priests, <b>and</b> yet <b>they do not render</b> the oil <b><i>piggul</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper, one is liable for</b> consuming <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> the <b>blood</b> of the offering <b>renders it permitted to</b> be placed on <b>the thumb and big toe</b> of the leper. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Meir: But a person</b> may <b>bring his guilt offering today and</b> the accompanying <b><i>log</i></b> of oil <b>from now until</b> even <b>ten days</b> later. Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: I too spoke only about</b> a <i>log</i> of oil that <b>comes with the guilt offering.</b> This indicates that even according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, it is the blood of the offering that renders the oil <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yirmeya says: Actually,</b> the aforementioned <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and omit</b> the case of the meal offering brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings <b>from</b> the list of items that are not subject to the <i>halakha</i> of <i>piggul</i>. <b>Abaye says: Actually, do not omit</b> this item from the list, and the <i>baraita</i> can be explained in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir as follows: The <i>tanna</i> first <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b><i>log</i></b> of oil <b>that comes with the</b> leper’s <b>guilt offering, and the same is true of libations that come with</b> an animal <b>offering,</b> as according to Rabbi Meir <i>piggul</i> status applies to both of these. <b>And then</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> that <i>piggul</i> does not apply to <b>libations that come by themselves, and the same is true of a <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>that comes by itself.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>the bird burnt offering, its blood renders its meat</b> and its skin <b>permitted to</b> be eaten by <b>the priests.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter,</b> that the meat of a bird burnt offering is eaten by the priests, derived? The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> <b>that Levi teaches,</b> with regard to a verse that discusses the gifts that are to be presented to the priests: “This shall be yours of the most sacred items, from the fire: Every offering of theirs, every meal offering of theirs, and every sin offering of theirs, and every guilt offering of theirs, which they shall render to Me, shall be most sacred for you and for your sons” (Numbers 18:9).
The <i>baraita</i> clarifies what is included by the term “every” in each of these clauses. The verse states: <b>“Every offering of theirs,”</b> which serves <b>to include</b> the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper;</b> it too is given to the priests. The Gemara explains why it is necessary to derive from the verse that the oil is a gift to the priesthood: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that the oil should not be included, as <b>the Merciful One writes</b> in this same verse: <b>“From the fire,” and this</b> <i>log</i> of oil, notwithstanding its status as an offering, <b>is not reserved from the fire.</b> Only an item concerning which part of it is brought to the altar can be said to be reserved from the fire, and none of the oil is brought to the altar. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> by the phrase: “Every offering of theirs,” that the oil goes to the priests.
The phrase: <b>“Every meal offering of theirs,”</b> serves <b>to include</b> the <b><i>omer</i> meal offering,</b> brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan, <b>and the meal offering of jealousy,</b> brought by a <i>sota</i>. The Gemara elaborates: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that as the verse states with regard to the consumption of sacrificial food by the priests: <b>“And they shall eat those items with which atonement is achieved”</b> (Exodus 29:33), only those foods that facilitate atonement are given to the priests. <b>And</b> this would exclude the <i>omer</i> meal offering and the meal offering of jealousy, as <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering comes to permit</b> the consumption of the new crop, <b>and the meal offering of jealousy comes to clarify</b> the <b>transgression</b> of the <i>sota</i>, as part of the ordeal undergone by the woman. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> by the phrase: “Every meal offering of theirs,” that even these meal offerings are eaten by the priests.
The phrase: <b>“And every sin offering of theirs,”</b> serves <b>to include the bird sin offering;</b> its meat too is given to the priests. The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that this meat should not be eaten at all, as <b>it is</b> an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass,</b> since the bird is killed by pinching its nape (see Leviticus 5:8) rather than by slaughtering, which is the manner of ritual slaughter of non-sacred birds. Therefore, the phrase: “And every sin offering of theirs,” teaches that the bird sin offering is eaten by the priests.
The phrase: <b>“Every guilt offering of theirs,”</b> serves <b>to include the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> who contracted ritual impurity, <b>and the guilt offering of a leper.</b> The Gemara elaborates: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that these should not be given to the priests to eat, as <b>they come to qualify</b> these individuals, rather than to atone. The guilt offering of a nazirite renders him fit to restart his term of naziriteship, and the guilt offering of a leper qualifies him to eat sacrificial food, whereas the verse states: “And they shall eat those items with which atonement is achieved” (Exodus 29:33). Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> by the phrase: “Every guilt offering of theirs,” that these offerings as well are eaten by the priests.
The Gemara challenges: <b>It is explicitly written with regard to the guilt offering of a leper</b> that it is consumed by the priests: “For as the sin offering is the priest’s, so is the guilt offering” (Leviticus 14:13). Why, then, is this derivation necessary? <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means to say that the phrase: “Every guilt offering of theirs,” serves <b>to include the guilt offering of a nazirite,</b> teaching that it is <b>like the guilt offering of a leper,</b> in that both are eaten by the priests.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to the phrase <b>“which they shall render</b> to Me,” <b>this is</b> referring to an item <b>stolen</b> from <b>a convert.</b> One who robs a convert who then dies with no heirs must give the stolen item and an additional one-fifth to the priests. Finally, the term <b>“for you”</b> teaches that <b>it shall be yours, even to betroth a woman with it,</b> i.e., these gifts are considered the priest’s property in all regards.
§ According to the first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, the bulls that are burned and the goats that are burned, the blood of which is presented on the inner altar, are subject to <i>piggul</i>, whereas Rabbi Shimon rules that they are not subject to <i>piggul</i>. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that there is a third opinion concerning the matter: <b>Rabbi Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili:</b> If in his service of the bulls that are burned or the goats that are burned the priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> with regard to a matter that is performed outside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., in the Temple courtyard, <b>he has rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> If his intention was <b>with regard to a matter that is performed inside</b> the Sanctuary or the Holy of Holies, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>How so?</b> If <b>he was standing outside</b> when slaughtering the animal, <b>and said: I hereby slaughter</b> the animal with the intention of <b>sprinkling its blood tomorrow</b> inside the Sanctuary, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The reason is <b>that</b> in the case of <b>an intention outside with regard to a matter that is performed inside, one has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> Likewise, if he <b>was standing inside</b> when sprinkling, <b>and said: I hereby sprinkle</b> the blood of the sin offering <b>in order to burn</b> its <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the external altar <b>and to pour out</b> its <b>remainder</b> on the base of the altar <b>tomorrow, he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> this is <b>an intention inside with regard to a matter that is performed outside.</b>
<b>But</b> if <b>he was standing outside, and said: I hereby slaughter</b> the animal with the intention of <b>pouring out</b> the <b>remainder</b> of its blood <b>tomorrow, or to burn</b> its <b>sacrificial portions tomorrow, he has rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> this is <b>an intention outside with regard to a matter that is performed outside.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: What is the verse</b> from which this is derived? The verse states with regard to the sacrificial portions of a bull for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, which is one of the bulls that are burned: <b>“As it is taken off from the bull of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:10). <b>But what, then, do we learn from the bull of a peace offering?</b> Everything that is specified with regard to a peace offering is stated with regard to this bull as well.
<b>Rather,</b> the verse <b>juxtaposes the bull</b> for an unwitting sin <b>of</b> the <b>anointed priest with the bull of the peace offering: Just as the bull of the peace offering</b> is not rendered <i>piggul</i> <b>unless</b> the priest’s <b>actions and intentions</b> relate to the service performed <b>on the external altar,</b> as that is where it is offered, <b>so too, the bull</b> for an unwitting sin <b>of</b> the <b>anointed priest</b> is not rendered <i>piggul</i> <b>unless</b> the priest’s <b>intentions and actions</b> relate to the service performed <b>on the external altar.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says</b> his ruling <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 45a

Does one issue <b>a <i>halakha</i> for the messianic</b> period, when the Temple will be rebuilt? <b>Abaye said to him: If that is so,</b> that such <i>halakhot</i> are not taught, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>not teach all</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the slaughter of sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i>, as <b>it is</b> entirely <b>a <i>halakha</i> for the messianic</b> period. <b>Rather,</b> one studies these <i>halakhot</i> due to the principle of: <b>Study</b> Torah <b>and receive reward,</b> i.e., one is rewarded for the study of Torah regardless of its practical applicability. <b>Here too, study</b> Torah <b>and receive reward.</b> Rava said to him: <b>This</b> is what <b>I am saying to you: Why do I</b> need a practical ruling of <b><i>halakha</i>?</b> According to <b>another version,</b> which presents the same answer in different terms, Rava <b>said to him: I spoke</b> in reference to the ruling of <b><i>halakha</i>,</b> as it is puzzling that a halakhic ruling is given in this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>offerings</b> consecrated by <b>gentiles</b> for sacrifice to God, <b>one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them,</b> neither <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i></b> if the sacrificial rites were performed with the intent to eat the offering beyond its designated time, nor due to violation of the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, nor</b> due to violation of the prohibition against eating the meat while <b>ritually impure. And one who slaughters them outside</b> the Temple courtyard is <b>exempt;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. And Rabbi Yosei deems</b> him <b>liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>offerings</b> consecrated by <b>gentiles,</b> one <b>may not derive benefit</b> from them <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one derived benefit from them, he is <b>not</b> liable after the fact for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property. <b>And one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them,</b> neither <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i></b> if the sacrificial rites were performed with the intent to eat the offering beyond its designated time, nor due to violation of the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, nor</b> due to violation of the prohibition against eating the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>And</b> gentiles <b>cannot render</b> an animal <b>a substitute,</b> i.e., if a gentile stated with regard to an animal that it should be the substitute of a consecrated animal, the substitution does not take effect. <b>And</b> gentiles <b>cannot bring libations</b> that are brought by themselves as a separate offering and do not accompany an animal offering, <b>but their</b> animal <b>offerings require libations.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: I see</b> the logic of the opinion that <b>in all of</b> these cases it is correct <b>to be stringent</b> about the offerings of gentiles, <b>as it is stated with regard to them:</b> “Any man of the house of Israel, or of the strangers in Israel that will sacrifice his offering…<b>to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 22:18). This indicates that all offerings, even those of gentiles, are fully consecrated to God; therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse, <i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, and eating the meat while ritually impure should all apply to the offerings of gentiles. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> the case of items <b>consecrated for the altar. But</b> with regard to items that are <b>consecrated</b> by gentiles <b>for Temple maintenance,</b> one who derives benefit from them is liable for <b>misusing them.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara begins to analyze this <i>baraita</i> in detail. The <i>baraita</i> taught that one <b>may not derive benefit</b> from items consecrated by gentiles <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one derived benefit from them, he is <b>not</b> liable after the fact for <b>misusing</b> of consecrated property. The Gemara explains: <b>One may not</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from them <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as the Sages prohibited deriving benefit from any item that was consecrated to God.
The Gemara’s explanation continues: <b>But</b> if one derived benefit from them, he is <b>not</b> liable after the fact for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property, <b>as</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property through a verbal analogy between <b>“sin”</b> stated with regard to misuse of consecrated items and the word <b>“sin”</b> stated with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> With regard to misuse of consecrated property, the verse states: “If any one commits a trespass, and sins through error, in the sacred items of the Lord” (Leviticus 5:15). In the case of <i>teruma</i>, the verse states: “Lest they bear sin for it, and die due to it, if they profane it” (Leviticus 22:9). And <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, it is written:</b> “And they shall not profane the sacred items of <b>the children of Israel”</b> (Leviticus 22:15), which indicates: <b>But not</b> the sacred items of <b>gentiles,</b> i.e., one is not liable for partaking of the <i>teruma</i> of gentiles while he is in a state of ritual impurity.
The <i>baraita</i> further taught: <b>And one is not liable for</b> eating the offerings of gentiles <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> or <b><i>notar</i>, or</b> eating the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara explains that the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i> is derived</b> through a verbal analogy between the word <b>“iniquity”</b> stated with regard to <i>piggul</i> and the word <b>“iniquity”</b> stated with regard to <b><i>notar</i>.</b> With regard to <i>piggul</i>, the verse states: “It shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18), and with regard to leftover sacrificial meat the verse states: “Therefore anyone who eats it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 19:8).
<b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>notar</i></b> itself is <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy between <b>profanation</b> stated with regard to <i>notar</i> and <b>profanation</b> stated with regard to <b>ritual impurity.</b> With regard to <i>notar</i> the verse states: “Because he has profaned the sacred item of the Lord” (Leviticus 19:8), and with regard to impurity the verse states: “And that they do not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2). <b>And with regard to impurity it is written</b> in that same verse: “That they separate themselves from the sacred items of <b>the children of Israel,”</b> which indicates: <b>But not</b> the sacred items of <b>gentiles.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: <b>And</b> gentiles <b>cannot render</b> an animal <b>a substitute.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara explains: It is <b>because substitution is juxtaposed</b> in the Torah <b>with animal tithe,</b> as the verse states: “And concerning the tithe of the herd, or of the flock…the tenth shall be sacred to the Lord…neither shall he make a substitute for it” (Leviticus 27:32–33). <b>And animal tithe is juxtaposed with the tithe of grains,</b> as the verse states: “You shall tithe [<i>asser te’asser</i>] all the increase of your seed that the field brings forth year by year. And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place that He shall choose to place His name there, the tithe of your grain” (Deuteronomy 14:22–23). The doubled verb form, <i>asser te’asser</i>, is understood as an allusion to two tithes, grain tithe and animal tithe. <b>And with regard to the tithe of grains it is written:</b> “When you take of <b>the children of Israel</b> the tithes” (Numbers 18:24), which indicates: <b>But not</b> of <b>gentiles.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does a matter derived via a juxtaposition again teach via a juxtaposition?</b> There is a principle that in consecrated matters, a <i>halakha</i> derived via a juxtaposition cannot teach another <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition. The Gemara answers: This derivation is not relevant exclusively to consecrated matters, as the <b>tithe of grains is non-sacred</b> food.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that when implementing this principle <b>we follow</b> the source that <b>teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i>, i.e., if the matter that teaches the first juxtaposition involves non-sacred items, one can employ two juxtapositions even with regard to deriving the <i>halakha</i> for consecrated matters. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the matter that <b>is taught</b> the <i>halakha</i>, i.e., the case to which we wish to apply the <i>halakha</i>, and if that case involves offerings one cannot employ two juxtapositions, <b>what can be said?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason why gentiles cannot bring an animal tithe offering is that <b>animal tithe is an obligation for which there is no fixed time, and</b> with regard to any <b>obligation for which there is no fixed time, a Jew can bring</b> it but <b>gentiles cannot bring</b> it. And as stated, substitution is juxtaposed with the animal tithe, and therefore gentiles can also not render an animal a substitute.
§ The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>And</b> gentiles <b>cannot bring libations</b> that are brought by themselves as a separate offering and do not accompany an animal offering, but their animal offerings require libations. The Gemara cites the source of these <i>halakh</i>ot. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to libations: “All who are <b>homeborn</b> shall do these things after this manner” (Numbers 15:13), which teaches that those who are <b>homeborn,</b> i.e., Jews, can <b>bring libations</b> as a separate offering, <b>but a gentile cannot bring</b> such <b>libations.</b> One <b>might</b> consequently have thought that a gentile’s <b>burnt offering should not require</b> the standard accompanying <b>libations.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “So</b> it shall be done for each bull” (Numbers 15:11), which indicates that every offering requires libations.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yosei says: I see</b> that <b>in all of</b> these cases it is correct <b>to be stringent. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> the case of items <b>consecrated for the altar.</b> But with regard to items that are consecrated by gentiles for Temple maintenance, one who derives benefit from them is liable for misusing them. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> of Rabbi Yosei?
The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yosei <b>holds</b> that <b>when</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>is derived</b> through a verbal analogy between <b>“sin”</b> stated with regard to misuse of consecrated property and <b>“sin”</b> stated with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> this is referring to items that are <b>similar to <i>teruma</i>, which is sacred</b> with <b>inherent sanctity. But</b> with regard to an item <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance, which</b> has no inherent sanctity, but only <b>sanctity</b> that inheres in its <b>value,</b> this exemption of gentiles does not apply.
The Gemara continues to analyze the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>blood that became impure and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it</b> on the altar, if he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the offering is <b>accepted.</b>

Daf 45b

But if he sprinkled the blood <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>not accepted. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the offering of <b>an individual. But with regard to</b> the offering of <b>the community, whether</b> the priest sprinkled the blood <b>unwittingly or</b> he did so <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>accepted. And</b> in the case of the offerings <b>of gentiles, whether</b> he sprinkled the blood <b>unwittingly or</b> he did so <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>not accepted.</b>
<b>The Sages said before Rav Pappa: In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this <i>baraita</i> taught? Apparently, it was taught <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as if</b> it reflects the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> there is a difficulty: <b>Doesn’t</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>say: I see</b> the logic of the opinion that <b>in all of</b> these cases it is correct <b>to be stringent</b> about the offerings of gentiles? This indicates that Rabbi Yosei equates the <i>halakhot</i> applying to the offerings of gentiles with those governing the offerings of Jews.
<b>Rav Pappa said to them: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> and it <b>is different there, as the verse states</b> with regard to the High Priest’s frontplate, which atones for ritual impurity contracted by offerings in the Temple without the knowledge of those offering them: “And it shall be always upon his forehead that it may be accepted <b>for them</b> before the Lord” (Exodus 28:38), which indicates that it is accepted <b>for them,</b> i.e., for Jews, <b>but not for gentiles.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: If that is so,</b> with regard to the verse discussing ritually impure priests and consecrated items: “That they separate themselves from the sacred items of the children of Israel, <b>which they consecrate to Me”</b> (Leviticus 22:2), <b>so too,</b> would Rabbi Yosei say that the prohibition against eating consecrated items in a state of ritual impurity applies only to offerings which <b>they,</b> the Jews, consecrate, <b>and not</b> to those of <b>gentiles?</b> This cannot be, as Rabbi Yosei explicitly states in the <i>baraita</i> that in this regard the offerings of gentiles are like those of Jews.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says</b> that it is not from the words “for them” that one derives that the offering of a gentile is not accepted when the blood that was sprinkled had become impure. Rather, it is because the atonement achieved by way of the High Priest’s frontplate does not apply to gentiles, as <b>the verse states: “That it may be accepted for them</b> before the Lord” (Exodus 28:38), <b>and gentiles are not subject to</b> the <b>acceptance</b> of offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Even with regard to those <b>items</b> enumerated in the previous mishna (42b) for <b>which one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> e.g., the handful, the frankincense, and the incense, <b>one is,</b> nevertheless, <b>liable for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>, and due to</b> violation of the prohibition against eating consecrated food while <b>ritually impure, except for the blood. Rabbi Shimon deems one liable for an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>eats</b> it. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the wood, the frankincense, and the incense, one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition against eating a consecrated item while <b>ritually impure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It <b>might</b> have been thought that <b>one should be liable due to</b> violation of the prohibition against eating consecrated food while in a state of <b>ritual impurity only for an item that has permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>And</b> this may be derived via <b>a logical derivation: Just as</b> with regard to <b><i>piggul</i>, which</b> renders one who unwittingly eats it liable to bring <b>a fixed</b> sin offering, <b>and</b> this liability is incurred <b>with one</b> change in his <b>awareness,</b> i.e., it suffices for the sinner to become aware after the fact that he had sinned unwittingly, <b>and</b> it has <b>no permitted</b> exceptions <b>from its general</b> prohibition, as there are no circumstances in which one is permitted to eat <i>piggul</i>, and yet <b>one is liable due to</b> violation of the prohibition against eating <i>piggul</i> <b>only for an item that has permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar,</b> so too, the same should certainly apply to the more lenient case of ritual impurity.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Impurity</b> is more lenient than <i>piggul</i>, <b>as</b> it renders the unwitting sinner liable only to bring <b>a sliding-scale offering,</b> which varies according to his financial circumstances: A poor person brings a bird offering or even a meal offering (see Leviticus 5:6–13). <b>And</b> liability is incurred only <b>with two</b> changes in his <b>awareness,</b> i.e., when the sinner was aware of his impurity beforehand, then forgot about it at the time of his sin, and then once again become aware of his impurity. <b>And</b> it has <b>permitted</b> exceptions <b>from its general</b> prohibition with regard to the community, as it is permitted to sacrifice communal offerings in the Temple in a state of impurity. With these leniencies in mind, <b>is it not right that one should be liable</b> due to violation of the prohibition against eating consecrated food while ritually impure <b>only for an item that has permitting factors, either for a person or for the altar.</b>
Therefore, <b>the verse states,</b> with regard to eating consecrated foods in a state of ritual impurity: “That they separate themselves from the sacred items of the children of Israel, <b>which they consecrate to Me,</b> and that they do not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2). This teaches that a ritually impure person is liable for eating any item that has been consecrated.
One <b>might</b> have thought that one is liable for eating sacred items <b>immediately</b> after they have been consecrated. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Whoever he is of all your seed among your generations that <b>approaches</b> the sacred items” (Leviticus 22:3), and <b>Rabbi Elazar said,</b> in explanation of this verse: <b>But is there</b> one who merely <b>touches,</b> i.e., approaches, consecrated items, <b>who is liable?</b> Only one who eats consecrated food while in a state of ritual impurity is liable.
<b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Approaches [<i>yikrav</i>]”?</b> This term alludes to sacrificing [<i>hakrava</i>], as though the verse has stated: Whoever sacrifices sacred items and eats them. This teaches that <b>the verse is speaking of flesh that has been rendered fit to be sacrificed. How so?</b> With regard to an item <b>that has permitting factors,</b> one is liable <b>from when</b> the <b>permitting factors are sacrificed.</b> In the case of an item that <b>does not have permitting factors,</b> one is liable <b>from when it is sanctified in</b> a service <b>vessel</b> for the purpose of its sacrifice.
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> proof that the prohibition against eating consecrated food in a state of <b>ritual impurity</b> applies even to an item that does not have a permitting factor. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b><i>notar</i></b> likewise applies to an item that does not have a permitting factor? The Gemara answers: This is <b>derived</b> through a verbal analogy between <b>profanation</b> stated in the context of <i>notar</i> and <b>profanation</b> stated in the context of <b>ritual impurity.</b> With regard to <i>notar</i> the verse states: “Because he has profaned the sacred item of the Lord” (Leviticus 19:8), and with regard to impurity the verse states: “And that they do not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2).
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>notar</i> <b>be derived</b> through a verbal analogy between <b>“iniquity”</b> stated in the context of <i>notar</i> and <b>“iniquity”</b> stated in the context of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> With regard to <i>piggul</i>, the verse states: “It shall be <i>piggul</i>, and the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 7:18), and with regard to leftover sacrificial meat the verse states: “Therefore anyone who eats it shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 19:8). If so, the <i>halakha</i> of <i>notar</i> should be similar to that of <i>piggul</i>, for which one is liable only for an item that has a permitting factor.
The Gemara answers that <b>it is</b> more <b>reasonable to derive</b> <i>notar</i> <b>from ritual impurity, for</b> several reasons, as indicated by the <b>mnemonic: <i>Gimmel</i>, <i>zayin</i>, <i>lamed</i>.</b> Both <i>notar</i> and impurity are disqualifications that apply to the body [<i>guf</i> ] of the offering itself, whereas <i>piggul</i> is caused by intent; unlike <i>piggul</i>, these two disqualifications are not determined by the sprinkling [<i>zerika</i>] of the blood, and in both cases the Torah uses the term profanation [<i>ḥillul</i> ].
The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary, it is</b> more <b>reasonable to derive</b> <i>notar</i> <b>from <i>piggul</i>, as</b> like <i>piggul</i> it does not have <b>permitted</b> exceptions from its general prohibition, it has no atonement through the High Priest’s <b>frontplate,</b> both <i>notar</i> and <i>piggul</i> apply to <b>a ritually pure</b> offering, these disqualifications are dependent <b>on time,</b> and both of them are disqualifications of the item being <b>sacrificed,</b> not the priest performing the service. None of these features are true of ritual impurity. <b>And these</b> reasons for comparing <i>notar</i> to <i>piggul</i> are more <b>numerous.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>notar</i> is derived <b>from that</b> which <b>Levi taught</b> with regard to the verse: “That they separate themselves from the sacred items of the children of Israel, which they consecrate to Me, and that they do not profane My holy name” (Leviticus 22:2), which is referring to the eating of consecrated food in a state of ritual impurity. <b>As Levi taught: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the verse is speaking even of a disqualification</b> caused by <b>time,</b> and not only ritual impurity? <b>The verse states</b> profanation elsewhere: <b>“And they shall not profane the sacred items of the children of Israel”</b> (Leviticus 22:15).

Daf 46a

<b>The verse is speaking</b> here <b>of two profanations; one</b> is the <b>disqualification of <i>notar</i> and one</b> is the <b>disqualification of ritual impurity.</b> This teaches that like impurity, <i>notar</i> applies even to an item that does not have a permitting factor.
§ The mishna teaches: Even with regard to the items for which one is not liable for eating them due to violation of the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>, one is, nevertheless, liable for eating them due to violation of the prohibition of <i>notar</i>, and due to violation of the prohibition against eating consecrated food while ritually impure, <b>except for the blood.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? Before answering this question, the Gemara cites another discussion as to why the <i>halakha</i> of misuse of consecrated property does not apply to blood. <b>Ulla says: The verse states</b> with regard to blood: “For the life of the flesh is in the blood, <b>and I have given it to you</b> upon the altar to make atonement for your souls” (Leviticus 17:11). “To you” indicates that <b>it shall be yours;</b> it is not the property of the Temple, so it is not subject to the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael</b> similarly <b>taught: The verse states: “To make atonement,”</b> teaching that God is saying: <b>I gave it for atonement, and not for</b> the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the latter part of <b>the verse,</b> which <b>states:</b> “For <b>it is</b> the blood that makes atonement for the soul” (Leviticus 17:11). The term “it is” teaches that the status of the blood remains as it is, i.e., <b>it is before atonement as</b> it is <b>after atonement.</b> As the Gemara will state, there is a principle that once the mitzva involving a consecrated item has been performed, the item is no longer subject to the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property. Accordingly, the term “it is” teaches that <b>just as after atonement,</b> i.e., after the blood has been presented on the altar, it is <b>not subject to</b> the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property, as the mitzva has already been performed, <b>so too, before atonement,</b> i.e., before the blood has been presented on the altar, <b>it is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: But if the term “it is” teaches that the status of the blood remains the same before and after atonement, one can <b>say</b> just the opposite: It is <b>after atonement as</b> it is <b>before atonement. Just as before atonement</b> the blood <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>so too after atonement it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. The Gemara rejects this: This cannot be the case, as there is a principle: <b>There is no item whose mitzva has been performed that is</b> still <b>subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misusing</b> consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> such case? <b>But there is</b> the mitzva of <b>the removal of the ashes</b> of offerings burned on the altar. Any benefit derived from them between their removal and their required burial constitutes misuse of consecrated property, despite the fact that their mitzva has already been performed.
The Gemara answers: The principle does not apply in that case, <b>because</b> the matter of <b>the removal of the ashes and</b> the matter of the <b>priestly vestments,</b> the four white garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, are both subject to the <i>halakha</i> that misuse of consecrated property applies to them even after their mitzva has been performed. Consequently, they <b>are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., they share a unique <i>halakha</i> not found elsewhere. <b>And</b> there is a principle: <b>Any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases. Instead, they are considered exceptional instances that cannot serve as models for other cases.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that the verse: “And he shall take off the linen garments, which he wore when he went into the Sanctuary, <b>and shall leave them there”</b> (Leviticus 16:23), <b>teaches that</b> the four white garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur are not fit for further use, and <b>they require interment.</b>
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa, who says</b> that these priestly vestments <b>are fit for an ordinary priest</b> and do not require interment, <b>provided that</b> a High Priest <b>does not use them on Yom Kippur</b> in <b>a different</b> year, one does not misuse consecrated property by using them after their mitzva has been performed, and therefore <b>what is there to say?</b> In his opinion, the <i>halakha</i> of misuse of consecrated property after the performance of a mitzva applies only to the removal of ashes from the altar, not to the priestly vestments, which means it is stated in only a single case. Why, then, does this case not serve as a paradigm for other instances in the Torah?
The Gemara responds: It is <b>because</b> the cases of <b>the removal of the ashes and</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the heifer whose neck is broken</b> are <b>two verses that come as one,</b> as it is prohibited to derive benefit from either of them even after their mitzva is completed, <b>and any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases.
The Gemara challenges this from a different angle: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases, <b>but according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one do <b>teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases, <b>what is there to say?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Two exclusions are written</b> in these two cases, which indicate that this <i>halakha</i> applies to them alone. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the heifer whose neck is broken, <b>it is written: “Whose neck was broken”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:6), and this superfluous description teaches that this <i>halakha</i>, that the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property is in effect even after the performance of a mitzva, applies solely to this case and should not be extended to others. <b>And there,</b> with regard to the removal of ashes, <b>it is written: “And he shall put it”</b> (Leviticus 6:3), indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies to “it,” and nothing else.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need <b>these three verses</b> stated <b>with regard to blood,</b> from which it is derived that the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property does not apply to blood? The reference is to the three terms specified earlier, in the expositions of Ulla, the school of Rabbi Yishmael, and Rabbi Yoḥanan, from the verse: “I have given it to you upon the altar to make atonement for your souls, for it is the blood that makes atonement for the soul” (Leviticus 17:11).
The Gemara answers: One of those terms serves <b>to exclude</b> the blood <b>from</b> the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property. Another phrase serves to exclude blood <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>.</b> If one consumed leftover blood, he is not liable for consuming <i>notar</i>. Rather, he is liable for violating only the prohibition against consuming blood. <b>And</b> the last phrase serves to exclude it <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b>ritual impurity.</b> If one consumed this blood in a state of ritual impurity, he is liable only for consuming blood, but not on account of consuming consecrated food while ritually impure.
<b>But no verse is required</b> to exclude this blood from the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> because this is already derived from another source, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna (43a): With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that has permitting factors, either for</b> consumption by <b>a person or for</b> burning on <b>the altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The permitting factor itself is not subject to <i>piggul</i>. <b>And</b> consequently, <i>piggul</i> does not apply to <b>blood itself,</b> as <b>it</b> renders the offering <b>permitted</b> for human consumption or for the altar.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why do I</b> need <b>three</b> mentions of <b><i>karet</i> with regard to</b> one who eats <b>peace offerings</b> in a state of ritual impurity? The three verses are: “But the soul that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, that pertain to the Lord, having his impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off [<i>venikhreta</i>] from his people” (Leviticus 7:20); “And when anyone shall touch any impure item, whether it is the impurity of man, or an impure animal, or any unclean detestable thing, and eat of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, that pertain to the Lord, that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:21); and: “Whoever he is of all your seed among your generations that approaches the sacred items, which the children of Israel consecrate to the Lord, having his impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off from before Me; I am the Lord” (Leviticus 22:3).

Daf 46b

<b>One</b> mention of <i>karet</i> in the verse: “That approaches the sacred items,” is <b>for a generalization, and one</b> mention in the verse: “Of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings,” is <b>for a detail.</b> This detail serves to include all items consecrated to the altar, in accordance with the hermeneutical principle that any matter that was included in a generalization but was explicitly specified to teach a certain <i>halakha</i> was intended to teach not just about itself but about the entire generalization. <b>And one</b> mention of <i>karet</i> in the verse: “And when anyone shall touch any impure item,” serves <b>to</b> include <b>items whose</b> typical manner is such that they are <b>not to be eaten,</b> e.g., wood and frankincense, and teaches that one who eats even these items is liable to receive <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> in the mishna with regard to <b>items whose</b> typical manner is such that they are <b>not to be eaten,</b> that one <b>is not liable for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> violation of the prohibition against eating consecrated items in a state of <b>ritual impurity, what</b> does this last mention of <i>karet</i> serve <b>to include?</b> The Gemara answers that it serves <b>to include the sin offerings</b> whose blood is presented <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary.
The Gemara explains why this inclusion is necessary. It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Shimon says</b> that concerning <b>any</b> offering <b>whose</b> blood <b>is not</b> presented <b>on the external altar like</b> that of <b>a peace offering, one is not liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> one should likewise <b>not be liable</b> for eating it <b>due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b>ritual impurity.</b> Therefore, the additional mention of <i>karet</i> <b>teaches us</b> that one who is impure is in fact liable for eating these sin offerings brought inside the Sanctuary.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon stated</b> a ruling in which he <b>deems</b> one <b>liable</b> for eating in a state of ritual impurity an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>eats</b> it, but not for eating the wood, the frankincense, or the incense, whose typical manner is such that one does not eat it. The Rabbis disagree and deem him liable in all these cases. It <b>was stated</b> that two pairs of <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to this issue; one pair is <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish,</b> and the other pair is <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina.</b> The two different opinions that follow were respectively stated by <b>one of this pair and one of that pair.</b>
<b>One says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between the Rabbis and Rabbi Shimon is <b>with regard to the impurity of meat,</b> i.e., the item that is eaten is impure. The Rabbis maintain that one who eats impure wood or frankincense is flogged, as derived from the two mentions of flesh in the verse: “And the meat that touches any impure item shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire. And as for the meat, everyone who is pure may eat of it” (Leviticus 7:19). <b>But</b> if one ate wood or frankincense <b>in</b> a state of <b>impurity of the body, everyone agrees</b> that <b>he is not flogged.</b>
<b>And one says: As</b> there is <b>a dispute with regard to this</b> case, when the item eaten is impure, <b>so</b> is there <b>a dispute with regard to that</b> case, when the one eating the wood or frankincense is impure. <b>What is the reason</b> for this opinion? <b>Since one reads with regard to</b> these inedible items: <b>“And the flesh that touches any impure item”</b> (Leviticus 7:19), as this phrase serves to include even items such as wood and frankincense in the prohibition against eating them when they are impure, <b>one</b> likewise <b>reads with regard to</b> them the next verse: “But the person that eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings…<b>having his impurity upon him,</b> that soul shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:20), which discusses one in a state of impurity who eats consecrated items.
The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Tavyumei teaches</b> the discussion in <b>this</b> preceding manner, whereas <b>Rav Kahana teaches</b> it in <b>this</b> alternative manner: <b>One of this pair</b> of <i>amora’im</i> <b>and one of that pair</b> disagreed <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> in the mishna, i.e., the meaning of Rabbi Shimon’s statement. <b>One says</b> that Rabbi Shimon’s <b>dispute</b> with the Rabbis is <b>with regard to the impurity of the body,</b> as he maintains that an impure individual who eats wood or frankincense is exempt. <b>But with regard to the impurity of flesh,</b> i.e., these items themselves, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>flogged. And one says: As</b> there is <b>a dispute with regard to this</b> case, <b>so</b> is there <b>a dispute with regard to that</b> case, i.e., Rabbi Shimon holds that one is exempt in both cases.
<b>Rava said:</b> It <b>stands to reason</b> that the correct interpretation is <b>like the one who says: As</b> there is <b>a dispute with regard to this</b> case, <b>so</b> is there <b>a dispute with regard to that</b> case. <b>What is the reason? Since one does not read with regard to</b> these inedible items: <b>“Having his impurity upon him, that soul shall be cut off,”</b> as according to both alternative explanations Rabbi Shimon deems exempt one who eats these items when he is in a state of impurity, similarly <b>one does not read with regard to</b> them the previous verse: <b>“And the flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten.”</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But doesn’t the Master say</b> that the term: <b>“And as for the flesh,”</b> in the same verse, serves <b>to include wood and frankincense?</b> This indicates that even these items can become ritually impure, and the prohibition against eating consecrated items that are impure applies to them. The Gemara answers: This is referring <b>merely to disqualification,</b> i.e., this inclusion applies by rabbinic law, and the verse is cited in mere support.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The slaughtered offering is slaughtered for the sake of six matters,</b> and one must have all of these matters in mind: <b>For the sake of</b> the particular type of <b>offering</b> being sacrificed; <b>for the sake of the one who sacrifices</b> the offering; <b>for the sake of God; for the sake of</b> consumption by the <b>fires</b> of the altar; <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>aroma; for the sake of</b> the <b>pleasing</b> of God, i.e., in fulfillment of God’s will; <b>and,</b> in the cases of <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering, for the sake of</b> atonement for the <b>sin.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> in the case of <b>one who did not have in mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for the sake of any one of these,</b> the offering is <b>valid, as it is a stipulation of the court</b> that he should not state any intent <i>ab initio</i>. This is necessary <b>because the intent follows only the one performing the</b> sacrificial <b>rite,</b> and therefore if the one who slaughters the animal is not careful and states the wrong intent, the offering would be disqualified through his improper intent.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says</b> with regard to the verse: “A burnt offering, an offering made by fire, of a pleasing aroma to the Lord” (Leviticus 1:9), the term <b>“a burnt offering”</b> means that one must intend that it be <b>for the sake of a burnt offering, to the exclusion of</b> one who sacrifices a burnt offering <b>for the sake of a peace offering, which</b> one may <b>not</b> do. The mention of <b>fires,</b> i.e., the term “an offering made by fire,” teaches that the offering must be sacrificed <b>for the sake of</b> complete consumption by the <b>fires</b> of the altar, <b>to the exclusion of</b> one who intends that its portions should only be <b>roasted</b> on the fire, <b>as</b> one may <b>not</b> do so.
Rav continues to expound the verse. The term <b>“aroma”</b> indicates that the offering must be sacrificed <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>aroma, to the exclusion of limbs that one</b> first <b>roasted and</b> afterward <b>took them up</b> to the altar, <b>which</b> he may <b>not</b> do. <b>As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>limbs that one</b> first <b>roasted and</b> afterward <b>took them up</b> to the altar, <b>they do not constitute</b> fulfillment of the requirement that the offering must be sacrificed for the sake of the <b>aroma.</b>
The term <b>“pleasing”</b> means <b>for the sake of pleasing</b> God’s <b>spirit,</b> i.e., that the offering should be accepted by God. Finally, the expression <b>“to the Lord”</b> indicates that it should be <b>for the sake of the One Who spoke and the world came into being.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered</b> with intent that the slaughter be <b>for the sake of a burnt offering,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> As explained (2a), a sin offering that was slaughtered for the sake of another offering is entirely disqualified. But if he intended the slaughter to be <b>for the sake of a non-sacred</b> animal, it is <b>valid. Rabbi Elazar says: What is the reason of Rav?</b> The verse states: <b>“And they shall not profane the sacred items of the children of Israel”</b> (Leviticus 22:15). This teaches that <b>consecrated items,</b> i.e., the intent to slaughter an offering for the sake of another type of offering, <b>profane consecrated items, but</b> the intent to slaughter an offering for the sake of <b>a non-sacred</b> animal <b>does not profane consecrated items.</b>
<b>Rabba raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> in the case of <b>one who did not have in mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for the sake of any one of these,</b> the offering is <b>fit, as it is a stipulation of the court</b> that one not state any intent <i>ab initio</i>. Rabba infers from this that <b>the reason</b> the offering is valid and it effects acceptance is that <b>he did not have in mind</b> any intent <b>at all. But</b> if he <b>had in mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for the sake of a non-sacred</b> animal, it is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Yosei means the following: If he <b>did not have</b> in mind any intent <b>at all,</b> the offering is <b>valid and</b> it <b>effects acceptance, but</b> if he <b>had in mind</b> to slaughter the offering <b>for the sake of a non-sacred</b> animal, the offering is <b>valid, but it does not effect acceptance,</b> as it is a flawed offering. Rav’s statement can be understood in a similar fashion.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> Indeed, <b>a sin offering that one</b> intentionally <b>slaughtered for the sake of a non-sacred</b> animal is <b>valid,</b> as stated by Rav. But if he slaughtered it <b>as a non-sacred</b> animal, actually thinking that it was non-sacred, it is <b>disqualified,</b> as when he slaughtered it, he did not intend to perform a sacrificial rite. This is <b>like the dilemma that Shmuel raised before Rav Huna:</b>

Daf 47a

<b>From where</b> is it derived with regard <b>to one who acts unawares</b> in the case <b>of consecrated</b> items, i.e., if one slaughtered an offering without intending to perform the act of slaughter at all, but rather like one occupied with other matters, <b>that</b> the offering <b>is disqualified?</b> Rav Huna said to Shmuel: It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “And he shall slaughter the young bull before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 1:5), teaching that the mitzva is not performed properly <b>unless the slaughter is for the sake of a young bull,</b> i.e., knowing that he is performing an act of slaughter.
Shmuel <b>said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>We have this</b> as an established <i>halakha</i> already, that it is a mitzva to slaughter the offering for the sake of a bull, but <b>from where</b> is it derived that this requirement is <b>indispensable?</b> Rav Huna <b>said to him</b> that the verse states: <b>“With your will you shall slaughter it”</b> (Leviticus 19:5), i.e., <b>with your</b> full <b>awareness you shall slaughter</b> it, in the form of a purposeful action.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Because the intent follows only the one performing the</b> sacrificial <b>rite.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: I heard that</b> even <b>the owner</b> of an offering <b>can render it <i>piggul</i></b> through improper intention. <b>Rava says: What is the reason of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei? As the verse states: “Then he who sacrifices shall sacrifice</b> his offering to the Lord” (Numbers 15:4). The term “he who sacrifices” is a reference to the owner; since the owner is considered one who sacrifices, he too can render his offering <i>piggul</i> with an improper intention.
<b>Abaye says: Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Eliezer, and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar all hold</b> that even in a case involving two people, where <b>this one has intention and that one performs the service, it is</b> the <b>intention</b> that is relevant, i.e., it is as though the one performing the service had the intention. The Gemara explains: The statement of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> is <b>that which we</b> just <b>said,</b> that the owner can render his offering <i>piggul</i> through improper intention despite the fact that it is the priest who performs the service.
The statement of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 38b): With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal on behalf <b>of a gentile, his slaughter is valid</b> and a Jew may eat the meat of this animal. <b>But Rabbi Eliezer deems it unfit,</b> as the intention of the gentile, which is presumably to use the animal for idol worship, invalidates the act of slaughter performed by the Jew.
The statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated a principle:</b> In the case of <b>any</b> item <b>that is not fit to be stored, and</b> therefore people do <b>not</b> typically <b>store</b> items <b>like it,</b> but <b>it was deemed fit</b> for storage <b>by this</b> person <b>and he stored it, and another</b> person <b>came and carried out</b> on Shabbat the item that was stored, <b>that</b> one who carried it out <b>is rendered liable by the thought of this</b> one who stored it.
The Gemara notes: <b>These two</b> Sages, Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, although their rulings are stated in the context of entirely different matters, <b>accept</b> as <i>halakha</i> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Now</b> that concerning matters <b>outside</b> the Temple, i.e., non-sacred slaughter and carrying on Shabbat, with regard to which the Torah makes no reference to intention, <b>we say</b> that the intention of one person is effective for the action of another, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to matters <b>inside</b> the Temple, i.e., offerings, with regard to which it is explicitly stated that intention is effective, as indicated by the verse: “With your will you shall slaughter it” (Leviticus 19:5)?
But <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, does not</b> necessarily <b>accept</b> as <i>halakha</i> the rulings of <b>these two</b> Sages, Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. The Gemara explains: <b>Perhaps</b> it is only concerning <b>inside</b> the Temple <b>that we say</b> that one person’s intention is effective for the action of another, whereas concerning <b>outside</b> the Temple, <b>we do not say</b> this.
The Gemara further differentiates between the opinions of those two Sages themselves. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar accepts</b> as <i>halakha</i> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Eliezer: Now</b> that <b>with regard to Shabbat we say</b> that the intention of one person is effective for the action of another, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that the same applies <b>concerning idol worship,</b> where the actions are somewhat similar to those performed in the Temple?
But <b>Rabbi Eliezer does not</b> necessarily <b>accept</b> as <i>halakha</i> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar: Perhaps it is</b> only <b>with regard to idol worship that you say</b> that one person’s intention is effective for the action of another, as idol worship is somewhat <b>similar to</b> service performed <b>inside</b> the Temple. Consequently, it is reasonable that one person’s intention is effective for the action of another in the case of idolatry, as it does for offerings. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat, the Torah prohibited</b> only <b>planned,</b> constructive <b>labor,</b> i.e., one is liable only for an action that includes the creative intent of the doer, and here the one who took the item out did not intend to perform a labor.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What is the location</b> of the slaughtering and consumption <b>of offerings?</b> The principle is that with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard.
Specifically, with regard to <b>the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur, their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north and the collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north, and their blood requires sprinkling between the staves</b> of the Ark in the Holy of Holies, <b>and upon the Curtain</b> separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies, <b>and on the golden altar.</b> Concerning all those sprinklings, failure to perform even <b>one placement of their</b> blood <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. As to <b>the remainder of the blood,</b> which is left after those sprinklings, a priest <b>would pour</b> it <b>onto the western base of the external altar. But if he did not place</b> the remainder of the blood on the western base, it does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering.
With regard to <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned, their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>and the collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north, and their blood requires sprinkling upon the Curtain</b> separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies, <b>and upon the golden altar,</b>

Daf 47b

and failure to perform even <b>one placement of their</b> blood <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. As for <b>the remainder of the blood</b> that is left after those sprinklings, a priest <b>would pour</b> it <b>onto the western base of the external altar, but if he did not pour</b> the remainder it does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering. <b>These,</b> the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur, <b>and those,</b> the bulls and the goats that are burned, <b>are</b> then <b>burned in the place of the ashes,</b> a place outside of Jerusalem where the priests would bring the ashes from the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna opens with a principle that the slaughter of offerings of the most sacred order is in the north of the Temple courtyard. The Gemara inquires: <b>And let</b> the mishna <b>also teach</b> as a principle: <b>And the collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard. Since collecting the blood is an indispensable part of the service, why is it not listed in this clause of the mishna? The Gemara explains: <b>Since there is</b> among the offerings of the most sacred order <b>the guilt offering of a leper,</b> for <b>which the collection of its blood is in the hand,</b> the mishna could not state this as a principle. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>omitted</b> this from the requirements for offerings of the most sacred order.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And</b> is the blood of the guilt offering of a leper <b>not</b> collected in a service vessel? <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>later</b> (54b): With regard to <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> brought for his purification <b>and the guilt offering of a leper</b> brought for his purification, <b>their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north.</b> Apparently, the <i>tanna</i> maintains that the blood of the guilt offering of a leper must be collected in a service vessel.
The Gemara answers: <b>Initially,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>held</b> that since <b>collection of the blood of</b> the guilt offering of a leper must also be <b>in the</b> priest’s <b>hand,</b> not exclusively in a service vessel, <b>he omitted it. But since</b> it is the case <b>that it is possible for</b> one to collect some of the blood <b>only in</b> a service <b>vessel,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>subsequently taught it.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nega’im</i> 9:2): The Torah states with regard to the guilt offering of a leper: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take</b> of the blood of the guilt offering, and the priest shall put it upon the tip of the right ear of him who is to be purified, and upon the thumb of his right hand, and upon the big toe of his right foot” (Leviticus 14:14). One <b>might</b> have thought that he should take it <b>in a vessel;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall put.” Just as putting</b> the blood on the ear, thumb, and big toe must be performed <b>with the priest’s own</b> body, <b>so too, taking</b> of the blood is performed <b>with the priest’s own</b> body, not with a service vessel.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> with regard to the blood of the leper’s guilt offering that he presents <b>on the altar,</b> like the blood of other guilt offerings, it is <b>so,</b> that he collects the blood in his hand rather than with a vessel. To counter this, <b>the verse states: “For as the sin offering is, so is the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:13). This teaches that <b>just as a sin offering requires a vessel</b> for collection of its blood, <b>so too,</b> the blood of <b>a guilt offering requires a vessel</b> for collection of its blood. <b>You consequently say:</b> In the case of <b>a leper’s guilt offering, two priests collect its blood; one</b> collects the blood <b>by hand, and</b> the other <b>one</b> collects the blood <b>in a vessel. This</b> one, <b>who collected</b> the blood <b>in a vessel, comes to the altar</b> and sprinkles some of the blood on it. <b>And that</b> one, <b>who collected</b> the blood <b>by hand, comes to</b> the <b>leper</b> and places some of the blood on his right ear, right thumb, and right big toe.

Daf 48a

§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur,</b> their slaughter is in the north and the collection of their blood in a service vessel is in the north. The Gemara asks: Why does the mishna list these sin offerings first? <b>After all,</b> while the <i>halakha</i> that slaughter must be in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>is written</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to a burnt offering</b> (Leviticus 1:11), the Torah does not explicitly state that the other offerings must be slaughtered in the north. Therefore, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a burnt offering first.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the location for slaughtering the <b>sin offering is derived through interpretation, it is dear to</b> the <i>tanna</i>, and he therefore he gives it precedence. The verse states: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying: This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered shall the sin offering be slaughtered before the Lord; it is most holy” (Leviticus 6:18). The Gemara (55a) derives from this verse that the sin offering must be slaughtered in the same place as the burnt offering, i.e., in the north of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teach</b> first the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the external sin offerings,</b> since those are the offerings to which the verse is referring. The Gemara explains: <b>Since</b> the <b>blood</b> of the Yom Kippur sin offerings <b>enters the innermost sanctum,</b> these offerings are <b>dear to</b> the <i>tanna</i>, and he taught them first.
The Gemara asks: <b>And where</b> is it <b>written</b> that <b>a burnt offering</b> must be slaughtered in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers that with regard to a sheep that is brought as a burnt offering the Torah states: <b>“And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar northward</b> before the Lord; and Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall dash its blood against the altar round about” (Leviticus 1:11).
