The Gemara clarifies: <b>We have found</b> that this verse provides a source that <b>a young sheep</b> burnt offering must be slaughtered in the north. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a young bull</b> burnt offering must also be slaughtered in the north? The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “And if</b> his offering be <b>of the flock,</b> whether of the sheep, or of the goats, for a burnt offering, he shall offer it a male without blemish” (Leviticus 1:10). The conjunctive “and” represented by the letter <b><i>vav</i> adds to the previous matter.</b> The previous passage addresses cattle offerings. <b>And let</b> the <b>upper</b> passage, the place of the slaughter of a bull, <b>be learned from</b> the <b>lower</b> passage, the place of slaughtering a sheep.
The Gemara comments: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>we learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> in this manner. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>we do not learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> in this manner, <b>what is there to say?</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Immediately following the passage in the Torah addressing a guilt offering for misuse of consecrated property, the Torah discusses the <i>halakhot</i> of a provisional guilt offering, brought by one who is uncertain as to whether he committed a sin that requires a sin offering. The verse states: <b>“And if anyone</b> sin, and does any of the commandments which the Lord has commanded not to be done, though he did not know it, yet is he guilty, and shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 5:17). This serves <b>to render</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a provisional guilt offering for uncertain misuse</b> of consecrated property; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt</b> in such a case. The Gemara suggests: <b>What, is it not</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that <b>we learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> of the upper passage from the lower passage, <b>and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> in this manner?
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is not correct, <b>as everyone</b> holds that <b>we learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> of the upper passage from the lower passage. <b>And this is</b> the <b>reason that the Rabbis</b> exempt from bringing an offering one who is uncertain whether he misused consecrated property: They learn a verbal analogy. <b>It is stated here:</b> “And if anyone sin, and does any of the <b>commandments</b> which the Lord has commanded not to be done” (Leviticus 5:17). <b>And it is stated with regard to the sin offering for</b> eating forbidden <b>fat:</b> “And if any one of the common people sin through error, in doing any of the <b>commandments</b> which the Lord has commanded not to be done, and be guilty” (Leviticus 4:27).
The verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as there,</b> the sin offering is brought only for an act <b>that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable</b> to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>, and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin offering, so too here,</b> one brings a provisional guilt offering only for an act <b>that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable</b> to be punished with <b><i>karet</i>, and for its unwitting</b> violation one is liable to bring <b>a sin offering,</b> which is not the case concerning misuse of consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> derive from this verbal analogy? He learns that <b>just as there</b> the verse obligates one to bring <b>a fixed</b> sin offering, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the provisional guilt offering, one brings it for a case of uncertain transgression of a prohibition for which one would be liable to bring <b>a fixed</b> sin offering, <b>to exclude a sin offering</b> brought for uncertain transgression <b>of</b> the <b>defiling of</b> the <b>Temple or sacrificial</b> foods, <b>as</b> the sin offering for that transgression is not fixed, but <b>is a sliding-scale</b> offering. If the sinner is poor he brings a meal offering or a bird offering; if he is rich he brings an animal offering. In a case of uncertainty one does not bring a provisional guilt offering.
<b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis,</b> who derived a different <i>halakha</i> from the verbal analogy, they hold that <b>there is no verbal analogy for half</b> of a matter. Once a provisional guilt offering is compared to a sin offering, it must be completely similar, and both matters are derived from the verbal analogy. The Gemara asks: <b>But Rabbi Akiva also</b> must hold that <b>there is no verbal analogy for half</b> of a matter, so why does he not agree with the derivation of the Rabbis?
The Gemara reconsiders: <b>Yes,</b> this <b>is indeed so. And here they disagree with regard to this: Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>it is written</b> with regard to the provisional guilt offering: <b>“And if anyone</b> sin, and does any of the commandments which the Lord has commanded not to be done, though he did not know it, yet is he guilty, and shall bear his iniquity” (Leviticus 5:17). The word “and” represented by the letter <b><i>vav</i> adds to the previous matter.</b> When a phrase begins with the conjunction <i>vav</i>, it is a continuation of the previous matter, and the <i>halakhot</i> of the previous passage can be learned from the subsequent passage. Therefore one brings a provisional guilt offering for uncertain misuse of consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis also, isn’t it written: “And if anyone</b> sin”? <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree about this: As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that a derivation from <b>a juxtaposition is preferable,</b> and derives from the juxtaposition of the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property to the <i>halakhot</i> of a provisional guilt offering that one is liable to bring a provisional guilt offering if he is not certain whether he misused consecrated property. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that a derivation from <b>a verbal analogy is preferable,</b> and therefore derive from a verbal analogy between the passage of misuse of consecrated property and the passage of a sin offering for eating forbidden fat that one is not liable to bring a provisional guilt offering if he is not certain whether he misused consecrated property.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it may be <b>that everyone</b> agrees <b>that</b> a derivation from <b>a juxtaposition is preferable. And the Rabbis would say to you</b> that the reason one is exempt from bringing a provisional guilt offering in a case of uncertain mis-use of consecrated property is that the juxtaposition should be understood in the opposite manner. <b>It is</b> the <b>lower</b> passage <b>that</b> is <b>derived from</b> the <b>upper</b> passage.
The juxtaposition teaches that a provisional <b>guilt offering</b> must be a ram <b>worth</b> a minimum of two <b>silver shekels,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the offering brought for misuse of consecrated property. This derivation is needed <b>so that you should not say</b> that a provisional guilt offering, brought for <b>his uncertain</b> transgression, <b>should not be</b> more <b>stringent than</b> the offering one brings in a case of <b>his definite</b> transgression. According to that claim, one would say that <b>just as</b> for <b>his definite</b> transgression one may bring <b>a sin offering worth</b> only <b>one-sixth [<i>danka</i>]</b> of a dinar, <b>so too,</b> for <b>his uncertain</b> transgression one may bring a provisional <b>guilt offering worth</b> only <b>one-sixth</b> of a dinar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where</b> does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> derive <b>this conclusion?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> it <b>from</b> the verse that states: <b>“And this is the law of the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:1), which teaches that there is <b>one law for all of the guilt offerings</b> and they must all be worth at least two shekels, provisional guilt offerings included.
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well</b> according to <b>one who holds</b> that there is a derivation from the word <b>“law,”</b> but according to the <b>one who does not hold</b> that there is a derivation from the word <b>“law,” from where does he learn</b> that all guilt offerings must have the same minimum value? The Gemara answers: <b>He learns</b> it from a verbal analogy between the term <b>“according to your valuation”</b> stated with regard to a guilt offering for misuse of consecrated property (Leviticus 5:15) and the term <b>“according to your valuation”</b> stated with regard to a provisional guilt offering (Leviticus 5:18) and a guilt offering for robbery (Leviticus 5:25).
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well</b> concerning guilt offerings <b>where it is written “according to your valuation,”</b> but with regard to <b>a guilt offering</b> brought for engaging in sexual intercourse with <b>an espoused maidservant, concerning which</b> it is <b>not written</b> in the Torah <b>“according to your valuation,” what is there to say?</b> How does one derive that the guilt offering brought for engaging in sexual intercourse with an espoused maidservant must be worth a minimum of two silver shekels?
The Gemara answers that it is <b>derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the term <b>“with the ram”</b> stated with regard to a guilt offering for mis-use of consecrated property (Leviticus 5:16) and the term <b>“with the ram”</b> stated with regard to the guilt offering for engaging in sexual intercourse with an espoused maidservant (Leviticus 19:22).
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the mishna. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a sin offering requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to an individual sin offering: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the sin offering, <b>and slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:29). Just as a burnt offering must be slaughtered in the north of the Temple courtyard, so too, a sin offering must also be slaughtered in the north.
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> from this verse that the <b>slaughter</b> must be in the north. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>collection</b> of the blood must also be in the north? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering</b> with his finger and place it upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering, and all its remaining blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar” (Leviticus 4:34). As this verse immediately follows the verse discussing the slaughter of a sin offering, evidently the taking of the blood is performed in the same place as the slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>the one collecting</b> the blood must <b>himself</b> stand in the north of the Temple courtyard? Perhaps he may stand near the north and extend his arm to collect the blood. The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall take [<i>velakaḥ</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 4:34), which can be read, as: <b>He will take himself [<i>lo yikkaḥ</i>].</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> that the offering must be slaughtered in the north and the blood collected in the north <b>to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner. <b>From where</b> is it derived that if one slaughters the offering or collects the blood anywhere else the offering is <b>disqualified?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is written</b> in <b>another verse</b> which speaks of a goat sin offering brought by a king who sins: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the goat <b>and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering</b> before the Lord; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Where is the burnt offering slaughtered? In the north. This</b> sin offering of a king must <b>also</b> be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard.

Daf 48b

The Gemara asks: <b>And do you learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from here? But isn’t it already stated:</b> “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying: This is the law of the sin offering: <b>In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered shall the sin offering be slaughtered</b> before the Lord; it is most holy” (Leviticus 6:18)? If so, <b>to what</b> purpose <b>was this singled out?</b> Why did the Torah state explicitly that the sin offering of the king requires slaughter in the north? The Gemara answers: <b>To fix a place for it,</b> that this is the only place where a sin offering may be slaughtered, teaching <b>that if it was not slaughtered in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, the offering is <b>disqualified</b> even after the fact.
The Gemara asks: Do <b>you say</b> that it is <b>singled out for this</b> purpose, to teach that even after the fact a sin offering slaughtered anywhere other than in the north is disqualified? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> to teach <b>that this</b> goat sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north but no other</b> goat sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states:</b> “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the sin offering, <b>and slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:29). <b>This established a paradigm for all sin offerings,</b> teaching <b>that they require</b> slaughter in the <b>north.</b>
The Gemara continues its explanation: <b>We have found</b> that the Torah writes with regard to the <b>goat</b> sin offering <b>of a king</b> that it requires slaughter in the north <b>both to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner and <b>to disqualify</b> the offering even after the fact. <b>We have also found</b> with regard to the <b>other sin offerings</b> that the Torah states that <b>to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner they must be slaughtered in the north of the Temple courtyard. <b>From where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>to disqualify</b> other sin offerings if they were not slaughtered in the north?
The Gemara explains: <b>As it is written with regard to a lamb</b> sin offering that it must be slaughtered in the north: “And slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:33) <b>and</b> it is also <b>written with regard to a she-goat</b> sin offering: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the sin offering, and slaughter it for a sin offering in the place of the burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:29). This repetition teaches that a sin offering is disqualified if it is not slaughtered in the north.
§ Having derived from these verses that all sin offerings are disqualified if they are slaughtered not in the north, the Gemara questions its earlier explanation. <b>Rather, why do I</b> need the term <b>“it”</b> stated with regard to the sin offering of a king in the verse: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the goat, and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before the Lord; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24)?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is required for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It,</b> the goat sin offering of a king, is slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Tabernacle, <b>but</b> the <b>goat</b> offered by <b>Nahshon</b> and the other princes was <b>not</b> slaughtered <b>in the north.</b> Nahshon was the prince of the tribe of Judah. He, along with all the other princes of the tribes, brought offerings to inaugurate the altar and the Tabernacle, as recorded in the Torah (Numbers, chapter 7). Although the offerings were classified as sin offerings because they shared some characteristics of sin offerings, they were not brought to atone for any particular sin. Therefore, the term “it” teaches that the offerings of the princes did not require slaughter in the north.
<b>And</b> the reason that it is necessary for the Torah to exclude Nahshon’s sin offering from the requirement of slaughter in the north is because <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sin offering of a king: <b>“And he shall place his hand upon the head of the goat,</b> and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before the Lord; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). The verse could have stated: Upon its head. The reason it adds “of the goat” is <b>to include</b> the <b>goat</b> brought as a sin offering by <b>Nahshon in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an offering. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The term “of the goat” serves <b>to include</b> the <b>goats</b> brought as sin offerings for communal <b>idol worship in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an offering.
The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the sin offerings of the princes <b>are included in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands, they are also included in</b> the requirement of being slaughtered in the <b>north.</b> Therefore, the term “it” <b>teaches us</b> that for the goat brought as a sin offering by Nahshon and the other princes there was no requirement of slaughter in the north.
<b>Ravina objects to this</b> interpretation: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that the offering of Nahshon required him to place his hands on the head of the animal. But <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, what is there to say?</b> Why should the Torah write the term “it,” since there is no reason to assume that it would require slaughter in the north?
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Tavi, said to Ravina: And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, does it work out well?</b> Why is it necessary for the Torah to specifically exclude the offerings of the princes from the requirement of slaughter in the north? Why not say that <b>for that</b> for <b>which it was included,</b> i.e., placing hands on the head of an animal, <b>it was included, and</b> for <b>that which it was not included,</b> i.e., slaughter in the north, <b>it was not included.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>if the verse had not excluded</b> the offerings of the princes <b>I would say</b> that one could <b>derive</b> the requirement for slaughter in the north <b>via a paradigm</b> from all other sin offerings, <b>if so,</b> one could also <b>derive</b> the requirement for <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an animal <b>itself via</b> the same <b>paradigm. Rather,</b> the reason that the requirement of placing hands cannot be derived via a paradigm is that <b>we do not learn</b> the requirements of the sin offering of Nahshon, which was only for the time of the inauguration of the Tabernacle alone, <b>from</b> the requirement of sin offerings applicable to all <b>generations. So too,</b> the requirement of slaughter in the north cannot be derived via a paradigm because <b>we do not learn</b> the requirements of the sin offering of Nahshon <b>from</b> the requirement of sin offerings applicable to all <b>generations.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>but the one who slaughters</b> it does <b>not</b> need to stand <b>in the north</b> when he slaughters it.
The Gemara challenges this: The <i>halakha</i> of the one who <b>slaughters</b> the offering has already been <b>derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Aḥiyya, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Aḥiyya says:</b> The verse states with regard to the burnt offering: <b>“And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar northward</b> before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:11). <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> the exclusionary term “it”?
He explains: <b>Since we have found</b> that the priest <b>stands in the north and collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal <b>in the north, and if he stood in the south and collected</b> the blood <b>in the north</b> the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that this is <b>so also</b> with regard to <b>this</b> one who slaughters the offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall slaughter <b>it,”</b> to teach that <b>it,</b> the animal, must be <b>in the north, but the one who slaughters</b> it is <b>not</b> required to be standing <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard when he slaughters the animal. Therefore, the question must be addressed: What is derived from the exclusionary term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king?
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it,</b> a goat brought as a sin offering, must be slaughtered <b>in the north, but a young bird</b> brought as an offering does <b>not</b> need to be killed <b>in the north.</b> This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a male bird requires</b> pinching of the nape in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard. <b>And this</b> can be derived through <b>a logical inference: Just as a young sheep</b> brought as a burnt offering is an offering for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did not fix</b> that <b>its</b> slaughter must be performed by <b>a priest</b> but nevertheless <b>fixed</b> that <b>its</b> slaughter must be in the <b>north,</b> with regard to <b>a young bird</b> brought as an offering, for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did fix</b> that <b>its</b> killing must be performed by <b>a priest, is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>should</b> also <b>fix its</b> slaughter in the <b>north?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states “it,”</b> to exclude a male bird from the requirement of being killed in the north.
The Gemara questions the logical inference. One cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of a bird offering from the <i>halakha</i> of a sheep offering, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a young</b> sheep offering? It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah <b>fixed</b> the requirement that <b>it</b> be slaughtered with <b>a utensil,</b> i.e., a knife. A bird, by contrast, is killed by the priest using his fingernail. Therefore, the term “it” cannot serve to counter this derivation.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it,</b> the goat of the king, is slaughtered <b>in the north, but</b> the <b>Paschal offering</b> is <b>not</b> slaughtered <b>in the north.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a Paschal offering requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north. And this</b> can be derived through <b>a logical inference: Just as a burnt offering</b> is an offering for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did not fix a time for its slaughter</b> but <b>fixed</b> that <b>it</b> requires slaughter in the <b>north,</b> with regard to <b>a Paschal offering,</b> for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>fixed a time for its slaughter,</b> as it must be slaughtered in the afternoon of the fourteenth day of Nisan, <b>is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>would fix</b> that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered in the <b>north?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states “it,”</b> to exclude the Paschal offering from the requirement of slaughter in the north.
The Gemara questions the logical inference. One cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of a Paschal offering from the <i>halakha</i> of a burnt offering, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah teaches that <b>it is entirely</b> burned on the altar. This is not so with regard to a Paschal offering.
The Gemara continues: If you would suggest a logical inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sin offering,</b> which is not entirely burned upon the altar but is slaughtered only in the north, this too can be refuted. As <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones for</b> those sins that render one <b>liable for</b> punishment by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which is not so with regard to a Paschal offering.
The Gemara continues: If you would suggest a logical inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a guilt offering,</b> which is not entirely burned, which does not atone for those sins punishable by <i>karet</i>, and which is slaughtered only in the north, this too can be refuted. As <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it has the status of <b>an offering of the most sacred order,</b> which is not so with regard to a Paschal offering. The Gemara adds: Having noted this distinction between a guilt offering and a Paschal offering, one can say that for <b>all of</b> the three offerings <b>as well,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a Paschal offering cannot be derived <b>from them, since</b> they all have the status of <b>offerings of the most sacred order.</b>
The Gemara returns to the earlier inference: <b>Actually,</b> the term “it” teaches <b>as we said initially: It,</b> i.e., the animal, must be standing <b>in the north, but</b> the <b>one who slaughters</b> the animal does <b>not</b> have to stand <b>in the north. And that</b> which is <b>difficult for you,</b> that <b>we derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Aḥiyya,</b> is in fact not difficult. The derivation from the term “it” is <b>not to exclude</b> one who <b>slaughters</b> from the requirement to slaughter <b>in the north,</b> since that <i>halakha</i> is known already from the statement of Rabbi Aḥiyya. <b>Rather,</b> the derivation is that it is only one who <b>slaughters</b> the animal who does <b>not</b> have to stand <b>in the north, but</b> by inference, the one who <b>collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal must stand <b>in the north.</b>
The Gemara questions this inference: The <i>halakha</i> that the one who <b>collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal must stand in the north is derived <b>from</b> the fact that the Torah could have written: The priest <b>shall take,</b> and instead writes: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take” [<i>velakaḥ</i>]</b> (Leviticus 4:34), which may be read as: He will take himself [<i>lo yikaḥ</i>], as explained on the previous <i>amud</i>. The Gemara explains: This <i>tanna</i> <b>does not learn</b> anything from this distinction between: The priest <b>shall take,</b> and: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take.”</b> He does not agree with this derivation, and therefore he must derive the requirement to collect the blood while standing in the north from a different verse.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the requirement of <b>slaughter</b> in the north <b>with regard to a burnt offering</b> in order <b>to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner. <b>We also found</b> a source for the requirement of <b>collecting</b> the blood while standing in the north in order <b>to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>slaughter and collection</b> of the blood are <b>disqualified</b> if they are not performed in the north?
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabba bar Sheila</b> who says: It is derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the slaughter and blood collection of <b>a sin offering</b> be performed in the north <b>comes by virtue of</b> a comparison to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a burnt offering,</b> as the verse states: “And slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:29), yet if the animal was not slaughtered or its blood was not collected in the north it <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, with regard to the <b>burnt offering</b> itself, <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the slaughter and blood collection of <b>a sin offering</b> be in the north <b>comes by virtue of it, is it not logical that</b> if it was not slaughtered or its blood was not collected in the north, this should <b>disqualify</b> the offering?
The Gemara rejects this logical inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones for</b> those sins that render one <b>liable for</b> punishment by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which is not so with regard to a burnt offering.
<b>Ravina said: This</b> is what is <b>difficult for Rav Adda bar Ahava.</b> In other words, regardless of the notable characteristic of a sin offering, he still is of the opinion that his logical inference stands. <b>Have we ever found</b> that <b>a secondary</b> prohibition is more <b>stringent than a primary</b> prohibition? Since the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering is derived via a comparison to the <i>halakha</i> of a burnt offering, the former cannot have stringencies that the latter lacks.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: But</b> have we <b>not</b> found a secondary prohibition that is more stringent than the primary one?

Daf 49a

<b>But there is</b> the case of the second <b>tithe, which</b> may be <b>redeemed, whereas</b> food that is <b>purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe</b> redemption <b>money</b> may <b>not</b> be <b>redeemed. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 10:10): With regard to food <b>that was purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money</b> and <b>that</b> then <b>became ritually impure,</b> this ritually impure food <b>must be redeemed</b> with money, with which one must purchase other food. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The food <b>must be buried.</b> The Gemara infers from the mishna: If the food purchased with the second-tithe money <b>became impure, yes,</b> it may be redeemed, but if it <b>did not become impure,</b> it may <b>not</b> be redeemed. If so, according to Rabbi Yehuda, the <i>halakha</i> that food purchased with second-tithe money must be buried if it becomes impure is more stringent than the <i>halakha</i> for second-tithe produce itself, which may be redeemed if it becomes impure.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the reason one may not redeem food that was purchased with second-tithe money and that then became ritually impure is not that the <i>halakha</i> is more stringent. Rather, there is a different reason. Since this food was merely purchased with second-tithe money, its <b>sanctity is not</b> as <b>strong</b> as the tithe itself and is unable <b>to grasp its redemption</b> money. Its status as second tithe is weak, and cannot be transferred to a third item. Consequently, if it becomes impure, according to Rabbi Yehuda it cannot be redeemed for money but must be buried, as an item that one is prohibited to derive benefit from.
Mar Zutra asks: <b>But there is</b> the case of <b>a substitution, as</b> the status of <b>an offering does not take effect with regard to a permanently blemished</b> animal, <b>while</b> consecration performed via substitution does <b>take effect</b> with regard to an animal with a permanent blemish. Although the animal cannot be sacrificed as an offering and must be redeemed, even after its redemption it may not be used for labor and its wool may not be used.
The Gemara answers: The sanctity of <b>a substitution comes by virtue of a consecrated</b> animal; therefore it has a stronger sanctity. <b>But</b> the sanctity of <b>a consecrated</b> animal itself <b>comes by virtue of a non-sacred</b> animal, as there was no consecrated animal by which the owner extended the sanctity to this animal.
Mar Zutra asks: But <b>there is</b> the case of <b>a Paschal offering, as it does not require</b> the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on its head, <b>or</b> wine <b>libations</b> to accompany the offering, <b>or waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh. While its remainder,</b> an animal that was designated as a Paschal offering but was not sacrificed at the right time, which is then sacrificed as a peace offering, has more stringent <i>halakhot</i>, because it <b>requires</b> the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on its head, <b>and</b> wine <b>libations</b> to accompany the offering, <b>and waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>A Paschal offering on the rest of the days of the year is</b> the same as <b>a peace offering,</b> and the animal is no longer considered to be a Paschal offering. Since it is a peace offering, all the <i>halakhot</i> of a peace offering apply to it, and the fact that it was once designated as a Paschal offering is irrelevant. The conclusion of the Gemara is that there are no cases where a secondary status is more stringent than the corresponding primary status. Therefore, the derivation from the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering to the <i>halakha</i> of a burnt offering, that the latter should be disqualified if it was not slaughtered in the north or if its blood was not collected in the north, remains.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> there is a different proof that even after the fact a burnt offering that was not slaughtered in the north is disqualified. <b>The verse states:</b> “And slaughter the sin offering in the place of <b>the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:29). Since the earlier verse (Leviticus 4:24) already stated: “In the place of the burnt offering,” the repetition in this verse stresses that <b>it shall be in its place,</b> meaning that the offering is disqualified if it is slaughtered anywhere else.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that a guilt offering,</b> which is an offering of the most sacred order, <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written: “In the place where they slaughter the burnt offering they shall slaughter the guilt offering,</b> and its blood shall be sprinkled around the altar” (Leviticus 7:2). Since the burnt offering must be slaughtered in the north, the guilt offering must also be slaughtered in the north.
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> a source that the <b>slaughter</b> must be in the north. <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>collection</b> of the blood must also be in the north? The Gemara answers that the second half of the verse states: <b>“And its blood shall be sprinkled</b> around the altar.” Since the blood must be collected immediately after the slaughter and before the sprinkling, just as the slaughter must be in the north, so the <b>collection of its blood</b> must <b>also</b> be <b>in the north.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the one who <b>collects</b> the blood must <b>himself</b> stand in the north? The Gemara answers: It is derived from the fact that the verse does not only state: <b>“Its blood</b> shall be sprinkled,” but states: <b>“And its blood</b> shall be sprinkled” (Leviticus 7:2). The conjunction “and [<i>ve’et</i>]” serves to include the one who collects the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> a verse teaching that in order <b>to</b> perform the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal manner, the slaughtering of the guilt offering is in the north. <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>to disqualify</b> after the fact an offering slaughtered elsewhere, not in the north? The Gemara answers: <b>Another verse is written,</b> referring to a guilt offering, which states: <b>“And he shall slaughter the sheep</b> in the place where they slaughter the sin offering and the burnt offering, in the place of the Sanctuary; for as the sin offering, so is the guilt offering; to the priest, it is most holy” (Leviticus 14:13). This teaches that all guilt offerings are disqualified if they are not slaughtered in the north.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does this</b> verse <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>This</b> verse is <b>necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a matter that was included in a general</b> category <b>but left to discuss a new matter,</b> i.e., if a novel aspect or special ruling is taught with regard to a specific case within a broader general category, <b>you may not return it to its general</b> category even for other matters, and this case is understood to have been entirely removed from the general category, <b>until the verse explicitly returns it to its general</b> category.
The Gemara explains: <b>How so?</b> The verse states: <b>“And he shall slaughter the sheep in the place where they slaughter the sin offering and the burnt offering, in the place of the Sanctuary; for as the sin offering, so is the guilt offering;</b> to the priest, it is most holy” (Leviticus 14:13). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “As the sin offering, so is the guilt offering,”</b> since the verse had already equated the guilt offering with the sin offering, <b>why</b> does the <b>verse state: “As the sin offering, so is the guilt offering”?</b> What does it serve to teach?
<b>Since the guilt offering of a leper left</b> the general category of guilt offerings <b>to teach a new matter,</b> as there is a <i>halakha</i> unique to the guilt offering of a leper in that blood of the offering is placed <b>on</b> the right <b>thumb of the hand and</b> the right <b>big toe of the foot and</b> the <b>right ear</b> of the leper, one <b>might</b> have thought that this guilt offering <b>does not require placement of blood or</b> the burning of <b>sacrificial portions on the altar,</b> as the <i>halakhot</i> of this guilt offering are unique.
To counter this reasoning, <b>the verse states: “As the sin offering, so is the guilt offering.” Just as the sin offering requires the placement of the blood and</b> the burning of <b>sacrificial portions on the altar, so too, the guilt offering of a leper requires placement of the blood and</b> the burning of <b>sacrificial portions on</b> the <b>altar.</b> Similarly, just as the verse had to teach these two <i>halakhot</i>, so too, the verse had to state: “And he shall slaughter the sheep in the place where they slaughter the sin offering and the burnt offering,” to teach that it requires slaughter in the north. It cannot serve as a source for the general <i>halakha</i> that a guilt offering slaughtered in a place other than in the north is disqualified.
The Gemara explains: <b>If so,</b> that the optimal manner to perform the mitzva is to slaughter a guilt offering in the north but failure to do so does not disqualify the offering, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write</b> the requirement to slaughter in the north <b>in this</b> context, i.e., in the context of the guilt offering of a leper, <b>and not write it in that</b> context, i.e., that of the standard guilt offering. The requirement for slaughter in the north for all other guilt offerings could be derived from the guilt offering of the leper. The repetition of the requirement to slaughter in the north serves to disqualify a guilt offering whose slaughter is not in the north.
The Gemara comments: <b>This works out well if we hold</b> that with regard to a matter that <b>left</b> its category <b>to teach a new matter,</b> the following principle applies: That matter itself <b>does not learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from its general</b> category until the Torah explicitly returns it to that category,

Daf 49b

<b>but</b> other matters in <b>its general</b> category <b>learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it;</b> in this case <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of slaughtering a guilt offering in the <b>north,</b> it is <b>well.</b> Although some of the <i>halakhot</i> of the guilt offering of a leper do not apply to the category of guilt offerings in general, it can still serve as the source for the <i>halakha</i> that any guilt offering is disqualified if slaughtered not in the north. <b>But if we hold that</b> in the case of a matter that left its category to teach a new matter, <b>it,</b> the original matter, <b>does not learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from its general</b> category <b>and its general</b> category <b>does not learn</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it,</b> then <b>this</b> verse <b>is necessary to</b> teach <b>its own</b> <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>Once</b> the verse <b>returned</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the guilt offering of a leper to the general category by stating “as the sin offering, so is the guilt offering,” <b>it returned it</b> completely. Therefore, when the verse states that it requires slaughter in the north of the Temple courtyard, the phrase is not needed to teach the <i>halakha</i> about the guilt offering of a leper, and it can be used to teach the <i>halakha</i> about guilt offerings in general.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: Say</b> that <b>when the verse returned</b> the guilt offering of a leper to the class of standard guilt offerings, that is only <b>with regard to place-ment of blood</b> on the altar <b>and</b> burning the <b>sacrificial portions, which require priesthood,</b> i.e., only a priest may perform those rites. As the verse states: “For as the sin offering, so is the guilt offering; to the priest” (Leviticus 14:13). <b>But</b> say that <b>slaughter, which does not require priesthood,</b> as even a non-priest may slaughter an offering, <b>does not require</b> that it be done in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard.
Ravina answered him: <b>If so, let the verse state: For as the sin offering, so is it. What</b> is added by the expanded phrase: “For <b>as the sin offering, so is the guilt offering”?</b> It teaches that the guilt offering of a leper <b>will be like the rest of</b> the <b>guilt offerings.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to juxtapose</b> the guilt offering of a leper <b>to a sin offering</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> that it must be slaughtered in the north, and <b>why do I</b> need <b>to juxtapose</b> it <b>to a burnt offering</b> to teach the same <i>halakha</i>? The verse states: “And he shall slaughter the sheep in the place where they slaughter the sin offering and the burnt offering, in the place of the Sanctuary” (Leviticus 14:13).
<b>Ravina said:</b> It <b>was necessary</b> to juxtapose the guilt offering to both of them, as, <b>if</b> the verse <b>had juxtaposed it</b> only <b>to a sin offering but had not juxtaposed it to a burnt offering, I would say: From where</b> is the requirement to slaughter <b>a sin offering</b> in the north <b>derived?</b> It is <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a burnt offering,</b> as explained on 48a. I would then assume that <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition,</b> i.e., the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering, which was derived via a juxtaposition to the <i>halakha</i> of a burnt offering, <b>then teaches</b> that <i>halakha</i> to another case <b>via a juxtaposition.</b> But there is a principle that with regard to matters of consecration the <i>halakha</i> may not be derived via a juxtaposition from another <i>halakha</i> that was itself derived via a juxtaposition. To prevent this incorrect assumption, the verse had to specifically teach the juxtaposition to a burnt offering.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: But let</b> the verse <b>juxtapose</b> the guilt offering of a leper only <b>to a burnt offering and not juxtapose it to a sin offering.</b> The juxtaposition to a sin offering appears superfluous.
Ravina answered: If that had been so, <b>I would</b> still <b>say</b> that <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teaches</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition. And if you would say</b> that if that were to be so, <b>let</b> the verse <b>juxtapose</b> the guilt offering of a leper only <b>to a sin offering,</b> one could answer that <b>it is preferable for</b> the Torah <b>that it juxtaposes</b> the guilt offering <b>to the primary</b> offering about which it states that it must be slaughtered in the north, i.e., the burnt offering, <b>and not juxtapose it to the secondary</b> offering, the sin offering. <b>For this</b> reason, i.e., to prevent the incorrect assumption that a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teaches its <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition, the verse <b>juxtaposed it to a sin offering and</b> also <b>juxtaposed it to a burnt offering, to say</b> that <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition does not then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition.</b>
<b>Rava says:</b> The principle that a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach its <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition is derived <b>from here, as it is written</b> with regard to the sin offering brought by the High Priest: “And the two kidneys, and the fat that is upon them, which is by the loins, and the diaphragm with the liver, which he shall take away by the kidneys. <b>As it is taken off from the ox of the sacrifice of peace offerings;</b> and the priest shall make them smoke upon the altar of burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:9–10). One can ask: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> is this offering juxtaposed to that of a peace offering? <b>If</b> it is <b>to</b> teach that the priest must sacrifice <b>the diaphragm with the liver and the two kidneys</b> from the offering, that is <b>written with regard to</b> the offering <b>itself,</b> in the previous verse. This does not need to be derived via a juxtaposition.
It is written <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the verse <b>wants to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the diaphragm with the liver and the two kidneys,</b> deriving it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the offering of <b>the bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> then teaching it <b>to</b> apply it to the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>goats</b> brought as sin offerings for communal <b>idol worship. It is not written</b> explicitly <b>in</b> the passage discussing the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself, and it is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the bull for</b> an unwitting sin of <b>an anointed priest,</b> i.e., the High Priest. The offering for an unwitting communal sin is juxtaposed to the sin offering brought by the High Priest in the verse: “So shall he do with the bull; as he did with the bull of the sin offering, so shall he do with this” (Leviticus 4:20).
<b>For this</b> reason it <b>was necessary</b> for the verse to state: <b>“As it is taken off</b> from the ox” (Leviticus 4:10), so <b>that it is as though it wrote</b> explicitly <b>in</b> the passage discussing the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself.</b> One of the hermeneutical principles applied to understanding verses in the Torah is: If the <i>halakha</i> stated is not required for the matter in which it is written, apply it to another matter. When this principle is employed, the <i>halakha</i> written in one context is viewed as if it were written elsewhere. In this case, as it was not necessary for the verse to write the juxtaposition to a peace offering in the context of the sin offering brought by the High Priest, it is applied to the case of the bull for an unwitting communal sin. <b>And</b> therefore it <b>will not be</b> a case of <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition</b> that <b>then teaches</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: But</b> why not <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write</b> explicitly <b>in</b> the passage discussing the bull for an unwitting communal sin <b>itself</b> that the diaphragm with the liver and two kidneys must be removed from the ox, <b>and not juxtapose</b> it to a peace offering in this convoluted manner?
Rava answered: <b>If</b> the Torah <b>had written</b> it <b>in</b> that passage <b>itself, and not juxtaposed</b> it, <b>I would say</b> that in general <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teaches via a juxtaposition,</b> as one would not have this instance to serve as a counterexample to that principle. <b>And if you would say:</b> If so, why not simply <b>juxtapose</b> the case of the bull for an unwitting communal sin to the case of the bull of the anointed priest, I would answer: <b>It is preferable for</b> the verse <b>that it writes it in</b> the passage <b>itself</b> rather <b>than to juxtapose it</b> alone. It is <b>for this</b> reason that <b>it wrote it and juxtaposed it, to say</b> that <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition.</b>
§ Before beginning a lengthy discussion concerning derivations via compounded methodologies of the hermeneutical principles, the Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for its forthcoming discussion: <b>Juxtaposition, verbal analogy, an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
The principle that <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition</b> is indicated <b>either from</b> the proof <b>of Rava or from</b> the proof <b>of Ravina,</b> both cited earlier. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition can</b> then <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a verbal analogy?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan ben Avtolemos says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> if leprosy <b>of garments spreads</b> throughout an entire garment <b>that it is pure?</b> It is derived via a verbal analogy: <b>A bareness within [<i>karaḥat</i>] and a bareness without [<i>gabbaḥat</i>]</b> are <b>stated with regard to</b> leprosy of <b>garments:</b> “And the priest shall look, after that the mark is washed; and behold, if the mark has not changed its color, and the mark has not spread, it is impure; you shall burn it in the fire; it is a fret, whether the bareness be within or without” (Leviticus 13:55); <b>and a bald head [<i>karaḥat</i>] and a bald forehead [<i>gabbaḥat</i>]</b> are <b>stated with regard to</b> leprosy of <b>a person:</b> “But if there be in the bald head, or the bald forehead, a reddish-white plague, it is leprosy breaking out in his bald head, or his bald forehead” (Leviticus 13:42).
<b>Just as there,</b> with regard to a person, if the leprosy <b>spread throughout him</b> entirely he is <b>pure,</b> as the verse states: “Then the priest shall look; and behold, if the leprosy has covered all of his flesh, he shall pronounce the one who has the mark pure; it is all turned white: He is pure” (Leviticus 13:13), <b>so too here</b> with regard to garments, if the leprosy <b>spread throughout the entire</b> garment it is <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara continues its proof: <b>But there,</b> with regard to the head, which serves as the source for this verbal analogy, <b>from where do we</b> derive that if the leprosy spreads throughout the head he is pure? <b>As it is written:</b> “And if the leprosy breaks out on the skin, and the leprosy covers all the skin of the one who has the mark, <b>from his head to his feet,</b> as far as it appears to the priest” (Leviticus 13:12). <b>And</b> the verse thereby <b>juxtaposes</b> leprosy on <b>his head to</b> leprosy on his <b>foot,</b> teaching the following <i>halakha</i>: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to leprosy of the body and foot, if <b>its entirety turned white,</b> and it <b>spread all over him,</b> he is <b>pure, so too here,</b> in the case of leprosy of the head, if <b>its entirety turned white and it spread over all his</b> head, he is <b>pure.</b> Evidently, a matter derived via a juxtaposition can then teach its <i>halakha</i> to another matter via a verbal analogy.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This cannot serve as a proof with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of consecrated matters. <b>With regard to the entire Torah,</b> one <b>derives</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>derived</b> via a verbal analogy <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>derived</b> via a juxtaposition, <b>apart from</b> with regard to <b>consecrated</b> matters, <b>where</b> one <b>does not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>derived</b> via a verbal analogy <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>derived</b> via a juxtaposition.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: <b>As if</b> it were to be <b>so</b> that one could derive a <i>halakha</i> in this manner even concerning consecrated matters, the verse <b>should not state</b> the requirement for slaughter in the <b>north with regard to a guilt offering,</b> as stated from the explicit juxtaposition of a burnt offering and a sin offering, <b>and</b> instead <b>derive it through a verbal analogy.</b> The verse describes a guilt offering <b>as an offering of the most sacred order</b> (see Leviticus 7:1), and its <i>halakha</i> can be derived via a verbal analogy <b>from</b> that of <b>a sin offering,</b> which is described in the same manner (see Leviticus 6:18).
Rabbi Yoḥanan continues: Is this <b>not to say,</b> at least with regard to consecrated matters, <b>that a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a verbal analogy?</b>
The Gemara rejects Rabbi Yoḥanan’s proof: <b>But perhaps</b> the requirement to slaughter a guilt offering in the north must be written explicitly <b>because</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones for</b> those sins <b>liable for</b> punishment by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which is not so with regard to a guilt offering.
The Gemara rejects this claim: There are <b>additional</b> descriptions of a guilt offering and a sin offering as <b>offerings of the most sacred order written</b> in the verses: “This shall be yours of the most sacred items, reserved from the fire: Every offering of theirs, every meal offering of theirs, and every sin offering of theirs, and every guilt offering of theirs, which they may offer to Me, shall be most holy for you and for your sons” (Numbers 18:9). A verbal analogy derived from extra phrases in the verse cannot be refuted with a logical claim. Therefore, Rabbi Yoḥanan’s claim stands, and, at least with regard to consecrated matters, a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach its <i>halakha</i> to another matter via a verbal analogy.
The Gemara states: That <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teaches</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference

Daf 50a

is apparent <b>from that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught,</b> discussed in the previous chapter (41a).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> in another context <b>via a paradigm? Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> It must be that it cannot, as, if it could, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>not write</b> the requirement to slaughter an offering in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>with regard to a guilt offering</b> (see Leviticus 14:13), <b>and</b> one can <b>derive</b> it <b>via a paradigm from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sin offering,</b> since they are both offerings of the most sacred order. <b>For what <i>halakha</i> did</b> the verse <b>write it</b> with regard to a guilt offering as well? Is this <b>not to say that a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> in another context <b>via a paradigm?</b>
The Gemara questions this proof: <b>But according to your reasoning,</b> why not <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a guilt offering must be slaughtered in the north <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a burnt offering, via a paradigm? What is the reason</b> that this <i>halakha</i> <b>is not derived</b> from there? It must be <b>because it can be refuted</b> with the following claim: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah teaches that <b>it is entirely</b> burned on the altar, which is not so with regard to a guilt offering. The Gemara now states its objection: In that case, the derivation from <b>a sin offering</b> via a paradigm <b>can also be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones for</b> those sins <b>liable for</b> punishment by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which is not so with regard to a guilt offering. If so, there is no proof from here.
The Gemara suggests an alternative paradigm: Although the requirement to slaughter <b>one</b> of these three offerings, i.e., a burnt offering, sin offering, or guilt offering, in the north <b>cannot be derived from</b> any <b>one</b> of the others, one can <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>one</b> of them <b>from</b> the other <b>two.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>From which</b> two could one <b>derive</b> the third? <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> the requirement to slaughter the offering in the north with regard to <b>a burnt offering, and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering.</b> The Gemara refutes this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> two offerings? They are notable <b>in that they atone</b> for transgressions, whereas a burnt offering does not atone for any sin.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> the requirement to slaughter an offering in the north <b>with regard to a sin offering, and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>these</b> others, the burnt offering and the guilt offering. The Gemara refutes this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> two offerings? They are notable <b>in that</b> they are brought only from <b>male</b> animals, whereas an individual’s sin offering is a female animal.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> the requirement to slaughter an offering in the north <b>with regard to a guilt offering, and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>these</b> other two. The Gemara refutes this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> two offerings? They are notable <b>in that they are</b> brought <b>by a community just as</b> they are brought <b>by an individual,</b> whereas a guilt offering can be brought only by an individual.
The Gemara returns to its discussion of hermeneutical principles. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a verbal analogy</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a juxtaposition? Rav Pappa says:</b> The verse states: <b>“And this is the law of the sacrifice of peace offerings,</b> which one may offer to the Lord. <b>If</b> he sacrifices it <b>for a thanks offering,</b> then he shall offer with the thanks offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour soaked” (Leviticus 7:11–12). From this juxtaposition <b>we have learned that</b> the money to purchase <b>a thanks offering</b> can <b>come from</b> money used to redeem <b>the</b> second <b>tithe, since we find that</b> the money to purchase <b>a peace offering</b> can <b>come from</b> money used to redeem the second <b>tithe.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the money to purchase <b>peace offerings themselves</b> can come from money used to redeem the second tithe? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to peace offerings: “And you shall sacrifice peace offerings and shall eat <b>there”</b> (Deuteronomy 27:7). And it is written with regard to second tithe: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place which He shall choose to cause His name to dwell <b>there”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:23). The usage of the term “there” in both passages serves as a verbal analogy, and demonstrates that a <i>halakha</i> derived via a verbal analogy, that of a peace offering, can then teach a <i>halakha</i> via its juxtaposition to a thanks offering.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina:</b> This is not a proof, because the <b>tithe of grain,</b> including the second tithe, <b>is merely non-sacred.</b> Therefore, it cannot be used to prove that in the realm of consecrated matters a <i>halakha</i> derived via a verbal analogy can teach a <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition.
Ravina <b>said to him:</b> Does the one who <b>said</b> that in the realm of consecrated matters a <i>halakha</i> derived via one of the hermeneutical principles cannot teach via another of those principles <b>say this</b> only when the <i>halakha</i> that is <b>derived</b> is in the realm of <b>consecrated</b> matters <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>teaches</b> is in the realm of <b>consecrated</b> matters as well? He holds that even if that which is derived is in the realm of consecrated matters it cannot teach its <i>halakha</i> via one of the hermeneutical principles. Therefore, since peace offerings are in the realm of consecrated matters, the <i>halakha</i> derived from the juxtaposition of thanks offerings to peace offerings serves as a source that a matter derived via a verbal analogy can teach its <i>halakha</i> to another matter via a juxtaposition.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a verbal analogy</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via</b> another <b>verbal analogy? Rami bar Ḥama says: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the types of bread that accompany a thanks offering: “If he sacrifices it for a thanks offering, then he shall sacrifice with the thanks offering unleavened loaves mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and loaves mingled with oil, of <b>fine flour cooked</b> with oil” (Leviticus 7:12). <b>We have derived</b> from here <b>that</b> the <b>poached</b> breads accompanying the thanks offering <b>come from fine flour.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived that the <b>loaves</b> accompanying a thanks offering are also prepared with fine flour? <b>The verse states: “Loaves</b> mingled with oil, of fine flour cooked with oil” (Leviticus 7:12), and it also states in the same verse: “Unleavened <b>loaves</b> mingled with oil.” <b>From where</b> is it derived that the unleavened <b>wafers</b> accompanying a thanks offering are also prepared with fine flour? <b>The verse states: “Unleavened</b> cakes mingled with oil” (Leviticus 7:12), and the verse also states: <b>“Unleavened</b> wafers spread with oil.” The <i>baraita</i> derives via a verbal analogy that the unleavened loaves mingled with oil are prepared with fine flour, and then teaches the <i>halakha</i> concerning unleavened wafers using a verbal analogy from the <i>halakha</i> of unleavened loaves.
<b>Ravina said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: <b>From where</b> do you know <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>learns</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“unleavened”</b> and <b>“unleavened” from loaves</b> of the thanks offering? <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>learns</b> the verbal analogy <b>from</b> the word “unleavened” stated with regard to meal offerings <b>baked in an oven,</b> about which the verse states explicitly that they are prepared with fine flour: “And when you bring a meal offering baked in the oven, it shall be unleavened cakes of fine flour mingled with oil, or unleavened wafers spread with oil” (Leviticus 2:4). If so, there is no source that a <i>halakha</i> derived via a verbal analogy can teach a <i>halakha</i> via a verbal analogy.
<b>Rather, Rava says</b> that the source is from a different <i>baraita</i>, as <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the bull offering of a High Priest: “And the skin of the bull and all its flesh, with its head and with its legs, <b>and its innards, and its dung,</b> the whole bull <b>shall he carry out</b> of the camp to a pure place, where the ashes are poured out, and burn it on wood with fire” (Leviticus 4:11–12). This <b>teaches that he brings</b> the offering <b>out whole.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that he should burn it whole</b> as well. <b>It is stated here: “Its head and its legs,” and it is stated there,</b> with regard to a burnt offering: “And he shall cut it into its pieces; and the priest shall lay them, with <b>its head</b> and its fats, in order on the wood that is on the fire which is upon the altar. But the innards <b>and the legs</b> shall he wash with water” (Leviticus 1:12–13). <b>Just as there,</b> the burnt offering is burned <b>by means of cutting</b> the offering into pieces, as explicitly stated in the verse, <b>so too here,</b> it is burned <b>by means of cutting</b> the offering into pieces.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>If</b> these are compared, one could say that <b>just as there,</b> the burnt offering is prepared for being burned <b>by</b> first <b>flaying</b> it, <b>so too here,</b> the bull offering of a High Priest should <b>also</b> be prepared for being burned <b>by</b> first <b>flaying</b> it. To counter this reasoning, <b>the verse states: “And its innards and its dung”</b> (Leviticus 4:11). The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation?</b> How do these words teach that there is no requirement to flay the animal? <b>Rav Pappa says: Just as the dung</b> remains <b>inside</b> the animal when the animal is burned, <b>so</b> the animal’s <b>flesh</b> remains <b>inside its skin.</b> In any event, the <i>halakha</i> that the bull offering of a High Priest is cut into pieces before it is burned is derived via a verbal analogy.
Rava continues: <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It <b>is stated here,</b> with regard to the bull and goat offered by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, the terms <b>skin, flesh, and dung,</b> in the verse: “And the bull of the sin offering, and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought in to make atonement in the Sanctuary, shall be carried out of the camp; and they shall burn in the fire their skin, and their flesh, and their dung” (Leviticus 16:27).

Daf 50b

<b>And it is stated below,</b> with regard to the bull sin offerings that are burned, the terms <b>skin, flesh, and dung,</b> in the verse: “But the skin of the bull, and all its flesh, with its head, and with its legs, and its innards, and its dung” (Leviticus 4:11). <b>Just as below</b> it is prepared for burning <b>by means of cutting</b> it into pieces but <b>not by means of flaying,</b> as derived by the verbal analogy, <b>so too here</b> it is prepared for burning <b>by means of cutting</b> it into pieces but <b>not by means of flaying.</b> Evidently, a <i>halakha</i> derived via a verbal analogy can then teach another <i>halakha</i> via a verbal analogy.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a verbal analogy</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? The Gemara answers: That question itself can be answered with <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> a matter derived via <b>a juxtaposition, which cannot</b> then <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>either from</b> the statement <b>of Rava or from</b> the statement <b>of Ravina</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), with regard to a matter derived via <b>a verbal analogy, which</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference?
The Gemara clarifies: <b>This works out well according to the one who accepts</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa. But according to the one who does not accept</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa,</b> i.e., Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, <b>what is there to say?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> this can be derived through a different <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> a matter derived via <b>a juxtaposition, which cannot</b> then <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>either from</b> the statement <b>of Rava or from</b> the statement <b>of Ravina</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), with regard to a matter derived via <b>a verbal analogy, which</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via another verbal analogy,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rami bar Ḥama</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference?
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a verbal analogy</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a paradigm?</b> The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a juxtaposition?</b> The Gemara answers that this itself can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>a verbal analogy, which cannot be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa</b> (50a), with regard to a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which <b>can be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition?</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>This works out well according to the one who accepts</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa. But according to the one who does not accept</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa,</b> i.e., Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara comments: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a verbal analogy?</b> The Gemara answers that this itself can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>And just as</b> a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>a verbal analogy, which cannot be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a verbal analogy,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rami bar Ḥama</b> (50a), with regard to a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which <b>can be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a verbal analogy?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? The Gemara answers that this itself can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>And just as</b> a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>a verbal analogy, which cannot be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, <b>as we have said,</b> with regard to a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which <b>can be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference?
The Gemara comments: <b>And this is an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that is the <b>son of,</b> i.e., is derived from, another <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. The Gemara challenges this last statement: <b>It is</b> not the son of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, but the <b>grandson of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which cannot be used. The very fact that a matter derived via a verbal analogy can then teach its <i>halakha</i> via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference is itself derived from an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as the Gemara stated.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether a matter derived via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference can teach its <i>halakha</i> to another matter via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference can be derived via another <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>And just as</b> a matter derived via <b>a juxtaposition, which cannot be derived via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>either from</b> the statement <b>of Rava or from</b> the statement <b>of Ravina</b> (49b), can nevertheless <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), with regard to a <i>halakha</i> derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, which <b>can be derived</b> from another <i>halakha</i> derived <b>via a juxtaposition,</b> as proven <b>from</b> the statement <b>that the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> (50a), <b>is it not logical that it should teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? The Gemara comments: <b>And this is an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that is the <b>son of</b> another <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a paradigm? Rabbi Yirmeya says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (69a–b): If a priest <b>pinched</b> the nape of a bird offering properly <b>and it was</b> then <b>found</b> to be a bird <b>with a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> which disqualifies it from being used as an offering and renders it prohibited for consumption by the priests, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> An olive-bulk of its meat <b>does not render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning a bird carcass, as the fact that it underwent pinching means that it is not in the category of a carcass. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Its status is like that of any other carcass of a kosher bird, and its meat <b>renders</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Meir said:</b> My opinion can be proved via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>And just as</b> with regard to <b>the carcass of an animal, which transmits impurity</b> to a person <b>through touching</b> it <b>and carrying</b> it, <b>its slaughter</b> nevertheless <b>purifies its <i>tereifa</i> from its impurity,</b> with regard to <b>the carcass of a bird,</b> which possesses less severe impurity, <b>as it does not transmit impurity through touching</b> it <b>and carrying</b> it, but only when it is in the throat, <b>is it not logical that its slaughter purifies its <i>tereifa</i> from its impurity?</b> And once it is established that slaughter purifies a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i>, it can be derived: <b>Just as we found with regard to</b> a bird’s <b>slaughter that it permits it for consumption</b>

Daf 51a

<b>and</b> it <b>purifies its <i>tereifa</i> from its impurity, so too</b> its <b>pinch-ing, which permits</b> bird offerings <b>with regard to consumption, should purify its <i>tereifa</i> from its impurity.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> Although one can derive from the case of an animal that slaughter purifies the <i>tereifa</i> of a bird from its impurity, that derivation cannot be extended to pinching. The same restriction that applies to every <i>a fortiori</i> inference, namely, that a <i>halakha</i> derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference is no more stringent than the source from which it is derived, applies here: <b>It is sufficient</b> for the halakhic status of the carcass of a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> to be <b>like</b> that of <b>the carcass of an animal</b> of <b>a kosher</b> species that is a <i>tereifa</i>; i.e., <b>that</b> only <b>its slaughter purifies it, but not its pinching.</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>And</b> that <b>is not so. Let it remain there,</b> i.e., one cannot learn from it, as that is a case that <b>comes from the slaughter of non-sacred</b> animals. The <i>halakha</i> of the pinching of a consecrated bird is derived through a paradigm from the <i>halakha</i> of the slaughter of a non-sacred bird, and the <i>halakha</i> of the slaughter of a non-sacred bird is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of the slaughter of a non-sacred animal. Outside of the realm of consecrated matters there is no question that a matter derived via one of the hermeneutical principles can then teach its <i>halakha</i> via another principle. The entire question under discussion is only with regard to the realm of consecrated matters.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>a matter derived via a paradigm</b> can <b>teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> to another matter <b>via a juxtaposition or via a verbal analogy or via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>or via a paradigm?</b>
The Gemara states: <b>Resolve at least one</b> of those questions. The Gemara cites a lengthy <i>baraita</i> before stating the resolution inferred from that <i>baraita</i>. <b>For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that <b>in</b> the case of <b>blood left overnight</b> it is <b>fit,</b> i.e., if blood of an offering had been left overnight and was then placed on the altar it need not be removed? This is <b>as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial portions,</b> where if they are <b>left overnight</b> they are <b>fit.</b> From where is it derived that <b>in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial portions</b> which are <b>left overnight,</b> they are <b>fit?</b> This is <b>as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>meat,</b> where if it is <b>left overnight</b> it is <b>fit,</b> because the meat of a peace offering may be eaten for two days and one night.
From where is it derived that if an offering that has <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard is then placed on the altar it need not be removed? This is derived by a paradigm, <b>since</b> an offering that <b>leaves</b> its area is <b>fit in</b> the case of an offering brought on a private <b>altar.</b>
From where is it derived that if an offering that has become <b>ritually impure</b> is placed on the altar it need not be removed? This is derived by a paradigm, <b>since</b> one is <b>permitted</b> to offer an impure offering <b>in</b> the case of <b>communal rites,</b> i.e., communal offerings. In cases of necessity, the communal offerings may be sacrificed even if they are ritually impure.
