From where is it derived that in the case of an offering that was disqualified due to the intention of the priest who slaughtered it to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time [<i>piggul</i>],</b> if it was placed on the altar it need not be removed? The <i>halakha</i> applies there <b>since</b> the sprinkling of its blood <b>effects acceptance</b> of the offering notwithstanding <b>its</b> status of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The status of <i>piggul</i> takes effect only if the sacrificial rites involving that offering were otherwise performed properly. This indicates that it still has the status of an offering, so it need not be removed from the altar.
From where is it derived that in the case of an offering that was disqualified due to the intention of the priest who slaughtered it to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> if it was placed on the altar it need not be removed? This is derived by a paradigm, <b>since</b> it is <b>juxtaposed to</b> an offering that was slaughtered with intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time.</b>
From where is it derived that in the case of an offering for <b>which</b> priests who are <b>disqualified collected and sprinkled its blood,</b> if it was placed on the altar it need not be removed? This is derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>these</b> priests who are generally <b>disqualified</b> because they are impure, yet <b>who are fit to</b> perform the <b>communal rites,</b> i.e., to sacrifice communal offerings, when all the priests or the majority of the Jewish people are impure. In any event, the <i>halakha</i> of the sacrificial portions was derived via a paradigm from the <i>halakha</i> of meat that was left overnight, and then the <i>halakha</i> of blood was derived via a paradigm from the <i>halakha</i> of the sacrificial portions. Evidently, a matter derived via a paradigm can teach its <i>halakha</i> to another matter via a paradigm.
The Gemara questions the derivations of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But can one deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a matter that is not fit,</b> i.e., sacrificial portions that are disqualified due to having been left overnight, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a matter that is fit,</b> i.e., the peace offering, which is permitted to be eaten for two days and one night? Similarly, how can the <i>baraita</i> derive the <i>halakha</i> of meat that was removed from the Temple courtyard from the <i>halakha</i> of a private altar, which has no sacred area surrounding it?
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i> relied on</b> the verse: “Command Aaron and his sons, saying: <b>This is the law of the burnt offering:</b> It is that which goes up on its firewood upon the altar all night until the morning; and the fire of the altar shall thereby be kept burning” (Leviticus 6:2), which <b>amplified</b> it, teaching that many types of disqualified offerings may be left upon the altar. The derivations written in the <i>baraita</i> are mere supports for those <i>halakhot</i>.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to the sin offerings whose blood is presented inside the Sanctuary: As to <b>the remainder of the blood</b> which is left after the sprinklings, a priest would pour it onto the western base of the external altar. But if he did not place the remainder of the blood on the western base, it does not disqualify the offering. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that it must be poured on the western base? The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the bull offering of the High Priest: “And the priest shall sprinkle the blood upon the corners of the altar of sweet incense before the Lord, which is in the Tent of Meeting; and all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out <b>at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 4:7). This means that he must pour it on <b>that</b> base <b>which he encounters first</b> when he leaves the Tent of Meeting, which is the western base.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There are three verses that contain the same phrase. With regard to pouring the remainder of the blood of a bull offering of the High Priest, the verse states: “All the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out <b>at the base of the altar of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:7). This teaches that it must be on the base of the external altar, <b>but not</b> on <b>the base of the inner altar,</b> where he had sprinkled the blood.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to the bull sacrificed for an unwitting communal sin the verse states: “And he shall sprinkle the blood upon the corners of the altar which is before the Lord, that is in the Tent of Meeting, and all the remaining blood shall he pour out <b>at the base of the altar of burnt offering,</b> which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:18). This teaches that the <b>inner altar itself has no base</b> at all.
Finally, the verse states with regard to the sin offering of a king: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and place it upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering, and the remaining blood thereof shall he pour out <b>at the base of the altar of the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25). This teaches that you must <b>give a base to the altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> i.e., that the remainder of any blood placed on the altar must be poured on the base.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Or</b> perhaps it <b>is not</b> so, but <b>rather</b> the verse serves to teach that any sprinkling of blood on the corners of the <b>altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering will be</b> done on a part of the altar where there is <b>a base. Rabbi Yishmael said:</b> There is no need for the verse to teach that <i>halakha</i>, because it can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood, <b>which does not effect atonement, requires</b> pouring on the <b>base</b> of the altar, with regard to <b>the initial</b> sprinkling of the blood <b>of a burnt offering, which effects atonement, is it not logical that it requires</b> a part of the altar where there is <b>a base?</b>
Similarly, <b>Rabbi Akiva said: Just as</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood, <b>which does not effect atonement and does not come for atonement,</b> nevertheless <b>requires</b> pouring on the <b>base</b> of the altar, with regard to <b>the initial</b> sprinkling of the blood <b>of a burnt offering, which effects atonement and comes for atonement, is it not logical that it requires</b> a part of the altar where there is <b>a base?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>If so, why</b> must <b>the verse state: “At the base of the altar of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25)? It is to teach that you must <b>give a base to the altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> i.e., that the remainder of the blood of the offering must be poured on the base.
The Gemara discusses this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master says:</b> The verse states: <b>“At the base of the altar</b> of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:18). This teaches that it must be on the base of the external altar, <b>but not the base of the inner altar.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t that necessary for the matter itself,</b> to teach that the remainder of the blood must be poured onto the base of the external altar? The Gemara answers: That <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived from: “Which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 4:18), referring to the external altar. Therefore, the verse mentions the altar of burnt offering to exclude the base of the inner altar.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches with regard to the sin offering of a king: The verse states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, and place it upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering, and the remaining blood thereof shall he pour out <b>at the base of the altar of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25).

Daf 51b

This teaches that you must <b>give a base to the altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> i.e., that the remainder of any blood placed on the altar must be poured on the base.
The Gemara explains: <b>Because if it enters your mind</b> that the verse states this simply to teach <b>as it is written,</b> concerning this offering alone, <b>why do I</b> need <b>these verses</b> with regard to the sin offering of a king? If you would answer: The verses are needed <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>remainder</b> of the blood must be poured on the external altar rather than on the inner altar, then the question remains: Is there any need for the Torah to teach this about the <b>remainder? But</b> the sprinklings of blood themselves are <b>performed</b> on the <b>external</b> altar, so why would one think that the remainder of the blood should be poured on the inner altar?
<b>And if you would say</b> that one might mistakenly say <b>that</b> the priest <b>reverses</b> the sprinklings,

Daf 52a

such that with regard to an offering for <b>which</b> he sprinkles the blood on the <b>external</b> altar he should pour the remainder of the blood <b>on</b> the <b>inner</b> altar, <b>and</b> this is analogous to the <i>halakha</i> that he pours the remainder <b>of</b> the blood sprinkled on the <b>inner</b> altar <b>on</b> the base of the <b>external</b> altar, this is not possible. <b>But the inner</b> altar <b>itself does not have a base,</b> and therefore it is not possible to pour the remainder of the blood on the base of the inner altar. Therefore, the verse must teach that the remainder of the blood of the burnt offering is poured on the base of the external altar.
The Gemara analyzes the next clause of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Or</b> perhaps it <b>is not</b> so, but <b>rather</b> the verse serves to teach that any sprinkling of blood on the corners of the <b>altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering will be</b> done on a part of the altar where there is <b>a base.</b> The Gemara asks: How can the verse mean that? <b>Is it written: At the base of the burnt offering?</b> This would indicate that the blood of the burnt offering must be placed where there is a base. <b>It is written</b> in the verse: <b>“At the base of the altar of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25).
The Gemara answers: Even if the verse were to be speaking about sprinkling the blood of the burnt offering and is not referring to pouring the remainder of the blood, the term “altar of” is necessary, because <b>if it were written: At the base of the burnt offering, I would say</b> that the priest must sprinkle the blood <b>on the upright</b> wall <b>of the base</b> of the altar, i.e., the side of the base, rather than on the upper surface of the base. <b>Now that it is written: “At the base of the altar of the burnt offering,”</b> it means that the blood must be sprinkled <b>on the upper surface of the base.</b>
The Gemara explains the next clause of the <i>baraita</i> based on this understanding: <b>Rabbi Yishmael said: Why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> to teach that the blood must be sprinkled on the <b>upper surface of</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar? <b>It</b> can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as the remainder</b> of the blood <b>of a sin offering, which does not effect atonement,</b> nevertheless <b>requires</b> that it must be poured on the <b>upper surface of</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar, with regard to <b>the initial</b> sprinkling of the blood <b>of a burnt offering, which effects atonement, is it not logical that it requires</b> the <b>upper surface of</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar?
<b>Rabbi Akiva</b> explained similarly and <b>said: And just as the remainder</b> of the blood <b>of a sin offering, which does not effect atonement and does not come for atonement,</b> nevertheless <b>requires</b> that it must be poured on the <b>upper surface of</b> the <b>base,</b> with regard to <b>the initial</b> sprinkling of the blood <b>of a burnt offering, which effects atonement and comes for atonement, is it not logical that it requires</b> the <b>upper surface of</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar? The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>If so, why</b> must <b>the verse state: “At the base of the altar of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:25)? It is to teach that you must <b>give a base to the altar of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> i.e., that the remainder of any blood sprinkled on the altar must be poured on the base.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the explanations of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva? <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> is whether failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, so that all the sprinklings must be done again. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, <b>holds</b> that failure to pour the remainder of the blood does <b>disqualify</b> the offering. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, who adds the words: Which does not come for atonement, <b>holds</b> that failure to pour the remainder of the blood does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering.
<b>Rav Pappa says: Everyone</b> agrees that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering. <b>But here they disagree with regard to</b> the issue of whether failure to <b>squeeze</b> the blood from <b>a bird sin offering</b> after sprinkling the blood <b>disqualifies</b> the offering or not. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, <b>holds</b> that it does <b>disqualify</b> the offering, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that it does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa</b> that even Rabbi Yishmael agrees that failure to pour the remainder of the blood on the base does not disqualify the offering. The verse states: “And the priest shall sprinkle the blood upon the corners of the altar of sweet incense before the Lord, which is in the Tent of Meeting; <b>and all the remaining blood</b> of the bull <b>he shall pour out</b> at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “of the bull”?</b> This seems superfluous, as the entire passage is referring to the bull. This serves to <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> another bull, i.e., <b>the bull of Yom Kippur, which</b> also <b>requires placement of blood on the base</b> of the external altar. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yishmael said:</b> It is not necessary for the Torah to write that the blood of the bull of Yom Kippur requires placement of blood on the base of the external altar. This is because it can be derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as if</b> the bull of the anointed priest, i.e., the sin offering of a High Priest, with regard to <b>which it is not obligatory to bring its blood inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., it is not an obligatory offering, as he brings it only if he sins, nevertheless <b>requires</b> sprinkling blood on the <b>base</b> of the altar; with regard to the bull of Yom Kippur, with regard to <b>which it is obligatory to bring its blood inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., it must be brought every year, <b>is it not logical that it requires</b> sprinkling of its blood on the <b>base</b> of the altar?
<b>Rabbi Akiva said: Just as</b> the bull of a High Priest, with regard to <b>which its blood does not enter the innermost sanctum, whether as</b> a fixed <b>obligation or as a mitzva,</b> nevertheless <b>requires</b> pouring of blood on the <b>base</b> of the altar, concerning the bull of Yom Kippur, with regard to <b>which its blood enters the innermost sanctum</b> as <b>an obligation, is it not logical that it requires</b> pouring of blood on the <b>base</b> of the altar?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that the reason the Torah writes the phrase “of the bull” is to teach that failure to place the blood on the base of the external altar <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the service of Yom Kippur, after sprinkling the blood in the Sanctuary: <b>“And when he has made an end of atoning for the Sanctuary,</b> and the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, he shall present the live goat” (Leviticus 16:20). This teaches that once he has sprinkled the blood in the innermost sanctum <b>all the atonements are completed.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From now,</b> i.e., based on this, one can state <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>to</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the bull of</b> the <b>anointed priest from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the goat of</b> the <b>king. Just as</b> the goat sin offering of a king, with regard to <b>which its blood does not enter inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>whether</b> as a fixed <b>obligation or</b> as <b>a mitzva,</b> but is sprinkled, like other individual sin offerings, on the external altar, <b>requires</b> that the blood be poured on the <b>base</b> of the altar (see Leviticus 4:25); with regard to the sin offering of a High Priest, the blood of <b>which enters inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>whether as</b> a fixed <b>obligation or as a mitzva, is it not logical that it should require</b> pouring on the <b>base</b> of the altar?
If so, the verse that states that there is a requirement that the blood of the sin offering of a High Priest is poured on the base of the altar is apparently superfluous. One <b>might</b> have thought that the reason the Torah writes it is to teach that failure to pour the blood there <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And the priest shall sprinkle of the blood upon the corners of the altar of sweet incense before the Lord, which is in the Tent of Meeting, <b>and all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour</b> out at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7).
The <i>baraita</i> explains: Since the verse inverted the terms in the clause, writing: “And all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out,” and not: He shall pour out all the remaining blood of the bull, the <b>verse detaches this positive</b> mitzva of pouring the remaining blood from the other mitzvot in the verse. <b>And</b> the verse thereby <b>made</b> this <b>a non-essential mitzva, to tell you</b> that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering. This <i>baraita</i> supports Rav Pappa’s interpretation, that Rabbi Yishmael agrees that failure to pour the remainder of the blood on the base of the altar does not disqualify the offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>Rabbi Yishmael hold</b> that failure to <b>squeeze out</b> the blood of <b>a bird sin offering disqualifies</b> the offering, as Rav Pappa explained? <b>But the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse states: “And he shall sprinkle of the blood of the sin offering upon the side of the altar; <b>and the remainder of the blood shall be squeezed out</b> at the base of the altar; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:9). This means: <b>And the remainder shall be squeezed out,</b> i.e., it needs to be squeezed out only if some blood remains.

Daf 52b

<b>And that which does not remain,</b> i.e., if there is no blood remaining, <b>he shall not squeeze</b> it <b>out.</b> This indicates that failure to squeeze the blood does not disqualify the offering. The Gemara answers: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
The Gemara continues its discussion of the remainder of the blood. <b>Rami bar Ḥama says: This</b> following <b><i>tanna</i> holds</b> that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of offerings whose blood is sprinkled inside the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“The priest that sacrifices it for sin</b> shall eat it” (Leviticus 6:19). The verse states the word “it” to teach that <b>it,</b> the offering <b>whose blood was sprinkled</b> correctly, <b>above</b> the red line of the altar, is valid, and the priest may eat the meat. <b>But</b> this is <b>not</b> so for an offering <b>whose blood was sprinkled below</b> the red line, which is disqualified.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>You said</b> this, <b>but from where did you come?</b> In other words, why would one think that such an offering is valid, so that the verse needs to teach that it is not? The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>From the fact that it is stated:</b> “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood, upon the altar of the Lord your God; <b>and the blood of your offerings shall be poured out against the altar</b> of the Lord your God, and you shall eat the flesh” (Deuteronomy 12:27), <b>we learned</b> that <b>with regard to</b> those offerings whose blood is <b>placed with four placements</b> on the corners of the altar, <b>that if</b> the priest <b>placed them with</b> only <b>one placement, he has effected atonement.</b> Therefore, since it is derived that if the priest does not present the blood on the specified corners of the altar, the offering is nevertheless valid, one <b>might</b> have thought that blood <b>that</b> should have been <b>placed above</b> the red line but <b>that one placed below</b> the red line <b>effects atonement as well,</b> and the offering is valid.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> it would seem there <b>is a logical inference</b> to counter this logic. <b>It is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is to be sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line, referring to the blood of an animal sin offering, which is to be sprinkled on the corners on the upper half of the altar, <b>and it is stated</b> that <b>blood</b> is to be sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line, referring to the blood of a bird sin offering, which is to be sprinkled on the lower half of the altar. <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood</b> about <b>which</b> it <b>is stated</b> that it is to be <b>below</b> the red line, if it is a case <b>where one placed</b> it <b>above</b> the red line, it does <b>not effect atonement,</b> as the Sages derived from the verse: “And he shall sprinkle of the blood of the sin offering upon the side of the altar, and the remainder of the blood shall be squeezed out at the base of the altar; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:9), <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>blood,</b> about <b>which</b> it <b>is stated</b> that it is to be <b>above</b> the red line, if it is a case <b>where one placed</b> it <b>below</b> the red line, it does <b>not effect atonement.</b>
This logical inference is rejected: <b>No, if you said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the blood of a bird sin offering, which is to be sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line <b>that was placed with a placement above</b> the red line, that may be <b>because they will not ultimately</b> be sprinkled <b>above.</b> For this reason it does <b>not effect atonement. Shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the blood that is to be sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line, i.e., the blood of an animal sin offering, but <b>which one placed below</b> the red line, that it will not effect atonement? The blood that is to be sprinkled above the red line is different, <b>as</b> some <b>of it is sacrificed below</b> the red line, when the remainder of the blood is poured on the base of the altar.
The <i>baraita</i> responds: The <b>blood</b> that is placed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>will prove</b> it, <b>as</b> some <b>of it is sacrificed outside, but if</b> the priest <b>initially placed</b> the blood on the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary it does <b>not effect atonement.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> rejects this proof: <b>No, if you said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the <b>blood</b> that is placed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, concerning <b>which the inner altar does not complete</b> the atonement, as they require additional blood placements, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> the blood offered <b>above</b> the red line, i.e., the blood of an animal sin offering, concerning <b>which</b> the <b>corners</b> of the altar <b>complete</b> the atonement? Accordingly, it is possible to say that <b>if one placed them below</b> the red line <b>they are valid.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: To counter this reasoning, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to an animal sin offering that is sacrificed outside: “The priest that sacrifices <b>it</b> for sin shall eat it” (Leviticus 6:19), to emphasize that <b>it,</b> the offering <b>whose blood was placed</b> correctly, <b>above</b> the red line of the altar, is valid, and the priest may eat the meat. <b>But</b> this is <b>not</b> so for an offering <b>whose blood was placed below</b> the red line, which is disqualified.
Rami bar Ḥama proves his point: <b>What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it says: If you said that this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood that is placed inside the Sanctuary, concerning <b>which the inner altar does not complete</b> the atonement? What is required to complete the atonement? Is it <b>not</b> referring to <b>this remainder</b> of the blood and is teaching that failure to pour the remainder of the blood on the base of the altar disqualifies the offering?
<b>Rava said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: <b>If so,</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> holds that failure to pour the remainder of the blood of the offerings whose blood is sprinkled inside the Sanctuary disqualifies the offering, you could <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that if the priest sprinkled the blood below the red line the offering is disqualified <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
<b>Just as</b> it is with regard to <b>the remainder</b> of the blood of the offerings <b>of the inner</b> altar, concerning <b>which their ultimate</b> rite, pouring on the base of the altar, is <b>obligatory on the external</b> altar, but if the priest <b>initially performed</b> the rite of placing the blood <b>on the external</b> altar, it does <b>not effect atonement,</b> with regard to those offerings whose blood <b>is placed above</b> the red line, concerning <b>which their ultimate</b> rite, pouring on the base of the altar, is <b>not obligatory below</b> the red line of the altar, <b>and</b> the priest <b>initially performed</b> the rite of placing the blood <b>below</b> the red line, <b>is it not logical that</b> it does <b>not effect atonement?</b> Since the <i>baraita</i> does not advance this claim, but derived the <i>halakha</i> from a verse, this indicates that pouring the remainder of the blood is not obligatory.
Rava continues: <b>Rather,</b> when the <i>baraita</i> states that the blood of the offerings offered inside the Sanctuary are those concerning which the inner altar does not complete the atonement it means that <b>the inner altar does not complete</b> the atonement <b>alone,</b> but <b>rather</b> requires that blood also be sprinkled inside the Sanctuary on the <b>Curtain</b> separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states concerning the sacrificial rite performed by the High Priest on Yom Kippur: <b>“And when he has finished atoning</b> for the Sanctuary, and the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, he shall present the live goat” (Leviticus 16:20). This verse indicates that <b>if he performed</b> the <b>atonement, he has finished</b> the service, <b>but if he did not perform</b> the <b>atonement, he has not finished.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yehuda said to him: For what</b> reason <b>do we not say: If he finished, he has performed atonement,</b> but <b>if he did not finish, he has not performed atonement?</b> This derivation would indicate <b>that if one of any of the</b> blood <b>placements is lacking</b> it is as though <b>he did nothing.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the two opinions: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between them? Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> engaged in a dispute concerning this. <b>One says</b> that <b>interpretation of the meaning</b> of the verse <b>is</b> the difference <b>between them,</b> i.e., there is no halakhic difference between them but only a dispute as to how to interpret the verses. <b>And one says</b> that <b>there is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to whether failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood at the base of the altar <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. According to Rabbi Akiva, it does not disqualify the offering, whereas Rabbi Yehuda maintains that it does disqualify the offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>It may be concluded that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is</b> the one <b>who says</b> that Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yehuda disagree as to whether or not failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the altar <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. <b>As Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood on the base of the altar <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, if the priest finished placing the blood on the inner altar and the blood was spilled before he poured the remainder on the external altar, he must <b>bring one bull</b> and slaughter it, <b>and begin</b> the sprinkling of the blood as he did <b>initially on the inner</b> altar, so that there will be blood remaining from the sprinkling, and then he pours the remainder of the blood on the external altar. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi discusses the opinion that failure to pour the remainder of the blood on the base of the altar disqualifies the offering, apparently in reference to the <i>baraita</i> cited here.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan does not</b> agree with <b>this reasoning? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> himself <b>say</b> (111a): <b>Rabbi Neḥemya taught</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of the one who says</b> that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of blood <b>disqualifies</b> the offering? Rabbi Yoḥanan also discusses the opinion of a <i>tanna</i> who holds that failure to pour the remainder of blood disqualifies the offering, apparently in reference to the <i>baraita</i> cited here.
<b>Rather,</b> there is no proof that Rabbi Yoḥanan is referring to the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yehuda. He is stating a <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of the one who says</b> that it disqualifies the offering, whichever <i>tanna</i> that may be, <b>but</b> he is <b>not</b> referring <b>to</b> the dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>. Here too,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is stating a <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the statement of the one who says</b> that it disqualifies the offering, whichever <i>tanna</i> that may be, <b>but</b> he is <b>not</b> referring <b>to</b> the dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> These are the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the communal and the individual sin offerings. These are the communal sin offerings: Goats of the New Moon and of the Festivals. Their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> the <b>collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north, and their blood requires four placements on the four corners of the altar. How</b> did the priest do so?

Daf 53a

<b>He ascended the ramp</b> of the altar <b>and turned</b> right <b>to the surrounding ledge</b> and he continued east, <b>and he came to the southeast corner</b> and sprinkled the blood of the sin offering there and then to the <b>northeast</b> corner and sprinkled the blood there, and then to the <b>northwest</b> corner and sprinkled the blood there, and the <b>southwest</b> corner, where he performed the fourth sprinkling and descended from the altar. <b>He would pour the remainder of the blood on the southern base</b> of the altar. <b>And</b> the meat portions of the offering <b>are eaten within the curtains,</b> i.e., in the Temple courtyard, <b>by the males of the priesthood.</b> And they are eaten prepared <b>in any</b> form of <b>food</b> preparation, <b>on</b> the <b>day</b> the offering is sacrificed <b>and</b> during the <b>night</b> that follows, <b>until midnight.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>How does</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the rite of sprinkling the blood on the corners of the altar? There is a dispute between <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar. One says</b> that the priest <b>places</b> the blood within <b>a cubit on this</b> side <b>or a cubit on that</b> side. He places the blood wherever he wants, provided that it is within one cubit of the corner of the altar. <b>And one says</b> that <b>he sprinkles</b> the blood <b>on the</b> outer <b>edge of</b> the <b>corner</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> it flows <b>down</b> on both sides of the altar.
The Gemara comments: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that the sprinkling of the blood of a sin offering <b>itself is performed only on the actual corner,</b> the one-by-one-cubit projection above each corner of the altar, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the blood may be sprinkled anywhere on the corner, and this will be a fulfillment of the verse: “And put it upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:25). <b>When they disagree</b> is only <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the blood may be sprinkled anywhere above the red line on the edge of the altar. One <b>Sage holds</b> that the blood may be sprinkled on the cubit on either side of the edge, because <b>a cubit on this</b> side <b>and a cubit on that</b> side <b>is</b> still considered to be <b>on</b> the <b>corner. And</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>on its edge, yes,</b> it is fit, but any <b>further</b> on either side is <b>not.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion that one cubit on either side of the edge is still considered on the edge, from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>communal sin offerings and individual</b> sin offerings, <b>how</b> is <b>the placement of their blood</b> on the altar performed? The priest <b>would ascend the ramp</b> of the altar <b>and turn</b> right <b>to the surrounding ledge</b> and he continued east, <b>and</b> he would <b>come to</b> the <b>southeast corner. And</b> he would then <b>dip with his right [<i>haymanit</i>] finger, the</b> most <b>dexterous [<i>hamyumenet</i>] of the right</b> hand, i.e., the index finger, <b>of the blood that is in the bowl, and</b> would <b>gather</b> the blood <b>with his thumb above and his smallest finger below,</b> so that it would remain on his finger. <b>And</b> he would <b>sprinkle</b> the blood <b>and</b> move his hand <b>down on the</b> outer <b>edge of</b> the <b>corner, until</b> he would <b>finish</b> sprinkling <b>all the blood that</b> was <b>on</b> his <b>finger. And</b> he would act <b>similarly</b> at <b>each and every corner.</b> This <i>baraita</i> states explicitly that the blood must be sprinkled on the actual edge.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> The optimal manner to perform the <b>mitzva</b> is to sprinkle the blood <b>on the edge of</b> the corner. But <b>if he did</b> the sprinkling on the <b>cubit on this</b> side, <b>or</b> the <b>cubit on that</b> side, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> and he has still fulfilled the mitzva.
The Gemara discusses the aforementioned dispute. <b>What</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and what</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon?</b> This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:11): The <b>blood</b> that must be placed on <b>the upper</b> half of the altar, e.g., the blood of a sin offering, <b>is placed</b> anywhere <b>from the red line</b> that circumscribed the middle of the altar <b>and above.</b> The <b>blood</b> that must be placed on <b>the lower</b> half of the altar <b>is placed</b> anywhere <b>from the red line or below it.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon says: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to a bird burnt offering,</b> as its blood may be placed anywhere above the red line. <b>But with regard to an animal sin offering,</b> the placement <b>itself may be performed only on the actual corner</b> of the altar. This is based on the verse that states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, and put it upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:25).
<b>Rabbi Abbahu says: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>As it is written: “And the altar shall be four cubits; and from the altar and above</b> there shall be four corners” (Ezekiel 43:15). The Gemara asks: <b>Was</b> the altar only <b>four cubits</b> wide? <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: And</b> the total <b>area</b> of the four <b>corners,</b> which were each one square cubit, was <b>four</b> cubits. The Gemara asks: <b>Was the area of</b> the <b>corners four</b> square cubits? If the four corners would be placed together the area would be only two square cubits. <b>Rather, say</b> that the <b>domain</b> of the <b>corners</b> is <b>four</b> cubits. In other words, the verse means that the blood may be sprinkled up to four cubits beneath the actual corners of the altar.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Middot</i> 35b): <b>A red line circumscribed</b> the altar <b>in the middle, to separate between</b> the area for the <b>blood</b> that must be placed on <b>the upper</b> part of the altar <b>and</b> the area for the <b>blood</b> that must be placed on <b>the lower</b> part of the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Ketina said</b> it is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated:</b> “And you shall put it under the ledge round the altar beneath, <b>and the net will reach halfway up the altar”</b> (Exodus 27:5). <b>The Torah provided</b> for <b>a separation</b> on the altar, <b>to separate between</b> the area for the <b>blood</b> placed on <b>the upper</b> part of the altar <b>and</b> the area for the <b>blood</b> placed on <b>the lower</b> part of the altar.
§ The mishna teaches: He would pour <b>the remainder of the blood</b> on the southern base of the altar. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Concerning the phrase: <b>“At the base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 4:30), mentioned with regard to pouring the remainder of the blood of the sin offering of a king, <b>this</b> is referring to the <b>southern base</b> of the altar. The <i>baraita</i> challenges: <b>Do you say</b> that <b>this</b> is referring to the <b>southern base, or is it</b> referring <b>only</b> to the <b>western base?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> suggests: <b>And</b> one can <b>derive</b> the meaning of this <b>unspecified</b> phrase <b>from</b> the meaning of <b>the explicit</b> phrase, as follows: <b>You said</b> that one can <b>derive</b> the location of the priest’s <b>descent from the ramp</b> of the external altar after sprinkling blood of the sin offering by comparing it <b>to his exit from the Sanctuary</b> with the blood that remained after having sprinkled blood inside the Sanctuary. The verse states with regard to the bull offering of the High Priest: “And all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7). <b>Just as</b> upon <b>his exit from the Sanctuary</b> the priest pours the remainder of the blood <b>on</b> the side <b>closest to him,</b> the western side, <b>so too,</b> upon <b>his descent from the ramp</b> of the external altar after sprinkling blood from the sin offering, he pours the blood <b>on</b> the side <b>closest to him,</b> which is the southern side.
<b>It is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: This and that,</b> both the remainder of the blood sprinkled inside the Sanctuary and the remainder of the blood sprinkled on the external altar, are poured on the <b>western base</b> of the altar. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: This and that</b> are poured on the <b>southern base</b> of the altar.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the blood is poured on the <b>western base</b> of the altar, it is clear how he derived his <i>halakha</i>. He <b>holds</b> that one can <b>derive</b> the meaning of <b>an unspecified</b> phrase <b>from</b> the meaning of <b>the explicit</b> phrase. Therefore, just as the remainder of the blood sprinkled inside the Sanctuary is poured on the western base of the external altar, the same is done with the remainder of the blood sprinkled on the external altar.
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that the blood is poured on the <b>southern base</b> of the altar, <b>what is the reason? Rabbi Asi said: This <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>the entire</b> external <b>altar stands in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard. Therefore, the southern base is in the center of the courtyard, opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary. This is what the verse is referring to when it states: “At the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 4:7). The Gemara presents <b>another formulation</b> of Rabbi Asi’s explanation: <b>The entire entrance</b> of the Sanctuary <b>stands in the south</b> of the altar. Accordingly, when the priest exits the Sanctuary the southern base is the first one he encounters.

Daf 53b

<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai, says:</b> Both <b>this and that,</b> i.e., the blood of an inner sin offering and that of an external sin offering, were poured at the <b>western base</b> of the altar. According to this version, Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai agrees with the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael. The Gemara comments: <b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember this change in opinion is: <b>The men pulled the man.</b> In this case, the numerous students of Rabbi Yishmael claim that Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai agrees with their teacher.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The burnt offering</b> is <b>an offering of the most sacred order. Its slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and the collection of its blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north, and its blood requires two placements that are four, and</b> it <b>requires flaying</b> of its carcass <b>and the cutting</b> of the sacrificial animal into pieces, <b>and</b> it is consumed <b>in its entirety,</b> with the exception of its hide, <b>by the fire</b> of the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the reason</b> that the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> that <b>a burnt offering</b> is <b>an offering of the most sacred order,</b> when the mishna earlier (52b) did not mention that a sin offering is of the most sacred order? The Gemara answers: It is <b>because</b> in the Torah <b>it is not written</b> explicitly <b>with regard to</b> the burnt offering: <b>It is most sacred,</b> as it states concerning the sin offering and the guilt offering in a verse concerning a meal offering: “It shall not be baked with leaven. I have given it as their portion of My offerings made by fire; it is most sacred, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering” (Leviticus 6:10). Consequently, the <i>tanna</i> explicitly states that a burnt offering is likewise of the most sacred order.
The mishna teaches: <b>And its blood requires two placements</b> that are four. <b>How does</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the placements? <b>Rav says: He places</b> the blood on one side of the corner of the altar, <b>and places</b> it <b>again</b> on the other side of the corner of the altar. He repeats this on the diagonally opposite corner, so that he places on two corners but on all four sides of the altar. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> He <b>places one placement</b> on each of the two diagonally opposite corners, so that each placement is <b>similar to</b> the shape of the Greek letter <b>gamma,</b> which is bent at a right angle.
The Gemara comments: This dispute between Rav and Shmuel is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that a priest <b>should sprinkle one sprinkling</b> with the blood of a burnt offering. To counter this possibility, <b>the verse states:</b> “And sprinkle the blood <b>around</b> against the altar that is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 1:5). <b>If</b> the blood must be sprinkled <b>around</b> the altar, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he should circumscribe</b> the altar <b>as</b> one would do with <b>a thread,</b> and sprinkle the blood all around. To counter this possibility, <b>the verse states:</b> “Shall present the blood, <b>and sprinkle</b> the blood around against the altar” (Leviticus 1:5), and one cannot have the blood circumscribe the altar as a thread would without directly applying it with a finger. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> verses be reconciled? He applies the blood in a shape that is <b>similar to</b> that of the Greek letter <b>gamma, and its blood requires two sprinklings that are four.</b> This opinion accords with the opinion of Shmuel.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: It is stated here:</b> “Shall present the blood, and sprinkle the blood <b>around</b> against the altar” (Leviticus 1:5), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the sin offering sacrificed at the inauguration of the Tabernacle: “And when it was slain, Moses took the blood, and put it upon the corners of the altar <b>around</b> with his finger” (Leviticus 8:15). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the sin offering, the blood was placed <b>discretely and</b> with <b>four placements,</b> one on each corner, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to a burnt offering, it must be placed <b>discretely and</b> with <b>four placements.</b> This opinion accords with the opinion of Rav.
<b>If</b> these offerings are compared to each other, why not say that <b>just as there,</b> the blood of the sin offering must have <b>four placements on</b> the <b>four corners, so too here,</b> the blood of the burnt offering requires <b>four placements on</b> the <b>four corners? You said</b> that <b>a burnt offering requires</b> that the blood be placed on a part of the altar that has <b>a base, and</b> the <b>southeast corner</b> of the altar <b>had no base</b> beneath it. Therefore, the blood had to be placed on the northeast corner and the southwest corner.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that there was no base on the southeast corner of the altar? <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Because it was not in the portion</b> of land <b>of the one who tears,</b> i.e., the tribe of Benjamin, as he is described in the following manner: “Benjamin is a wolf that tears apart; in the morning he devours the prey, and in the evening he divides the spoil” (Genesis 49:27). <b>As Rav Shmuel, son of Rav Yitzḥak, says:</b> The <b>altar</b> would <b>consume,</b> i.e., occupy, <b>one cubit of the portion of Judah.</b> The part of the altar in Judah’s portion was the southeast corner of the base, and therefore there was no base on that corner.
<b>Rabbi Levi bar Ḥama says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: A strip</b> of land <b>emerged from the portion of Judah and entered into the portion of Benjamin,</b> and the southeast corner of the base was on that strip. <b>And</b> the tribe of <b>Benjamin the righteous would agonize over it every day,</b> desiring <b>to take it</b> into its portion, due to its unique sanctity. <b>As it is stated</b> in Moses’ blessing to the tribe of Benjamin:

Daf 54a

<b>“He covers it throughout the day,</b> and He dwells between his shoulders” (Deuteronomy 33:12). The term “covers it” is understood to mean that Benjamin is continually focused upon that site. <b>Therefore, Benjamin the righteous was privileged and became the host of the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> as the Holy of Holies was built in his portion. <b>As it is stated: “And He dwells between his shoulders.”</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How</b> was the rite of <b>a bird burnt offering performed?</b> The priest ascended the ramp and turned to the surrounding ledge. When he arrived at the southeast corner, the priest <b>would pinch</b> the bird’s <b>head</b> by pinching <b>at</b> its <b>nape</b> with his thumbnail <b>and sever</b> the bird’s head from its body, <b>and</b> would <b>squeeze out its blood on the wall of the altar.</b>
The Gemara states its objection: <b>And if you say</b> that the southeast corner of the altar <b>had no base, is he merely performing</b> the rite <b>in the air,</b> i.e., not within the domain of the altar? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Say</b> that when Eretz Yisrael was apportioned, they <b>made this condition: The airspace</b> of what would become the southeast part of the altar is in the portion of the tribe <b>of Benjamin,</b> so the pinching of the bird offering was performed within the domain of the altar. But the <b>land</b> was in the portion of the tribe <b>of Judah.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it states that the southeast corner of the altar <b>had no base? Rav says:</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the fact that it had no base <b>built</b> on those sides. <b>Levi says:</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the fact that no <b>blood</b> was sprinkled on that side, as the blood was not permitted to be presented there, even though there was a physical base. Based on this dispute, each of them disagreed as to the correct Aramaic translation of the verse: “Benjamin is a wolf that tears apart; in the morning he devours the prey, and in the evening he divides the spoil” (Genesis 49:27). <b>Rav translates</b> this as: <b>In his portion will the altar be built. Levi translates</b> this as: <b>In his portion will the Sanctuary be built,</b> which means: <b>A place sanctified for blood.</b>
The Gemara brings proof for each opinion: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof for the explanation of Rav from a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 35b): <b>The base</b> of the altar <b>would extend along all of the northern</b> side <b>and along all of the western</b> side. It <b>consumed one cubit on the southern</b> side <b>and one cubit on the eastern</b> side. This indicates that there was no base on most of the southern or eastern sides of the altar. The Gemara comments: Levi would explain: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Consume?</b> The <i>baraita</i>, <b>as well,</b> is stated <b>with regard to</b> consuming <b>blood</b> of the offerings.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof for the explanation of Levi from that same mishna: <b>The altar was thirty-two</b> cubits <b>by thirty-two</b> cubits. This indicates that there was a base on all four sides, in accordance with the opinion of Levi. Rav could answer: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> the measurement <b>from the side.</b> In other words, only the northern and western sides were thirty-two cubits in length.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof for the explanation of Levi from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It turns out</b> the top of the ramp of the altar would <b>overhang</b> one <b>cubit</b> in the air <b>over</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar <b>and</b> one <b>cubit over</b> the <b>surrounding ledge.</b> This indicates that it had a base on all four sides, as the ramp was on the southern side. Rav could answer: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means it would overhang <b>toward</b> the place where the <b>base</b> of a <b>cubit</b> would have been, <b>and</b> one <b>cubit over</b> the <b>surrounding ledge.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as Levi teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one build the altar?</b> He <b>brings a square</b> wooden frame, <b>which is thirty-two</b> cubits <b>by thirty-two</b> cubits, <b>and its height is one cubit. And he brings pieces of damp [<i>mefulamot</i>] stone, both large and small,</b> which are the main components of the altar, which is described as: “An altar of stone” (Exodus 20:22). <b>And he brings plaster and molten lead and tar, and melts</b> them <b>and pours</b> the mixture into the gaps between the stones. <b>And this is the place of</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar.
<b>And then he brings a square</b> wooden frame, <b>which is thirty cubits by thirty cubits, and its height is five cubits. And he brings pieces of</b> damp <b>stone,</b> both large and small. And he brings plaster and molten lead and tar, and melts them and pours the mixture into the gaps between the stones. <b>And then he brings a square</b> wooden frame, <b>which is twenty-eight</b> cubits <b>by twenty-eight cubits, and its height is three cubits. And he brings pieces of</b> damp stone, both large and small. And he brings plaster and molten lead and tar, and melts them and pours the mixture into the gaps between the stones. <b>And this is the place of the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar.
<b>And then he brings a square</b> wooden frame, <b>which is</b> one <b>cubit by</b> one <b>cubit. And he brings pieces of damp stone, both large and small. And he brings plaster and molten lead and tar, and melts</b> them <b>and pours</b> the mixture into the frame. <b>And this is</b> the <b>corner</b> of the altar. <b>And so</b> he does this <b>for each and every corner.</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that the altar had a base around all four sides.
The Gemara comments: <b>And if you would say</b>

Daf 54b

<b>that he cuts</b> the base on the southern and western sides after he has poured the mixture for the altar and it has dried, <b>it is written</b> concerning the altar: “You shall build the altar of the Lord your God of <b>unhewn stones;</b> and you shall offer burnt offerings on it to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 27:6), so it cannot be cut.
Rav could answer: This means <b>that he places something under</b> the frame, in the place where there is to be no base, <b>and</b> after the poured mixture has dried he <b>removes it,</b> leaving the space empty. <b>As if you do not say so,</b> how will you explain <b>that which Rav Kahana says: The stone</b> interiors <b>of the corners were hollow,</b> i.e., there were gaps between the stones, <b>as it is written: “And they shall be filled like the basins, like the corners of the altar”</b> (Zechariah 9:15)? The verse compares the corners to hollow basins. <b>Here too,</b> doesn’t <b>the Merciful One state</b> that the altar must be made of <b>“unhewn stones”?</b> If so, how could the corners be hollow? <b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>that he places something,</b> e.g., sticks and twigs, <b>under</b> the frame and pours the mixture for the corners over it, <b>and</b> when it has hardened, <b>removes</b> the sticks and twigs, leaving the corners somewhat hollow. <b>Here too, he places something under</b> the frame <b>and</b> later <b>removes it.</b>
§ Apropos the altar and the Temple, the Gemara relates that <b>Rava taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> concerning David: <b>“And he and Samuel went and dwelt in Naioth.</b> And it was told Saul, saying: Behold, David is at Naioth [<i>beNayot</i>] <b>in Ramah”</b> (I Samuel 19:18–19)? <b>But what does Naioth have to do with Ramah?</b> They are in two distinct places. <b>Rather,</b> this means <b>that they were sitting in Ramah and</b> were <b>involved in</b> discussing <b>the beauty [<i>benoyo</i>] of the world,</b> i.e., the Temple.
David and Samuel <b>said: It is written: “Then you shall arise, and get you up unto the place</b> which the Lord your God shall choose” (Deuteronomy 17:8). This <b>teaches that the Temple is higher than all</b> places in <b>Eretz Yisrael. And Eretz Yisrael is higher than all countries. They did not know where</b> the highest <b>place</b> in Eretz Yisrael was.
<b>They brought the book of Joshua. With regard to all of</b> the borders of the tribes <b>it is written: “And went down”</b> (see Joshua 15:10, 16:3, 17:9), and it is written: <b>“And the border went up</b> to Beth Hoglah.” (Joshua 15:6), and: <b>“And the border was drawn</b> from the top of the mountain to the fountain of the waters of Nephtoah” (Joshua 15:9). The verse uses different terms to describe the borders of the portion of each tribe. And <b>with regard to</b> the borders of <b>the tribe of Benjamin it is written</b> only: <b>“And went up”</b> (Joshua 18:11), but it <b>is not written: “And went down.” They said: Conclude from</b> the verses that the Temple’s <b>place is here,</b> in the portion of Benjamin.
<b>They thought to build it at Ein Eitam, which is higher</b> than any other place in the portion of Benjamin. <b>They said: Let us lower it a bit, as it is written:</b> “He covers it throughout the day, <b>and He dwells between his shoulders”</b> (Deuteronomy 33:12). This indicates that the Temple is situated slightly lower, between two peaks.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>it is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that</b> the <b>Sanhedrin</b> is to be located <b>in the portion of Judah, and</b> the place of the <b>Divine Presence is</b> to be located <b>in the portion of Benjamin.</b> They said: <b>And if we raise it</b> and place it near Ein Eitam <b>it</b> will be <b>too distant</b> from the portion of Judah. They said: It is <b>preferable that we lower it a bit, as it is written:</b> “He covers it throughout the day, <b>and He dwells between his shoulders”</b> (Deuteronomy 33:12).
<b>And with regard to this matter,</b> that David and Samuel discovered the location of the Temple, <b>Doeg the Edomite was jealous of David, as it is written: “Because jealousy for Your House has eaten me up”</b> (Psalms 69:10), <b>and it is written: “Lord, remember for David all his affliction; how he swore to the Lord,</b> and vowed unto the Mighty One of Jacob: <b>I will not come into the tent of my house,</b> nor go up into the bed that is spread for me; <b>if I will give sleep to my eyes, or slumber to my eyelids; until I find a place for the Lord,</b> a dwelling place for the Mighty One of Jacob” (Psalms 132:1–5).
The verse following those verses states: <b>“We heard of it as being in Ephrath; we found it in the field of the wood”</b> (Psalms 132:6). Rava explains the meaning of these words: <b>“In Ephrath”; this</b> is a reference to <b>Joshua, who came from</b> the tribe of <b>Ephraim.</b> This alludes to the fact that David and Samuel were able to locate the highest place in Eretz Yisrael based on the book of Joshua. <b>“We found it in the field of the wood”; this</b> is a reference to <b>Benjamin, as it is written</b> concerning him: <b>“Benjamin is a wolf that tears apart;</b> in the morning he devours the prey, and in the evening he divides the spoil” (Genesis 49:27). A wolf is a wild animal living in the field, and David and Samuel found the location of the Temple in the portion of Benjamin.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> These are the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>communal peace offerings and guilt offerings. These are guilt offerings: The guilt offering for robbery,</b> brought by one from whom another demanded payment of a debt and he denied it and took a false oath (see Leviticus 5:20–26); <b>the guilt offering for</b> unwitting <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property (see Leviticus 5:14–16); <b>the guilt offering of an espoused maidservant,</b> brought by one who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant betrothed to a Hebrew slave (see Leviticus 19:20–22); <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> who became impure via contact with a corpse (see Numbers 6:12); <b>the guilt offering of a leper,</b> brought for his purification (see Leviticus 14:12); and <b>the provisional guilt offering,</b> brought by one who is uncertain as to whether he committed a sin that requires a sin offering (see Leviticus 5:17–18).
Concerning all of these, <b>their slaughter</b> is <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and collection of their blood in a service vessel</b> is <b>in the north, and their blood requires two placements that are four. And</b> the meat portions of the offering <b>are eaten within the curtains,</b> i.e., in the Temple courtyard, <b>by male priests.</b> And they are eaten prepared <b>in any</b> manner of <b>food</b> preparation, <b>on</b> the <b>day</b> the offering was sacrificed <b>and</b> during the <b>night</b> that follows, <b>until midnight.</b>

Daf 55a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> the communal peace offerings, i.e., the two sheep brought on <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>require</b> slaughter in the <b>north</b> of the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers: <b>As Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan taught before Rava:</b> The passage in the Torah discussing the offerings of <i>Shavuot</i> states: <b>“And you shall offer one he-goat for a sin offering,</b> and two male sheep in their first year for a sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 23:19). The peace offerings are juxtaposed with the sin offering. <b>Just as</b> the <b>sin offering</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>so too, communal peace offerings</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard.
<b>Rava said to him: But from where</b> is the requirement to slaughter <b>a sin offering</b> in the north of the Temple courtyard <b>derived?</b> It is derived <b>from</b> its juxtaposition with <b>a burnt offering,</b> as the verse states: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying: This is the law of the sin offering: In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered shall the sin offering be slaughtered before the Lord; it is most holy” (Leviticus 6:18). In the realm of consecrated matters, can <b>a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition?</b> The Gemara (49b) demonstrates that it cannot.
Rava explains: <b>Rather,</b> the source that communal peace offerings must be slaughtered in the north of the Temple courtyard is derived <b>from</b> that <b>which Rav Mari, son of Rav Kahana, teaches:</b> The verse states: “Also in the day of your gladness, and in your appointed seasons, and in your New Moons, you shall blow with the trumpets <b>over your burnt offerings, and over your peace offerings;</b> and they shall be to you for a memorial before your God: I am the Lord your God” (Numbers 10:10). This verse directly juxtaposes burnt offerings with communal peace offerings. <b>Just as burnt offerings</b> are <b>offerings of the most sacred order, so too, communal peace offerings</b> are <b>offerings of the most sacred order.</b> Furthermore, <b>just as a burnt offering</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>so too, communal peace offerings</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> <i>halakha</i> does <b>the first juxtaposition</b> between communal peace offerings and the he-goat sin offering <b>come to</b> teach? The Gemara answers: It teaches that the <i>halakhot</i> of communal peace offerings are <b>like</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a sin offering. Just as a sin offering is eaten only by male priests, so too, communal peace offerings</b> are eaten only <b>by male priests.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>If so,</b> then <b>with regard to a nazirite’s ram,</b> concerning <b>which it is written</b> in the verse: <b>“And he shall present his offering to the Lord, one he-lamb in its first year without blemish for a burnt offering, and one ewe-lamb in its first year without blemish for a sin offering, and one ram without blemish for a peace offering”</b> (Numbers 6:14), <b>so too shall we say that the Torah juxtaposed</b> the nazirite’s ram <b>with a sin offering</b> of a nazirite to teach that <b>just as a sin offering is eaten only by male priests, so too, a nazirite’s ram is eaten only by male priests?</b> As the next mishna states, a nazirite’s ram may be eaten by every ritually pure Jew.
Rava answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to the nazirite’s ram, <b>since it is written: “And the priest shall take the foreleg of the ram when it is cooked”</b> (Numbers 6:19), <b>by inference</b> one can deduce <b>that the owner may eat all of</b> the remaining portions of the animal.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>in any event,</b> the <b>cooked foreleg</b> of the nazirite’s ram <b>should be eaten only by male priests.</b> The mishna states that the cooked foreleg may be eaten by priests, their wives, and their slaves. The Gemara concedes: This is <b>difficult.</b> Based on its juxtaposition with the sin offering of a nazirite, the <i>halakha</i> should be that only the male priests may eat it, yet that is not the case.
The Gemara offers another explanation: <b>And if you wish, say</b> that the foreleg of the nazirite’s ram <b>is called sacred, but it is not called an offering of the most sacred order.</b> Therefore, it cannot be juxtaposed with the sin offering of a nazirite in this regard. The Gemara asks: <b>But rather, with regard to what <i>halakha</i> is</b> the nazirite’s ram <b>juxtaposed</b> with the sin offering of a nazirite? <b>Rava says:</b> It is juxtaposed to teach <b>that if</b> the nazirite <b>shaved after</b> the sacrifice of any <b>one of the three</b> offerings, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation after the fact.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The thanks offering and nazirite’s ram</b> are <b>offerings of lesser sanctity. Their slaughter</b> is <b>anywhere in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, and their blood requires two placements that are four, and they are eaten throughout the city</b> of Jerusalem, <b>by every person,</b> i.e., any ritually pure Jew, prepared <b>in any</b> manner of <b>food</b> preparation, <b>on</b> the <b>day</b> the offering was sacrificed <b>and</b> during the <b>night</b> that follows, <b>until midnight.</b> The status of the portion <b>that is separated from them</b> and given to the priests <b>is similar to theirs; but</b> the portion <b>that is separated is eaten by the priests, by their wives, and by their children, and by their slaves.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the priests: <b>“And the breast of waving and the thigh of heaving you shall eat in a pure place;</b> you, and your sons, and your daughters with you; for they are given as your due, and your sons’ due, out of the peace offerings of the children of Israel” (Leviticus 10:14). <b>Rabbi Neḥemya said: But did they eat</b> the <b>first</b> offerings, mentioned in the previous two verses, <b>in</b> a place of <b>impurity?</b> The previous verses make reference to the remainder of the meal offering, which also had to be eaten in a pure place.
<b>Rather, by inference,</b> the word <b>“pure”</b> in this context is referring to a place <b>that is</b> to some degree <b>ritually impure,</b> but pure in some respects. The priest must eat in a place that is <b>pure due to the impurity of a leper, but</b> it may be a place that is <b>impure due to the impurity of a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>]. And which</b> place <b>is this? This</b> is <b>the Israelites’ camp</b> in the wilderness, and, once the Temple was built in Jerusalem, the entire city of Jerusalem. A <i>zav</i> could remain in these places, but not a leper. This is the source for the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna that these offerings may be eaten anywhere in Jerusalem.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that the word “pure” is referring to a place which is <b>pure from the impurity of a <i>zav</i> and impure due to ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse? And which</b> place <b>is this? This</b> is <b>the Levites’ camp</b> in the wilderness, and, once the Temple was built in Jerusalem, the Temple Mount.
<b>Abaye says</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the meal offering: <b>“And you shall eat it in a sacred place”</b> (Leviticus 10:13). The word “it” is a restriction, teaching that one must eat <b>“it,”</b> i.e., the meal offering, <b>in a sacred place,</b> i.e., in the camp of the Divine Presence, <b>but</b> one is <b>not</b> required to eat <b>another</b> offering, i.e., the breast of waving and the thigh of heaving, <b>in a sacred place.</b> This <b>removes</b> the portions from the camp of the Divine Presence, <b>to</b> be eaten in <b>the Levites’ camp. Then it is written:</b> “You shall eat <b>in a pure place,”</b> which <b>removes</b> the portions from the Levites’ camp, <b>to</b> be eaten in <b>the Israelites’ camp.</b>
<b>Rava says</b> a different explanation: <b>“It,”</b> i.e., the meal offering, must be eaten <b>in a sacred place, but</b> one is <b>not</b> required to eat <b>another</b> offering, i.e., the breast of waving and the thigh of heaving, <b>in a sacred place.</b> This verse <b>removes</b> the portions <b>completely</b> from any pure place, and according to this stage of Rava’s interpretation, these portions may be eaten anywhere. <b>Then the Merciful One wrote: “You shall eat in a pure place,”</b> which <b>brings it into the Israelites’ camp,</b> which is a pure place, relative to everywhere outside it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that the verse <b>brings it into the Levites’ camp,</b> which is also referred to as pure? The Gemara answers: <b>We bring it into one</b> camp, adjacent to the area outside the encampment of the Jewish people, but <b>we do not bring it into two</b> camps.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, also</b> with regard to <b>removing it,</b> why not say that <b>we remove it to one</b> place, but <b>we do not remove it from two</b> places? Accordingly, the initial derivation should be to eat it in the Israelites’ camp. <b>And furthermore, it is written: “You may not eat within your gates</b> the tithe of your grain, or of your wine, or of your oil, or the firstborn of your herd or of your flock, nor any of your vows which you vow, nor your gift offerings, nor the offering of your hand” (Deuteronomy 12:17). This verse negates the possibility that an offering may be eaten “in your gates,” i.e., outside of Jerusalem. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that the source for the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>of Abaye.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Peace offerings</b> are <b>offerings of lesser sanctity. Their slaughter</b> is <b>anywhere in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, and their blood requires two placements that are four, and they are eaten throughout the city</b> of Jerusalem, <b>by every person,</b> i.e., any ritually pure Jew, prepared <b>in any</b> manner of <b>food</b> preparation, <b>for two days and one night,</b> i.e., the day on which they are slaughtered, the following day, and the intervening night. The status of the portion <b>that is separated from them</b> and given to the priests <b>is similar to theirs; but</b> the portion <b>that is separated is eaten by the priests, by their wives, and by their children, and by their slaves.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to cattle peace offerings, the verse states: “And he shall lay his hand upon the head of his offering, <b>and slaughter it at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2). With regard to sheep peace offerings the verse states: “And he shall lay his hand upon the head of his offering, <b>and slaughter it before the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:8). With regard to goat peace offerings the verse states: “And he shall lay his hand upon the head of it, <b>and slaughter it before the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:13).
This repetition serves <b>to render fit all directions</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>for</b> the slaughter of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> From here one can derive <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>to</b> permit slaughter in <b>the north</b> of the Temple courtyard: <b>Just as</b> the rites of slaughtering <b>offerings of the most sacred order, which are not rendered fit in all directions, are rendered fit in the north,</b> with regard to the rites of slaughtering <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, which are rendered fit in all directions, is it not logical that they are rendered fit in the north?</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The repetition of <b>the verse is stated only to render fit</b> slaughter in the <b>north. As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: <b>And could this not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference? Just as</b> with regard to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, whose</b> slaughter is <b>rendered fit in any direction,</b> nevertheless <b>their place is not rendered fit for</b> the slaughter of <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, whose</b> slaughter is <b>rendered fit only in the north, is it not logical that their place should not be rendered fit for</b> the slaughter of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Tent of Meeting,”</b> to teach that offerings of lesser sanctity may be slaughtered in the north.

Daf 55b

The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>three verses are written. One</b> verse serves <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>itself, that we require</b> that the slaughter take place at the <b>entrance of the Tent of Meeting. And one</b> verse serves <b>to render fit</b> slaughter at the <b>sides,</b> i.e., the entire length of the Temple courtyard eastward from the entrance, and not only that part which is directly in front of the entrance. <b>And one</b> verse serves <b>to disqualify the sides of the sides,</b> i.e., those parts of the courtyard that are not in front of the entrance at all. <b>And it was not necessary</b> to have <b>a verse</b> teach the fitness of slaughtering in the <b>north,</b> as it can be derived via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>one</b> verse is necessary <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>itself, that we require</b> slaughter at the <b>entrance of the Tent of Meeting. And one</b> verse serves <b>to render fit</b> slaughter in the <b>north</b> of the courtyard. <b>And one</b> verse serves <b>to render fit</b> slaughter at the <b>sides</b> of the courtyard. <b>But</b> according to him, <b>it was not necessary</b> to have <b>a verse</b> teach that the <b>sides of the sides</b> are not fit for the slaughter of the offering.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is different here that it is written: “At the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), <b>and what is different there that it is written: “Before the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:8, 13)? The Gemara answers: This <b>teaches us</b> a matter <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Shmuel says. As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Peace offerings that one slaughtered</b> in the Temple <b>before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened are disqualified, as it is stated</b> with regard to peace offerings: <b>“And he shall slaughter it at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), which teaches that it must be slaughtered <b>when</b> the entrance <b>is open</b> and serves as an actual entrance, <b>and not when it is locked.</b> As long as the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, or in the Temple the doors to the Sanctuary, remain closed, one may not sacrifice the peace offerings, and if they are sacrificed, they are disqualified.
<b>It was also stated: Mar Ukva bar Ḥama says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: Peace offerings that one slaughtered before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened are disqualified, as it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“He shall slaughter it at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2). This means <b>when the entrance of the Sanctuary is open, and not when it is locked.</b>
<b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>like this: Rav Ya’akov bar Aḥa says</b> that <b>Rav Ashi says: Peace offerings that one slaughtered before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened are disqualified. And in the Tabernacle,</b> which had no doors, peace offerings that were slaughtered <b>before</b> the <b>Levites erected the Tabernacle or after</b> the <b>Levites dismantled the Tabernacle are disqualified.</b>
The Gemara comments: It is <b>obvious</b> that if the door is <b>closed</b> but not locked it has the same status <b>as if it were locked.</b> The Gemara asks: If there is <b>a curtain</b> covering the entrance, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> A curtain <b>itself is made only</b> to be used <b>like an open entrance,</b> and therefore it is not considered as if the entrance is closed.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if <b>a tall</b> item is blocking the entrance? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof that a tall item does not render an entrance as closed, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: There were two wickets,</b> i.e., openings, <b>in the Chamber of Knives, and their height</b> was <b>eight</b> cubits. The function of these openings was <b>in order to render fit the entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard for the eating of offerings of the most sacred order, and</b> to render fit all of the Temple courtyard <b>for the slaughter of offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> Due to the openings, the western area of the courtyard was considered to be “before the Tent of Meeting.”
The Gemara explains the inference: <b>What, is</b> the reference to eight cubits <b>not</b> referring to the fact <b>that in front of</b> the wickets there was an obstruction <b>eight</b> cubits high? Nevertheless, the area outside of it is considered open to the Chamber of Knives. The Gemara answers: <b>No, their height</b> was <b>eight</b> cubits, i.e., the wickets themselves were eight cubits high.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this explanation from a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 35a), which teaches: <b>All the gates that were there,</b> in the Temple, were <b>twenty cubits high and ten cubits wide.</b> If so, how could these wickets be only eight cubits high? The Gemara answers: The <b>wickets are different,</b> and they are not considered gates.
The Gemara questions the ruling of the <i>baraita</i>. How did the wickets render fit the entire Temple courtyard? <b>But there are</b> the <b>sides,</b> i.e., to the north and south of the Chamber of Knives, and the wickets faced only to the west. The Gemara answers <b>that they inserted</b> the wickets <b>in</b> the <b>corner</b> of the Chamber, so that one opened to the northwest, and one to the northeast.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the area <b>behind the Hall of the Ark Cover,</b> i.e., behind the Sanctuary, from where one could not see the entrance of the Temple courtyard or the two wickets?
