The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rami bar Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: There was a small niche behind the Hall of the Ark Cover,</b> which was <b>eight cubits high.</b> The function of this niche was <b>in order to render fit the entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard for the eating of offerings of the most sacred order, and</b> to render fit all of the Temple courtyard <b>for the slaughter of offerings of lesser sanctity. And this is as it is written:</b> “For the precinct westward, four at the causeway, and <b>two at the precinct”</b> (I Chronicles 26:18). <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>“For the precinct [<i>laparbar</i>]”? Rabba bar Rav Sheila said:</b> It is <b>like one who says: Facing outward [<i>kelappei bar</i>].</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> One is <b>liable for</b> entering the Temple courtyard in a state of <b>ritual impurity only with regard to</b>

Daf 56a

an area whose <b>length</b> is <b>187</b> cubits <b>by 135</b> cubits in <b>width.</b>
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman: The entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard was 187</b> cubits in length <b>by 135</b> cubits in <b>width.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> the <i>tanna</i>: <b>My father said this to me:</b> In an area <b>such as this,</b> the <b>priests enter there and eat offerings of the most sacred order there, and slaughter offerings of lesser sanctity there, and are liable due to</b> entering in a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: These specific dimensions serve <b>to exclude what? If we say</b> they are stated <b>to exclude</b> the <b>windows, doors, and thickness of the wall, we learn</b> the opposite in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 85b): <b>The windows</b> in the wall <b>and the thickness of the wall</b> are considered <b>as though</b> they are <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard.
<b>But rather,</b> they are stated <b>to exclude</b> the <b>chambers</b> in the Temple courtyard. The Gemara asks: <b>And if</b> it is referring to chambers that are <b>built in the non-sacred</b> area, which is outside this designated space, <b>and open to the sacred</b> area, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 3:8): The inside of chambers that are built in the sacred area but are open to the non-sacred area is non-sacred, but their roofs are sacred. If they are built in a non-sacred area and open to a sacred area, <b>their interior</b> is <b>sacred</b> and their roofs are non-sacred? The Gemara answers: They have sanctity <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> do they <b>not</b> have sanctity <b>by Torah law? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b>chambers</b> that are <b>built in the non-sacred</b> area of the Temple Mount <b>and open to the sacred</b> area, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that the priests enter there and eat there offerings of the most sacred order and the remainders of meal offerings? The verse states</b> with regard to a meal offering: “It shall be eaten without leaven in a holy place; <b>in the courtyard of the Tent of Meeting they shall eat it.”</b> (Leviticus 6:9). The verse could have simply stated: “In a holy place,” which indicates the courtyard. By also stating: “In the courtyard of the Tent of Meeting,” <b>the Torah amplified many courtyards with one</b> type of <b>eating,</b> i.e., of the meal offering. If the chambers do not have sanctity by Torah law, the Sages would not have permitted the priests to eat offerings of the most sacred order there.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> <b>concerning eating</b> is <b>different.</b> The Torah specifically includes these chambers in addition to the Temple courtyard itself for eating offerings of the most sacred order. By contrast, with regard to slaughtering offerings of lesser sanctity and the punishment for entering the courtyard in a state of ritual impurity, these chambers are not considered sacred by Torah law.
The Gemara asks: <b>But with regard to ritual impurity,</b> is one <b>not</b> liable to receive <i>karet</i> for entering these chambers? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <b>chambers that are built in the non-sacred</b> area <b>and</b> that <b>open to the sacred</b> area, <b>priests enter there and eat offerings of the most sacred order there, but may not slaughter offerings of lesser sanctity there, and are liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to ritual impurity</b> if they enter there while ritually impure?
Rava could answer: <b>Did you not say</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>they may not slaughter</b> offerings of lesser sanctity in those chambers? If so, emend the text of the <i>baraita</i> and <b>teach also: They are not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> for entering in a state of ritual impurity.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Granted,</b> the priests <b>may not slaughter</b> there, because slaughtering an offering <b>requires</b> that it be performed <b>before the entrance</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> if he slaughters it inside a chamber, it <b>is not. But why</b> would they <b>not</b> be <b>liable</b> for entering there in a state of ritual impurity?
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> when it teaches that they <b>may not slaughter</b> there, <b>are we not dealing</b> even with a case in <b>which there is</b> an act of <b>slaughter</b> performed <b>before the entrance,</b> i.e., the entrance to the chamber directly faced the entrance of the Temple? <b>As if not, for what</b> purpose <b>was</b> it <b>necessary</b> to teach this at all? <b>Rather, even though he slaughters</b> the offering <b>before the entrance,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that a priest <b>may not slaughter</b> offerings in the chambers <b>because</b> that area <b>is not sacred.</b> If so, <b>teach also</b> that they <b>are not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> for entering the chambers in a state of ritual impurity, as they are not sacred.
The Gemara asks: <b>And for eating</b> an offering, <b>do we not require</b> that this take place <b>before the entrance</b> of the Temple courtyard? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: There were two wickets in the Chamber of Knives,</b> and <b>their height</b> was <b>eight</b> cubits; the function of these openings was <b>in order to render fit the</b> entire Temple <b>courtyard for the eating of offerings of the most sacred order, and</b> to render fit all of the Temple courtyard <b>for the slaughter of offerings of lesser sanctity? Ravina said: Remove from here</b> the clause concerning <b>eating.</b> The eating of offerings does not have to take place before the entrance of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to the offerings brought at the inauguration of the Tabernacle: “And Moses said to Aaron and to his sons: <b>Cook the meat at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting; and eat it there”</b> (Leviticus 8:31). This indicates that the eating of offerings had to be at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting. The Gemara answers: <b>Offerings</b> that were sacrificed only one <b>time are different.</b> Since they were specifically commanded for just that time, one cannot derive from there any <i>halakhot</i> with regard to offerings in general.
§ <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the blood</b> of offerings <b>becomes disqualified at sunset</b> and can no longer be presented on the altar? This is <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse: “But if the sacrifice of his offering be a vow, or a gift offering, <b>it shall be eaten on the day that he sacrifices his offering [<i>zivḥo</i>],</b> and on the morrow” (Leviticus 7:16). This means that <b>on the day that you slaughter [<i>zove’aḥ</i>]</b> the offering <b>you sacrifice</b> it on the altar and present its blood. But <b>on the day that you do not slaughter</b> the offering <b>you may not sacrifice</b> it and present its blood.
The Gemara challenges: But <b>he requires this</b> verse

Daf 56b

<b>for</b> the matter <b>itself,</b> to teach that a peace offering may be eaten for only two days? The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse state: On the day he slaughters it shall it be eaten,</b> and the following day. <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to add the term <b>“that he sacrifices it”? Conclude from</b> the wording of the verse that <b>on the day that you slaughter</b> the offering <b>you sacrifice</b> the blood on the altar, but <b>on a day that you do not slaughter</b> the offering <b>you do not sacrifice</b> the blood on the altar.
The Gemara questions this proof: <b>But perhaps this</b> is what <b>the Merciful One is saying: If</b> the <b>blood is sacrificed today,</b> i.e., the day the offering was slaughtered, the <b>meat</b> may <b>be eaten today and tomorrow. If</b> the <b>blood is sacrificed tomorrow,</b> the <b>meat may be eaten tomorrow and the following day.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse state: On the day it is sacrificed it shall be eaten,</b> and the following day. <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to state: “That he sacrifices <b>his offering”? Conclude from</b> the wording of the verse that <b>on the day that you slaughter</b> the offering <b>you sacrifice</b> the blood on the altar, but <b>on a day that you do not slaughter</b> the offering <b>you do not sacrifice</b> the blood on the altar.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who</b> slaughters a peace offer-ing and <b>intends</b> to eat it <b>on the evening</b> preceding the <b>third</b> day, <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> The offering is <b>valid,</b> and it is not disqualified due to his intention to eat it after its designated time [<i>piggul</i>]. And <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Ḥizkiyya says</b> that the offering is <b>valid because</b> on the evening preceding the third day, the peace offering has <b>not</b> yet <b>been removed</b> from its previous status and designated <b>for burning.</b> A peace offering is not burned until the third morning, as the verse states: “It shall be eaten the same day you offer it, and on the following day; and if anything remain until the third day, it shall be burned with fire” (Leviticus 19:6). <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> it is <b>disqualified, because it has been rejected from</b> being <b>eaten.</b>
These two <i>amora’im</i> have the same dispute concerning a similar matter: With regard to <b>one who eats</b> a peace offering <b>on the evening</b> preceding the <b>third</b> day, <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> He is <b>exempt</b> from <i>karet</i>, <b>because</b> the offering has <b>not</b> yet <b>been removed</b> from its previous status and designated <b>for burning.</b> And <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>, <b>because it has been rejected from</b> being <b>eaten.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that may be eaten for one day,</b> if one <b>intends to</b> present <b>their blood after sunset, or</b> if one intends <b>to</b> eat <b>their meat or to</b> sacrifice <b>their sacrificial portions after the first rays of dawn,</b> the offering is considered to be <i>piggul</i> and is disqualified. With regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that may be eaten for two days and one night,</b> if one <b>intends to</b> present <b>their blood after sunset, or</b> if one intends <b>to</b> sacrifice <b>their sacrificial portions after the first rays of dawn, or</b> if one intends <b>to</b> eat <b>their meat after sunset</b> following the second <b>of</b> the <b>two days,</b> the offering is considered to be <i>piggul</i> and is disqualified.
The Gemara cites another <i>baraita</i> on this topic. <b>The Sages taught:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that peace offerings, which may be eaten for two days, <b>may</b> also <b>be eaten on the evening</b> preceding the <b>third</b> day. <b>And this</b> is the conclusion of <b>a logical inference:</b> Other <b>offerings,</b> e.g., thanks offerings, <b>are eaten for one day, and</b> peace <b>offerings are eaten for two days. Just as</b> with regard to <b>offerings that are eaten for one day,</b> the <b>night follows</b> the previous day, i.e., the offering may be eaten during the day and the subsequent night, <b>so too,</b> with regard to peace <b>offerings that are eaten for two days,</b> say that the <b>night follows</b> the day, and rule that they may be eaten on the night after the second day.
To counter this logic, <b>the verse states:</b> “And when you sacrifice a peace offering to God, you shall sacrifice it of your own will. It shall be eaten the same day you sacrifice it, and on the next day; <b>and if any remains until</b> the third <b>day,</b> it shall be burned with fire” (Leviticus 19:5–6). This teaches that <b>it may be eaten while</b> it is still <b>daytime,</b> i.e., during the second day, <b>but it may not be eaten on the evening</b> preceding the <b>third</b> day.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If a peace offering may not be eaten beyond the second day, one <b>might</b> have thought that it should <b>be burned immediately</b> after the conclusion of the second day, <b>and this</b> too is the conclusion of <b>a logical inference:</b> Other <b>offerings are eaten for one day, and</b> peace <b>offerings are eaten for two days. Just as</b> with regard to <b>offerings that are eaten for one day, immediately</b> after the conclusion of their permitted time <b>for eating</b> should their <b>burning</b> commence, on the morning of the second day, <b>so too,</b> with regard to peace <b>offerings that are eaten for two days</b> say that <b>immediately</b> after the conclusion of their permitted time <b>for eating</b> should their <b>burning</b> commence, at night after the second day.
To counter this logic, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if any remains of the flesh of the sacrifice <b>on the third day, it shall be burned with fire”</b> (Leviticus 7:17), meaning: <b>You</b> must <b>burn it during the day, but you may not burn it during the night.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The firstborn</b> offering, <b>the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and the Paschal offering are offerings of lesser sanctity. Their slaughter is anywhere in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, and their blood requires one placement, provided that</b> the priest <b>places it</b> so that the blood goes <b>on the base</b> of the altar.
The <i>halakha</i> <b>differs with regard to their consumption. The firstborn</b> offering <b>is eaten by the priests, and the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offer-ing is eaten <b>by any person,</b> i.e., any ritually pure Jew. <b>And they are eaten throughout the city</b> of Jerusalem, prepared <b>in any</b> manner of <b>food</b> preparation, <b>for two days and one night. The Paschal offering is eaten only at night, and it is eaten only until midnight, and it is eaten only by its registrants,</b> i.e., those who registered in advance to partake of the offering, <b>and it is eaten only roasted,</b> not prepared in any other manner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that the blood of these offerings is placed, not poured, so that it goes on the base of the altar? <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>it is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> The verse states: “But the firstborn of an ox, or the firstborn of a sheep, or the firstborn of a goat, you shall not redeem; they are sacred; you shall sprinkle their blood upon the altar and you shall burn their fat for an offering made by fire, for a pleasing aroma to the Lord” (Numbers 18:17). <b>It is not stated: Its fat, but</b> rather: <b>“Their fat.”</b> Similarly, <b>it is not stated: Its blood, but</b> rather: <b>“Their blood.”</b> This <b>teaches with regard to a firstborn</b> offering, which is mentioned explicitly in the verse, <b>and</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and a Paschal offering,</b> which are similar in their sanctity to a firstborn offering, <b>that they</b> all <b>require placement of their blood and</b> the burning of their <b>sacrificial portions on the altar.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that their blood must be placed so that it goes <b>on the base</b> of the altar? <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> This is <b>derived</b> by way of a verbal analogy, with the meaning of the word <b>“sprinkling”</b> stated here derived <b>from</b> the meaning of the word <b>“sprinkling”</b> stated with regard to <b>a burnt offering.</b>

Daf 57a

The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a burnt offering itself</b> has its blood presented on the altar in a place where there is a base? The Gemara answers: We derive it from a verse, <b>as it is written:</b> “And he shall pour all the blood of the bull <b>at the base of the altar of the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:7). This <b>teaches that</b> the blood of <b>an obligatory burnt offering requires</b> presentation at the <b>base</b> of the altar, as the verse specifically describes the base of the altar as connected to the burnt offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is derived from a burnt offering via a ver-bal analogy, one might think that <b>just as there,</b> a burnt offering requires <b>two placements that are four, so too here,</b> a firstborn offering, an animal tithe offering, and a Paschal offering should also require <b>two placements that are four,</b> and not just a single placement.
<b>Abaye says: Why do I</b> need the Torah <b>to write:</b> “And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall present the blood, and sprinkle the blood <b>around</b> against the altar” (Leviticus 1:5), <b>with regard to a burnt offering,</b> to teach that the blood must be placed on all four sides of the altar, in addition to writing: “And Moses took the blood, and put it upon the corners of the altar <b>around</b> with his finger” (Leviticus 8:15), <b>with regard to a sin offering? They are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., they teach the same matter; <b>and any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common aspect to apply to other cases. Therefore, a firstborn offering, an animal tithe offering, and a Paschal offering do not require two placements that are four.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common aspect with regard to other cases. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one do <b>teach</b> their common aspect with regard to other cases, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: Together with the verse stated with regard to <b>a guilt offering, there are three</b> verses, as it is written: “And its blood shall be sprinkled around the altar” (Leviticus 7:2), <b>and three</b> verses which come as one <b>certainly do not teach</b> their common aspect with regard to other cases.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>The firstborn</b> offering is <b>eaten by the priests,</b> throughout the city of Jerusalem, prepared in any manner of food preparation, for two days and one night. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a firstborn</b> offering <b>that</b> it is <b>eaten for two days and</b> the intervening <b>night?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to a firstborn offering: <b>“And their flesh shall be yours, as the breast of waving and as the right thigh”</b> (Numbers 18:18). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> the firstborn offering <b>with the breast and thigh of peace offerings. Just as peace offerings are eaten for two days and one night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering is <b>eaten for two days and one night.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> relates: <b>And this question was asked before the Sages in the vineyard,</b> i.e., the academy, <b>in Yavne: For how many</b> days and nights is <b>a firstborn</b> offering <b>eaten? Rabbi Tarfon responded and said: For two days and one night.</b>
<b>There was one student there who came to the study hall before the Sages</b> for the <b>first</b> time, <b>and his name</b> was <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. He said to</b> Rabbi Tarfon: <b>My teacher, from where do you</b> derive this? Rabbi Tarfon <b>said to him: My son, peace offerings</b> are <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, and a firstborn</b> offering is <b>an offering of lesser sanctity. Just as peace offerings are eaten for two days and one night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering is <b>eaten for two days and one night.</b>
Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>said to him: My teacher,</b> there is a different comparison that can be made: <b>A firstborn</b> offering is given as <b>a gift to the priest, and a sin offering and a guilt offering</b> are each given as <b>a gift to the priest. Just as a sin offering and a guilt offering</b> are eaten <b>for</b> one <b>day and</b> one <b>night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering should be eaten <b>for</b> one <b>day and</b> one <b>night.</b>
Rabbi Tarfon <b>said to him: Let us judge a matter from a matter</b> to which it is most similar, i.e., a firstborn offering is an offering of lesser sanctity, as are peace offerings, <b>and learn a matter from a matter,</b> i.e., there is another comparison to be made: <b>Just as peace offerings do not come</b> as atonement <b>for a sin, so too, a firstborn</b> offering <b>does not come</b> as atonement <b>for a sin. Just as peace offerings are eaten for two days and one night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering is <b>eaten for two days and one night.</b>
Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>said to him: My teacher,</b> I can answer you in a similar way. <b>Let us judge a matter from a matter</b> to which it is most similar, i.e., a firstborn offering is more similar to a sin offering and a guilt offering, and <b>learn a matter from a matter,</b> i.e., there is another comparison to be made: <b>A sin offering and a guilt offering</b> are each given as <b>a gift to the priest, and a firstborn</b> offering is given as <b>a gift to the priest. Just as a sin offering and a guilt offering do not come as a vow</b> offering <b>or</b> as <b>a gift</b> offering, i.e., they are brought only by one obligated to bring them, <b>so too, a firstborn</b> offering <b>does not</b> come <b>as a vow</b> offering <b>or as a gift</b> offering. <b>Just as a sin offering and a guilt offering are eaten for one day</b> and one night, <b>so too, a firstborn</b> offering should be <b>eaten for one day</b> and one night.
<b>Rabbi Akiva jumped</b> into the discussion, <b>and Rabbi Tarfon left.</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: <b>But</b> the verse <b>states: “And their flesh shall be yours,</b> as the breast of waving and as the right thigh” (Numbers 18:18). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> firstborn offerings <b>with a breast and thigh of peace offerings. Just as peace offerings are eaten for two days and one night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering is <b>eaten for two days and one night.</b>
Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>said to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>You juxtaposed it with a breast and thigh of peace offerings. But</b> since the Torah does not specify with which offering the firstborn is juxtaposed, <b>I juxtapose it with a breast and thigh of a thanks offering,</b> which are also given to a priest. <b>Just as a thanks offering is eaten for</b> one <b>day and</b> one <b>night, so too, a firstborn</b> offering should be <b>eaten for</b> one <b>day and</b> one <b>night.</b>
Rabbi Akiva <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: I concede that it is possible to juxtapose a firstborn offering with a thanks offering, <b>but</b> the verse <b>states: “And their flesh shall be yours,</b> as the breast of waving and as the right thigh, it shall be yours” (Numbers 18:18). <b>Since</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> a second time: <b>“It shall be yours,” what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> a second time: <b>“It shall be yours”? The verse adds another</b> day on which it is permitted <b>for a firstborn</b> offering to <b>be</b> eaten, i.e., a second day.
The Gemara relates: <b>And when these matters were said before Rabbi Yishmael, he said to</b> his students: <b>Go out and tell Rabbi Akiva: You were mistaken</b> when you conceded to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili that the allotted time for eating a firstborn offering could have been derived from the allotted time for eating a thanks offering. Why? <b>From where is</b> it <b>derived</b> that the breast and thigh of <b>a thanks offering</b> are eaten by priests? It is derived <b>from</b> a juxtaposition with <b>a peace offering.</b> Nowhere is it stated explicitly that the breast and thigh of a thanks offering are eaten only by priests. <b>And</b> in the realm of consecrated matters, <b>can a matter derived via a juxtaposition then teach</b> its <i>halakha</i> <b>via a juxtaposition?</b> The Gemara (49b) demonstrated that it cannot. <b>Consequently, you should not infer from the latter formulation</b> of the verse, from the words “It shall be yours,” <b>but</b> rather, <b>from the first formulation</b> of the verse, as you claimed that the Torah juxtaposes a firstborn offering with the breast and thigh of a peace offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Yishmael do with this</b> extra phrase: <b>“It shall be yours”?</b> This <b>teaches about a blemished firstborn</b> offering, <b>that it is</b> also given as <b>a gift to the priest, as we have not found</b> it written explicitly anywhere <b>in the entire Torah</b> what should be done with a blemished firstborn.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> derive that a blemished firstborn offering is also given as a gift to the priest? <b>He derives it from</b> the term <b>“their flesh,”</b> which is written in the plural. This teaches that <b>both an unblemished</b> firstborn offering <b>and a blemished</b> firstborn offering are given as gifts to the priest. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> understand the plural term? The Gemara answers that he understands it to be <b>saying</b> that the priest receives gifts <b>from the flesh of</b> all <b>these firstborn</b> offerings mentioned in the verse, i.e., the firstborn of cattle, sheep, and goats.
The Gemara asks: Since Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael both agree that a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot then teach its <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition, <b>with regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, <b>holds</b> that a <i>halakha</i> derived both <b>from that</b> juxtaposition <b>and</b> from <b>another</b> principle <b>is</b> considered <b>a juxtaposition.</b> In this case, the specific detail that the breast and thigh of a thanks offering are given to a priest is derived from a juxtaposition with peace offerings. The length of time in which it may be eaten, one day and one night, is written explicitly. Since it is nevertheless considered a juxtaposition, it cannot be used to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a firstborn offering. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that such a case <b>is not</b> considered to be <b>a juxtaposition,</b> and therefore it can be used to teach another <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that a matter derived via a juxtaposition and another principle <b>is not</b> considered <b>a juxtaposition, this is</b> the reason <b>that it is written</b> with regard to the rites performed by the High Priest on Yom Kippur: <b>“And so shall he do for the Tent of Meeting</b> that dwells with them in the midst of their impurity” (Leviticus 16:16).
The High Priest sprinkles the blood of two offerings, the bull and the goat. He sprinkles their blood between the staves of the Ark and on the Curtain separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies. In each location he sprinkles their blood once above and seven times below. The verse does not write all of the details of these sprinklings with regard to each offering, and the details of each are derived from what is written explicitly in the other, as follows: <b>Just as</b> the High Priest <b>sprinkles in the innermost sanctum,</b> between the staves of the Ark, <b>once above and seven</b> times <b>below, with the blood of the bull, so he sprinkles</b> on the Curtain <b>in the Sanctuary.</b>
<b>And just as in the innermost sanctum</b> he sprinkles <b>once above and seven</b> times <b>below, with the blood of the goat, so he sprinkles</b> on the Curtain <b>in the Sanctuary.</b> This is an instance of a <i>halakha</i> derived both from a juxtaposition and from another principle, and the stringency that a matter derived via a juxtaposition cannot also teach its <i>halakha</i> via a juxtaposition is not applied in this case.
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that this too <b>is</b> considered <b>a juxtaposition, what can be said?</b> How can these <i>halakhot</i> be derived? The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> the <b>locations</b> where the blood is sprinkled <b>that are derived from one another</b> in the second juxtaposition. The first juxtaposition teaches one <i>halakha</i>, namely, that the blood of the bull and the blood of the goat are to be compared to one another. The second juxtaposition does not teach a <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood of the bull and the blood of the goat per se; rather it teaches a comparison between the sprinkling performed in the Holy of Holies and the sprinkling performed in the Sanctuary. These are two unconnected juxtapositions.

Daf 57b

The Gemara suggests: <b>And if you wish, say</b> there is a different resolution: The sprinkling <b>outside is derived from</b> the sprinkling <b>inside, all at once.</b> There are not two comparisons here, one derived from the other, but rather a single, complex juxtaposition, from which all of the relevant <i>halakhot</i> are derived.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that a matter derived via a juxtaposition and another principle <b>is not a juxtaposition, this is</b> the reason <b>that it is written</b> with regard to the offering brought on <i>Shavuot</i>: <b>“You shall bring out of your dwellings two wave loaves</b> of two-tenths of an ephah; they shall be of fine flour” (Leviticus 23:17).
<b>Since</b> apparently there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “You shall bring,”</b> as it already states: “And you shall present a new meal offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 23:16), <b>why</b> must <b>the verse state: “You shall bring”?</b> It states this to teach that <b>anything that you bring from another place</b> that is similar to this offering, i.e., the leavened bread that accompanies a thanks offering, <b>shall be</b> prepared <b>like this. Just as there,</b> with regard to the two loaves, they must be prepared from <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>for</b> each <b>loaf, so too here,</b> each of the ten loaves of leavened bread that accompany a thanks offering must be prepared from <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>for</b> each <b>loaf.</b>
<b>If</b> they are compared, why not say that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the two loaves, the total amount of flour is <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the ten loaves that accompany a thanks offering, the total amount of flour for all ten should be <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah? To counter this comparison, <b>the verse states: “They shall be,”</b> to serve as a restriction and teach that only these two loaves amount to a total of two-tenths of an ephah, but the bread accompanying the thanks offering does not amount to two-tenths of an ephah.
The Gemara continues: The ten loaves accompanying a thanks offering must each be a tenth of an ephah, and this has been derived from two sources: A juxtaposition with the offering of <i>Shavuot</i> and another principle, which is that which the verse states concerning the thanks offering, that there must be ten leavened loaves. <b>And we have learned</b> that <b>ten</b>-tenths of an ephah is required <b>for</b> the ten loaves of <b>leavened bread. From where</b> is it derived that <b>ten</b>-tenths of an ephah are required <b>for</b> the <b><i>matza</i></b> which also accompanies a thanks offering? After stating that thirty <i>matzot</i> accompany a thanks offering, <b>the verse states: “With cakes of leavened bread”</b> (Leviticus 7:13), to juxtapose the <i>matza</i> with the leavened bread. This teaches that one must <b>bring <i>matza</i></b> of an amount <b>corresponding to</b> the <b>leavened bread.</b> In any event, this derivation can be employed according to the one who says that a matter derived via a juxtaposition and another principle is not a juxtaposition.
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that a matter derived via a juxtaposition and another principle <b>is a juxtaposition,</b> and therefore it cannot then teach its <i>halakha</i> via another juxtaposition, <b>what is there to say?</b> How can the measure of flour for the <i>matza</i> be derived from the measure of flour for the leavened bread? The Gemara answers: The first <i>halakha</i>, connecting the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i> to the bread accompanying a thanks offering, is not derived via a juxtaposition, but rather via a superfluous word. The term <b>“You shall bring,”</b> written with regard to the two loaves, <b>is extra,</b> and is therefore considered as if it were written explicitly with regard to the leavened bread accompanying the thanks offering. Therefore, it is possible to derive the <i>halakha</i> concerning matza from the <i>halakha</i> concerning leavened bread via a juxtaposition.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>The Paschal offering is eaten only</b> at night and it is eaten only until midnight. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who taught this mishna? <b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>it is Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And they shall eat of the flesh on that night” (Exodus 12:8). <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: It is stated here: “On that night,”</b> without stating when the night ends. <b>And it is stated there,</b> with regard to the plague that afflicted the firstborn Egyptians: <b>“And I will pass through the land of Egypt on that night</b> and I will strike every firstborn in the land of Egypt” (Exodus 12:12). With regard to the death of the firstborns the Torah states: “So said the Lord: At about midnight, I will go out into the midst of Egypt and every firstborn in Egypt shall die” (Exodus 11:4–5).
Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya continues: <b>Just as</b> in the verse <b>there,</b> the death of the firstborns occurred <b>until midnight,</b> as stated explicitly in the verse, <b>so too,</b> in the verse <b>here,</b> the mitzva to eat the Paschal offering continues <b>until midnight</b> but not beyond.
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to</b> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya: <b>But isn’t it</b> already <b>stated:</b> “And so you shall eat it, with your loins girded, your shoes on your feet, your staffs in your hands, <b>and you will eat it in haste,</b> for it is the Paschal offering for the Lord” (Exodus 12:11)? This verse indicates that the Paschal offering may be eaten <b>until the time of haste,</b> i.e., until dawn, as the Jewish people left Egypt hastily the next morning.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, why</b> must <b>the verse state: “On that night,”</b> with regard to eating the Paschal offering? The Gemara explains: This phrase is necessary, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the Paschal offering is <b>like all the</b> other <b>offerings</b> in <b>that it should be eaten during the day,</b> on the day it is sacrificed. To counter this reasoning, <b>the verse states: “On</b> that <b>night,”</b> to emphasize that this particular offering <b>shall be eaten at night, but it shall not be eaten during the day.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And from where</b> do you know <b>that</b> the mishna represents the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, and</b> is stating that the Paschal offering must be eaten by midnight <b>by Torah law? Perhaps</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, and is stating that the Paschal offering must be eaten by midnight <b>by rabbinic law, and</b> the reason for the rabbinic decree was <b>to distance</b> one <b>from a sin.</b> Rav Yosef replied: <b>If so, what</b> does the mishna mean when it says: It is eaten <b>only until midnight?</b> With regard to the other offerings the mishna teaches: Until midnight, without specifying: Only. <b>Rather,</b> one must say that it is <b>like there,</b> with regard to the other <i>halakhot</i> of the Paschal offering stated in the mishna. <b>Just as there,</b> the requirements are <b>by Torah law, so too here,</b> with regard to the final time for eating the meat, the requirement is <b>also by Torah law.</b>

Daf 58a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It was taught in the previous chapter that offerings of the most sacred order are to be slaughtered in the northern section of the Temple courtyard. With regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order that one slaughtered atop the altar, Rabbi Yosei says:</b> Their status is <b>as though they were slaughtered in the north,</b> and the offerings are therefore valid. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> The status of the area <b>from the halfway point of the altar and to the south</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>the south,</b> and offerings of the most sacred order slaughtered in that area are therefore disqualified. The status of the area <b>from the halfway point of the altar and to the north</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>the north.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yosei used to say: The entire altar stands in the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard. The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is the meaning of Rabbi Yosei’s statement that if one slaughtered offerings of the most sacred order atop the altar it is <b>as though</b> they were slaughtered in the north, which indicates that they were not actually slaughtered in the north? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yosei said this <b>lest you say</b> that <b>we require</b> that the offering be slaughtered <b>“on the side</b> of the altar northward” (Leviticus 1:11), i.e., on the ground beside the altar, <b>and</b> that requirement <b>is not</b> fulfilled when it is slaughtered on top of the altar. Therefore, Rabbi Yosei <b>teaches us</b> that the offering is still valid.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Asi:</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan apparently understands that the reason Rabbi Yosei holds that an offering of the most sacred order slaughtered on the altar is valid is because the entire altar is in the northern section of the Temple courtyard. <b>If that is so,</b> shall one <b>also</b> say <b>that according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, half of</b> the altar was situated <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and half of it</b> was situated <b>in the south?</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>indeed</b> that is so, <b>wasn’t it you who said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, concedes that if one slaughtered</b> offerings of the most sacred order <b>on the ground opposite</b> the northern half of the altar, the offering is <b>disqualified?</b> Accordingly, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, apparently maintains that the altar is not located in the north at all.
Rav Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement with regard to Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is an independent statement rather than an inference from the mishna. And with regard to the dispute in the mishna, <b>this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Both of them derived</b> their opinions <b>from one verse:</b> “An altar of earth you shall make for Me, <b>and you shall slaughter upon it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings”</b> (Exodus 20:21).
<b>Rabbi Yosei maintains</b> that the verse teaches that <b>all of it,</b> i.e., the entire altar, is fit <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>a burnt offering, and all of it</b> is also fit <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>a peace offering. And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, maintains</b> that the verse teaches that <b>half of it</b> is fit <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>a burnt offering and half of it</b> is fit <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara explains the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda: <b>As if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that <b>all of it is fit for</b> slaughtering <b>a burnt offering, now</b> that <b>all of it is fit for</b> slaughtering <b>a burnt offering,</b> which must be slaughtered in the northern section of the Temple courtyard (see 53b), <b>is it necessary</b> to teach that it is also fit <b>for</b> slaughtering <b>a peace offering,</b> which may be slaughtered anywhere in the Temple courtyard (see 55a)? The verse therefore must be understood as teaching that half the altar is fit for slaughtering burnt offerings and half is fit for slaughtering peace offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Yosei, respond to this reasoning? The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary</b> for the verse to mention peace offerings. Otherwise, it could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that the verse allows one to slaughter only <b>a burnt offering</b> atop the altar, <b>as the location</b> where <b>it</b> may be slaughtered on the ground is <b>narrow. But</b> with regard to <b>peace offerings, whose location</b> for slaughter on the ground is <b>not narrow, say</b> that <b>no,</b> one may not slaughter them atop the altar. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that peace offerings as well may be slaughtered atop the altar.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, concedes that if one slaughtered</b> offerings of the most sacred order <b>on the ground opposite</b> the northern half of the altar, the offering is <b>disqualified. Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>On the ground opposite</b> the northern half of the altar? <b>If we say</b> it means that the offering was sacrificed upon the <b>cubit</b>-wide <b>base</b> of the altar or upon the <b>cubit</b>-wide <b>surrounding ledge</b> of the altar, <b>this itself is</b> part of the <b>altar. And furthermore, what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>On the ground opposite</b> the northern half of the altar? The base and ledge are not on the ground.
<b>And if you would say</b> that the case is <b>where one dug tunnels in the ground</b> beneath the altar, <b>and slaughtered</b> the offerings <b>in them, in a case like this would</b> the <b>altar</b> itself <b>be</b> fit for use so that according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, one may slaughter the offerings of the most sacred order on the altar but not on the ground? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“An altar of earth you shall make for Me”</b> (Exodus 20:21)? This verse indicates <b>that</b> the altar <b>must be attached to the earth,</b> so <b>that one may not build it on top of tunnels nor on top of arches.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to have the phrase: On the ground opposite the northern half of the altar, in order to teach the <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where one minimized</b> the dimensions of the altar and slaughtered the offerings on the ground where the northern half of the altar had previously stood.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that according to Rabbi Yosei the entire altar was located in the northern section of the Temple courtyard. The Gemara had mentioned that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is an independent statement, not based on the mishna. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> Is it <b>possible</b> that <b>this</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan is</b> correct <b>and we did not learn it in</b> any <b>mishna?</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>went out, examined</b> the matter, <b>and discovered</b> a mishna that alludes to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 2:5): The priests <b>selected fine wood of a fig tree from</b> the chamber of firewood, with which <b>to lay out a second arrangement</b> of wood on the altar so that coals from this arrangement could be used <b>for</b> burning the <b>incense.</b> This second arrangement was located <b>opposite</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>distanced from</b> the <b>corner northward</b> by <b>four cubits.</b> They would arrange enough wood which, when burned, would produce <b>approximately five <i>se’a</i></b> of <b>coals. And on Shabbat,</b> there was enough wood to produce <b>approximately eight <i>se’a</i></b> of <b>coals, as they would place there the two bowls of frankincense of the shewbread.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the</b> significance of the mishna’s <b>defining</b> the precise location of the arrangement and the fact that this is where the frankincense is burned? The Gemara embarks on a lengthy discussion to answer this question: This mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that this arrangement of wood and the burning of the frankincense must be in that precise location, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 58b

<b>Rabbi Yosei says: This</b> is the <b>principle</b> of where sacrificial items are placed on the inner and outer altars: <b>Any</b> sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary in order <b>to be placed</b> on the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, in the Temple courtyard, <b>may be placed only on</b> the area of that altar that is <b>near</b> the Sanctuary, so <b>that there is no</b> area closer to the <b>inside</b> of the Sanctuary. It must therefore be placed on the part of the external altar closest to the entrance to the Sanctuary.
<b>And any</b> sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, in the Temple courtyard, in order <b>to be placed</b> on the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>may be taken only from</b> the area of the external altar that is <b>near</b> the Sanctuary, so <b>that there is no</b> area closer to the <b>inside</b> of the Sanctuary, i.e., from the part of the external altar closest to the entrance to the Sanctuary.
The Gemara clarifies: With regard to the statement concerning <b>any</b> sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary in order <b>to be placed</b> on the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>what are these</b> items? <b>If we say</b> they are the <b>remaining</b> blood of the sin offerings whose blood is presented on the inner altar, there is no reason for Rabbi Yosei to formulate his principle, as <b>it is explicitly written concerning them:</b> “And all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out <b>at the base of the altar of the burnt offering, which is at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 4:7). This verse describes how the blood of the inner sin offerings that remained after the sprinkling was to be poured out on the base of the west side of the altar, which is the side closest to the entrance to the Sanctuary.
<b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to the statement about <b>any</b> sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, in the Temple courtyard, in order <b>to be placed</b> on the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>what are these</b> items? <b>If we say</b> these are the <b>coals of</b> the <b>Yom Kippur</b> service, which must be taken from the western side of the altar, <b>it is explicitly written concerning them: “And he shall take a coal pan full of coals of fire</b> from off the altar before the Lord” (Leviticus 16:12). The expression “before the Lord” is a reference to the western side of the altar, which is the side closest to the Sanctuary.
The Gemara continues: <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yosei’s statement with regard to <b>any</b> sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary in order <b>to be placed</b> on the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary is referring to the <b>two bowls of frankincense of the shewbread.</b> According to Rabbi Yosei, they must be burned on the western side of the altar, <b>as he derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the location on the base of the altar where the <b>remaining</b> blood of the inner sin offerings is poured.
Rabbi Yosei’s next statement, that any sacrificial item <b>that is taken</b> from <b>the</b> altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary in order <b>to be placed on</b> the altar located <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary may be taken only from the area of the external altar that is near the Sanctuary, is referring to the <b>coals that</b> are taken from the external altar <b>each and every day</b> and placed on the inner altar in order to burn the incense. According to Rabbi Yosei these coals must be taken from the western side of the altar, <b>as we derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the location on the altar from where the <b>coals of</b> the <b>Yom Kippur</b> service must be taken.
The Gemara discusses Rabbi Yosei’s opinion that the second arrangement of wood was placed four cubits north of the southwest corner of the altar: <b>And what does</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>hold</b> about the placement of the altar in the Temple courtyard? <b>If he holds</b> that <b>the entire altar stands in the south</b> side of the Temple courtyard, then only the five northernmost cubits of the altar are opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary. Accordingly, in order for the arrangement of wood to be opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary, one is <b>required to move</b> it <b>twenty-seven</b> cubits north of the southwest corner of the altar.
The Gemara continues: <b>And even if</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>holds</b> that the level of <b>sanctity of</b> the <b>Sanctuary and</b> the <b>Entrance Hall is the same,</b> so that the arrangement of wood can be opposite the Entrance Hall, which is ten cubits wider than the Sanctuary, his opinion is still difficult. In order for the arrangement of wood to be opposite the Entrance Hall, one is <b>required to move</b> it <b>twenty-two</b> cubits north of the southwest corner of the altar.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> even <b>if</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>holds</b> that <b>half of</b> the altar was located <b>in the north</b> side of the Temple courtyard <b>and half in the south,</b> in order for the arrangement of wood to be opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary one is still <b>required to move</b> it <b>eleven</b> cubits to the north of the southwest corner of the altar. <b>And</b> if one suggests that, <b>rather, he holds</b> that <b>the sanctity of</b> the <b>Sanctuary and</b> the <b>Entrance Hall is one matter,</b> i.e., equal, one is still <b>required to move</b> the arrangement of wood <b>six</b> cubits from the southwest corner in order to be opposite the Entrance Hall.
<b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> that Rabbi Yosei’s opinion that the arrangement of wood was located four cubits from the altar’s southwest corner is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he holds</b> that <b>the entire altar stands in the north</b> side of the Temple courtyard? Accordingly, only the five southernmost cubits of the altar were opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary.
<b>And</b> of <b>these four cubits</b> from which the arrangement of wood was distanced from the southwest corner of the altar, one <b>cubit</b> was the <b>base</b> of the altar; <b>and</b> one <b>cubit</b> was <b>the surrounding ledge</b> of the altar; <b>and</b> one <b>cubit</b> was the <b>place</b> where the <b>corners</b> of the altar were located; <b>and</b> another <b>cubit</b> was <b>the place of the feet of the priests,</b> i.e., space for the priests to walk around the perimeter of the surface of the altar in order to perform the sacrificial rites. The arrangement of wood was located specifically in that location, <b>as if</b> one were to <b>move</b> it <b>farther away</b> from the southwest corner of the altar, it would <b>no longer</b> be opposite the <b>entrance</b> to the Sanctuary. This proves that according to Rabbi Yosei, the entire altar was located in the northern side of the Temple courtyard, as stated by Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara challenges this proof by suggesting an alternative explanation of the mishna in <i>Tamid</i>: <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The altar was centered and standing</b> precisely <b>in the middle of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, and it was thirty-two cubits</b> wide. <b>Ten cubits</b> were <b>opposite the entrance to</b> the <b>Sanctuary, eleven cubits</b> were <b>to this</b> side of the entrance to the Sanctuary, <b>and eleven cubits</b> were <b>to that</b> side of the entrance to the Sanctuary. It <b>turns out</b> that the length of the <b>altar was aligned opposite</b> the width of the <b>Sanctuary,</b> which itself was thirty-two cubits wide.
The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> one is still <b>required to move</b> the arrangement of wood <b>eleven</b> cubits from the southwest corner in order for it to be opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary. <b>And</b> even <b>if he holds</b> that <b>the sanctity of</b> the <b>Sanctuary and</b> the <b>Entrance Hall is one matter,</b> i.e., equal, one is still <b>required to move</b> the arrangement of wood <b>six</b> cubits in order to be opposite the Entrance Hall. Therefore, the mishna, which states that the arrangement of wood is four cubits north of the southwest corner, cannot be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara responds: <b>Do you hold</b> that <b>these four cubits include</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>base</b> of the altar <b>and</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>surrounding ledge</b> of the altar? Actually, the <b>four cubits</b> are <b>aside from</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>base</b> of the altar <b>and</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>surrounding ledge</b> of the altar. Accordingly, the arrangement of wood was actually a total of six cubits from the southwest corner of the altar, and the mishna can be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara asks why Rav Adda bar Ahava interpreted the mishna to be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda: <b>But let him interpret it</b> to be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei and</b> explain that the altar is located <b>in the center</b> of the Temple courtyard. The Gemara explains: Rav Adda bar Ahava interpreted the mishna to be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda <b>because we heard that Rabbi Yehuda explicitly</b> said that the altar was positioned <b>in the center</b> of the Temple courtyard, whereas we did not hear that Rabbi Yosei maintains such an opinion.
<b>And Rav Sherevya said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna in <i>Tamid</i>, which holds that the entire altar was located in the northern part of the Temple courtyard? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: Since it is stated: “And you shall set the Basin between the Tent of Meeting</b> and the altar” (Exodus 40:7), and another verse states: <b>“And</b>

Daf 59a

<b>the altar of the burnt offering</b> he set at the entrance to the Tabernacle of the Tent of Meeting.” (Exodus 40:29), indicating that no object was allowed to be located between the altar and the Tent of Meeting, whose parallel, in the Temple, was the Sanctuary. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili derives from these verses that only the <b>altar</b> stood <b>at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting, but</b> the <b>Basin</b> did <b>not</b> stand <b>at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. Where would</b> they <b>place</b> the Basin? It was placed <b>between the Entrance Hall and the altar, extended slightly toward the south.</b> Therefore, although the Basin was closer to the Sanctuary than the altar was, it did not actually stand between the altar and the Sanctuary.
The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>What does</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>the entire altar stands in the south</b> section of the Temple courtyard, <b>let him stand</b> the Basin anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Sanctuary</b> begins <b>and southward,</b> so that it is not opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary but it is <b>between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b> This would allow for the optimal fulfillment of both verses (Exodus 40:29; Leviticus 4:7), as the Basin would be located between the altar and the Sanctuary without interposing between the altar and the entrance to the Sanctuary.
The Gemara continues: <b>And even if he holds</b> that <b>the</b> level of <b>sanctity of</b> the <b>Sanctuary and</b> the <b>Entrance Hall is the same,</b> in which case the Basin could not be located opposite the entrance to the Entrance Hall as this too would be considered a violation of the second verse, <b>let him stand</b> the Basin anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Entrance Hall</b> begins <b>and southward,</b> so that it is not opposite the entrance to the Entrance Hall but is <b>in between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b> From the fact that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili did not say that, it is clear he held that the altar was not located in the southern section of the Temple courtyard.
<b>Alternatively,</b> if Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>holds</b> that <b>half of</b> the altar was located <b>in the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard <b>and half of it</b> was located <b>in the south, let him stand</b> the Basin anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Sanctuary</b> begins <b>and southward,</b> so that it is not opposite the entrance to the Sanctuary but <b>between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b> Since the entrance to the Sanctuary was five cubits wide and stood in the middle of the courtyard, and the altar was thirty-two cubits long, there would have been eleven cubits to both the north and the south of the entrance to the Sanctuary where the Basin could be placed in order to be located between the altar and the Sanctuary without interposing between the altar and the entrance to the Sanctuary.
<b>And even if</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>holds</b> that <b>the</b> level of <b>sanctity of</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and</b> that of the <b>Sanctuary is the same,</b> in which case the Basin could not be located opposite the entrance to the Entrance Hall because this too would be considered a violation of the second verse, <b>let him stand</b> the Basin anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Entrance Hall</b> begins <b>and southward,</b> so that it is not opposite the entrance to the Entrance Hall but <b>in between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b> Why does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili require that the Basin be placed south of the altar? The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather, is it not due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>holds</b> that <b>the entire altar</b> stood <b>in the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard?
The Gemara asks: Even if this is the case, why does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili require that the Basin be located to the south of the altar so that it is not actually in between the altar and the Sanctuary? <b>Even if you stand it</b> anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Sanctuary</b> begins <b>and northward,</b> it would not interpose between the altar and the entrance to the Sanctuary but <b>it would</b> actually <b>be</b> located in <b>between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b>
<b>And</b> even if Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds that the sanctity of the Entrance Hall is equal to that of the Sanctuary, and that the Basin cannot interpose between the altar and the entrance to the Entrance Hall, <b>stand</b> the Basin anywhere <b>from</b> where <b>the wall of</b> the <b>Entrance Hall</b> begins <b>and northward,</b> so that it is not opposite the entrance to the Entrance Hall but it is located <b>in between</b> the <b>Entrance Hall and the altar.</b>
The Gemara answers: That suggestion is technically not feasible, as <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar <b>northward [<i>tzafona</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 1:11). This verse indicates <b>that the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard must <b>be vacant of</b> all <b>vessels,</b> including the Basin. This concludes the Gemara’s explanation of Rav Sherevya’s assertion that the mishna in <i>Tamid</i>, which holds that the altar was located in the northern part of the Temple courtyard, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says:</b> The verse states: <b>“Northward</b> before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:11). This indicates <b>that the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard must <b>be vacant of everything, and even of the altar.</b> Therefore, he maintains that the entire altar stood in the southern section of the Temple courtyard.
§ <b>Rav says:</b> In a case of <b>an altar that was damaged, all sacrificial</b> animals <b>that were slaughtered there</b> are <b>disqualified.</b> Rav continues: <b>We have a verse</b> as the source for this <i>halakha</i> <b>but we have forgotten</b> which one <b>it</b> is. <b>When Rav Kahana,</b> Rav’s disciple, <b>ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>saying in the name of Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei: From where</b> is it derived that in the case of <b>an altar that was damaged, that all sacrificial</b> animals <b>that were slaughtered there</b> are <b>disqualified?</b>
It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse with regard to the altar: “An altar of earth you shall make for Me, <b>and you shall slaughter upon it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings [<i>shelamekha</i>]”</b> (Exodus 20:21). <b>Is it</b> true that <b>you slaughter</b> sacrificial animals <b>on</b> the altar itself? They are slaughtered on the ground near the altar. No, <b>rather,</b> the verse indicates that one is able to slaughter the sacrificial animals on account of the altar, i.e., <b>when</b> the altar <b>is complete [<i>shalem</i>], but not when it is lacking,</b> i.e., damaged. Rav Kahana <b>said: This is the verse that eluded Rav.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Both this</b> one <b>and that</b> one are <b>disqualified,</b> i.e., all animals that were designated as offerings when the altar was in a damaged state are disqualified, even if they were not yet slaughtered. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> issue do Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rav holds</b> that <b>living</b> animals <b>are not</b> permanently <b>deferred, and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds</b> that <b>living</b> animals are permanently <b>deferred.</b> If the altar is damaged and it is therefore impossible to sacrifice offerings, Rav holds that only offerings that were already slaughtered become permanently deferred, whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that even those that were not yet slaughtered become permanently deferred.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s opinion, based on a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>all sacrificial</b> animals <b>that were</b> consecrated <b>before the altar was built, and then the altar was</b> subsequently <b>built,</b> the animals are <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara assumes that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to animals that were consecrated before the building of the altar in the Second Temple. The Gemara responds: In a case where the animals were consecrated before the altar <b>was built,</b> the animals are considered <b>initially deferred,</b> i.e., deferred from the time they were initially consecrated. In this case all agree they are not permanently deferred and they can be sacrificed when the altar is built.
<b>Rather,</b> explain the <i>baraita</i> as follows: If the animals were consecrated <b>before the altar was destroyed</b> in the First Temple, and then the altar was destroyed and rebuilt, the animals are still disqualified. The Gemara questions this reading: Can the <i>baraita</i> be referring to a case where the altar was <b>destroyed</b> in the First Temple? <b>Didn’t</b> the animals <b>become</b> too <b>old</b> for sacrifice by the time the altar was constructed in the Second Temple?
The Gemara emends the <i>baraita</i> yet again: <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where one consecrated the animals <b>before the altar was damaged, and subsequently the altar was damaged.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that the animals are <b>disqualified.</b> It seems from this <i>baraita</i> that even sacrificial animals that were not yet slaughtered when the altar became damaged are nevertheless permanently disqualified, in contrast to the opinion of Rav. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But did you not</b> already have to <b>emend</b> the text of the <i>baraita</i>? Emend it differently and <b>say that</b> the case is where the animals <b>were slaughtered</b> before the altar became damaged. Accordingly, there is no proof from this <i>baraita</i> with regard to the deferral of living animals.
Rav said that sacrificial animals that were slaughtered in the Temple courtyard when the altar was in a damaged state are disqualified. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rav Giddel say</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> In a case <b>where</b> the golden <b>altar became uprooted</b> from its location in the Sanctuary, <b>one may burn</b> the <b>incense in its place?</b> Apparently, it is not essential to have the altar in order to sacrifice offerings.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>like that which Rava says</b> (60a): Although Rabbi Yehuda maintains that the entire Temple courtyard is fit for burning the sacrificial portions of offerings, <b>Rabbi Yehuda would concede with regard to</b> the presenting of the <b>blood</b> that it must be performed specifically on the altar. <b>Here too,</b> the Gemara says, <b>Rav concedes with regard to</b> the <b>blood</b> that an altar is required. Consequently, if consecrated offerings were slaughtered when the altar was in a damaged state, since the blood may not be presented, the offering is disqualified.
Having briefly mentioned Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the context of the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the inauguration of the Temple in the time of King Solomon: <b>“On that day the king sanctified the middle of the court</b> that was before the House of the Lord; as there he offered the burnt offering, and the meal offering, and the fat of the peace offerings; <b>because the copper altar that was before the Lord was too small to receive</b> the burnt offering, and the meal offering, and the fat of the peace offerings” (I Kings 8:64). <b>The matters</b> in the verse <b>are</b> to be understood <b>as they</b> are <b>written,</b> i.e., that the altar in the Temple was too small to receive all of the offerings that Solomon sacrificed, and Solomon therefore sanctified the Temple courtyard so that it, too, could function as an altar; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei said to him:</b>

Daf 59b

<b>But isn’t it already stated</b> with regard to the altar that Moses built: <b>“A thousand burnt offerings did Solomon offer upon that altar”</b> (I Kings 3:4), <b>while with regard to the Eternal House,</b> i.e., the Temple, <b>it states: “And Solomon offered for the sacrifice of peace offerings, which he offered to the Lord, two and twenty thousand cattle</b> and one hundred and twenty thousand sheep” (I Kings 8:63)?
<b>And when you arrive at the calculation of burnt offerings and the number of cubits</b> for each altar, <b>this</b> was <b>greater than that,</b> i.e., Solomon sacrificed more offerings per square cubit on Moses’ altar than he did on the altar in the Temple upon its inauguration. Therefore, it is difficult to suggest that the altar in the Temple was not large enough to accommodate the number of offerings that Solomon sacrificed.
Rabbi Yosei presents an alternative understanding of the verse: <b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of the phrase “because the copper altar…<b>was too small to receive”?</b> It is not referring to the altar built by Solo-mon, but rather to the copper altar built in the time of Moses, which was disqualified from use from the day of the Temple’s inauguration on. Rather than stating outright that the altar became disqualified, the verse employed a euphemism, <b>like a person who says to his friend: So-and-so is a dwarf [<i>nanas</i>], and</b> what he really means to say is that he is <b>disqualified from</b> performing the Temple <b>service.</b> Similarly, rather than stating outright that the altar built in the time of Moses became disqualified, the verse states that it was too small to accommodate the offerings sacrificed in the Temple.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> respond to this claim? <b>Rabbi Yosei is saying well,</b> i.e., his claim is persuasive. The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> that <b>the altar that Moses built was large. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states that the altar built in the time of Moses was: <b>“Five cubits long and five cubits wide”</b> (Exodus 27:1). <b>The matters</b> in the verse are to be understood <b>as they are written;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It is stated here</b> that the altar built in the time of Moses was: <b>“Square”</b> (Exodus 27:1), <b>and it is stated there,</b> in Ezekiel’s prophetic description of the altar, that it is: <b>“Square”</b> (Ezekiel 43:16). <b>Just as there,</b> in Ezekiel’s vision, <b>he was measuring</b> the distance in each direction <b>from its center, so too here,</b> the verse <b>was measuring</b> the altar that Moses built <b>from its center.</b> Accordingly, the altar built by Moses was ten cubits by ten cubits. As a result, Solomon sacrificed more offerings per square cubit of space on the altar in the Temple than he did on the altar built by Moses. It is therefore possible that the altar in the Temple was not sufficient to accommodate the offerings, and Solomon consecrated the Temple courtyard to serve as an altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that the altar mentioned <b>there,</b> in Ezekiel, was measured from its center? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written: “And the hearth shall be twelve cubits</b> long by twelve wide, square, to its four sides” (Ezekiel 43:16). The Gemara asks: Does the verse mean twelve cubits <b>in each direction</b> from the center of the altar, so that in total it was twenty-four by twenty-four cubits? <b>Or</b> perhaps the altar was <b>only</b> a total of <b>twelve by twelve</b> cubits. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “To its four sides,” it teaches that</b> Ezekiel was <b>measuring from the center</b> of the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> respond to Rabbi Yehuda’s claim? The Gemara answers: <b>When he learns the verbal analogy, he learns it with regard to</b> the altar’s <b>height. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the altar built in the time of Moses: <b>“And its height shall be three cubits”</b> (Exodus 27:1). The <b>matters</b> in the verse are to be understood <b>as they are written,</b> i.e., that the height of the altar was three cubits. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: It is stated here</b> that the altar built in the time of Moses was: <b>“Square”</b> (Exodus 27:1), <b>and it is stated there</b> that the incense altar was: <b>“Square”</b> (Exodus 30:2). The verbal analogy indicates that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the incense altar, <b>its height</b> was <b>twice its length, so too here,</b> the height of the altar built in the time of Moses was <b>twice its length,</b> i.e., ten cubits.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said to</b> Rabbi Yosei: <b>But isn’t it already stated:</b> “The length of <b>the court shall be a hundred cubits…and the height five cubits”</b> (Exodus 27:18)? Is it <b>possible</b> that the <b>priest</b> would <b>stand atop the altar and</b> hold the items with which he would perform the sacrificial <b>service in his hand, and the whole nation</b> could <b>see him from outside</b> the courtyard? That would constitute a lack of respect for the service in the Tabernacle.
<b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> back <b>to him: But isn’t it already stated: “And the curtains of the court, and the screen for</b> the door of <b>the gate of the court which is by the Tabernacle and by the altar”</b> (Numbers 4:26)? This verse juxtaposes the Tabernacle with the altar to teach that <b>just as</b> the <b>Tabernacle</b> was <b>ten cubits</b> high, <b>so too,</b> the <b>altar</b> was <b>ten cubits</b> high. <b>And</b> another verse <b>states: “The curtains were fifteen</b>

Daf 60a

<b>cubits for the one side”</b> (Exodus 38:14), which indicates that the height of the curtains surrounding the courtyard of the Tabernacle was fifteen cubits. <b>And what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “And the height <b>five cubits”</b> (Exodus 27:18)? It is referring to the height of the curtains <b>from the</b> upper <b>edge of the altar and above;</b> the curtains surrounding the courtyard were five cubits higher than the altar.
Rabbi Yosei continues: <b>And what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall make the altar…<b>and its height shall be three cubits”</b> (Exodus 27:1)? The verse means that the altar measures three cubits <b>from the edge of</b> the <b>surrounding ledge and above.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who understands that the copper altar built in the time of Moses was actually three cubits high, interpret the verbal analogy based upon the word “square,” from which Rabbi Yosei derived that the height of the copper altar was ten cubits? The Gemara answers: <b>When he learns</b> the <b>verbal analogy, he learns it with regard to the</b> altar’s <b>width,</b> not its height. This is based on the verse in Ezekiel (see 59b). Accordingly, it teaches that the altar built in the time of Moses was ten cubits by ten cubits.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the altar was three cubits high and the curtains surrounding the courtyard of the Tabernacle were five cubits high, <b>isn’t the priest visible</b> while performing the service atop the altar? The Gemara answers: <b>Granted, the priest is visible,</b> but the items with which he performs the sacrificial <b>service that</b> are <b>in his hand</b> are <b>not visible.</b>
The Gemara returns to the original dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei with regard to whether or not Solomon consecrated the floor of the Temple courtyard. <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the floor of the Temple courtyard was consecrated so that it could serve as an altar, <b>this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “The king <b>sanctified</b> the middle of the court” (I Kings 8:64). <b>But according to Rabbi Yosei, what</b> is the meaning of the phrase “the king <b>sanctified”?</b> The Gemara answers: It means that Solomon sanctified the courtyard in order <b>to stand the altar in it.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yosei,</b> who maintains that the surface of the altar built in the time of Moses was five cubits by five cubits, <b>this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> in the continuation of that verse: “Because the copper altar that was before the Lord was <b>too small</b> to receive.” <b>But according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that its surface area was ten cubits by ten cubits, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“too small”?</b> The Gemara answers: The verse is referring to the altar built by Solomon, and <b>this</b> is what it <b>is saying: The stone altar that Solomon built in place of the copper altar</b> built in the time of Moses <b>was</b> too <b>small</b> to accommodate the large quantity of offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei <b>disagree</b> that causes them to interpret differently the verbal analogy based on the word “square”? The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>we derive</b> the dimensions of the <b>external</b> altar built in the time of Moses <b>from</b> the <b>external</b> altar described in Ezekiel; <b>but we do not derive</b> the dimensions of the <b>external</b> altar <b>from</b> the dimensions of the <b>inner</b> altar, used for burning the incense.
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that <b>we derive</b> the dimensions of a portable <b>vessel,</b> i.e., the copper altar built in the time of Moses, <b>from</b> the dimensions of another portable <b>vessel,</b> i.e., the golden incense altar built at that time; <b>but we do not derive</b> the dimensions of a portable <b>vessel from</b> the dimensions of <b>an edifice,</b> i.e., the stone altar in the Temple.
§ <b>Rava says:</b> Although <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> maintains that the entire Temple courtyard is fit for burning the sacrificial portions of offerings, he <b>concedes with regard to</b> the <b>blood</b> and holds that it must be presented on the altar, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> On Passover eve, a priest <b>would fill one cup with the blood of the</b> many offerings brought that day and that was now <b>mixed</b> together on the floor. <b>And</b> then he would <b>pour it on the altar, so that if</b> all of <b>the blood of one of the</b> offerings had been <b>spilled</b> and was never presented on the altar, <b>this</b> cup would contain a small amount of that blood and pouring it on the altar <b>would render</b> the offering <b>fit.</b>
Rava explains his proof: <b>And if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda maintains the entire Temple courtyard was consecrated</b> so that it had the status of the altar, then <b>the mitzva of</b> sacrificing the Paschal offering <b>was performed</b> even if the blood spilled on the ground of the courtyard and was never presented on the altar.
The Gemara attempts to reject this proof: <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Yehuda requires pouring a cup of the mixture of blood on the altar <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he holds we require pouring</b> of the blood of the Paschal offering <b>by human force.</b> Since the blood on the floor of the courtyard was not poured there by a person, the mitzva has not yet been fulfilled despite the fact that the floor has the same status as the altar. The Gemara responds: <b>If so, let</b> the priest <b>take</b> the cup of the mixture of blood <b>and pour it in its place</b> on the floor rather than on the altar.
