The Gemara rejects Rava’s proof: <b>But perhaps</b> Rabbi Yehuda requires the blood to be poured on the altar only <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that we require</b> the <b>mitzva</b> to be performed in <b>the optimal</b> manner. Even if Rabbi Yehuda holds that the floor of the courtyard has the same status as the altar, he would agree that it is preferable for the blood to be poured on the altar itself.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> In the case of <b>an altar that was damaged, one may not eat the remainder of a meal offering on its account, as it is stated:</b> “Take the meal offering…<b>and eat it without leaven beside the altar;</b> for it is most holy” (Leviticus 10:12). The verse is difficult: <b>But did</b> the priests have to <b>eat</b> the meal offering <b>beside the altar?</b> A priest may eat sacrificial items even of the most sacred order anywhere in the Temple courtyard. <b>Rather,</b> the verse means that one may eat the meal offering only <b>at a time when</b> the altar <b>is complete, but not at a time when it is lacking.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>We found</b> a source for this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>remainder of a meal offering; from where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> applies to all <b>offerings of the most sacred order?</b> The Gemara answers: The end of <b>the verse states:</b> “For it is <b>most holy.”</b> Since this term is also used with regard to the other offerings of the most sacred order, it is derived through verbal analogy that these offerings may not be eaten if the altar is damaged.
The Gemara continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived that this <i>halakha</i> also applies to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity? Abaye said:</b> It is <b>derived from the exposition of Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says three</b> halakhic <b>matters in the name of</b>

Daf 60b

<b>three elders, and this is one of them: Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person would bring second-tithe</b> produce <b>up to Jerusalem in the present,</b> after the destruction of the Temple, <b>and eat it. And</b> ostensibly, <b>it</b> could be derived by means of <b>a logical inference</b> that one may not do so: <b>A firstborn</b> offering <b>requires bringing</b> it <b>to</b> the <b>place,</b> to Jerusalem, and eating it there, <b>and</b> second<b>-tithe</b> produce <b>requires bringing</b> it <b>to</b> the <b>place</b> (see Deuteronomy 12:17–18); <b>just as</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering may be eaten there <b>only in the presence of the Temple, so too,</b> second<b>-tithe</b> produce may be eaten there <b>only in the presence of the Temple.</b>
Rabbi Yishmael notes that this derivation can be challenged: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a firstborn?</b> Bringing the firstborn to Jerusalem is required only in the presence of the Temple, because it is notable <b>in that it requires placement of</b> its <b>blood and</b> its <b>sacrificial portions upon</b> the <b>altar;</b> will you say the same with regard to second-tithe produce, which requires only that it be consumed in Jerusalem?
He continues: <b>First fruits will prove</b> that placement of blood upon the altar is not a factor, as they do not require placement of blood upon the altar, and yet they are brought to Jerusalem only in the presence of the Temple. Rabbi Yishmael counters: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about first fruits?</b> They are notable <b>in that they require placement</b> alongside the altar. Perhaps, since second-tithe produce does not require placement at all, even in the present one must bring it to Jerusalem and eat it there.
Rabbi Yishmael concludes: Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And there you shall bring your burnt offerings,</b> and your sacrifices, and your tithes…and the firstborns of your herd and of your flock” (Deuteronomy 12:6); the Torah <b>juxtaposes</b> second-<b>tithe</b> produce <b>with</b> the <b>firstborn. Just as</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering may be eaten there <b>only in the presence of the Temple, so too,</b> second<b>-tithe</b> produce may be eaten there <b>only in the presence of the Temple.</b>
The Gemara questions why a verse was needed to teach that second-tithe produce may not be consumed nowadays: <b>But let the logical derivation return and</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>will be derived from the common element</b> between the <i>halakhot</i> of firstborn animals and first fruits. Although each has a unique factor, they share a common element: They must be brought to Jerusalem and that they may be eaten only in the presence of the Temple. So too, second-tithe produce, which also must be brought to Jerusalem, should be permitted for consumption only in the presence of the Temple.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yishmael did not present this derivation <b>because</b> it <b>can be refuted</b> in the following manner: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the two sources that share <b>a common element?</b> Both firstborn animals and first fruits are notable <b>in that they possess an aspect</b> of being offered upon the <b>altar.</b> Since second-tithe produce does not share this characteristic, its <i>halakhot</i> cannot be derived from those pertaining to firstborn animals and first fruits.
The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>hold? If he holds</b> that the <b>initial consecration</b> of the Temple <b>sanctified it for its time and sanctified it forever,</b> then it should be permitted to build an altar and sacrifice offerings even nowadays, and therefore <b>even a firstborn</b> animal may be eaten. <b>And if he holds</b> that the initial consecration of the Temple area <b>did not sanctify it forever, let the dilemma be raised</b> with regard to <b>a firstborn as well.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Actually,</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>holds</b> that that the initial consecration of the Temple <b>did not sanctify it</b> forever. <b>And</b> al-though one cannot slaughter the firstborn to begin with, <b>here we are dealing with a firstborn</b> that was slaughtered and <b>whose blood was sprinkled</b> on the altar <b>before the destruction of the Temple, and</b> then <b>the Temple was destroyed, and the meat of</b> the firstborn <b>still exists.</b>
It is prohibited to eat the meat of the firstborn in this case because <b>its meat was juxtaposed with its blood,</b> which is mentioned in the previous verse, as it is stated: “You shall sprinkle their blood…and you shall burn their fats…and their flesh shall be yours” (Numbers 18:17–18). The juxtaposition teaches that <b>just as its blood</b> is sprinkled only <b>on the altar, so too, its meat</b> may be consumed only <b>in</b> a time when there is <b>an altar. And</b> the case of second-<b>tithe</b> produce <b>comes and is derived from</b> the case of <b>a firstborn.</b> Consequently, second-tithe produce may not be consumed unless there is an altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does a matter derived via a juxtaposition</b> with another case <b>then teach</b> that the <i>halakha</i> applies to a third case <b>via a juxtaposition</b> between the second and third cases? There is a principle that this is not a valid method of deriving <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to consecrated matters. Since the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the meat of the firstborn offering is derived from the juxtaposition of the meat with the blood of the firstborn, one cannot then prove that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to second-tithe produce simply because it is juxtaposed in a verse with the meat of the firstborn. The Gemara answers: Second-<b>tithe grain is non-sacred,</b> and therefore the acceptable methods for deriving its <i>halakhot</i> are not limited in this manner.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says:</b> In determining whether the derivation involves consecrated matters or whether it involves non-sacred matters, <b>we follow</b> the matter that <b>is derived</b> from a matter derived from a juxtaposition. Since in this case the matter derived is second-tithe produce, which for these purposes is non-sacred, its legal status may be derived from juxtaposition with the <i>halakhot</i> of sacrificial matters. <b>But according to the one who says: We follow</b> the matter that <b>teaches,</b> i.e., from which the <i>halakha</i> is derived, <b>what is there to say?</b> The status of second-tithe produce may not be derived by means of juxtaposition with the status of the firstborn offering, which itself was derived from the blood of the offering, because the firstborn offering is a sacrificial matter.
The Gemara answers: This is not a matter derived from a matter derived from a juxtaposition, as the status of the firstborn offering is not derived from the status of blood; <b>blood and meat are one matter.</b> There is only one derivation in this case, which is that the status of second-tithe produce is derived from the status of the blood and the meat of the firstborn. In any event, Abaye has proven, quoting Rabbi Yishmael’s statement cited by Rabbi Yosei, that even sacrificial items of lesser sanctity may not be eaten if the altar is missing or damaged.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Ravin ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he stated this <i>halakha</i>,</b> that even items of lesser sanctity are disqualified if the altar is damaged or missing, <b>in the presence of Rabbi Yirmeya.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said: Foolish Babylonians! Because they dwell in a dark land, they state <i>halakhot</i> that are dim. Have they not heard that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>At the time</b> when the Jewish people would dismantle the Tabernacle in order to <b>depart</b> on their <b>journeys</b> in the wilderness, <b>sacrificial</b> food was <b>disqualified</b> from being consumed, since the altar was not in place. Nevertheless, <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers</b> were <b>sent out of</b> the relevant <b>partition;</b> a <i>zav</i> was sent out of the Levite camp and a leper was sent out of the Israelite camp.
<b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Sacrificial</b> food could be <b>consumed in two locations,</b> i.e., one could eat it while the Tabernacle was in place and one could continue eating it after the Tabernacle had been disassembled and transported. <b>What, is it not</b> that <b>this</b> first <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to offerings of the most sacred order,</b> and <b>that</b> second <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to offerings of lesser sanctity?</b> Accordingly, Abaye’s statement that offerings of lesser sanctity may not be consumed if the altar is damaged is incorrect.
<b>Ravina said</b> that there is an alternative reconciliation of the two <i>baraitot</i>: Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring <b>to offerings of lesser sanctity, and</b> it is <b>not difficult:</b>

Daf 61a

<b>This</b> first <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who derives that meat of a firstborn offering, which is an offering of lesser sanctity, cannot be consumed if the altar is damaged or absent, based upon the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to the blood of the firstborn. <b>That</b> second <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Sages,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yishmael.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> there is a different resolution of the two <i>baraitot</i>: Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring <b>to offerings of the most sacred order. And what</b> does the second <i>baraita</i> mean when it says the food may be consumed <b>in two locations?</b> It is referring to when the Israelites arrive at a new camp, <b>before the Levites erect the Tabernacle,</b>

Daf 61b

<b>and,</b> when they are leaving the camp, <b>after the Levites dismantle the Tabernacle</b> but before they remove the altar. Since the altar has not yet been moved, it is still permitted to consume the sacrificial food.
The Gemara continues: It was necessary to state this <i>halakha</i> <b>lest you say</b> that once the partitions surrounding the courtyard have been taken down, the sacrificial food <b>has been disqualified because</b> it is considered to have <b>left</b> the courtyard of the Tabernacle. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that the food is permitted for consumption as long as the altar remains in place.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> it is <b>indeed</b> so, that the sacrificial food should be disqualified because it is no longer within the partitions surrounding the courtyard. The Gemara explains: <b>The verse states: “Then the Tent of Meeting shall travel”</b> (Numbers 2:17). This verse indicates that <b>even though it traveled it is</b> still considered <b>the Tent of Meeting.</b> Therefore, the sacrificial food is not considered to have left its designated area.
§ The Gemara raises another discussion concerning the altar: <b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: The altar in Shiloh was</b> fashioned <b>of stones,</b> unlike the portable altar constructed in the time of Moses, which was fashioned from copper. This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: Why</b> must <b>the verses state</b> that the altar must be fashioned from <b>stones</b> (Exodus 20:22), and state again that the altar must be fashioned from <b>stones</b> (Deuteronomy 27:5), and mention yet again the word <b>stones</b> (Deuteronomy 27:6), with regard to the altar, for a total of <b>three times?</b> These allude to three different stone altars: <b>One in Shiloh, and one in Nov and Gibeon, and</b> one in the <b>Eternal House,</b> i.e., the Temple.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ami raises an objection</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>fire that descended from Heaven</b> upon the altar <b>in the days of Moses</b> (see Leviticus 9:24) <b>departed from atop the copper altar only in the days of Solomon,</b> when he replaced the copper altar with a stone altar, <b>and</b> the <b>fire that descended</b> upon the altar <b>in the days of Solomon did not depart until Manasseh came and removed it</b> by destroying the altar. <b>And if it is so</b> that the altar in Shiloh was fashioned of stones, <b>it</b> emerges <b>that</b> the fire <b>departed</b> the copper altar <b>earlier,</b> when the stone altar in Shiloh replaced the copper altar of Moses, many years before King Solomon.
The Gemara explains: Rav Huna <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Natan, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: The altar in Shiloh was</b> fashioned <b>of copper;</b> it was <b>hollow and full of stones.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says</b> there is an alternative answer: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the statement in the <i>baraita</i> that the fire <b>did not depart</b> until the days of Solomon? It means that <b>it did not depart</b> in a manner in which it was <b>nullified;</b> it was still somewhat present in Shiloh on the copper altar, which stood together with the stone altar. The Gemara asks: <b>What is it,</b> i.e., what does it mean that the fire did not depart a manner in which it was nullified? The Gemara answers: <b>The Rabbis say:</b> The fire on the copper altar <b>would emit sparks</b> toward the stone altar when the priests would sacrifice offerings on the stone altar. <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The fire <b>was</b> as <b>a guest; sometimes</b> it was <b>here,</b> on the copper altar, <b>and sometimes</b> it was <b>there,</b> on the stone altar.
§ The Gemara continues discussing the altar: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Middot</i> 35b): The altar in the First Temple was twenty-eight by twenty-eight cubits. <b>When the members of the exile ascended</b> to Jerusalem in the beginning of the Second Temple period, <b>they added four cubits to it on the south and four cubits on the west</b> sides of the altar, <b>like</b> the shape of the Greek letter <b>gamma,</b> i.e., the additions made a right angle. As a result, the altar in the Second Temple was thirty-two by thirty-two cubits. The Gemara asks: <b>What was the reason</b> for this expansion? <b>Rav Yosef said: Because</b> the size of the altar from the First Temple <b>was not sufficient.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: Now,</b> if in <b>the First Temple</b> era, <b>about which it is written: “Judah and Israel were many as the sand that is by the sea”</b> (I Kings 4:20), the altar <b>was sufficient,</b> how could it be that in <b>the Second Temple</b> era, <b>about which it is written: “The whole congregation together was forty</b> and two <b>thousand</b> three hundred and sixty” (Ezra 2:64), the altar <b>was not sufficient?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>There,</b> in the First Temple, a <b>heavenly fire</b> would <b>assist them</b> and consume the offerings. <b>Here,</b> in the Second Temple, there was <b>no heavenly fire</b> that would <b>assist them.</b> Therefore, they needed a larger area in which to burn the offerings.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he reported that which <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi says in the name of Bar Kappara</b> with regard to the expansion of the altar: <b>They expanded</b> the altar to extend over the underground <b>cavities</b> into which the libations flowed. <b>Initially,</b> in the First Temple era, <b>they held</b> that when the verse states: <b>“An altar of earth</b> you shall make for Me” (Exodus 20:21), it means <b>that it</b> should be completely <b>filled with earth.</b>
<b>But ultimately,</b> in the Second Temple era, <b>they maintained</b> that the altar’s <b>drinking is like</b> its <b>eating,</b> i.e., just as the offerings are burned upon the altar, so too, the libations must be poured onto the altar itself and not down its side. Consequently, they expanded the altar to cover the underground cavities, and created holes in the altar so that the libations could be poured on top of the altar and flow into the underground cavities. <b>And</b> according to this, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“an altar of earth”?</b> It teaches <b>that</b> the altar must <b>be attached to the earth,</b> so <b>that one may not build it on top of arches</b>

Daf 62a

<b>and</b> one may <b>not</b> build it <b>on top of tunnels.</b>
The Gemara relates that after reconsidering the reason for the expansion of the altar, <b>Rav Yosef said: Is this not as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And they set the altar upon its bases”</b> (Ezra 3:3), which teaches <b>that</b> in the Second Temple the size of the altar <b>reached its full measure,</b> i.e., that it was the ideal size, whereas in the First Temple it was not the ideal size? The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to the instructions David gave Solomon about how to build the Temple: <b>“All this in writing, as the Lord has made me wise by His hand upon me,</b> even all the works of this pattern” (I Chronicles 28:19), indicating that the design of the First Temple was dictated by God?
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said:</b> The size of the altar in the First Temple was ideal, but in the Second Temple era there was a need to expand the altar, and they <b>found a verse and interpreted</b> it as follows. The verse states: <b>“Then David said: This is the House of the Lord God, and this is the altar of burnt offering for Israel”</b> (I Chronicles 22:1). The verse juxtaposes the House, i.e., the Temple, with the altar, which indicates that the altar is <b>like</b> the <b>Temple: Just as</b> the <b>House</b> was <b>sixty cubits</b> (see I Kings 6:2), <b>so too,</b> the <b>altar</b> may be extended up to a length of <b>sixty cubits.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses the construction of the altar in the Second Temple. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to the location of the <b>House, its shape</b> was <b>discernable</b> from the vestiges of its foundations; <b>but how did they know</b> the proper location of the <b>altar?</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: They saw</b> a vision of the <b>altar</b> already <b>built and Michael the archangel standing and sacrificing</b> offerings <b>upon it. And Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa says: They saw</b> a vision of <b>the ashes of Isaac</b> that were <b>placed in that location. And Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says: From the entire House they smelled the scent of incense,</b> yet <b>from there,</b> the location of the altar, <b>they smelled a scent of</b> burned animal <b>limbs.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Three prophets ascended with them from the exile: One who testified to them about</b> the size and shape of <b>the altar, and one who testified to them about the</b> proper <b>location of the altar, and one who testified to them that one sacrifices</b> offerings <b>even if there is no Temple,</b> provided that there is a proper altar.
It <b>was taught in a <i>baraita</i></b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says: Three prophets ascended with</b> the Jewish people <b>from the exile: One who testified to them about</b> the size and shape of <b>the altar and about the</b> proper <b>location of the altar, and one who testified to them that one sacrifices</b> offerings <b>even if there is no Temple, and one who testified to them about the Torah</b> and instructed <b>that it be written</b> in <b>Assyrian script [<i>Ashurit</i>]</b> rather than the ancient Hebrew script used in the times of Moses.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>corner</b> built at each point where the edges of the altar meet, the <b>ramp</b> upon which the priests ascended the altar, the <b>base</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> the requirement that the altar must be exactly <b>square, are</b> all <b>indispensable</b> in order for the altar to be fit for use. But <b>the measurement of its length, and the measurement of its width, and the measurement of its height are not indispensable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Huna says:</b> In reference to each of these characteristics <b>the verse states</b> the term <b>“the altar,”</b> and there is a principle that <b>wherever</b> the term <b>“the altar” is stated,</b> it serves <b>to</b> indicate that the halakhic detail mentioned is <b>indispensable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then the <b>engraving [<i>kiyyur</i>]</b> that was on the altar <b>according to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>or</b> the <b>surrounding ledge</b> of the altar <b>according to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> should <b>also be indispensable, as it is written: “And you shall put it under the <i>karkov</i> of the altar beneath”</b> (Exodus 27:5). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the <b><i>karkov</i>? Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: This is</b> the <b>engraving</b> on the altar. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: This is the surrounding ledge.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> the <i>karkov</i> is also indispensable, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: On <b>that day</b> when <i>etrogim</i> were pelted at a Sadducee priest who poured the water libation of <i>Sukkot</i> on his feet rather than on the altar (see <i>Sukka</i> 48b), <b>the corner of the altar was damaged</b> as a result of the pelting and the ensuing chaos. <b>They brought a fistful of salt and sealed</b> the damaged section. They did this <b>not because</b> it rendered the altar <b>fit for the</b> Temple <b>service, but</b> in deference to the altar, <b>so that the altar would not be seen</b> in its <b>damaged</b> state. The reason the altar is disqualified is <b>because any altar that does not have a corner, a ramp, and a base, and</b> any altar that is not <b>square,</b> is <b>disqualified. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: Even the surrounding ledge</b> is indispensable.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the <b><i>karkov</i></b> of the altar? It is the area <b>between</b> one <b>corner and</b> the next <b>corner,</b> which is the <b>cubit-</b>wide <b>place</b> on top of the altar where <b>the priests</b> would <b>walk.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>the priests would walk between</b> one <b>corner and</b> the next <b>corner?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, say:</b> The <i>karkov</i> is the cubit-wide area between one corner and the other, <b>and</b> there was an additional <b>cubit</b> that was <b>the place</b> where <b>the priests</b> would <b>walk.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written:</b> “And he made for the altar a grating of network of brass, <b>under the <i>karkov</i> beneath, reaching halfway up”</b> (Exodus 38:4), which indicates that the <i>karkov</i> was on the side of the altar and not on top of it? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: There were two</b> entities called <i>karkov</i>. <b>One</b> was a slight protrusion above the midway point of the altar <b>for aesthetic</b> purposes, <b>and one</b> was an indentation on top of the altar <b>for</b> the benefit of <b>the priests,</b> to ensure <b>that they</b> would <b>not slip</b> off the top of the altar.
It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> cited above that <b>the measurement of</b> the altar’s <b>length, and the measurement of its width, and the measurement of its height are not indispensable. Rabbi Mani says:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that one does not decrease its</b> size so that it is smaller <b>than</b> the <b>altar constructed by Moses.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how</b> large was the altar constructed by Moses? <b>Rav Yosef says:</b> One <b>cubit.</b> Those in the study hall <b>mocked</b> Rav Yosef, as it is written explicitly: <b>“Five cubits long and five cubits wide; the altar shall be square”</b> (Exodus 27:1).
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Perhaps the Master is speaking</b> about <b>the area of the arrangement</b> of wood? Since the corners took up one cubit on each side and there was an additional cubit on each side for the priests to walk, only one cubit was left for the arrangement of wood. Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>The Master,</b> i.e., Abaye, <b>who is a great man, knows what I</b> mean to <b>say.</b> Rav Yosef <b>read,</b> i.e., applied, the following verse <b>to those</b> who mocked him:

Daf 62b

<b>“The children of Keturah”</b> (Genesis 25:4). Although Keturah’s children were children of Abraham, they were not of the same caliber as Isaac. Similarly, Rav Yosef was saying that his other students were not of the caliber of Abaye. Having mentioned this term, the Gemara relates: <b>The sons of Rabbi Tarfon’s sister were sitting</b> silently <b>before Rabbi Tarfon.</b> In an attempt to encourage them to say something, <b>he began and said:</b> The verse states: <b>And Abraham took another wife, and her name was Yoḥani. They said to</b> Rabbi Tarfon: <b>It is written: “Keturah”</b> (Genesis 25:1), not Yoḥani. Rabbi Tarfon <b>read,</b> i.e., said, <b>about them</b> the phrase <b>“the children of Keturah”</b> as they were able to contribute only this small piece of information.
§ <b>Abaye bar Huna says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya says:</b> With regard to the <b>logs that Moses prepared</b> for the mitzva of burning wood upon the altar, <b>their length</b> was <b>a cubit and their width</b> was <b>a cubit, and their thickness</b> was <b>like</b> that of <b>a leveler,</b> a kind of flat stick used to remove the excess grain <b>heaped</b> on top of a container that holds one <b><i>se’a</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> The length and width of the logs men-tioned were measured <b>with a shortened cubit. Rav Yosef said: Is this not as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“Upon the wood that is on the fire that is upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:8). The seemingly superfluous phrase “that is upon the altar” teaches <b>that the wood should not extend at all beyond</b> the area of <b>the altar</b> designated for the arrangement of wood. Since this area was one square cubit, the logs were exactly one cubit as well.
§ The Gemara discusses the ramp of the altar: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Middot</i> 36a): <b>There was a ramp</b> that was located <b>on the south</b> side <b>of the altar,</b> whose size was <b>a length</b> of <b>thirty-two</b> cubits <b>by a width</b> of <b>sixteen</b> cubits. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived, i.e., from where is it derived that the ramp is on the south side of the altar? <b>Rav Huna said: The verse states: “And he shall slaughter it on the side [<i>yerekh</i>] of the altar northward”</b> (Leviticus 1:11), which teaches <b>that</b> the altar’s <b>thigh [<i>yarekh</i>] should be</b> located <b>in the north, and its face,</b> i.e., the front of the altar where the priests ascend to it, should be <b>in the south.</b> The verse likens the positioning of the altar to a person who is lying down flat, in which case if his legs are to the north, his face is to the south.
The Gemara asks: Why not <b>say</b> that its <b>thigh</b> should be <b>in the north and its face</b> should also be <b>in the north?</b> Perhaps the verse is referring to a person sitting with both his face and feet in the north. <b>Rava said</b> in response: <b>Place the man on his face,</b> i.e., the analogy is to a man who is lying down. <b>Abaye said to him: On the contrary, sit the man straight up</b> so that his face and his legs are facing the same direction.
Rava <b>said</b> back <b>to him: It is written</b> in a verse that the altar must be <b>“square [<i>ravua</i>]”</b> (Exodus 27:1), which indicates lying down or crouching, as it is similar to the term <i>ravutz</i>, meaning crouching. Abaye challenges Rava: <b>But</b> this word is <b>necessary to</b> teach <b>that</b> the altar must be <b>square.</b> Rava responds: <b>Is it written</b> in the verse that the altar must be <b>square [<i>merubba</i>]?</b> The verse specifically uses the form <i>ravua</i> in order to allude to the word <i>ravutz</i>, crouching. Abaye counters: <b>According to your reasoning, is it written</b> in the verse that the altar must be <b><i>ravutz</i>?</b> Rava answers: It <b>is written</b> in the verse that the altar must be <b><i>ravua</i>, which</b> is a term that <b>indicates this,</b> i.e., that the altar must be square, <b>and indicates that,</b> i.e., that its positioning is comparable to that of a person who is lying down.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> another <b><i>tanna</i> cites</b> the source for the ramp’s positioning <b>from here, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The verse states with regard to the future altar: <b>“And its steps shall look [<i>penot</i>] toward the east”</b> (Ezekiel 43:17), which indicates that <b>all the turns [<i>pinot</i>] that you turn should be only to the right</b> and you should turn <b>to the east.</b> Only if the ramp is in the south can one turn to the right and be facing eastward.
The Gemara challenges: The verse indicates only that after a person turns he is facing eastward. Why not <b>say</b> that the ramp was located in the north and the priest turns <b>left</b> and faces <b>eastward?</b> The Gemara answers: This possibility should <b>not enter your mind, as Rami bar Yeḥizkiya teaches:</b> A verse describes the <b>sea,</b> i.e., the Basin, <b>that Solomon built,</b> in the following terms: <b>“It stood upon twelve oxen, three looking toward [<i>ponim</i>] the north, and three looking toward [<i>ponim</i>] the west, and three looking toward [<i>ponim</i>] the south, and three looking toward [<i>ponim</i>] the east”</b> (II Chronicles 4:4). From the order of the directions in which the verse lists the groups of oxen under the Basin, it can be derived that <b>all the turns that you turn should be only to the right</b> and <b>to the east.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary to</b> teach <b>its own</b> information describing the Basin. The Gemara explains: <b>If so, why do I</b> need the verse to repeat the term <b><i>ponim</i>, <i>ponim</i>?</b> It must be in order to teach how one turns while performing the sacrificial rite upon the altar, which, in turn, teaches the location of the ramp.
§ <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei ben Lakonya asked Rabbi Yosei:</b> Is it so that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai used to say</b> that <b>there is airspace,</b> i.e., a gap, <b>between the ramp and the altar?</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said to him: And you, don’t you say so</b> as well? <b>But isn’t it already stated: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27)? The verse juxtaposes the flesh of the burnt offering with its blood to teach that <b>just as</b> the <b>blood</b> is presented upon the altar <b>via tossing</b> while the priest stands on the ground next to the altar (see Leviticus 1:5), <b>so too,</b> the <b>flesh</b> of the burnt offering is presented <b>via tossing.</b> In order to fulfill this requirement, the priest stands on the ramp and tosses the flesh over the gap between the ramp and the altar, so that it lands on the arrangement of wood.
Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei ben Lakonya <b>said to him:</b> If the verse simply teaches that the flesh must be tossed onto the arrangement of wood, it does not prove that there must be a gap between the ramp and the altar, <b>as I say</b> that the priest should <b>stand next to</b> the <b>arrangement</b> of wood <b>and toss</b> the flesh onto it.
Rabbi Yosei <b>said to him: When he tosses</b> the flesh, <b>does he toss</b> it <b>onto</b> a part of the <b>arrangement</b> of wood that is <b>burning or does he toss</b> it <b>onto</b> a part of the <b>arrangement</b> of wood <b>that is not burning? You must say</b> that <b>he tosses</b> it <b>onto</b> a part of the <b>arrangement</b> of wood that is <b>burning.</b> And <b>there,</b> according to your suggestion that the priest is standing next to the arrangement of wood, he would have to toss the flesh, <b>because it is impossible</b> to place the flesh directly into the fire without the priest getting burned. It would be unnecessary for the verse to teach that the priest tosses the flesh while standing next to the arrangement. Consequently, when the verse juxtaposed the blood with the flesh, it must be teaching that the flesh must be tossed over a gap between the ramp and the altar.
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The requirement that there be a gap between the ramp and the altar can be derived from this verse, because the juxtaposition teaches that the flesh is <b>like blood</b> in the manner in which it is tossed: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood</b> there is <b>space</b> on the <b>ground</b> that <b>interposes</b> between the priest and the altar, <b>so too</b> with regard to the <b>flesh,</b> there is <b>space</b> on the <b>ground</b> that <b>interposes</b> between the priest and the altar, i.e., he stands on the ground next to the altar and tosses the flesh onto the altar.
§ The Gemara continues discussing the ramp: <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> There were <b>two small ramps protruding from the</b> main <b>ramp</b> that led to the altar, <b>on which</b> the priests could <b>turn to the base</b> of the altar <b>and to the surrounding ledge</b> of the altar. They were <b>separated from the altar</b> by <b>a hairbreadth, because it is stated: “Roundabout”</b> (Leviticus 1:5), with regard to the altar. This indicates that nothing is attached to the entire perimeter of the altar. <b>And Rabbi Abbahu says</b> there is a different source, as it states: <b>“Square”</b> (Exodus 27:1), and if the ramps would be connected to the altar it would no longer be square.
The Gemara continues: <b>And it was necessary</b> for the verse <b>to write: “Roundabout,” and it was necessary</b> for the verse <b>to write: “Square,” as, had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“Roundabout,” I would say that</b> the altar <b>can be circular.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One wrote</b> that the altar must be <b>“square.” And had the Merciful One written</b> only that the altar must be <b>“square [<i>ravua</i>],” I would say that</b> the word <i>ravua</i> simply means rectangular and the altar can be <b>long and narrow.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One wrote</b> the term <b>“roundabout,”</b> which teaches that the altar must not have some sides that are longer than others.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Middot</i> 37b): <b>The ramp and the altar</b> together were <b>sixty-two</b> cubits long. The Gemara challenges: The dimensions of <b>these are sixty-four</b> cubits, as the altar and the ramp were each thirty-two cubits long (<i>Middot</i> 36a). The Gemara explains: The thirty-two-cubit measurement of the ramp is explained by a <i>baraita</i> that states: It <b>is found</b> that the ramp of the altar <b>overhung</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar by one <b>cubit and</b> the <b>surrounding ledge</b> by one <b>cubit,</b> resulting in an aggregate length of thirty-two cubits.

Daf 63a

<b>Rami bar Ḥama says:</b> The slope of <b>each</b> of the <b>minor ramps,</b> was <b>one cubit</b> of rise <b>per three cubits</b> of run; this was true <b>aside from the</b> main <b>ramp of the altar, which</b> rose one cubit in <b>three and a half cubits and one fingerbreadth and one-third of a fingerbreadth,</b> measured <b>by the tip</b> of the thumb. The slope of the main ramp of the altar was slightly less than that of the minor ramps in order to make it easier for the priests to ascend the ramp while holding the sacrificial portions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Handfuls were removed from the meal offerings in any place in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and were consumed within</b> the area enclosed by <b>the curtains by males of the priesthood,</b> prepared <b>in any</b> form of <b>food</b> preparation that he chooses, e.g., roasted or boiled, <b>for</b> one <b>day and night, until midnight.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says: A meal offering that had its handful removed in the Sanctuary</b> is <b>valid, as we found with regard to</b> the <b>removal of</b> the two <b>bowls</b> of frankincense that were placed beside the shewbread on the Table, which was located in the Sanctuary. On Shabbat, these bowls of frankincense were removed and burned on the altar, which allowed the shewbread to be eaten. Removal of the bowls of frankincense paralleled the process of removing a handful from a meal offering; just as the removal of the bowls took place in the Sanctuary, so could the removal of a handful of the meal offering be done in the Sanctuary.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the meal offerings: “And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons, the priests; <b>and he shall take from there</b> his handful” (Leviticus 2:2). The term “from there” indicates that the handful must be taken <b>from a place where the feet of the non-priest</b> who brought the meal offering may <b>stand,</b> i.e., the Temple courtyard, but not the Sanctuary, in direct contradiction to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Ben Beteira says</b> there is a different explanation of the verse. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> the priest <b>removed a handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>that he should return</b> the handful to the vessel <b>and</b> then <b>remove</b> another <b>handful with</b> his <b>right</b> hand? <b>The verse states:</b> “And he shall take <b>from there</b> his handful,” indicating that he may take it <b>from the place where he already removed a handful.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rabbi Yirmeya <b>raises the objection and he resolves it,</b> and <b>there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi Akiva said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: I will explain to you</b> the solution. The verse that indicates that the handful is taken from a place where non-priests may stand <b>is necessary only to render the entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard valid</b> for removing the handful, but not to indicate that one may not take the handful in the Sanctuary.
This was necessary because it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since a burnt offering</b> is one of the <b>offerings of the most sacred order, and a meal offering</b> is also one of the <b>offerings of the most sacred order, just as a burnt offering requires</b> slaughter specifically in the <b>north</b> side of the Temple courtyard, <b>so too, a meal offering requires</b> the taking of the handful specifically in the <b>north</b> side of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara responds: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it is <b>completely</b> burned upon the altar. Therefore, one would not have derived that just as a burnt offering must be slaughtered in the north side of the Temple courtyard, the handful must be taken from a meal offering in the north side of the Temple courtyard.
And if one would attempt to derive that the handful of a meal offering must be taken in the north side of the Temple courtyard <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a sin offering,</b> which is an offering of the most sacred order whose slaughtering must take place in the north side, yet is not completely consumed upon the altar, this too can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it atones for those liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
And if one would attempt to derive that the handful of a meal-offering must be taken in the north side of the Temple courtyard <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to <b>a guilt offering,</b> which is an offering of the most sacred order that must be slaughtered in the north, and that does not share the unique characteristics of the burnt offering or sin offering, this too can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it is one of the <b>types of</b> offerings whose sacrificial rites are performed with their <b>blood,</b> which is not so with regard to a meal offering.
The Gemara adds: It also cannot be suggested to draw an analogy <b>from</b> the common element shared by <b>all of the</b> offerings mentioned above. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about all of them?</b> They are notable <b>in that</b> they are all <b>types of</b> offerings whose sacrificial rites are performed with their <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara presents a different answer: <b>Rather, it was necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to teach that the handful may be taken from the meal offering anywhere in the Temple courtyard because it may <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since it is written: “And he shall bring it to the altar”</b> (Leviticus 2:8), and then it states: <b>“And he shall take up from there his handful”</b> (Leviticus 6:8), indicating that the handful must be taken from the vessel in which the meal offering was brought near the altar, that the verses also indicate that the handful must be taken in the place where the vessel is brought near the altar.
Therefore, <b>just as</b> one must <b>bring</b> the meal offering <b>to</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>so too,</b> the <b>removal of</b> its <b>handful</b> must take place <b>at</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar. To counter this, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that the removal of the handful may take place anywhere in the Temple courtyard.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Peace offerings that one slaughtered in the Sanctuary are valid, as it is stated: “And he shall slaughter it at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), i.e., in the courtyard; <b>and</b> the courtyard, which is of <b>secondary</b> sanctity, <b>should not be weightier than the</b> place of <b>primary</b> sanctity. Accordingly, as the offering is valid if it was slaughtered in the courtyard, it is certainly valid if it was slaughtered in the Sanctuary.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beteira says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that if gentiles surrounded the entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> and were attacking, making it impossible for the priests to remain there, <b>the priests may enter that area,</b> i.e., the Sanctuary, <b>and eat the offerings of the most sacred order there? The verse states: “In a most holy place shall you eat it”</b> (Numbers 18:10).
The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> is there a need to derive the <i>halakha</i> from this source? <b>Let us say</b> that it can be derived from the verse: <b>“In the court of the Tent of Meeting they shall eat it”</b> (Leviticus 6:9), <b>and</b> the place of <b>secondary</b> sanctity <b>should not be weightier than the</b> place of <b>primary</b> sanctity. Therefore, similar to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, if the sacrificial food can be eaten in the courtyard, it can certainly be eaten in the Sanctuary. The fact that the <i>baraita</i> requires another source indicates that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s method of derivation is not valid.
The Gemara answers: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to slaughtering offerings, the act of slaughter is a sacrificial <b>rite,</b> and <b>a person serves in the presence of his master.</b> Therefore, <b>we say</b> that the place of <b>secondary</b> sanctity <b>should not be weightier than the</b> place of <b>primary</b> sanctity, and if one can slaughter an offering in the courtyard, he can certainly do so in the Sanctuary. By contrast, in the case of <b>eating</b> sacrificial food, <b>which</b> is different because <b>a person does not eat in the presence of his master, we do not say</b> the rationale that the place of <b>secondary</b> sanctity <b>should not be weightier than the</b> place of <b>primary</b> sanctity. Therefore, a verse was required to teach that the priest may partake of the offerings in the Sanctuary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The sacrificial rite of <b>a bird sin offering would be performed at</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar. <b>And</b> if its sacrificial rite was performed <b>in any place</b> on the altar, the offering <b>was</b> deemed <b>valid; but that</b> corner <b>was its</b> designated <b>place. And</b> there were <b>three matters</b> for which the portion of <b>that corner below</b> the red line that served as the demarcation between the upper and lower portions of the altar <b>served</b> as the proper location, <b>and</b> there were <b>three</b> matters for which the portion of that corner <b>above</b> the red line served as their proper location. The following rites were performed <b>below</b> the red line: Sacrificing <b>a bird sin offering, and bringing</b> meal offerings <b>near</b> the altar before removal of the handful, <b>and</b> pouring out <b>the remaining blood.</b>
<b>And</b> the following rites were performed <b>above</b> the red line: <b>The wine libation</b> that is brought together with animal offerings or as an offering by itself, <b>and the water</b> libation on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>and</b> sacrificing <b>a bird burnt offering when</b> they were <b>numerous</b> and it was impossible to perform the rite <b>in the east,</b> i.e., the southeastern corner where the bird burnt offering was sacrificed.
<b>All</b> those <b>who ascend</b> the ramp <b>to the altar ascend via</b> the <b>right</b> side of the ramp toward the southeast corner

Daf 63b

<b>and circle</b> the altar until reaching the southwest corner <b>and descend via</b> the <b>left</b> side of the ramp, <b>except for one who ascends for</b> one of <b>these three matters, where they would ascend</b> directly to the southwest corner of the altar, <b>and descend</b> by turning <b>on</b> their <b>heels</b> and retracing the path by which they ascended rather than circling the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks a question about the mishna’s statement that the sacrificial rite of a bird sin offering is performed at the southwest corner of the altar: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: The verse states</b> with regard to the sin offering of a destitute sinner, which is a meal offering brought in lieu of an animal or bird: <b>“He shall put no oil upon it, neither shall he put any frankincense on it; for it is a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 5:11). From this verse it is evident that <b>a sin offering is called a meal offering and a meal offering is called a sin offering,</b> so that their <i>halakhot</i> may be compared.
<b>Just as a sin offering requires</b> slaughtering in the <b>north</b> section of the Temple courtyard, <b>so too,</b> the handful of <b>a meal offering requires</b> sanctification in a service vessel in the <b>north. And just as a meal offering</b> is brought near <b>to</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>so too,</b> the blood of <b>a sin offering</b> is sprinkled <b>on</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering itself, from where do we</b> derive that it must be brought near the altar at the southwest corner? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And this is the law of the meal offering…<b>before the Lord,</b> in front of the altar” (Leviticus 6:7). From the phrase: “Before the Lord,” one <b>might</b> have thought that the rite of bringing the meal offering near the altar must be performed <b>at the west</b> side of the altar, which faces the Sanctuary. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In front of the altar,”</b> which is its south side, from where the priests ascend the ramp.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> the verse merely stated: <b>“In front of the altar,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the practice of bringing the meal offering near the altar must be performed <b>at the south</b> side of the altar. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Before the Lord,”</b> which indicates the west side. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? The priest <b>brings it near at</b> the <b>southwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>opposite the edge of</b> the <b>corner</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> that is <b>sufficient.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that the priest may <b>bring it near</b> the altar <b>to the west of</b> the southwest <b>corner or to the south of</b> the southwest <b>corner. You</b> must <b>say: Anywhere you find two verses,</b> and acting in accordance with <b>one</b> of them <b>fulfills itself,</b> i.e., the requirement stated in that verse, <b>and fulfills the</b> requirement stated in the <b>other</b> verse, whereas acting in accordance with the other <b>one</b> of them <b>fulfills itself and negates the</b> requirement stated in the <b>other</b> verse, <b>one leaves the</b> verse <b>that fulfills itself and negates the other, and seizes</b> the verse <b>that fulfills itself and fulfills the other</b> verse as well.
The Gemara explains: In this context, <b>when you say: “Before the Lord,”</b> which indicates that the meal offering should be brought near the altar <b>at the west</b> side of the altar, <b>how have you fulfilled</b> the other part of the verse: <b>“In front of the altar,”</b> which indicates the south side? <b>But when you say: “In front of the altar,”</b> and bring it near the altar <b>at the south</b> side, <b>you have</b> also <b>fulfilled</b> the phrase: <b>“Before the Lord.”</b> Consequently, the meal offering must be brought near the south side of the altar.
The Gemara asks: If one brought the meal offering near the altar <b>at the south</b> side, <b>how have you fulfilled</b> the phrase: “Before the Lord”? <b>Rav Ashi says: This <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>the entire altar stood in the north</b> section of the Temple courtyard. The southern side of the altar was directly aligned with the midpoint of the Temple courtyard, directly opposite the entrance of the Sanctuary, and therefore it is considered “before the Lord.”
§ The mishna teaches that if the sacrificial rite of a bird sin offering was performed <b>in any place</b> on the altar, the offering is <b>valid,</b> but the southwest corner was its designated place. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the mishna <b>saying</b> when it states that the southwest corner was its designated place? The mishna already stated that the sacrificial rite of a bird sin offering should be performed at the southwest corner. <b>Rav Ashi said: This</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: Any place was valid for its pinching, but</b> the southwest corner <b>was the place for</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of <b>its</b> blood.
The Gemara notes: <b>We learn</b> in this mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a bird sin offering: If the priest <b>pinched its</b> nape <b>in any place on the altar,</b> it is <b>valid.</b> If <b>he sprinkled its blood in any place</b> on the altar, it is <b>valid.</b> If <b>he sprinkled</b> the blood, <b>but did not squeeze out</b> the remaining blood upon the lower part of the wall of the altar, in accordance with the verse: “And he shall sprinkle of the blood of the sin offer-ing upon the side of the altar; and the rest of the blood shall be squeezed out at the base of the altar” (Leviticus 5:9), it is nevertheless <b>valid, provided that he places</b> some <b>of the blood of the soul</b> anywhere on the altar <b>from the red line and below.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> It first states that the offering is valid no matter where on the altar its blood is sprinkled, and it then states that blood must be placed specifically below the red line. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>he pinched its</b> nape <b>in any place on the altar,</b> it is <b>valid.</b> If <b>he squeezed out its blood in any place on the altar,</b> it is <b>valid,</b>

Daf 64a

<b>because if he sprinkled</b> the blood <b>but did not squeeze out</b> the rest of it, it is still <b>valid, provided that he places</b> some <b>of the blood of the soul</b> anywhere on the altar <b>from the red line and below.</b> This version of the <i>baraita</i> states that the offering is valid no matter where on the altar its blood was squeezed out; but it is essential that blood is sprinkled on the lower half of the altar.
§ The mishna teaches that there were <b>three matters</b> for which the portion of the southwest corner below the red line served as the proper location: The sacrificing of a bird sin offering, and the bringing of the meal offerings near the altar, and pouring the remaining blood. The Gemara cites sources to prove that each of these three matters was performed at the southwest corner: The source with regard to <b>the bird sin offering</b> is <b>that which we said</b> earlier (63b), that it is derived from a comparison to meal offerings.
The source for <b>bringing</b> meal offerings <b>near</b> the altar at the southwest corner is derived from that <b>which is written: “And he shall bring it to the front of the altar.”</b> The source for pouring <b>the remaining blood</b> at the southwest corner of the altar is <b>as it is written: “And all the remaining blood of the bull he shall pour out at the base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 4:7), which the Gemara derives to be referring to the southwest corner (see 53a).
§ The mishna teaches that there were three matters for which the portion of the southwest corner <b>above</b> the red line served as the proper location: <b>The water and wine libations, and</b> sacrificing <b>a bird burnt offering when</b> they were <b>numerous in the east,</b> i.e., the southeast corner. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> the sacrificial rites of a bird burnt offering were ideally supposed to be performed at the southeast corner of the altar? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Because it is the closest</b> of all the corners <b>to the place of the ashes,</b> i.e., the place where the ashes from the altar are placed every morning. The crop and feathers of a bird burnt offering are placed there as well.
The Gemara cites a comment pertaining to the mishna’s statement that when the southeast corner of the altar is too crowded, the sacrificial rites of a bird burnt offering can be performed at the southwest corner: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Come and see how great</b> was <b>the strength of the priests, as you have no</b> parts <b>of birds lighter than the crop and feathers,</b> and there were <b>times when the priest would toss them more than thirty cubits</b> from the southwest corner of the altar to the place of the ashes.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 28b) describing the procedure of separating the ashes: The priest <b>would take a coal pan of silver and ascend to the top of the altar and clear the</b> upper layer of <b>coals to</b> this <b>side and to</b> that <b>side, and,</b> using the coal pan, <b>scoop up</b> coals <b>from</b> among <b>the inner, consumed</b> coals <b>and descend</b> the ramp. When he <b>reached the floor</b> of the Temple courtyard, he would <b>turn his face</b> to the left, <b>toward the north, and walk about ten cubits along the eastern</b> side of the ramp. There, he would <b>heap the coals upon the floor</b> at <b>a distance</b> of <b>three handbreadths from the ramp.</b> This was <b>the location where one places</b> the <b>crop and feathers, and the ashes removed from the inner altar and the Candelabrum.</b>
The Gemara challenges: The distance from the southwest corner to the location described in that mishna <b>is more than thirty-one cubits.</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>did not consider the space</b> taken up by <b>people,</b> i.e., the priest performing the service, in his calculation.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>everyone who ascends</b> the ramp <b>to the altar</b> ascends via the right side of the ramp, circles the altar until reaching the southwest corner, and descends via the left side of the ramp, with the exception of one ascending in order to perform the wine or water libations, or to sacrifice a bird burnt offering on the southwest corner of the altar. In those cases the priest would ascend directly to the southwest corner. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for these exceptions to the standard practice? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to the <b>libations,</b> the priest would not walk all the way around the altar <b>lest</b> the wine or water <b>absorb</b> the <b>smoke</b> of the altar fire. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a bird burnt offering</b> he would not walk all the way around <b>lest</b> the bird <b>die from</b> inhaling <b>the smoke.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the following mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 33b): If the High Priest was performing the sacrificial rites of the daily offering, after he would place the limbs on the fire on top of the altar and <b>he would come to circle the altar, from where does he start</b> walking? He starts <b>from</b> the <b>southeast corner,</b> continues to the <b>northeast</b> corner, then to the <b>northwest</b> corner, and finally arrives at the <b>southwest</b> corner. <b>And he is given wine to pour</b> on the altar. This indicates that the High Priest circles the altar while holding the wine for the libation, and there is no concern that it will absorb too much smoke.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b>

Daf 64b

The <b>circling</b> around the altar by the High Priest is done <b>on foot,</b> i.e., empty-handed, as he was given the wine to pour only once he arrived at the southwest corner. <b>Rava said:</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> that <b>he is given wine to pour, and</b> the mishna <b>does not teach</b> that <b>one tells him</b> to <b>pour</b> the wine, which would have indicated that the High Priest was already holding the wine as he circled the altar. The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude from</b> the language of the mishna that the High Priest was given the wine only once he arrived at the southwest corner of the altar.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All</b> those <b>who ascend</b> the ramp to <b>the altar ascend via</b> the <b>right</b> side of the ramp <b>and descend via</b> the <b>left</b> side; they <b>ascend via</b> the <b>east</b> side of the ramp <b>and descend via</b> the <b>west</b> side, <b>except for one who ascends for</b> one of <b>these three matters:</b> The wine libation, the water libation, and the sacrificial rite of a bird burnt offering. In these cases, one <b>ascends via</b> the <b>west</b> side of the ramp <b>and descends via</b> the <b>west</b> side; one <b>ascends via</b> the <b>right</b> side <b>and descends via</b> the <b>right</b> side.
The Gemara asks: Does one who ascends via the west side of the ramp do so <b>via</b> the <b>right</b> side? Ascending via the west side of the ramp <b>is</b> the same as ascending <b>via</b> the <b>left. Ravina says:</b> Emend the <i>baraita</i> so that it <b>teaches</b> that he ascends via the <b>left</b> side. <b>Rava says: What</b> is the meaning of the <b>right</b> side mentioned in the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>? It is the <b>right</b> side from the standpoint <b>of</b> the <b>altar,</b> facing south, in which case the altar’s west side is synonymous with its right side. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the <b>left</b> side mentioned in the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>? It is the <b>left</b> side from the standpoint <b>of a person</b> facing the altar.
The Gemara objects: <b>But let</b> the <i>baraita</i> be consistent and <b>teach</b> both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, i.e., the first clause and latter clause, from the standpoint <b>of the altar, or</b> let it teach both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case from the standpoint <b>of a person</b> facing the altar. The Gemara concedes: This is <b>difficult.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The sacrifice of <b>the bird sin offering, how was it performed?</b> The priest <b>would pinch</b> off <b>the</b> bird’s <b>head</b> by cutting <b>opposite its nape</b> with his thumbnail <b>and</b> would <b>not separate</b> the bird’s head from its body. <b>And he sprinkles from its blood on the wall of the altar</b> below the red line. <b>The remaining blood would be squeezed out</b> from the body of the bird <b>on the base</b> of the altar. <b>The altar has only its blood and the entire</b> bird goes <b>to the priests</b> for consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the bird sin offering: <b>“And he shall sprinkle of the blood of the sin offering</b> upon the side of the altar” (Leviticus 5:9). This teaches that the blood is sprinkled directly <b>from the body of the sin offering,</b> not with the priest’s finger or from a vessel. <b>How so?</b> The priest <b>holds the head and the body and sprinkles</b> its blood <b>on the wall of the altar. And</b> he does <b>not</b> sprinkle it <b>on the wall of the ramp, and not on the wall of</b> the <b>Sanctuary, and not on the wall of</b> the <b>Entrance Hall. And which</b> is this wall of the altar that the blood is sprinkled on? <b>This is the lower wall,</b> below the red line.
The <i>baraita</i> suggests: <b>Or</b> perhaps the verse is referring <b>only</b> to <b>the upper wall,</b> above the red line. <b>And</b> this should be <b>a logical inference: Just as</b> with regard to <b>an animal</b> offering, <b>where</b> the blood of <b>a burnt offering</b> is applied <b>below</b> the red line (see 10b), nevertheless, the blood of <b>the sin offering</b> is applied <b>above</b> the red line (see Leviticus 4:30), with regard to <b>a bird</b> offering, <b>where</b> the blood of <b>the burnt offering</b> is sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line (see 65a), <b>is it not logical that</b> the blood of <b>its sin offering</b> is sprinkled <b>above</b> the red line?
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And the rest of the blood shall be squeezed out [<i>yimmatze</i>] at the base of the altar”</b> (Leviticus 5:9), which teaches that the priest sprinkles the blood on the <b>wall where its remaining</b> blood <b>drains to the base</b> of the altar. <b>And which</b> wall is this? <b>This is the lower wall.</b> The surrounding ledge of the altar is located one cubit above the red line, and any blood sprinkled above this ledge will not drip down to the base of the altar. The verse teaches that the blood is sprinkled on the wall of the altar from which it would drip down to the altar’s base unimpeded.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the sprinkling of the blood <b>above,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> logically deduced, <b>and then perform</b> the squeezing <b>below</b> in fulfillment of the aforementioned verse. <b>Rava said: Is it written: He shall drain [<i>yematze</i>]? It is written: It shall be drained [<i>yimmatze</i>], which indicates</b> that the blood trickles down to the base of the altar <b>by itself.</b> Accordingly, the blood must be sprinkled on a part of the altar wall from which it can trickle down to the base of the altar.
§ <b>Rav Zutra bar Toviyya says</b> that <b>Rav says: How</b> does the priest <b>pinch</b> the nape of <b>a bird sin offering?</b> He holds the bird by its back in the palm of his hand and <b>holds its wings with two fingers,</b> i.e., the middle and index fingers, <b>and</b> its <b>two legs with</b> his next <b>two fingers,</b> i.e., the ring finger and pinky, leaving the head resting between his index finger and thumb, <b>and he stretches its neck over the width of his thumb and pinches</b> its nape with his thumbnail.
The Gemara cites a varying opinion: <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The bird</b> is not in the priest’s palm, but rather <b>on the outside</b> of his hand. The priest <b>holds its wings with two fingers and</b> its <b>two legs with two fingers.</b> Using his thumb, the priest bends its head into his palm <b>and stretches its neck over the width of his two fingers, and pinches</b> its nape. <b>And this</b> is the most <b>difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rite in the Temple</b> to perform.
The Gemara asks: <b>This is</b> the most difficult rite to perform, <b>and no other? But isn’t there</b> also the <b>removal of the handful</b> of the meal offering <b>and the handful</b> of the incense on Yom Kippur? The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, say</b> that the pinching procedure was <b>a difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rite,</b> one <b>of the</b> most <b>difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rites in the Temple</b> to perform.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The sacrifice of <b>the bird burnt offering, how was it performed?</b> The priest <b>ascended the ramp and turned to the surrounding ledge and came to</b> the <b>southeast corner</b> of the altar. He <b>would</b> then <b>pinch</b> off <b>the</b> bird’s <b>head</b> by cutting <b>at its nape</b> with his thumbnail <b>and separate</b> the bird’s head from its body, <b>and</b> would <b>squeeze out its blood on the wall of the altar. He took the head and neared the place of its pinching,</b> i.e., its nape, <b>to the altar</b> in order to squeeze the blood from the head. <b>He would</b> then <b>absorb</b> the remaining blood <b>with salt and throw</b> the head <b>onto the fire</b> on the altar.
<b>He</b> then <b>arrived at the body and removed the crop and the feather</b> attached to it <b>and the innards that emerge with them and he tossed them to the place of the ashes. He</b> then <b>ripped</b> the bird lengthwise <b>and did not separate</b> the two halves of the bird; <b>but if he separated</b> them, the offering is <b>valid.</b> He would then <b>absorb</b> the remaining blood <b>with salt and throw</b> the body of the bird <b>onto the fire</b> on the altar.
If <b>he neither removed the crop, nor the feather and the innards that emerge with them, nor absorbed</b> the blood <b>with salt,</b> with regard to <b>any</b> detail <b>that he changed in</b> the sacrificial rites <b>after he squeezed out its blood,</b> the offering is <b>valid.</b> If <b>he separated</b> the head from the body <b>in</b> sacrificing <b>the sin offering, or</b> if <b>he did not separate</b> the head from the body <b>in</b> sacrificing <b>the burnt offering,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> In a case where <b>he squeezed out the blood of the head and did not squeeze out the blood of the body, it is disqualified.</b> If he squeezed out the <b>blood of the body and did not squeeze out the blood of the head,</b> the offering is <b>valid.</b>
In the case of <b>a bird sin offering that</b> the priest <b>pinched not for its sake,</b> or if <b>he squeezed out its blood not for its sake,</b> or if he did so <b>for its sake and</b> then <b>not for its sake, or not for its sake and</b> then <b>for its sake,</b> it is <b>disqualified,</b> like all other sin offerings that are disqualified when performed not for their sake (see 2a). <b>A bird burnt offering</b> sacrificed not for its sake is <b>valid;</b> it is <b>just that it did not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b>
With regard to <b>both a bird sin offering and a bird burnt offering where</b> the priest <b>pinched its nape or squeezed out its blood</b> with the intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>burns</b> it on the altar, <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> But <b>there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> one who partakes of the offering. If his intent was to eat it or burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and</b> one is <b>liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of the offering, <b>provided that the permitting factor,</b> the blood, <b>was sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If one <b>pinched</b> the nape <b>in silence,</b> i.e., with no disqualifying intent, <b>and squeezed out</b> its <b>blood</b> with the intent to partake of the parts typically eaten or to burn the portions that are to be burned on the altar, <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> in the case of one <b>who pinched</b> with the intent to partake of the offering or burn it on the altar <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and squeezed out</b> its <b>blood in silence; or</b> in the case of one <b>who pinched and squeezed out the blood</b> with the intent to partake of the offering or burn it on the altar <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, that is</b> the case of a bird offering <b>where</b> the <b>permitting factor is sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If the priest <b>pinched</b> the nape of the bird with the intent to partake of it or burn it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> and <b>squeezed out</b> its <b>blood</b> with the intent to partake of it or burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, or</b> he <b>pinched</b> with the intent to partake of it or burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time and squeezed out</b> its <b>blood</b> with the intent to partake of it or burn it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, or</b> if the priest <b>pinched and squeezed out the blood</b> with the intent to partake of it or burn it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b>

Daf 65a

or in the case of <b>a bird sin offering where one pinched</b> its nape <b>not for its sake and squeezed out</b> its <b>blood</b> with the intent of consuming it or burning it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, or</b> in a case <b>where he pinched</b> its nape with the intent to consume it or burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time and squeezed out</b> its <b>blood not for its sake, or</b> in a case <b>where he pinched</b> its nape <b>and squeezed out its blood not for its sake, that is</b> a case of a bird offering <b>whose permitting factor is not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
If one pinched the nape of the bird and squeezed out its blood with the intent <b>to eat an olive-bulk</b> of the offering <b>outside</b> its designated area and <b>an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, or <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>half an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, the offering is <b>disqualified and</b> it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> disagreed and <b>said</b> that <b>this is the principle: If the</b> improper <b>intent</b> with regard to <b>the time preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating <b>it. And if the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified and</b> it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And the Rabbis say:</b> In both <b>this</b> case where the intent with regard to time came first <b>and that</b> case where the intent with regard to area came first, the offering is <b>disqualified and</b> it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
If his intent was <b>to eat half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> not at the appropriate time or in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>valid, because eating and burning do not join together.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse pertaining to a bird burnt offering: “And the priest shall bring it to the altar, and pinch off its head, and make it smoke on the altar” (Leviticus 1:15). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it</b> to the altar? Since the previous verse states that “he shall bring his offering,” this verse should have started with the phrase “And he shall pinch off its head.”
<b>Since it is stated</b> in the preceding verse: “And if his offering to the Lord be a burnt offering of birds, <b>then he shall bring</b> his offering <b>of doves, or of pigeons”</b> (Leviticus 1:14), one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who donates a bird</b> as an offering <b>may not</b> donate <b>fewer than two birds.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it,”</b> indicating that <b>one may bring even one bird to</b> be sacrificed on <b>the altar.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues analyzing the verse: <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> that <b>“the priest</b> shall bring it to the altar” (Leviticus 1:15)? It is <b>to establish</b> that only <b>a priest</b> may pinch its nape, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that even a non-priest may perform this procedure. <b>Could this not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference: And if</b> with regard to <b>a sheep</b> burnt offering, with regard to <b>which</b> the verse <b>established</b> that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered in the <b>north</b> (see Leviticus 1:11), it did <b>not establish</b> that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered by a <b>priest</b> (see 32a), then in the case of <b>a bird</b> burnt offering, with regard to <b>which</b> the verse <b>did not establish</b> that its nape must be pinched in the <b>north, is it not logical that</b> the verse does <b>not establish</b> that its nape must be pinched by <b>a priest?</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states</b> that <b>“the priest</b> shall bring it to the altar,” in order <b>to establish</b> that its nape must be pinched specifically by <b>a priest.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that the priest should <b>pinch its</b> nape <b>with a knife. And</b> one could derive this through <b>a logical inference: And if</b> with regard to <b>slaughtering,</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the verse <b>did not establish</b> that <b>it</b> must be performed by <b>a priest,</b> it <b>established</b> that <b>it</b> must be performed with <b>an instrument,</b> i.e., a knife (see 97b); then in the case of <b>pinching, which</b> the verse <b>established</b> must be performed by <b>a priest, is it not logical that</b> the verse <b>establishes</b> that <b>it</b> must be performed with <b>an instrument?</b>
To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “And the <b>priest</b> shall bring it near the altar <b>and pinch off</b> its head.” In explanation of this verse, <b>Rabbi Akiva said: Could it enter your mind that a non-priest may approach</b> the <b>altar</b> in order to sacrifice an offering? Since this is impossible, the verse does not need to state that the sacrificial rite is performed by a priest. <b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “The <b>priest”?</b> It means <b>that the pinching must be</b> performed <b>with the very</b> body of the <b>priest.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues to analyze the verse: One <b>might</b> have thought that the priest <b>may pinch</b> the bird’s nape <b>whether above</b> the red line of the altar <b>or below</b> it. To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “And the priest shall bring it unto the altar <b>and pinch off</b> its head, <b>and make it smoke</b> on the altar.” The verse juxtaposes the pinching to the burning of the bird on the altar to teach that <b>just as</b> the <b>burning</b> occurs <b>atop the altar, so too,</b> the <b>pinching</b> occurs <b>on</b> the <b>top</b> part of the wall of <b>the altar.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The verse states that the priest shall <b>“pinch off</b> its head,” which must be performed <b>at the nape. Do you say</b> that the pinching occurs <b>at the nape, or</b> is it <b>only at the throat? It</b> can be derived through <b>a logical inference:</b> It <b>is stated here,</b> with regard to a bird burnt offering: <b>“And pinch off</b> its head” (Leviticus 1:15), <b>and</b> it <b>is stated there,</b> with regard to a bird sin offering: <b>“And pinch off</b> its head opposite its nape, but shall not separate it” (Leviticus 5:8). <b>Just as there,</b> the head is pinched <b>at the nape, so too here,</b> the head is pinched <b>at the nape.</b>
<b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a bird burnt offering is derived from that of a bird sin offering, perhaps it should also be derived that <b>just as there,</b> the priest <b>pinches</b> off the head <b>but does not separate</b> it completely from the body, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to a bird burnt offering, he <b>pinches</b> off the head <b>but does not separate</b> it from the body. To counter this, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to a bird burnt offering: <b>“And pinch off</b> its head, <b>and make it smoke</b> on the altar” (Leviticus 1:15). This indicates that <b>just as</b> with regard to the <b>burning</b> of the bird burnt offering, <b>the head</b> is burned <b>by itself and the body</b> is burned <b>by itself, so too</b> with regard to the <b>pinching, the head</b> is <b>by itself and the body</b> is <b>by itself,</b> i.e., the head is completely detached from the body.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that the burning of the head</b> is <b>by itself and the body</b> is burned <b>by itself? As it is stated:</b> “And he shall rend it by its wings…<b>and</b> the priest <b>shall make it smoke</b> upon the altar” (Leviticus 1:17).
