Since <b>the burning of the body is stated</b> in this verse, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the earlier phrase: <b>“And make it smoke on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:15)? One must conclude that <b>the verse is speaking about the burning of the head.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues to expound the verse stated with regard to a bird burnt offering: “And its blood shall be drained out on the wall of the altar” (Leviticus 1:15). When the verse states: <b>“And its blood shall be drained out,”</b> it means that <b>all of it</b> must be drained out. The continuation of the verse indicates that it must be drained out <b>“on the wall of the altar,” and not on the wall of the ramp, nor on the wall of the Sanctuary. And which</b> wall of the altar <b>is this? This is the upper wall,</b> i.e., above the red line.
<b>Or</b> perhaps the verse is referring <b>only</b> to <b>the lower wall,</b> i.e., below the red line; <b>and this</b> can be supported by <b>a logical inference:</b> And <b>if</b> with regard to <b>an animal</b> offering, <b>where</b> the blood of <b>its sin offering</b> is applied <b>above</b> the red line, the blood of <b>its burnt offering</b> is applied <b>below</b> the red line, then with regard to <b>a bird</b> offering, <b>where</b> the blood of <b>its sin offering</b> is sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line, <b>is it not logical that</b> the blood of <b>its burnt offering</b> is sprinkled <b>below</b> the red line?
To counter this, <b>the verse states: “And pinch off</b> its head, <b>and make it smoke</b> on the altar; <b>and its blood shall be drained out.” Could it enter your mind</b> that <b>after he has burned</b> the bird, the priest <b>goes back and drains out</b> its blood? <b>Rather,</b> the verse serves <b>to tell you: Just as</b> the <b>burning</b> occurs <b>atop the altar, so too,</b> the <b>draining</b> occurs <b>atop the altar. How so?</b> The priest <b>would ascend the ramp and turn to the surrounding ledge and arrive at</b> the <b>southeast corner. He would pinch off the</b> bird’s <b>head at its nape, and separate</b> it from its body. <b>He would</b> then <b>squeeze out its blood on the wall of the altar</b> beside him. Nevertheless, <b>if</b> the priest <b>performed</b> the squeezing <b>below his feet,</b> i.e., below the surrounding ledge, <b>even</b> one <b>cubit</b> beneath the ledge, it is <b>valid.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes by citing a dissenting opinion: <b>Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov say: The entire</b> rite of a bird burnt offering <b>is performed only atop the altar.</b> The Gemara asks: Since the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov agree that the bird must be burned atop the altar and its blood must be squeezed on the top part of the wall of the altar, <b>what is</b> the difference <b>between them?</b>
<b>Abaye and Rava both say: There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to whether one may <b>form an arrangement</b> of wood <b>on</b> the <b>surrounding ledge</b> and burn the bird there. According to the first <i>tanna</i>, this is permitted when needed, and therefore it is valid if the priest squeezes out the blood on the wall up to a cubit below the surrounding ledge. According the Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, one may never burn the bird on the surrounding ledge, and therefore it is not valid if the priest squeezed out the blood below the surrounding ledge.
§ The mishna teaches that after the priest throws the bird’s head onto the fire on the altar, <b>he arrives at the body</b> and removes the crop and the feathers attached to it and the innards that emerge with them, and tosses them to the place of the ashes. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse pertaining to a bird burnt offering: <b>“And he shall take away <i>murato</i> with its feathers”</b> (Leviticus 1:16). <b>This</b> word, <i>murato</i>, is referring to the <b>crop.</b>
Had the verse written only “its crop,” one <b>might</b> have thought that the priest may <b>cut</b> the skin <b>with a knife and take</b> the crop without any other part of the bird. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “With its feathers [<i>benotzatah</i>],”</b> which teaches that <b>he takes the feathers with it,</b> i.e., he must remove the skin with the feathers still attached. The Gemara presents another opinion: <b>Abba Yosei ben Ḥanan says: He takes</b> the crop <b>and he</b> also <b>takes its gizzard with it.</b>
A Sage <b>from the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The word <b><i>benotzatah</i></b> is a contraction of the words <b><i>benotza shelah</i>,</b> meaning its feathers. This teaches that the priest <b>cuts it with a knife,</b> creating an opening <b>like a window</b> opposite the crop. This allows him to remove the crop with only the feathers and skin directly opposite it, and that is what he brings to the place of the ashes.

Daf 65b

§ The mishna teaches that after removing the crop and the feathers and innards that emerged with it, the priest <b>ripped</b> the bird lengthwise <b>and did not separate</b> the two halves of the bird. In this regard <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And he shall rend”</b> (Leviticus 1:17). The act of <b>rending is</b> performed <b>only by hand, and so too,</b> the verse <b>states</b> with regard to Samson: <b>“And he rent it as one would have rent a kid,</b> and he had nothing in his hand” (Judges 14:6).
§ The mishna teaches that if the priest <b>did not remove the crop,</b> or he changed any detail of the sacrificial rite after he squeezed out the blood, the offering is valid. If he separated the head from the body of a bird sin offering, it is disqualified. The Gemara says: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said: I heard that one may separate</b> the head from the body <b>of a bird sin offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the reason for the difference <b>between them,</b> i.e., what is the basis of the disagreement? <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> concerns the question of whether <b>squeezing out</b> the blood of <b>a bird sin offering</b> after its blood has been sprinkled is <b>indispensable. The first <i>tanna</i>,</b> whose opinion is cited in the mishna, <b>holds</b> that <b>squeezing out</b> the blood of <b>a bird sin offering</b> is <b>indispensable. And since squeezing out</b> the <b>blood</b> is indispensable, the priest will have to squeeze out the blood after separating the head from the body, and he will have <b>performed the rite of</b> a bird <b>burnt offering on a bird sin offering,</b> which disqualifies the offering (see 66a).
<b>And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds</b> that <b>squeezing out</b> the blood of <b>a bird sin offering is not indispensable.</b> Consequently, if the priest would separate the bird’s head from its body, he would refrain from squeezing out the blood, in which case the rite is dissimilar to that of a bird burnt offering. <b>And</b> the separation of the head <b>is</b> considered as though the priest was <b>merely cutting flesh,</b> and the offering is valid.
<b>Rava says</b> there is an alternative explanation of the dispute: It is possible that all agree that squeezing the blood of a bird sin offering is indispensable, and <b>there is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to whether <b>interrupting</b> the pinching before severing the <b>second <i>siman</i>,</b> i.e., the gullet or windpipe, one of the organs that must be cut in the ritual slaughter, <b>of a bird burnt offering disqualifies</b> the offering. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>interrupting</b> the pinching before severing the <b>second <i>siman</i> of a bird burnt offering does not disqualify</b> the offering, <b>and</b> therefore, if the priest separates the head of a bird sin offering from its body, <b>even though he interrupted</b> the pinching before severing the second <i>siman</i>, <b>he has performed the rite of</b> a bird <b>burnt offering on</b> a bird <b>sin offering,</b> which disqualifies it.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds</b> that interrupting the pinching of a bird burnt offering <b>disqualifies</b> the offering. Therefore, in the case of a bird sin offering, <b>since</b> the priest <b>interrupted</b> the pinching before severing the second <i>siman</i>, even if he separates the head from the body <b>he is merely cutting flesh,</b> i.e., it is an insignificant act because he is not performing the rite of a burnt offering on a sin offering, and the offering is not disqualified.
<b>Abaye says</b> there is a third explanation of the dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i>: It is possible that all agree that interrupting the pinching before severing the second <i>siman</i> disqualifies a bird burnt offering, and <b>there is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to whether cutting the <b>majority of</b> the <b>flesh</b> of the nape of a bird sin offering is <b>indispensable.</b>
The Gemara points out: <b>And</b> Rava and Abaye disagree <b>with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak. One says</b> that the difference <b>between</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, concerns whether <b>interrupting</b> the pinching before severing the <b>second <i>siman</i> of a bird burnt offering disqualifies</b> the offering. <b>And one says</b> that the difference <b>between them</b> concerns whether cutting the <b>majority of</b> the <b>flesh</b> of the nape of a bird sin offering is <b>indispensable.</b>
The Gemara asks: Since there is a dispute concerning whether cutting the majority of the flesh of the nape of a bird sin offering is indispensable, can it be deduced <b>by inference</b> that all agree <b>that we require</b> the priest to cut <b>the majority of the flesh <i>ab initio</i>?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes; and</b> similarly it <b>was taught</b> in <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one pinch</b> the nape of <b>a bird sin offering?</b> Using his thumbnail, the priest <b>cuts</b> the <b>spine and nape, without</b> cutting through the <b>majority of</b> the <b>flesh, until he reaches</b> either <b>the gullet or the windpipe.</b> Upon <b>reaching the gullet or the windpipe, he cuts one <i>siman</i></b> entirely, <b>or</b> at least <b>the majority of it, and</b> he cuts <b>the majority of the flesh with it. And in</b> the case of a bird <b>burnt offering,</b> he cuts the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>or the majority of the two</b> <i>simanim</i>.
The Gemara relates that the Rabbis <b>said this</b> dispute between the <i>amora’im</i> concerning the reason for the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said: Have they not heard that which Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim said in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Pedat, in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua: Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, used to say: I heard that one may</b> completely <b>separate</b> the head of <b>a bird sin offering</b> from its body. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the verse that states: “But <b>shall not separate it”</b> (Leviticus 5:8)?

Daf 66a

It means that the priest <b>does not have to separate</b> it, but not that it is prohibited to do so. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: If that is so,</b> then <b>with regard to a pit</b> in the public domain, <b>where it is written:</b> “And if a man shall open a pit…<b>and does not cover it”</b> (Exodus 21:33), can one claim that this verse <b>also</b> means <b>that he does not have to cover</b> it?
The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> with regard to a pit, <b>since it is written</b> in the following verse: <b>“The owner of the pit shall pay”</b> (Exodus 21:34), it is evident that <b>it is incumbent upon him to cover</b> the pit. <b>But here, since it is written</b> with regard to a bird burnt offering: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it</b> to the altar” (Leviticus 1:15), the term “it” indicates that the verse is referring only to a burnt offering, and <b>the verse has</b> thereby <b>differentiated between a bird sin offering and a bird burnt offering.</b>
Consequently, it is obvious that whereas the priest must completely separate the head of a bird burnt offering, this is not the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a sin offering. <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to state with regard to a bird sin offering: “But <b>shall not separate it”</b> (Leviticus 5:8)? <b>Conclude from</b> this verse that it is not forbidden to separate the head of a bird sin offering from the body, but rather <b>one does not have to separate</b> it.
§ The mishna teaches that if the priest squeezed out the blood of the head and did not squeeze out the blood of the body, it is disqualified. If he <b>squeezed out</b> the <b>blood of the body</b> and did not squeeze out the blood of the head, the offering is valid. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In reference to a bird burnt offering, the verse states, seemingly unnecessarily: “It is <b>a burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 1:17). This teaches <b>that even though</b> the priest <b>squeezed out the blood of the body and did not squeeze out the blood of the head,</b> it is valid. One <b>might</b> have thought that if the priest <b>squeezed out the blood of the head and did not squeeze out the blood of the body</b> the offering is still valid. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It is.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> for the opinion that the offering is valid if the priest squeezed out only the blood of the body but not if he squeezed out only the blood of the head? <b>Ravina said:</b> There is no conclusive proof from the language of the verse itself, but it <b>stands to reason</b> that this is the case, <b>as most of the blood is found in the body,</b> not the head.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the priest <b>sacrificed a bird sin offering</b> in its designated place <b>below</b> the red line, and he sacrificed it <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering</b> with pinching, i.e., cutting from the nape with a fingernail, and sprinkling, and he sacrificed it <b>for the sake of a sin offering,</b> the offering is <b>fit.</b> This is the manner in which a priest is to sacrifice a sin offering <i>ab initio</i>.
If the priest sacrificed the bird sin offering below the red line in the middle of the altar and <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering,</b> but he sacrificed it <b>for the sake of a burnt offering;</b> or if he sacrificed it <b>according to the procedure of a burnt offering,</b> even if he sacrificed it <b>for the sake of a sin offering;</b> or if he sacrificed it <b>according to the procedure of a burnt offering for the sake of a burnt offering;</b> in all these cases the sin offering is <b>disqualified.</b> If <b>one sacrificed</b> a bird sin offering <b>above</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of any of</b> the offerings, it is <b>disqualified,</b> because he did not sacrifice it in its designated place.
<b>A bird burnt offering that one sacrificed</b> in its designated place <b>above</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a burnt offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a burnt offering</b> is <b>fit.</b> This is the manner in which a priest is to sacrifice a burnt offering <i>ab initio</i>. If he sacrificed a bird burnt offering above the red line <b>according to the procedure of</b> the <b>burnt offering</b> but <b>for the sake of a sin offering,</b> the offering is <b>fit, but it did not satisfy the obligation of its owner.</b>
If the priest sacrificed a bird burnt offering <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering for the sake of a burnt offering,</b> or <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering for the sake of a sin offering,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified.</b> If <b>he sacrificed it below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of any of</b> the offerings, it is <b>disqualified,</b> because he did not sacrifice it in its designated place.

Daf 66b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> According to the mishna, a bird sin offer-ing that one sacrificed according to the procedure of a burnt offering is disqualified. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> rite <b>did</b> the priest <b>change</b> the procedure? <b>If we say that he changed</b> the <b>pinching</b> by severing the head completely, as is proper for a burnt offering, shall <b>we say that</b> the mishna <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says: I heard that</b> the priests would <b>sever</b> the head completely even <b>in</b> the sacrifice of <b>a bird sin offering?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>And</b> what is wrong with this conclusion? <b>Have we not</b> already <b>explained that</b> the mishna in the previous chapter (65a), with regard to pinching, <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon?</b>
The Gemara offers another explanation: <b>No,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>changed</b> the procedure <b>in</b> the rite of <b>sprinkling</b> by squeezing out all the blood at once, as one would do with a burnt offering, rather than first sprinkling the blood on the altar as is proper for a sin offering. Under such circumstances, Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, would also agree that the offering is disqualified.
<b>This, too, stands to reason</b> that the mishna is referring to a change in the sprinkling. This can be inferred <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> If <b>one sacrificed</b> a bird sin offering <b>above</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of any of</b> the offerings, it is <b>disqualified, and</b> this applies <b>even</b> if he sacrificed it <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering. With regard to what</b> rite <b>did</b> the priest <b>change</b> the location of the procedure? <b>If we say that he changed</b> the <b>pinching,</b> performing it above the red line, <b>didn’t the Master</b> already <b>say</b> with regard to a bird sin offering that <b>pinching is valid anywhere on the altar? Rather, is it not that he changed</b> the location of the <b>sprinkling? And since</b> the ruling of <b>the latter clause</b> is stated <b>with regard to sprinkling,</b> by inference, the ruling of <b>the first clause</b> is <b>also</b> stated <b>with regard to sprinkling.</b>
The Gemara responds to this proof: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b> Even if the ruling of the latter clause is stated with regard to a change in the location of the sprinkling, the ruling of the first clause may still be stated with regard to a change in the procedure of the pinching, in which case the mishna would not be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.
§ According to the mishna, <b>a bird burnt offering</b> that one sacrificed according to the procedure of a sin offering is disqualified. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> rite <b>did</b> the priest <b>change</b> the procedure?
<b>If we say</b> that <b>he changed</b> the <b>pinching</b> of the bird’s nape by leaving the head partially attached, as is proper for a sin offering, then <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause,</b> i.e., the first clause of the next mishna (66b), <b>teaches: All of</b> the offerings enumerated above <b>do not render</b> one who swallows their meat <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat, and</b> one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, by inference, <b>we</b> must <b>say</b> that the mishna <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. As, if</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, doesn’t he say</b> later on in that mishna concerning a burnt offering whose nape was pinched according to the procedure of a sin offering: One who derives benefit from it is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property?
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be referring to a change <b>in</b> the procedure of <b>squeezing</b> out the blood. Instead of squeezing out the blood, the priest sprinkled it on the wall of the altar as if it were a sin offering. In this case, even Rabbi Yehoshua would concede that one is liable for misusing it.
But <b>say the last clause</b> of the subsequent mishna: In the case of <b>a bird burnt offering that one sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering,</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering, Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One who benefits <b>from it</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, as it remains a burnt offering. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> One who benefits <b>from it</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, as the bird assumes the status of a sin offering. Here, <b>with regard to what</b> rite <b>did</b> the priest <b>change</b> the procedure and perform it as if it were a sin offering?
<b>If we say</b> that he changed the <b>squeezing,</b> this poses a difficulty, as it is reasonable to <b>say that Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that one is not liable for misuse specifically <b>when</b> the priest <b>changed</b> the <b>pinching,</b> as pinching a burnt offering for a bird as though it were a sin offering changes its status; but <b>does he say</b> this <b>in</b> a case where it was pinched properly, and the priest changed the <b>squeezing</b> procedure alone? It is unreasonable to suggest that the offering changes its status at this later stage.
<b>Rather,</b> this final clause must be referring to a change <b>with regard to</b> the <b>pinching.</b> But can it be that <b>the first clause</b> concerning a sin offering sacrificed as a burnt offering <b>and the last clause</b> concerning the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua are both referring to a change <b>with regard to</b> the <b>pinching, but the middle clause</b> concerning a burnt offering sacrificed as a sin offering is referring to a change <b>with regard to</b> the <b>squeezing?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Indeed, the first clause and the last clause</b> are referring to a change <b>with regard to</b> the <b>pinching, and the middle clause</b> is referring to a change <b>with regard to</b> the <b>squeezing.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And all of</b> the offerings enumerated in the previous mishna, even those that are disqualified and may not be eaten or sacrificed, still differ from carcasses of unslaughtered kosher birds in that they <b>do not render</b> one who swallows their meat <b>ritually impure</b> when the meat is <b>in the throat.</b> This is because the pinching of the napes of bird offerings, like the slaughter of animals, prevents them from assuming the status of a carcass. <b>But</b> nevertheless, since they are forbidden to the priests, one who derives benefit from any of <b>them</b> is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property. This is the <i>halakha</i> in all cases <b>except for the bird sin offering that one sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering.</b> Since it was sacrificed properly and it is permitted for priests to partake of a fit sin offering, there is no liability for misuse of consecrated property.
In the case of <b>a bird burnt offering that</b> one improperly <b>sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of</b> the <b>sin offering,</b> and one did so <b>for the sake of a sin offering, Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One who derives benefit from <b>it</b> is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property, as it remains a burnt offering, whose meat is never permitted to the priests. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> One who derives benefit from <b>it</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property. Since the entire sacrificial process was conducted according to the procedure of a sin offering, the offering assumes the status of a sin offering in this regard.
The mishna recounts the dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i>. <b>Rabbi Eliezer said: And if</b> in the case of <b>a sin offering that</b> was sacrificed <b>for its sake,</b> one is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misusing it,</b> and nevertheless, <b>when one changed its designation</b> and sacrificed it not for its sake, one is liable for <b>misusing it,</b> then in the case of <b>a burnt offering, where</b> one is liable for <b>misusing it</b> even when it was sacrificed <b>for its sake, when one changed its designation</b> and sacrificed it not for its sake <b>is it not right that</b> he is liable for <b>misusing it?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No,</b> that <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not correct, as <b>if you said with regard to a sin offering</b> for <b>which one changed its designation</b> and sacrificed it <b>for the sake of a burnt offering</b> that there is liability for misuse, this is reasonable, <b>because he changed its designation to an item for which there is</b> liability for <b>misuse. Would you say in</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering</b> for <b>which one changed its designation</b> and sacrificed it <b>for the sake of a sin offering</b> that there is liability for misuse, <b>as</b> in that case <b>he changed its designation to an item for which there is no</b> liability for its <b>misuse?</b>

Daf 67a

<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him:</b> The case of <b>offerings of the most sacred order that one slaughtered in the south</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>and slaughtered for the sake of offerings of lesser sanctity, will prove</b> that the fact that one changed the offering’s designation to an item that is not subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse is not a relevant factor. <b>As</b> in this case, one <b>changed their designation to an item that is not subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse and,</b> nevertheless, one is liable for <b>misusing them. You too should not be puzzled about the burnt offering,</b> concerning which <b>even though one changed its designation to an item that is not subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> one would be liable for <b>misusing it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No,</b> that is no proof, as <b>if you said with regard to offerings of the most sacred order that one slaughtered in the south</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>and slaughtered them for the sake of offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> that one is liable for misusing them, that is reasonable. The reason is <b>that</b> one who slaughtered them <b>changed their designation to an item for which there are both prohibited and permitted</b> elements as offerings of lesser sanctity. Although one is not liable for misuse of their flesh, after the blood is sprinkled one is liable for misuse of the portions consumed on the altar. <b>Would you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> is the same <b>in</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering</b> for <b>which one changed its designation to an item that</b> is <b>permitted in its entirety,</b> i.e., a bird sin offering, which is eaten by the priests and none of it is burned on the altar?
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The discussion between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, where it is recounted in greater detail: <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to Rabbi Yehoshua:</b> The case of <b>a guilt offering that one slaughtered in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>for the sake of a peace offering will prove</b> my point, <b>as</b> here the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation</b> to an item for which there is no liability for misuse, <b>and</b> yet one is liable for <b>misusing it. And you too should not be puzzled about the</b> bird <b>burnt offering</b> that was sacrificed as a sin offering, concerning <b>which even though</b> the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation</b> to an item for which there is no liability for misuse, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> one is liable for <b>misusing it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No, if you say</b> that this this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a guilt offering</b> sacrificed as a peace offering, <b>as although</b> the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation, he</b> still <b>did not change its location</b> but sacrificed it in the north of the Temple courtyard, which is the appropriate location for both guilt offerings and peace offerings, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> a bird <b>burnt offering</b> sacrificed below the red line as a sin offering, <b>where</b> the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and</b> also <b>changed its location?</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: A guilt offering that one slaughtered in the south</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>for the sake of a peace offering will prove</b> my point, <b>as</b> here the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and</b> also <b>changed its location, and</b> yet one is liable for <b>misusing it. You too should not be puzzled about the</b> bird <b>burnt offering</b> that was sacrificed below the red line as a sin offering, concerning <b>which even though</b> the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and</b> also <b>changed its location,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that one is liable for <b>misusing it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: No, if you say</b> that this this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a guilt offering</b> sacrificed as a peace offering, in <b>which</b> case the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and changed its location, but</b> he <b>did not change its procedure, shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> a bird <b>burnt offering</b> sacrificed entirely according to the procedure of a sin offering, in <b>which</b> case the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and procedure and</b> also <b>changed its location?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> ends here, and it would appear that Rabbi Eliezer had no response to this claim. <b>Rava said:</b> Why? <b>Let him say to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua that <b>a guilt offering that one slaughtered in the south</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>for the sake of a peace offering with a deviation with regard to</b> the offering’s <b>owner,</b> i.e., he slaughtered it for the sake of someone other than the offering’s owner, will prove my opinion; <b>as</b> this is tantamount to a case where the one who performed the slaughter <b>changed its designation and changed its location and</b> also <b>changed its procedure,</b> yet one is liable for its misuse.
Rava concluded: <b>Since he did not say this to him, learn from it</b> that at this stage <b>Rabbi Eliezer grasped Rabbi Yehoshua’s</b> line of <b>reasoning; as Rav Adda bar Ahava says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua would say</b> the following reasoning: In the case of <b>a bird burnt offering that one sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering, once he pinched one of the organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [<i>siman</i>],</b> i.e., either the gullet or the windpipe, the offering <b>is removed</b> from its status as a burnt offering <b>and becomes a bird sin offering.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then in the case of <b>a bird sin offering that one sacrificed above</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a burnt offering, too, as soon as he pinches one <i>siman</i> it should be removed</b> from its status as a sin offering <b>and become a bird burnt offering. And if you would say</b> that <b>indeed</b> that is so, this is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say in the name of Rabbi Bena’a</b> that <b>this is</b> the accurate <b>presentation of the mishna? What,</b> does he <b>not</b> mean that <b>this is</b> the accurate <b>presentation</b> in the sense that Rabbi Yehoshua’s principle applies specifically to the case stated in the mishna, namely, that of a burnt offering sacrificed as a sin offering, <b>and</b> to <b>nothing more?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> what Rabbi Bena’a means is that <b>this is</b> the accurate <b>presentation of the entire mishna.</b> Just as Rabbi Yehoshua disagrees with Rabbi Eliezer with regard to a bird burnt offering sacrificed entirely as a sin offering, he holds similarly that a bird sin offering sacrificed entirely as a burnt offering assumes the status of a burnt offering.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The two cases are different. <b>Granted,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s principle applies to <b>a bird burnt offering that one sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering. Since</b> the method of <b>preparing</b> this bird sin offering is <b>by</b> pinching <b>one <i>siman</i>, and</b> the method of <b>preparing that</b> bird burnt offering is <b>by</b> pinching <b>two <i>simanim</i>, and</b> since <b>there</b> can be <b>no bird burnt offering below</b> the red line, therefore <b>once he pinched one <i>siman</i></b> below the red line, the offering <b>is removed</b> from its status as a burnt offering <b>and becomes a bird sin offering.</b>
<b>But</b> one cannot say this with regard to <b>a bird sin offering</b> that was sacrificed as a burnt offering. <b>Since the Master said</b> with regard to the bird sin offering: <b>Pinching is valid everywhere</b> on the altar, it follows that <b>as soon as one pinched one <i>siman</i></b> for the sake of a burnt offering it was <b>disqualified,</b> like any other sin offering pinched for the sake of a different type of offering. Consequently, <b>when he then pinched the other <i>siman</i></b> according to the procedure of a burnt offering, <b>how could it</b> then <b>be removed</b> from its status as a sin offering <b>and become a bird burnt offering?</b>
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua would say:</b> In the case of <b>a bird burnt offering that one sacrificed below</b> the red line <b>according to the procedure of a sin offering</b> and <b>for the sake of a sin offering, once he pinched one <i>siman</i>,</b> the offering <b>is removed</b> from its status as a burnt offering <b>and becomes a bird sin offering.</b>

Daf 67b

The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a challenge to this principle from a mishna in tractate <i>Kinnim</i> (24a). A woman after childbirth must bring two bird offerings: A burnt offering and a sin offering. The mishna discusses a case where two women after childbirth, one of whom already brought her burnt offering and one of whom already brought her sin offering, bring their remaining offerings to the Temple, <b>a sin offering for this one and a burnt offering for that one,</b> but confusion has arisen as to which bird is which.
If the priest <b>sacrificed both of them above</b> the red line, <b>half</b> of the birds, i.e., one of them, <b>is fit,</b> as in any event the burnt offering has been sacrificed properly, <b>and half</b> of the birds, i.e., the other one, <b>is disqualified.</b> Likewise, if he sacrificed <b>both of them below</b> the red line, <b>half are fit,</b> as in any event the sin offering was sacrificed properly, <b>and half are disqualified.</b> If he sacrificed <b>one above</b> the red line <b>and one below, they are both disqualified, as I say</b> that perhaps the <b>sin offering was sacrificed above, and</b> the <b>burnt offering was sacrificed below.</b>
But according to Rav Adda bar Ahava’s explanation of Rabbi Yehoshua’s principle, the sin offering should be deemed fit in any event; <b>even</b> though the <b>burnt offering was indeed sacrificed below</b> the red line, <b>it should be removed</b> from its status as a burnt offering <b>and become a bird sin offering.</b>
The Gemara rejects this claim: It is reasonable to <b>say that Rabbi Yehoshua stated</b> his principle <b>with regard to one person,</b> whose offering the priest sacrificed below the red line instead of above it; but <b>did he state</b> it <b>with regard to two people,</b> one of whose offering the priest sacrificed for the sake of the other person? In the case of the two women, the priest sacrificed the offering for the sake of a different person altogether, and Rabbi Yehoshua would concede that such an offering does not become a sin offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge from a mishna in tractate <i>Kinnim</i> (24a). The mishna discusses a case of two women who jointly brought three pairs of birds, as follows: The birds of one pair were designated as <b>a sin offering and a burnt offering</b> respectively, but it was not specified which woman’s obligation they were to satisfy; <b>and</b> the second pair was <b>unspecified</b> as to which bird was to be which offering; <b>and</b> the third pair was <b>specified</b> as to both the type of offering of each bird and whose obligation each bird was to satisfy.
If the priest <b>sacrificed all of them above</b> the red line, <b>half</b> of the birds <b>are fit,</b> as in any event the burnt offerings have been sacrificed properly, <b>and half are disqualified.</b> Likewise, if he sacrificed <b>all of them below</b> the red line, <b>half are fit,</b> as in any event the sin offerings were sacrificed properly, <b>and half are disqualified.</b> If he sacrificed <b>half of</b> every pair <b>above</b> the red line <b>and half of</b> it <b>below,</b> but it is unclear which bird he sacrificed above and which he sacrificed below, <b>only</b> the <b>unspecified</b> pair is <b>fit,</b> as by sacrificing one above and one below the priest has in effect designated them. <b>And</b> since the women brought the birds jointly, the fit pair <b>is divided between them,</b> one bird counting toward the obligation of each woman.
The mishna teaches that only the unspecified pair is fit, <b>while</b> the <b>specified</b> birds are <b>not,</b> as perhaps each bird was sacrificed on the wrong side of the red line and disqualified. <b>But why</b> should that be the <i>halakha</i>? According to Rav Adda bar Ahava’s explanation of Rabbi Yehoshua’s principle, <b>even</b> if the <b>burnt offering was indeed sacrificed below</b> the red line, <b>it should be removed</b> from its status as a burnt offering <b>and become a bird sin offering.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>this</b> mishna <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, how can you say that?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> evidence that the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Kinnim</i> are in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua from another mishna in the same chapter (24b): The mishna discusses the case of <b>a woman who said: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>one nest,</b> i.e., one pair of bird offerings, <b>if I give birth to a male</b> child. Since all women who give birth must bring one pair of birds in any event, if <b>she</b> ultimately <b>gave birth to a male, she must bring two nests, one for her vow and one for her obligation.</b>
If <b>she gave them to the priest</b> without specifying which bird is to be which type of offering, <b>the priest must sacrifice three above</b> the red line <b>and one below.</b> This is because the obligatory pair must consist of a burnt offering and a sin offering, while a pair of birds brought to fulfill a vow must consist of two burnt offerings.
If the priest <b>did not do so,</b> but <b>rather,</b> thinking that both pairs were obligatory, <b>sacrificed two above and two below, and</b> he <b>did not consult</b> the woman before sacrificing them, <b>she must bring one more bird [<i>perida</i>] and sacrifice it above</b> the red line to satisfy her remaining obligation.
This is the <i>halakha</i> only if both pairs were <b>of the same species</b> of bird, either doves or pigeons; <b>but</b> if the two pairs were <b>of two</b> different <b>species,</b> and the priest does not remember which pair he sacrificed first, <b>she must bring two</b> more birds, one of each species. Whichever pair was sacrificed first is deemed the obligatory pair, and the woman must bring a bird of the other species to satisfy her remaining obligation of a burnt offering. But since it is not known which species of bird that is, she must bring one of each.
If the woman initially <b>specified</b> which species of bird she would bring for <b>her vow</b> but subsequently forgot what species she specified, and she then brought two pairs of a single species, and the priest mistakenly sacrificed two birds above the red line and two below, then <b>she must bring three more birds,</b> all as burnt offerings. One must be of the species she brought, to replace the bird mistakenly sacrificed below, and the other two must be of the other species, in case that was the species she specified in the first place.
This is the <i>halakha</i> only if both pairs that she brought were <b>of the same species. But</b> if they were <b>of two</b> different <b>species,</b> and the priest does not remember which pair he sacrificed first, <b>she must bring four,</b> two of each species. This is because no matter which species she specified, the priest may have sacrificed the pair of that species first, leaving none of that species to satisfy even part of her vow. She therefore may still need to satisfy an entire vow of either species.
The mishna continues: If, besides forgetting which species of bird she specified to bring for her vow, the woman also <b>committed</b> to sacrificing the birds of <b>her vow</b> together with the burnt offering of the obligatory pair, but the priest mistakenly sacrificed two birds above the red line and two below,

Daf 68a

<b>she must bring another five birds</b> and sacrifice them all <b>above</b> the red line as burnt offerings. Since her commitment was not satisfied, she has not fulfilled even part of her vow. She must therefore bring two burnt offerings of each species to ensure that she fulfills her vow, and she must bring another bird to replace the initial obligatory burnt offering and fulfill her commitment to bring them together.
This is the <i>halakha</i> only if both pairs that she brought were <b>of the same species. But</b> if they were <b>of two</b> different <b>species,</b> and the priest does not remember which he sacrificed first as the obligatory pair, <b>she must bring six,</b> two of each species to ensure that she fulfills her vow, and one more of each species to ensure that she properly replaces the original burnt offering of the obligatory pair and fulfills her commitment.
If the woman specified the species of bird for her vow but then forgot which species she specified, and <b>she gave</b> two pairs of birds <b>to the priest but does not know</b> now <b>what</b> species <b>she gave,</b> or even if she gave him one or two species of birds, and <b>the priest went and sacrificed</b> the birds <b>but does not know</b> now <b>what he sacrificed</b> where, in this case, <b>she must</b> bring seven birds, as follows: <b>Four birds,</b> two of each species, <b>for her vow; and two</b> more birds, one of each species, <b>for her obligatory</b> burnt offering, in case the priest sacrificed a sin offering of a certain species and the burnt offering must now match that species; <b>and one sin offering</b> of either species, in case the priest sacrificed them all as burnt offerings.
<b>Ben Azzai says</b> she must bring <b>two sin offerings,</b> one of each species, as he holds that if the priest sacrificed a bird of a certain species specifically as the obligatory burnt offering, the sin offering must now match that species.
The mishna concludes: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> that there is a parable that explains this situation: <b>This is what</b> people <b>say</b> about a sheep: <b>When it is alive it</b> makes <b>one sound, and when it is dead it</b> makes <b>seven sounds.</b> Its two horns become trumpets, its two shinbones become flutes, its skin becomes a drumhead, its large intestines become harp strings, and its small intestines become lyre strings. Here too, because of the uncertainty as to what had occurred, the woman must bring seven extra birds. Since Rabbi Yehoshua summarizes the mishna, the <i>mishnayot</i> in this chapter must be in accordance with his opinion. According to Rav Adda bar Ahava’s explanation of Rabbi Yehoshua’s principle, burnt offerings of birds sacrificed as sin offerings become valid sin offerings. Why then, according to these <i>mishnayot</i>, are they disqualified?
The Gemara responds: Rav Adda bar Ahava’s explanation is not at odds with these <i>mishnayot</i>; while it is reasonable to <b>say,</b> i.e., to explain, <b>that Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> that the offering becomes a sin offering insofar as <b>to exclude</b> one who derives benefit from <b>it from</b> liability for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>did he say</b> that it becomes a sin offering so expansively as <b>to</b> indicate that it would <b>satisfy</b> the owner’s <b>obligation?</b> In the cases in the <i>mishnayot</i> in <i>Kinnim</i>, all burnt offerings that were sacrificed as sin offerings are not subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property, but the women must nevertheless bring replacement offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>any</b> of those people <b>disqualified</b> from performing the Temple service <b>who pinched</b> the nape of a bird offering, <b>their pinching is not valid, but</b> the offering’s meat <b>does not render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> as would the meat of a kosher bird that was not ritually slaughtered. If a priest <b>pinched</b> it <b>with</b> the thumbnail of his <b>left</b> hand, <b>or</b> if he pinched it <b>at night,</b> or if <b>he slaughtered a non-sacred</b> bird <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or a sacrificial</b> bird <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, in all these cases, although it is prohibited to consume these birds, <b>they do not render</b> one <b>ritually impure</b> when they are <b>in the throat,</b> as the halakhic status of pinching is like that of slaughtering.
If <b>he pinched with a knife</b> and not with his thumbnail; or if <b>he pinched a non-sacred</b> bird <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or a sacrificial</b> bird <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard;

Daf 68b

or if he pinched <b>doves whose time</b> of fitness for sacrifice <b>has not</b> yet <b>arrived,</b> as they are too young to be sacrificed; <b>or if he</b> pinched <b>pigeons whose time</b> of fitness <b>has passed,</b> as they are too old; or if he pinched the nape of a fledgling <b>whose wing was withered,</b> or <b>whose eye was blinded, or whose leg was severed;</b> in all these cases, although the bird’s nape was pinched, <b>it renders</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
<b>This is the principle:</b> The meat of <b>any</b> bird that was initially fit for sacrifice and <b>whose disqualification</b> occurred in the course of the service <b>in the sacred</b> Temple courtyard <b>does not render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b> The meat of any bird <b>whose disqualification did not occur in the sacred</b> area, but rather was disqualified before the service began, <b>renders</b> one <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav says:</b> Pinching with the thumbnail of the <b>left</b> hand <b>and</b> pinching at <b>night do not</b> cause the offering’s meat to <b>render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat</b> as would the carcass of an unslaughtered bird; but pinching by <b>a non-priest and</b> pinching, i.e., cutting from the nape of the neck, with <b>a knife</b> rather than the fingernail do cause the meat to <b>render</b> one <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>What is different</b> about the first two cases that prevents the bird from assuming the status of a carcass? Temple service with the <b>left</b> hand <b>has</b> an instance of <b>validity</b> during the service <b>on Yom Kippur,</b> when the High Priest enters the Holy of Holies holding the spoon of incense in his left hand. <b>And</b> Temple service at <b>night has</b> an instance of <b>validity in</b> the burning of <b>limbs and fats</b> of offerings on the altar, which may be burned throughout the night. But <b>a non-priest also has</b> an instance of <b>validity in</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of animal offerings. Why then does Rav rule that pinching by a non-priest renders the bird a carcass? The Gemara answers: <b>Slaughter is not</b> considered a full-fledged sacrificial <b>rite,</b> and therefore it cannot be compared to pinching.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it <b>not</b> a full-fledged rite? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>the slaughter of</b> a red <b>heifer by a non-priest is not valid,</b> which indicates that it is a full-fledged rite? <b>And Rav showed</b> a source in the Torah <b>for</b> this <i>halakha</i>: The verses concerning the red heifer mention both <b>Elazar</b> the priest as performing the slaughter <b>and</b> the word <b>“statute,”</b> which is mentioned in the verse: “This is the statute of the law” (Numbers 19:2), teaching that Elazar’s involvement was halakhically required.
The Gemara answers: The red <b>heifer is different, as it</b> has the halakhic status of an item <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance</b> rather than for sacrifice on the altar. Therefore, its slaughter cannot teach the <i>halakha</i> concerning an actual offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> can <b>it not</b> be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> that slaughter is a sacrificial rite? If animals that have the status of items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance,</b> which are of lesser sanctity, <b>require</b> slaughter by the <b>priesthood, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that the slaughter of animals <b>consecrated for</b> sacrifice on the <b>altar,</b> which are of greater sanctity, is a sacrificial rite that should require a priest? Apparently, the fact that non-priests may slaughter offerings proves that certain sacrificial rites apply to them.
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The slaughter of a red heifer does not constitute Temple service at all, and therefore it cannot be compared to the slaughter of an offering. The <i>halakha</i> is <b>just as it is with regard to</b> the examination of the <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks, which</b> does <b>not</b> constitute Temple <b>service but requires</b> a declaration of purity or impurity by the <b>priesthood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But let us derive from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a private <b>altar,</b> which was a valid medium for sacrificing offerings before the Temple was built, where non-priests were permitted to pinch the napes of bird offerings, that there is a circumstance in which pinching by non-priests is valid. Why then does the bird assume the status of a carcass when the pinching is performed by a non-priest?
The Gemara answers: <b>One cannot derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the Temple service <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a private <b>altar,</b> which was considered non-sacred by comparison.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> can one <b>not</b> derive the <i>halakhot</i> of the Temple service from the <i>halakhot</i> of a private altar? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> an item, e.g., the limbs of an offering, which <b>emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard and was thereby rendered unfit for sacrifice upon the altar, <b>that if</b> it nevertheless <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall not descend?</b> It is derived from the fact <b>that</b> an item that <b>emerged is valid</b> for sacrifice <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> This indicates that one can learn from the <i>halakhot</i> of a private altar with regard to the Temple service.
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>relies on</b> the verse: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering [<i>ha’ola</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:2), from which it is derived that any item that ascends [<i>ola</i>] upon the altar shall not descend from it, even if it was disqualified. In other words, the verse is the actual source for the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, whereas the case of a private altar is cited merely in support of this ruling.
Until this point the Gemara has discussed the opinion of Rav, who holds that the pinching of a non-priest renders the bird a carcass with regard to ritual impurity. <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If <b>a non-priest</b> pinched the nape of a bird offering, the meat <b>does not render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat;</b> but if a priest pinched it, i.e., cut it from the nape of the neck, with <b>a knife,</b> the meat <b>renders</b> one <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
The Gemara brings proof for the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan from that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>any</b> of those <b>disqualified</b> for Temple service <b>pinched</b> the nape of a bird offering, <b>their pinching is not valid,</b> but the meat does not render one who swallows it ritually impure when it is in the throat. <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> the word: <b>Any,</b> is written <b>to add</b> that even the pinching of <b>a non-priest</b> does not render the bird a carcass. <b>But according to Rav,</b> who holds that it does render the bird a carcass, <b>what is added</b> by the word: <b>Any?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is written <b>to add</b> pinching with the <b>left</b> hand <b>or</b> pinching at <b>night.</b> The Gemara challenges: The word: Any, is unnecessary with regard to teaching the cases of pinching with the <b>left</b> hand <b>and</b> pinching at <b>night,</b> as <b>they are taught</b> in the mishna <b>explicitly.</b> The Gemara answers: According to Rav, the word: Any, is not meant to add a specific case. Rather the mishna <b>teaches</b> the principle <b>and then explains</b> using specific examples.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the continuation of the mishna: <b>This is the principle:</b> The meat of <b>any</b> bird <b>whose disqualification occurred</b> during the course of the service <b>in the sacred</b> Temple courtyard <b>does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when the meat is <b>in the throat. Granted, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> the word: <b>Any,</b> is written <b>to add</b> that even the pinching of <b>a non-priest</b> does not render the bird a carcass. <b>But according to Rav,</b> who holds that it does render the bird a carcass, <b>what is added</b> by the word: Any?

Daf 69a

The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> one could infer the opposite from the following clause: The meat of any bird <b>whose disqualification did not occur in the sacred</b> Temple courtyard transmits ritual impurity to one who swallows it. Here, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>what</b> disqualification <b>is added</b> if not pinching by a non-priest?
<b>Rather,</b> both clauses add other disqualifications not mentioned in the mishna. <b>The former clause,</b> concerning an offering that was disqualified in the Temple courtyard, is written <b>to add</b> that <b>the slaughter of sacrificial</b> birds <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard does not render them carcasses. <b>The latter clause,</b> with regard to an offering disqualified outside the Temple courtyard, is written <b>to add</b> that <b>the pinching of non-sacred</b> birds <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard does render them carcasses.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> In a case where <b>a non-priest pinched</b> a bird offering, or a priest <b>disqualified</b> from the Temple service <b>pinched it,</b> or it became <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., it was sacrificed with the intent to consume it beyond its designated time, <b>or</b> it became <b><i>notar</i>,</b> i.e., its meat remained uneaten beyond its designated time, <b>or</b> it became <b>ritually impure,</b> in all these cases, even though the meat of these birds may not be consumed, they still <b>do not render</b> one who swallows them <b>ritually impure</b> when they are <b>in the throat.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: I heard [<i>shamati</i>] two</b> <i>halakhot</i>, <b>one</b> concerning <b>the removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering <b>by a non-priest</b> for burning on the altar, <b>and one</b> concerning the <b>pinching</b> of a bird offering <b>by a non-priest.</b> Although both offerings are disqualified, I heard that <b>one shall descend</b> from the altar if it ascended, <b>and one shall not descend; but I do not know</b> which <i>halakha</i> applies to which case. <b>Ḥizkiyya said: It stands to reason</b> that in the case of the <b>removal of</b> the <b>handful</b> the offering <b>shall descend</b> and in the case of <b>pinching</b> the offering <b>shall not descend.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>pinching</b> by a non-priest that would allow the bird to be sacrificed if it ascended onto the altar? If the difference is <b>that</b> for a non-priest to do so <b>would be</b> valid <b>on</b> a private <b>altar,</b> where all sacrificial rites were performed by non-priests, this does not constitute a difference, as the <b>removal of</b> the <b>handful</b> by a non-priest <b>would also be</b> valid <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that no handfuls were removed on private altars because <b>no meal offering</b> was sacrificed <b>on</b> a private <b>altar,</b> as meal offerings were brought before the construction of the Temple only on the altar in the Tabernacle, you must also say that there was no pinching either, as according to this opinion <b>no birds</b> were sacrificed <b>on</b> a private <b>altar either.</b>
<b>As Rav Sheshet says: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>a meal offering was</b> sacrificed <b>on</b> a private <b>altar, birds were</b> sacrificed <b>on</b> a private <b>altar. According to the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>no meal offering</b> was sacrificed on a private altar, <b>no birds</b> were sacrificed there either. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? This is because the Torah, in describing the offerings brought at Mount Sinai, before the Tabernacle was built, mentions <b>slaughtered offerings</b> (see Exodus 24:5) <b>but not meal offerings;</b> it mentions <b>slaughtered offerings,</b> i.e., animal offerings, <b>but not birds.</b>
<b>Rather, say</b> that even though both pinching the nape of a bird offering and removing the handful of a meal offering by a non-priest are valid on a private altar, the <i>halakhot</i> of meal offerings sacrificed on a private altar cannot be compared to those of meal offerings sacrificed in the Temple. This is because in the case of <b>a meal offering</b> sacrificed <b>on</b> a private <b>altar, there is no consecration in a service vessel of</b> the handful removed from it. By contrast, in the Temple, the handful must always be consecrated in a service vessel.
§ The mishna rules that if a priest <b>pinched with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>or</b> if he pinched <b>at night,</b> the offering does not render one ritually impure when in his throat. With regard to this issue <b>the Sages taught:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that invalid <b>pinching that</b> occurs <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, such as pinching with the left hand or pinching at night, <b>would</b> cause the offering to <b>render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b> Therefore <b>the verse states:</b> “Every soul that eats <b>a carcass</b>…shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 17:15). Bird offerings whose napes were pinched inside the Temple courtyard are not considered carcasses.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> a bird offering whose nape was pinched inside the Temple courtyard <b>also a carcass? Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the mishna is derived from that which <b>the verse states:</b> “Every soul that eats a carcass or <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b>…shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 17:15). A <i>tereifa</i> is an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months. It is derived from this verse that <b>just as</b> having the status of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> does not render permitted</b> any <b>forbidden</b> bird, <b>so too, any</b> type of death <b>that does not render permitted</b> any <b>forbidden</b> bird renders the animal a carcass with regard to ritual impurity.
Consequently, invalid <b>pinching that is</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>is excluded, since it renders permitted a forbidden</b> bird, as it is permitted to sacrifice such a disqualified offering if it ascended onto the altar, whereas it was prohibited to sacrifice such a disqualified offering if it was not pinched. The meat of such an offering therefore <b>does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
This principle <b>includes</b> two other cases of invalid pinching, for which the Gemara gives a two-word <b>mnemonic: <i>Ketz</i>, <i>ḥefetz</i>.</b> These words are acronyms for the cases of <b>one who pinches</b> the napes of <b>sacrificial</b> birds <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> one who <b>pinches</b> the napes of <b>non-sacred</b> birds <b>whether inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or outside</b> of it. <b>Since</b> these offerings <b>do not render permitted</b> any <b>forbidden</b> bird, as these offerings may not be sacrificed even if brought onto the altar, <b>they render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows them <b>ritually impure</b> when they are <b>in the throat.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that the slaughter of non-sacred</b> birds <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>or</b> the slaughter of <b>sacrificial</b> birds <b>whether inside or outside</b> of it, would cause their meat to <b>render</b> the garments of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b> Therefore <b>the verse states:</b> “Every soul that eats <b>a carcass</b>…shall be impure until the evening.” Birds that have been slaughtered in this manner are not considered carcasses, and so they do not impart ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> a bird slaughtered in one of these manners <b>also a carcass? Rather,</b> it is derived from that which <b>the verse states:</b> “Every soul that eats a carcass or <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b>…shall be impure until the evening,” as follows: <b>Just as</b> the status of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> is the same,</b> if the bird is slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> it is if the bird is slaughtered <b>outside</b> of it, i.e., forbidden, <b>so too all</b> forbidden birds whose status <b>is the same</b> if slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> it is if they were slaughtered <b>outside</b> of it constitute carcasses.
Consequently, <b>the slaughter of non-sacred</b> birds <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>or</b> of <b>sacrificial</b> birds <b>whether inside or outside</b> of it, <b>is excluded, since</b> the status of such birds <b>is not the same</b> if they are slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> if they are slaughtered <b>outside</b> of it. The meat of such an offering therefore <b>does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>Granted,</b> the status of <b>non-sacred</b> birds <b>is not the same</b> if slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> if they are slaughtered <b>outside</b> of it, as if slaughtered inside the Temple courtyard they are forbidden, while if slaughtered outside of it they are permitted. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> birds, in both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, whether slaughtered inside the Temple courtyard or outside of it, they <b>are disqualified.</b>
<b>Rava says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to slaughtered sacrificial birds outside the Temple should not be derived from the verse at all, but rather by logic. <b>If the slaughter of</b> a sacrificial bird <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>has</b> sufficient <b>effect on it</b> as proper slaughter <b>to render</b> the one who slaughtered it <b>liable to excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>],</b> which is the punishment for slaughtering offerings outside the Temple courtyard (see 107a), could it be that <b>it does not have</b> sufficient <b>effect on</b> the bird as proper slaughter <b>to render it ritually pure</b> by preventing it <b>from</b> assuming the status of <b>a carcass?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the slaughter of sacrificial birds <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard; <b>from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> with regard to their slaughter <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers that it is derived from the principle articulated above: <b>Since</b> their status <b>is not the same</b> if they are slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> if they are slaughtered <b>outside</b> of it, as one who slaughters a sacrificial bird outside the Temple courtyard is liable to receive <i>karet</i>, the status of a carcass does not apply.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> it follows that if the priest <b>pinched sacrificial</b> birds <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, they are <b>also not</b> considered carcasses, <b>as</b> their status <b>is not the same</b> if they are pinched <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>as</b> if they are pinched <b>outside</b> of it; if they are pinched inside, they are fit offerings, and if they are pinched outside, they are disqualified. This conclusion would contradict the mishna, which rules that sacrificial birds pinched outside the Temple courtyard are considered carcasses, and they render one who eats their meat impure.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi says: One can derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> i.e., sacrificial birds slaughtered outside the Temple courtyard, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to another <b>item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> i.e., sacrificial birds slaughtered inside it. <b>But one cannot derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> i.e., sacrificial birds pinched outside the Temple courtyard, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>in its valid manner,</b> i.e., those pinched inside it. The cases of a bird pinched outside and a bird pinched inside the Temple courtyard are not subject to comparison, so one cannot derive conclusions from the differences between them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> can one <b>not</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to disqualified offerings from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to fit offerings? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> an item that <b>emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard and was thereby disqualified, <b>that if</b> it nevertheless <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall not descend?</b> It is derived from the fact <b>that</b> an item that <b>emerged is valid</b> for sacrifice <b>on</b> a private <b>altar,</b> i.e., that disqualification was not applicable to an offering sacrificed on a private altar, as there was no Temple. Here, the <i>baraita</i> derives the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an disqualified offering from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a fit one.
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>relies on</b> the phrase: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering [<i>ha’ola</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:2), a seemingly superfluous general phrase which is interpreted homiletically to <b>include</b> the <i>halakha</i> that any item that ascends [<i>ola</i>] upon the altar shall not descend from it, even if it was disqualified. The verse is the actual source for the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, whereas the case of a private altar is cited merely in support of this ruling.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the priest <b>pinched</b> the nape of the bird’s neck properly <b>and</b> then <b>it was found</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and it was therefore disqualified from being sacrificed and forbidden for consumption by a priest, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> An olive-bulk of its meat <b>does not render</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> as the pinching prevents it from assuming the status of a carcass.

Daf 69b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Its status is like any other carcass of an unslaughtered kosher bird, and its meat <b>renders</b> one who swallows it <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir said:</b> My opinion can be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i>. If an animal carcass transmits impurity</b> to a person <b>through touching</b> it <b>and through carrying</b> it, and nevertheless the <b>slaughter of</b> an animal <b>purifies it,</b> even if it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity,</b> i.e., its slaughter prevents it from assuming the impurity status of a carcass, then with regard to <b>a bird carcass, which</b> possesses a lesser degree of impurity, as it <b>does not transmit impurity</b> to a person <b>through touching</b> it <b>and through carrying</b> it, but only through swallowing it, <b>is it not logical that its slaughter should purify it,</b> even if it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity?</b>
And once it is established that slaughter renders a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> pure, it can be inferred that <b>just as we found with regard to its slaughter that it renders</b> a bird <b>fit for consumption and purifies</b> a bird, even if it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity, so too its pinching, which renders</b> a bird offering <b>fit with regard to consumption, should purify it,</b> even if it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> Although one can derive from the case of an animal that slaughter renders even a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> pure, that derivation cannot be extended to pinching. The same restriction that applies to every <i>a fortiori</i> inference, namely, that a <i>halakha</i> derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference is no more stringent than the source from which it is derived, applies here: <b>It is sufficient</b> for the halakhic status of the carcass of a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> to be <b>like</b> that of <b>the carcass of</b> an <b>animal</b> that is a <i>tereifa</i>; <b>its slaughter renders it pure, but its pinching</b> does <b>not.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> In the mishna, Rabbi Yosei answers Rabbi Meir by invoking the principle that a <i>halakha</i> derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference is no more stringent than the source from which it is derived. The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Meir not require</b> that <i>a fortiori</i> inferences conform to the principle that <b>it is sufficient</b> for the conclusion that emerges from an <i>a fortiori</i> inference to be like its source? <b>But isn’t</b> the principle: <b>It is sufficient,</b> etc., mandated <b>by Torah law?</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How</b> is it derived from the Torah that derivation <b>by</b> means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference</b> is a valid method of biblical exegesis? The Torah states with regard to Miriam, who was reprimanded by God: <b>“And the Lord said to Moses: If her father had but spit in her face,</b> should she not hide in shame seven days? Let her be shut up outside the camp seven days” (Numbers 12:14). If one who was reprimanded by her father would hide in shame for seven days, one could infer through an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that one reprimanded by <b>the Divine Presence</b> should be shut up outside the camp for <b>fourteen days. Rather,</b> one must say: <b>It is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Avin, said: Rabbi Meir</b> does require that <i>a fortiori</i> inferences conform to this principle. But he does not actually infer his opinion <i>a fortiori</i>; rather, <b>he found a verse and interpreted</b> it.
The Torah states, with regard to the impurity of unslaughtered animal carcasses: <b>“This is the law of the beast, and of the fowl”</b> (Leviticus 11:46), indicating that the two are somehow equated. <b>But with regard to what law is a beast equal to a fowl and a fowl</b> equal <b>to a beast?</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity governing animals and birds are not comparable; <b>an animal transmits impurity by touching and by carrying,</b> whereas <b>a bird does not transmit impurity by touching or by carrying.</b> Furthermore, <b>a bird renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat; an animal does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> this verse serves <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>an animal, that which renders it fit for consumption,</b> i.e., slaughter, <b>purifies it,</b> even when it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity, so too</b> with regard to <b>a bird, that which renders</b> it <b>fit for consumption,</b> i.e., both the slaughter of a non-sacred bird and pinching the nape of a bird offering, <b>purifies</b> a bird, even if it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, from its impurity.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that a bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> imparts impurity even when slaughtered? He too <b>found a verse and interpreted</b> it. The Torah states with regard to the ritual impurity of kosher bird carcasses: “And every soul that eats <b>a carcass,</b> or <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b>…he shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 17:15). <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Why was</b> the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> stated? If</b> the verse is referring to <b>a live <i>tereifa</i>,</b> it should not be impure, as the term <b>“a carcass” is stated,</b> indicating that to impart impurity the bird must be dead. <b>If</b> it is referring to <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that <b>is not alive,</b> but rather has died of its wounds, <b>it</b> falls <b>within the category of a carcass. Rather,</b> the word <i>tereifa</i> is written <b>to include a <i>tereifa</i> that one slaughtered</b> before it had the opportunity to die by itself, to teach <b>that it imparts ritual impurity</b> as would a carcass.
<b>Rav Sheizevi said to</b> the Sage who suggested this source for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion: <b>If that is so,</b> one should interpret another verse likewise, <b>as it is written: “And the fat of a carcass, and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> may be used for any other service” (Leviticus 7:24), meaning that although the meat of a carcass imparts ritual impurity, those fats that would be forbidden even if the animal had been slaughtered do not impart impurity.
<b>There too let us say,</b> interpreting the verse according to Rabbi Yehuda’s logic: Why is the case of a <i>tereifa</i> stated? <b>If</b> it is referring to <b>a live <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the case is superfluous, as <b>“a carcass” is stated.</b> Since the forbidden fat of a carcass is pure, obviously that of a live animal is pure. <b>If</b> it is referring to <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that <b>is not alive,</b> but has rather died of its wounds, <b>it is</b> included <b>within the category of “a carcass,”</b> and likewise it need not be mentioned. <b>Rather,</b> the word “<i>tereifa</i>” is written <b>to include a <i>tereifa</i> that one slaughtered,</b> to teach <b>that its</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> is <b>pure. By inference,</b> one should then conclude <b>that</b> its meat <b>does impart impurity.</b>
<b>But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav says, and some say it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> The verse concerning the impurity of carcasses states: <b>“And if some animal,</b> of which you may eat, <b>dies,</b> one who touches its carcass shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:39)? The word “some” teaches that <b>some animals impart impurity</b> and <b>some animals do not impart impurity. And what is</b> it <b>that</b> does not impart impurity? <b>That is a <i>tereifa</i> that one slaughtered.</b> And if even its meat does not impart impurity, the word <i>tereifa</i> is not needed to teach that its forbidden fat is pure.
<b>Rather,</b> the word <b><i>tereifa</i></b> in the verse concerning forbidden fat (Leviticus 7:24) <b>is necessary to exclude non-kosher</b> animals from the <i>halakha</i> in the verse and to teach that their forbidden fat is impure. The word indicates that only the forbidden fat of <b>those</b> carcasses <b>to whose species</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> applies,</b> i.e., those of kosher animals, impart impurity. Forbidden fat of a carcass of a non-kosher animal <b>is excluded, as</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> does not apply to its species.</b> The status of <i>tereifa</i> is immaterial for a non-kosher animal as its consumption is prohibited in any event.
<b>Here too,</b> the word <i>tereifa</i> in the verse concerning the impurity of kosher bird carcasses (Leviticus 17:15) should be interpreted as <b>excluding</b> a carcass of <b>a non-kosher bird</b> from ritual impurity, <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> does not apply to its species.</b> Therefore, this verse cannot serve as a source for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion with regard to the impurity of a slaughtered bird that is a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>According to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that carcass of <b>a non-kosher bird</b> does not impart impurity <b>is derived from</b> the phrase <b>“a carcass”</b> as it appears elsewhere.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>the carcass of a non-kosher bird renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b> But <b>the verse states,</b> concerning the impurity of carcasses of birds: <b>“A carcass, or a <i>tereifa</i>, he shall not eat”</b> (Leviticus 22:8).
