This type of impurity applies only to <b>those</b> birds <b>that are forbidden</b> specifically <b>due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat</b> of <b>a carcass,</b> i.e., kosher birds that died without ritual slaughter. <b>This</b> carcass of a non-kosher animal <b>is excluded,</b> and is not impure, <b>as</b> it is <b>forbidden not due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat</b> of <b>a carcass,</b> but <b>rather due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat a non-kosher</b> bird, to render yourself impure with it. Consequently, the word <i>tereifa</i> in the aforementioned verse (Leviticus 17:15) teaches that a slaughtered <i>tereifa</i> imparts ritual impurity, as originally posited.

Daf 70a

The Gemara challenges: According to <b>this</b> logic, one can <b>also derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the forbidden fat of the carcass of a non-kosher animal is impure <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And the fat of a carcass,</b> and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i>, may be used for any other service” (Leviticus 7:24), which teaches that such forbidden fat is ritually pure.
The continuation of the verse: “But you shall in no way eat of it,” indicates that the verse renders pure only fat <b>that</b> is <b>forbidden</b> specifically <b>due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a carcass,</b> i.e., the forbidden fat of kosher animals. This serves <b>to exclude this</b> forbidden fat of a non-kosher animal, <b>which is not forbidden due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a carcass,</b> but <b>rather due to</b> the prohibition against eating <b>a non-kosher</b> animal. Since the verse that states that fats are ritually pure is referring only to kosher animals, the forbidden fat of a carcass of a non-kosher animal must be impure. Rav Sheizevi’s derivation of this <i>halakha</i> from the word <i>tereifa</i> is therefore superfluous.
<b>Rather, this</b> word <b>“<i>tereifa</i>” is necessary to include</b> the forbidden fat of a carcass of a kosher <b>undomesticated animal,</b> to teach that it is ritually pure; as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that only the forbidden fat of carcasses of <b>those</b> animals <b>whose fat is forbidden and whose meat</b> is <b>permitted</b> if slaughtered, i.e., kosher domesticated animals, is ritually pure, and this serves <b>to exclude this</b> forbidden fat of carcasses of those animals <b>whose fat and meat are</b> both <b>permitted</b> if slaughtered, i.e., kosher undomesticated animals, whose fat is impure. To counter this possibility, the word “<i>tereifa</i>” <b>teaches us</b> that the fat of a carcass of any animal that can become a <i>tereifa</i> is ritually pure, including the fat of kosher undomesticated animals.
<b>He said to him:</b> If it is derived from the verse that the forbidden fat of a carcass of a kosher undomesticated animal is pure, <b>what is different</b> about <b>a non-kosher</b> animal that would cause its forbidden fat to be impure? If the difference is <b>that its fat is not distinct from its meat,</b> as both are forbidden for consumption, <b>the fat of</b> a kosher <b>undomesticated animal is also not distinct from its meat,</b> as both are permitted. <b>And furthermore, isn’t it written</b> later in the verse: <b>“But you shall in no way eat of it”</b> (Leviticus 7:24)? This phrase is interpreted (70b) as excluding the fat of undomesticated animals, teaching that it is impure.
<b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> The word <b>“<i>tereifa</i>”</b> in this verse <b>was necessary for its own</b> sake, to teach that the forbidden fat of a carcass of a <i>tereifa</i> of a kosher domesticated animal is pure. The inclusion of the word teaches <b>that you should not say</b> that <b>since a non-kosher</b> animal is <b>forbidden while</b> still <b>alive, and a <i>tereifa</i></b> is <b>forbidden while</b> still <b>alive,</b> therefore <b>just as the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a non-kosher</b> animal is <b>impure, so too the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a <i>tereifa</i></b> is <b>impure.</b> The word “<i>tereifa</i>” therefore teaches that it is pure.
The Gemara asks: But <b>if so,</b> i.e., if one could have learned the <i>halakha</i> of the forbidden fat of a <i>tereifa</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of the forbidden fat of a non-kosher animal, then <b>this</b> word “<i>tereifa</i>” in the verse concerning the impurity of a kosher bird carcass (Leviticus 17:15) <b>is also necessary</b> for its own sake, to teach that the carcass of a kosher bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> is impure. It is necessary for this to be written with regard to the carcass of a kosher bird so <b>that you should not say</b> as follows: <b>Since a non-kosher bird</b> is <b>forbidden for consumption, and a <i>tereifa</i></b> is <b>forbidden for consumption,</b> therefore <b>just as a non-kosher bird does not impart impurity, so too a <i>tereifa</i> does not impart impurity.</b> According the Rabbi Yehuda, the word is necessary to include the slaughtered kosher bird that is a <i>tereifa</i>, not a carcass.
<b>And furthermore, is it</b> possible <b>to derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a <i>tereifa</i> from</b> that concerning <b>a non-kosher</b> animal, as suggested? The two cases are incomparable, as <b>a non-kosher</b> animal <b>never had a kosher period</b> before being forbidden, whereas <b>a <i>tereifa</i> had a kosher period</b> before becoming a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And if you would say: What can be said</b> with regard to an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i> from the womb,</b> which never had a kosher period? <b>In any event, there are</b> kosher animals <b>among its species,</b> i.e., the <i>tereifa</i> is a member of a kosher species, which cannot be said of a non-kosher animal.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The word <i>tereifa</i> in the verse concerning forbidden fat (Leviticus 7:24) teaches a different <i>halakha</i>. By stating: “But you shall in no way eat of it,” referring to the forbidden fat of a carcass, <b>the Torah states: Let the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a carcass come and take effect</b> where <b>the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat</b> already exists. One who eats the forbidden fat of a carcass is liable both for eating forbidden fat and for eating from a carcass. Likewise, the word “<i>tereifa</i>” in the verse teaches: <b>Let the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> come and take effect</b> where <b>the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat</b> already exists, so that one who eats the forbidden fat of a <i>tereifa</i> is liable for transgressing two prohibitions.
<b>And</b> both the word “carcass” and the word “<i>tereifa</i>” <b>are necessary,</b> even though they teach similar <i>halakhot</i>. <b>As, had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> about additional liability only with regard to the forbidden fat of <b>a carcass,</b> one might have thought that it applies to only a carcass, <b>as it imparts ritual impurity, but</b> with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> which does not, one might <b>say</b> that the additional liability does <b>not</b> apply. <b>And had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> one might have thought that it applies only to a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>as its prohibition</b> takes effect <b>while</b> it is still <b>alive, but</b> with regard to <b>a carcass,</b> which becomes forbidden only when it dies, one might <b>say</b> that it does <b>not</b> apply. Both words are therefore <b>necessary.</b>
§ The Gemara has established that according to Rabbi Yehuda, the word “<i>tereifa</i>” in the verse concerning the impurity of a kosher bird carcass (Leviticus 17:15) teaches that a slaughtered bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> imparts ritual impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that a slaughtered bird that is a <i>tereifa</i> does not impart ritual impurity, <b>do with this</b> word <b>“<i>tereifa</i>”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is necessary to exclude</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of non-sacred birds <b>that</b> occurs <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, teaching that it does not cause them to impart ritual impurity as would a carcass, even though they are forbidden for consumption.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Another</b> instance of the word <b><i>tereifa</i> is written</b> concerning the ritual impurity of birds: “A carcass, or a <i>tereifa</i>, he shall not eat to become impure with it” (Leviticus 22:8). Rabbi Yehuda derives the <i>halakha</i> from this verse.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> interpret the appearance of the word <i>tereifa</i> in both verses? The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> is necessary <b>to ex-clude</b> the <b>slaughter that</b> occurs <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard as mentioned above, <b>and one</b> is necessary <b>to exclude a non-kosher bird,</b> to teach that the carcass of a non-kosher bird does not impart ritual impurity.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> derive that the carcass of a non-kosher bird does not impart ritual impurity? The Gemara answers: He <b>derives it from</b> the word <b>“carcass”</b> in the verse: “A carcass, or a <i>tereifa</i>, he shall not eat to become impure with it” (Leviticus 22:8), which indicates that only carcasses of birds that are forbidden for consumption due to their status as a carcass are impure. Non-kosher birds are forbidden due to their non-kosher status, not due to their status as a carcass.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Meir do with this</b> word <b>“carcass”?</b> The Gemara answers: Since the verse mentions eating, Rabbi Meir holds that the word “carcass” is written <b>to</b> teach that the minimum <b>measure of consumption</b> of the meat of a bird carcass that renders one impure is <b>an olive-bulk,</b> which is the standard legal measure of consumption for Torah laws in general.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him derive</b> this measure <b>from the first verse:</b> “And every soul that eats a carcass…shall be impure” (Leviticus 17:15), <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One expresses</b> this <i>halakha</i> using <b>the language of consumption.</b>
The Gemara responds: Both verses are necessary, <b>one to</b> indicate that <b>the measure of consumption</b> that renders one impure is <b>an olive-bulk, and one to</b> indicate that <b>the</b> maximum <b>measure of</b> time for <b>consumption</b> of the olive-bulk is the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. One who takes longer than this standard measure of time will not contract impurity.
It is necessary for the Torah to indicate this latter <i>halakha</i> as well, as otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since</b> the impurity of carcasses of birds <b>is a novelty,</b> as one contracts it by eating rather than by touching or carrying, perhaps its <i>halakhot</i> are unusually stringent and even one who eats an olive-bulk in <b>more than</b> the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread <b>should also contract impurity.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> otherwise.
§ The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> concerning the impurity of the forbidden fat of a carcass. <b>The Sages taught:</b> When the verse: <b>“And the fat of a carcass, and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> may be used for any other service” (Leviticus 7:24) teaches that such fat is pure, <b>the verse speaks of the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a kosher animal.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> challenges: <b>Do you say</b> that <b>the verse speaks of the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a kosher animal, or</b> perhaps does it <b>only</b> speak <b>of the</b> forbidden <b>fat of a non-kosher animal?</b>
<b>You</b> may <b>say</b> in response: The Torah <b>renders</b> a slaughtered animal <b>pure</b> of the impurity of a carcass <b>due to the fact</b> that it was ritually <b>slaughtered. And</b> likewise the Torah <b>renders</b> the forbidden fat of a carcass <b>pure, due to the fact</b> that it is forbidden <b>fat.</b> Therefore, the two cases are comparable: <b>Just as when</b> the Torah <b>renders</b> a slaughtered animal <b>pure due to the fact</b> that it was <b>slaughtered,</b> it is referring only <b>to a kosher</b> animal <b>and not to a non-kosher</b> animal, which is impure even when ritually slaughtered, <b>so too, when</b> the Torah <b>renders</b> forbidden fat <b>pure due to the fact</b> that it is forbidden <b>fat,</b> it is referring only <b>to a kosher</b> animal <b>and not to a non-kosher</b> animal.
The <i>baraita</i> challenges: <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way</b> and maintain that since the Torah <b>renders</b> the carcass of a non-kosher animal ritually <b>pure,</b> removing it <b>from the category of a carcass, and</b> likewise the Torah <b>renders</b> the forbidden fat of a carcass <b>pure, due to the fact</b> that it is forbidden <b>fat;</b> therefore, the two cases are comparable: <b>Just as when</b> the Torah <b>renders</b> the carcass of a non-kosher animal <b>pure,</b> removing it <b>from the category of a carcass,</b> it is referring only <b>to a non-kosher</b> animal <b>and not to a kosher</b> animal, the carcass of which imparts impurity, <b>so too, when</b> the Torah <b>renders</b> forbidden fat <b>pure due to the fact</b> that it is forbidden <b>fat,</b> it is referring only <b>to a non-kosher</b> animal <b>and not to a kosher</b> animal.
<b>You</b> may <b>say</b> in response:

Daf 70b

<b>When one approaches</b> the matter <b>this</b> first <b>way,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that forbidden fat is pure <b>applies</b> specifically <b>to kosher</b> animals, but <b>when one approaches</b> the matter <b>that</b> second <b>way,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>applies</b> specifically <b>to non-kosher</b> animals. To decide the matter, <b>the verse states:</b> “The fat of <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> may be used for any other service” (Leviticus 7:24), indicating that only the forbidden fat of <b>those</b> animals <b>to whose species</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> applies,</b> i.e., kosher animals, is ritually pure. The status of <i>tereifa</i> is immaterial to a non-kosher animal as its consumption is prohibited in any event.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: One might still assume that <b>I will exclude</b> from this <i>halakha</i> only the forbidden fat of a carcass of <b>a non-kosher</b> animal, <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> does not apply to its species, but I will not exclude</b> the fat of a carcass of <b>an undomesticated</b> kosher <b>animal, as</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>tereifa</i> applies to its species.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> in conclusion: <b>“But you shall in no way eat of it,”</b> indicating that the reference is only to animals <b>whose fat</b> is <b>forbidden</b> for consumption if slaughtered <b>but whose meat</b> is <b>permitted,</b> i.e., kosher domesticated animals. <b>Excluded</b> are kosher <b>undomesticated animals, whose fat and meat</b> are both <b>permitted</b> for consumption.
<b>Rav Ya’akov bar Abba said to Rava: If that is so,</b> it appears from the <i>baraita</i> that <b>the carcass of a kosher animal imparts impurity,</b> but <b>the carcass of a non-kosher animal does not impart impurity.</b> Rava <b>said to him: How many elders have you caused to err in</b> the interpretation of this <i>baraita</i>? In <b>the latter clause we come to</b> discuss only <b>the carcass of a non-kosher bird,</b> which does not impart impurity. By contrast, carcasses of non-kosher animals are impure.
§ In the mishna, Rabbi Meir states that a bird offering whose nape was pinched and was found to be a <i>tereifa</i> does not impart impurity as would a carcass. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Meir deemed pure only unblemished</b> birds whose napes were pinched, as they are fit to be sacrificed, <b>but</b> he did <b>not</b> deem pure <b>blemished</b> birds, which are not fit to be sacrificed. <b>And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> Rabbi Meir deemed <b>even blemished</b> birds pure and did not distinguish between the two. <b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rav Beivai says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Rabbi Meir would deem pure blemished</b> birds, <b>and</b> this was his opinion <b>even</b> concerning <b>geese and chickens,</b> species that may not be brought as offerings and as such are never supposed to be pinched.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> According to Rabbi Elazar’s understanding of Rabbi Meir’s opinion, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who <b>broke the neck of a goat?</b> Does the impurity of animal carcasses apply? The breaking of the neck is considered the proper procedure in certain cases, as the Torah commands that a heifer’s neck be broken if a murdered body is found between two cities and the identity of the murderer is unknown (see Deuteronomy 21:4).
One could claim: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>geese and chickens</b> are pure if their napes are pinched? It is <b>because they are species of birds</b> and the napes of some birds are pinched; <b>but a goat is not</b> of the same <b>species</b> as <b>a heifer,</b> as goats are considered small livestock whereas cattle are large livestock. <b>Or perhaps</b> one could claim: Since a goat <b>is</b> still <b>a species of domesticated animal,</b> it is similar enough to a heifer that the breaking of its neck prevents it from imparting impurity as a carcass.
<b>Rav Dimi was sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i>,</b> i.e., this dilemma. <b>Abaye said to him: By inference</b> from this dilemma, it seems that you assume that <b>a heifer whose neck is broken is</b> itself <b>pure</b> and does not impart impurity as would a carcass. Rav Dimi <b>said to him: Indeed,</b> as the Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> Since the language of <b>atonement is written with regard to</b> the heifer whose neck is broken, in the verse: “Forgive, Lord, Your people Israel” (Deuteronomy 21:8), just <b>as</b> atonement is written with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, the breaking of the heifer’s neck is equivalent to the pinching of the nape of a bird offering, and breaking its neck prevents the heifer from imparting ritual impurity.
<b>Rav Natan, father of Rav Huna bar Natan, raises an objection</b> based on a <i>baraita</i> concerning the purity of the forbidden fat of a kosher animal, mentioned in the verse: “And the fat of a carcass, and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i>, may be used for any other service; <b>but you shall in no way eat of it”</b> (Leviticus 7:24). <b>I have</b> derived from the verse <b>only</b> that forbidden <b>fat that</b> is <b>forbidden for consumption but from which</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> is <b>permitted</b> is pure. <b>From where</b> is it derived that this <i>halakha</i> also applies to the forbidden <b>fat of an ox that is stoned</b> by the court <b>or</b> the forbidden fat of <b>a heifer whose neck is broken,</b> from both of which one is prohibited from deriving benefit?
<b>The verse states:</b> “You shall eat <b>no fat</b> nor blood” (Leviticus 3:17). The generalization “no fat” indicates that the same <i>halakhot</i> apply to the forbidden fats of all domesticated kosher animals, including those from which one is prohibited from deriving benefit.
Rav Natan concludes his objection: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the meat of <b>a heifer whose neck is broken is pure,</b> why must the verse teach that its forbidden fat is pure? Could one entertain the possibility that its meat <b>is pure but its</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> is <b>impure?</b>
The Gemara responds: The derivation in the <i>baraita</i> <b>was not necessary for</b> a case <b>where one broke the neck</b> of the heifer. <b>It was necessary</b> for the verse to teach that the forbidden fat is pure even in a case <b>where one slaughtered</b> a heifer whose neck was designated to be broken.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself <b>should be effective in purifying</b> the forbidden fat, as slaughter prevents an animal <b>from</b> assuming the impure status of <b>a carcass,</b> and the derivation is still superfluous. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach that the forbidden fat of a heifer <b>that died</b> before its neck could be broken is pure even though the heifer itself assumes that status of a carcass.
The Gemara asks: If the <i>baraita</i> is referring only to a heifer that died before its neck could be broken, and it describes benefitting from it as being prohibited, <b>by inference,</b> is it <b>prohibited</b> to derive benefit from the heifer <b>while</b> it is still <b>alive?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Indeed,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yannai says: I heard</b> the <b>boundary,</b> i.e., stage, beyond which it is forbidden, <b>but I have forgotten</b> what it is, <b>and</b> yet the members of <b>the group</b> of scholars <b>were inclined to say</b> that <b>its descent to a hard valley</b> (see Deuteronomy 21:4), where its neck was broken, is the action that <b>renders it forbidden.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the offerings that were intermingled with</b> animals from which deriving benefit is forbidden, e.g., <b>sin offerings</b> left to <b>die, or with an ox that</b> was sentenced to be <b>stoned, even</b> if the ratio is <b>one in ten thousand,</b> deriving benefit from them all is prohibited and <b>they all must die.</b> If the offerings <b>were intermingled with</b> animals whose sacrifice is forbidden but deriving benefit from them is not, the <i>halakha</i> is different. Examples of this are <b>an ox with which a transgression was performed,</b> which disqualifies it from being sacrificed as an offering, <b>or</b>

Daf 71a

an ox <b>that</b> is known to have <b>killed a person based on</b> the testimony of <b>one witness or based on</b> the admission of <b>the owner.</b> Had two witnesses testified, deriving benefit from the ox would have been prohibited. Additional examples include when an offering is intermingled <b>with an animal that copulated with a person; or an animal that was the object of bestiality;</b> or <b>with</b> an animal that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship; <b>or</b> one that <b>was worshipped</b> as a deity; or <b>with</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as the <b>price</b> of a dog, as it is written: “You shall not bring the payment of a harlot, or the price of a dog, into the house of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 23:19).

Daf 71b

Additional examples include an offering that was intermingled <b>with</b> an animal born of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds,</b> e.g., the offspring of a ram and a goat, <b>or with an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> or <b>with</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section.</b> In all these cases the animals that are intermingled <b>shall graze until they become unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>and</b> then <b>they shall be sold. And</b> from the money received in the sale, the owner <b>shall bring</b> another offering <b>of the monetary value of</b> the <b>highest-quality</b> animal <b>among them, of the same type</b> of offering that the intermingled offering was.
The mishna continues: If sacrificial animals <b>were intermingled with unblemished, non-sacred</b> animals, which, if consecrated, are fit for sacrifice, <b>the non-sacred</b> animals <b>shall be sold for the purpose</b> of purchasing offerings <b>of the same type</b> as the offering with which they were intermingled.
In a case where <b>sacrificial</b> animals were intermingled <b>with</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> animals, if it was an animal of one <b>type</b> of offering <b>with</b> animals of the same <b>type</b> of offering, <b>one shall sacrifice this</b> animal <b>for the sake of whoever is</b> its owner <b>and one shall sacrifice that</b> animal <b>for the sake of whoever is</b> its owner, and both fulfill their obligation.
In a case where <b>sacrificial</b> animals were intermingled <b>with</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> animals, where an animal of one <b>type</b> of offering was intermingled <b>with</b> animals <b>not</b> of the same <b>type</b> of offering, e.g., two rams, where one is designated as a burnt offering and one as a peace offering, <b>they shall graze until they become unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>and</b> then <b>they shall be sold. And</b> from the money received in the sale, the owner <b>shall bring</b> another offering <b>of the monetary value of</b> the <b>highest-quality</b> animal <b>among them as this type</b> of offering, <b>and</b> another offering <b>of the monetary value of</b> the <b>highest-quality</b> animal <b>among them as that type</b> of offering, <b>and he will lose the additional</b> expense of purchasing two highest-quality animals, when he had sold only one highest-quality animal, <b>from his</b> own <b>assets.</b>
In a case where sacrificial animals <b>were intermingled with a firstborn</b> offering <b>or with</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>they shall graze until they become unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>and they shall</b> both <b>be eaten as a firstborn</b> offering <b>or as</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering.
<b>All</b> offerings <b>can become</b> indistinguishably <b>intermingled</b> with each other, <b>except for a sin offering and a guilt offering,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches the <i>halakha</i> of all the offerings that were intermingled with animals from which deriving benefit is forbidden. This indicates that one offering became intermingled with a majority of prohibited animals, as it is usual to describe the smaller unit as being intermingled with the larger unit. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Even,</b> in the clause: Even if the ratio is one in ten thousand, deriving benefit from them all is prohibited and they all must die. If the permitted animal is rendered prohibited by a simple majority, of course it is prohibited if the ratio is one in ten thousand.
The Gemara explains: <b>This</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: All the offerings in which were intermingled sin offerings</b> left to <b>die, or</b> in which <b>an ox that</b> was sentenced to be <b>stoned</b> was intermingled, <b>even</b> if the ratio is <b>one</b> forbidden animal intermingled <b>with ten thousand</b> offerings, <b>they all must die.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: Why is this mishna necessary? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> on <b>another occasion,</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 28a): With regard to <b>all</b> animals <b>whose</b> sacrifice <b>on the altar</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> if they are intermingled with animals whose sacrifice is permitted <b>they render</b> the entire mixture <b>prohibited in any amount,</b> regardless of the ratio of permitted to prohibited animals. The mishna adds that these are the animals whose sacrifice is prohibited: <b>An animal that</b> actively <b>copulated with a person, and an animal that was the object of bestiality.</b> That mishna proceeds to add other categories of animals to this list, including ones mentioned in the mishna here. In any event, the basic <i>halakha</i> of the mishna is also taught in tractate <i>Temura</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi says: I said this <i>halakha</i> in the presence of Rav Shimi, and he</b> explained to <b>me</b> that both <i>mishnayot</i> <b>are necessary,</b> as each teaches a novelty not included in the other. Rav Ashi clarifies: <b>As, if</b> this <i>halakha</i> was learned only <b>from there,</b> the mishna in <i>Temura</i>, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that prohibited animals render a mixture prohibited in any ratio, applies only to prohibiting the animals from being sacrificed <b>to the Most High; but</b> with regard to prohibiting the animals even <b>to an ordinary</b> person <b>[<i>hedyot</i>],</b> e.g., that if they became intermingled with an ox that is to be stoned they all must die without the possibility of redemption, one might <b>say</b> that they are <b>not</b> all rendered prohibited in benefit, as the prohibited animal is nullified in a majority. Therefore, the mishna here teaches that even with regard to deriving benefit, all the animals in the mixture are prohibited.
Rav Ashi continues: <b>And if</b> this <i>halakha</i> was learned only <b>from here, I would say</b> that <b>it is</b> only <b>these</b> categories that are mentioned in this mishna, i.e., sin offerings that were condemned to die or an ox that was sentenced to be stoned, that render a mixture prohibited in any ratio. The <i>halakha</i> is stringent with regard to them, as <b>they are items from which</b> deriving <b>benefit is prohibited. But</b> with regard to <b>these</b> categories mentioned in the mishna in <i>Temura</i>, e.g., an animal that copulated with a person, which are not items from which deriving benefit is prohibited, one might <b>say</b> that they are <b>not</b> disqualified from being sacrificed, and they are nullified in a majority. Therefore, both <i>mishnayot</i> <b>are necessary.</b>
The Gemara questions this explanation: This justifies the mishna here, but concerning the <i>halakha</i> stated in <i>Temura</i>, why did that mishna teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to those animals <b>that are not items from which</b> deriving <b>benefit is prohibited,</b> such as an animal that copulated with a person; the <i>tanna</i> already <b>taught this</b> <i>halakha</i> in the mishna here. The Gemara answers: <b>Does</b> the mishna here <b>teach by what</b> ratio they render the mixture prohibited? The important measure: <b>In any amount, is taught there,</b> in <i>Temura</i>, not in the mishna here, and that is the novelty of the mishna in <i>Temura</i>.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach that</b> mishna in <i>Temura</i>, <b>and</b> then he would <b>not require this</b> mishna here. Why teach the second clause of the mishna here? The Gemara explains: It <b>was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention <b>the remedy,</b> i.e., that the animals that are intermingled shall graze until they become unfit for sacrifice and then they shall be sold; and from the money received in the sale, the owner shall bring another offering of the monetary value of the highest-quality animal among them as the same type of offering that the sacrificial animal was. This <i>halakha</i> is not stated in the mishna in <i>Temura</i>.
The Gemara raises another difficulty. The <i>halakha</i> of the mishna that items from which deriving benefit is prohibited render a mixture prohibited in any amount even <b>to an ordinary</b> person, as stated with regard to the sin offerings that were condemned to die and an ox that was sentenced to be stoned, is <b>also taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 74a): <b>And these</b> following items are themselves <b>forbidden, and any amount</b> of them <b>renders</b> other items with which they become mixed <b>forbidden: Wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> that became mixed with kosher wine, <b>and</b> objects of <b>idol worship</b> that were intermingled with permitted items.

Daf 72a

The Gemara explains that both the mishna here and the mishna in <i>Avoda Zara</i> <b>are necessary, as, if</b> this <i>halakha</i> had been learned only <b>from there,</b> the mishna in <i>Avoda Zara</i>, <b>I would say</b> that this applies only if the prohibited animal is intermingled with a non-sacred animal and thereby becomes prohibited <b>to an ordinary</b> person. <b>But</b> if it is intermingled with offerings that are designated <b>to the Most High</b> so a loss to the Temple would ensue, one might <b>say</b> that <b>we</b> should <b>not lose all</b> the valid offerings, and therefore the prohibited animal should be nullified in a simple majority. Accordingly, the ruling of the mishna here was necessary, to teach that the same applies to a mixture involving offerings.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> this <i>halakha</i> were learned only <b>from here I would say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that the entire mixture is prohibited, applies specifically to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>as</b> it is <b>repulsive</b> to sacrifice to God an animal from a mixture that includes a prohibited animal. <b>But</b> with regard to deriving benefit from <b>a non-sacred</b> animal from this mixture, <b>which is not a repulsive</b> act, one might <b>say: Let</b> the <b>items from which</b> deriving <b>benefit is prohibited be nullified in a majority.</b> Therefore, the mishna in <i>Avoda Zara</i> is also <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara questions the ruling of the mishna: <b>But let</b> the prohibited animals <b>be nullified in a majority,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning other matters, in which the minority items assume the status of the majority. <b>And if you would say</b> in response that animals <b>are significant,</b> as they are counted individually <b>and</b> therefore <b>they are not nullified</b> in a majority, this answer is unsatisfactory. The Gemara elaborates: <b>This</b> suggested answer <b>works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna discussing nullification in a majority (see <i>Orla</i> 3:6–7): <b>Any</b> item <b>whose manner is</b> also <b>to be counted,</b> i.e., that are sometimes sold by unit rather than weight or volume, is considered significant. This definition includes animals, as they are sometimes sold as individual animals, and therefore they would be considered significant.
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>we learned</b> in that mishna: An item <b>whose manner is</b> exclusively <b>to be counted,</b> i.e., one that is always sold by unit, is considered significant, <b>what can be said?</b> Although animals are often sold by unit, they are occasionally sold as part of a herd, and would therefore not be considered significant. The Gemara cites the mishna in which this dispute appears. <b>As we learned</b> (<i>Orla</i> 3:6–7): With regard to <b>one who had bundles of fenugreek,</b> a type of legume, that were <b>diverse kinds</b> planted <b>in a vineyard,</b> from which it is prohibited to derive benefit,

Daf 72b

those bundles <b>must be burned.</b> If the bundles <b>were intermingled with others, and</b> those <b>others</b> were intermingled <b>with others, they all must be burned.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: They can be nullified when</b> the total is <b>201</b> items, i.e., one prohibited item intermingled with two hundred permitted ones.
The mishna continues: Rabbi Meir holds that they all must be burned, <b>as Rabbi Meir would say: Any</b> item <b>whose manner is to be counted renders</b> its mixture <b>prohibited,</b> as it is considered significant and cannot be nullified. <b>And the Rabbis say: Only six items</b> are sufficiently significant to <b>render</b> their mixture <b>prohibited. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> There are <b>seven. And they are: Nuts</b> with <b>brittle</b> shells, <b>and pomegranates from Badan, and sealed barrels</b> of wine, <b>and beet greens, and cabbage stalks, and Greek gourd. Rabbi Akiva adds: Loaves of a homeowner</b> are <b>also</b> in this category.
The mishna continues: Different prohibitions apply to these items. <b>That which is fit</b> to be forbidden due <b>to the prohibition against eating the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [<i>orla</i>],</b> i.e., nuts, pomegranates, and sealed barrels of wine, prohibit their mixture as <b><i>orla</i>. That which is fit</b> to be forbidden due <b>to diverse kinds</b> planted <b>in a vineyard,</b> i.e., beets, cabbage, and gourd, prohibit their mixture as <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard.</b>
<b>And it was stated</b> that there is a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> <b>with regard to</b> the wording of Rabbi Meir’s opinion in this mishna. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>we learned:</b> Only an item <b>whose manner is</b> exclusively <b>to be counted</b> is significant and cannot be nulli-fied, and it therefore renders its mixture prohibited according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> that <b>we learned: Any</b> item <b>whose manner is</b> also <b>to be counted</b> is significant and cannot be nullified.
The Gemara reiterates its question: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish, but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, what can be said?</b> According to his opinion, since animals are not sold exclusively by unit, they are not sufficiently significant. Therefore, a prohibited animal should be nullified in a simple majority. <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>this <i>tanna</i>,</b> who says that a prohibited animal cannot be nullified, <b>is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>of</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a <i>litra</i> of dried figs, who says:</b>

Daf 73a

<b>Any item that is counted, even</b> if it is prohibited <b>by rabbinic law,</b> e.g., <i>teruma</i> of fruit, <b>cannot be nullified, and all the more so</b> items prohibited <b>by Torah law,</b> such as animals that are disqualified for the altar, as in the mishna.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 5:11): The <i>baraita</i> discusses three cases, all of which relate to the tithing of figs, which is an obligation by rabbinic law. The first is the case of <b>a <i>litra</i> of</b> untithed <b>dried figs</b> that were pressed in different vessels and shaped into circles, <b>that</b> one placed into a barrel containing tithed figs, and during the process of producing a circle he <b>pressed</b> the figs <b>onto the opening of</b> one of the <b>circular</b> vessels in which the circles are formed, <b>and he does not know into which circular</b> vessel <b>he pressed it.</b> The second is the case in which he recalls that he pressed it <b>on the opening of a barrel</b> containing tithed figs, <b>but he does not know into which barrel he pressed it.</b> The third case is that he recalls that he pressed it <b>on the opening of</b> a straw <b>receptacle</b> containing tithed figs, <b>but he does not know into which receptacle he pressed it.</b> In all of these cases, there is a dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda as to the details of a dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua.
<b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One views the upper</b> layers of possibly untithed dried figs <b>as though they are separate</b> pieces, rather than one unit. <b>And the lower</b> ones, which were there beforehand and have certainly been tithed, <b>nullify the upper</b> ones, as there are enough circles of figs to nullify the upper layer. One does not need to tithe the figs at the top of any of the containers.
Rabbi Meir continues: By contrast, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: If there are one hundred openings</b> of containers present there, the untithed <i>litra</i> of figs on the opening of one of the containers <b>is nullified</b> in a ratio of one part of untithed figs to one hundred parts of similar, tithed figs. <b>But if not,</b> all of <b>the</b> layers of figs at the <b>openings</b> of the containers <b>are prohibited,</b> i.e., viewed as untithed, as one of them certainly contains an untithed <i>litra</i> that has not been nullified. <b>And the</b> figs on the <b>insides</b> of the vessels <b>are permitted,</b> as the untithed figs certainly did not reach there. This is Rabbi Meir’s version of the dispute.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If there are one hundred openings</b> of containers with tithed figs present <b>there,</b> in addition to the untithed figs, <b>it is nullified</b> in the one hundred. <b>But if not,</b> all of <b>the</b> layers of figs at the <b>openings</b> of the containers <b>are prohibited,</b> i.e., viewed as untithed, as one of them certainly contains an untithed <i>litra</i> that has not been nullified. And the figs on the insides of the vessels are permitted, as the untithed figs certainly did not reach there.
Rabbi Yehuda continues his statement: By contrast, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: Even</b> if <b>there are three hundred openings</b> present <b>there,</b> the layer at the top of the container is <b>not nullified.</b> This <i>litra</i> cannot be nullified in any manner, as Rabbi Yehoshua maintains that even an item occasionally sold by unit, such as a circle of dried figs, can never be nullified.
Rabbi Yehuda continues: But if one <b>pressed</b> the <i>litra</i> of dried figs <b>into a circular</b> vessel along with other dried figs, <b>but does not know onto which place,</b> i.e., which side, <b>of the circular</b> vessel <b>he pressed it, whether,</b> e.g., <b>to its northern</b> side <b>or to its southern</b> side, in this case, as the prohibited <i>litra</i> is not located in a defined place and it cannot be distinguished from the others, it is not considered an item of significance, and <b>everyone agrees</b> that it is <b>nullified.</b> Accordingly, the ruling of the mishna that animals that are disqualified from being sacrificed are not nullified is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua as stated by Rabbi Eliezer, that an item occasionally sold by unit is not nullified. Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, that only an item whose manner is exclusively to be counted is significant and cannot be nullified, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
<b>Rav Ashi says: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Meir, who maintains that an item that is not always counted is nullified in a majority. The reason is that <b>living creatures are significant, and</b> therefore <b>they are not nullified.</b>
§ The Gemara raises a difficulty with the ruling of the mishna that all of the animals are prohibited. <b>And let us draw out and sacrifice one</b> animal <b>from</b> the mixture, <b>and say,</b> i.e., apply the principle: <b>Any</b> item <b>that separates</b> from a group is assumed to have <b>separated from the majority.</b> Accordingly, the animal that was sacrificed is presumed to be fit. One can continue in this manner until only two animals from the mixture remain. The Gemara questions this suggestion: Should <b>we draw out</b> an animal from the mixture? But this <b>is</b> the removal of an item from its <b>fixed</b> place,

Daf 73b

<b>and</b> there is a principle that <b>anything fixed is considered as</b> though it was <b>half and half,</b> i.e., equally balanced, and it remains a case of uncertainty. The Gemara clarifies its suggestion: <b>Rather, let us push</b> the intermingled animals so <b>that they</b> all <b>move</b> from their places, which negates the fixed status of the prohibited item. <b>And</b> accordingly, <b>let us say</b> with regard to each animal: <b>Any</b> item <b>that separates</b> from a group is assumed to have <b>separated from the majority.</b>
<b>Rava says: Now that the Sages have said</b> that <b>we do not sacrifice</b> any of them, this is evidently a rabbinic <b>decree, lest ten priests come simultaneously and sacrifice</b> all the animals in the mixture together, not one at a time. Therefore, the fact that there could be a method to permit the animals is immaterial.
<b>One of the Sages said to Rava: If that is so,</b> do you hold that <b>the large basin [<i>megisa</i>]</b> on which the sacrificial portions of the animal are placed is <b>prohibited?</b> In other words, is it possible that these animals, which were slaughtered when they were initially declared permitted after being separated from their places, could later become prohibited again when their sacrificial portions are ready to be burned on the altar?
Rava responded that he did not mean there is a concern that ten priests would sacrifice their sacrificial portions simultaneously. Rather, the decree is <b>due to</b> the concern <b>lest</b> when the animals move, <b>ten priests will come simultaneously and take</b> them from the mixture. As all or most of the animals were separated simultaneously in this case, it is assumed that the prohibited animal is among those that were separated. The Gemara asks: <b>Is it possible</b> for <b>ten priests</b> to take these scattered animals <b>simultaneously? Rather, Rava says</b> that one may not allow the animals to be sacrificed by moving them <b>due to</b> a decree that if this is allowed, one may, in another circumstance, allow them to be sacrificed even when they are taken from <b>a fixed</b> location.
§ <b>Rava said: Now that the Sages say</b> in the mishna that <b>we do not sacrifice</b> any of the animals, <b>if we did sacrifice</b> one of them, the offering <b>does not effect acceptance</b> for the owner. <b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda raised an objection to Rava</b> from a mishna (<i>Kinnim</i> 22b): With regard to a bird <b>sin offering that was intermingled with</b> a bird <b>burnt offering, or</b> a bird <b>burnt offering that was intermingled with</b> a bird <b>sin offering, even</b> if the ratio is <b>one in ten thousand, they all must die,</b> as there is no remedy for these birds. It is not known which is which, and their sacrificial rites are performed differently.
The mishna continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> the case of <b>a priest</b> who <b>consulted</b> the court to ask how he should proceed. <b>But in</b> the case of <b>a priest who did not consult</b> the court, but sacrificed them of his own accord, if there was an equal number of bird sin offerings and burnt offerings, and <b>he performed</b> all their sacrificial rites <b>above</b> the red line that circumscribes the altar at its midpoint, as required for a burnt offering, <b>half</b> of the birds are <b>fit,</b> as in any event the burnt offerings were sacrificed properly, <b>and half</b> are <b>unfit.</b>
Likewise, if he performed all of their sacrificial rites <b>below</b> the red line, <b>half</b> are <b>fit,</b> as in any event the sin offerings were sacrificed properly, <b>and half</b> are <b>unfit.</b> If he performed the sacrificial rites of <b>one</b> of the birds <b>below</b> the red line and <b>one</b> of the birds <b>above</b> the red line, <b>they are both unfit, as I say</b> that the <b>sin offering</b> was <b>sacrificed above</b> the red line <b>and</b> the <b>burnt offering</b> was <b>sacrificed below.</b> This mishna proves that an offering that is prohibited to be sacrificed as part of a mixture is fit after the fact, which contradicts the statement of Rava.
<b>Rather,</b> Rava would claim that this matter depends on a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>. <b>This</b> statement of Rava is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that <b>living creatures</b> that become disqualified <b>are</b> permanently <b>rejected</b> from being sacrificed on the altar, and this animal was rejected when it was part of the mixture. <b>That</b> ruling of the mishna in <i>Kinnim</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that <b>living creatures are not</b> permanently <b>rejected</b> from the altar. Therefore, if the animal was sacrificed it is fit.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>there is</b> the case of <b>slaughtered</b> offerings that are rejected from the altar, concerning <b>which everyone agrees</b> that these <b>are rejected.</b> Even those who say that living creatures generally are not rejected agree that, in this case, they should be rejected.

Daf 74a

<b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (77b) that in a case where sacrificial portions from unblemished burnt offerings became mixed with sacrificial portions from blemished burnt offerings, which are disqualified, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If the head of one of them was sacrificed</b> on the altar before they knew of the blemish, <b>all the heads should be sacrificed,</b> as it is assumed that the head of the disqualified animal was the one already sacrificed on the altar. This indicates that even with regard to slaughtered animals, if they were rejected from the altar due to being in a mixture, they are not permanently rejected, but are fit after the fact.
The Gemara explains that this mishna affords no proof, as Rabbi Eliezer <b>states</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian,</b> who maintains that even slaughtered animals are not permanently rejected. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥanan the Egyptian says,</b> with regard to the two goats of Yom Kippur, the one sacrificed to God and the scapegoat designated to be sent to Azazel: <b>Even</b> if the <b>blood</b> of the sacrificed goat is already <b>in the cup</b> where it was collected and the scapegoat dies, the sacrificed goat is still a fit offering, and the priest <b>brings another</b> goat <b>and joins it to</b> this slaughtered goat to serve as the scapegoat. By contrast, the other <i>tanna’im</i>, who maintain that slaughtered animals are rejected, hold that once they have become rejected due to being in a mixture they are no longer fit for sacrifice, as stated by Rava.
§ Concerning a similar case, <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rava bar Avuh says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a ring</b> used in <b>idol worship,</b> from which it is prohibited to derive benefit and which is not nullified even in a ratio of one in one hundred, <b>that was intermingled with one hundred</b> permitted <b>rings, and</b> subsequently <b>one of them fell into the Great Sea [<i>Yam HaGadol</i>], they are all permitted.</b> The reason is <b>that we say: That</b> ring <b>that fell</b> into the Great Sea <b>is the prohibited</b> ring.
<b>Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</b> from the mishna: With regard to all the offerings that were intermingled with animals from which deriving benefit is prohibited, <b>even</b> if the ratio is <b>one in ten thousand, they all must die.</b> According to the opinion of Rav, that we say the one that was lost is the prohibited item, <b>why</b> must they all die? <b>Let us say,</b> with regard to the first animal <b>that died,</b> that <b>the prohibited</b> animal <b>died,</b> and the rest should be permitted.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>Rav states</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If the head of one of them is sacrificed</b> on the altar before the priests knew of the blemish, <b>all the heads should be sacrificed,</b> as it is assumed that the head of the disqualified animal was the one already sacrificed on the altar.
Rava asked Rav Naḥman: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar say: Rabbi Eliezer permitted</b> the sacrifice of all the heads <b>only</b> if they were sacrificed <b>two</b> by <b>two,</b> as at least one of them is certainly permitted; <b>but</b> he did <b>not</b> permit them to be sacrificed <b>one</b> by <b>one,</b> in case the priest sacrifices the prohibited head by itself? How, then, can Rav Naḥman permit the rings without qualification? Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>I</b> too <b>am saying</b> that Rav permits the rings only if they are sold <b>two</b> at a time, in which case one of them is certainly not from idol worship.
The Gemara discusses a similar case. <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a ring</b> used in <b>idol worship that was intermingled with one hundred</b> permitted <b>rings, and</b> then <b>forty</b> of them became <b>separated to one place, and</b> the other <b>sixty</b> became separated <b>to another place,</b> so that they are now two distinct groups of rings, if <b>one</b> ring <b>from</b> the group of <b>forty</b> became <b>separated</b> from them and then became intermingled with other rings, <b>it does not render</b> them <b>prohibited.</b> But if <b>one</b> ring <b>from</b> the other <b>sixty</b> became separated from its group and became mixed with other rings, it <b>renders</b> them <b>prohibited.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> concerning the case in which <b>one</b> ring <b>from</b> the group of <b>forty</b> separated, <b>that</b> it does <b>not</b> render the other rings prohibited? The reason is <b>that we say:</b> The <b>prohibited</b> ring <b>is in</b> the group that contains <b>the majority</b> of the rings, i.e., it is in the group of sixty. If so, in the case where <b>one</b> ring <b>from</b> the group of <b>sixty</b> became separated and became intermingled with the other rings, <b>we</b> should <b>also say</b> that the <b>prohibited</b> ring <b>is</b> still <b>in</b> the group that contains <b>the majority</b> of the rings, i.e., it is one of the fifty-nine remaining rings. <b>Rather,</b> Rav’s statement was as follows: <b>If all forty</b> became <b>separated to one place,</b> where they became intermingled with other rings, the forty rings <b>do not render</b> those other rings <b>prohibited,</b> as it is assumed that the prohibited ring is in the group of sixty. Conversely, if all of the <b>sixty</b> rings became separated <b>to one place,</b> where they became intermingled with other rings, the sixty rings <b>render</b> those other rings <b>prohibited.</b>
Rav Yehuda, who said this statement citing Rav, added: <b>When I said this</b> ruling <b>in the presence of Shmuel,</b> that if the forty rings became intermingled with others they do not render them prohibited, <b>he said to me: Disregard</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the case of <b>idol worship, as</b> this prohibition is so stringent that <b>its uncertainty and its compound uncertainty are prohibited forever,</b> i.e., no matter how many uncertainties are added they are all prohibited.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Shmuel from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An uncertainty of idol worship</b> is <b>prohibited, but its compound uncertainty</b> is <b>permitted. How so?</b> With regard to <b>a cup</b> used in <b>idol worship that fell into a storeroom full of cups, they are all prohibited.</b> If <b>one of these</b> cups <b>separated</b> from the rest and fell <b>into</b> a group of <b>ten thousand</b> other cups, <b>and from</b> that <b>ten thousand</b> cups a single cup fell <b>into ten thousand</b> other cups, <b>they</b> are <b>permitted.</b> This <i>baraita</i> teaches that only one uncertainty is prohibited, not a compound uncertainty.
The Gemara explains: This <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 5:10) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Prohibited <b>pomegranates</b> from <b>Badan,</b> which are too significant to be nullified, <b>prohibit</b> a mixture <b>in any amount. How so?</b> If <b>one of them fell into</b> a group of <b>ten thousand</b> other pomegranates, <b>and</b> one of that group fell <b>from</b> that <b>ten thousand into</b> another <b>ten thousand, they</b> are all <b>prohibited,</b> despite the fact that this is a compound uncertainty.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> If a prohibited pomegranate fell <b>into</b> a group of <b>ten thousand</b> pomegranates, <b>they</b> are all <b>prohibited,</b> as he concedes that these pomegranates are not nullified in a majority. <b>But</b> if one pomegranate <b>from</b> the <b>ten thousand</b> fell <b>into</b> a group of <b>three</b> pomegranates, <b>and</b> one <b>of</b> these <b>three</b> pomegranates fell <b>into a different place,</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> as this is a compound uncertainty.
The Gemara inquires: <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>which</b> of these <i>tanna’im</i> <b>does Shmuel state</b> his opinion that an item used in idol worship remains prohibited no matter how many uncertainties are involved? <b>If</b> you say that he stated his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> then <b>even with regard to other prohibitions</b> a compound uncertainty should be <b>prohibited,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda stated his ruling with regard to a prohibited pomegranate, not an item of idol worship. And <b>if</b> Shmuel stated his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> then <b>even in the</b> case of <b>idol worship</b> a compound uncertainty should be <b>permitted,</b> as Rabbi Shimon did not differentiate between different types of prohibitions.
<b>And if you would say</b> that there is <b>a difference according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon between idol worship and other prohibitions,</b> and he prohibits compound uncertainties only in the case of idol worship, <b>then</b> if so, <b>that which is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited previously: <b>An uncertainty of idol worship</b> is <b>prohibited but its compound uncertainty</b> is <b>permitted, whose</b> opinion does this represent? It is <b>neither</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda nor</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> that <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> as he permits a compound uncertainty in all cases. <b>And Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to one</b> matter, that a compound uncertainty is prohibited in the case of idol worship, <b>and disagrees with him with regard to one</b> matter, as Shmuel does not apply this stringency to other prohibitions.
§ The Gemara continues its analysis. <b>The Master,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda citing Rabbi Shimon, <b>says</b> above: If one pomegranate <b>from</b> the <b>ten thousand</b> fell <b>into</b> a group of <b>three</b> pomegranates, <b>and</b> one <b>of</b> these <b>three</b> pomegranates fell <b>into a different place,</b> the mixture is <b>permitted.</b>

Daf 74b

The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about a case where the pomegranate fell into a group of <b>three</b> other pomegranates? The essential factor is <b>that there is a majority</b> of permitted pomegranates, which nullify the pomegranate that fell from the ten thousand. <b>Even</b> if it fell into a group of <b>two</b> others, <b>there is a majority</b> of permitted items. Why must it fall into a group of three? The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>three that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches?</b> It means that there were <b>two</b> permitted pomegranates initially, <b>and</b> the pomegranate of uncertain status fell into them, for a total of three.
The Gemara returns to the question concerning the opinion of which <i>tanna</i> is followed by Shmuel, who is stringent with regard to a compound uncertainty involving idol worship. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that Shmuel <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as he is similarly stringent with regard to mixtures of items of idol worship, as explained in tractate <i>Avoda Zara</i> (49b).
§ The Gemara discusses a related topic. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> In the case of <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> produce, which may be eaten only by a priest and his household, <b>that was intermingled with one hundred barrels</b> of non-sacred produce, they are all considered as <i>teruma</i>, as a sealed barrel is significant and is not nullified. <b>And</b> if <b>one of</b> these barrels <b>fell into the Dead Sea, all</b> the barrels <b>are permitted, as we say:</b> Since there is <b>that</b> barrel <b>that fell,</b> the assumption is <b>that</b> it is <b>the prohibited</b> barrel that <b>fell.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it <b>was necessary</b> for the Gemara to record the ruling <b>of Rav Naḥman</b> with regard to rings used in idol worship, <b>and</b> it <b>was</b> also <b>necessary</b> for the Gemara to record the ruling <b>of Reish Lakish</b> with regard to barrels of <i>teruma</i>, despite the similarity between the two cases. The Gemara elaborates: <b>As, if</b> the <i>halakha</i> were taught only <b>from</b> the ruling <b>of Rav Naḥman, I would say</b> that <b>this matter</b> applies only with regard to a mixture involving an item of <b>idol worship, which has no permitting factors;</b> such items themselves cannot be permitted in any other manner. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> is to be lenient, i.e., to assume that the prohibited ring fell into the sea. <b>But</b> in the case of <b><i>teruma</i>, which has permitting factors,</b> as the mixture can be sold in its entirety to priests, perhaps the mixture should <b>not</b> be permitted because one of them fell into the sea.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>halakha</i> was taught only <b>from</b> the ruling <b>of Reish Lakish, I would say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is lenient only in the case of <b>a barrel</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as its falling is noticeable,</b> and everyone will know that the other barrels were permitted due to the one that fell. Accordingly, they will not come to permit barrels in a similar case where no barrel became separated from the mixture. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a ring, whose falling is not noticeable,</b> perhaps the rest of the rings should <b>not</b> be permitted. Therefore, both statements <b>are necessary.</b>
<b>Rabba says: Reish Lakish deemed</b> the rest of the items <b>permitted only</b> in the case of <b>a barrel, as its falling is noticeable. But</b> in the case of <b>a fig</b> that fell from a group of figs that contained a fig of <i>teruma</i>, Reish Lakish does <b>not</b> deem the rest of the figs permitted, as the one that fell is too small for its fall to be discernible. <b>And Rav Yosef says:</b> Reish Lakish deemed the rest of the items permitted <b>even</b> with regard to <b>a fig.</b> The reason is that just <b>as</b> the initial <b>falling</b> of one fig rendered the entire mixture prohibited, <b>so too, the emerging of</b> one fig from the pile permits the rest.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> With regard to <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> wine <b>that fell among one hundred barrels</b> of non-sacred wine, it cannot be nullified in its current state, as sealed barrels are significant and are therefore not nullified. How should one proceed? He should <b>open one of them,</b> so that it is no longer an item of significance, <b>and take from it as much as</b> ought to be taken from a normal <b>mixture</b> of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce, i.e., one-hundredth. He should give that to a priest, <b>and</b> then he may <b>drink</b> the rest of the wine.
<b>Rav Dimi sat and said this <i>halakha</i>,</b> and <b>Rav Naḥman said to him: I see</b> a ruling of: <b>Swallow and drink here,</b> i.e., this formulation indicates that one may act in this manner <i>ab initio</i>, which is puzzling. <b>Rather, say:</b> If <b>one of</b> the barrels <b>was opened,</b> after the fact <b>one may take from it as much as</b> ought to be taken from a normal <b>mixture</b> of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce. He should give that to a priest, <b>and</b> then he may <b>drink</b> the rest of the wine.
With regard to the same issue, <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> In the case of <b>a barrel of <i>teruma</i></b> wine <b>that was intermingled with 150 barrels</b> of non-sacred wine, <b>and one hundred of them opened, one may take from it as much as</b> ought to be taken from a normal <b>mixture</b> of <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred produce. He should give that to a priest, <b>and</b> then he may <b>drink</b> the rest of the wine. <b>And</b> as for the <b>rest</b> of the fifty barrels, <b>they</b> remain <b>prohibited,</b> i.e., they have <i>teruma</i> status, <b>until they are opened</b> and the ratio of <i>teruma</i> is separated from them. This is because <b>we do not say</b> that the <b>prohibited</b> barrel <b>is in</b> the group that contains <b>the majority</b> of barrels and the one he opens is likely permitted.
§ The mishna listed various categories of prohibited animals: <b>An animal that copulated with a person, or an animal that was the object of bestiality,</b> an animal that was set aside for idol worship or one that was worshipped as a deity, an animal that was given as payment to a prostitute or as the price of a dog, or an animal born of a mixture of diverse kinds, or an animal that is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> the other examples in this list, the prohibited animal is <b>not known.</b> In other words, it is physically indistinguishable from the other animals. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>this <i>tereifa</i></b> animal, <b>what are the circumstances? If,</b> due to its physical impairment, it is <b>known to him</b> which animal it is, <b>let him come and take it</b> from there, and all the other animals will be permitted. <b>If it is not known to him, how does he know that</b> a <i>tereifa</i> animal <b>was intermingled</b> with others in the first place?
<b>They say</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai: What are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> an animal that was <b>pierced by a thorn,</b> which does not render it a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>was intermingled with</b> an animal that was <b>clawed by a wolf,</b> which renders it a <i>tereifa</i>. Since the skin of both animals has been pierced, one cannot identify the <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Reish Lakish says</b> there is a different answer: The mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> a healthy animal <b>was intermingled with a fallen</b> animal, i.e., one that has fallen from a great height. A fallen animal is prohibited in case it is a <i>tereifa</i>, despite the fact that it bears no external sign of injury. The Gemara raises a difficulty: With regard to <b>a fallen</b> animal <b>as well, let us examine it</b> and see if it can walk by itself, in which case it is not a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara answers: According to the opinion of Reish Lakish, even after an examination of this kind it is still a possible <i>tereifa</i>, which is prohibited to be sacrificed upon the altar, as <b>he holds</b> that if an animal fell and <b>stood</b> up again, <b>it requires</b> a twenty-four-hour waiting <b>period</b> to determine if it is in fact injured. Furthermore, even if it both stood up and <b>walked</b> after the fall, <b>it requires inspection</b> after slaughter to determine whether it was injured by the fall and rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> there is a third answer: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> a healthy animal <b>was intermingled with the offspring of a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> which of course bears no sign of a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And</b> this <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says: The offspring of a <i>tereifa</i> may not be sacrificed upon the altar.</b>
The Gemara explains why each of these Sages suggests a different interpretation of the mishna: <b>All of them,</b> i.e., Reish Lakish and Rabbi Yirmeya, <b>do not say</b> that the explanation of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yannai</b> that an animal pierced by a thorn became mixed up with one clawed by a wolf, as they maintain that the difference <b>between</b> an animal <b>pierced by a thorn and</b> one that was <b>clawed by a wolf is known,</b> as <b>this</b> perforation caused by a wolf is <b>elongated, and that</b> perforation caused by a thorn is <b>round.</b>
The Gemara continues: Rabbi Yannai and Rabbi Yirmeya <b>do not say</b> that the explanation of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> that the mishna is discussing a case where a healthy animal became intermingled with one that has fallen, as <b>they hold</b> that if a fallen animal <b>stood,</b> it <b>does not require</b> a twenty-four-hour waiting <b>period,</b> and if it <b>walked it does not require</b> any further <b>inspection</b> after slaughter at all. Consequently, one can simply examine the animals to see if they can walk, and if they can, they are fit.
Finally, Rabbi Yannai and Reish Lakish <b>do not say</b> that the explana-tion of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yirmeya,</b> that the mishna is discussing a case where a healthy animal became intermingled with the offspring of a <i>tereifa</i>, as they <b>do not</b> want to <b>interpret</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> because the <i>halakha</i> does not follow his ruling.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where <b>sacrificial</b> animals were intermingled <b>with</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> animals, if it was an animal of one <b>type</b> of offering <b>with</b> animals of the same <b>type</b> of offering, one should sacrifice this animal for the sake of whoever is its owner and one should sacrifice that animal for the sake of whoever is its owner, and both owners fulfill their obligations. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> each animal <b>requires placing hands</b> on its head, a rite that must be performed by its owner, and in this case the owner is unknown.
<b>Rav Yosef says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to an offering of women,</b> who do not perform the placing of hands. The Gemara is puzzled by this suggestion: <b>But</b> this indicates that <b>with regard to an offering of men,</b> the <i>halakha</i> stated in the mishna is <b>not</b> applicable, and therefore there is no way of rectifying a mixture of consecrated animals of the same type of offering.

Daf 75a

<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> this from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:22): With regard to <b>the offering of an individual that was intermingled with</b> another <b>offering of an individual, and</b> likewise <b>a communal offering that was intermingled with</b> another <b>communal offering, or the offering of an individual and a communal offering that were intermingled with each other,</b> the priest <b>places four placements</b> of blood <b>from each and every one</b> of them on the altar, and in this manner fulfills the obligation of the blood rites of all the offerings. <b>But if he placed</b> one <b>placement from each one,</b> he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>And</b> likewise, <b>if he placed four</b> placements <b>from all of them</b> together, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that he places from the blood of each of the offerings <i>ab initio</i>, <b>said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the offerings <b>were intermingled</b> when they were still <b>alive,</b> before they were sacrificed, and therefore the priest could perform four placements from the blood of each animal separately. <b>But</b> if <b>slaughtered</b> animals <b>were</b> then <b>intermingled,</b> i.e., their blood became mixed together in one container, the priest <b>places four placements from all of them</b> together, only one set of four.
<b>And</b> in any case, <b>if he placed one placement from all of them,</b> he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the blood of all these offerings is placed on the outer altar, and with regard to all of them one fulfills the obligation after the fact with a single placement. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: One assesses the</b> blood of the <b>placement</b> given from each animal; <b>if there is enough in</b> that blood for a placement of blood <b>for this</b> offering <b>and enough for that</b> one, it is <b>fit, but if not,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: This <i>baraita</i> indicates that if live offerings became intermingled, each is sacrificed for its owner, despite the fact that these offerings are owned by men and therefore require placing of the hands. It is evident that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to offerings of men, as it <b>teaches</b> the case of the offering of <b>an individual</b> adjacent to, and therefore <b>similar to,</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering: <b>Just as a communal</b> offering is sacrificed by <b>men, so too,</b> the offering of <b>an individual</b> that is being discussed here also belongs to <b>men.</b> This presents a difficulty to the explanation of Rav Yosef.
<b>Rava says: And can you understand</b> the <i>baraita</i> in this manner? Is <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>accurate</b> as it stands? There is another difficulty with the <i>baraita</i>, <b>as it teaches: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> these offerings <b>were intermingled</b> when they were still <b>alive. But</b> if <b>slaughtered</b> animals <b>were intermingled</b> it is <b>not</b> said. This is problematic, as <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> whether the animals are <b>alive</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>slaughtered?</b> This is not the decisive factor, as even if the animals were slaughtered, if the blood of each is in a separate vessel the priest should perform separate placements from the blood of each.
Rava continues: <b>Rather, this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> these offerings <b>were intermingled</b> after they were <b>slaughtered,</b> but they were <b>similar to living</b> animals, i.e., the blood of each animal was <b>in</b> separate <b>cups. But</b> in a situation <b>where</b> the blood of these animals was <b>mixed</b> together in a single cup, the priest <b>places four placements</b> of blood <b>from all of them. And if he placed one placement from all of them,</b> he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. If so, this <i>baraita</i> has no bearing on the issue of offerings that became intermingled while they were still alive, as it deals exclusively with the blood of animals that have been slaughtered.
§ The <i>baraita</i> cited teaches that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: One assesses the</b> blood of the <b>placement</b> given from each animal; <b>if there is enough in</b> that blood for a placement of blood <b>for this</b> offering <b>and enough for that</b> offering, it is <b>fit, but if not,</b> the offerings are <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>hold</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> that there must be a minimum amount of blood placed from each offering? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Para</i> 9:5) with regard to the water of purification into which water that is invalid for sprinkling fell that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: According to the statement of Rabbi Eliezer,</b>

Daf 75b

<b>a sprinkling of any</b> amount of the water of purification on someone rendered impure by impurity imparted by a corpse <b>purifies</b> him from his ritual impurity, as <b>sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> to purify him. Likewise, <b>a sprinkling</b> of water that is <b>half fit and half unfit</b> for sprinkling serves to purify the individual. Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that no minimum amount is required for the sprinkling of the water of purification, and the same should apply to the sprinkling of blood on the altar.
The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> but he himself does not agree with this opinion. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>sprinkling</b> of water of purification <b>is discrete and placement</b> of blood on the altar <b>is discrete,</b> i.e., these are two separate <i>halakhot</i> that have no bearing on each other.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where sacrificial animals <b>were intermingled with a firstborn</b> offering <b>or with</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, they shall graze until they become unfit for sacrifice and they shall both be eaten as a firstborn offering or as an animal tithe offering. This means that one may not sell them in the marketplace nor sell their meat by weight, so as not to degrade consecrated animals. <b>Rami bar Ḥama says:</b> With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> who hold (<i>Bekhorot</i> 33a) that even after a firstborn offering develops a blemish the priest may not eat it in a state of ritual impurity, and therefore <b>one may not feed</b> it <b>to menstruating women, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>its substitute?</b> That is, if the owner of a firstborn animal stated with regard to a non-sacred animal in his possession: This animal is a substitute for the firstborn offering, is a menstruating woman permitted to eat that substitute after it develops a blemish?
Rami bar Ḥama further asks: <b>A firstborn</b> offering itself <b>may not be redeemed,</b> even after it develops a blemish, but <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to redeeming <b>its substitute?</b> He likewise inquired: <b>A firstborn</b> offering itself, even after it develops a blemish, <b>may not be weighed</b> and sold <b>by the <i>litra</i>,</b> in the manner that non-sacred meat is sold. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>its substitute</b> in this regard? <b>Rava says</b> that an answer to these questions <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a firstborn</b> offering <b>or</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>from when they develop a blemish they</b> can be used to <b>render</b> another animal <b>a substitute, and their substitute</b> has the same status <b>as them.</b> Their substitutes have the same <i>halakhot</i> as they do.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma:</b> If the priest who received a firstborn offering <b>dedicated</b> the <b>firstborn</b> offering <b>to the Temple maintenance,</b> i.e., he vowed to give the value of the firstborn offering to the Temple, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the matter <b>that he may weigh</b> its meat <b>by the <i>litra</i>?</b> The Gemara explains the dilemma: In this case, is consideration of <b>the profit of the Temple</b> treasury <b>preferable, or perhaps</b> avoidance of the <b>demeaning of the firstborn</b> offering is <b>preferable.</b> If the profit of the Temple treasury is preferable, the firstborn offering should be weighed in the normal manner so as to increase its price; a buyer will pay more for meat he is able to resell it afterward by exact weight. If avoidance of demeaning the firstborn offering is preferable, it should not be weighed by the <i>litra</i>, even though a loss to the Temple would result.
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Zevida says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the ruling of the mishna: In a case where sacrificial animals <b>were intermingled with a firstborn</b> offering <b>or with</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>they shall graze until they become unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>and they shall</b> both <b>be eaten as a firstborn</b> offering <b>or as</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering. Is this <b>not</b> meaning <b>to say that</b> the sacrificial animal that became intermingled with a firstborn offering <b>is</b> also <b>not weighed by the <i>litra</i>,</b> despite the fact that this causes a slight loss to the Temple?
<b>Rav Huna and Rabbi Ḥizkiyya,</b> the <b>students of Rabbi Yirmeya, say: Are</b> these cases <b>comparable? There,</b> the mishna is referring to <b>two</b> separate <b>sanctities,</b> the sanctity of a firstborn offering and that of another offering, <b>and two</b> separate <b>bodies,</b> i.e., two different animals, and in such a case one may not degrade the sanctity of the firstborn due to the other animal with which it is intermingled.
