Conversely, <b>here,</b> with regard to one who vows to give the value of a firstborn to the Temple, there are <b>two sanctities,</b> a firstborn offering and the Temple maintenance, <b>but</b> they are both found in <b>one body.</b> In this case, as the sanctity of the Temple maintenance itself is in the firstborn offering, it may be weighed by the <i>litra</i>, because of the profit the Temple will gain.
<b>Rav Yosei bar Avin objects to this: What</b> would be the <i>halakha</i> <b>if one says: Redeem for me,</b> i.e., I wish to redeem, <b>a firstborn</b> offering <b>that he</b> had previously <b>dedicated</b> as the object of his vow <b>to the Temple maintenance? Does</b> the court <b>listen to him?</b> His request is certainly not granted, as by Torah law a firstborn offering may not be redeemed. Similarly, the fact that he dedicated the value of the firstborn offering to the Temple should not negate the prohibition of weighing it by the <i>litra</i>. The Gemara questions this comparison: One cannot raise a difficulty from a case where someone says: <b>Redeem</b> the firstborn offering for me, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> with regard to a firstborn offering: “But the firstborn of a bull, or the firstborn of a sheep, or the firstborn of a goat, <b>you shall not redeem;</b> they are sacred” (Numbers 18:17). But the weighing of the offering by the <i>litra</i> is not prohibited by Torah law.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests a different resolution of Rami bar Ḥama’s dilemma: <b>Rabbi Ami says: Can this</b> priest <b>transfer</b> to the Temple maintenance anything <b>other than that which was transferred to him?</b> In other words, just as the priest who took the vow may not weigh the firstborn by the <i>litra</i> and gain a profit, the same applies to the Temple treasury, the recipient of his vow.
§ The mishna teaches: All offerings <b>can become</b> indistinguishably <b>intermingled</b> with each other, except for a sin offering and a guilt offering. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>a sin offering and a guilt offering,</b> that they cannot become intermingled? Is the reason <b>that this,</b> a guilt offering, is always <b>a male, and that,</b> a sin offering, is always <b>a female?</b>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>A sin offering and a burnt offering</b> are <b>also</b> like this, as a sin offering is always female while a burnt offering is always male. The Gemara answers that although the standard sin offering is always female, <b>there is</b> the <b>goat</b> of the <b><i>Nasi</i>,</b> which is a male sin offering, and therefore it can become intermingled with a male goat burnt offering. And as to the statement of the mishna that a sin offering cannot become intermingled with a guilt offering despite the male sin offering of the <i>Nasi</i>, that is because <b>this</b> goat has straight <b>hair and that</b> guilt offering comes only from sheep or rams, which have <b>wool,</b> and the wool is curly.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>A Paschal offering and a guilt offering also cannot become intermingled,</b> as <b>this</b> Paschal offering is <b>in its first year, and that</b> guilt offering is <b>in its second year.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>there is the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper,</b> which must be in their first year. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that an animal in its first year can become intermingled with an animal in its second year, as <b>there is</b> an animal <b>in its first year that looks like</b> an animal <b>in its second year, and</b> likewise <b>there is</b> an animal <b>in its second year that looks like</b> an animal <b>in its first year.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a guilt offering that was intermingled with a peace offering, Rabbi Shimon says: Both of them should be slaughtered in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, as a guilt offering must be slaughtered in the north while a peace offering may be slaughtered anywhere in the courtyard. <b>And</b> they both <b>must be eaten in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the</b> more <b>stringent of them,</b> i.e., the guilt offering, with the following <i>halakhot</i>: They may be eaten only in the courtyard rather than throughout Jerusalem; by male priests and not by any ritually pure Jew; and on the day they were sacrificed and the following night, and not on the day they were sacrificed, the following day, and the intervening night.
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon: One may not limit the time of the consumption of an offering, as <b>one may not bring sacrificial</b> animals <b>to the status of unfitness.</b> According to Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, the peace offering becomes leftover, <i>notar</i>, the morning after it is sacrificed, and not at the end of that day, as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning peace offerings. Rather, the Rabbis hold, the owner shall wait until these animals become blemished, redeem them, and bring an offering of each type that is worth the monetary value of the higher-quality animal among them.
The mishna adds: Even according to the opinion of the Rabbis, if <b>pieces</b> of the meat of one offering <b>were intermingled with pieces</b> of the meat of another offering, e.g., meat from <b>offerings of the most sacred order with</b> meat from <b>offerings of lesser sanctity;</b> or if pieces of meat from offerings <b>eaten for one day</b> and the following night were intermingled <b>with</b> pieces of meat from offerings <b>eaten for two days and</b> one <b>night,</b> since in that case the remedy with regard to offerings that were intermingled cannot be implemented, they both <b>must be eaten in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the</b> more <b>stringent of them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> In connection to the principle cited by the Rabbis in the mishna that one may not bring consecrated animals to the status of unfitness, <b>a <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Shevi’it</i> 6:29) <b>before Rav:</b> With regard to produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>one may not purchase</b> produce of <b><i>teruma</i></b> from a previous year <b>with its money,</b> i.e., money received in its sale, <b>because</b> one thereby <b>reduces the</b> time of <b>eating</b> the <i>teruma</i>. The produce of the Sabbatical Year may be eaten only until the time of the removal of that type of produce from the field, whereas <i>teruma</i> may be consumed at any time.
<b>The Sages said</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rabba,</b> and they explained that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> in the mishna. Their reasoning was <b>that if</b> you would say it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, doesn’t he say,</b> as can be inferred from the mishna, that <b>one may bring sacrificial</b> animals <b>to the status of unfitness?</b> Similarly, one can limit the time allowed for the consumption of the Sabbatical Year produce.
Rabba <b>said to them: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. That statement,</b> that one may bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness, applies only in a case that is <b>after the fact,</b> as in the mishna, where offerings became intermingled. Rabbi Shimon did <b>not</b> permit one to bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does Rabbi Shimon <b>not</b> permit one to bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness <b><i>ab initio</i>? Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba from a mishna that discusses the manner of eating the meat of offerings (Zevachim 90b):

Daf 76a

<b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> the offerings that are eaten, the <b>priests are permitted to alter</b> the manner <b>of their consumption</b> and eat them as they choose. Therefore, the priests are permitted <b>to eat them roasted, boiled, or cooked, and</b> they are likewise permitted <b>to place non-sacred spices or <i>teruma</i> spices in</b> the cooking pot. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b> This indicates that it is permitted to spice offerings with <i>teruma</i> spices <i>ab initio</i>, despite the fact that this reduces the time available to eat the <i>teruma</i>. Rabba <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Set aside</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>teruma</i> of spices,</b> as this <i>teruma</i> applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> not by Torah law.
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabba from a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 3:2): <b>One may not purchase <i>teruma</i> with</b> second <b>tithe money, because</b> he thereby <b>limits</b> the circumstances <b>for the eating of</b> the <i>teruma</i>. <i>Teruma</i> may be eaten in any place and even by an acute mourner, i.e., one whose relative died that same day and has not yet been buried, whereas second tithe and food purchased with second tithe money must be eaten in Jerusalem and is prohibited to an acute mourner. <b>And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> one to purchase <i>teruma</i> with second tithe money. This indicates that Rabbi Shimon allows one to bring <i>teruma</i> to the status of unfitness. Rabba <b>was silent</b> in response <b>to his</b> statement, and did not answer Abaye.
<b>When</b> Abaye <b>came before Rav Yosef</b> and told him of his discussion with Rabba, Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Why didn’t you raise an objection to</b> Rabba <b>from this</b> mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 8:7): <b>One may not cook vegetables of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year <b>in <i>teruma</i> oil, so that one does not bring consecrated</b> food, <i>teruma</i>, <b>to the status of unfitness,</b> as the <i>teruma</i> oil would have to be eaten before the time of the removal of the Sabbatical Year produce; <b>and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> one to cook in this manner. Evidently, Rabbi Shimon allows one to bring <i>teruma</i> to the status of unfitness <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And didn’t I raise an objection to</b> Rabba <b>from that</b> mishna discussing the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>spices, and he said to me: Disregard</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>teruma</i> of spices,</b> as this <i>teruma</i> applies <b>by rabbinic law. Here too,</b> with regard to vegetables of the Sabbatical Year, he could likewise say that this <b><i>teruma</i></b> oil is not olive oil, but oil that is <b><i>teruma</i> of vegetables,</b> which applies <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Rav Yosef replied: <b>If so,</b> that this mishna is referring to vegetable oil of <i>teruma</i>, <b>it should teach the opposite</b> case, that one may not cook <b>vegetables of <i>teruma</i> in oil of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. Since the <i>tanna</i> specifies <i>teruma</i> oil, he must certainly be speaking of <i>teruma</i> by Torah law, i.e., olive oil.
Abaye then said to Rav Yosef: <b>And didn’t I raise an objection to</b> Rabba <b>from the mishna,</b> in <b>which Rabbi Shimon permits</b> one to bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness, <b>and</b> Rabba <b>said to me that</b> Rabbi Shimon’s ruling applies only after the fact, when the guilt offering and peace offering <b>have become intermingled? Here too,</b> he would say <b>that</b> this ruling is after the fact, that when the <i>teruma</i> oil and the vegetables of the Sabbatical Year <b>have become intermingled</b> one may then cook them together, but he does not permit one to cook them together <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the foods <b>have</b> already <b>become intermingled, what is the reason of the Rabbis</b> for prohibiting one to cook them together? The Gemara answers: This is <b>just as it is</b> in the case of the mishna <b>with regard to a guilt offering and a peace offering</b> that became intermingled, that even after the offerings are intermingled, one may not bring the flesh of the peace offering to the status of unfitness.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Are</b> these two cases <b>comparable? There,</b> with regard to the offerings, the situation <b>has a remedy by</b> having the offerings <b>graze</b> until they develop a blemish, at which point the owner brings each offering of each type with the monetary value of the higher-quality animal. By contrast, in <b>this</b> case of <i>teruma</i> oil mixed with vegetables of the Sabbatical Year, the situation <b>has no remedy</b> similar to that <b>of</b> having the offerings <b>graze,</b> and therefore if the Rabbis prohibited the mixture the <i>teruma</i> would go to waste.
If one wishes to compare this case of oil and vegetables to an intermingling of sacrificial animals, <b>this is comparable only to</b> the other <i>halakha</i> of the mishna, which addresses <b>a piece</b> of the flesh of an offering of the most sacred order <b>that</b> was intermingled <b>with pieces</b> of the flesh of offerings of lesser sanctity. Here the Rabbis concede that <b>since there is no remedy</b> for the intermingled pieces, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> they both <b>must be eaten in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the</b> more <b>stringent among them,</b> but they are not prohibited.
<b>Ravina objects to this</b> comparison: <b>Are</b> these cases <b>comparable?</b> In the case of the <b>piece</b> of sacrificial flesh <b>that</b> is intermingled <b>with the</b> other <b>pieces, it has no remedy at all,</b> whereas <b>this</b> case of <i>teruma</i> oil <b>has a remedy through squeezing</b> the oil from the vegetables. If so, this case of vegetables is in fact comparable to that of an intermingling of a guilt offering and peace offering, which also have a means of remedy, and for this reason the Rabbis prohibited the mixture.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>Rav Yosef</b> respond to the claim that the Rabbis prohibit this mixture after the fact because there is a remedy available through squeezing it? The Gemara explains that Rav Yosef would respond that squeezing is not in fact a remedy, as <b>how can one squeeze</b> it? If <b>one squeezes</b> the vegetables <b>a lot,</b> he thereby <b>causes a loss of Sabbatical</b> Year produce; if <b>one squeezes</b> the vegetables <b>a little, ultimately</b> the <i>teruma</i> oil and vegetables of the Sabbatical Year <b>will</b> still <b>be intermingled,</b> as this squeezing will be ineffective. If so, Rav Yosef’s contention that in this case the Rabbis would not have prohibited cooking vegetables of the Sabbatical Year in <i>teruma</i> oil remains valid. Consequently, this must be referring to a case where the vegetables and oil have not yet become mixed, which means that this case does prove that Rabbi Shimon permits one to bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness <i>ab initio</i>, not only after the fact, as claimed by Rabba.
Rav Yosef <b>raised an objection to</b> the opinion of Rabba from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nazir</i> 6:1): How should one whose status as a confirmed leper has not been determined bring his guilt offering and <i>log</i> of oil on the eighth day of his purification? <b>Rabbi Shimon says: On the following day,</b> after his seven days of purification, <b>he brings his guilt offering and his <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>with it, and says</b> the following stipulation: <b>If this</b> offering is one <b>of a leper,</b> i.e., if I am a confirmed leper, <b>this is his,</b> i.e., my, <b>guilt offering and that is his <i>log</i></b> of oil.

Daf 76b

<b>And if</b> he is <b>not</b> a leper, <b>this</b> animal that is brought for <b>a guilt offering</b> shall be <b>a voluntary peace offering,</b> because their sacrificial rites are equivalent. <b>And that</b> uncertain <b>guilt offering requires slaughter in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard as a guilt offering, <b>and placement</b> of the blood on the right <b>thumb</b> and <b>big toe</b> and right ear of the leper, as described in Leviticus 14:14, <b>and</b> it requires <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the animal, <b>and</b> the accompanying wine <b>libations and waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh</b> like a peace offering.
<b>And</b> lastly, <b>it is eaten</b> by males of the priesthood <b>on</b> the <b>day</b> it is sacrificed <b>and</b> the following <b>night,</b> in the Temple courtyard, like a guilt offering, not for two days and one night in the manner of a peace offering. This indicates that Rabbi Shimon permits one to bring sacrificial animals to the status of unfitness even <i>ab initio</i>, not only when the animals became intermingled. The Gemara answers that <b>the remedy of a man is different</b> from the case discussed by Rabba. Since this person has no way of purifying himself from his leprosy other than by bringing the offering, the concern of reducing the time available for its consumption is disregarded.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the resolution suggested by Rabbi Shimon of bringing the offerings and stating a stipulation. This <b>works out well</b> with regard to the <b>guilt offering,</b> but with regard to the <b><i>log</i></b> of oil <b>what can be said?</b> A <i>log</i> of oil does not accompany a peace offering. The Gemara explains <b>that</b> the individual bringing the offering <b>says:</b> If I am not a leper, then <b>this <i>log</i> shall be a gift</b> to the Temple, as one can dedicate oil to the Temple. The Gemara questions this resolution: <b>But perhaps he is not</b> in fact <b>a leper, and</b> if so, it is <b>required</b> that a priest <b>remove a handful</b> of the donated oil and sacrifice a handful of it on the altar before the rest of the oil may be consumed by the priests, as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to oil brought as an offering. The Gemara explains that this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest already <b>removed a handful.</b>
The Gemara further questions: <b>But perhaps he is</b> in fact <b>a leper, and he requires the placement of seven</b> sprinklings of oil before the Lord (see Leviticus 14:15–16). The Gemara answers <b>that</b> the priest does <b>place</b> these sprinklings.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: How can the priest sprinkle the oil? <b>But it is lacking,</b> as a handful has been removed from the oil, and one sprinkles only from a whole <i>log</i>. The Gemara explains <b>that</b> after the handful is removed the priest <b>brings a little</b> more oil to the container <b>and fills it</b> up to a <i>log</i>. This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:10): In a case where <b>the <i>log</i> lacked</b> a full measure, then <b>if</b> it became lacking <b>before</b> the priest <b>poured</b> from it into his palm in order to place it on the right thumb and big toe of the leper, <b>he shall fill it.</b>
The Gemara poses yet another question: <b>But</b> if he is not a leper, and that <i>log</i> of oil is a gift, that handful removed from the oil <b>requires burning</b> on the altar for the remainder of the oil to be permitted to the priests. The Gemara explains <b>that</b> the priest does in fact <b>burn</b> the handful.
The Gemara asks: <b>When</b> does the priest burn the handful? <b>If</b> he does so <b>after the placement of seven</b> sprinklings for the leper’s purification, in such a case the <i>log</i> will be lacking due to the sprinklings. That which remains <b>is</b> akin to the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>that was lacking between</b> the <b>removal of</b> the <b>handful and</b> the <b>burning, and one may not burn the handful for that</b> remainder. Similar to a gift of oil, in a meal offering a handful is removed from the offering and then sacrificed on the altar. If after the handful is removed but before it is sacrificed some of the remainder of the meal offering is separated, the handful may not be sacrificed. The same should apply if some of the oil was sprinkled after the handful was removed.
<b>If,</b> alternatively, the priest burns the handful <b>before the placement of seven</b> sprinklings, once he has burned the handful he may no longer perform the sprinklings, in accordance with the principle: <b>Whatever is partly</b> burned <b>in the fire</b> on the altar <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of: <b>You may not make as an offering</b> (see Leviticus 2:11). This principle states that if part of an item, such as the blood of an animal offering or the handful of a meal offering, has been sacrificed, one who sacrifices any other part of it that is not designated for sacrifice has violated a prohibition. The sprinkling of the oil is equivalent to sacrifice in this regard.
<b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, says that</b> the priest does not sprinkle the oil as a definite rite but stipulates that if the man is not a leper he is sprinkling it in a manner analogous to other items that one <b>burns for the sake of wood,</b> i.e., as fuel for the altar and not as a sacrificial rite. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The verse states: “No meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord shall be made with leaven; for you shall make no leaven, nor any honey, smoke from it as an offering made by fire to the Lord. As an offering of first fruits you may bring them to the Lord; but they shall not come up for a pleasing aroma on the altar” (Leviticus 2:11–12). This verse indicates that <b>you may not offer up</b> leaven and honey <b>as a pleasing aroma,</b> an offering. <b>But you may offer up</b> leaven and honey and other substances

Daf 77a

<b>for the sake of wood,</b> not as an offering. Here as well, the priest stipulates that if the man is not a confirmed leper, the sprinkling of the oil should not be viewed as a rite.
The Gemara questions further: <b>But</b> even if the priest removes a handful from the oil and burns it, and also sprinkles from the oil, <b>there is</b> the matter of the <b>remainder</b> of the oil, <b>which must be filled</b> after the removal of the handful so that the priest can perform the sprinkling with a full <i>log</i>, <b>and there is</b> therefore <b>that bit</b> of oil that was added <b>from which</b> the priest <b>did not remove</b> the <b>handful</b> initially. If the one bringing the offering is not a leper, and the <i>log</i> of oil is a gift, it will turn out that there is a small portion of the oil that was not permitted by the removal of the handful. The Gemara explains <b>that</b> the priest <b>redeems it,</b> i.e., after the sprinklings of the oil have been performed, he stipulates that if the person who brought the offering is not a leper then the oil should be desacralized by his giving its value to the Temple treasury.
The Gemara asks: If you say <b>that he redeems it, where</b> does he redeem it? <b>If</b> he redeems it when the oil is <b>within</b> the walls of the Temple, he would thereby be <b>bringing non-sacred</b> oil <b>into the courtyard. If</b> he redeems the oil <b>outside</b> the courtyard, before he can redeem the oil <b>it would become disqualified due to</b> the prohibition of a consecrated item <b>leaving</b> the courtyard. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> he redeems the oil when it is <b>within</b> the walls of the Temple. This is permitted because the <b>non-sacred</b> oil <b>is</b> then found in the Temple courtyard <b>by itself,</b> i.e., he did not bring a non-sacred item into the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the suggested resolution, according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, that one whose status as a leper is uncertain should bring a <i>log</i> of oil as a gift offering and state a stipulation. <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon say</b> that <b>one may not donate oil</b> as a gift? The Gemara answers, as on 76b: <b>The remedy of a person is different,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon concedes that one may donate oil in this instance, as this is the only manner by which this person can undergo ritual purification.
The Gemara continues to discuss the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. It was stated above that according to Rabbi Shimon, one whose status as a leper is uncertain may bring a lamb as a gift for a peace offering and state a stipulation with regard to it. The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Reḥumi was sitting before Ravina, and he was sitting and saying</b> the following <b>in the name of Rav Huna bar Taḥlifa: But</b> why can’t he bring a lamb for a guilt offering and <b>say</b> that if he is not a leper then <b>this guilt offering shall be a provisional guilt offering,</b> brought by one who is uncertain whether he committed a sin that requires a sin offering? This guilt offering is eaten for one day and night, like the guilt offering of a leper, and therefore he would not be reducing the time for its consumption, unlike when he stipulates that it should be a peace offering.
Rav Reḥumi continued: Since this option was not suggested, one can <b>learn from</b> here that <b>who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that one may donate a provisional guilt offering (<i>Keritut</i> 25a)? <b>It is Rabbi Shimon, who says,</b> by inference from his suggestion here, that <b>one may not donate a provisional guilt offering.</b> Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Reḥumi: <b>Torah, Torah!</b> That is, where is the Torah of such a great man as yourself? <b>You are confusing lambs with rams.</b> The guilt offering of a leper is a lamb in its first year (see Leviticus 14:10), which cannot be brought as a provisional guilt offering because these must be rams (see Leviticus 5:15), i.e., they must be in their second year.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>the limbs of a sin offering,</b> which are eaten by priests and may not be burned on the altar, <b>that were intermingled with the limbs of a burnt offering,</b> which are burned on the altar, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest <b>shall place</b> all the limbs <b>above,</b> on the altar, <b>and I view the flesh</b> of the limbs <b>of the sin offering above</b> on the altar <b>as though they are</b> pieces of <b>wood</b> burned on the altar, and not as though they are an offering. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One should wait until <b>the form of</b> all the intermingled limbs <b>decays and they will</b> all <b>go out to the place of burning</b> in the Temple courtyard, where all disqualified offerings of the most sacred order are burned.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer</b> for deeming it permitted to burn the limbs of the sin offering on the altar as wood? The Gemara explains: <b>The verse states:</b> “No meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord shall be made with leaven; for you shall make no leaven, nor any honey, smoke as an offering made by fire to the Lord. As an offering of first fruits you may bring them to the Lord; <b>but they shall not come up for a pleasing aroma on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 2:11–12). This indicates that <b>you may not offer up</b> leaven and honey <b>as a pleasing aroma,</b> i.e., as an offering. <b>But you may offer up</b> leaven and honey and other substances that are prohibited to be sacrificed upon the altar, such as the limbs of a sin offering, <b>for the sake of wood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer, how do they respond to this reasoning? They claim that <b>the Merciful One excludes</b> other cases at the beginning of the verse: “As an offering of first fruits you may bring <b>them.”</b> This indicates that <b>it is</b> with regard to <b>them,</b> i.e., leaven and honey alone, <b>that</b> it is stated: <b>You may not offer up</b> as an offering, <b>but you may offer up</b> leaven and honey <b>for the sake of wood. But</b> with regard to any <b>other substances</b> that are prohibited to be brought on the altar, one may <b>not</b> offer them up to the altar at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer,</b> what does he derive from this term of exclusion “them”? The Gemara explains: Rabbi Eliezer expounds this word as follows: It is only with regard to <b>them,</b> leaven and honey, <b>that</b> the verse <b>includes</b> a prohibition against bringing them up to the <b>ramp</b> of the altar <b>like</b> offering them up on <b>the altar</b> itself. <b>But</b> with regard to any <b>other substances</b> that are prohibited to be sacrificed upon the altar, bringing them up to the ramp is <b>not</b> considered like offering them up on the altar itself.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> from where do they derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that the Rabbis <b>learn two</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> the word “them.” This term of emphasis teaches that all that is stated in this verse is referring only to leaven and honey, both the <i>halakha</i> that it is permitted to offer them up on the altar as wood, and the ruling that the ramp is considered like the altar with regard to this <i>halakha</i>.
§ The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:15) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis did not disagree with regard to the limbs of a sin offering that were intermingled with the limbs of a burnt offering,</b> as all agree <b>that they shall be sacrificed.</b> Likewise, they agree that if limbs that are fit to be burned on the altar became intermingled <b>with</b> the limbs of <b>an animal that</b> actively <b>copulated with a person, or</b> with the limbs of <b>an animal that was the object of bestiality,</b> which are prohibited to be sacrificed upon the altar, <b>that they shall not be sacrificed,</b> even according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
Rabbi Yehuda continues: <b>With regard to which</b> case <b>did</b> Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis <b>disagree?</b> They disagreed <b>with regard to the limbs of an unblemished burnt offering that were intermingled with the limbs of a blemished</b> animal, which is disqualified from the altar. <b>As</b> in this case <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> All the limbs <b>shall be sacrificed, and I consider</b> the flesh of the limbs of the sin offering <b>above,</b> on the altar, <b>as though they are</b> pieces of <b>wood</b> burned on the altar. <b>And the Rabbis say: They shall not be sacrificed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, what is different</b> about the limbs of <b>an animal that</b> actively <b>copulated with a person, or</b> the limbs of <b>an animal that was the object of bestiality,</b> that they may not be sacrificed? If one says that the reason is <b>that they are not fit</b> for the altar, that cannot be the reason, as <b>a blemished</b> animal <b>is not fit</b> for the altar <b>as well,</b> and there he holds that the limbs are burned.

Daf 77b

<b>Rav Huna says:</b> When Rabbi Eliezer makes reference to a blemished animal, he is speaking of an unobtrusive blemish, e.g., one that is <b>on the cornea of the eye. And</b> his ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that in the case of an offering with such a blemish, <b>if</b> its sacrificial parts <b>ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend</b> from it, because it is not a disgrace to the altar for the sacrificial parts of such an offering to be burned on it. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Say that Rabbi Akiva says</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>after the fact,</b> meaning that if the priest already brought up the limbs of these blemished animals, they do not descend from the altar. <b>Does</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>say</b> that one may burn a mixture of these limbs <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says: What are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> all the limbs in the mixture were <b>brought up upon</b> the <b>ramp.</b> Since they have been brought on the ramp and sanctified as offerings, it is considered after the fact. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if we are dealing with a case in which the limbs were already carried to the ramp, then <b>even</b> if they were <b>as is,</b> and not intermingled, the limbs of the blemished animal should be burned, as claimed by Rabbi Akiva.
<b>Rather, the reason of Rabbi Eliezer</b> is that with regard to the prohibition against sacrificing a blemished animal upon the altar, <b>the Merciful One excludes</b> certain cases. After listing the various disqualifying blemishes, the verse states: “Neither from the hand of a foreigner shall you offer the bread of your God of any of these, because their corruption is in them, there is a blemish in them; they shall not be accepted for you” (Leviticus 22:25). This teaches that <b>it is</b> only if there is <b>a blemish</b> clearly <b>in them that they shall not be accepted; but</b> if they were sacrificed <b>by means of a mixture they shall be accepted.</b> This exclusion is stated only with regard to blemished animals, not with regard to animals that copulated with people, and consequently the limbs of these animals are not brought up to the altar even if they became intermingled with the limbs of fit offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> how do they expound this verse? The Gemara explains that they expound it as follows: <b>It is</b> only if the <b>blemish</b> is still <b>in them that they shall not be accepted; but</b> if their <b>blemish has passed, they shall be accepted. And Rabbi Eliezer</b> derives this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the previous clause in that same verse: “Because their corruption is in them [<i>bahem</i>].” Since the verse could have stated the shorter form of <b><i>bam</i>,</b> and instead stated <b>“<i>bahem</i>,”</b> one derives from here that if the animal no longer is blemished it is accepted as an offering. <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis, they do not interpret</b> anything from the variation between <b><i>bam</i></b> and <b>“<i>bahem</i>”;</b> they do not see this as a significant deviation from the standard language of the verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> and Rabbi Eliezer permits the limbs of blemished animals to be sacrificed if they are in a mixture, why is it necessary for him to say: I <b>view</b> the flesh of the limbs of the blemished animals as though they are pieces of wood? After all, <b>the Merciful One permits</b> them as an offering. The Gemara explains that Rabbi Eliezer is <b>speaking to</b> the Rabbis <b>in accordance with their statement,</b> as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, <b>the Merciful One permits</b> these limbs to be sacrificed upon the altar. But even <b>according to your</b> opinion, <b>at least agree with me</b> that the <b>flesh of a blemished</b> animal that was intermingled with the flesh of a qualified offering <b>is considered like wood, just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>flesh of a sin offering</b> that became intermingled with the flesh of a burnt offering, as according to this <i>baraita</i> the Rabbis concede that the flesh of these two offerings should be sacrificed together.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> how do they respond to this claim of Rabbi Eliezer? The Gemara explains: According to the Rabbis there is a difference between the cases: <b>Here,</b> with regard to a mixture that includes limbs of blemished animals, these limbs <b>are repulsive,</b> and therefore they may not be brought upon the altar, even as wood. Conversely, <b>there,</b> in the case of a mixture of limbs of a sin offering and limbs of a burnt offering, the limbs of the sin offering <b>are not repulsive</b> in and of themselves, and consequently they may be sacrificed upon the altar as wood.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where <b>limbs</b> of burnt offerings fit for sacrifice were intermingled <b>with limbs of blemished</b> burnt offerings, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Although all the limbs are unfit for sacrifice, <b>if the head of one of them was sacrificed all the heads shall be sacrificed,</b> as the head that was sacrificed is assumed to have been that of the unfit animal in the mixture. Likewise, if one sacrificed <b>the legs of one of them all the legs shall be sacrificed. And the Rabbis say: Even</b> if <b>all</b> the limbs <b>were sacrificed except for one of them,</b> there is a concern that the remaining limb is the unfit limb, which may not be sacrificed. Rather, all of the limbs <b>must go out to the place of burning</b> in the Temple courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Rabbi Eliezer permitted</b> the sacrificing of all the heads <b>only</b> if they were sacrificed <b>two</b> by <b>two,</b> as at least one of each pair is certainly permitted; <b>but</b> he did <b>not</b> permit them to be sacrificed <b>one</b> by <b>one,</b> in case the priest may be sacrificing the prohibited head by itself. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises an objection</b> from the mishna, which states: <b>And the Rabbis say: Even</b> if <b>all</b> the limbs <b>were sacrificed except for one of them,</b> all the limbs <b>must go out to the place of burning</b> in the Temple courtyard. This indicates that even in this situation, where only one of the limbs remains, the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis still applies, which means that Rabbi Eliezer permits it to be sacrificed despite the fact that it is only one limb.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya in response: <b>I will explain</b> the meaning of this statement <b>to you: What</b> does the mishna mean when it states: Except for <b>one</b> of them? It means except for <b>one pair,</b> i.e., two limbs, as even Rabbi Eliezer did not permit one to sacrifice the limbs individually.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>blood</b> of an offering fit for sacrifice <b>that was mixed with water, if</b> the mixture <b>has the appearance of blood</b> it is <b>fit</b> for sprinkling on the altar, even though the majority of the mixture is water. If the blood <b>was mixed with</b> red <b>wine, one views</b> the wine <b>as though it is water.</b> If that amount of water would leave the mixture with the appearance of blood it is fit for presentation. And likewise if the blood <b>was mixed with the blood of</b> a non-sacred <b>domesticated animal or the blood of</b> a non-sacred <b>undomesticated animal, one considers</b> the non-sacred blood <b>as though it is water.</b>

Daf 78a

<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Blood does not nullify blood.</b> Therefore, the priest presents the blood of the mixture on the altar.
If blood fit for presentation <b>was mixed with the blood of unfit</b> offerings, there is no remedy. Therefore, the entire mixture <b>shall be poured into the drain</b> running through the Temple courtyard. Likewise, if blood fit for presentation was mixed <b>with blood of exudate,</b> i.e., that exudes from the neck after the initial spurt following its slaughter concludes, which is unfit for presentation, the entire mixture <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain. Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> this mixture <b>fit</b> for presentation. Even according to the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>if</b> the priest <b>did not consult</b> the authorities <b>and placed</b> the blood on the altar, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that in a case where water became mixed with the blood of an offering, if the mixture has the appearance of blood it is fit, despite the fact that there is more water than blood. Concerning this <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the <b>water fell into</b> the <b>blood. But</b> in a case where the <b>blood fell into</b> the <b>water,</b> the <b>first</b> drop of blood, and then the next <b>first</b> drop of blood, is <b>nullified</b> in the water, i.e., each drop is nullified in turn. Consequently, the mixture is unfit for presentation, regardless of whether it has the appearance of blood.
<b>Rav Pappa says: But with regard to</b> the mitzva of <b>covering</b> the blood of birds or undomesticated animals that are slaughtered, <b>it is not so.</b> In this case, even if the blood fell into water, the mitzva of covering applies to it, provided that the mixture has the appearance of blood. The blood is not nullified by the water <b>because there is no</b> permanent <b>rejection with regard to mitzvot,</b> i.e., its nullification was merely temporary, but once there is enough blood in the water, it reassumes its status of blood.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss various mixtures. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> With regard to meat of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it beyond its designated time, <b>and</b> meat of <b><i>notar</i>,</b> an offering whose designated time for consumption has passed, <b>and ritually impure</b> sacrificial meat, each of which was an olive-bulk, the minimum size for which one is liable to be flogged for its consumption, <b>that one mixed together and ate them</b> as a mixture, he is <b>exempt</b> from being flogged. The reason is that it is <b>impossible that</b> while eating them one <b>type would not be greater than another</b> type <b>and nullify it.</b> Since it is unknown which prohibition will nullify the other, one cannot forewarn the offender as to which prohibition he is about to transgress, and in order to be liable to be flogged one must receive a forewarning concerning a specific prohibition.
The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude three</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> this statement of Reish Lakish. <b>Conclude from it</b> that <b>prohibitions nullify one another</b> in a majority, just as permitted items nullify a prohibited item. <b>And conclude from it</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that when a prohibited food <b>imparts flavor</b> to a permitted substance it prohibits it even <b>when</b> the permitted substance is the <b>majority</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>by Torah law,</b> but by rabbinic law. The proof is that if this principle were applied by Torah law, then one should be flogged for this consumption, as the meats are of different types and therefore one of them must have imparted flavor to the other. <b>And</b> finally, <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>an uncertain forewarning,</b> e.g., one in which the witnesses cannot be sure which prohibition the transgressor is about to violate, <b>is not considered a forewarning.</b>
Concerning the inference that the <i>halakha</i> that when a prohibited food imparts flavor to a permitted substance it prohibits it even when the permitted substance is the majority does not apply by Torah law, <b>Rava raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 3:7): In a case where one <b>prepared a dough from wheat and from rice, if</b> this mixture <b>has the taste of wheat,</b> it is <b>obligated in</b> the separation of <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> a portion of dough that must be given to a priest (see Numbers 15:17–21). <i>Ḥalla</i> is separated only from one of the five species of grain, not rice. Rava explains his objection: <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even though the majority</b> of the mixture is flour from <b>rice.</b> Apparently, the fact that the wheat imparts flavor to the dough renders it obligated in <i>ḥalla</i> even if the wheat is the minority.
The Gemara answers: The obligation to set aside <i>ḥalla</i> in this case applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> not by Torah law. Rava raises a difficulty: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of that same mishna: <b>A person can fulfill his obligation with</b> <i>matza</i> from this type of dough <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover.</b> Since by Torah law this mitzva must be fulfilled with <i>matza</i> made from a grain, evidently the principle that one substance that imparts flavor to a greater amount of a different substance affects its status applies by Torah law.

Daf 78b

<b>Rather,</b> one must say that according to Reish Lakish, in a case of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> such as wheat flour and rice flour, whose tastes are different, the status is determined <b>by the flavor.</b> Therefore, if the dough tastes like wheat, it has the <i>halakha</i> of a dough made from wheat. But if it is <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> e.g., a mixture of <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i> meat, which is the case addressed by Reish Lakish, the status of the mixture is determined <b>by the majority.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let us estimate</b> in a case of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type as</b> though it were a mixture of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> and if so, the minority is not nullified if it is substantial enough to impart flavor to the majority. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: If the blood of an offering <b>was mixed with wine, one considers it as though it is water.</b> Although blood and wine certainly have different flavors, in the case of the mishna the determinative factor is not the taste of the mixture, but the appearance. Since they share the same appearance, they are considered a case of a substance in contact with the same type of substance. <b>What, is it not</b> correct to explain the mishna as stating that <b>one views</b> the <b>wine as though it is water,</b> i.e., a substance of a different type, and if the mixture would have the appearance of blood if the wine were water it is fit for presentation, despite the fact that the blood is not the majority?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this is not the explanation of the mishna. Rather, it means that <b>one views the blood as though it is water,</b> i.e., it is unfit for presentation, since it is as though one presented water on the altar. The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>If so,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>should have</b> said: The blood is <b>nullified.</b>
<b>And furthermore, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Mikvaot</i> 7:4): With regard to a ritually impure bucket containing a certain amount of white wine or milk that one immersed in a ritual bath, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Although the appearance of the white wine or milk is not discernible in the water of the ritual bath that enters the bucket, <b>one views</b> the white wine or milk <b>as though it is red wine,</b> and makes the following determination: <b>If its</b> conjectured red <b>appearance would pale</b> due to the water that enters the bucket, the wine or milk is nullified by the water. Therefore, the act of purification is <b>fit,</b> and the bucket is ritually pure.
Rabbi Yehuda continues: <b>But if</b> its conjectured red appearance would <b>not</b> pale, the act of purification is <b>unfit,</b> and the bucket remains ritually impure. This is a case in which a substance was mixed with another substance of similar appearance, as white wine and milk have a similar appearance to the water, and yet it is treated as a mixture of a substance with a different type of substance, and it is not nullified in a majority.
The Gemara explains: One cannot cite a proof from the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, as this <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> and the ruling follows the opinion of the Rabbis, who disagree with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. <b>As it is taught</b> in that <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a ritually impure <b>bucket in which there is white wine or milk, and one immersed it</b> in a ritual bath, <b>one follows the majority,</b> i.e., if the majority of the contents of the bucket is now water from the ritual bath, it is pure. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One views</b> the white wine or milk <b>as though it is red wine</b> and makes the following determination: <b>If its</b> conjectured red <b>appearance would pale</b> due to the water that enters the bucket, the act of purification is <b>fit,</b> and the bucket is ritually pure. <b>But if</b> its conjectured red appearance would <b>not</b> pale, the act of purification is <b>unfit,</b> and the bucket remains ritually impure.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda from a mishna (see <i>Mikvaot</i> 10:6): If one had an impure <b>bucket that is filled with spittle and one immersed it</b> in a ritual bath, the spittle is considered an interposition between the water of the ritual bath and that of the bucket, and therefore it is <b>as though he did not immerse</b> it.
If the impure bucket was full of <b>urine</b> and he immersed it, although urine is slightly different in appearance than water, <b>one views</b> the urine <b>as though it is water,</b> and therefore once the urine is in contact with the ritual bath it is considered connected to the water, and it is not an interposition preventing the bucket from becoming ritually pure.
The mishna continues: If the impure bucket was <b>filled with water of purification,</b> the bucket is not purified <b>until the water</b> of the ritual bath that enters the bucket <b>becomes greater</b> in quantity <b>than</b> the <b>water of purification</b> it contains, thereby nullifying it in a majority.
The Gemara explains the contradiction: <b>Whom have you heard who accepts</b> this reasoning of: <b>One views,</b> which appears in this mishna with regard to urine? It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as stated in the <i>baraita</i> cited above. <b>And</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches that a majority suffices</b> to nullify the water of purification that became mixed with water, and it is not considered as though it is red wine. This conflicts with the ruling of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to white wine and milk.
<b>Abaye says:</b> This is <b>not difficult;</b>

Daf 79a

<b>this</b> statement, that the water of purification is nullified in a majority of water, is <b>his,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda’s, own opinion, whereas <b>that</b> statement, in the <i>baraita</i>, that white wine is not nullified in a majority of water, is <b>his teacher’s</b> ruling, i.e., that of Rabban Gamliel, who is stringent with regard to a mixture of a substance in contact with the same type of substance. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabban Gamliel: Blood does not nullify blood, spittle does not nullify spittle, and urine does not nullify urine.</b>
<b>Rava says</b> there is a different resolution of the apparent contradiction between the mishna that states that water of purification is nullified in a majority of water of a ritual bath and Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to white wine mixed with water: In the mishna, <b>we are dealing with a bucket whose internal</b> surface is <b>ritually pure, and</b> only <b>its external</b> surface is <b>impure.</b> The significance of this is <b>that by</b> Torah <b>law it suffices for</b> the water of the ritual bath to enter the bucket <b>in any amount</b> to purify its external surface, and therefore the water of purification in the bucket does not prevent the purification of the bucket at all.
Rava continues: <b>And it is the Sages who decreed with regard to</b> this case that the internal surface must be purified as well, <b>lest</b> the owner wish to <b>spare</b> the water of purification <b>and not</b> to <b>nullify</b> it from its sanctity. In that case he would wish to avoid allowing water from the ritual bath to enter the vessel, and might immerse it in a manner which would not allow even the full external surface to come in contact with the water. Therefore, the Sages required that one immerse the entire vessel. <b>But once there is a majority</b> of water in the bucket from the ritual bath, he does <b>not need</b> to enable any more water to enter the vessel, as by Torah law it is already pure.
§ <b>Rava says,</b> in summary of these <i>halakhot</i>: <b>The Sages said that</b> the status of an item in a mixture is determined <b>by the taste,</b> i.e., if the taste of one substance is noticeable in a mixture with another substance it is not nullified, <b>and the Sages said</b> that a prohibited item is nullified <b>by the majority, and the Sages</b> also <b>said</b> that the status of an item in a mixture is determined <b>by the appearance,</b> i.e., if the appearance of a substance is recognizable in a mixture it is not nullified. Rava elaborates: With regard to <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> the nullification is determined <b>by the taste.</b> In the case of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> the nullification is determined <b>by the majority.</b> In a case <b>where there is</b> a possibility to determine the status of an item based on <b>appearance,</b> the nullification is <b>by appearance.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion of the opinion of Reish Lakish that prohibited items, such as <i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, and ritually impure meat, nullify one another. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> Reish Lakish <b>disagrees</b> with the statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar says: Just as</b> items used in the performance of <b>mitzvot do not nullify one another,</b> despite the fact that one is of greater volume than the other or imparts flavor to it, <b>so too,</b> items to which <b>prohibitions</b> apply <b>do not nullify one another.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>Whom did you hear who says</b> that items used in the performance of <b>mitzvot do not nullify one another? It is Hillel, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They said about Hillel the Elder that</b> when eating the Paschal offering, <i>matza</i>, and bitter herbs on the first night of Passover, <b>he would wrap them</b> all <b>at once and eat them</b> together, <b>because it is stated</b> with regard to the Paschal offering: <b>“They shall eat it with <i>matzot</i> and bitter herbs”</b> (Numbers 9:11), which indicates that these three foods should be eaten together. Hillel was not concerned that the taste of the bitter herbs would nullify the taste of the <i>matza</i>.

Daf 79b

§ The Gemara continues its discussion of cases involving a mixture of one substance in contact with the same type of substance, in which according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in the mishna the prohibited substance is not nullified. <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Teharot</i> 5:3): In a case where <b>a broken earthenware</b> flask had absorbed the urine <b>of a <i>zav</i> or a <i>zava</i>,</b> whose urine is a primary source of ritual impurity, which imparts impurity to one who carries it, in such a case, if one poured water into this flask to clean it, after the <b>first time and</b> the <b>second</b> time one washed it, it remains <b>ritually impure,</b> but after the <b>third</b> time it is <b>ritually pure,</b> as the impure urine has been expelled from the flask.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>when one placed water into</b> the flask. <b>But</b> if he <b>did not place water into it,</b> but instead placed the urine of a ritually pure person into it, <b>even</b> after the <b>tenth</b> time he places this urine into the flask it remains <b>ritually impure,</b> as one substance in contact with the same type of substance is not nullified. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> After the <b>third</b> time, <b>even though he did not place water into it,</b> but rather urine, it is <b>ritually pure.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Whom did you hear who says</b> that <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance is not nullified? Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and therefore he is the first <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i>.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Teharot</i> 4:11): With regard to <b>flax that was woven by a menstruating woman,</b> although it has absorbed the spittle of a menstruating woman, which imparts impurity by being carried, <b>one who moves it</b> remains <b>ritually pure,</b> as the spittle has dried. <b>But if</b> the flax <b>was</b> still <b>moist, one who moves it</b> is rendered <b>impure due to the liquid of her mouth,</b> i.e., the spittle of the menstruating woman. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who wets</b> the flax <b>with water</b> is rendered <b>impure due to</b> the <b>liquid of her mouth, and</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> if he wet the flax <b>a great deal,</b> several times, as the water does not nullify and expel the spittle. This apparently contradicts Rabbi Yehuda’s claim with regard to the broken flask that was washed with water three times.
<b>Rav Pappa says: Spittle is different, as it is</b> thoroughly <b>absorbed</b> and adheres to the flax, and therefore washing the flax with water does not nullify the spittle.
§ The mishna teaches: If blood fit for presentation <b>was mixed with the blood of unfit</b> offerings, the entire mixture <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain,</b> and similarly, if blood fit for presentation became mixed with blood of exudate, it shall be poured into the drain, whereas Rabbi Eliezer deems the mixture fit for presentation. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Eliezer <b>disagree?</b>
<b>Rav Zevid says: They disagree with regard to</b> the question of whether the Sages <b>issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> of this kind <b>with regard to the Temple. As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that the Sages <b>issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to the Temple, and therefore one may not present this mixture of blood, lest one present a mixture that contains a majority of blood of unfit offerings or blood of exudate. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that the Sages do <b>not issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to the Temple, and consequently this mixture of blood is fit for presentation.
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> that there is a different explanation of the dispute: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that the Sages <b>issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to the Temple, and therefore in a case where blood fit for presentation was mixed with the blood of unfit offerings Rabbi Eliezer agrees that it should be poured into the Temple courtyard drain, and he deems the blood permitted only if it was mixed with blood of exudate.
Rav Pappa continues: <b>And here they disagree with regard to</b> the question of whether it is <b>common for blood of exudate to be greater</b> in quantity <b>than blood of the soul,</b> i.e., the blood that emerges immediately following the slaughter of the animal. One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that this is <b>a common</b> occurrence, and therefore the Sages issued a decree concerning all mixtures of blood of exudate and blood of the soul. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that this is <b>not a common</b> occurrence, and therefore the Sages did not issue a decree concerning a mixture of this kind.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappa</b> that Rabbi Eliezer’s lenient ruling applies only to a mixture with blood of exudate, but that he concedes to the first <i>tanna</i> that if blood fit for presentation was mixed with the blood of unfit offerings it is poured down the Temple courtyard drain, <b>this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If blood fit for presentation <b>was mixed with the blood of unfit</b> offerings, it <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain;</b> if blood fit for presentation <b>was mixed with blood of exudate,</b> it <b>shall be poured into the drain.</b> In other words, the fact that the mishna separates these two cases into different clauses makes sense, as Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling applies only to one case.
<b>But according to</b> the interpretation of <b>Rav Zevid</b> that Rabbi Eliezer disagrees with regard to both cases, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>combine them and teach them</b> together, as follows: If blood fit for presentation was mixed with the blood of unfit offerings or with blood of exudate, the entire mixture shall be poured into the drain running through the Temple courtyard, and Rabbi Eliezer deems the mixtures fit for presentation. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, the wording of the mishna poses <b>a difficulty</b> to the explanation of Rav Zevid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>the blood of unblemished</b> offerings was mixed <b>with the blood of blemished</b> animals unfit for sacrifice, the entire mixture <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> when the fit and unfit blood were mixed in one vessel. By contrast, if <b>a cup</b> of the blood of a blemished offering was intermingled <b>with cups</b> of blood fit for offering and it is unclear which blood is in the cup, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Although it is prohibited to present all the blood due to the uncertainty, <b>if</b> it happened that a priest already <b>sacrificed,</b> i.e., presented, <b>one cup,</b> the blood in <b>all</b> the other <b>cups shall be sacrificed,</b> as the blood that was presented is assumed to have come from the unfit cup in the mixture. <b>And the Rabbis say: Even</b> if the blood in <b>all</b> the cups <b>was sacrificed except for one of them,</b> the remaining blood <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b>
With regard to blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line circumscribing the altar, e.g., blood of a burnt offering, a guilt offering, or a peace offering, <b>that was mixed with</b> blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line, e.g., blood of a sin offering, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest <b>shall</b> initially <b>place</b> the blood of the mixture <b>above</b> the red line for the sake of the sin offering, <b>and I view</b> the blood that was to be placed <b>below</b> that was in fact placed <b>above as though it is water, and</b> the priest shall <b>again place</b> blood from the mixture <b>below. And the Rabbis say:</b> It <b>shall</b> all <b>be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b> Even according to the Rabbis, <b>if</b> the priest <b>did not consult</b> the authorities <b>and placed</b> the blood above the red line, the offering is <b>fit,</b> and he should then place the remaining blood below the red line.

Daf 80a

In a case of the blood of an offering <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>with one placement that was mixed with</b> the blood of another offering <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>with one placement,</b> e.g., the blood of a firstborn offering with the blood of another firstborn offering or the blood of an animal tithe offering, the blood <b>shall be placed with one placement.</b> In a case of the blood of an offering that is to be placed on the altar with <b>four placements</b> that was mixed with the blood of another offering that is to be placed on the altar <b>with four placements,</b> e.g., the blood of a sin offering with that of another sin offering, or the blood of a burnt offering with that of a peace offering, the blood <b>shall be placed with four placements.</b>
If the blood of an offering that is to be placed on the altar with <b>four placements</b> was mixed with the blood of an offering that is to be placed on the altar <b>with one placement, Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The blood <b>shall be placed with four placements. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The blood <b>shall be placed with one placement,</b> as the priest fulfills the requirement with one placement after the fact.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: According to your opinion, the priest <b>violates</b> the prohibition of: <b>Do not diminish,</b> as it is written: “All these matters that I command you, that you shall observe to do; you shall not add thereto, nor diminish from it” (Deuteronomy 13:1). One may not diminish the number of required placements from four to one. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: According to your opinion, the priest <b>violates</b> the prohibition of: <b>Do not add,</b> derived from the same verse. One may not add to the one required placement and place four.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: The prohibition of: <b>Do not add, is stated only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>is by itself,</b> not when it is part of a mixture. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: Likewise, the prohibition of: <b>Do not diminish, is stated only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>is by itself. And Rabbi Yehoshua also said: When you placed</b> four placements, <b>you transgressed</b> the prohibition of: <b>Do not add, and you performed a direct action. When you did not place</b> four placements but only one, although <b>you transgressed</b> the prohibition of: <b>Do not diminish, you did not perform a direct action.</b> An active transgression is more severe than a passive one.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, if a cup containing the blood of blemished animals became intermingled with cups holding the blood of fit offerings, and the blood in one of the cups was sacrificed, all the remaining cups are fit. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Rabbi Eliezer permitted</b> the rest of the cups <b>only</b> if they were sacrificed <b>two</b> by <b>two,</b> as at least one of them is certainly permitted; <b>but</b> he did <b>not</b> permit them to be sacrificed <b>one</b> by <b>one,</b> as he may be found to have presented the blood of the prohibited cup by itself.
<b>Rav Dimi raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that <b>even</b> if the blood in <b>all</b> the cups <b>was sacrificed except for</b> the blood in <b>one of them,</b> the blood <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b> This indicates that even in this case, where only one cup remains, Rabbi Eliezer disagrees with the Rabbis and permits the blood in the cup to be presented. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: I will explain</b> it <b>to you: What</b> does the mishna mean when it states: Except for the blood in <b>one</b> of them? It means except for <b>one pair,</b> i.e., two cups, as even Rabbi Eliezer did not permit the presentation of the cups one by one.
§ The dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis was also stated above with regard to a mixture of limbs from fit and unfit offerings. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this dispute with regard to both cases, <b>as, if it were stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case of the limbs, one would have said that it is <b>in that</b> case alone that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that the rest of the limbs are sacrificed, <b>because</b> the offering’s <b>atonement,</b> i.e., the presenting of the blood, <b>has</b> already <b>been performed,</b> as the limbs are sacrificed after the blood has been presented. <b>But in this</b> case of the blood in the cups, <b>say</b> that Rabbi Eliezer <b>concedes to the Rabbis</b> that the rest of the blood is unfit to be presented.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the dispute <b>were stated</b> only <b>with regard to this</b> case of the cups, one would have said that it is <b>in this</b> case alone that <b>the Rabbis say</b> that the blood in the rest of the cups is unfit, <b>but in that</b> case of the limbs, <b>say</b> that the Rabbis <b>concede to Rabbi Eliezer</b> that the rest of the limbs are fit to be sacrificed, as the blood has already been presented. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state that the dispute applies in both cases.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Para</i> 9:1): With regard to <b>a flask</b> containing water of purification <b>into which any amount of</b> regular <b>water fell, Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest <b>should sprinkle two sprinklings</b> on the ritually impure person, as in this manner he ensures that he will be sprinkled with some of the water of purification; <b>but the Rabbis disqualify</b> the mixture for purification.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Granted,</b> one can understand why <b>the Rabbis</b> disqualify the mixture, as <b>they hold</b> three opinions: They hold that <b>there is mixing,</b> i.e., when two substances are mixed together each drop is assumed to contain a bit of each of them. <b>And</b> they hold that an act of <b>sprinkling</b> of the water of purification <b>requires</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> of water of purification, and in this case each sprinkling contained some of the regular water. <b>And</b> they hold that it is of no help to sprinkle the water twice, as <b>one cannot combine sprinklings,</b> i.e., two acts of sprinkling the water of purification do not combine to render one pure. Therefore, the person is not purified.
<b>But what</b> does <b>Rabbi Eliezer hold? If he holds</b> that <b>there is no mixing,</b> i.e., when two substances are mixed together each drop is not assumed to contain a bit of each of them, then even <b>if one sprinkles two sprinklings, what of it? Perhaps</b> on <b>both</b> occasions <b>he sprinkles</b> regular <b>water. Rather,</b> one must say that Rabbi Eliezer <b>holds</b> that <b>there is mixing. If he holds</b> that the act of <b>sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure, why do I</b> need <b>two sprinklings?</b> One act of sprinkling would be enough. <b>Rather,</b> you must say that Rabbi Eliezer <b>holds</b> that the act of <b>sprinkling requires</b> a minimum <b>measure. And if</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>holds</b> that <b>one cannot combine sprinklings,</b> then even <b>if one sprinkles two sprinklings, what of it? And alternatively,</b> if he holds that <b>one combines sprinklings, who says that</b> the two sprinklings will <b>amount to</b> the minimum <b>measure?</b> Perhaps most of the water he sprinkled was regular water.
<b>Reish Lakish says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer holds that <b>there is mixing, and sprinkling requires</b> a minimum <b>measure. And here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the two types of water <b>were mixed</b> together in a ratio of <b>one to one,</b> and therefore by performing two sprinklings the priest ensures that he has sprinkled the minimum measure of one sprinkling of water of purification.
<b>Rava says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer maintains that <b>there is mixing, and sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure.</b> Consequently, it should suffice for the priest to perform one sprinkling. <b>And</b> the requirement to sprinkle twice is <b>a penalty</b> that <b>the Sages imposed, so that</b> one who mixes regular water with the water of purification <b>would not benefit from this</b> act by diluting the valuable water of purification.
<b>Rav Ashi states</b> a different explanation: Rabbi Eliezer holds that <b>there is no mixing,</b> and therefore if the priest sprinkles only once there is a concern that he might not have sprinkled any water of purification at all, and therefore he <b>sprinkles two sprinklings.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> against Reish Lakish’s opinion that Rabbi Eliezer holds that sprinkling requires a minimum measure. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: According to the statement of Rabbi Eliezer</b> that if the priest performs two sprinklings the purification ritual is valid, <b>a sprinkling of any amount renders</b> the impure person <b>ritually pure,</b> as <b>sprinkling does not require</b> a minimum <b>measure,</b> and even <b>a sprinkling</b> that contains <b>half fit</b> water <b>and half unfit</b> water renders the individual ritually pure.

Daf 80b

The Gemara adds: <b>And furthermore,</b> one can raise another difficulty against the opinion of Rav Ashi, who maintains that according to Rabbi Eliezer there is no mixing, as it <b>is taught explicitly</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to blood of an offering, e.g., a sin offering, <b>which is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line <b>that was mixed with</b> blood of an offering, e.g., a burnt offering, <b>which is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest <b>shall</b> initially <b>place</b> the blood of the mixture <b>above</b> the red line for the sake of the sin offering, and the priest should then place blood from the mixture below the red line for the sake of the burnt offering, <b>and</b> both the blood placed above and <b>the</b> blood placed <b>below count for him</b> toward the fulfillment of the mitzva.
The Gemara explains the difficulty from this <i>baraita</i>: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>there is no mixing, why</b> do both of the placements <b>count for him? Perhaps he placed</b> the blood of the mixture that belongs <b>above</b> the red line <b>below</b> it, <b>and the</b> blood that belongs <b>below</b> the red line <b>above</b> it.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where there is a majority</b> of blood that is to be placed <b>above</b> the line, <b>and</b> the priest <b>placed</b> blood <b>above</b> by the <b>measure</b> of the blood in the mixture that is to be placed <b>below</b> the line, <b>and</b> slightly <b>more</b> blood. In this manner he ensures that he must have placed above the red line some of the blood that belongs there.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: The</b> blood placed <b>below counts for him</b> toward the fulfillment of the mitzva. According to this explanation, it is possible that all the blood of the burnt offering was placed above the red line. Why, then, has he fulfilled the mitzva by placing blood below the red line? The Gemara explains: The <i>baraita</i> does not mean that it counts for the mitzva of the placing of the blood of a burnt offering below the red line; rather, it means that it counts for him <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of the sin offering, which must be poured onto the base of the altar.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If the priest <b>placed</b> the mixed blood <b>below</b> the red line <b>and did not consult</b> the authorities, what should he do now? <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> He <b>shall again place</b> the blood <b>above</b> the red line, <b>and the</b> blood placed <b>below counts for him.</b> Once again, the difficulty is that if Rabbi Eliezer maintains that there is no mixing, why does the placement count for him? Perhaps he placed the blood of the mixture that belongs above the red line below it, and the blood that belongs below the red line above it.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here too, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where the majority</b> of blood belongs <b>above</b> the line, <b>and</b> the priest <b>placed</b> blood <b>above</b> from the <b>measure</b> of the blood in the mixture that belongs <b>below</b> the line, <b>and</b> slightly <b>more</b> blood. Again the Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: The</b> blood placed <b>below counts for him.</b> Since it is possible that all of the blood of the burnt offering was placed above the red line, why does the blood placed below count for him? The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> means it counts for him <b>for the sake of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the sin offering.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If the priest <b>placed</b> the mixed blood <b>above and did not consult</b> the authorities, both <b>these</b> Sages <b>and those</b> Sages, i.e., the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer, <b>concede that he shall again place</b> the blood <b>below</b> the red line, <b>and these</b> placements <b>and those</b> placements <b>count for him.</b> If Rabbi Eliezer maintains that there is no mixing, he would not concede this point, as perhaps he placed the blood that belongs below the red line above it, and the blood that belongs above, below.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> this is referring to a case <b>where the majority</b> of blood belongs <b>above</b> the line, <b>and</b> the priest <b>placed</b> blood <b>above</b> in the <b>measure</b> of the blood in the mixture that belongs <b>below</b> the line, <b>and</b> slightly <b>more</b> blood. In this manner he fulfills the mitzva of the blood that is to be placed above the red line alone.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: These and those count for him,</b> not only the blood that is to be placed above. The Gemara explains: <b>Does</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: These</b> Sages <b>and those</b> Sages <b>concede</b> that these placements and those placements count for him? It <b>teaches</b> only: <b>These and those count for him.</b> In other words, although the <i>baraita</i> states in the first clause that both the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer concede that the priest returns and places the blood below the red line, this agreement does not apply to the next clause of the <i>baraita</i>, as in <b>the latter clause we come to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> alone, <b>who say</b> that <b>there is mixing,</b> which is why both placements count.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: In a case of the blood of an offering <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>with one placement that was mixed with</b> the blood of another offering <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b> on the altar <b>with one placement,</b> the blood <b>shall be placed with one placement. And if you say</b> that according to Rabbi Eliezer <b>there is no mixing, why shall they be placed with one placement? Perhaps he places from this</b> blood <b>and does not place from that</b> blood. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the measure of <b>one</b> placement of this blood <b>was mixed with</b> the measure of <b>one</b> placement of that blood, and no more. Consequently, he certainly placed both types of blood.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: The mishna teaches that in a case of the blood of an offering that is to be placed on the altar with <b>four placements</b> that was mixed <b>with</b> the blood of another offering that is to be placed on the altar <b>with four placements,</b> the blood shall be placed with four placements. But if there is no mixing, perhaps he placed only the blood of one offering. The Gemara explains: <b>Here too,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the measure of <b>four</b> placements of this blood <b>was mixed with</b> the measure of <b>four</b> placements of that blood, and therefore he certainly placed blood from both offerings.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: The mishna teaches that if the blood of an offering that is to be placed on the altar with <b>four placements</b> was mixed with the blood of another offering that is to be placed on the altar <b>with one placement,</b> Rabbi Eliezer says: The blood shall be placed with four placements. Here too, if there is no mixing according to Rabbi Eliezer, perhaps he placed the blood of only one of the offerings.

Daf 81a
