<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here too,</b> the mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> the measure of four placements <b>was mixed with</b> precisely the amount of <b>one</b> placement, and therefore the priest certainly placed some blood of both offerings, <b>if so,</b> how would one explain the clause in the mishna that states: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: According to your opinion, doesn’t the priest <b>violate</b> the prohibition of: <b>Do not add? From where</b> is the violation of: <b>Do not add, here?</b> After all, the priest places only the measure of one placement from the offering that requires one placement.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis <b>do not disagree with regard to</b> a case of actual blood <b>mixed</b> together. <b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>cups</b> of blood that were intermingled, and it is unknown which blood is in which cup. The explanation <b>according to Rabbi Eliezer</b> is that he <b>is of</b> the opinion that <b>one views</b> the blood that was not placed properly as though it were water, and therefore it is permitted to present the blood; whereas the explanation <b>according to the Rabbis</b> is that they <b>are not of</b> the opinion that <b>one views</b> the blood that was not placed properly as though it were water, and consequently all of it must be poured into the Temple courtyard drain.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do they not disagree with regard to</b> blood <b>mixed</b> together? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis did not disagree</b> in a case <b>of blood of a sin offering that was mixed with blood of a burnt offering that</b> the mixture <b>shall be sacrificed,</b> or <b>in</b> a case of blood that was fit for presentation that was mixed with the blood of <b>an animal that copulated with a person, or an animal that was the object of bestiality, that it shall not be sacrificed.</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>did they disagree? With regard to blood of an unblemished</b> animal <b>that was mixed with blood of a blemished</b> animal, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that it <b>shall be sacrificed, whether in</b> a case of blood <b>mixed</b> together <b>or in</b> a case of <b>cups</b> intermingled, <b>and the Rabbis say</b> it <b>shall not be sacrificed.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda, in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> i.e., when Rabbi Yehuda teaches the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, <b>teaches</b> that the dispute applies <b>both in</b> a case of blood <b>mixed</b> together <b>and in</b> a case of intermingled <b>cups, but the Rabbis</b> who taught the mishna maintain that Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> only <b>in</b> a case of intermingled <b>cups.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that if the blood of a sin offering, which is to be placed above the red line, was mixed with blood of a burnt offering, which is to be placed below the line, Rabbi Eliezer holds that it shall all be placed above the red line, and one views the blood of the burnt offering placed there as though it is water, and subsequently the priest shall place the blood below the red line. By contrast, the Rabbis rule that all the blood shall be poured into the Temple courtyard drain. Concerning this, <b>Abaye says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> that according to the opinion of the Rabbis the blood shall be poured into the drain <b>only</b> if the <b>first</b> portion of the blood <b>of a sin offering,</b> i.e., that blood which is to be placed above the red line, <b>and</b> the blood of <b>a burnt offering</b> were mixed.
<b>But</b> if the <b>final</b> portion of the blood <b>of a sin offering,</b> i.e., the remainder of the blood that is poured onto the base of the altar (see Leviticus 4:25), <b>and</b> the blood of <b>a burnt offering</b> were mixed, <b>everyone agrees</b> that since <b>the place</b> of the blood <b>of a burnt offering,</b> below the red line, is the same as <b>the place of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering, as the remainder of the blood of a sin offering is poured on the base of the altar, the priest shall place all the blood on the side of the altar below the red line. <b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Abaye: <b>This is what Rav Yehuda says:</b> The places are not the same, as the <b>remainder</b> of blood <b>needs</b> to be placed on the <b>bench,</b> i.e., on the upper horizontal surface of the base itself, and not on the side of the altar as is the case with the blood of a burnt offering.
The Gemara notes that <i>amora’im</i> of Eretz Yisrael disagreed in the same manner as Abaye and Rav Yosef: <b>And likewise Rabbi Shimon</b> ben Lakish <b>says:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> that according to the opinion of the Rabbis the blood shall be poured into the drain <b>only</b> if the <b>first</b> portion of the blood <b>of a sin offering and</b> the blood of <b>a burnt offering</b> were mixed. <b>But</b> if the <b>final</b> portion of the blood <b>of a sin offering and</b> the blood of <b>a burnt offering</b> were mixed, <b>everyone agrees</b> that since <b>the place</b> of the blood <b>of a burnt offering</b> is the same as <b>the place of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering, the priest shall place all the blood on the side of the altar below the red line. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> who says: This case of the remainder of blood of a sin offering that was mixed with the blood of a burnt offering <b>is still</b> included in the <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to firstborn animals: <b>“They are holy”</b> (Numbers 18:17). The emphasis of the term “they” serves to teach <b>that</b> even <b>if</b> the blood of a firstborn offering <b>was mixed with blood of other sacrificial</b> animals, the blood <b>shall be sacrificed,</b> as the blood of firstborn offerings is not nullified. <b>What, is it not</b> referring even to a case of the <b>final</b> portion of the blood <b>of a burnt offering and</b> the blood of <b>a firstborn</b> offering that were mixed, indicating that the priest places the mixture below the red line? <b>And</b> if so, one can <b>learn from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that <b>the place</b> of the blood <b>of a burnt offering,</b> which is also the place of the blood of a firstborn offering, is the same as <b>the place of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of blood of a sin offering. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the <b>first</b> part of the blood <b>of a burnt offering and</b> the blood of <b>a firstborn</b> offering.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what is</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> Is it teaching that the blood of offerings <b>that ascend</b> to the altar <b>do not nullify one another? This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> already <b>derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat”</b> (Leviticus 16:18), from which it is understood that although the blood of the two animals is in the same vessel, they each retain their distinct identity. The Gemara answers: This <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as <b>there is</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from here, and there is</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives it from there.</b>
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that discusses a verse describing a burnt offering: <b>“And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall present the blood and sprinkle the blood”</b> (Leviticus 1:5). The superfluous second mention of the blood teaches that it is still called the blood of a burnt offering even after it was mixed with other blood, and therefore it should be sprinkled in its proper manner. <b>What</b> does it mean when

Daf 81b

<b>the verse states</b> twice: <b>“Blood,” “blood”?</b> The <i>baraita</i> explains: If “blood” were written only once, one <b>might</b> have thought: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> was stated with regard to a case <b>where this,</b> i.e., the blood of a burnt offering, <b>was mixed with</b> the blood of <b>its substitute, as even</b> if these offerings were intermingled <b>when</b> the animals were <b>alive,</b> the burnt offering and its substitute <b>shall be sacrificed. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> even a case of the blood of <b>a thanks offering or a peace offering</b> that was mixed with the blood of a burnt offering, as these offerings are not sacrificed if they became intermingled with a burnt offering while alive?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: And even if one says: <b>I include</b> in this first mention of blood the case of the blood of <b>a thanks offering or a peace offering</b> that was mixed with the blood of a burnt offering, <b>as</b> they are similar in that <b>they</b> both <b>come as a vow</b> offering <b>and a gift</b> offering, <b>like</b> a burnt offering, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> even a case of the blood of <b>the guilt offering</b> that was mixed with the blood of a burnt offering, as a guilt offering cannot be brought as a vow offering or a gift offering?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: And even if one says: <b>I include</b> in this first mention of blood even a case of the blood of <b>the guilt offering</b> that was mixed with the blood of a burnt offering, <b>as</b> they are similar in that a guilt offering <b>requires</b> the <b>placement of</b> two placements that are <b>four, like</b> a burnt offering, <b>from where</b> is it derived that the same applies to the blood of <b>a firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> whose blood is placed once on the altar? Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> twice: <b>“Blood,” “blood.”</b> This repetition serves to teach that in any case where the blood of a burnt offering became mixed with the blood of another offering that is placed below the red line, this blood is presented.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What, is it not</b> referring even to a case of the <b>final</b> portion of the blood <b>of a burnt offering and</b> the blood of <b>a firstborn</b> offering that were mixed? <b>And</b> if so, one can <b>learn from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that the <b>place</b> of the blood <b>of a burnt offering</b> is the same as the <b>place of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a firstborn offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the <b>first</b> part of the blood <b>of a burnt offering and</b> the blood of <b>a firstborn</b> offering. <b>But</b> if so, <b>what is</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> Is it teaching that the blood of offerings that <b>ascend</b> to the altar <b>do not nullify one another?</b> This <i>halakha</i> is already <b>derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat”</b> (Leviticus 16:18). The Gemara explains: This <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as <b>there is</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from here, and there is</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives it from there.</b>
§ The Gemara has cited three different verses as the source for the <i>halakha</i> that the blood of offerings that ascend to the altar do not nullify one another: “They are holy” (Numbers 18:17); “And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat” (Leviticus 16:18); “And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall present the blood and sprinkle the blood” (Leviticus 1:5). The Gemara notes: <b>And these</b> other <b><i>tanna’im</i> do not derive</b> this principle <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat,”</b> as <b>they maintain</b> that the High Priest <b>does not mix</b> the blood of the bull with the blood of the goat in order <b>to</b> place the blood on the <b>corners</b> of the golden altar; rather, each type of blood is placed separately. Additionally, these other <i>tanna’im</i> <b>do not derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the repeated mention of: <b>“Blood,” “blood,”</b> as <b>they do not learn</b> anything from this repetition.
The Gemara asks: <b>But what is the reason</b> that those other <i>tanna’im</i> <b>do not derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“They are holy”</b> (Numbers 18:17)? The Gemara explains: <b>They hold</b> that the verse should be understood as follows: <b>“They are holy,”</b> i.e., <b>they,</b> the firstborn offerings themselves, <b>are sacrificed, but their substitutes are not sacrificed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, i.e., the <i>tanna</i> who derives the <i>halakha</i> that the blood of offerings that ascend to the altar do not nullify one another from the verse: “They are holy” (Numbers 18:17), from where does he learn that the substitute of a firstborn is not sacrificed? The Gemara explains: He <b>derives it from</b> the verse: <b>“Whether it be ox or sheep, it is the Lord’s”</b> (Leviticus 27:26). The emphasis of “it is” teaches that <b>it is sacrificed but its substitute is not sacrificed.</b>
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of whether the place of the blood of a burnt offering is the same as the place for the remainder of the blood of offerings. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to blood that is to be placed above the red line that was mixed with blood that is to be placed below the line, which according to the Rabbis must be poured into the Temple courtyard drain, if the priest <b>placed</b> the mixed blood <b>above and did not consult</b> the authorities, both <b>these</b> Sages <b>and those</b> Sages, i.e., the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer, <b>concede that he shall again place</b> the blood <b>below</b> the red line, and <b>these</b> placements <b>and those</b> placements <b>count for him.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the blood of <b>a sin offering and a burnt offering were mixed? And once</b> the priest <b>placed</b> blood of the sin offering <b>above</b> the red line, that which is left from the blood of the sin offering <b>is</b> considered the <b>remainder</b> of the blood. <b>And</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> Both <b>these</b> Sages <b>and those</b> Sages <b>concede that he shall again place</b> the blood <b>below</b> the red line. <b>And</b> if so, one can <b>learn from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that the <b>place</b> of the blood <b>of a burnt offering</b> is the same as the <b>place of</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>What are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing not with a mixture of blood of a sin offering and blood of a burnt offering, but with a case <b>where</b> the blood of <b>a sin offering</b> sacrificed on <b>the external</b> altar, which is placed above the red line, <b>was mixed with</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering whose blood is presented inside the Sanctuary. This remainder is poured on the base of the external altar. Consequently, once the priest has placed blood from the mixture above the red line, all that remains is a mixture of remainders, which are placed in the same location.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef: Why is it necessary to cite the case of the remainder of the blood of a sin offering whose blood is presented inside the Sanctuary? <b>But let the Master say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the blood of a sin offering sacrificed on the external altar <b>was mixed with</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering sacrificed on the external altar. <b>Perhaps</b> you chose that case to indicate that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us: Even according to the one who says</b> that failure to pour the <b>remainder</b> of the blood of a sin offering whose blood is presented inside the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, nevertheless, if the remainder was merely <b>lacking,</b> as in this case, as some of the blood had been placed above the red line, this does <b>not disqualify</b> the offering.
<b>Rava Tosfa’a said to Ravina:</b> How can that <i>baraita</i> be cited as proof for the issue at hand? <b>We</b> already <b>interpreted it</b> (80b) <b>with regard to</b> a mixture of blood that is to be placed above the red line with blood that is to be placed below the red line, which contains <b>a majority</b> of blood that is to be placed <b>above</b> the line, <b>and</b> the priest <b>places above</b> the red line <b>a measure</b> of blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the line <b>and</b> slightly <b>more.</b> Ravina <b>said to him: That statement</b> applies <b>according to those who said initially</b> that Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree with regard to a mixture of blood, and that Rabbi Eliezer holds that <b>there is no mixing.</b> But according to <b>the conclusion,</b> Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to cups</b> of blood that were intermingled, and therefore the above interpretation of the <i>baraita</i> was rejected.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed</b> on three locations <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., between the staves, on the Curtain, and on the golden altar, <b>that was mixed with</b> blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary on the external altar in the Temple courtyard, has no remedy, as one may not change the location of the placement of the blood of one to fulfill his obligation with the other type of blood. Therefore, all the blood <b>shall be poured into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain.</b> If the priest, on his own initiative, <b>placed</b> the mixture of blood <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>and again placed</b> the mixture of blood <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, the offering is <b>fit.</b>
If the priest, on his own initiative, placed the mixture of blood <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>and again placed</b> the mixture of blood <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>Rabbi Akiva deems</b> the blood placed outside <b>disqualified, and the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>fit. As Rabbi Akiva says: Any blood</b> that is to be presented outside <b>that entered to atone in the Sanctuary is disqualified; but the Rabbis say:</b> That is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood of an external <b>sin offering alone,</b> as it is written: “And any sin offering, whereof any of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The status of <b>a guilt offering</b> is like that of a sin offering <b>as well, as it is stated: “As is the sin offering, so is the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:7), i.e., there is one <i>halakha</i> for them. That is not the case with regard to the blood of other offerings.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if blood that is to be placed inside the Sanctuary was mixed with blood that is to be placed outside the Sanctuary, all the blood should be poured into the Temple courtyard drain, and there is no opposing opinion recorded in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>And let Rabbi Eliezer disagree</b> even <b>with regard to this</b> case, just as he disagrees with regard to a mixture of blood that is to be placed above the red line that was mixed with blood that is to be placed below the red line, where he holds that the improperly placed blood is considered as though it were water.
The Gemara explains that Rabbi Eliezer does not disagree in this case, as <b>how should</b> the priest <b>act?</b> If one says that he <b>should</b> first <b>place</b> blood from the mixture on the altar <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>and again place</b> blood from the mixture <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, this is not allowed. <b>Just as</b> it is <b>a mitzva to give precedence</b> to the blood that is to be placed <b>above</b> the red line <b>over</b> the blood that is to be placed <b>below</b> the line, e.g., the presentation of the blood of a sin offering precedes the presentation of the blood of a burnt offering, since a sin offering serves to effect atonement, <b>so too</b> is it <b>a mitzva to give precedence</b> to the blood that is to be placed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>over</b> blood that is to be placed <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary.

Daf 82a

<b>And</b> if you suggest that the priest <b>should</b> first <b>place</b> blood from the mixture <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>and again place</b> blood <b>outside,</b> on the altar, although this resolution is applicable to most offerings whose blood is placed outside, nevertheless the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna chose to omit this case. The reason is that <b>since there are a sin offering and a guilt offering,</b> concerning <b>which,</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, <b>when their blood enters</b> the Sanctuary <b>they are disqualified</b> from being placed on the external altar, the <i>tanna</i> could <b>not</b> teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>categorically.</b> In other words, as the <i>tanna</i> could not issue a categorical ruling that applies to all types of offerings, he omitted the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer here.
§ The mishna teaches <b>that Rabbi Akiva would say:</b> Any blood that is to be presented outside that entered to atone in the Sanctuary is disqualified. The Gemara discusses the source for Rabbi Akiva’s ruling. The verse states: “And any sin offering, whereof any of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). How does Rabbi Akiva apply this <i>halakha</i> to all offerings whose blood is presented on the external altar? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> Hear <b>a parable: To what is this matter comparable? To a student who mixed</b> wine <b>with hot water for his teacher. And</b> the teacher <b>said to him: Mix</b> another drink <b>for me.</b> The student <b>said to him: With what</b> should I mix the wine, hot or cold water? The teacher <b>said to him: Aren’t we dealing with hot</b> water? <b>Now</b> that I requested that you mix me another cup, I mean that you should mix it <b>either in hot</b> water <b>or in cold.</b> Otherwise, the teacher would not have needed to say anything.
<b>Here too, since we have been dealing with a sin offering</b> in that passage (see Leviticus 6:17–22), <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“sin offering” that the Merciful One writes</b> in this verse? Even without this term it is clear that the Torah is referring to a sin offering. <b>Rather,</b> as in the parable, the Torah mentions a sin offering to teach: <b>I do not say this</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a sin offering</b> alone, i.e., that only the blood of a sin offering is disqualified when it is brought inside the Sanctuary, <b>but</b> the blood of <b>all sacrificial</b> animals is disqualified by being brought into the Sanctuary.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, objects to this</b> explanation: Accordingly, one should reach the opposite conclusion: <b>Since all sacrificial</b> animals that are sacrificed <b>on the altar are included</b> in this passage of the Torah <b>with regard to scouring and rinsing,</b> as derived by the Sages, despite the fact that this requirement is stated in connection with a sin offering (see Leviticus 6:21), it is already established that this chapter is speaking of all offerings. Consequently, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“sin offering” that the Merciful One writes</b> with regard to the matter of blood that entered the Sanctuary? <b>Learn from</b> the verse that in the case of <b>a sin offering</b> whose blood entered the Sanctuary, <b>yes,</b> it is disqualified, but if the blood of any <b>other</b> offering entered the Sanctuary, <b>no,</b> it is not disqualified.
Rav Huna addresses Shmuel’s parable: <b>And</b> if you wish to provide a comparison, it <b>is comparable only to a student who</b> initially <b>mixed</b> wine <b>for his teacher with both hot and cold</b> water, and <b>his teacher</b> then <b>said to him: Mix</b> wine <b>for me only</b> with <b>hot</b> water.
Rav Huna continues: <b>Rather, the reasoning of Rabbi Akiva</b> is <b>from</b> the fact that the verse does not state simply: <b>“Sin offering,” but</b> states: <b>“Any sin offering”;</b> this serves to include all other offerings. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And any <b>sin offering,</b> whereof any of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). <b>I have</b> derived that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering; from where</b> is it derived that it also applies to <b>offerings of the most sacred order? The verse states: “Any sin offering.” And from where</b> is it derived that it also applies to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity? The verse states: “And any sin offering.”</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili said to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>Even</b> if <b>you include</b> offerings in this manner from the verse <b>all day long, I</b> will <b>not listen to you. Rather,</b> this verse is referring to a sin offering alone, and it should be expounded as follows: The verse states: <b>“Sin offering”; I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>the sin offering of an individual. From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to <b>a communal sin offering? The verse states: “Any sin offering.” And</b> one can still say: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a male sin offering; from where</b> is it derived that the same applies to <b>a female sin offering? The verse states: “And any</b> sin offering.”
The Gemara asks: Why is it assumed that the application of this <i>halakha</i> to a male sin offering is more obvious than to a female sin offering? <b>Isn’t it the opposite [<i>kelapei layya</i>],</b> as the standard sin offering of an individual is a female? <b>Rather, this</b> is what Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>is saying:</b> One can still ask: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a female sin offering; from where</b> is it derived that the same applies to <b>a male sin offering? The verse states: “And any sin offering.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili hold</b> that <b>this verse comes for this</b> purpose, to teach the <i>halakha</i> of sin offerings whose blood was brought inside the Sanctuary? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: As we have found the entire matter</b> that is stated in the verse: “And any sin offering, whereof any of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire” (Leviticus 6:23), is not stated with regard to a standard sin offering improperly brought inside the Sanctuary; rather, it <b>speaks only about bulls that are burned and goats that are burned.</b>
Rabbi Yosei HaGelili elaborates: These are unique sin offerings, and the Torah states that their blood should be brought inside the Sanctuary. The verse is stated with regard to these sin offerings both in order to command the Jewish people <b>to burn their disqualified ones in the Temple and</b> in order <b>to establish a prohibition with regard to their consumption.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: If you expound the verse in this fashion, then <b>from where</b> is it derived that a standard <b>sin offering whose blood entered the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies, must be burned? Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>said to them</b> that it is derived from the verse: <b>“Behold, its blood was not brought</b> into the Sanctuary within” (Leviticus 10:18). This indicates that had the sin offering referred to in the verse been brought inside the Sanctuary, it should have been burned. In any event, with regard to the issue at hand, since Rabbi Yosei HaGelili interprets the verse from Leviticus 6:23 in this manner, how can he interpret it differently in his dispute with Rabbi Akiva?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>spoke according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> i.e., although Rabbi Yosei HaGelili interprets the verse in a different manner, according to Rabbi Akiva’s explanation it should be understood as referring only to a sin offering, not to other offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a sin offering</b> whose blood placement is on the external altar <b>whose blood</b> the priest <b>collected in two cups,</b> if <b>one of them left</b> the Temple courtyard and was thereby disqualified, <b>the</b> cup that remained <b>inside</b> the courtyard is <b>fit</b> to be presented. If <b>one of the</b> cups <b>entered inside</b> the Sanctuary and was thereby disqualified, <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili deems</b> the blood <b>in the</b> cup that remained <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, in the courtyard, <b>fit</b> to be presented, <b>and the Rabbis deem it disqualified</b> from being presented.
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili said</b> in support of his opinion: The <i>halakha</i> is that if one slaughters an offering with the intent that its blood be presented outside of the Temple courtyard, the offering is disqualified, but if his intention was that the blood be presented inside the Sanctuary, the offering is not disqualified. <b>Just as in</b> a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where the intent</b> to present the blood there <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, i.e., <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, and yet when some of the blood is taken there it <b>does not render the</b> status of the <b>remaining</b> blood disqualified <b>like</b> that of blood that <b>leaves</b> the courtyard, so too, in a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where the intent</b> to present the blood there <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering, i.e., <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>is it not logical that we will not deem</b> the status of <b>the remaining</b> blood <b>like</b> that of blood that <b>entered</b> the Sanctuary?
The mishna continues: If all of the blood of a sin offering whose blood placement is on the external altar <b>entered</b> the Sanctuary <b>to atone</b> through sprinkling, <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the priest <b>did not</b> actually sprinkle the blood to <b>atone,</b> the offering is <b>disqualified;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The offering is disqualified <b>only when he atones</b> and sprinkles the blood in the Sanctuary. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If he took</b> the blood <b>into</b> the Sanctuary <b>unwittingly,</b> the blood remains <b>fit</b> to be presented.
With regard to <b>all the blood disqualified</b> for presentation <b>that was placed on the altar, the frontplate effects acceptance only</b> for offerings sacrificed <b>that</b> are <b>ritually impure.</b> Although it is written with regard to the frontplate worn on the forehead of the High Priest: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron shall bear the iniquity committed in the sacred matters” (Exodus 28:38), this does not apply to all disqualifications of offerings. This is <b>because the frontplate effects acceptance for</b> offerings sacri-ficed <b>that</b> are <b>ritually impure but does not effect acceptance for</b> offerings <b>that leave</b> the courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the dispute between Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and the Rabbis as to whether the blood of a sin offering in a second cup is disqualified if the blood in the first cup entered the Sanctuary, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili said:</b> This is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as in</b> a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where</b> the <b>intent</b> to present the blood there <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, i.e., <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, and yet that <b>blood that</b> was taken <b>outside does not disqualify</b> the blood that is still <b>inside</b> the courtyard, so too, in a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where</b> the <b>intent</b> to present the blood there <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering, i.e., <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>is it not logical that</b> the <b>blood that</b> was taken <b>inside will not disqualify</b> the blood <b>that</b> is still <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary?
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: <b>But</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And any sin offering, <b>whereof any of the blood is brought</b> into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). This indicates that <b>even</b> if <b>part of its blood</b> is brought inside the Sanctuary, the sin offering is disqualified.
Rabbi Yosei HaGelili <b>said to</b> the Rabbis: If you expound the verse in that manner, then <b>from now</b> one can derive <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>with regard to the</b> blood that <b>leaves</b> the courtyard: <b>And just as in</b> a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where</b> the <b>intent</b> to present the blood there <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering, i.e., <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, the <b>blood that</b> was taken <b>inside disqualifies</b> the blood that is still <b>outside,</b> i.e., in the courtyard, so too, in a case where part of the blood reached <b>a place where</b> the <b>intent</b> to present the blood there <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, i.e., <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>is it not logical that</b> the <b>blood that</b> was taken <b>outside will disqualify</b> the blood <b>that</b> is still <b>inside</b> the courtyard? Why do the Rabbis deem this blood fit?
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili in response: <b>But</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And any sin offering, whereof any of the blood <b>is brought</b> into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23). This teaches that only blood <b>that enters</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the blood in the courtyard, <b>but</b> the blood <b>that leaves</b> the courtyard <b>does not disqualify</b> the blood in the courtyard.
In light of this discussion, the Gemara asks: <b>And let intent</b> to present the blood <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualify</b> the offering <b>based on an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as in a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>outside does not disqualify</b> the rest of the blood <b>that is inside</b> the courtyard, and yet <b>intent</b> to present the blood in this place <b>disqualifies</b> the offering, i.e., <b>outside</b> the courtyard, so too, in <b>a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the rest of the blood <b>that is outside</b> the Sanctuary, in the courtyard, <b>is it not logical that intent</b> to present the blood in this place <b>will disqualify</b> the offering, i.e., <b>inside</b> the courtyard?
The Gemara explains that one does not derive this <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as the verse <b>states:</b> “And if it be eaten at all <b>on the third day,</b> it is <i>piggul</i>; it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 19:7), and the Sages expounded this verse with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of intent while slaughtering an offering.

Daf 82b

This verse teaches that the <b>place where</b> improper intent disqualifies the offering <b>must be triply</b> functional: <b>For</b> the presenting of <b>the blood, for</b> the eating of <b>the meat,</b> and <b>for</b> the burning of <b>the sacrificial portions</b> of the offering that are consumed on the altar. In other words, it must be outside its designated place with regard to all three of these issues. Consequently, intent to present the blood in the Sanctuary does not disqualify the blood.
The Gemara suggests the opposite: <b>And</b> if so, <b>let intent</b> to present the blood <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>not disqualify</b> the offering <b>based on an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as</b> in <b>a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the rest of the blood <b>that is outside</b> in the courtyard, and yet <b>intent</b> to present the blood <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering, so too, in <b>a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>does not disqualify</b> the rest of the blood <b>that is inside</b> the courtyard, <b>is it not logical that intent</b> to present the blood <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>does not disqualify</b> the offering?
The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states:</b> “And if it be eaten at all on the third day, it is <i>piggul</i>; it shall not be accepted,” and the Sages interpreted this verse as follows: “On the <b>third</b> day” is referring to intent to perform its rites <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time;</b> “it is <b><i>piggul</i>”</b> is referring to intent to perform its rites <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area.</b>
A <i>baraita</i> teaches: The <b>meat</b> of offerings <b>that left</b> its designated area and was taken <b>to</b> a place that is <b>outside</b> its designated area for consumption, which is outside the wall of Jerusalem in the case of offerings of lesser sanctity and outside the wall of the Temple courtyard in the case of offerings of the most sacred order, is <b>disqualified</b> from being eaten. By contrast, meat of offerings <b>that entered inside</b> the Sanctuary is not disqualified and remains <b>fit</b> to be eaten.
One might have thought <b>that it should be</b> derived <b>based on a logical inference that</b> this meat is <b>disqualified,</b> as follows: <b>And just as in a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>does not disqualify</b> the rest of the blood <b>that</b> remained <b>inside</b> the courtyard, yet <b>meat that leaves</b> and is taken <b>outside</b> the courtyard is <b>disqualified,</b> so too, in <b>a place where</b> the part of the <b>blood that</b> went <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the rest of the blood <b>that is outside</b> the Sanctuary, <b>is it not right that meat that enters</b> the Sanctuary <b>should be disqualified?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains that one does not derive this inference, as the verse <b>states:</b> “And any sin offering, whereof any <b>of the blood</b> is brought into the Tent of Meeting to atone in the Sanctuary, shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23), which indicates that the <b>blood of</b> an offering that is brought inside is disqualified, <b>but not meat</b> that enters the Sanctuary.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From now,</b> as it has been established that the meat of offerings that is brought inside the Sanctuary is not disqualified, one can suggest <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And just as in a place where blood that</b> went <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>disqualifies</b> the blood <b>that</b> remained <b>outside</b> in the courtyard, and yet <b>meat that enters</b> the Sanctuary is <b>fit,</b> therefore, in <b>a place where</b> the <b>blood that</b> went <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>does not disqualify</b> the blood <b>that is inside</b> the courtyard, <b>is it not logical that meat that left</b> and was taken <b>outside</b> the courtyard should be <b>fit?</b>
The Gemara explains that one does not derive this <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as the verse <b>states: “And you shall not eat any flesh that is torn of beasts in the field”</b> (Exodus 22:30). The apparently superfluous term “in the field” teaches a general <i>halakha</i>: <b>Once meat has left</b> and been removed <b>outside of its boundary,</b> i.e., the area in which it is permitted to consume it, it <b>has become prohibited.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion of the blood of a sin offer-ing that entered the Sanctuary. <b>The Sages taught:</b> It is stated that when Moses questioned Aaron as to why a sin offering was not consumed, he said: “Behold, its blood was not brought into the sacred place <b>within”</b> (Leviticus 10:18). This indicates that had the blood been brought within, Moses would have understood that the offering would have been disqualified and rendered prohibited for consumption. The <i>baraita</i> comments: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the offering is disqualified if the blood is brought <b>within,</b> i.e., into the Holy of Holies; <b>from where</b> is it derived that the same applies if it was merely brought into the <b>Sanctuary? The verse states: “Into the sacred place within,”</b> and this sacred place is the Sanctuary.
The Gemara questions this derivation: <b>And let</b> the verse <b>state</b> only <b>“sacred place,” and</b> it need <b>not state “within.”</b> If blood that entered the Sanctuary is already disqualified, this <i>halakha</i> certainly applies if it was brought farther inside, to the Holy of Holies. <b>Rava says: This</b> verse <b>comes and teaches about that</b> verse. In other words, had the verse stated only “sacred place,” it would have been interpreted as referring to the Holy of Holies. The addition of “within” indicates that this sacred place is the Sanctuary, while the term “within” is referring to the Holy of Holies. The Gemara cites a similar example: This is <b>just as it is with regard to a tenant and a hired worker.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning <i>teruma</i>: The verse states: “A tenant of a priest or a hired worker shall not eat of the consecrated” (Leviticus 22:10). <b>“A tenant”; this</b> is referring to a Hebrew slave who has been <b>acquired</b> as <b>a permanent acquisition,</b> i.e., one who said he wishes to stay with his master. This slave has his ear pierced and he remains with his master until the Jubilee Year. <b>“A hired worker”; this</b> is referring to a Hebrew slave who has been <b>acquired</b> for <b>an acquisition of</b> six <b>years,</b> the standard period of servitude for a Hebrew slave.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Let</b> the verse <b>say “tenant” and let it not say “hired worker,” and I</b> would <b>say:</b> If one who is <b>acquired</b> as <b>a permanent acquisition does not partake</b> of his master’s, i.e., the priest’s, <i>teruma</i>, as despite his status as a slave he is not considered his master’s property, is it <b>not all the more so</b> logical that one who is <b>acquired</b> for <b>an acquisition of</b> six <b>years</b> should not be permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>?
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>If so,</b> that the verse were stated in this manner, <b>I would say: “A tenant”; this is</b> one who was <b>acquired</b> for <b>an acquisition of</b> six <b>years,</b> as the term itself is ambiguous, <b>but</b> one who was <b>acquired</b> as <b>a permanent acquisition may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, the term <b>“hired worker,”</b> which is certainly referring to one who is less permanent than a tenant, <b>comes and teaches about</b> the meaning of the term <b>“tenant,” that this</b> one was <b>acquired</b> as <b>a permanent acquisition and that</b> one was <b>acquired</b> for <b>an acquisition of</b> six <b>years, and</b> both this one and that one <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Similar reasoning applies in the above case concerning the terms “sacred place” and “within.”
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: Are these cases comparable? <b>Granted, there,</b> the tenant and the hired worker <b>are two bodies. And</b> this is significant, as <b>even though the verse could have written</b> explicitly that <b>a pierced</b> tenant <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, from which the <i>halakha</i> of a Hebrew slave for six years could have been inferred, <b>and the other</b> case, that of a slave for six years, is therefore <b>a matter that can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, it need not be stated explicitly. Nevertheless, there is a principle: At times, with regard to <b>a matter that can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, the <b>verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly. <b>But here,</b> the same blood enters the Holy of Holies via the Sanctuary, and <b>once it is disqualified in the Sanctuary, why is it necessary</b> for the verse to teach that this blood is disqualified when it enters <b>the innermost sanctum,</b> the Holy of Holies?
<b>Rather, Abaye says:</b> This mention of “within” <b>is necessary only for</b> a case where the blood entered the Holy of Holies not via the Sanctuary but in <b>a roundabout manner,</b> e.g., from the roof or the loft of the Holy of Holies, without having entered the Sanctuary. <b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>But</b> an expression of <b>bringing is written in</b> the verse: “Behold, its blood was not brought into the sacred place within,” which indicates a standard manner of bringing it into the Holy of Holies. <b>Rather, Rava says:</b> In <b>any</b> circumstance <b>where</b> the priest <b>intended</b> to bring the blood inside <b>the innermost sanctum, it is not disqualified</b> when it is only <b>in the Sanctuary,</b> and therefore it was necessary for the verse to teach both disqualifications.
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin and</b> the <b>goat for</b> a sin of <b>idol worship,</b> whose blood should be presented in the Sanctuary, if it occurred <b>that</b> the priest <b>brought their blood into the innermost sanctum, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rava explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>Do we say</b> that since the verse states: <b>“Into the sacred place within”</b> (Leviticus 10:18) as a single phrase, and therefore <b>anywhere that we read</b> a prohibition against bringing the blood <b>“into the sacred place,”</b> i.e., that the blood is disqualified by being brought into the Sanctuary, <b>we</b> also <b>read</b> a prohibition against bringing the blood <b>“within,”</b> i.e., that it is likewise disqualified when it is brought into the Holy of Holies; but <b>anywhere that we do not read</b> a prohibition against bringing the blood <b>“into the sacred place,”</b> such as with regard to these offerings, whose blood is supposed to be brought into the Sanctuary, <b>we do not read</b> a prohibition against bringing the blood <b>“within”</b> the Holy of Holies? <b>Or perhaps,</b> since in any event the Holy of Holies <b>is not the</b> proper <b>place</b> for the blood <b>of these</b> offerings, it is disqualified.
<b>And if you say that</b> the Holy of Holies <b>is not the</b> proper <b>place</b> for the blood <b>of these</b> offerings and they are therefore disqualified, one can raise another dilemma: In the case of the <b>bull and goat of Yom Kippur, where</b> the High Priest <b>sprinkled from their blood on the staves</b> of the Ark, as required (see Leviticus 16:14), <b>and he brought</b> their remaining blood <b>out to the Sanctuary and</b> subsequently <b>brought</b> it <b>in</b> again to the Holy of Holies, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the blood disqualified by this improper second entrance into the Holy of Holies?
Rava explains the sides of the question: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>it is its place,</b> as the High Priest is supposed to bring this blood into the Holy of Holies on Yom Kippur at some point? <b>Or perhaps</b> one should say that <b>since</b> the High Priest has performed the mitzva and the blood has been <b>brought out,</b> it has been <b>brought out,</b> and the Holy of Holies is no longer considered its place.
<b>And if you say that since</b> the blood has been <b>brought out,</b> it has been <b>brought out,</b> one can raise another dilemma: If the High Priest <b>sprinkled from their blood on the</b> Sanctuary <b>Curtain</b>

Daf 83a

<b>and</b> then <b>brought out</b> the blood <b>to the</b> golden <b>altar</b> in the Sanctuary and sprinkled the blood there, as required (see Leviticus 16:18), <b>but</b> subsequently <b>brought</b> the remainder of the blood <b>in</b> toward the Curtain dividing the Sanctuary from the Holy of Holies, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rava explains the sides of the dilemma: Do we say that <b>here</b> the area of the Curtain and the golden altar <b>is certainly one place,</b> as they are both in the Sanctuary, and therefore the blood should not be disqualified by being brought back toward the Curtain? <b>Or perhaps,</b> since <b>we call</b> the taking of the blood to the golden altar: <b>Going out,</b> in the verse: “And he shall go out unto the altar” (Leviticus 16:18), its return to the Curtain should be considered bringing in, and therefore the blood should be disqualified? No answers were found, and therefore the Gemara states that these dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that the Sages disagree as to the <i>halakha</i> in a case where the priest carrying the blood of a sin offering whose blood placement is on the external altar <b>entered</b> the Sanctuary <b>to atone</b> through sprinkling, but in practice the priest did not actually sprinkle the blood. According to Rabbi Eliezer the blood is disqualified, whereas Rabbi Shimon maintains that the blood is disqualified only if the priest sprinkles it in the Sanctuary. Concerning this, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: It is stated here:</b> “And any sin offering, whereof any of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting <b>to atone in the Sanctuary,</b> shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:23), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the service of the High Priest on Yom Kippur: <b>“And there shall be no man in the Tent of Meeting when he goes in to atone in the Sanctuary,</b> until he comes out” (Leviticus 16:17).
Rabbi Eliezer explains: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to Yom Kippur, the phrase “when he goes in to atone” is referring <b>to</b> the stage <b>when</b> he <b>has not</b> yet <b>atoned, so too here,</b> with regard to the disqualification of blood brought inside the Sanctuary, the phrase “to atone in the Sanctuary” is referring <b>to</b> a situation where the blood enters the Sanctuary at a time <b>when</b> the priest <b>has not</b> yet <b>atoned.</b>
Conversely, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: It is stated here: “To atone”</b> (Leviticus 6:23), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the conclusion of the service on Yom Kippur: <b>“And the bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought in to atone</b> in the Sanctuary, shall be taken outside the camp, and they shall burn in the fire” (Leviticus 16:27). <b>Just as there,</b> the phrase “to atone” is referring <b>to</b> the stage <b>when</b> he has already <b>atoned,</b> as the bull and goat of Yom Kippur are burned after their blood has been sprinkled, <b>so too here,</b> the phrase “to atone” is referring <b>to</b> a situation <b>where</b> he has already <b>atoned,</b> whereas merely bringing the blood into the Sanctuary does not disqualify it.
The Gemara inquires: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara explains that one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>one derives</b> a case of <b>outside,</b> i.e., the blood of a sin offering whose blood placement is on the external altar, which may not be brought inside the Sanctuary, <b>from</b> another prohibition of <b>outside,</b> the prohibition against entering the Sanctuary; <b>but one does not derive</b> a case of <b>outside from</b> the bull and goat of Yom Kippur, whose blood is brought <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary.
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>one derives</b> a <i>halakha</i> involving <b>an animal,</b> i.e., a sin offering whose blood placement is on the external altar, <b>from</b> another <i>halakha</i> involving <b>an animal,</b> the bull and goat of Yom Kippur; <b>but one does not derive</b> a case of <b>an animal from</b> a prohibition involving <b>a person.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the priest took the blood into the Sanctuary unwittingly, the blood remains fit for presentation. The Gemara infers: <b>But</b> if his taking of the blood into the Sanctuary was <b>intentional,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara analyzes this <i>halakha</i>: Is the blood disqualified only <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> he took the blood into the Sanctuary and <b>atoned,</b> by sprinkling it inside the Sanctuary, as claimed by Rabbi Eliezer in the mishna; <b>or</b> even <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> he took the blood in and <b>did not</b> yet <b>atone,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that one can cite a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is stated</b> with regard to the Yom Kippur service: <b>“And the bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought in to atone in the Sanctuary,</b> shall be taken outside the camp, and they shall burn in the fire their skins, and their flesh, and their dung; and he who burns them shall wash his clothes” (Leviticus 16:27–28), one can ask the following question: <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “And he who burns”?</b>
The Gemara interrupts its citation of the <i>baraita</i> to question its line of inquiry. <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “And he who burns”?</b> One can answer that this term <b>was necessary for itself,</b> to teach that the one who burns the bull and goat of Yom Kippur is thereby rendered ritually impure. <b>Rather,</b> this is what the <i>baraita</i> is saying: <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> twice: <b>“Sin offering,” “sin offering,”</b> with regard to the bull and the goat? It could have stated merely: And the bull and the goat of the sin offering.
The <i>baraita</i> answers <b>that</b> if the term “sin offering” had appeared only once, <b>we</b> would <b>have learned only with regard to</b> the <b>bull and</b> the <b>goat of Yom Kippur that are burned in the place of the ashes</b> that <b>they render ritually impure</b> the <b>garments</b> of the one who carries them. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to <b>other</b> sin offerings that are <b>burned? The verse states: “Sin offering,” “sin offering,”</b> twice, to include all sin offerings that are burned. This <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir says: This</b> derivation from the repeated mention of sin offering <b>is not necessary. Now</b> consider, the verse <b>states: “And the bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering</b>…shall be taken outside the camp.” <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> with regard to these offerings: “Whose blood was brought in <b>to atone</b> in the Sanctuary,” <b>why</b> must <b>the verse</b> nevertheless <b>state: “To atone”?</b> This <b>teaches with regard to all</b> offerings <b>that atone</b> inside the Sanctuary <b>that one who burns them renders</b> his <b>garments impure.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda does not learn</b> anything from the term <b>“to atone.” What is the reason</b> for this? Is it <b>not because he requires</b> this phrase <b>for a verbal analogy,</b> to derive that the blood of an external sin offering that was taken inside the Sanctuary is disqualified only if the priest sprinkled it, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? This answers the Gemara’s question, as Rabbi Yehuda evidently follows the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Certain unfit items, once they have been placed on the altar, are nevertheless sacrificed. The mishna teaches: <b>The altar sanctifies</b> only items <b>that are suited to it.</b> The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree as to the definition of suited for the altar.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: Any</b> item <b>that is suited to</b> be consumed by <b>the fire</b> on the altar, e.g., burnt offerings and the sacrificial portions of other offerings, which are burned on the altar, <b>if it ascended</b> upon the altar, even if it is disqualified from being sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>, <b>it shall not descend.</b> Since it was sanctified by its ascent upon the altar, it is sacrificed upon it, <b>as it is stated: “It is the burnt offering on the pyre</b> upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2), from which it is derived: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering, which is suited to</b> be consumed by <b>the fire</b> on the altar, <b>if it ascended it shall not descend, so too,</b> with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that is suited to</b> be consumed by <b>the fire</b> on the altar, <b>if it ascended it shall not descend.</b>
<b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that is suited to</b> ascend upon <b>the altar,</b> even if it is not typically consumed, <b>if it ascended, it shall not descend,</b> even if it is disqualified from being sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>, <b>as it is stated: “It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar,”</b> from which it is derived: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering, which is fit for the altar, if it ascended it shall not descend, so too, any</b> item <b>that is fit for the altar, if it ascended it shall not descend.</b>
The mishna comments: <b>The difference between the statement of Rabban Gamliel and the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua is only</b> with regard to disqualified <b>blood and</b> disqualified <b>libations,</b> which are not consumed by the fire but do ascend upon the altar, <b>as Rabban Gamliel says: They shall not descend,</b> as they are fit to ascend upon the altar, <b>and Rabbi Yehoshua says: They shall descend,</b> as they are not burned on the altar.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Whether <b>the offering was fit and</b> the accompanying <b>libations</b> were <b>unfit,</b> e.g., if they became ritually impure or they were brought outside their designated area, or whether <b>the libations</b> were <b>fit and the offering</b> was <b>unfit,</b> rendering the accompanying libations unfit as well, and <b>even</b> if both <b>this and that were unfit, the offering shall not descend,</b> as it was sanctified by the altar, <b>but the libations shall descend.</b>

Daf 83b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the altar sanctifies items that are suited to it, from which the Gemara infers: Items <b>suited to</b> the altar, <b>yes,</b> they are sanctified by it, but items <b>that are not suited to</b> the altar, <b>no,</b> they are not sanctified by it and descend from it even after ascending. The Gemara asks: This inference serves <b>to exclude what? Rav Pappa said:</b> It serves <b>to exclude handfuls</b> of flour that were removed from meal offerings by a priest in order to be burned on the altar, and <b>that were not sanctified</b> by being placed <b>in</b> a service <b>vessel</b> before they ascended upon the altar. Those handfuls did not yet become suited for the altar and therefore shall descend.
<b>Ravina objects to</b> Rav Pappa’s assertion: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that of Ulla? As Ulla says: Sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that</b> one <b>offered up</b> on the altar <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the offering’s <b>blood,</b> and are therefore not yet suited for the altar, <b>shall not descend,</b> as <b>they have become the bread of</b> the <b>altar,</b> i.e., they have been sanctified such that they must be burned.
The Gemara responds that there is a difference between the cases: <b>These</b> sacrificial portions described by Ulla <b>do not lack</b> the performance of <b>an action with regard to themselves</b> that will render them fit for the altar; they lack only the sprinkling of the blood, an independent action. By contrast, <b>these</b> handfuls mentioned by Rav Pappa <b>lack</b> the performance of <b>an action with regard to themselves,</b> as they have yet to be sanctified through placement in a service vessel and never became fit for the altar.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: Any</b> item <b>that is suited to</b> be consumed by <b>the fire</b> on the altar, if it ascended upon the altar it shall not descend, as it is stated: “It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2), from which it is derived that any item suited for burning on the altar shall not descend. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabban Gamliel also,</b> who holds that any item suited for the altar, whether it is to be burned or not, shall not descend, <b>isn’t it written</b> in the verse: <b>“Burnt offering on the pyre”?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes</b> to teach the mitzva <b>to restore</b> to the pyre any parts of the offering that were <b>dislodged</b> from the pyre, and is not discussing unfit items at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>from where does he</b> derive the requirement <b>to restore</b> to the fire sacrificial portions that were <b>dislodged</b> from it? The Gemara responds: <b>He derives it from</b> the verse: <b>“That the fire has consumed</b> of the burnt offering on the altar” (Leviticus 6:3), indicating that items already partially consumed by the fire are restored to it even if they were dislodged from the pyre.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabban Gamliel, what does he derive from that verse? The Gemara responds: Rabban Gamliel <b>requires that</b> verse <b>to</b> derive that <b>you return</b> partially <b>consumed</b> parts <b>of a burnt offering</b> to the altar, <b>but you do not return</b> partially <b>consumed</b> parts <b>of an incense</b> offering that fell from the golden altar. <b>As Rabbi Ḥanina bar Minyumi, son of Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, teaches</b> that the verse <b>“that the fire has consumed of the burnt offering on the altar”</b> teaches that <b>you return</b> partially <b>consumed</b> parts <b>of a burnt offering</b> that fell from the pyre, <b>but you do not return</b> partially <b>consumed</b> parts <b>of an incense</b> offering that fell from the pyre.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehoshua, from where does he derive this distinction? The Gemara responds: Can it <b>not be learned by itself</b> from the straightforward meaning of the verse <b>that we restore</b> partially <b>consumed</b> parts <b>of a burnt offering</b> to the altar? Therefore, there is no need for an additional verse, as both <i>halakhot</i> can be derived from the same verse.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that is suited</b> to ascend upon the altar, even if it is not typically consumed, if it ascended, it shall not descend, even if it is disqualified from being sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>, as it is stated: “It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2). The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yehoshua as well, isn’t it written:</b> “Upon the <b>altar,”</b> and not merely: “On the pyre”? The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> term <b>is required</b> by Rabbi Yehoshua to teach: <b>What is the reason the Merciful One states</b> that <b>any</b> item <b>that is suited for the pyre</b> does not descend from the altar? It is because the <b>altar sanctifies</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabban Gamliel, from where does he derive that the altar sanctifies the items that ascend upon it? The Gemara responds: It is from the fact that the term <b>“altar” is written another</b> time, in the verse: “Whatever touches the altar shall be sacred” (Exodus 29:37). The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehoshua, why does he require two verses to teach the same <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that the altar sanctifies items that ascend upon it? The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> verse is necessary <b>for</b> a case <b>where</b> an item <b>had a time of fitness</b> for consumption by the fire and was then disqualified, e.g., it became ritually impure; <b>and one</b> verse is necessary <b>for</b> a case <b>where</b> an item <b>did not have a time of fitness,</b> e.g., an offering that became disqualified at the moment of its slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabban Gamliel, why does he not require another verse to teach that even items that had no time of fitness shall not descend from the altar? The Gemara responds: <b>Once there are disqualified</b> items <b>that the Merciful One included</b> in the <i>halakha</i> that they shall not descend from the altar, it <b>is no different</b> if the item <b>had a time of fitness</b> and it <b>is no different</b> if the item <b>did not have a time of fitness.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Whether <b>the offering was fit</b> and the accompanying libations were unfit, or whether the libations were fit and the offering was unfit, and even if both this and that were unfit, the offering shall not descend, but the libations shall descend. The Gemara elaborates: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The verse that teaches that fit items shall not descend from the altar states: “This is the law of the <b>burnt offering:</b> It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2). From there it is derived: <b>Just as a burnt offering,</b> which is an item <b>that comes</b> upon the altar <b>for its own sake,</b> shall not descend, <b>so too, all items that come</b> upon the altar <b>for their own sake</b> shall not descend. <b>Excluded</b> are <b>libations, which come</b> upon the altar <b>for the sake of the offering,</b> not for their own sake; these shall descend.
§ The Gemara cites another <i>baraita</i> relating to the mishna. <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: From that</b> which <b>is stated: “Whatever touches the altar shall be sacred”</b> (Exodus 29:37), <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> that the altar sanctifies any item that ascends upon it, <b>whether</b> it <b>is fit</b> for the altar <b>or whether</b> it <b>is unfit.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Now this is that which you shall offer upon the altar: Two <b>lambs”</b> (Exodus 29:38), to teach: <b>Just as lambs</b> are <b>fit</b> for the altar and are sanctified by it, <b>so too, all</b> items <b>fit</b> for the altar are sanctified by it. <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that the verse states: <b>“Burnt offering,”</b> to teach: <b>Just as a burnt offering</b> is <b>fit</b> for the altar and is sanctified by it, <b>so too, all</b> items <b>fit</b> for the altar are sanctified by it.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these opinions? <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> The case of <b>a disqualified bird burnt offering is</b> the practical difference <b>between them.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, who <b>cites</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>“burnt offering,”</b> includes a disqualified bird burnt offering in the <i>halakha</i> that the offering shall not descend, as it is a burnt offering. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who <b>cites</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>“lambs,”</b> does not include a disqualified bird burnt offering in the <i>halakha</i>, as it is not similar to a lamb.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who cites</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>“lambs,” isn’t it written: “Burnt offering”?</b> The Gemara answers: According to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>if “lambs”</b> had been <b>written and “burnt offering”</b> had <b>not</b> been <b>written, I would say</b> that <b>even</b> an animal that became disqualified and ascended upon the altar <b>while alive</b> shall not descend. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Burnt offering,”</b> indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to animals once they are fit to ascend the altar. Live animals are not fit to ascend the altar.
The Gemara continues: <b>And according to the one who derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from “burnt offering,” isn’t it written: “Lambs”?</b> The Gemara explains: According to Rabbi Akiva, <b>if “burnt offering”</b> had been <b>written and “lambs”</b> had <b>not</b> been <b>written, I would say</b> that any item fit to ascend the altar is included in the <i>halakha</i>, <b>even a meal offering.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Lambs,”</b> indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to animal offerings and bird offerings, not to meal offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva, and the opinions of <b>these <i>tanna’im</i> of the mishna? Rav Pappa said:</b> The difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to <b>handfuls</b> of flour, removed from meal offerings, <b>that were sanctified in</b> a service <b>vessel</b> and were then disqualified. According <b>to our <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> i.e., those in the mishna here, those handfuls <b>shall not descend,</b> as they are fit for the altar and for consumption by the fire as well. According <b>to the <i>tanna’im</i> of the <i>baraita</i>,</b> those handfuls <b>shall descend,</b> as those <i>tanna’im</i> hold that the <i>halakha</i> applies only to animal offerings and bird offerings.
<b>Reish Lakish says</b> in summary: With regard to <b>a meal offering that comes by itself</b> and does not accompany another offering, <b>according to the statements of all</b> of the <i>tanna’im</i> in the mishna, <b>it shall not descend</b> once it ascended, either because it is fit to be consumed by the fire, or because it comes by itself. <b>According to the statements of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva,</b>

Daf 84a

even that meal offering <b>shall descend,</b> as it is not similar to lambs. With regard to <b>a meal offering that comes with</b> an animal <b>offering,</b> either a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>according to the statements of Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua, it shall not descend,</b> as it is meant for consumpion by the fire. <b>According to the statements of everyone</b> else, i.e., Rabbi Shimon and the <i>tannai’im</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>it shall descend,</b> as it is neither offered by itself nor is it an animal.
Reish Lakish continues: With regard to <b>libations that come by themselves, according to the statements of everyone,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, Rabbi Akiva, and Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>they shall descend,</b> but <b>according to the statements of Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Shimon, they shall not descend.</b> With regard to <b>libations that come with an animal offering, according to the statements of everyone, they shall descend,</b> while according to <b>the statement of Rabban Gamliel alone, they shall not descend.</b>
The Gemara questions the need for such a summary: Isn’t it <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> him to state the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a meal offering that comes by itself, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava. As Rava says: A person</b> can <b>volunteer</b> to bring <b>a meal offering</b> that normally accompanies libations, <b>on any day,</b> even without offering the libations and animal offering that it normally accompanies. Although the summary is itself obvious, it is nevertheless stated to indicate that it is possible to offer such a meal offering.
The Gemara asks: If the intent of his summary is to express his agreement with the statement of Rava, then <b>let</b> Reish Lakish <b>teach us</b> explicitly that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava.</b> The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> the case of <b>libations that come with</b> an animal <b>offering,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> in such a case is <b>that he may sacrifice</b> the libations <b>the next day and on a later [<i>ḥara</i>] day</b> sometime after sacrificing the animal offering that they accompany.
Accordingly, it may <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since the Master says</b> that the verse: “And <b>their meal offering and their liba-tions”</b> (Numbers 29:18), indicates that libations may be offered <b>at night,</b> and the phrase “and <b>their meal offering and their libations”</b> indicates that libations may be offered <b>the next day</b> and on a later day, perhaps libations offered on a later date than the animal itself are to be <b>considered as libations which come by themselves, and Rabbi Shimon</b> would <b>concede that they shall not descend.</b> Reish Lakish therefore <b>teaches us</b> the case of libations that accompany an animal offering, to indicate that such libations are still considered as those that accompany an animal offering and that they shall descend from the altar.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These</b> are the items that even if they were disqualified, <b>if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend:</b> Blood, sacrificial portions, or limbs of a burnt offering, any of <b>which were left overnight</b> off the altar, <b>or that emerge</b> from the Temple courtyard, <b>or that</b> become <b>ritually impure, or</b> that came from an animal <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intent to sacrifice it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, or</b> an offering <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> to perform the Temple service <b>collected and</b> then <b>sprinkled its blood.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In the case of a sacrificial animal <b>that was slaughtered at night, or</b> one <b>whose blood was spilled</b> on the floor of the Temple without its being collected in a vessel, <b>or</b> one whose <b>blood emerged outside the curtains,</b> i.e., outside the Temple courtyard: Even <b>if it ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall descend. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In all these cases, if it ascended <b>it shall not descend, because its disqualification</b> occurred <b>in sanctity. As Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> unfit offering <b>whose disqualification</b> occurred <b>in sanctity,</b> i.e., in the course of the Temple service, <b>the sacred</b> area <b>renders</b> the offering <b>acceptable,</b> and if it ascended onto the altar it shall not descend. But with regard to any offering <b>whose disqualification</b> did <b>not</b> occur <b>in sanctity</b> but rather was unfit initially, <b>the sacred</b> area <b>does not render</b> the offering <b>acceptable.</b>
<b>And these are</b> the offerings <b>whose disqualification</b> did <b>not</b> occur <b>in sanctity: An animal that copulated with a person, and an animal that was the object of bestiality, and</b> an animal that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>and</b> an animal that was <b>worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>and</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as <b>the price</b> of a dog, <b>and</b> an animal born of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds, and an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], and</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section, and blemished</b> animals. <b>Rabbi Akiva deems blemished</b> animals <b>fit</b> in the sense that if they ascended they shall not descend. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, says: My father would reject blemished</b> animals <b>from upon the altar.</b>
Concerning those animals that, if they ascended, do not descend, <b>just as if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend, so too, if they descended they shall not</b> then <b>ascend. And all of them that</b> if they ascend they do not descend, if <b>they ascended to the top of the altar alive they descend,</b> as an animal is fit for the altar only after it is slaughtered. <b>A burnt offering that ascended to the top of the altar alive shall descend,</b> as one does not slaughter an animal atop the altar <i>ab initio</i>. But if <b>one slaughtered</b> the animal <b>at the top of the altar, he should flay</b> it <b>and cut it into pieces in its place,</b> and it is not removed from the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The verse from which is derived the <i>halakha</i> that items that ascended upon the altar shall not descend, states: <b>“This</b> is the law of the burnt offering: <b>It is the burnt offering</b> on the pyre upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:2). <b>These are three</b> terms of <b>exclusion</b> used in the verse: “This,” “it,” and “the,” from which it is derived that three instances are <b>excluded</b> from this <i>halakha</i>: A sacrificial animal <b>that was slaughtered at night, and</b> one <b>whose blood was spilled, and</b> one <b>whose blood emerged outside the curtains,</b> i.e., outside the Temple courtyard. With regard to these cases, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that if</b> one of them <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall descend.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> From the usage of the term <b>“burnt offering” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a fit burnt offering</b> that it shall not descend. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the verse also <b>includes</b> a sacrificial animal that was disqualified, such as one <b>that was slaughtered at night; or whose blood was spilled; or whose blood emerged outside the curtains,</b> i.e., outside the Temple courtyard; <b>or that was left overnight; or that emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard, <b>or that</b> became <b>ritually impure; or</b> that came from an animal <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intent to sacrifice it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area; or</b> an offering <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> to perform the Temple service <b>collected and</b> then <b>sprinkled its blood?</b>
In addition, from where is it derived that the following are also included in this <i>halakha</i>: <b>Those</b> offerings whose blood is to be <b>placed below</b> the red line that divided between the upper and lower halves of the external altar, i.e., a burnt offering, a guilt offering, or a peace offering, but it <b>was placed above</b> the red line; <b>and</b> a sin offering, whose blood is to be placed <b>above</b> the red line, <b>that</b> had its blood <b>placed below</b> the red line; <b>and those</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed outside,</b> on the external altar, <b>that</b> had their blood <b>placed inside,</b> in the Sanctuary; and those offerings whose blood is to be placed <b>inside that</b> had their blood <b>placed outside?</b>
<b>And</b> in addition, with regard to <b>a Paschal offering or sin offering that were slaughtered not for their sake, from where</b> is it derived that if they ascended upon the altar they shall not descend? <b>The verse states: “The law of the burnt offering,”</b> which <b>included</b> in <b>one law all</b> items <b>that ascend</b> upon the altar, establishing the principle <b>that if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend.</b>
