One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should also <b>include an animal that copulated with a person, and an animal that was the object of bestiality, and</b> an animal that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>and</b> an animal that was <b>worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>and</b> an animal that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as the <b>price</b> of a dog, <b>and</b> an animal born of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds, and</b> an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, and</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This,”</b> to exclude these types of disqualifications, which descend even after they have ascended the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> as reason <b>to include those and exclude these?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>After</b> noting <b>that</b> the verse <b>included</b>

Daf 84b

<b>and</b> subsequently <b>the verse excluded,</b> I say the following claim with regard to what to include and what to exclude: <b>I will include those whose disqualification was in sanctity,</b> i.e., in the course of Temple service, and rule that if they ascended they shall not descend, <b>and I will exclude these whose disqualification was not in sanctity,</b> and rule that if they ascended they shall descend.
<b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who disagrees with Rabbi Shimon and does not deem it permitted for items whose disqualification occurred in sanctity to remain on the altar, yet agrees that those items listed in the beginning of the mishna, such as sacrificial portions left overnight, shall not descend, <b>he derives it from here,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say to us</b> that <b>in</b> the case of <b>blood</b> left overnight it is <b>fit,</b> i.e., if blood of an offering had been left overnight and was then placed on the altar it is not removed?
This is <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial portions,</b> which if they are <b>left overnight</b> are <b>fit.</b> From where is it derived that <b>in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial portions</b> that are <b>left overnight,</b> they are <b>fit?</b> This is <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in</b> the case of <b>meat,</b> which if it is <b>left overnight</b> is <b>fit,</b> because the meat of a peace offering may be eaten for two days and one night.
From where is it derived that if an offering that <b>emerges</b> from the Temple courtyard is then placed on the altar it is not removed? This is derived by comparison, <b>since</b> an offering that <b>leaves</b> its area is <b>fit in</b> the case of an offering brought on a private <b>altar,</b> as the entire notion of sacrifice on such an altar is that it may be performed anywhere.
From where is it derived that if an offering that has become <b>ritually impure</b> is placed on the altar it is not removed? This is derived by comparison, <b>since</b> it is <b>permitted to</b> offer an impure offering in <b>the</b> case of <b>communal rites,</b> i.e., communal offerings. In cases of necessity, the communal offerings may be sacrificed even if they are ritually impure.
From where is it derived that if an offering that was disqualified due to the intention of the priest who slaughtered it to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time</b> [<i>piggul</i>] was placed on the altar, it is not removed? This is derived by comparison, <b>since</b> the sprinkling of its blood <b>effects acceptance</b> with regard to <b>its</b> status as <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The status of <i>piggul</i> takes effect only if the sacrificial rites involving that offering were otherwise performed properly. This indicates that it still has the status of an offering, so it is not removed from the altar.
From where is it derived that if an offering that was disqualified due to the intention of the priest who slaughtered it to consume it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> was placed on the altar, it is not removed? This is derived by comparison, <b>since</b> it is <b>juxtaposed to</b> an offering that was slaughtered with intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time.</b>
From where is it derived that if an offering <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>collected and</b> then <b>sprinkled its blood</b> was placed on the altar, it is not removed? This is derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>these</b> priests who are generally <b>disqualified</b> because they are impure, yet <b>who are fit to</b> perform <b>the communal rites,</b> i.e., to sacrifice communal offerings, in a case when all the priests or the majority of the Jewish people are impure.
The Gemara questions the derivations of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But can one deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a matter that is not fit,</b> i.e., sacrificial portions that are disqualified due to having been left overnight, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a matter that is fit,</b> i.e., the peace offering, which is permitted for eating for two days and one night? Similarly, how can the <i>baraita</i> derive the <i>halakha</i> of flesh that was removed from the Temple courtyard from the <i>halakha</i> of a private altar, which has no halakhic area surrounding it?
The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i> relied on</b> the verse: “Command Aaron and his sons, saying: <b>This is the law of the burnt offering:</b> It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar all night until the morning; and the fire of the altar shall be kept burning there” (Leviticus 6:2), which <b>amplified</b> the application of the <i>halakha</i> stated in the verse, teaching that many types of disqualified offerings may be left upon the altar. The derivations written in the <i>baraita</i> are mere supports for those two <i>halakhot</i>. The explanations cited in the <i>baraita</i> for including these disqualifications are mentioned only to clarify why Rabbi Yehuda does not exclude them based on the terms “this,” “it,” and “that.”
§ With regard to an offering that was slaughtered at night, which Rabbi Yehuda holds shall descend from the altar even if it ascended, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One who slaughters</b> a sacrificial <b>animal at night inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> then <b>offers</b> it <b>up</b> on an altar <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>, which is the punishment for one who sacrifices an offering outside the Temple courtyard. Although one is normally liable for sacrificing an offering outside the Temple courtyard only if it was fit to be offered on the altar within the Temple, and an animal slaughtered at night is disqualified and shall descend from the altar according to Rabbi Yehuda,

Daf 85a

nevertheless, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who slaughters an animal at night <b>should not be less</b> stringent <b>than</b> that of one who <b>slaughters</b> an animal <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>and offers</b> it <b>up outside.</b> With regard to that case, the mishna (106a) states that such a person is liable, even though an animal slaughtered outside the Temple is not fit to be offered on the altar inside the Temple and shall descend from the altar even if it has ascended.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan from a mishna (111a): <b>One who slaughters a bird inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> then <b>offers</b> it <b>up</b> on an altar <b>outside</b> the Temple is <b>exempt,</b> as a bird offering is supposed to be pinched at the nape of the neck and not slaughtered with a knife. But if he <b>slaughtered</b> the bird <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and offered</b> it <b>up outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>let us say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who slaughters an animal inside the Temple <b>should not be less</b> stringent <b>than</b> that of one who <b>slaughters</b> an animal <b>and offers</b> it <b>up outside</b> the Temple. Why, then, is such a person exempt?
The Gemara responds: This is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan is rejected. The Gemara adds a possible explanation: <b>If you wish, say</b> that one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of a bird slaughtered inside the Temple from that of a bird slaughtered outside of it, because in the case of <b>the slaughter of a bird inside</b> the Temple, it is considered as if <b>he killed it.</b> By contrast, in the case of an animal slaughtered at night within the Temple, although it is disqualified, it is still considered a slaughtered animal, and its status may therefore be derived from that of an animal that is slaughtered outside the Temple.
§ Concerning items that were inappropriately placed on the altar, <b>Ulla says: Sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that</b> one <b>offered up</b> upon the altar <b>before the sprinkling of their blood,</b> which is the act that sanctifies such portions for the altar, <b>shall not descend,</b> as <b>they have become the bread of</b> the <b>altar.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> in support of Ulla: <b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>as well:</b> The sacrificial portions of an offering <b>whose blood was spilled, or whose blood emerged outside the curtains,</b> shall not descend if they ascended. From this one can infer: <b>And if there, where</b> the blood was spilled, <b>if he comes to sprinkle</b> it <b>he cannot sprinkle</b> it, as there is no blood with which to do so, and <b>you said</b> that <b>if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend,</b> then <b>here,</b> where the blood is intact such <b>that if he comes to sprinkle</b> it <b>he sprinkles</b> it, which renders the sacrificial portions permitted for sacrifice upon the altar, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that if they ascended they shall not descend?
The Gemara rejects the inference of Rabbi Zeira: <b>Interpret</b> the mishna as referring specifically <b>to offerings of the most sacred order,</b> whose sacrificial portions are sanctified for the sake of the altar before their blood is presented. Therefore, such sacrificial portions are considered fit for the altar and shall not descend if they ascended. It may be that the sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity are entirely unfit for the altar before the presentation of their blood.
The Gemara challenges: But there is <b>a Paschal offering, which is an offering of lesser sanctity,</b> and it is mentioned in the same list of items that shall not descend if they ascended. The Gemara explains: <b>Interpret</b> the case of a Paschal offering as referring <b>to</b> where it was slaughtered <b>not for its sake,</b> but not to where its blood was spilled or emerged outside the curtains.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And all of them that</b> if they ascend they do not descend, if <b>they ascended to</b> the top of <b>the altar alive, they descend. But</b> it may be inferred from here that <b>slaughtered</b> animals <b>shall not descend,</b> even if their blood was not presented. <b>What, is it not</b> that this inference applies to all offerings, and the <i>halakha</i> <b>is not different</b> with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, and it is not different</b> with regard to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is possible to infer as follows: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>slaughtered</b> animals, some <b>of them shall descend</b> and some <b>of them shall not descend.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>all of them</b> shall descend if they ascended alive, in which case it must be inferred with regard to all of them that if they were slaughtered they shall not descend. The Gemara explains: When the mishna states: <b>All of them</b> shall descend, it is referring only <b>to</b> animals that ascended upon the altar while still <b>alive,</b> in order to emphasize that all fit animals that ascended while still alive shall descend and are not slaughtered atop the altar. The mishna did not intend to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all slaughtered animals.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that live animals that ascended upon the altar shall descend? The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna intends to teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to living</b> animals <b>but</b> is referring specifically <b>to</b> animals blemished on <b>the cornea of the eye, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that in the case of such a small blemish, <b>if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend.</b> The phrase: All of them shall descend, teaches that even Rabbi Akiva agrees that such animals that ascended while still alive shall descend.
The Gemara asks: <b>To what</b> case <b>did you interpret</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna to be referring? You interpreted it as referring <b>to disqualified</b> offerings. <b>Say the latter clause: And likewise, a burnt offering that ascended to the top of the altar alive shall descend.</b> But if <b>one slaughtered</b> the animal <b>at the top of the altar, he should flay</b> it <b>and cut</b> it <b>into pieces in its place,</b> and it is not removed from the altar. <b>And if</b> the mishna is referring to <b>a disqualified</b> offering one must ask: Is a disqualified offering <b>fit for flaying and cutting? The Merciful One states:</b> “And he shall flay the burnt offering, <b>and cut it</b> into its pieces” (Leviticus 1:6), and the word <b>“it”</b> indicates an exclusion: Only <b>fit</b> offerings are flayed and cut, <b>and not</b> those that are <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara answers: In <b>the latter clause we come to</b> refer to <b>a fit</b> offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And what does</b> this <b>teach us?</b> The Gemara answers: It teaches <b>that there is flaying and cutting at the top of the altar,</b> and it is not considered degrading to the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>there is no flaying and cutting at the top of the altar, what can be said?</b> The Gemara answers: According to that opinion, <b>what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the animal that ascended while still alive <b>had a time of fitness,</b> during which it was slaughtered atop the altar and its blood was presented, <b>and</b> thereafter it <b>became disqualified. And</b> the last clause of the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says: Since the blood was sprinkled,</b> thereby <b>effecting acceptance of the flesh</b> of the offering for <b>a moment,</b> even if the offering then became disqualified, <b>he shall flay it and its hide</b> is given <b>to the priests,</b> and its flesh is burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the mishna is referring to an offering that became disqualified, then with regard to <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning the mishna: <b>What shall</b> he <b>do</b> with such an offering? He <b>takes the innards down</b> from the altar, placing them <b>below</b> it, <b>and</b> thereafter <b>rinses them, why do I</b> need to do so? Since the innards of a disqualified offering may not be returned to the altar once they have been removed from it, why should they be removed from the altar?
The Gemara responds: Rather, <b>what should we do? Should we offer them with their dung?</b> Doesn’t the verse state: <b>“Present it now to your governor; will he be pleased with you? Or will he accept your person?”</b> (Malachi 1:8), and isn’t it derived from this verse that items considered repulsive to people are not fit for use as an offering for the Most High?
The Gemara clarifies: <b>This is what we are saying:</b> Since one removes the innards of a disqualified offering from atop the altar and they may not be returned, <b>why do I</b> need to <b>rinse them?</b> The Gemara answers: The concern is <b>that if another priest chances</b> upon these innards <b>and does not know</b> that they are disqualified for the altar, <b>he will sacrifice them</b> upon the altar with their dung.

Daf 85b

The Gemara asks: <b>And shall we stand</b> and <b>do something for the priests through which they</b> shall <b>come to</b> encounter <b>a stumbling block?</b> Were these innards to remain unwashed, no priest would mistakenly sacrifice them upon the altar. The Gemara answers: <b>Even so,</b> rinsing disqualified innards is <b>preferable, so that the sanctified offerings of Heaven shall not be lying as a carcass.</b>
With regard to the matter discussed by Ulla (85a), <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that</b> one <b>offered up before the sprinkling of their blood,</b> which is the act which sanctifies such portions for the altar, <b>shall they descend or shall they not descend?</b>
<b>Rabbi Ami said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: Instead of raising the dilemma of whether or not such portions shall descend, <b>you should raise the dilemma</b> of whether their ascension upon the altar sanctifies them with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> With regard to the <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>I do not raise the dilemma, as</b> certainly the rite of <b>sprinkling</b> and not their ascension to the altar <b>determines</b> their status <b>with regard to</b> the <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. <b>When</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised the dilemma</b> it was with regard to their <b>descent</b> from the altar. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>resolved</b> his dilemma and ruled: If they ascended <b>they shall not descend, and they are not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak teaches</b> the discussion in <b>this</b> manner: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that</b> one <b>offered up</b> on the altar <b>before the sprinkling of their blood, are they subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse or not? Rabbi Ami said to him: And you should raise the dilemma</b> with regard to their <b>descent</b> from upon the altar. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> With regard to their <b>descent I do not raise the dilemma, because</b> after these sacrificial portions ascend the altar <b>they become the bread of</b> the <b>altar</b> and shall not descend. <b>When I raise the dilemma</b> it is with regard to the <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>resolved</b> his dilemma in <b>this</b> manner: <b>They shall not descend, and they are not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And these are</b> the offerings <b>whose disqualification</b> did <b>not</b> occur in sanctity: An animal that copulated with a person, or an animal that was the object of bestiality…or blemished animals. Such offerings shall descend from the altar if they ascended. Rabbi Akiva deems blemished animals fit in the sense that if they ascended upon the altar they shall not descend.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Akiva deemed fit only</b> those animals with small blemishes, such as <b>on the cornea of the eye, as</b> such blemishes <b>are fit with regard to bird</b> offerings <i>ab initio</i>. And <b>this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when their consecration preceded their blemish,</b> since such an animal was fit for the altar at the time of its consecration. But if their blemish preceded their consecration, they shall descend, as they were never fit for the altar. <b>And Rabbi Akiva concedes with regard to a female burnt offering</b> that it shall descend from the altar. Since only a male animal may be used for a burnt offering, <b>it is like</b> a case <b>where</b> the animal’s <b>blemish preceded its consecration.</b>
The Gemara presents a discussion in which the opinion of Rabbi Akiva is cited: <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises the dilemma: Is</b> the disqualification of <b>an animal that was the object of bestiality</b> applicable <b>with regard to birds, or is</b> there <b>no</b> disqualification of <b>an animal that was the object of bestiality with regard to birds? Did</b> the verse <b>say:</b> “When any man of you brings an offering to the Lord, you shall bring your offering <b>of the animals”</b> (Leviticus 1:2), where the term “of” serves <b>to exclude</b> from being brought as offerings both <b>an animal that copulated with a person and an animal that was the object of bestiality,</b> in order to equate the two?
If so, then derive from it that <b>anywhere that there is</b> a disqualification <b>of an animal that copulated with a person there is</b> a disqualification <b>of an animal that was the object of bestiality,</b> and <b>anywhere that there is no</b> disqualification <b>of an animal that copulated with a person there is no</b> disqualification <b>of an animal that was the object of bestiality.</b> Consequently, since birds cannot be the active party in an act of bestiality, the disqualification of an animal that was the object of bestiality is also inapplicable to birds. <b>Or perhaps</b> the disqualification of an animal that was the object of bestiality does apply with regard to birds, as nevertheless <b>a sin was committed with it?</b>
<b>Rabba said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: <b>Rabbi Akiva deems blemished</b> animals <b>fit</b> when the blemish is on the cornea, since such blemishes are fit with regard to bird offerings <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And if it is so</b> that a bird that was the object of bestiality is fit as an offering, then <b>let us also deem fit an animal that was the object of bestiality, since</b> such an offering is <b>fit with regard to birds.</b> From the fact that such animals are not deemed fit, <b>conclude from</b> the mishna that the disqualification of an animal that was the object of bestiality applies to birds as well.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We learn</b> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>as well:</b> A bird <b>that was the object of bestiality, or</b> that was <b>set aside</b> for idol worship, <b>or</b> that <b>was worshipped</b> as a deity, <b>or</b> that was given as <b>payment</b> to a prostitute <b>or</b> as the <b>price</b> of a dog, <b>or</b> that was a <b><i>tumtum</i> or</b> a <b>hermaphrodite,</b> in <b>all of</b> those cases, if its nape was pinched, it <b>renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows an olive-bulk from the carcass <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all unslaughtered carcasses of birds. Since the <i>baraita</i> lists a bird that was the object of bestiality among those disqualified offerings, <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that such a bird is in fact disqualified.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest,</b> says: My father would reject blemished animals from upon the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is Rabbi Ḥanina <b>teaching us?</b> The first <i>tanna</i> already stated that blemished animals shall descend. The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina <b>teaches us an incident,</b> to express that this <i>halakha</i> was not only stated theoretically but applied practically as well. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: Would <b>reject?</b> It means that he would remove blemished animals from the altar <b>in a backhanded manner,</b> i.e., privately rather than publicly, so as not to disgrace the honor of the altar.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to those disqualified offerings that shall not descend from the altar if they ascended it: <b>Just as if it ascended</b> it does not descend, so too, if it descended it does not then ascend. <b>Ulla says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where the fire has not</b> yet <b>taken hold of</b> these offerings. <b>But</b> if <b>the fire has taken hold of</b> these offerings, then even if they descended from the altar <b>they shall ascend.</b>
<b>Rav Mari teaches</b> that the statement of Ulla is referring <b>to the first clause,</b> i.e., to this mishna. <b>Rav Ḥanina of Sura teaches</b> that Ulla is referring <b>to the latter clause,</b> i.e., to the next mishna, which states: <b>The bones, and the tendons, and the horns, and the hooves</b> of a burnt offering; <b>when they are attached</b> to the flesh of the offering <b>they shall ascend</b> upon the altar and be sacrificed with the offering. If <b>they separated</b> from the flesh of the offering <b>they shall not ascend.</b> With regard to this <b>Ulla says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that if they separated from the flesh they shall not ascend <b>only</b> in a case <b>where the fire has not</b> yet <b>taken hold of them. But</b> if <b>the fire has taken hold of them,</b> then even if they separated from the flesh of the offering <b>they shall ascend.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: According to <b>the one who teaches</b> Ulla’s statement, i.e., if the fire has taken hold of them they still ascend the altar, as referring <b>to the latter clause,</b> which discusses items that are not burned on the altar, <b>all the more so</b> will Ulla’s statement apply <b>to the first clause,</b> which discusses items that are burned on the altar but were disqualified. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who teaches</b> Ulla’s statement as referring <b>to the first clause,</b> it applies only to those items that were to be burned on the altar but were disqualified. <b>But</b> with regard <b>to the latter clause</b> it does not apply, since the bones, tendons, and other items mentioned there <b>are not subject to burning</b> at all.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these</b> are the items that <b>if they ascended</b> upon the altar <b>they descend,</b> because they are completely unfit for the altar: <b>The meat of offerings of the most sacred order,</b> i.e., a guilt offering and a sin offering, the meat of which is eaten by priests; <b>and the meat of offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> which is eaten by the owners; <b>and the surplus of the <i>omer</i></b> meal offering brought on the second day of Passover after the handful was removed and burned on the altar; <b>and the two loaves</b> meal offering brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>; <b>and the shewbread; and the remainder of the meal offerings</b> after the handful was removed, which are all eaten by the priests; <b>and the incense</b> that ascended upon the external altar and not the golden altar where it should be burned.
With regard to <b>the wool that is on the heads of the sheep</b> brought as burnt offerings, <b>and the hair that is in the beard of goats</b> that were sacrificed, <b>and the bones, and the tendons, and the horns, and the hooves: When they are attached</b> to the flesh of the offering <b>they shall ascend</b> upon the altar and be sacrificed with the offering, <b>as it is stated: “And the priest shall make the whole smoke</b> on the altar” (Leviticus 1:9). If <b>they separated</b> from the flesh of the offering <b>they shall not ascend, as it is stated: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27), and nothing else.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And the priest shall make the whole smoke on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:9). The term “the whole” serves <b>to include the bones and the tendons and the horns and the hooves</b> among those items that are sacrificed on the altar. One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> if <b>they separated</b> from the flesh of the burnt offering they are sacrificed upon the altar. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27), indicating that only those items and anything attached to them are sacrificed upon the altar.
<b>If</b> one derives the <i>halakha</i> with regard to bones and tendons from the phrase <b>“the flesh and the blood,”</b>

Daf 86a

then one <b>might</b> have thought that a priest must first <b>remove</b> the <b>tendons and bones</b> from an offering <b>and</b> then <b>sacrifice the flesh upon the altar.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And the priest shall make the whole smoke</b> on the altar,” including the tendons and bones. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? If they were <b>attached</b> to the flesh, <b>they shall ascend.</b> If <b>they separated</b> from the flesh, then <b>even</b> if <b>they</b> are already <b>at the top of the altar, they shall descend.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> that you heard that says</b> if <b>they separated they shall descend? It is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And the priest shall make the whole smoke on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:9); the term “the whole” serves <b>to include the bones, and the tendons, and the horns, and the hooves,</b> among those items that are offered on the altar, <b>even</b> if <b>they separated</b> from the flesh of the offering.
<b>But</b> if so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27), which indicates that only the flesh and blood of an offering ascend upon the altar? This verse is necessary <b>to tell you</b> an additional <i>halakha</i>, that <b>you return</b> the <b>consumed</b> flesh of <b>a burnt offering</b> to the fire if it is dislodged from it, <b>but you do not return</b> the <b>consumed tendons and bones</b> if they are dislodged from the fire.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that <b>one verse states: “And the priest shall make the whole smoke on the altar,”</b> which <b>included</b> tendons and bones, <b>and one verse states: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood,”</b> which <b>excluded</b> any part other than the flesh and the blood. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? If they were <b>attached</b> to the flesh, <b>they shall ascend.</b> If <b>they separated</b> from the flesh, then <b>even</b> if <b>they</b> are already <b>on top of the altar, they shall descend.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that items that are not meant for consumption on the altar, such as the bones and tendons, are sacrificed along with the flesh if they are attached to it. But if <b>they separated they shall not ascend. Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that if they separated from the flesh they shall not ascend <b>only when they separated</b> from the offering <b>downward,</b> i.e., away from the altar, whereby they became distanced from the pyre when they were separated. <b>But</b> if they separated from the offering <b>upward,</b> i.e., they became closer to the pyre when they were separated from the offering, <b>they have become closer to consumption</b> and shall ascend. The Gemara asks: <b>And even</b> if <b>they separated,</b> shall they be offered? Doesn’t the mishna state that they shall ascend only if they are still attached to the flesh?
<b>Rabba said: This</b> is what Rabbi Zeira <b>is saying:</b> It was necessary for the Sages to <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i>, that bones or tendons that separated from the flesh of an offering shall not ascend the altar, <b>only where they separated after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of its blood, since at the time that the flesh itself became permitted for the altar through the sprinkling, the bones and tendons were still attached to the flesh and therefore fit to be offered with it. <b>But</b> if <b>they separated</b> from an offering <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of its blood they shall certainly not ascend, as they were already separated from the flesh when it became permitted for the altar. Instead, the <b>sprinkling comes and permits them</b> for any use, just as the hide of a burnt offering is permitted to the priests upon the sprinkling of its blood. In fact, one may <b>even</b> use such tendons or bones <b>to fashion the handles of knives from them.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: Rabba <b>holds in accordance with that which Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> It <b>is stated: “He shall have</b> the hide of the burnt offering that he has offered” (Leviticus 7:8), <b>with regard to a burnt offering, and</b> it <b>is stated:</b> “The priest that makes atonement, <b>he shall have it”</b> (Leviticus 7:7), <b>with regard to a guilt offering.</b> The following verbal analogy is derived from here: <b>Just as</b> after the blood of <b>a guilt offering</b> is presented <b>its bones</b> become <b>permitted</b> to the priest for any use, since only the portions intended for consumption on the altar are sacrificed whereas the rest of the animal is given to the priests, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering, bones</b> that are not attached to the flesh and therefore are not intended for the altar are <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara notes: The phrase “He shall have” is <b>free,</b> i.e., superfluous in its context and therefore available for the purpose of establishing a verbal analogy, and there is a principle that such verbal analogies are not refuted. <b>As, if</b> these words were <b>not</b> considered <b>free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted</b> by saying: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that its meat is permitted</b> and its bones are therefore permitted as well, while the flesh of a burnt offering ascends upon the altar in its entirety. If so, <i>halakhot</i> may not be applied to one based on the other. Consequently, the phrase <b>“He shall have”</b> with regard to a burnt offering is considered as having been <b>written superfluously,</b> as it would have sufficed to state: The hide of the burnt offering that he has offered, to the priest.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raises an objection</b> to the explanation of Rabba from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the bones of sacrificial</b> animals, specifically sin offerings or guilt offerings, which are offerings of the most sacred order that are intended for consumption, <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of their blood, one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, similar to the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the flesh of offerings of the most sacred order before their blood is sprinkled.
<b>After</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of their blood, one who benefits <b>from them</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, as they are not intended for sacrificing upon the altar. <b>But</b> concerning the bones <b>of a burnt offering,</b> one who benefits <b>from them</b> is <b>always</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. This <i>baraita</i> contradicts the opinion of Rabba, who said that if the bones separated from a burnt offering before the sprinkling of its blood, it is permitted to derive benefit from them.
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> meant the following: <b>But</b> concerning the bones <b>of a burnt offering,</b> if <b>they separated before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of its blood and its blood was then sprinkled, then one who benefits <b>from them</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. If they separated <b>after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of its blood, one who benefits <b>from them</b> is <b>always</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
<b>And</b> Rabba <b>disagrees with Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If the bones of a burnt offering <b>separated</b> from its flesh <b>before sprinkling,</b> one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. If they separated <b>after sprinkling,</b> the Sages decreed that one <b>may not benefit</b> from them <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one benefitted from them after the fact, he is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse,</b> since by Torah law they were permitted through the sprinkling of the offering’s blood.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And all of</b> those disqualified offerings with regard to which it was taught (84a) that if they ascended they do not descend, in a case <b>where they were dislodged from upon the altar,</b> the priest <b>does not restore</b> them to the altar. <b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>an ember that was dislodged from upon the altar,</b> the priest <b>does not restore</b> it to the altar. As for <b>limbs</b> of a fit burnt offering <b>that were dislodged from upon the altar,</b> if they were dislodged <b>before midnight,</b> the priest <b>should restore</b> them to the altar <b>and</b> one is liable for <b>misusing them.</b> But if they were dislodged <b>after midnight,</b> the priest <b>does not restore them and</b> one is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misusing them,</b> as one is not liable for misuse of consecrated property after it has fulfilled the purpose for which it was designated.
With regard to unfit items that if they ascended do not descend, <b>just as the altar sanctifies</b> items <b>that are suited to it, so too, the ramp sanctifies</b> items that are suited to it. <b>Just as the altar and the ramp sanctify</b> items <b>that are suited to them, so too, the</b> service <b>vessels sanctify</b> items that are placed in them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that limbs of a fit burnt offering that were dislodged from upon the altar before midnight are returned to the altar, but that if they were dislodged after midnight they are not returned. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the limbs <b>have substance,</b> i.e., they were not yet consumed in their entirety by the fire, then <b>even</b> if they were dislodged <b>after midnight</b> the priest must return them to the fire. <b>If they do not have substance</b> and have been reduced to ash, then <b>even</b> if they were dislodged <b>before midnight</b> the priest does <b>not</b> return them to the altar. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b>

Daf 86b

<b>with regard to hardened</b> limbs that were dried by the fire but have not yet been reduced to ash. The mishna teaches that before midnight, such limbs should be returned to the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived that midnight determines whether or not they shall be returned?
<b>Rav says: One verse states: All night and he shall burn</b> the burnt offering, which indicates that there is a mitzva to burn the limbs of a burnt offering all night, as the verse states: “It is the burnt offering on the pyre upon the altar all night until the morning” (Leviticus 6:2). <b>And one verse states: “All night</b> until the morning…<b>and he shall remove</b> the ashes that the fire has consumed of the burnt offering on the altar, and he shall put them beside the altar” (Leviticus 6:2–3), which indicates that one may remove the ashes at any time during the night, including the limbs of a burnt offering that were already hardened by the fire. How can these texts be reconciled?
Rav explains: <b>Divide</b> the night into two parts: <b>Half of</b> the night, i.e., until midnight, is designated <b>for</b> the mitzva of <b>burning,</b> and during this time, that which is dislodged from the altar shall be returned; <b>and half of</b> the night, i.e., after midnight, is designated <b>for removing.</b>
With regard to Rav’s assertion that one may begin to remove the ashes only after midnight, <b>Rav Kahana raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 20a): <b>Every day</b> the priests would <b>remove</b> the ashes from <b>the altar</b> and place them on the east side of the ramp <b>at the rooster’s crow or close to</b> the time of its crowing, whether <b>before it or after it,</b> as there was no insistence on a precise time. <b>On Yom Kippur</b> they would remove the ashes <b>at midnight. On the Festivals</b> the ashes were removed even earlier, <b>at</b> the end of <b>the first watch.</b> Rav Kahana concludes his objection: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the proper time for removing the ashes <b>by Torah law</b> is <b>from midnight, how do we advance</b> the removal of the ashes on the Festivals, <b>and how do we delay</b> their removal the rest of the year?
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The proper time of the removal of the ashes is based on the following: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> it <b>is stated</b> with regard to the burning of the limbs: <b>“All night”</b> (Leviticus 6:2), <b>don’t I know that</b> he may burn a burnt offering <b>until the morning?</b> If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Until the morning”?</b> It means: <b>Add</b> another <b>morning to the morning of</b> the <b>night.</b> Arise before dawn, as that is the time for the removal of the ashes. Nevertheless, there is no specific hour fixed for performing this removal, and one may remove the ashes from the beginning of the night.
<b>Therefore, every day,</b> performing the removal <b>at the rooster’s crow is sufficient. On Yom Kippur, due to</b> the <b>weakness of the High Priest,</b> who must perform the entire Temple service on that day, they would hasten to remove the ashes <b>from midnight. On the Festivals,</b> during <b>which</b> there are <b>many offerings</b> on account of the masses of <b>Jewish people</b> in Jerusalem on those days, who, in order to offer their sacrifices, would <b>arrive early</b> at the Temple, they would remove the ashes beginning <b>from</b> the end of <b>the first watch, as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> (<i>Yoma</i> 20a): <b>The call of the rooster would not arrive</b> on Festivals <b>until the Temple courtyard was filled with Jews.</b>
§ The Gemara previously explained the mishna as saying that limbs that were hardened by the fire but not entirely consumed are not returned to the altar if they were dislodged from it after midnight, since the mitzva of burning has been performed and the limbs are considered to have been entirely consumed. It <b>was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> engage in a dispute concerning the following matter: In the case of limbs that <b>separated</b> from upon the altar <b>before midnight and</b> were <b>returned after midnight,</b> whereby the mitzva of burning was not completed by midnight, <b>Rabba says:</b>

Daf 87a

The <b>second midnight,</b> i.e., midnight of the following night, <b>renders them consumed,</b> and if they were dislodged from the altar thereafter they are not returned. <b>Rav Ḥisda says: Dawn</b> following the first evening <b>renders them consumed,</b> and if they were dislodged from the altar thereafter they are not returned.
<b>They say</b> in <b>the school of Rav: What is the reasoning of Rav Ḥisda,</b> who says that dawn renders these limbs consumed? It is the following <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>And if midnight, which does not cause</b> the disqualification of being <b>left overnight</b> with regard to limbs that were left off the altar until that time, still <b>causes consumption,</b> i.e., limbs burned on the altar until midnight are considered entirely consumed, then certainly with regard to <b>dawn, which causes</b> the disqualification of being <b>left overnight</b> with regard to limbs that were not left off the altar until that time, <b>isn’t it logical that it causes consumption?</b>
These <i>amora’im</i> also dispute the <i>halakha</i> in a case where the limbs <b>separated</b> from the altar <b>before midnight and were returned</b> to the altar <b>after dawn: Rabba says</b> that the <b>second midnight renders them consumed,</b> and if they separated after this time they are not returned. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> Since these limbs were not returned to the altar by dawn, <b>they are never subject to consumption</b> through the passage of time. Rather, they are returned to the altar and allowed to burn until they are reduced to ash. These two disputes between Rabba and Rav Ḥisda indicate that both agree that limbs not on the altar by midnight are not considered consumed.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this: And who shall say to us that midnight,</b> specifically when the limbs are <b>at the top of the altar, effects for them consumption? Perhaps anywhere that</b> the limbs <b>are found,</b> midnight <b>effects for them consumption.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>They sent from there,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef,</b> i.e., the passing of midnight renders all limbs consumed, regardless of their location at that time.
It <b>was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says:</b> In the case of limbs that <b>separated</b> from upon the altar <b>before midnight and</b> were <b>returned</b> to the altar <b>after midnight,</b> one <b>may not benefit</b> from them <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one benefited from them after the fact he is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, since the mitzva of burning is considered fulfilled after midnight has passed. <b>And bar Kappara also taught:</b> If <b>they separated</b> from upon the altar <b>before midnight and</b> were <b>returned</b> to the altar <b>after midnight,</b> the limbs <b>are removed from</b> being subject to liability for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: And since they sent from there</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef</b> that midnight effects consumption even for those items left off the altar, <b>and Rav Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> this as well, <b>and bar Kappara also teaches</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>, then <b>with regard to what do Rabba and Rav Ḥisda disagree?</b> Abaye <b>said to him:</b> They disagree <b>with regard to fatty</b> limbs, whose consumption is delayed due to their surrounding fat, and consequently midnight may not effect consumption for these limbs.
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma before Rabba:</b> Is the disqualification of <b>being left overnight effective</b> in disqualifying limbs that are situated <b>at the top of the altar</b> at dawn but were not placed on the pyre, <b>or is</b> it <b>not effective</b> in disqualifying limbs that are <b>at the top of the altar</b> but were not placed on the pyre? The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say that</b> the limbs <b>have not descended</b> from the altar, then the <i>halakha</i> should be obvious: <b>Now</b> that with regard to limbs that were <b>left overnight in the Temple courtyard, you said</b> in the mishna (84a) <b>that</b> if they ascended upon the altar <b>they shall not descend,</b> then with regard to limbs left <b>on top of the altar,</b> is it <b>necessary</b> to teach that they shall not descend?
<b>But rather,</b> the dilemma is in a case <b>where</b> they were left overnight on top of the altar and <b>descended</b> from it after dawn. Do <b>we compare</b> limbs left overnight on top of the altar <b>to</b> the <b>Table</b> of the shewbread, and they are therefore returned, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Menaḥot</i> 100a): <b>Even</b> if loaves of shewbread, which are supposed to be replaced every Shabbat, remained <b>on the Table many days</b> beyond Shabbat, there is <b>nothing</b> wrong <b>with that,</b> and the loaves are not disqualified by being left overnight. <b>Or perhaps we compare</b> the limbs <b>to</b> flesh left on the <b>ground</b> of the Temple courtyard, which is disqualified when left there until dawn, and they are not returned.
Rabba <b>said to him: There is no</b> disqualification of limbs that are <b>left overnight at the top of the altar.</b> The Gemara asks: Did Rava <b>accept</b> this response <b>from</b> Rabba <b>or not?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that <b>which was stated:</b> With regard to <b>limbs that were left overnight in the Temple courtyard,</b> the priest may place them upon the altar to <b>burn</b> them <b>all night</b> long provided that they are placed there before dawn. With regard to a limb that was <b>left overnight at the top of the altar,</b> the priest may <b>burn</b> it <b>forever,</b> i.e., no matter how much time has passed.
With regard to limbs that were left overnight on top of the altar and then <b>descended</b> from it, <b>Rabba says</b> that <b>they shall ascend,</b> while <b>Rava says</b> that <b>they shall not ascend. Conclude from it</b> that Rava <b>did not accept</b> the response <b>from</b> Rabba, as he holds here that limbs are disqualified when left overnight on top of the altar. The Gemara confirms: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Just as the altar sanctifies</b> items, so too, the ramp and the service vessels sanctify items. With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>the Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “Whatever <b>touches the altar</b> shall be sacred” (Exodus 29:37). From here <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <b>altar</b> sanctifies items. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the <b>ramp</b> sanctifies items as well? <b>The verse states:</b> “And you shall anoint…<b>the altar [<i>et hamizbe’aḥ</i>]”</b> (Exodus 40:10), and the addition of the word <i>et</i> serves to include the ramp. With regard to <b>service vessels, from where</b> is it derived that they sanctify items? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to them: <b>“Whatever touches them shall be sacred”</b> (Exodus 30:29).
<b>Reish Lakish raises a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>whether service vessels sanctify disqualified</b> items? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: You learned</b> in the mishna that <b>just as the altar and the ramp sanctify</b> items <b>that are suited to them</b> even if those items are disqualified, <b>so too,</b> the service <b>vessels sanctify</b> items placed in them.
Reish Lakish <b>said to him:</b> The mishna indicates that service vessels sanctify that which is placed in them in the sense that they may no longer be redeemed even if they become disqualified. <b>I raise the dilemma</b> with regard to whether service vessels sanctify disqualified items such that they may be <b>sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: <b>This also we learn</b> in a mishna (84a):

Daf 87b

An offering <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>collected and</b> then <b>sprinkled its blood</b> shall not descend from the altar if it ascended. <b>What, is it not</b> that the mishna means <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood <b>and</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>sprinkled</b> it as well, which disqualifies it from ascending the altar? But if the collection alone was performed by people unfit for performing the Temple service, although the offering becomes disqualified, those fit to perform the Temple service may sprinkle the blood and sacrifice the offering <i>ab initio</i>. The reason, apparently, is that service vessels sanctify disqualified blood such that it may be sprinkled <i>ab initio</i>.
Reish Lakish rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> the mishna may be referring to two independent cases, i.e., <b>that</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>collected</b> the blood, <b>or that</b> people <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service <b>sprinkled</b> the blood after it was collected by people who were fit for performing the Temple service. Accordingly, the mishna teaches only that if such offerings ascended the altar they shall not descend after the fact, but service vessels do not sanctify disqualified items such that they are offered <i>ab initio</i>.
§ The Gemara raises a dilemma: Is the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>altar considered as</b> the <b>altar</b> itself, whereby items that enter this airspace shall not descend from the altar, <b>or</b> is it <b>not</b> considered like the altar? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna, which states: <b>Just as the altar sanctifies</b> items, <b>so too,</b> the <b>ramp sanctifies</b> items, and if they ascended upon it they shall be sacrificed upon the altar and shall not descend.
<b>And if you say</b> that the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>altar</b> is <b>not considered as</b> the <b>altar</b> itself, then the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>ramp as well</b> should <b>not</b> be <b>considered as the ramp.</b> If so, <b>how</b> can one <b>elevate</b> the disqualified limbs of an offering <b>from</b> the <b>ramp to</b> the <b>altar?</b> The moment one elevates a limb from upon the ramp, <b>it is</b> considered to have <b>descended</b> from the ramp, and all disqualified items that descended shall not be returned.
The Gemara responds: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>drags</b> the offering up the ramp, but it never enters its airspace. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> even if he drags it up the ramp, he must still lift it, as <b>there is a space between</b> the <b>ramp and the altar.</b> The Gemara responds: Since this gap is small, only a minority of the limb of an offering will be located over the gap as it passes from the ramp to the altar. Therefore, when <b>a majority of</b> the limb is <b>on the ramp,</b> the minority situated above the gap is considered <b>as</b> if it is on <b>the ramp.</b> Once <b>a majority of</b> the limb is <b>on the altar,</b> the minority situated above the gap is considered <b>as</b> if it is on <b>the altar.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>resolve from this</b> mishna <b>the dilemma that was raised by Rami bar Ḥama: Is there a connection of</b> limbs that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar, i.e., is an offering considered a unit such that even those parts that do not ascend the altar shall be considered as if they are upon it, <b>or</b> is there <b>not,</b> and each part is considered independent? Based on the previous answer, <b>resolve</b> the dilemma by saying <b>that there is a connection</b> of limbs. The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as one may indeed <b>resolve</b> Rami bar Ḥama’s dilemma from here.
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan objects to</b> the assumption that the airspace above the altar is considered as the altar itself: <b>But if you say</b> that the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>altar</b> is <b>considered as</b> the <b>altar</b> itself, then with regard to <b>a bird burnt offering that</b> one <b>disqualified by</b> having the <b>intention</b> to burn it beyond its designated time, i.e., the day after it was pinched, <b>how can you find</b> the circumstances for such a disqualification to take effect?
One’s intent to burn an offering beyond its designated time disqualifies it only when he intended to burn it during a time that he may not do so. Since a bird burnt offering is pinched in the airspace above the altar, the <b>altar</b> has already <b>accepted it.</b> Therefore, even if one delayed burning it until the next day, it does not descend from the altar, like all other offerings that are disqualified by being left overnight.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi objects to</b> the objection raised by Rava bar Rav Ḥanan: <b>Why</b> is it <b>not</b> possible for a bird burnt offering to be disqualified through the intention to burn it beyond its designated time? <b>You find it</b> in a case <b>where he says: I am hereby pinching it in order to take it down</b> from the altar <b>tomorrow and</b> thereafter <b>sacrifice it and burn it.</b> If he takes it down from the altar the next day, he may not subsequently return it there for burning, as all disqualified items that have descended from the altar shall not be returned to it. Accordingly, even if the airspace above the altar is considered as the altar itself, a bird burnt offering can still be disqualified with such intention.
The Gemara questions the objection of Rav Shimi bar Ashi: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who says</b> that the disqualification of <b>being left overnight</b> is <b>effective</b> even when the offering is <b>at the top of the altar.</b> Accordingly, if he were to take the bird burnt offering down from the altar the next day, he may not restore it to the altar for burning. <b>But</b> this is difficult <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba, who says:</b> The disqualification of <b>being left overnight</b> is <b>not effective</b> when the offering is <b>at the top of the altar,</b> and therefore even if the next day he removed the bird burnt offering from the altar, he must return it there to burn it, as it has not been disqualified. If so, <b>his intention is not</b> significant, i.e., he does not disqualify a bird burnt offering with such intention.
Rav Shimi bar Ashi responds: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba as well, you find</b> a case of a bird burnt offering that is disqualified due to one’s intention, <b>such as where he says: I am hereby pinch-ing it in order to take it down</b> from the altar <b>before dawn and</b> to then <b>sacrifice it after dawn.</b> In such a case, where the offering is removed from the altar before dawn, even Rabba would agree that one’s intention renders a bird burnt offering disqualified by being left overnight.
Rav Shimi bar Ashi adds: Irrespective of the validity of the proof of Rava bar Rav Ḥanan, <b>in any event, resolve</b> the issue <b>to this side,</b> i.e., in favor of the claim <b>that</b> the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>altar</b> is <b>considered as</b> the <b>altar</b> itself. <b>As if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that the <b>airspace</b> above the <b>altar</b> is <b>not considered as</b> the <b>altar,</b>

Daf 88a

then with regard to the case of <b>a disqualified bird sin offering</b> that was pinched at the top of the altar, <b>how</b> does one <b>sprinkle from its blood</b> on the wall of the altar? When the priest raises the bird in his hand in order to sprinkle its blood, the bird <b>is</b> considered to have <b>descended</b> from upon the altar and he cannot sprinkle its blood, as the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all disqualified items is that once they have descended from upon the altar they shall not ascend. Likewise, concerning the blood of <b>other</b> offerings that were <b>disqualified</b> that ascended upon the altar, <b>how</b> does he <b>sprinkle from their blood,</b> since it is sprinkled from the airspace above the altar? Rather, it must be that the airspace above the altar is considered as the altar.
The Gemara rejects this proof: It is possible that in such cases one does not sprinkle the blood in its normal fashion, but in such a manner <b>that he presses it</b> against the wall of the altar immediately without the blood passing through the air. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Is this</b> considered <b>sprinkling?</b> It <b>is squeezing,</b> an act that is performed for a bird burnt offering, not for a bird sin offering. Likewise, if one sprinkles the blood of other disqualified offerings in this manner, is <b>this sprinkling? It is pouring.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to a disqualified bird burnt offering, is <b>the manner of sprinkling in such</b> a fashion? And in the case of other disqualified offerings, is <b>the manner of sprinkling in such</b> a fashion? It is not. Rather, the airspace above the altar must be considered as the altar.
<b>Rav Ashi said: If</b> the question concerns a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>held</b> the blood or limbs while standing <b>at the top of the altar,</b> they would <b>indeed</b> be considered as having ascended the altar, and shall not descend from it. But <b>when</b> the dilemma was <b>stated</b> with regard to the airspace above the altar, it was with regard to an instance <b>where he suspended them with a pole</b> above the altar, while he himself stood on the floor of the Temple courtyard. <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in such a case? The Gemara responds that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna elaborates on the <i>halakha</i> taught in the previous mishna (86a) that service vessels sanctify items placed in them. <b>The</b> service <b>vessels</b> used for <b>liquids sanctify</b> only <b>liquids</b> used in the service, <b>and</b> the service vessels that serve as <b>dry measures sanctify</b> only <b>dry</b> items used in the service. <b>The</b> service <b>vessels</b> used for <b>liquids do not sanctify dry</b> items, <b>and</b> the service vessels used for <b>dry</b> items <b>do not sanctify liquids.</b> With regard to <b>sacred vessels that were perforated, if one</b> continues to <b>utilize them</b> for a use <b>similar to the use for which they would utilize them</b> previously when <b>they</b> were <b>whole, they</b> continue to <b>sanctify</b> their contents. <b>And if not, they do not sanctify</b> their contents. <b>And all of</b> these vessels <b>sanctify</b> items <b>only</b> when they are <b>in the sacred</b> area, i.e., the Temple courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement of the mishna that the vessels used for liquids do not sanctify dry items, <b>Shmuel says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>measures</b> used for liquids, i.e., wine or oil. <b>But cups,</b> which are used for collecting the blood of offerings, <b>sanctify</b> dry items as well, <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse: “One silver cup of seventy shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary; <b>both of them full of fine flour</b> mingled with oil for a meal offering” (Numbers 7:13), indicating that the cups were also fashioned for use with flour, a dry item.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina:</b> The <b>meal offering</b> of the verse <b>is</b> also considered <b>a liquid,</b> as it is mixed with oil, and one cannot derive from it the <i>halakha</i> with regard to items that are entirely dry. Ravina <b>said to him:</b> The verse cited by Shmuel <b>was only necessary to</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the dry</b> portions <b>of</b> a meal offering, teaching that even flour that remained dry because it did not get thoroughly mixed with the oil is sanctified by the cups as well. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead: <b>A meal offering,</b> even though it is mixed with oil, is, <b>in comparison to blood, considered as a dry</b> item. Accordingly, one can derive from the verse that the cups sanctify all dry items.
Additionally, <b>Shmuel says: Service vessels sanctify</b> items <b>only</b> when the vessels are <b>whole,</b> i.e., they do not have a hole; <b>they sanctify only full</b> measures, i.e., when they contain a measurement fit for offering; and <b>they sanctify</b> items <b>only from within them</b> and not items that merely touched their exterior. <b>And some say</b> there is another version of the statement of Shmuel: Service vessels <b>sanctify</b> items <b>only</b> when the vessels are <b>whole, and</b> when they contain <b>full</b> measures, <b>and from inside.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> these two versions? The Gemara responds: The difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to <b>heaping measures.</b> According to the first version, that service vessels sanctify only items that are within them, nothing that overflows is included. The Gemara notes that it <b>was taught in a <i>baraita</i></b> in accordance with both versions: Service vessels <b>sanctify</b> items <b>only</b> when they are <b>whole, and</b> only <b>full</b> measurements, <b>and from within them, and inside.</b>
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that service vessels sanctify only full measurements, <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only when</b> the priest’s initial <b>intention</b> was <b>not to add</b> to that which was already placed inside the vessel. <b>But</b> if <b>his</b> initial <b>intention</b> was <b>to add,</b> then <b>each initial</b> amount placed in the vessel becomes <b>sacred,</b> no matter how small.
<b>This</b> distinction <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that service vessels sanctify <b>full</b> measurements, <b>full</b> measurements are <b>nothing other than whole</b> measurements. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: When</b> are full measurements whole ones? It is <b>at a time that</b> the priest’s <b>intention</b> was <b>not to add. But</b> if <b>his intention</b> was <b>to add, each initial</b> amount is <b>sacred.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>the</b> service <b>vessels</b> used for <b>liquids do not sanctify</b> dry items. With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rav says, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Asi</b> says: The service vessels used for liquids <b>do not sanctify</b> dry items to permit them <b>for sacrifice</b> upon the altar, <b>but they sanctify</b> dry items in order for the items <b>to be disqualified</b> by them, i.e., dry items placed in such vessels may be disqualified by that which disqualifies only sanctified items, e.g., if they are touched by one who immersed that day, or if they emerged from the Temple courtyard.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who teach this</b> statement <b>with regard to this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>One may not bring meal offerings, or libations, or meal offerings</b> accompanying <b>an animal, or first fruits, from a mixture</b> containing <i>teruma</i>, since that which may not be consumed by all Jews may not be used for an offering. <b>And needless to say,</b> one may not bring these items <b>from</b> the fruit of a tree that is <b><i>orla</i>,</b> i.e., a tree during the first three years after its planting, from which it is prohibited to eat, <b>or</b> from <b>diverse kinds</b> sown <b>in a vineyard,</b> both of which are prohibited for consumption to priests as well. <b>And if he brought</b> an offering from them, it is <b>not sanctified.</b> With regard to this issue, <b>Rav says, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Asi</b> says: It is <b>not sanctified for sacrifice</b> upon the altar, <b>but</b> it is <b>sanctified</b> in order <b>to be disqualified.</b>
§ With regard to perforated vessels, <b>the Sages taught:</b> In the case of <b>sacred vessels that were perforated, one may not melt them</b> in order to seal the perforation, <b>and one may not melt lead into them</b> for such a purpose. If the vessels <b>were damaged, one may not repair them.</b> Concerning <b>a knife that was damaged, one may not sharpen</b> the spot of <b>its damage.</b> If the blade <b>separated</b> from the handle, <b>one may not restore it. Abba Shaul says: There was</b> a certain <b>knife in the Temple</b> whose metal was soft and easily damaged, such that when used it would often <b>render</b> animals <b>prohibited,</b> thereby disqualifying them. Accordingly, the <b>priests voted concerning it, and</b> elected to <b>hide it.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: Priestly vestments are not fashioned</b> by <b>needlework,</b> i.e., by stitching various parts together, but <b>rather</b> through <b>woven work,</b> whereby the entire garment is initially woven into one entity, <b>as it is stated: “Woven work”</b> (Exodus 28:32). If the garments <b>were soiled one may not launder</b> them, <b>neither with natron nor with soap,</b> two common detergents.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> may it be inferred from this that <b>with water one may launder</b> the priestly vestments? <b>Abaye said: This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the dirtied garments have only <b>reached</b> the point where laundering them <b>with water</b> alone would suffice, <b>one may launder them with natron and soap,</b> as they are not considered soiled.

Daf 88b

But if the garments became so dirty that they <b>reached</b> a point that laundering them would require the use of <b>natron or soap,</b> then <b>one may not launder</b> them, <b>even with water. And some say: One may not launder</b> the priestly vestments <b>at all,</b> even if laundering them with water would suffice, <b>because there is no poverty in a place of wealth,</b> i.e., only priestly vestments that were clean as new should be worn, as is befitting the Temple service, and those that were laundered should not be worn.
§ With regard to the priestly vestments, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The robe</b> of the High Priest <b>was</b> sewn <b>entirely of sky-blue wool, as it is stated: “And he made the robe of the ephod</b> of woven work, <b>all of sky-blue wool”</b> (Exodus 39:22). With regard to <b>its skirts,</b> concerning which it states: “And they made upon the skirts of the robe pomegranates of sky blue, and purple, and scarlet, twined” (Exodus 39:24), <b>how</b> were they fashioned? The tailor <b>brings sky-blue wool, and purple wool, and scarlet wool,</b> which are <b>twined</b> together, <b>and fashions them</b> to appear <b>as pomegranates that have not opened their mouths,</b> i.e., they are sewn in the appearance of pomegranates that are not yet ripe enough for the crown on top to open, <b>and as</b> the <b>cones [<i>konaot</i>] of</b> the <b>helmets [<i>kenasot</i>] that</b> are found <b>on the heads of children.</b>
<b>And</b> in order to fulfill that which is stated: “And they made bells of pure gold, and put the bells between the pomegranates” (Exodus 39:25), he <b>brings seventy-two bells,</b> i.e., the outer part of bells, made from gold, <b>that</b> contain <b>inside them seventy-two bell clappers, and he suspends</b> them <b>on</b> the skirts: <b>Thirty-six</b> of each, i.e., pomegranates and bells, <b>on this side</b> of the robe, <b>and thirty-six</b> of each <b>on that side,</b> as the verse states: “A bell and a pomegranate, a bell and a pomegranate, upon the skirts of the robe around it” (Exodus 39:26). <b>Rabbi Dosa says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda: There were thirty-six</b> bells suspended around the skirt, <b>eighteen from this side and eighteen from that side.</b>
<b>Rabbi Inini bar Sason says: Just as</b> there is <b>a disagreement here</b> between <i>tanna’im</i> with regard to the total number of bells suspended around the skirt of the robe of the High Priest, <b>so</b> is there <b>a disagreement</b> between <i>tanna’im</i> <b>with regard to</b> the total number of <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 1:4): With regard to the total number of <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks, Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas says:</b> There are <b>thirty-six,</b> while <b>Akavya ben Mahalalel says:</b> There are <b>seventy-two.</b>
§ The Gemara cites another statement of this sage: <b>And Rabbi Inini bar Sason says: Why</b> was <b>the passage</b> in the Torah that discusses <b>offerings</b> (Leviticus, chapters 1–7) <b>juxtaposed to the passage</b> that discusses the <b>priestly vestments</b> (Leviticus, chapter 8)? It was juxtaposed <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as offerings effect atonement, so too, priestly vestments effect atonement.</b>
The <b>tunic atones for bloodshed, as it is stated</b> with regard to the brothers of Joseph after they plotted to kill him: <b>“And they killed a goat, and dipped the tunic in the blood”</b> (Genesis 37:31). The <b>trousers atone for forbidden sexual relations, as it is stated</b> with regard to fashioning the priestly vestments: <b>“And you shall make them linen trousers to cover the flesh of their nakedness”</b> (Exodus 28:42). The <b>mitre atones for the arrogant. From where</b> is this derived? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> It is logical that <b>an item</b> that is placed <b>at an elevation,</b> i.e., on the head of a priest, <b>shall come and atone for</b> the sin of <b>an elevated</b> heart.
Rabbi Inini bar Sason continues: The <b>belt atones for thought of the heart.</b> The Gemara elaborates: The belt atones for the sins occurring <b>where it is</b> situated, i.e., over the heart. The <b>breastplate</b> of the High Priest <b>atones for</b> improper <b>judgments, as it is stated: “And you shall make a breastplate of judgment”</b> (Exodus 28:15). The <b>ephod</b> of the High Priest <b>atones for idol worship, as it is stated:</b> “And <b>without ephod or teraphim”</b> (Hosea 3:4), meaning that when there is no ephod, the sin of teraphim, i.e., idol worship, is found. Therefore, it may be inferred that if there is an ephod, there is no sin of idol worship.
The <b>robe</b> of the High Priest <b>atones for malicious speech. From where</b> is this known? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> It is logical that <b>an item that</b> produces <b>sound,</b> i.e., the robe, which has bells, <b>shall come and atone for an evil sound. And</b> the <b>frontplate</b> of the High Priest <b>atones for brazenness.</b> This is derived from the fact that <b>with regard to the frontplate it is written: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead”</b> (Exodus 28:38), <b>and with regard to brazenness it is written: “And you had a harlot’s forehead”</b> (Jeremiah 3:3).
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> that the priestly vestments atone for these sins? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi say:</b> There are <b>two matters</b> that <b>we do not find for them an atonement with offerings, but we find for them an atonement from another place, and they are: Bloodshed and malicious speech.</b>
With regard to <b>bloodshed,</b> its atonement comes <b>from</b> the <b>heifer whose neck is broken.</b> This is referring to a case where a murdered body is found but the identity of the murderer is not known. In such an instance, the Torah mandates that the neck of a heifer must be broken as an atonement for the murder. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>malicious speech,</b> its atonement comes <b>from incense, as Rav Ḥananya teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>the incense effects atonement? As it is stated</b> after the Israelites spoke slanderously against Moses and Aaron and a plague was sent against them: <b>“And he put on the incense, and made atonement for the people”</b> (Numbers 17:12).
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> similarly, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael teaches: For what does incense effect atonement?</b> It effects atonement <b>for malicious speech,</b> in order that <b>an item that</b> is offered <b>in private,</b> i.e., the incense, which is offered by a priest acting alone, <b>shall come and atone for an action</b> generally occurring in <b>private,</b> i.e., malicious speech.
Accordingly, there is <b>a difficulty</b> between that which is stated with regard to <b>malicious speech and</b> that which is stated with regard to <b>malicious speech,</b> as according to Rabbi Inini bar Sason the robe atones for malicious speech, whereas according to the <i>baraita</i> it is only the incense that effects atonement for that transgression. Likewise, there is <b>a difficulty</b> between that which is stated with regard to <b>bloodshed and</b> that which is stated with regard to <b>bloodshed,</b> as according to Rabbi Inini bar Sason the tunic effects atonement for bloodshed, whereas according to the <i>baraita</i> only the heifer whose neck is broken effects atonement for it.
The Gemara answers: With regard to bloodshed, it is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this,</b> the tunic, effects atonement for bloodshed in an instance <b>where it is known who killed</b> the victim, and <b>this,</b> the heifer, effects atonement in an instance <b>where it is not known who killed</b> the victim. The Gemara challenges: <b>If it is known who killed</b> the victim, that man <b>is deserving of death,</b> and there is no atonement for the community otherwise, as it is stated: “And no atonement can be made for the land for the blood that is shed within it, but by the blood of him that shed it” (Numbers 35:33). The Gemara responds: It is referring to a case where he murdered <b>intentionally but</b> witnesses <b>did not forewarn him</b> of the consequences of committing murder. Therefore, the court may not execute him, as no earthly punishment may be administered without forewarning.
<b>And</b> with regard to the contradiction between that which is stated with regard to <b>malicious speech and</b> that which is stated with regard to <b>malicious speech,</b> it is <b>also not difficult. This,</b> the incense, effects atonement for malicious speech spoken <b>in private,</b> whereas <b>this,</b> the robe, on which the bells that produce noise are placed, effects atonement for malicious speech spoken <b>in public.</b>

Daf 89a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any</b> offering <b>that is</b> more <b>frequent than another precedes the other</b> offering. Therefore, <b>the daily offerings precede the additional offerings,</b> which are sacrificed only on certain days. When Shabbat and the New Moon coincide, the <b>additional Shabbat offerings precede</b> the <b>additional New Moon offerings.</b> Likewise, the <b>additional New Moon offerings precede</b> the <b>additional New Year offerings.</b> The mishna cites the source for the principle that the frequent precedes the less frequent: <b>As it is stated</b> with regard to the additional offerings of the first day of Passover: <b>“Besides the burnt offering of the morning, which is for a daily burnt offering, you shall offer these”</b> (Numbers 28:23). The verse indicates that the daily offering is sacrificed first, and then the additional offerings are sacrificed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive the principle that the frequent precedes the less frequent? The Gemara expresses puzzlement at this question: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? One must say <b>that the reason is stated</b> in the mishna, which says that it is derived from the verse: <b>“Besides the burnt offering of the morning.”</b> The Gemara explains: If that verse is the only source, it could be claimed that <b>perhaps it is</b> only the <b>daily offerings that precede</b> the <b>additional offerings, because they are</b> far more <b>frequent,</b> as they are sacrificed daily. With regard to the precedence of a relatively frequent <b>additional offering over</b> a relatively less frequent <b>additional offering,</b> the question arises: <b>From where do we</b> derive this?
<b>Rabbi Ile’a said</b> that it is derived from the fact <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to the additional offerings of Passover: <b>“Like these you shall offer daily, for seven days”</b> (Numbers 28:24). This verse, which immediately follows the one cited previously, indicates that the principle that governs <b>these</b> additional offerings shall be <b>like</b> the principle governing <b>those</b> daily offerings and additional offerings mentioned previously, i.e., the more frequent precedes the less frequent.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But that</b> verse <b>is required to</b> teach <b>its own</b> <i>halakha</i>, that the additional offerings of the first day of Passover recur on each day of Passover. The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let</b> the verse <b>write: These you shall offer daily.</b> Since the Torah writes: “Like these,” both the <i>halakha</i> that these additional offerings are brought on each day of Passover and the principle concerning precedence can be derived from this verse.
