The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>If</b> the verse <b>had written</b> only: <b>These you shall offer daily for the seven days, I would say</b> that <b>these</b> offerings mentioned in the previous verse are sacrificed in total, over <b>the seven days.</b> Therefore, the Torah writes: “Like these,” to teach that they are all sacrificed each day. The Gemara counters: That interpretation is not possible, as the phrase: “You shall offer <b>daily,” is written</b> in the verse, which indicates that these offerings are sacrificed on each of the seven days.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And still,</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>these</b> specific offerings are required <b>for the</b> first <b>day; but</b> with regard to the <b>other days, I do not know how many</b> offerings are to be sacrificed. Therefore, the term “like these” is needed to teach this, and cannot be used for the principle that relatively frequent additional offerings precede relatively less frequent additional offerings. The Gemara answers: That interpretation is also not possible, as <b>the verse states: “You shall offer [<i>ta’asu</i>],”</b> indicating <b>that all the</b> sacrificial <b>rites [<i>asiyyot</i>]</b> on all the days of Passover <b>should be equal.</b> Therefore, the term “like these” is in fact superfluous and can be cited as the source of the principle of precedence.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The application of the principle of precedence to all frequent offerings can be derived <b>from the verse itself,</b> cited in the mishna. The reason is that <b>if so,</b> that only the daily offering precedes less frequent offerings, <b>let the verse say</b> merely: <b>“Besides the burnt offering of the morning,” and remain silent</b> from the rest of the verse. <b>Why do I</b> need the additional phrase: <b>“Which is for a daily burnt offering”?</b> This serves <b>to say that this</b> offering <b>that is</b> more <b>frequent,</b> i.e., any more frequent offering, <b>should precede</b> any less frequent offering.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any</b> offering <b>that is</b> more <b>sacred than another precedes the other</b> offering. The mishna elaborates: If there is blood of a sin offering and blood of a burnt offering to be presented, <b>the blood of the sin offering precedes the blood of the burnt offering because it effects acceptance,</b> i.e., atonement, for severe transgressions punishable by <i>karet</i>. Likewise, if there are limbs of a burnt offering and portions of a sin offering to be burned on the altar, the burning of <b>the limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering precedes the portions of</b> the <b>sin offering, because</b> the burnt offering <b>is entirely</b> burned <b>in the flames</b> on the altar, whereas only part of the sin offering is burned.
Similarly, although both effect atonement, <b>a sin offering precedes a guilt offering due to</b> the fact <b>that its blood is placed on</b> the <b>four corners</b> of the altar and the remnants of its blood are poured <b>on the base</b> of the altar, whereas the blood of the guilt offering is sprinkled on only two corners of the altar. <b>A guilt offering precedes a thanks offering and</b> the <b>nazirite’s ram due to</b> the fact <b>that it is an offering of the most sacred order,</b> and the others are offerings of lesser sanctity. <b>A thanks offering and a nazirite’s ram precede a peace offering due to</b> the fact <b>that they are eaten for one day,</b> like offerings of the most sacred order, whereas a peace offering is eaten for two days, <b>and</b> the thanks offering and nazirite’s ram <b>require loaves</b> to be brought with them, four types with the thanks offering and two types with the nazirite’s ram.
Sacrifice of <b>the peace offering precedes</b> sacrifice of <b>the firstborn</b> offering <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the peace offering <b>requires placing</b> the blood on the altar, in the form of two placements that are <b>four, and placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>and libations, and the wavings of</b> the <b>breast and the thigh</b> by the priest and the owner; none of which is required for the firstborn offering. <b>The firstborn</b> offering <b>precedes the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>because it is sanctified from</b> the <b>womb,</b> i.e., unlike the animal tithe offering it does not require consecration, <b>and it is eaten by the priests,</b> whereas everyone may partake of the animal tithe offering.
<b>The</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>precedes bird</b> offerings <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it</b> requires <b>slaughtering,</b> whereas the bird’s nape is pinched; <b>and there are</b> two elements <b>of</b> the animal tithe offering that have the status of <b>offerings of the most sacred order: Its blood</b> that is presented on the altar <b>and its portions</b> that are burned on the altar, whereas with regard to bird offerings only the blood is presented on the altar. <b>The bird</b> offerings <b>precede meal offerings due to</b> the fact <b>that they are types</b> whose <b>blood</b> is presented, and atonement is effected by the blood. The <b>meal offering of a sinner precedes a voluntary meal offering due to</b> the fact <b>that it comes</b> to atone <b>for a sin.</b> For the same reason the sacrifice of <b>the bird sin offering precedes</b> the sacrifice of <b>the bird burnt offering, and likewise with regard to its consecration,</b> the sin offering takes precedence.

Daf 89b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the placement of the blood of a sin offering precedes the sprinkling of the blood of a burnt offering, whereas the burning of the limbs of a burnt offering precedes the burning of the portions of a sin offering. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara answers: This is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> discussing a verse about the consecration of the Levites: “Then let them take a young bull, and its meal offering, fine flour mingled with oil; <b>and a second young bull you shall take for a sin offering”</b> (Numbers 8:8).
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>If</b> this verse <b>comes to teach that they are two</b> bulls, this is superfluous, as it <b>is already stated: “And offer the one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering”</b> (Numbers 8:12). <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “And a second young bull you shall take for a sin offering”? As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought <b>that</b> the <b>sin offering should precede all</b> the <b>rites of</b> the <b>burnt offering,</b> therefore <b>the verse states: “And a second young bull you shall take for a sin offering,”</b> which indicates that the sin offering actually comes second to the burnt offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> the verse had stated only that the sin offering is the <b>second bull,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the <b>burnt offering precedes</b> the <b>sin offering with regard to all its rites.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And offer the one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering,”</b> indicating that the sin offering precedes the burnt offering. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> verses be reconciled? The placement of the <b>blood of</b> the <b>sin offering precedes</b> the sprinkling of the <b>blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering because it effects acceptance,</b> whereas the burnt offering does not effect atonement. And burning the <b>limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering</b> on the altar precedes burning the portions of the sin offering, in fulfillment of the phrase: “And a second young bull you shall take for a sin offering.”
The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> do all four placements of the blood of the sin offering precede the sprinkling of the blood of the burnt offering? <b>Let</b> only the <b>first placement</b> of blood, <b>which effects atonement, take precedence, and those</b> other placements should <b>not</b> come before the sprinkling of the blood of the burnt offering.
<b>Ravina said:</b> In the verse <b>here, we are dealing with</b> the <b>sin offering</b> brought by <b>the Levites</b> for their consecration. <b>And even though</b> it does not effect atonement and <b>is</b> therefore <b>comparable to a burnt offering, the Merciful One states</b> that the sin offering <b>precedes</b> the burnt offering with regard to the presentation of the blood. This indicates that in general, all four placements of the blood of a sin offering precede the sprinkling of the blood of the burnt offering, despite the fact that only the first placement effects atonement. <b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say</b> there is another answer: <b>Once</b> the priest <b>commenced with the placements</b> of the blood of the sin offering, he <b>completes</b> all of them before sprinkling the blood of the burnt offering.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>blood of a sin offering and limbs of a burnt offering</b> to be sacrificed, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does the <b>blood of</b> the <b>sin offering take precedence, due to</b> the fact <b>that it effects acceptance? Or perhaps</b> the <b>limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering take precedence, due to</b> the fact <b>that they are entirely</b> burned <b>in the flames</b> of the altar.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the mishna teaches that the <b>blood of a sin offering precedes</b> the <b>blood of a burnt offering.</b> One can infer from this that the blood of the sin offering does not precede all elements of the burnt offering; it is only <b>with regard to the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering that it takes precedence,</b> whereas it does <b>not take precedence with regard to the limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering.</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>On the contrary,</b> the opposite conclusion can be inferred <b>from the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which teaches that <b>limbs of a burnt offering precede the portions of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> consumed on the altar. This indicates that <b>it is</b> only <b>with regard to the portions of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> consumed on the altar <b>that</b> the limbs of the burnt offering <b>take precedence,</b> but they do <b>not take precedence with regard to the blood of</b> the <b>sin offering.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather, no</b> inference is <b>to be learned from this</b> mishna concerning this matter.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>blood of a burnt offering</b> to be sprinkled <b>and portions of a sin offering</b> to be burned, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does <b>the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering take precedence, as it comes from</b> an offering that is burned in its <b>entirety</b> on the altar? <b>Or perhaps the portions of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> to be burned <b>take precedence because they come from</b> an offering that <b>effects atonement.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the mishna teaches that <b>the blood of</b> the <b>sin offering precedes the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering.</b> One can infer from this that <b>it</b> is only <b>the blood of</b> the <b>sin offering that precedes the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering, but the portions</b> of the <b>sin offering</b> to be burned do <b>not</b> take precedence.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>On the contrary,</b> the opposite conclusion can be inferred <b>from the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which teaches that <b>the limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering precede</b> the <b>portions of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> to be consumed on the altar. This indicates that <b>it is</b> only <b>the limbs of</b> the <b>burnt offering that precede the portions of</b> the <b>sin offering</b> to be burned, <b>but the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering</b> does <b>not.</b> The Gemara again concludes: <b>Rather, no</b> inference is <b>to be learned from this</b> mishna concerning this dilemma.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>blood of a burnt offering and blood of a guilt offering</b> to be sprinkled on the altar, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does the <b>blood of the burnt offering take precedence, as it comes from</b> an offering that is burned in its <b>entirety</b> on the altar? <b>Or perhaps the blood of a guilt offering takes precedence, as it effects atonement.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the mishna teaches that <b>the blood of</b> the <b>sin offering precedes the blood of</b> the <b>burnt offering.</b> One can infer from here: <b>But</b> the <b>blood of a guilt offering</b> does <b>not</b> precede the blood of a burnt offering.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>By right</b> the mishna <b>should have taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>blood of a guilt offering.</b> One could then have inferred that the blood of a sin offering, which takes precedence over the blood of a guilt offering, also precedes blood of a burnt offering. <b>But since</b> the mishna <b>wants to teach the latter clause:</b> The burning of <b>the limbs of a burnt offering precedes the portions of a sin offering,</b> it also mentions a sin offering in the former clause.
The Gemara explains why the latter clause had to mention a sin offering rather than a guilt offering: <b>As, had</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> this principle of the latter clause with regard <b>to the portions of a guilt offering, I would say</b> that <b>it is</b> only <b>the portions of a guilt offering</b> over <b>which</b> the limbs of a burnt offering <b>take precedence,</b> but they <b>do not take precedence over the portions of a sin offering,</b> as a sin offering is of greater sanctity than a guilt offering. <b>Due to this</b> reason the mishna in the former clause also <b>taught</b> this principle with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> and one cannot infer from this that its <i>halakha</i> does not apply to the guilt offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the mishna states that <b>a sin offering precedes a guilt offering.</b> One can infer from this that <b>it</b> is only <b>a sin offering that precedes a guilt offering, but a burnt offering</b> does <b>not. What, is</b> the mishna <b>not</b> referring to the sprinkling of the <b>blood,</b> which would indicate that the blood of a burnt offering does not precede the blood of a guilt offering?
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No,</b> it is referring <b>to the</b> precedence of the <b>sacrificial portions</b> consumed on the altar. The Gemara adds that the language of the mishna <b>is also precise</b> in this regard, <b>as it teaches</b> that the sin offering takes precedence <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that its blood is placed</b> on the four corners of the altar, rather than simply teaching: It is placed on the four corners of the altar, as it would have taught had it been speaking of the blood. One can therefore <b>conclude from</b> the statement of the mishna that its subject is the sacrificial portions burned on the altar, not the blood.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>A sin offering precedes</b> a guilt offering due to the fact that its blood is placed on the four corners of the altar and the remainder of its blood is poured on the base of the altar. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary,</b> the <b>guilt offering</b> should <b>precede</b> the sin offering, <b>as it has a fixed</b> minimal <b>value</b> of two shekels, as stated in the Torah (see Leviticus 5:15), whereas the sin offering has no minimal value. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that the sin offering requires <b>more</b> placements of the blood <b>on the altar</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance.
The mishna further teaches: <b>A guilt offering precedes a thanks offering</b> and the nazirite’s ram due to the fact that it is an offering of the most sacred order. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary, the thanks offering and</b> the <b>nazirite’s ram</b> should <b>precede</b> the guilt offering, <b>as they require loaves</b> to be brought with them. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that the guilt offering is an <b>offering of the most sacred order</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance.
The mishna teaches: <b>A thanks offering and</b> the <b>nazirite’s ram</b> precede a peace offering due to the fact that they are eaten for only one day. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary, peace offerings</b> should <b>precede</b> the thanks offering and the nazirite’s ram, <b>as they are</b> offered <b>by the community as well as by the individual.</b> A communal peace offering is sacrificed on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, but there is no communal thanks offering or nazirite’s ram. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that the thanks offering and the nazirite’s ram <b>are eaten for</b> only <b>one day</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>a thanks offering and a nazirite’s ram</b> to be sacrificed, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does the <b>thanks offering take precedence, as it requires four types of loaves,</b> whereas the nazirite’s ram requires only two? <b>Or perhaps</b> the <b>nazirite’s ram takes precedence, as there are other</b> offerings whose <b>blood</b> is placed on the altar together <b>with</b> the nazirite’s ram. A nazirite is required to sacrifice a burnt offering and a sin offering, as well as a ram. The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> that explicitly discusses this case: <b>This</b> offering <b>precedes that</b> offering, <b>as this</b> offering, i.e., the thanks offering, <b>requires four types of loaves, and that</b> offering, the nazirite’s ram, <b>requires only two types of loaves.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>And the peace offering precedes the firstborn</b> offering due to the fact that the peace offering requires two placements of the blood on the altar that are four, and the placement of hands on the animal’s head, and libations, and the wavings of the breast and thigh. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary,</b> the sacrifice of the <b>firstborn</b> offering should <b>precede</b> the peace offering, <b>as it is sanctified from</b> the <b>womb and it is eaten</b> only <b>by the priests,</b> whereas the peace offering may be eaten by non-priests. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that <b>additional mitzvot</b> are performed in the case of the peace offering is of <b>greater</b> importance.
The mishna further teaches: <b>The firstborn</b> offering <b>precedes</b> the animal tithe offering because it is sanctified from the womb and is eaten only by the priests. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary,</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering should <b>precede</b> the firstborn offering, <b>as</b> if one mistakenly called the ninth or eleventh animal that emerged from the pen the tenth, those animals that came out <b>before or after</b> the tenth are also <b>sanctified.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that the firstborn is <b>sanctified from</b> the <b>womb</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance.
The mishna teaches: The animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>precedes bird</b> offerings due to the fact that it requires slaughtering, whereas the bird’s nape is pinched; and furthermore, there are two elements of the animal tithe offering that have the status of offerings of the most sacred order: Its blood, which is presented on the altar, and its portions that are burned on the altar. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary, bird</b> offerings should <b>precede</b> the animal tithe offering, <b>as</b> they are <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> whether they are burnt offerings or sin offerings. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that the animal tithe is a <b>type of</b> offering that requires <b>slaughtering</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance.
§ <b>Ravina bar Sheila says</b> with regard to the sacrificial portions that are consumed on the altar: <b>Sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the <b>blood are disqualified. And the <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna also <b>taught:</b> The animal tithe offering precedes bird offerings <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it</b> requires <b>slaughtering, and there are</b> two elements of the animal tithe offering that have the status of <b>offerings of the most sacred order: Its blood and its sacrificial portions</b> consumed on the altar.
The Gemara explains how Ravina bar Sheila interprets the mishna in support of his opinion: <b>Granted, there are no sacrificial portions</b> consumed on the altar <b>from a bird</b> offering, <b>but</b> its <b>blood at least is</b> sprinkled. Why, then, does the mishna mention the blood? <b>Rather, is it not</b> mentioned in order to <b>teach us</b> that the status of the <b>sacrificial portions</b> consumed on the altar from the animal tithe offering and other offerings of lesser sanctity is <b>comparable to</b> the status of <b>its blood?</b>
The Gemara explains the implications of this comparison. <b>Just as its blood</b> referred to in the mishna is blood <b>before</b> its <b>sprinkling</b> on the altar, as afterward it no longer has any sanctity, <b>so too,</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> mentioned in the mishna are from <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>and</b> the mishna <b>calls them</b> at this stage <b>offerings of the most sacred order. And</b> therefore one can infer from this that <b>just as</b> the animal tithe’s <b>blood is disqualified by leaving</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>so too,</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> to be burned on the altar <b>are disqualified by leaving</b> the courtyard.
The Gemara attempts to prove the opinion of Ravina bar Sheila. <b>Let us say</b> that the following dispute between <i>amora’im</i> <b>supports his</b> statement: With regard to <b>flesh of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the <b>blood, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it is <b>fit</b> and <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that it is <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara clarifies this dispute: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it is <b>fit, since it will ultimately leave</b> the Temple courtyard, as offerings of lesser sanctity may be eaten anywhere within the walls of Jerusalem. <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that it is <b>unfit,</b> as <b>its time to leave</b> the Temple courtyard <b>has not yet arrived</b> because the flesh cannot be taken out until after the sprinkling of the blood. The Gemara infers that these <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree only with regard to</b> the <b>flesh</b> of the offering, which will eventually leave the Temple courtyard. <b>But with regard to</b> the <b>sacrificial portions</b> of the offering, which will never leave the courtyard, they do <b>not</b> disagree, as Rabbi Yoḥanan concedes that those portions are disqualified.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>The same is true with regard to</b> the <b>sacrificial portions,</b> i.e., these <i>amora’im</i> <b>also disagree</b> in that case, as Rabbi Yoḥanan holds they are fit. <b>And</b> the reason <b>that</b> they <b>disagree</b> explicitly <b>with regard to</b> the <b>flesh is to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish, as even</b> with regard to the <b>flesh, which will ultimately leave</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>he says</b> that it is disqualified, because <b>its time to leave</b> the courtyard <b>has not yet arrived.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute between <i>amora’im</i> is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b> With regard to the <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of</b> the <b>blood, Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that one who benefits <b>from them</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property,

Daf 90a

<b>and</b> one <b>is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for them due to</b> prohibitions against eating <b><i>piggul</i></b> or <b><i>notar</i>, or</b> for partaking of the flesh while he is <b>ritually impure.</b> All these prohibitions apply only if the sacrificial portions are otherwise fit for sacrifice. <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>and</b> one <b>is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>them due to</b> the prohibitions of <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, or</b> partaking of the flesh while he is <b>ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that they <b>disagree with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> after taking the portions to be burned out of the Temple courtyard one <b>then brought them</b> back <b>into</b> the courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood? <b>And,</b> if so, it is <b>with regard to this</b> very point that <b>they disagree: As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that the portions <b>are disqualified by leaving</b> the courtyard, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the portions <b>are not disqualified by leaving</b> the courtyard.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>Rav Pappa said</b> that <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> after taking these portions out of the Temple courtyard one <b>then brought them</b> back <b>into</b> the courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood, <b>everyone agrees</b> they are fit. <b>And here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> these portions <b>are outside</b> the courtyard when the blood is sprinkled on the altar. <b>And they disagree with regard to this</b> following matter: <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>is not effective</b> with regard <b>to</b> those portions that were <b>taken out</b> of the courtyard, i.e., it does not render them fit, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>is effective</b> with regard <b>to</b> those portions that were <b>taken out</b> of the courtyard, i.e., it renders them fit.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> Rav Pappa’s statement here apparently contradicts his claim concerning the two loaves brought with the two sheep on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>. The sprinkling of the blood of the sheep renders those two loaves fit for consumption by the priests, and the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva also applies in that case. The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav Pappa is</b> the one <b>who said</b> that <b>with regard to</b> a situation <b>where</b> the two loaves <b>are outside</b> the Temple courtyard when the blood of the two sheep is sprinkled on the altar, <b>everyone,</b> even Rabbi Akiva, <b>agrees</b> that the sprinkling does not render the two loaves fit, and therefore if one eats them he is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> due to the prohibition against eating <i>piggul</i>. Rather, the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> one <b>returned</b> the loaves <b>to within</b> the Temple courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood.
The Gemara answers: <b>This statement</b> of Rav Pappa applies only <b>to</b> the <b>two loaves, as</b> they <b>are not</b> part of <b>the offering itself. But</b> with regard to the <b>sacrificial portions, which are</b> part of <b>the offering itself,</b> everyone agrees that they are rendered fit if they are within the Temple courtyard at the time the blood is sprinkled on the altar. Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva <b>disagree</b> only <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where they are outside</b> the Temple courtyard when the blood is sprinkled on the altar.
§ The mishna teaches: The <b>bird</b> offerings <b>precede</b> meal offerings due to the fact that they are types whose blood is presented, and atonement is effected by the blood. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary, meal offerings</b> should <b>precede</b> bird offerings, <b>as they are</b> sacrificed both as <b>communal</b> offerings and <b>as individual</b> offerings, whereas there are no communal bird offerings. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the fact that bird offerings are <b>types</b> whose <b>blood</b> is sprinkled is of <b>greater</b> importance.
The mishna further teaches: <b>The meal offering of a sinner</b> precedes a voluntary meal offering. The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary, a voluntary meal offering</b> should <b>precede</b> the meal offering of a sinner, <b>as it requires oil and frankincense.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Even so, the meal offering of a sinner, which comes due to a sin,</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance, <b>as</b> it <b>effects atonement.</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>,</b> a woman suspected by her husband of having committed adultery, <b>and a voluntary meal offering</b> being brought by someone at the same time, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does the <b>voluntary meal offering take precedence, as it requires oil and frankincense? Or perhaps the meal offering of a <i>sota</i> takes precedence, as it comes to clarify</b> the woman’s <b>transgression,</b> as part of the rite performed with a <i>sota</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as the mishna states that <b>the meal offering of a sinner precedes a voluntary meal offering.</b> One can infer from this that <b>it is</b> only <b>the meal offering of a sinner that precedes a voluntary meal offering, but the meal offering of a <i>sota</i></b> does <b>not.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Is</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> that the meal offering of a sinner takes precedence <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it effects atonement?</b> The mishna <b>teaches: Due to</b> the fact <b>that it comes</b> because <b>of a sin, and</b> the meal offering of a <i>sota</i> <b>also comes</b> because <b>of a sin,</b> as she secluded herself with another man.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the statement of a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This</b> meal offering <b>precedes that</b> meal offering, <b>as this</b> meal offering <b>comes from wheat, and that</b> meal offering <b>comes from barley. What, does</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> refer to the precedence of <b>a voluntary meal offering to the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>?</b> The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the precedence of <b>the meal offering of a sinner over the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>.</b>
The Gemara responds: If the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the meal offering of a sinner, why is its precedence to the meal offering of a <i>sota</i> derived from the fact that the meal offering of a sinner comes from wheat, whereas the meal offering of a <i>sota</i> is brought from barley? <b>I</b> could <b>derive</b> the precedence of the meal offering of the sinner <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the meal offering of a sinner <b>effects atonement and</b> the meal offering of a <i>sota</i> <b>does not effect atonement.</b>
The Gemara counters: <b>Rather, what</b> is the <i>baraita</i> referring to? Is it referring to the precedence of <b>a voluntary meal offering</b> over the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>? If so, <b>I</b> could <b>derive</b> its precedence from the fact <b>that this</b> voluntary meal offering <b>requires oil and frankincense and that</b> meal offering of a <i>sota</i> <b>does not require oil and frankincense. Rather,</b> one cannot prove anything from the omission of an alternative explanation, as whichever way one interprets the <i>baraita</i> it clearly <b>cited one of two reasons.</b>
§ The mishna states: The sacrifice of <b>the bird sin offering precedes</b> the sacrifice of the bird burnt offering. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara answers: This is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the bird sin offering and the bird burnt offering that a poor sinner sacrifices instead of an animal sin offering. The verse states: <b>“And he shall offer that which is for the sin offering first”</b> (Leviticus 5:8). <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> this? <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this in order <b>to teach that</b> the sin offering <b>is sacrificed first, as</b> it <b>is already stated: “And he shall prepare the second for a burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 5:10).
<b>Rather, this</b> verse <b>established a paradigm for all sin offerings,</b> teaching <b>that they should precede the burnt offering that comes with them; whether</b> in the case of <b>a bird sin offering</b> taking precedence <b>over a bird burnt offering, whether</b> in the case of <b>an animal sin offering</b> taking precedence <b>over an animal burnt offering, and even</b> with regard to <b>a bird sin offering</b> taking precedence <b>over an animal burnt offering.</b>
The Gemara summarizes: <b>Therefore,</b> the precedence of <b>a bird sin offering over a bird burnt offering</b> is learned <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And</b> he shall prepare <b>the second</b> for a burnt offering.” The precedence of <b>an animal sin offering over an animal burnt offering</b> is derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One extends</b> the <i>halakha</i> derived from the sin offering of the Levites (see 89a). Finally, the precedence of <b>a bird sin offering over an animal burnt offering</b> is derived <b>from</b> the principle stated in this <i>baraita</i>, that <b>this</b> verse <b>established a paradigm</b> for all sin offerings, teaching that they should precede the burnt offering that comes with them.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a further proof from a <i>baraita</i>. The Torah states that a woman who has given birth must bring a sheep as a burnt offering and a bird as a sin offering. If she is poor she may bring two birds: “One for a burnt offering and the other for a sin offering” (Leviticus 12:8). <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> In <b>every</b> other <b>instance where</b> a bird offering <b>is exchanged</b> for an animal <b>sin offering,</b> the <b>sin offering precedes</b> the burnt offering. For example, in the case of the sliding scale sin offering brought for entering the Temple while ritually impure, where a poor person brings two birds, one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering, the sin offering comes first. <b>But here, in</b> the case of <b>a woman who gave birth,</b> the <b>burnt offering takes precedence,</b> as it takes the place of an animal burnt offering, mentioned first in the verse: “She shall bring a lamb in its first year for a burnt offering, and a pigeon or a dove for a sin offering (Leviticus 12:6).
Furthermore, in <b>every instance where</b> the sin offering <b>comes</b> because <b>of a sin,</b> the <b>sin offering precedes</b> the burnt offering. <b>But here,</b> in the case of a poor woman who gave birth, where the sin offering effects ritual purity rather than atonement, the <b>burnt offering precedes</b> the sin offering. <b>And</b> in <b>every instance where two</b> birds <b>come instead of</b> an animal for <b>a sin offering,</b> the <b>sin offering precedes</b> the burnt offering. <b>But here,</b> in the case of a poor woman who gave birth, the bird burnt offering replaces the animal burnt offering of a rich woman, whereas the bird sin offering is sacrificed even by a rich woman who gave birth. Therefore, in this particular case of a woman who gave birth, the <b>burnt offering precedes</b> the sin offering.
The straightforward reading of this <i>baraita</i> contradicts the statement of the previous <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that a sin offering always precedes a burnt offering. In order to reconcile the two <i>baraitot</i>, <b>Rava said:</b> The fact that <b>the verse mentions</b> the animal burnt offering <b>first</b> is only <b>with regard to reading</b> it, but in practice the sin offering is sacrificed first.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i> which apparently contradicts this principle. When there are different animal offerings to be sacrificed, <b>bulls precede rams, and rams precede sheep,</b> and <b>sheep</b> precede <b>male goats.</b>

Daf 90b

<b>What, is it not</b> referring to the additional offerings <b>of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>? If so, the <i>baraita</i> is teaching that bulls, rams, and sheep, which are burnt offerings, precede the sin offerings of male goats. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> with regard to all these animals the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to gift</b> offerings. The Gemara interprets the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with this explanation: <b>Bulls precede rams, as</b> they require <b>a greater</b> quantity <b>of libations; and likewise rams</b> precede <b>sheep</b> for the same reason. <b>Sheep</b> precede <b>male goats,</b> although their libations are identical, <b>as</b> the portions of the sheep consumed on the altar are <b>greater;</b> the sheep’s <b>tail</b> is burned, whereas the goat’s tail is not.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> which seems to contradict the principle that a sin offering always precedes a burnt offering: <b>The bull of</b> the <b>anointed priest,</b> i.e., the High Priest, which he sacrifices if he issues and then acts upon an erroneous halakhic ruling, <b>precedes</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> sacrificed if the Sanhedrin issues an erroneous halakhic ruling and the community then acts upon it. Similarly, the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin precedes</b> the <b>bull</b> sacrificed as a burnt offering to atone <b>for</b> an unwitting communal sin involving <b>idol worship.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The <b>bull</b> sacrificed as atonement <b>for</b> communal <b>idol worship precedes</b> the <b>male goats</b> that atone <b>for idol worship,</b> i.e., the goat sacrificed together with the bull. This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though</b> the <b>bull</b> that atones <b>for idol worship</b> is <b>a burnt offering, and</b> the <b>male goats</b> sacrificed as atonement <b>for idol worship</b> are <b>sin offerings.</b> This <i>baraita</i> seems to contradict the statement of the previous <i>baraita</i> that a sin offering always precedes a burnt offering.
The Gemara responds: <b>But</b> you can <b>say</b> that the opposite conclusion is derived <b>from the first clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>, as at least the first clause supports the principle that sin offerings take precedence: The <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> which is a sin offering, <b>precedes</b> the <b>bull</b> sacrificed to atone <b>for</b> an unwitting communal sin involving <b>idol worship,</b> which is a burnt offering.
The Gemara dismisses this answer: <b>In any event, with regard to</b> offerings that are both of <b>one species</b> of animal, <b>we did not say</b> there is any doubt <b>that a sin offering takes precedence. When we say</b> there is a contradiction between the rulings of the <i>baraitot</i>, it is <b>with regard to</b> offerings of <b>two species.</b> According to the earlier <i>baraita</i>, even a bird sin offering precedes an animal burnt offering, whereas here <b>we find a burnt offering that precedes a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>They say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of Rava bar Mari:</b> The <b>sin offering</b> sacrificed to atone <b>for idol worship is</b> written <b>without an <i>alef</i></b> (see Numbers 15:24). <b>It is written <i>lamed</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>tet</i>, <i>tav</i>.</b> This indicates that it is different from other sin offerings in that it does not precede the burnt offering. <b>Ravina says</b> that the term <b>“according to the ordinance” is written with regard to</b> the offerings sacrificed to atone for idol-worship, in the verse: “The congregation shall offer one young bull…according to the ordinance, and one goat for a sin offering” (Numbers 15:24). This mention of an ordinance indicates that they must be sacrificed in the precise order stated by the verse.
The Gemara comments: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation, the previous <i>baraita</i> can be explained in a similar manner: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the <b>bulls</b> and other offerings <b>of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, there is <b>also</b> no difficulty with regard to the burnt offering sheep taking precedence over the sin offering male goats, as the term <b>“according to their ordinance” is written concerning</b> these offerings as well (see Numbers 29:33).
<b>A dilemma</b> ensuing from the conclusion of the previous discussion <b>was raised before</b> the Sages: If there is <b>a bird sin offering, and an animal burnt offering, and</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering to be sacrificed, <b>which of them precedes</b> the others? If you say that <b>the bird sin offering should take precedence, there is</b> the animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>that</b> generally <b>precedes it,</b> since it requires slaughtering, as stated by the mishna. If you say that the animal <b>tithe</b> offering <b>should take precedence, there is</b> the <b>animal burnt offering that precedes it,</b> as the burnt offering is an offering of the most sacred order. If you say that the <b>animal burnt offering should take precedence, there is the bird sin offering that precedes it,</b> as the Gemara previously concluded.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here,</b> in Babylonia, <b>they explained</b> that the fact that the animal tithe offering is <b>a type of</b> offering that requires <b>slaughtering</b> is of <b>greater</b> importance than the other factors. Therefore, the animal tithe offering is sacrificed first, followed by the bird sin offering, and finally the animal burnt offering. <b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say:</b> The <b>animal burnt offering has an effect on the bird sin offering</b> sacrificed with it <b>and raises its</b> importance <b>above</b> that of the animal <b>tithe</b> offering. Therefore, the bird sin offering is sacrificed first, followed by the animal burnt offering, and finally the animal tithe offering.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the sin offerings</b> mandated <b>by the Torah take precedence over the guilt offerings,</b> as explained in the previous mishna (89a), <b>except for the guilt offering of a leper, because it comes to</b> render one <b>fit.</b> One who has been cured of leprosy must undergo a process through which he is rendered ritually pure before coming into contact with consecrated items. Although he must also bring a sin offering, his guilt offering is more central to that process of purification and therefore it takes precedence over the sin offering.
<b>All the guilt offerings</b> mandated <b>by the Torah come</b> as rams <b>in their second year, and come worth</b> two <b>silver shekels, except for the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper, as they come</b> from sheep <b>in their</b> first <b>year, and do not</b> need to <b>come worth</b> two <b>silver shekels,</b> as they have no fixed value.
<b>Just as</b> the more sacred offerings <b>precede</b> other offerings <b>with regard to their sacrifice,</b> as taught in the previous mishna (89a), <b>they</b> also <b>precede</b> the others <b>with regard to their consumption.</b> If one has <b>a peace offering from yesterday and a peace offering from today,</b> the peace offering <b>from yesterday precedes</b> the peace offering <b>from today.</b> If one has <b>a peace offering from yesterday</b> and <b>a sin offering or a guilt offering from today,</b> the <b>peace offering from yesterday precedes</b> the others; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> The <b>sin offering precedes</b> the peace offering, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is an offering of the most sacred order.</b> Likewise, the guilt offering precedes the peace offering, as it is also of the most sacred order.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> the offerings that are eaten, <b>the priests are permitted to alter</b> the manner of <b>their consumption</b> and eat them as they choose. Therefore, the priests are permitted <b>to eat them roasted, or boiled, or cooked,</b> and <b>to place in</b> the cooking pot <b>non-sacred spices or <i>teruma</i> spices.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Meir says: One may not place <i>teruma</i> spices in it,</b> so <b>that he will not bring the <i>teruma</i> to</b> a state <b>of disqualification.</b> Consumption of consecrated foods is permitted only for a limited period, after which they are disqualified and burned. Adding <i>teruma</i> spices might cause those spices to be similarly disqualified.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: The <i>mishnayot</i> (89a) taught that a frequent offering precedes other offerings, and also that an offering of greater sanctity precedes others. If there is <b>a frequent</b> offering <b>and</b> an offering <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity</b> to be sacrificed, <b>which of them precedes</b> the other? Does the <b>frequent</b> offering <b>take precedence, due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> it is <b>frequent, or perhaps</b> the offering <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity takes precedence, as</b> it is <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the ruling of the first mishna in this chapter, that the <b>daily offerings precede</b> the <b>additional offerings</b> because they are frequent.

Daf 91a

<b>And even though</b> the <b>additional offerings</b> are <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity,</b> as they are sacrificed due to the sanctity of Shabbat, the frequent offering precedes the offering of greater sanctity. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Is that to say</b> that the sanctity of <b>Shabbat affects</b> the sanctity of the <b>additional offerings</b> but does <b>not affect</b> the <b>daily offerings</b> brought on Shabbat? Rather, the sanctity of Shabbat elevates the sanctity of the daily offerings as well, and as both are of equal sanctity, the frequent daily offering precedes the additional offerings.
The Gemara cites another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the continuation of this mishna: The <b>additional Shabbat offerings precede</b> the <b>additional New Moon offerings</b> because they are more frequent, despite the fact that the New Moon elevates the sanctity of its additional offerings. The Gemara rejects this proof in a similar manner: <b>Is that to say</b> that the sanctity of the <b>New Moon affects</b> the sanctity of <b>its additional offerings</b> but <b>does not affect the additional offerings of Shabbat?</b> These additional offerings are also imbued with the sanctity of the New Moon.
The Gemara cites another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the continuation of this mishna: The <b>additional New Moon offerings precede</b> the <b>additional New Year offerings</b> because they are more frequent, <b>even though the New Year</b> is <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>Is that to say</b> that the sanctity of <b>the New Year affects</b> the sanctity of <b>its additional offerings</b> but <b>does not affect the additional offerings of</b> the <b>New Moon?</b>
The Gemara cites another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Berakhot</i> 5:25) that discusses the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel with regard to the order of blessings in <i>kiddush</i>. After stating one reason for the opinion of Beit Hillel that one recites the blessing on the wine before the blessing of the sanctity of the day, the <i>Tosefta</i> adds: <b>Alternatively,</b> Beit Hillel say: <b>The blessing over wine</b> is recited <b>frequently, and the blessing over the day is not</b> recited <b>frequently, and</b> there is a principle: When <b>a frequent</b> practice <b>and an infrequent</b> practice clash, the <b>frequent</b> practice <b>takes precedence</b> over the infrequent practice. This applies <b>even though the blessing of the day</b> is <b>of</b> greater <b>sanctity,</b> as it is recited due to the sanctity of Shabbat. The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>Is that to say</b> that the sanctity of <b>Shabbat affects</b> the sanctity of <b>the blessing of the day</b> but <b>does not affect</b> the sanctity of <b>the blessing on the wine?</b>
The Gemara cites another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one did not recite the additional prayer on Shabbat until the time of the afternoon prayer arrived, the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a person prays the afternoon prayer and afterward the additional prayer,</b> as the afternoon prayer is more frequent. This ruling applies despite the fact that the additional prayer is of greater sanctity. Once again the Gemara rejects the proof: <b>Is that to say</b> that the sanctity of <b>Shabbat affects</b> the sanctity of <b>the additional prayer</b> but <b>does not affect</b> the sanctity of <b>the afternoon prayer?</b>
The Gemara cites yet another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna: If one has <b>a peace offering from yesterday</b> and <b>a sin offering or a guilt offering from today, the peace offering from yesterday precedes</b> the others; this is the statement of Rabbi Meir. One can infer from this that if both <b>this</b> offering <b>and that</b> offering are <b>from today,</b> the <b>sin offering or guilt offering takes precedence, and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though the peace offering</b> is more <b>frequent,</b> as people sacrifice voluntary peace offerings more often than sin offerings or guilt offerings.
<b>Rava said</b> in response: <b>Are you speaking</b> of <b>a common</b> offering? Although peace offerings are sacrificed more often than sin offerings, there is no obligation to sacrifice them at any particular frequency. <b>We raise the dilemma</b> only with regard to a clash between <b>a frequent</b> offering and one of greater sanctity, but <b>we do not raise the dilemma</b> with regard to <b>a common</b> offering.
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said to Rava: Is that to say</b> that <b>a common</b> obligation is <b>not</b> considered tantamount to <b>a frequent</b> obligation? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to positive mitzvot whose intentional neglect results in the punishment of <i>karet</i> but whose unwitting transgression does not entail the sacrifice of a sin offering: <b>I should exclude</b> the neglect of <b>the Paschal offering</b> from the obligation to sacrifice a sin offering, <b>as it is not frequent, and I should not exclude</b> the neglect of <b>the</b> mitzva of <b>circumcision, as it is frequent?</b> Circumcision is considered a frequent mitzva, as it is performed more often than the Paschal offering, despite the fact that there is no obligation to perform circumcisions at any particular frequency.
Rava answers: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>frequent</b> in that context? It means that circumcision is <b>frequent in</b> terms of the numerous <b>mitzvot</b> commanded with regard to its fulfillment. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>circumcision in relation to</b> the <b>Paschal offering is considered like a frequent</b> obligation, as it is occurs far more often, whereas peace offerings are brought only somewhat more often than sin offerings. In sum, one cannot infer from the mishna that an offering of greater sanctity precedes a frequent offering.
§ An additional <b>dilemma</b> with regard to precedence <b>was raised before</b> the Sages: If the priest had two offerings to sacrifice, <b>a frequent</b> offering <b>and an infrequent</b> offering, <b>and</b> although he should have initially sacrificed the frequent offering <b>he slaughtered the infrequent</b> offering <b>first, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>since</b> he already <b>slaughtered</b> the infrequent offering he also proceeds to <b>sacrifice it? Or perhaps</b> he does not yet sacrifice it but <b>gives</b> it <b>to another</b> priest, <b>who stirs its blood</b> to prevent it from congealing, <b>until</b> he <b>sacrifices</b> the <b>frequent</b> offering; <b>and then</b> he <b>sacrifices the infrequent</b> offering.
<b>Rav Huna from Sura said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer from the mishna: If one has <b>a peace offering from yesterday</b> and <b>a sin offering or a guilt offering from today,</b> the peace offering <b>from yesterday precedes</b> the sin offering <b>from today.</b> It can be assumed that the mishna is not discussing a case where none of the offerings have been slaughtered, as the peace offering would not take precedence in this situation. Rather, it is discussing a peace offering from yesterday that was slaughtered but its blood has not yet been presented. One can infer from this that only a peace offering from yesterday takes precedence in this situation, <b>but</b> in the case of a peace offering <b>from today</b> that is <b>similar</b> in other aspects <b>to</b> a peace offering <b>from yesterday,</b> the peace offering does not take precedence.
The Gemara explains: <b>And what are the circumstances</b> of this case? This is a situation <b>where</b> one <b>first slaughtered the peace offering</b> from today. In this case the <b>sin offering or guilt offering takes precedence,</b> although the peace offering is already slaughtered, as both of them are of greater sanctity. The same should apply to an infrequent offering that was slaughtered before a frequent offering: The frequent offering is slaughtered before the blood of the infrequent offering is presented.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>Perhaps</b> when the mishna makes reference to <b>a peace offering from yesterday and a sin offering or a guilt offering from today,</b> the circumstances should be understood differently. <b>How can you find these</b> other circumstances? The mishna discusses a case <b>where</b> the priest already <b>slaughtered both of them,</b> the peace offering and the sin- or guilt offering, and the blood of both awaits presentation on the altar. <b>But</b> had he <b>not</b> yet <b>slaughtered both of them,</b> but only the peace offering, <b>you</b> can still <b>raise the dilemma</b> of whether the priest should set aside the blood of the peace offering in order to slaughter the sin offering first, due to its greater sanctity.
The Gemara cites another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: <b>Alternatively,</b> Beit Hillel say: With regard to the order of blessings in <i>kiddush</i>, <b>the blessing on wine</b> is recited <b>frequently and the blessing of the day is not</b> recited <b>frequently, and</b> there is a principle: When <b>a frequent</b> practice <b>and an infrequent</b> practice clash, the <b>frequent</b> practice <b>takes precedence</b> over the infrequent practice. The obligation to recite the blessing of the day is due to the sanctity of Shabbat and applies at the start of Shabbat, before wine is placed on the table. Nevertheless, the blessing on the wine takes precedence due to its frequency. So too, the slaughtering of the frequent offering should take precedence, even if the priest had already commenced the sacrificial rites of the infrequent offering.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Here too,</b> with regard to <i>kiddush</i>, the circumstances are different, <b>since</b> wine is available when one recites <i>kiddush</i>, and therefore the obligation of both blessings <b>come</b> together. This means that it is <b>comparable to</b> a situation <b>where one</b> already <b>slaughtered both</b> animals.
The Gemara cites yet another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a person prays the afternoon prayer and afterward the additional prayer,</b> despite the fact that the obligation of the additional prayer applies first, which is similar to an offering slaughtered first. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Here too, since the time of the afternoon prayer has</b> now <b>arrived,</b> one is obligated in both prayers, and again this is <b>comparable to</b> a situation <b>where one</b> already <b>slaughtered both</b> animals.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ashi, said to Ravina</b> that an answer to this dilemma can be found in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 61a): If one <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering <b>before midday</b> it is <b>disqualified, because it is stated in its regard: “In the afternoon”</b> (Exodus 12:6). If he slaughtered it <b>before the daily</b> afternoon <b>offering</b> was slaughtered it is <b>valid,</b> even though the daily offering should be sacrificed first, <b>but</b> someone <b>should stir its blood</b> to prevent it from congealing <b>until</b> he slaughters and <b>sprinkles the blood</b> of the daily offering. Although the infrequent Paschal offering is already slaughtered, the priest first slaughters the frequent daily offering and then sprinkles the blood of the Paschal offering.
The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> he <b>gave precedence to the daily offering</b> and <b>slaughtered it first,</b> and then slaughtered the Paschal offering before sprinkling the blood of the daily offering. Since the blood of both offerings requires sprinkling on the altar, the blood of the daily offering takes precedence. <b>Rav Aḥa the Elder said to Rav Ashi</b> that the wording of <b>the mishna is also precise, as it teaches: Until the blood of the daily offering is sprinkled, and does not teach: Until he slaughters and sprinkles the blood.</b> This indicates that the daily afternoon offering has already been slaughtered. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> its wording that this is the meaning of the mishna.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And with regard to all of</b> the offerings that are eaten, <b>the priests are permitted</b> to alter the manner of their consumption and eat them as they choose. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: The <b>verse states,</b> with regard to the gifts of the priesthood: “Of all the consecrated items of the children of Israel to you have I given them <b><i>lemoshḥa</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:8). <i>Targum Onkelos</i> renders this term as: <b>For greatness,</b> indicating that the flesh of the offerings should be eaten <b>in</b> the <b>manner that kings eat</b> their food, i.e., prepared in any way they want.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Shimon said: If you saw oil that is being distributed in the Temple courtyard</b> for consumption by the priests and you seek to ascertain its nature, you <b>do not need to ask what it is. Rather,</b> it is <b>left over</b> from the oil <b>of the wafers of the meal offerings of Israelites</b> after they smeared a bit of oil on them, <b>or</b> it is left over from the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper</b> after a small amount of the oil was placed on him.
<b>If you saw oil that is placed on the flames</b> of the altar in the manner of an offering, you <b>do not need to ask what it is. Rather,</b> it is <b>left over</b> from the oil <b>of the wafers of the meal offering of priests, or</b> it is the leftover oil from <b>the meal offering of the anointed priest,</b> which requires a great deal of oil and which is burned in its entirety on the altar. The mishna adds: One can-not say that the oil distributed to priests or burned on the altar was brought as a gift offering, <b>as one may not contribute oil</b> as a gift offering. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: One may contribute oil</b> as a gift offering.

Daf 91b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Shmuel says: According to the statement of Rabbi Tarfon</b> that oil may be sacrificed as a gift offering, in the case of <b>one who contributes oil,</b> a priest <b>removes a handful of</b> the oil and sacrifices it on the altar, <b>and its remainder is eaten</b> by the priests. <b>What is the reason</b> for the ruling of Shmuel? The <b>verse states:</b> “And when one brings <b>a meal offering [<i>korban minḥa</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 2:1). The superfluous word <i>korban</i> <b>teaches that one may contribute oil, and</b> its status is <b>like</b> that of <b>a meal offering: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering</b> the priest <b>removes a handful and its remainder is eaten, so too</b> with regard to <b>oil,</b> the priest <b>removes a handful and its remainder is eaten.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>we learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna <b>as well: Rabbi Shimon said: If you saw oil that is being distributed in the Temple courtyard, you do not need to ask what it is; rather,</b> it is <b>left over</b> from the oil <b>of the wafers of the meal offerings of Israelites, or</b> it is left over from the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper, as one does not contribute</b> oil as a gift offering. Rabbi Zeira learns <b>by inference</b> from the mishna <b>that</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> that <b>one may contribute</b> oil, it is <b>distributed</b> to the priests for consumption and it is not sacrificed entirely.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>Say the last clause</b> of the mishna: <b>If you saw oil that is placed on the flames</b> of the altar, <b>you do not need to ask what it is; rather,</b> it is <b>left over</b> from the oil <b>of the wafers of the meal offering of priests or</b> it is left over from <b>the meal offering of the anointed priest, as one does not contribute oil</b> as a gift offering. Abaye learns <b>by inference</b> from the mishna <b>that according to the one who says</b> that <b>one may contribute</b> oil, it is burned in its <b>entirety in the flames</b> on the altar. This contradicts Shmuel’s statement that according to Rabbi Tarfon only a handful of the oil is burned on the altar. The Gemara comments: <b>For Abaye</b> the inference from <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna is <b>difficult,</b> while <b>for Rabbi Zeira</b> the inference from <b>the last clause</b> is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Zeira,</b> the inference from <b>the first clause</b> that the oil is distributed for consumption by the priests can be explained as referring <b>to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the oil, whereas the inference from <b>the last clause</b> that the oil is burned on the altar is referring <b>to</b> the <b>handful</b> removed from the oil. <b>But</b> according <b>to Abaye,</b> the contradictory inferences pose <b>a difficulty.</b> The Gemara answers: One cannot infer anything from the first clause, as the mishna <b>taught the first clause due to the last clause.</b> That is, as the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna wishes to teach the last clause in a certain manner, he teaches the first clause in a similar style, despite the fact that one might come to an erroneous conclusion from the wording of the first clause.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> a <i>tanna</i> may <b>teach the last clause</b> of a mishna <b>due to the first clause,</b> i.e., a <i>tanna</i> might teach in a similar formulation to one he had already used. <b>But would</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>teach the first clause</b> of a mishna <b>due to the last clause?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes; they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, that a <i>tanna</i> <b>taught the first clause due to the last clause.</b>
The Gemara cites a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If one contributes <b>wine, according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva</b> that one may contribute wine, it is poured <b>into the basins</b> adjacent to the corner of the altar. If one contributes <b>oil, according to the statement of Rabbi Tarfon</b> that one may contribute oil, it is burned <b>in the flames</b> of the altar. <b>What, is it not</b> possible to infer <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>wine</b> is poured in <b>its entirety into the basins</b> that the <b>oil</b> is likewise burned in <b>its entirety in the flames</b> of the altar, contrary to Shmuel’s statement? The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is and that</b> case is <b>as it is,</b> i.e., the donations of wine and the oil are separate cases, and the two statements of the <i>baraita</i> need not accord with each other.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Shmuel’s statement is <b>like</b> one side of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: One who contributes <b>oil</b> should <b>not</b> bring <b>less than a <i>log</i>. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Three <i>log</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>disagree? The Sages said this before Rav Pappa:</b> They disagree with regard to the nature of an inference by means of verbal analogy or juxtaposition: Is the secondary case equated to the primary case in all aspects, in accordance with the exegetical principle: <b>Infer from it and</b> again <b>from it;</b> or does the comparison extend only to one specific issue derived from the primary case, in accordance with the principle: <b>Infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place,</b> i.e., in all other aspects the cases are not equated?
The Gemara explains that this <b>is</b> the difference <b>between them, as the Rabbis hold</b> by the principle: Infer from it and again from it. The Gemara explains the application of this principle: <b>Just as a meal offering is contributed, so too, oil is contributed,</b> as inferred from the verse addressing the meal offering. <b>And</b> again one infers <b>from</b> this source: <b>Just as a meal offering</b> requires <b>a <i>log</i> of oil, so too here,</b> an offering of oil alone must be <b>a <i>log</i> of oil. And just as</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering</b> the priest <b>removes a handful and its remainder is eaten, so too</b> with regard to <b>oil,</b> the priest <b>removes a handful and its remainder is eaten.</b>
<b>And the other,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, holds by the principle: Infer from it but interpret the <i>halakha</i> according to its own place. The Gemara explains that here too, one infers <b>from</b> the case of <b>a meal offering: Just as a meal offering is contributed, so too, oil is contributed. But</b> with regard to all other aspects of this <i>halakha</i>, <b>interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place,</b> and its status is <b>like</b> that of wine <b>libations,</b> which are similar to oil in that they are also poured onto the altar: <b>Just as</b> one contributes <b>libations</b> of <b>three <i>log</i>, so too,</b> when one contributes <b>oil</b> one contributes <b>three <i>log</i>; and just as libations</b> are poured in <b>their entirety into the basins, so too,</b> the <b>oil</b> is burned in <b>its entirety in the flames</b> of the altar.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: If Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>cited</b> the source of the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> the verse addressing the <b>meal offering</b> he would not disagree with the Rabbis, <b>as everyone</b> employs the principle of: <b>Infer from it and</b> again <b>from it. Rather, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>derives</b> the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> a verse that deals with libations: “All that are <b>homeborn</b> shall do these things after this manner, in presenting an offering made by fire” (Numbers 15:13). Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi derives from here that just as one may contribute wine libations, so too, one may contribute oil. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi compares oil to wine libations: Just as one contributes libations of three <i>log</i>, so too, one contributes three <i>log</i> of oil.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: How can you say that,</b> i.e., that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the source of the gift offering of oil is not from the meal offering? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And when one brings <b>a meal offering [<i>korban minḥa</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 2:1), that the superfluous word <i>korban</i> <b>teaches that one may contribute oil?</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And how much</b> must one contribute? <b>Three <i>log</i>.</b> The Gemara explains the question: <b>And whom did you hear who says</b> the gift offering of oil is <b>three <i>log</i>? This is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and</b> yet he <b>cites</b> the source of the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> the word <b><i>korban</i>,</b> which is referring to a meal offering. Rav Pappa <b>said to him: If</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught;</b> and I cannot take issue with it.
§ <b>Shmuel says: One who contributes wine brings</b> it <b>and sprinkles it on the flames</b> of the altar. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The verse states: “And you shall present for the libation half a <i>hin</i> of wine, for an offering made by fire, of a pleasing aroma to the Lord”</b> (Numbers 15:10). The verse indicates that there is a type of wine libation which is an offering made by fire. The Gemara challenges: <b>But he</b> thereby <b>extinguishes</b> the fire on the altar, and the Torah states: “A perpetual fire shall be kept burning on the altar, it shall not go out” (Leviticus 6:6). The Gemara explains: <b>Extinguishing in a partial</b> manner <b>is not called extinguishing;</b> in other words, this act is not included in the prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: One who takes down a coal from upon the altar and extinguishes it is liable</b> for violating the prohibition: “It shall not go out”? The Gemara answers: This statement is referring to a situation <b>where there is only this</b> coal on the altar, and therefore the fire is entirely extinguished. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that even if partial extinguishing is prohibited, <b>extinguishing</b> for the sake <b>of a mitzva,</b> as in the case of sprinkling wine on the altar, <b>is different,</b> and is permitted.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>that Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov teaches: Since the Torah gave</b> a mitzva <b>to remove</b> the ashes of the offerings from the altar, one <b>might</b> have thought that it is permitted to <b>extinguish</b> the coals so that they become ashes <b>and</b> then to <b>remove</b> them. Therefore, <b>you say: He shall not extinguish,</b> in accordance with the verse: “It shall not go out.” Although this is a case of extinguishing for the sake of a mitzva, the <i>baraita</i> deems it prohibited. The Gemara explains: It <b>is different there,</b> as it is <b>possible</b> for the priest <b>to sit and wait</b> until some of the coals become ashes, and then remove them. By contrast, with regard to wine, there is no alternative to sprinkling the wine on the fire, and therefore it is permitted.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> that prohibits sprinkling wine on the fire of the altar: If one contributes <b>wine, according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva</b> that one may contribute wine, it is poured <b>into the basins</b> on the altar. If one contributes <b>oil, according to the statement of Rabbi Tarfon</b> that one may contribute oil, it is poured <b>onto the flames</b> of the altar. <b>And</b> it <b>is furthermore taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>wine libation</b> is poured <b>into the basins.</b> The <i>baraita</i> suggests: <b>Or</b> perhaps it is <b>not</b> so; <b>rather,</b> it is poured <b>onto the flames.</b> Therefore, <b>you say: He shall not extinguish.</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that even an unintentional action, i.e., a permitted action from which a prohibited action inadvertently ensues, is prohibited; and <b>this</b> statement of Shmuel is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that a permitted action from which a prohibited action inadvertently ensues is permitted. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? But doesn’t Shmuel say: One may extinguish a piece of white-hot metal in a public thoroughfare</b> on Shabbat <b>so that the masses will not be injured by it;</b>

Daf 92a

<b>but</b> one may <b>not</b> extinguish <b>a wood coal,</b> because extinguishing it is prohibited by Torah law? <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that Shmuel <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> it should be permitted to extinguish <b>even a wood coal.</b> Rabbi Shimon maintains that extinguishing a coal is prohibited by Torah law only when one intends to use the extinguished coal. Otherwise, this constitutes a labor performed on Shabbat which is not necessary for its own sake, which is not prohibited by Torah law.
The Gemara answers: Shmuel’s statements are not contradictory, as <b>with regard to an unintentional act,</b> he <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> But <b>with regard to labor not necessary for its own sake, he holds</b> that it is prohibited by Torah law, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> With regard to wine <b>libations that became ritually impure, one prepares for them an arrangement</b> of wood <b>by themselves and burns them</b> there, without removing them from the Temple courtyard. This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is stated</b> with regard to a disqualified sin offering: <b>“In the sacred place…it shall be burned with fire”</b> (Leviticus 6:23). This requirement of burning in the sacred place applies to all offerings that are meant to be sacrificed on an altar and became disqualified. <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the blood, the oil, the meal offerings, and the libations that became ritually impure, one prepares for them an arrangement</b> of wood <b>by themselves and burns them</b> there.
The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel said to Rav Ḥana of Baghdad: Bring me an assembly of ten</b> men <b>and I will tell you in their presence</b> this <i>halakha</i> that I wish to disseminate: With regard to <b>libations that became ritually impure, one prepares for them an arrangement</b> of wood <b>by themselves and burns them</b> there.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>the blood of a sin offering</b> designated for presentation <b>that was sprayed on a garment, that</b> garment <b>requires laundering,</b> as is stated with regard to a sin offering: “And when any of its blood shall be sprinkled on a garment, you shall launder that on which it shall be sprinkled in a sacred place” (Leviticus 6:20). <b>Although the verse is speaking only of</b> sin offerings <b>that are eaten</b> and whose blood is presented on the outer altar, <b>as it is stated: “In a sacred place shall it be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:19), the principle is not exclusive to eaten sin offerings. With regard to the blood of <b>both</b> the sin offerings <b>that are eaten and the</b> sin offerings that are wholly burned and not eaten and whose blood is presented on the <b>inner</b> altar, garments sprayed with blood from each of these offerings <b>require laundering. As it is stated</b> at the start of that passage: “This is <b>the law of the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:18), it is understood: There is <b>one law for all the sin offerings.</b>
That is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to sin offerings fit for sacrifice. With regard to <b>a disqualified sin offering, its blood does not</b> cause a garment to <b>require laundering whether</b> the offering <b>had a period of fitness</b> when its blood was fit for presentation <b>or whether it did not have a period of fitness. Which</b> offering <b>is</b> the disqualified sin offering <b>that had a period of fitness?</b> It is one <b>that was left overnight</b> and then became disqualified; <b>or</b> it is one <b>that became ritually impure; or</b> it is one <b>that emerged</b> from of the Temple courtyard. <b>Which</b> offering <b>is</b> the disqualified sin offering <b>that did not have a period of fitness?</b> It is one <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intent to eat it or present its blood <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area; or</b> it is one whose blood was <b>collected</b> by people <b>disqualified</b> for Temple service <b>and</b> they <b>sprinkled its blood.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: In the case of <b>the blood of a sin offering that was sprayed</b> on a garment, the garment must be laundered, and this is the <i>halakha</i> concerning the blood of sin offerings that are eaten and sin offerings that are wholly burned, as it is stated: “This is the law of the sin offering”; there is one law for all sin offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>And if</b> there is <b>one law for all sin offerings, even</b> the blood of <b>a bird sin offering</b> should <b>also</b> require laundering. If so, <b>why is it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that the <b>blood of a bird sin offering requires laundering.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “This</b> is the law of the sin offering.” The word “this” teaches that the <i>halakha</i> is to be restricted to the blood of an animal sin offering and it does not apply to the bird sin offering.
<b>Reish Lakish said in the name of bar Kappara: The verse states:</b> “This is the law of the sin offering…<b>shall</b> the sin offering <b>be slaughtered”</b> (Leviticus 6:18). <b>The verse is speaking</b> specifically <b>of</b> sin offerings <b>that are slaughtered</b> and not of bird offerings, which are killed by pinching the nape of the neck, rather than slaughtering with a knife.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And I</b> might <b>say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is to be learned in another manner, and <b>the verse is speaking</b> specifically <b>of</b> sin offerings <b>that are eaten, as it is written: “In a sacred place shall it be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:19); <b>but internal</b> sin offerings, which are not eaten, should <b>not</b> be included. The Gemara explains: <b>The Merciful One amplifies</b> the <i>halakha</i> by stating: “This is <b>the law of</b> the sin offering,” which includes all sin offerings, even those that are not eaten.
The Gemara suggests: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even</b> the blood of <b>the bird sin offering</b> should be included. The Gemara explains: <b>The Merciful One restricts</b> the <i>halakha</i> by stating: <b>“This</b> is the law,” which excludes bird offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that indicated that the verse is to be understood as including internal sin offerings and excluding bird offerings, and not the opposite? The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason that internal animal sin offerings should have been included</b> by the inclusive language of the verse, <b>as</b> internal sin offerings resemble eaten animal sin offerings in several ways: Each variety is a large <b>animal</b> and not a bird; each variety is subject to <b>slaughter on the north</b> side of the Temple courtyard; <b>and</b> the blood of each requires <b>collection</b> in <b>a vessel;</b>

Daf 92b

<b>and</b> their blood is placed on the <b>corner</b> of the altar; <b>and</b> the blood is placed with a priest’s <b>finger; and</b> the blood is placed on <b>the edge of</b> the corner of the altar; <b>and</b> parts of each are consumed in <b>flames</b> upon the altar.
