None of these apply to bird sin offerings.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>On the contrary, the bird sin offering should have been included</b> and likened to the eaten animal sin offerings, <b>as</b> the blood of bird sin offerings is presented on the <b>outer</b> altar <b>like</b> an animal sin offering that is eaten, <b>and</b> the bird sin offering has portions set aside for <b>eating, like it.</b> The Gemara rejects the reasoning for including bird offerings: <b>Those</b> features that are common to internal sin offerings and eaten animal sin offerings <b>are more numerous</b> than the features common to bird sin offerings and eaten animal sin offerings.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> There is another way to prove that the blood of a bird sin offering is not required to be laundered out if it is sprayed on a garment. With regard to laundering, <b>the verse states:</b> “The priest that offers it for sin <b>shall eat it”</b> (Leviticus 6:19); the obligation described applies <b>to it,</b> i.e., the eaten animal sin offering, <b>and not to another</b> similar sin offering. Consequently, <b>the verse is excluding</b> a case <b>within</b> the broad category of <b>eaten</b> sin offerings, and one is not required to launder out the blood of a bird sin offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the exclusion of bird offerings is derived from this verse, then <b>why do I</b> need the derivation from the verse: <b>“This</b> is the law of the sin offering”? The Gemara answers: <b>If not</b> for the derivation from <b>“this,” I would say</b> that the term <b>“shall eat it”</b> is simply <b>the manner</b> of speech <b>of the verse,</b> so that it does not indicate any exclusion. Therefore, the word “this” <b>teaches us</b> that a sin offering is excluded, and the term “shall eat it,” demonstrates that the excluded sin offering is one that is eaten.
<b>Rabba said</b> that there is a different explanation. Internal sin offerings cannot be excluded from the requirement of laundering sprayed garments, as the verse speaks specifically of internal sin offerings, as <b>the verse states: “It shall be sprinkled”</b> (Leviticus 6:20). <b>The verse is speaking of</b> sin offerings that require <b>sprinklings,</b> and sprinkling is mentioned specifically with regard to internal sin offerings (see Leviticus 4:6), unlike eaten animal sin offerings, with regard to which the Torah uses a term of placing to describe the presenting of its blood (see Leviticus 4:25).
The Gemara raises a difficulty: Can one say that the passage about laundering applies specifically to internal sin offerings? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the mishna: <b>Although the verse is speaking only of</b> sin offerings <b>that are eaten,</b> indicating that the passage certainly applies to sin offerings that are eaten? The Gemara answers: The mishna’s statement pertains <b>to the matter of scouring and rinsing</b> copper vessels in which a sin offering was cooked (see Leviticus 6:21), which is relevant only to sin offerings that are eaten. <b>But in the matter of laundering:</b> “You shall launder that on which <b>it shall be sprinkled”</b> (Leviticus 6:20) <b>is written,</b> and the term “it shall be sprinkled” indicates only internal sin offerings. By contrast, eaten sin offerings are included only through the amplification in the verse: “The law of the sin offering” (Leviticus 6:18).
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that the verses prescribing laundering are primarily discussing internal sin offerings, and eaten sin offerings are included only through a derivation, then with regard to the statement in the mishna: <b>Both</b> the sin offerings <b>that are eaten and the internal</b> sin offerings, is this statement not misleading? Rather, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> stated: <b>Both the internal</b> sin offerings <b>and</b> the sin offerings <b>that are eaten,</b> first mentioning the offerings most clearly indicated in the verse. The Gemara answers: <b>Teach</b> it as: <b>Both the internal</b> sin offerings <b>and the</b> sin offerings <b>that are eaten.</b>
<b>If so,</b> that the requirement of laundering applies to those sin offerings with regard to which the Torah uses the term sprinkling, the blood of <b>a bird sin offering</b> should require laundering <b>as well,</b> as sprinkling is also mentioned with regard to it (see Leviticus 5:9). The Gemara answers: <b>The Merciful One excludes</b> bird offerings by stating: <b>“This</b> is the law of the sin offering.” The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> that the function of this verse is to be understood as a restriction, <b>an external</b> sin offering <b>also</b> should <b>not</b> require laundering. The Gemara responds: <b>The Merciful One amplified</b> the <i>halakha</i> to include external sin offerings by stating: <b>“The law of.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that convinced you to exclude bird offerings and include external sin offerings? The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that the eaten <b>animal sin offering should have been included, as</b> the eaten animal sin offering resembles the internal sin offering in several respects: Each is a large <b>animal;</b> each is subject to <b>slaughter on the north</b> side of the courtyard; <b>and</b> the blood of each requires <b>collection in a vessel; and</b> their blood is placed on the <b>corner</b> of the altar; <b>and</b> the blood is placed with a priest’s <b>finger; and</b> the blood is placed on <b>the edge of</b> the corner of the altar; <b>and</b> parts of each are consumed in <b>flames</b> upon the altar. None of these apply to bird sin offerings.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>On the contrary,</b> the <b>bird sin offering should have been included</b> in the requirement for laundering, <b>as</b> the offering of the blood of the bird sin offering is termed <b>sprinkling,</b> just <b>like it</b> is in the case of the internal sin offering. The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> features common to internal sin offerings and eaten animal sin offerings <b>are more numerous</b> than the features common to internal sin offerings and bird sin offerings.
§ The Gemara indicated that the blood of the bird sin offering is not received in a vessel, unlike that of animal sin offerings. With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rabbi Avin asks:</b> When the blood of an eaten animal sin offering is brought into the Sanctuary in a vessel, this disqualifies it. In the case of <b>a bird sin offering,</b> which is killed by pinching the nape of its neck, <b>whose blood</b> a priest <b>brought inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>in its neck, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is <b>its neck comparable to a service vessel,</b> since it is from its neck that the blood is presented, <b>and</b> therefore it is <b>disqualified</b> if brought into the Sanctuary this way?
<b>Or perhaps</b> is its neck <b>comparable to the neck of</b> a large <b>animal</b> offering, about which <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“Of whose blood</b> is brought into the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 6:23), which teaches that its blood is disqualified when brought inside in a service vessel, <b>but</b> the blood is <b>not</b> disqualified when the animal’s <b>flesh</b> is brought inside. What is the status of the bird’s neck? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If, after its nape is pinched, a bird sin offering <b>convulsed and</b> consequently <b>entered inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>and</b> then it <b>returned</b> to the courtyard, it remains <b>valid;</b> its blood may be sprinkled and its meat eaten. It can be inferred that the bird offering remains valid if it has entered on its own, <b>but</b> if a priest has <b>brought it in,</b> it is <b>disqualified</b> because of the blood in its neck.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>But according to your reasoning,</b> one might draw a faulty inference from the <i>halakha</i> of a convulsing offering, as follows. <b>With regard to</b> an animal <b>offering of the most sacred order,</b> about <b>which it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If, after being slaughtered appropriately on the north side of the courtyard, the animal <b>convulsed, and</b> consequently it <b>went out to the south</b> side of the courtyard <b>and</b> then <b>returned</b> to the north side, it remains <b>valid;</b> should it be inferred: <b>But</b> if a priest <b>took it out</b> to the south side it becomes <b>disqualified?</b> The sacrifice is certainly not disqualified by being taken to the south side of the courtyard, and the inference is incorrect.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be assumed that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that of the convulsing animal that moved from the northern side to the southern side, is taught for another purpose. It <b>was necessary for</b> the <i>baraita</i> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in order to establish a contrast with an animal that <b>went out to the outside</b> beyond the courtyard, which is disqualified even if it goes out by itself. <b>Here, too,</b> with regard to the bird sin offering, the <i>halakha</i> of the convulsing animal that moved into the Sanctuary is taught for another purpose. This <i>halakha</i> <b>was necessary for</b> establishing a contrast with a bird offering that <b>went out to the outside</b> beyond the courtyard, which is disqualified even if it goes out by itself. Accordingly, this may not be used to resolve Rabbi Avin’s dilemma.
§ <b>Rabbi Avin asks</b> another question about the blood of a bird offering, which is sprinkled directly from the body of the bird and not collected in a service vessel. With regard to the blood of a large animal, which spills on the floor before it is received in a service vessel, it becomes disqualified for presentation (see 25a), but if it spills after it is received in a vessel, it may be collected from the floor and presented (see 32a). If the blood of a bird offering <b>spilled onto the floor and</b> the priest <b>collected it</b> from the floor in order to sprinkle it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Is it simply that <b>the Merciful One did not require a service vessel</b> for the collection of the bird’s blood, <b>and therefore</b> a priest <b>may collect it</b> from the floor <b>and</b> it remains <b>fit</b> for sprinkling on the altar? <b>Or perhaps the Merciful One rendered a service vessel unfit for</b> sprinkling <b>it</b> in any case, and the blood must be sprinkled directly from the bird’s body, <b>and therefore,</b> if it spills on the floor and the priest <b>collects it,</b> it is <b>unfit</b> for sprinkling.
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, deduced from a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>the blood of a bird sin offering would require laundering</b> if sprayed on a garment. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This</b> is the law of the sin offering” (Leviticus 6:18), which excludes the bird sin offering. <b>But if it enters your mind</b> that <b>the Merciful One rendered</b> a vessel <b>unfit for</b> sprinkling the blood of a bird, this interpretation is unnecessary. <b>I will deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a bird’s blood does not require laundering <b>because</b> the blood <b>becomes disqualified</b> even by merely passing <b>into the airspace of a vessel.</b> Consequently, the blood is disqualified when coming into the airspace of the garment, which is considered a vessel, and, as disqualified blood, it does not subsequently require laundering.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> provides no decisive proof, as even if a bird’s blood is disqualified by passing into the airspace of a vessel, the word “this” must still be interpreted to exclude the blood of a bird sin offering from the requirement of laundering. The interpretation of the verse accounts for cases in which the blood reaches the vessel without first passing into its airspace, as <b>in</b> a case when the priest <b>affixes a vessel to</b> the bird’s <b>neck.</b> Consequently, no resolution can be derived for Rav Avin’s question.
§ The Gemara returns to the primary subject of the mishna, the requirement of laundering garments from the sprayed blood of a sin offering. <b>Levi asked</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: If the blood of an offering <b>sprayed from</b> one <b>garment to</b> another <b>garment, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>By</b> contact with the <b>first garment,</b> is the blood thereby <b>dismissed</b> with regard to the requirement <b>of laundering,</b> such that a subsequent garment would not require laundering? <b>Or perhaps not.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: This</b> is an excellent <b>question;</b> and the answer is: The garment <b>requires laundering whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it. <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that with regard to blood that sprayed onto a garment the priest <b>may collect it and</b> it is still <b>fit</b> for presentation on the altar, then <b>this</b> blood is also <b>fit.</b> Consequently, even the second garment must be laundered. <b>And if</b> you say that with regard to blood that sprayed onto a garment if <b>he collects it, it is unfit</b> for presentation, <b>I hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says:</b> If the offering <b>had a period of fitness and</b> then <b>was disqualified, its blood requires laundering.</b> Accordingly, since the blood upon the second garment was initially collected in a service vessel, it too had a period of fitness.

Daf 93a

§ In a related matter, <b>Rami bar Ḥama asked of Rav Ḥisda:</b> If the blood of a sin offering <b>sprayed onto a ritually impure garment,</b> so that the blood became impure and unfit for presentation, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does the garment require laundering? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: From</b> the fact <b>that</b> Rami bar Ḥama <b>asked</b> the question in <b>this</b> manner, with regard to ritually pure blood that sprayed onto an impure garment, and not with regard to blood that was already impure that sprayed onto a garment, <b>conclude from it</b> that he holds that even if the sin offering <b>had a period of fitness and</b> then <b>was disqualified,</b> a garment onto which <b>its blood</b> sprayed <b>does not require laundering.</b>
His question, therefore, is: Does <b>this statement</b> apply only when <b>one</b> event, the spraying of the blood, occurs <b>after the other</b> event, i.e., the disqualification of the blood? <b>But</b> if the spraying and the disqualification occur <b>simultaneously,</b> as in this case, perhaps the principle does <b>not</b> apply, and the garment must be laundered. <b>Or, perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether the events occur this way or that way, and even if the offering becomes unfit only as the blood touches the garment, it still does not require laundering? Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: The matter is subject to <b>the dispute between Rabbi Elazar and the Rabbis, in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>of Rabba, and as Abaye resolves</b> it.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> With regard to <b>water of purification, which</b> has been sanctified by the ashes of the red heifer, even if the water is <b>rendered impure</b> it nevertheless performs its function and <b>purifies</b> a person from the ritual impurity imparted by a corpse. This is evident <b>because</b> those performing the rite would <b>sprinkle</b> water of purification even <b>on a menstruating woman</b> who has been rendered impure by a corpse. Although her menstruation impurity renders the water of purification impure when it touches her, it is effective in removing the ritual impurity imparted by a corpse. Rabbi Elazar’s opinion is in opposition to that of the Rabbis.
<b>And</b> concerning this dispute, <b>Rabba says:</b> Although it would seem that the water of purification applied to a menstruating woman does not become impure until it touches her, the case may still provide precedent for all water of purification that has become impure, as follows: <b>Rabbi Elazar stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the opinion of his teacher Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that <b>passing a vessel</b> containing water of purification <b>over</b> the <b>place</b> where <b>a ritually impure</b> item is renders the vessel <b>considered as</b> if <b>resting</b> there, so that the water becomes impure. Consequently, just as the water of purification is effective for the menstruating woman although it has become impure when hovering above her, water of purification always remains effective after having contracted ritual impurity.
That is Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 10:5): There is a dispute with regard to the case of a ritually pure person who <b>was standing beyond an oven,</b> which stood between him and the wall, <b>and</b> a carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which imparts impurity, was <b>in the oven; and</b> the person <b>stretched out his hand to the window and took the jug [<i>halagin</i>]</b> containing water of purification <b>and passed it over the opening of the oven. Rabbi Akiva deems</b> the water of purification <b>impure,</b> although the jug has merely passed over the oven’s opening and has not come to rest on it, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> the water <b>pure. And</b> according to Rabba, <b>in this</b> manner <b>do they disagree: That Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that the jug is <b>considered as</b> if <b>resting</b> on the opening of the oven, <b>and the Rabbis hold</b> that the jug is <b>not considered as</b> if <b>resting</b> there.
<b>And Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s interpretation from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Para</i> 10:6): Although he deems the water of purification impure in the previous case, <b>Rabbi Akiva concedes</b> that <b>in</b> the act of <b>sprinkling,</b> in <b>which</b> the person <b>passed</b> the water of purification <b>over an impure earthenware vessel</b> or <b>over</b> an impure item designated for <b>lying or sitting,</b> the water remains <b>pure.</b> This is so <b>because there is nothing that renders impure</b> all that is in the airspace directly <b>above</b> it, <b>like</b> anything <b>below</b> that touches it, <b>other than an olive-bulk from a corpse and all other</b> items which impart ritual impurity to those items <b>which overlie</b> them, <b>including a stone marked</b> with leprosy. Such a stone also imparts overlying impurity, rendering impure anything under the same roof or, if there is no roof, in the airspace directly above it up to the sky.
<b>Rather, Abaye said: Everyone</b> agrees that a vessel containing water of purification passing over an item that is ritually impure <b>is not considered as</b> if it is <b>resting</b> on it. <b>And here,</b> with regard to the jug being taken over the oven, <b>they disagree about this: Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>we decree</b> that the vessel contracts impurity by rabbinic law, since <b>perhaps</b> a vessel carried above an impure item <b>will</b> come to <b>rest</b> directly on that impure item. <b>And the Rabbis hold: We do not decree</b> that the vessel contracts impurity in such a case. <b>And Rabbi Akiva concedes</b> that <b>in</b> the act of <b>sprinkling,</b> while the water passes over an impure item, <b>once it has set forth</b> into the air, <b>it has set forth.</b> Since the water has left the person’s hand, the person cannot leave it to rest upon an impure item.
The Gemara asks: If so, Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis would agree that the water of purification does not become impure before touching a menstruating woman. <b>And,</b> if so, then <b>Rabbi Elazar and the Rabbis,</b> who disagree as to whether impure water of purification renders one pure, <b>with regard to what</b> case <b>do they disagree? Abaye said: They disagree with regard to</b> whether one may <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>impurity</b> rendered <b>earlier,</b> before sprinkling the water of purification, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>impurity</b> rendered <b>at that</b> very <b>moment</b> that the purification occurs, as in the case of the menstruating woman.
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>holds:</b> One <b>derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this manner, and, therefore, the water effects purification even if the water has become impure first. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that one does <b>not derive</b> this <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, Rav Ḥisda’s answer to Rami bar Hama is that, according to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, if the impurity occurs in the moment that the sin offering’s blood touches the impure garment, the <i>halakha</i> is the same as it is when the blood has become impure before reaching the garment. In both cases, the garment is exempt from laundering. According to the opinion of the Rabbis, the <i>halakha</i> is not the same in both cases: If the blood becomes impure at the very moment it reaches the garment, laundering is required.
<b>Rava said:</b> The case of sprinkling water of purification upon a menstruating woman has no bearing upon the case of the sprayed garment, <b>as everyone</b> holds that one does <b>not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of impurity incurred earlier from the <i>halakha</i> of impurity incurred at that very moment.
Rava continues: <b>But here,</b> with regard to the precedent of the menstruating woman, <b>they disagree about this: Rabbi Elazar holds</b> that <b>sprinkling</b> the water of purification <b>requires</b> a specific <b>measure</b> of the water, <b>but</b> sprinklings of small quantities <b>combine to</b> constitute <b>sprinklings</b> of the required measure. Therefore, if the initial sprinkling on the woman does not contain a sufficient measure of water, the small quantity of water of purification first becomes impure, but it later combines with the subsequent sprinkling to purify her. Consequently, water of purification that has already become impure may effect purification. <b>But the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>sprinkling</b> of the water <b>does not require a measure.</b> Accordingly, the woman is purified by the initial sprinkling, although the purification water becomes impure at the very moment that it reaches her; and this does not have any bearing on a case in which the purification water is impure before it touches the person upon whom it is sprinkled.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>a disqualified sin offering,</b> a garment on which its blood is sprayed does not require laundering, whether the offering had a moment of qualification when its blood was fit for sprinkling or whether it did not have a moment of qualification. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a garment on which the blood of a sin offering sprayed, the verse states: “And when any <b>of its blood</b> shall be sprinkled on a garment” (Leviticus 6:20), teaching that laundering is required when some <b>of the blood of a fit</b> sin offering is sprayed on the garment, <b>but</b> this is <b>not</b> so in the case <b>of the blood of a disqualified</b> sin offering. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> If the sin offering <b>had a period of fitness and</b> then <b>was disqualified,</b> a garment onto which <b>its blood</b> sprayed still <b>requires laundering.</b> If it <b>did not have a period of fitness</b> at all <b>and was</b> then <b>disqualified,</b> a garment onto which <b>its blood</b> sprayed <b>does not require laundering.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to <b>both this</b> sin offering that had a period of fitness <b>and that</b> sin offering that did not, a garment onto which <b>its blood</b> sprayed <b>does not require laundering. What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is written</b> in the Torah with regard to laundering the blood of a sin offering: “Every male among the priests may eat <b>it”</b> (Leviticus 6:22), and only it. <b>And it is written</b> earlier in that same section: <b>“Of its blood”</b> (Leviticus 6:20), but not all its blood. Therefore, there are two exclusionary terms; <b>one</b> excludes laundering <b>for</b> the situation <b>where</b> the unfit offering <b>had a period of fitness,</b> and the other excludes a situation in which the offering did not have a period of fitness.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> interpret these verses? From the term “of its blood” he derives that the offering that has no period of fitness is excluded. The exclusion indicated by the word <b>“it”</b> teaches that the requirement for scouring and rinsing a copper vessel in which sacred food was cooked <b>excludes <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., scouring and rinsing is not required for a vessel in which <i>teruma</i> was cooked. <b>And</b> rejecting Rabbi Akiva’s understanding, <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Offerings of lesser sanctity do not require scouring and rinsing</b> as explained on 96b, <b>and all the more so</b> does <b><i>teruma</i></b> not require this. Consequently, Rabbi Shimon does not need a verse to exclude <i>teruma</i>, and he interprets the verse to exclude both a sin offering that had a period of fitness and a sin offering that did not have a period of fitness.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the blood of a sin offering <b>sprayed from the neck</b> of the animal <b>onto a garment,</b> the garment <b>does not require laundering.</b> If the blood was collected in a vessel and sprinkled on the altar and sprayed <b>from the corner or from the base</b> of the altar onto the garment, the garment <b>does not require laundering,</b> as the blood was already sprinkled and its mitzva was fulfilled. If the blood <b>spilled</b> from the neck <b>onto the floor</b> before it was collected in a vessel, <b>and</b> the priest <b>collected</b> the blood and it sprayed on a garment, the garment <b>does not require laundering.</b> It is <b>only</b> with regard to <b>blood that was received in</b> a sacred <b>vessel and is fit for sprinkling</b> that the garment <b>requires laundering.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara cites sources for the <i>halakhot</i> mentioned in the mishna. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that if blood <b>sprayed from the neck</b> of the animal <b>onto a garment,</b> the garment <b>should require laundering.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “On <b>which it shall be sprinkled”</b> (Leviticus 6:20), which teaches: <b>I told you</b> that a garment requires laundering <b>only with regard to</b> blood which is <b>fit for sprinkling,</b> which must be collected in a vessel directly from the neck of the animal. <b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that if blood <b>sprayed from the corner or from the base</b> of the altar, the garment <b>should require laundering.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “On <b>which it shall be sprinkled,” excluding that</b> blood <b>that was already sprinkled.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If the blood <b>spilled</b> from the neck <b>onto the floor</b> before it was collected in a vessel, and the priest collected the blood and it sprayed on a garment, the garment does not require laundering. It is only with regard to blood that was received in a sacred vessel and is fit for sprinkling that the garment requires laundering.

Daf 93b

With regard to the statement that only blood that was collected in a vessel and is fit for sprinkling requires the laundering of the garment on which it sprayed, the Gemara asks: <b>Why do I also</b> need <b>this?</b> After all, it was already taught that if blood spilled from the neck onto the floor before it was collected in a vessel, and it sprayed on a garment, the garment does not require laundering. The Gemara answers: This is not an additional <i>halakha</i>, but rather the mishna <b>is saying: What is the reason? What is the reason</b> that if the blood <b>spilled</b> from the neck <b>onto the floor</b> before it was collected in a vessel, <b>and</b> the priest <b>collected it</b> and it sprayed on a garment, the garment <b>does not require laundering?</b> This is <b>because</b> it is <b>only</b> with regard to <b>blood that was received in</b> a sacred <b>vessel and is fit for sprinkling</b> that the garment <b>requires laundering.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: It is only with regard to blood that was received in a sacred vessel and is <b>fit for sprinkling</b> that the garment <b>requires laundering.</b> The Gemara asks: As it was already taught that when disqualified blood is sprayed on a garment, it does not require laundering, this reiteration serves <b>to exclude what?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to exclude</b> the case where a priest <b>received less</b> blood <b>than</b> is <b>sufficient for sprinkling in this vessel, and less than</b> is <b>sufficient for sprinkling in that vessel,</b> and then he mixed together the blood from the two vessels. In such a case, even though the combined amount is now enough for sprinkling, the blood did not become fit for sprinkling.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the sanctification of water of purification, <b>Rabbi Ḥalafta bar Shaul says:</b> If a priest <b>sanctified less than</b> is <b>sufficient for sprinkling in this vessel and less than</b> is <b>sufficient for sprinkling in that vessel,</b> and he then mixed together the water from the two vessels, he <b>has not sanctified</b> it to become water of purification.
In a related issue, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a priest did this <b>for</b> the <b>blood</b> of an internal sin offering, collecting less than is sufficient for sprinkling in each vessel and then mixing all the blood together, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is</b> Rabbi Ḥalafta’s statement about the water of purification <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and we do not learn from</b> such <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> an application to a different matter?
<b>Or, perhaps: What is the reason there,</b> that the combined water of purification is not fit for sprinkling? It may be <b>because it is written</b> about sprinkling the water: <b>“And dip it in the water”</b> (Numbers 19:18), stressing that it is to be dipped in precisely the same water that was first placed in the vessel. This indicates that from the outset there must be an amount sufficient for sprinkling. If so, then <b>here also</b> there is comparable language employed with regard to the blood of a sin offering. <b>It is written: “And</b> the priest shall <b>dip</b> his finger <b>in the blood,</b> and sprinkle of the blood” (Leviticus 4:6). Does this prove that from the outset there must be sufficient blood for sprinkling?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as Rabbi Zerika says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even in</b> the case of the <b>blood</b> of a sin offering, if one collected two insufficient amounts and then mixed them together, he <b>did not sanctify</b> the blood to make it fit for sprinkling on the altar, and therefore, if it sprays on a garment, one is not required to launder the garment.
§ <b>Rava says: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the internal sin offering, whose blood is sprinkled in the Sanctuary: The verse states: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger in the blood, and sprinkle of the blood” (Leviticus 4:6); <b>and</b> there must be enough blood in the vessel for the priest to dip his finger in it so that he does <b>not</b> need to <b>wipe</b> blood from the sides or the bottom of the vessel onto his finger. The verse states: <b>“In the blood,”</b> teaching that the blood is unfit for sprinkling <b>unless there is a measure of the blood</b> fit for <b>dipping</b> in the vessel <b>from the outset,</b> and the blood is disqualified if more blood is added to a vessel that initially contained less than the required measure. The verse states: “Sprinkle <b>of the blood,”</b> which teaches that he must sprinkle <b>of the blood that is</b> mentioned <b>in</b> this <b>matter,</b> which is the blood in the vessel.
<b>And it was necessary</b> for the Torah <b>to write</b> the term: <b>“In the blood,”</b> as well as the term: “And the priest shall dip.” <b>As, had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip,” I would say</b> that if there is sufficient blood at the time of dipping, <b>even though there was not a measure</b> of blood fit for <b>dipping</b> in the vessel <b>from the beginning,</b> it is nevertheless fit for dipping. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “In the blood,”</b> to teach that there must be sufficient blood from the beginning.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“In the blood,” I would say</b> that if at the beginning there was an appropriate measure of blood, it is not necessary for the vessel to retain a measure of enough blood throughout the whole rite, and <b>even</b> if he eventually <b>wipes</b> blood off of the vessel onto his finger, it is sufficient for sprinkling. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “And</b> the priest <b>shall dip,”</b> to teach that there must remain enough blood to dip his finger each time.
The cited <i>baraita</i> states: The verse states: “Sprinkle of the blood,” which teaches that he must sprinkle <b>of the blood that is</b> mentioned <b>in</b> this <b>matter,</b> which is the blood in the vessel. The Gemara asks: In order <b>to exclude what</b> was this mentioned? <b>Rava said:</b> This serves <b>to exclude the remainder</b> of the blood <b>that is on the</b> priest’s <b>finger</b> after sprinkling, which may not be used for further sprinkling, as he must dip his finger in the blood again for each sprinkle. Rava continues: This <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar says: The remainder</b> of the blood <b>that is on the</b> priest’s <b>finger</b> after sprinkling is <b>unfit</b> for further sprinkling.
<b>Ravin bar Rav Adda said to Rav,</b> i.e., Rava: <b>Your student says</b> that <b>Rav Amram says: We</b> already <b>learn</b> a <i>baraita</i> opposing Rabbi Elazar’s opinion: If a priest <b>was sprinkling</b> the blood of an internal sin offering, <b>and a sprinkle sprayed from his hand</b> onto a garment, the <i>halakha</i> depends on the circumstances. If it sprayed <b>before he sprinkled,</b> the garment <b>requires laundering,</b> but if it sprayed <b>once he has sprinkled,</b> it <b>does not require laundering.</b>
Ravin bar Rav Adda explains: <b>What, is it not this</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the blood sprayed on a garment <b>before</b> the priest <b>concluded sprinkling,</b> the garment <b>requires laundering,</b> even if it sprayed from the remainder on his finger; but if it sprayed <b>once</b> the priest <b>has concluded sprinkling, it does not require laundering?</b> This indicates that blood sprayed from the remainder on his finger requires laundering, so it must be fit for sprinkling. Rava replied: <b>No, this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If the blood sprayed on a garment <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling has left his hand, it requires laundering,</b> but if it sprayed <b>once</b> the <b>sprinkling has left his hand,</b> the remainder on his finger <b>does not require laundering</b> if it then sprays onto a garment.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabbi Elazar’s opinion from what is taught about sprinkling the blood of the red heifer in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 3:9): When the priest has <b>concluded sprinkling</b> the blood, <b>he wipes his hand on the body of</b> the red <b>heifer.</b> Evidently, if he <b>concluded</b> sprinkling, <b>yes,</b> he does wipe his hand; but if he <b>did not conclude</b> sprinkling, he does <b>not</b> wipe his hand, even though a remainder is left on his finger. Evidently, this remainder is fit for sprinkling. Rava <b>said to him:</b> The mishna is to be understood otherwise: If he <b>concluded</b> sprinkling, <b>he wipes his</b> entire <b>hand on the body of the</b> red <b>heifer;</b> but if he <b>has not concluded</b> sprinkling, <b>he wipes</b> only <b>his finger</b> after each sprinkling.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> if he <b>concluded</b> sprinkling, <b>he wipes his hand on the body of</b> the red <b>heifer, as it is stated: “And the heifer shall be burned in his sight;</b> its skin, and its flesh, and its blood” (Numbers 19:5), indicating that the remaining blood must be incinerated together with the flesh. <b>But on what does he wipe his finger</b> after each sprinkling, since he must not wipe it on the body of the heifer, which might cause hair to stick to his finger, interfering with the sprinkling? <b>Abaye said:</b> He wipes his finger <b>on the lip of</b> the <b>bowl</b> holding the blood for sprinkling, <b>as it is written: “Atoning bowls [<i>keforei</i>] of gold”</b> (Ezra 1:10). The atoning bowls are so named because the priest wipes his finger on them, and the word <i>keforei</i> indicates cleansing by way of wiping (see <i>Ḥullin</i> 8b).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Apropos laundering the blood of a sin offering from garments onto which it sprayed, the mishna discusses what is considered a garment. If the blood of a sin offering <b>sprayed onto the hide</b> of an animal <b>before it was flayed</b> from the animal, the hide <b>does not require laundering,</b> because its status is not that of a garment, which is susceptible to ritual impurity. If the blood sprayed onto the hide <b>after it was flayed, it requires laundering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even</b> if the blood sprayed onto the hide <b>after it was flayed, it does not require laundering</b> until it is crafted into a vessel or garment that is actually susceptible to ritual impurity. This is the principle with regard to laundering: A garment must be laundered <b>only</b> in the <b>place</b> where <b>the blood</b> was sprayed, <b>and</b> only if it is <b>an item that is fit to become ritually impure, and</b> only if it is an item <b>fit for laundering.</b>
With regard to <b>the garment</b> mentioned explicitly in the Torah, <b>and the sackcloth, and the hide, all</b> of these <b>require laundering. And the laundering</b> must be performed <b>in a sacred place,</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and the breaking of an earthenware vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked must be performed <b>in a sacred place, and scouring and rinsing of a copper vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked must be performed <b>in a sacred place.</b> With regard to <b>this</b> matter, <b>a stringency</b> applies <b>to a sin offering</b> more <b>than</b> it applies to <b>offerings of the most sacred order.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to blood sprayed on a flayed hide, <b>from where are these matters,</b> i.e., the divergent opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar, derived? The Gemara explains: They are derived <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is stated with regard to laundering: “And when any of its blood shall be sprinkled on <b>a garment”</b> (Leviticus 6:20). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only a garment; from where</b> do I <b>include</b> an animal’s <b>hide after it was flayed? The</b> same <b>verse states: “You shall launder that on which it shall be sprinkled,”</b> to include any item on which the blood sprayed.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> would <b>include a hide</b> even <b>before it was flayed.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “Garment.”</b> Consequently, <b>just as</b> any manner of <b>garment</b> is an item <b>fit to become ritually impure</b> if one intends to use it, e.g., making it a patch for his clothing, <b>so too</b> the requirement of laundering applies to <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> becomes <b>fit to become ritually impure</b> when one intends to use it as is. A hide is fit to become ritually impure after it has been flayed, when one intends to use it for a rug or the like; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar</b> holds that, even after it is flayed, the hide does not require laundering. In interpreting the verse, he <b>says:</b> The verse states: <b>“Garment,”</b> and from this <b>I have</b> derived <b>only a garment; from where</b> do I <b>include sackcloth</b>

Daf 94a

<b>and all types of garments</b> made of other materials in the requirement of laundering? <b>The verse states: “You shall launder that on which</b> it shall be sprinkled.” One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I include</b> an animal’s <b>hide after it was flayed.</b> That <b>verse states: “Garment,”</b> to teach that <b>just as a garment is an item that is susceptible to ritual impurity</b> as is, <b>so too any</b> comparable <b>item that is</b> a ready utensil and therefore <b>susceptible to impurity</b> must be laundered. Accordingly, Rabbi Elazar holds that merely flaying a hide is insufficient to render it an item that must be laundered.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the practical difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar? Is there an item that is fit to become ritually impure, but is not actually susceptible to impurity? <b>Abaye said: A patch</b> of cloth <b>less than three</b> by three fingerbreadths presents a practical difference <b>between</b> the two opinions. According to <b>the one who says</b> that any garment <b>fit</b> to become ritually impure must be laundered, <b>this</b> patch of cloth <b>is also fit</b> to become ritually impure, <b>as if</b> the owner <b>wants, he can intend it</b> for a specific use, as in patching his garment. According to <b>the one who says</b> that only <b>an object</b> already <b>susceptible to impurity</b> must be laundered, <b>this</b> patch, <b>in any event, is not</b> yet <b>susceptible to impurity</b> so it does not require laundering.
<b>Rava said: A garment upon which</b> an individual initially <b>intended to</b> place <b>an image</b> constitutes a practical difference <b>between</b> the two opinions. Since the garment was initially intended to have an adornment, the garment is considered incomplete and not yet susceptible to impurity until the image is added. According to <b>the one who says</b> that any garment <b>fit</b> to become ritually impure requires laundering, <b>this</b> garment <b>is also fit</b> to become ritually impure, <b>as if</b> the owner <b>wants</b> to, <b>he can void his intention</b> to add the image, and the garment will be automatically susceptible to impurity. According to <b>the one who says</b> that only <b>an item</b> already <b>susceptible to impurity</b> requires laundering, <b>now, at least,</b> this garment <b>is not susceptible to impurity</b> and does not require laundering.
According to a different version, <b>Rava said: An unfinished hide [<i>utzeva</i>] that one intended to trim</b> in a precise manner constitutes a practical difference <b>between</b> the two opinions. According to <b>the one who says</b> that any garment-like item <b>fit</b> to become ritually impure must be laundered, <b>this</b> hide must be laundered, since it <b>is also fit</b> to be susceptible to impurity if he voids his intention. According to <b>the one who says</b> that only <b>an item</b> already <b>susceptible to impurity</b> must be laundered, <b>this</b> hide does not require laundering since it <b>is not susceptible to impurity until he trims it.</b> This explanation may be corroborated, as <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: An unfinished hide that</b> one <b>intended to trim is ritually pure until he trims it.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: A garment <b>requires laundering</b> only in the place that the blood was sprayed; but the entire garment does not require laundering. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? They are derived from a verse, <b>as the Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “And when any of its blood shall be sprinkled on a garment.” One <b>might</b> have thought that even if the blood <b>sprayed</b> only <b>on part of a garment, the entire garment should require laundering.</b> To counter this, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states:</b> “That on <b>which it shall be sprinkled.”</b> This is to be understood: <b>I told you</b> that laundering is required <b>only</b> in <b>the place</b> that the <b>blood</b> was sprayed.
The mishna also teaches: A garment must be laundered only if it is <b>an item that is fit to become ritually impure,</b> and only if it is an item fit for laundering. The Gemara observes: Evidently, <b>the unattributed</b> portion of the mishna is taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> This statement is unlike the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, who holds that only an item that is presently susceptible to impurity requires laundering.
The mishna also teaches: Only an item <b>fit for laundering</b> must be laundered. The Gemara observes: This qualification serves <b>to exclude a vessel</b> from the requirement of laundering, <b>as it is suitable for scraping</b> blood off of it. Laundering is necessary only for material or fabric into which blood is absorbed.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>the garment</b> mentioned explicitly in the Torah, <b>and the sackcloth,</b> and the hide, all of these must be laundered. Apparently, <b>that is to say that a hide,</b> i.e., leather, <b>is suitable for laundering. And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between that assumption and a mishna that discusses laundering on Shabbat (<i>Shabbat</i> 142b): If <b>there were bird droppings [<i>lishleshet</i>] on</b> the cushion, one <b>wipes it with a</b> dry <b>rag,</b> but one may not rinse it with water because of the prohibition against laundering. If <b>it was on</b> a cushion <b>of leather, he applies water to it until</b> the filthy substance <b>dissolves.</b> Evidently, cleaning leather with water is not considered laundering.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This contradiction is <b>not difficult. That</b> mishna in tractate <i>Shabbat</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and <b>this</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>others. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> about the blood of a sin offering: If blood sprays onto <b>a garment or</b> onto <b>sackcloth, he launders it;</b> but if it sprays onto a <b>vessel or</b> onto <b>leather, he scrapes it</b> off. <b>Others say:</b> If it sprays onto <b>a garment, or</b> onto <b>sackcloth, or</b> onto <b>leather, he launders it; but</b> if it sprays onto <b>a vessel, he scrapes it</b> off. According to this <i>baraita</i>, the Rabbis hold that laundering is not applicable to leather, and the opinion attributed to: Others say, holds that it is applicable.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: Many times I would stand before Rav</b> on Shabbat <b>and place water on his</b> leather <b>shoes,</b> which he did not consider laundering on Shabbat? <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> in this <i>baraita</i>.
§ <b>Rava said: And is there anyone who says</b> that <b>leather is not suitable for laundering? But isn’t it written</b> with regard to leprosy: <b>“And the garment, or the warp, or the woof, or any article of leather that you shall wash”</b> (Leviticus 13:58)? <b>Rather, Rava said: The verse</b> that speaks of leprosy <b>and the mishna</b> that speaks of the sin offering are ruling <b>with regard to soft</b> leather, which is considered subject to laundering. In the <i>baraita</i>, <b>when</b> the Rabbis and the others <b>disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> an item that is made of <b>hard</b> leather; as the Rabbis hold that laundering does not apply to hard leather.
The Gemara challenges Rava’s explanation: <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥiyya</b> bar Ashi <b>say: Many times I would stand before Rav</b> on Shabbat <b>and place water on his</b> leather <b>shoes,</b> which he did not consider laundering on Shabbat? Since shoes are normally made of soft leather, according to Rava’s explanation, this should have constituted laundering on Shabbat. The Gemara resolves the difficulty: It was a case <b>of hard</b> leather shoes, <b>and</b> Rav acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that laundering does not apply to hard leather.
<b>Rava then said:</b> That <b>which I said,</b> that the verse about leprosy relates to soft leather, <b>is not correct. Shall we stand</b> and <b>say of the verse that when</b> leather articles <b>are written,</b> it is only <b>of soft</b> leather articles that the Torah <b>writes?</b> A verse cannot be constrained in such a manner. <b>Are we not</b> also <b>dealing with articles of hard leather [<i>aksilgiyya</i>] that come from overseas, and</b> yet <b>the Merciful One says</b> in the verse that <b>they require laundering?</b>
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> Although the verse also relates to hard leather, this does not mean that all opinions must agree that laundering is always applicable to hard leather. The hard leather in the verse is an exception, because in the case of <b>leprosy, since</b> leprosy <b>sprouts from</b> within the garment <b>itself, it loosens it and renders it soft</b> so that its halakhic status is that of soft leather. <b>Rava said:</b> Nevertheless, <b>if</b> something poses <b>a difficulty for me,</b> according to my opinion that everyone agrees that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to laundering applies to soft leather, <b>this</b> is what poses <b>a difficulty for me:</b>

Daf 94b

<b>Cushions and blankets that are</b> of <b>soft</b> leather, and for which the <i>halakha</i> with regard to laundering should be relevant, <b>and</b> yet <b>we learned</b> about them in the mishna (<i>Shabbat</i> 142b): If the filth <b>was</b> on a cushion <b>of leather, he applies water to it until</b> the filth <b>dissolves,</b> which indicates that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to laundering is not applicable even to soft leather. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>any laundering that does not include rubbing,</b> it <b>is not considered laundering.</b> Consequently, one may apply water to a soft leather cushion, but soft leather remains subject to laundering, so long as there is rubbing.
<b>And that</b> statement <b>that Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said: Many times I would stand before Rav</b> on Shabbat <b>and place water on his</b> leather <b>shoes,</b> may be explained accordingly. With regard to <b>placing</b> water on leather, <b>yes,</b> that is permitted, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>laundering,</b> which includes rubbing, it is <b>not</b> permitted. This may be explained as follows: <b>If</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi spoke <b>of soft</b> leather shoes, then <b>all agree</b> that only placing water is permitted. And <b>if</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi spoke <b>of hard</b> leather shoes, the distinction between placing and rubbing <b>accords with</b> the opinion of <b>the others,</b> who hold that the requirement of laundering sprayed blood applies even to hard leather.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that placing water upon something is not considered laundering so long as one does not also rub the item, then with regard to a non-leather <b>garment as well,</b> one should be allowed to place water upon it on Shabbat. Why does the cited mishna state that one may wipe it only with a dry rag? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>a garment, its soaking is its laundering,</b> and merely placing water on it is forbidden.
The Gemara comments: <b>Rava</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning; as Rava says:</b> If one <b>cast a cloth into water</b> on Shabbat, he is <b>liable</b> for laundering on Shabbat, as it is made of fabric like any garment; and if <b>one cast flax</b> seeds <b>into water,</b> he too is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>Granted,</b> if he casts <b>a cloth</b> into water, he <b>performs laundering; but</b> with regard to <b>flaxseed, what is the reason</b> that one may not cast it into water on Shabbat?
<b>And if you would say</b> that it is prohibited <b>because it sprouts</b> in the water and constitutes the prohibited act of planting, <b>if so,</b> with regard to <b>wheat and barley,</b> it should <b>also</b> be forbidden to place them into water. The Gemara explains: Casting the flax into the water is not prohibited because of planting but because <b>these</b> flax seeds <b>have discharges</b> when soaked. <b>If so,</b> with regard to <b>hides,</b> it should <b>also</b> be prohibited to place them into water, because they too produce discharges in water. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to flaxseed, it is prohibited because it <b>effects kneading,</b> as the discharges cause the seeds to combine together, which is not true of hides.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rava taught</b> in public: It is <b>permitted to launder a shoe on Shabbat. Rav Pappa said to Rava: But didn’t Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi say: Many times I would stand before Rav</b> on Shabbat <b>and place water on his</b> leather <b>shoes?</b> Evidently, <b>placing</b> water upon leather, <b>yes,</b> that is permitted, <b>but laundering,</b> which includes rubbing, is <b>not</b> permitted. <b>Rava went back and placed an interpreter before him</b> so that he could tell the public that he had been wrong, <b>and taught</b> in public: The <b>statements that I said before you</b> earlier <b>are my error. Truly,</b> the Sages <b>said like this: Placing</b> water upon shoes is <b>permitted,</b> but <b>laundering</b> them is <b>prohibited.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>The laundering</b> must be performed <b>in a sacred place,</b> and the breaking of an earthenware vessel must be performed in a sacred place, and the scouring and rinsing of a copper vessel must be performed in a sacred place. <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Concerning a garment on which blood was sprayed, the verse states: <b>“You shall launder</b> that on which it shall be sprinkled <b>in a sacred place”</b> (Leviticus 6:20). <b>From where</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the breaking of an earthenware vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked derived? <b>The</b> subsequent <b>verse states: “And the earthenware vessel in which it is cooked shall be broken”</b> (Leviticus 6:21). <b>From where</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>scouring and rinsing of a copper vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked derived? <b>The verse states</b> immediately thereafter: <b>“And if it be cooked in a copper vessel, it shall be scoured, and rinsed in water.”</b>
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>this</b> matter, <b>a stringency</b> applies <b>to a sin offering</b> more than it applies to offerings of the most sacred order. The Gemara asks: <b>And are there no more</b> <i>halakhot</i> specific to a sin offering? <b>But there is</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>That its blood enters the innermost sanctum</b> to be sprinkled. The Gemara answers: The mishna is dealing <b>with external sin offerings,</b> and this <i>halakha</i> applies only to internal sin offerings.
The Gemara challenges: But there is the stricture <b>that if its blood enters into</b> the Sanctuary it becomes <b>disqualified.</b> The Gemara explains: This mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says: Every</b> offering’s <b>blood,</b> not only that of a sin offering, <b>that enters the Sanctuary to atone</b> becomes <b>disqualified;</b> therefore, this is not a <i>halakha</i> specific to a sin offering.
The Gemara challenges: But there is the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> external sin offerings <b>atone for those who are liable to</b> receive excision, <b><i>karet</i>,</b> through unintentional sins. The Gemara explains: The mishna includes an offering that does not have that <i>halakha</i>, as its principles also apply <b>to a sin offering</b> brought <b>for hearing the voice,</b> i.e., for falsely taking an oath that one is unable to testify in another’s case. This transgression is not punishable by <i>karet</i>.
The Gemara challenges: But there is the stricture <b>that</b> the blood of a sin offering <b>requires four placements</b> on the altar, unlike other offerings of the most sacred order. The Gemara explains: This mishna is composed <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who says</b> that <b>all blood</b> of offerings <b>requires four placements,</b> one <b>upon</b> each of the <b>four corners</b> of the altar; accordingly, this is not a <i>halakha</i> limited to the sin offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> even <b>according to your reasoning,</b> can it be said that there is only one <i>halakha</i> that applies to a sin offering but does not apply to other offerings? <b>Isn’t there</b> the requirement to place a sin offering’s <b>blood</b> on the <b>corner</b> at the top of the altar? <b>Isn’t there</b> the requirement that a priest place a sin offering’s blood on the altar with his <b>finger? Isn’t there</b> the requirement to place it on <b>the edge of</b> the altar? Therefore, it should not be assumed that this is the only <i>halakha</i> unique to a sin offering, but <b>rather</b> that the mishna simply <b>cited one of two</b> or <b>three stringencies.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a garment</b> upon which the blood of a sin offering was sprayed <b>that went outside the curtains,</b> i.e., the Temple courtyard, before being laundered, the garment <b>reenters</b> the courtyard <b>and</b> one <b>launders it in a sacred place.</b> If the garment <b>became ritually impure outside the curtains,</b> one <b>tears</b> the garment in order to render it ritually pure, <b>enters</b> the courtyard with it, <b>and launders it in a sacred place.</b> With regard to <b>an earthenware vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked <b>that went outside the curtains,</b> the vessel <b>reenters</b> the courtyard <b>and</b> one <b>breaks it in a sacred place.</b> If the vessel <b>became ritually impure outside the curtains,</b> one <b>punctures</b> the vessel to render it ritually pure, <b>and</b> one <b>enters</b> the courtyard with it <b>and breaks it in a sacred place.</b>
With regard to <b>a copper vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked <b>that went outside the curtains,</b> the vessel <b>reenters</b> the courtyard, <b>and</b> one <b>scours it and rinses it in a sacred place.</b> If the vessel <b>became ritually impure outside the curtains, one breaks</b> the vessel by boring a large hole in it to render it ritually pure <b>and enters</b> the courtyard with it <b>and scours and rinses it in a sacred place.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: If the garment became ritually impure outside the curtains, one tears the garment in order to render it ritually pure, enters the courtyard with it, and launders it in a sacred place. <b>Ravina objects to this:</b> How can the mishna say that <b>one tears it? The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that one must launder <b>“a garment”</b> (Leviticus 6:20), <b>and</b> once this article is torn, <b>this is no</b> longer <b>a garment,</b> but only a scrap of cloth.
The Gemara answers: The mishna describes a scenario <b>when he leaves</b> untorn a fragment <b>of</b> the garment that is size <b>enough for a small cloth. Is that so?</b> If he leaves such a portion intact, is he still permitted to bring the garment back into the courtyard? <b>But doesn’t Rav Huna say:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that an impure garment, most of which has been torn, loses its impurity <b>only when</b> one <b>did not leave of it enough for a small cloth, but if he left enough of it</b> untorn <b>for a small cloth, it is</b> considered <b>a joining</b> of the pieces, and the garment remains ritually impure. Accordingly, leaving a piece that size would not serve any purpose with regard to ritual impurity.

Daf 95a

The Gemara answers that Rav Huna’s statement means that <b>it is</b> ritually impure <b>by rabbinic law,</b> since the Sages decreed the small cloth impure lest one fail to tear a garment enough to render it truly pure. By Torah law, this small cloth is torn enough to be ritually pure, so that one may bring it back into the Temple courtyard to launder it.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>an earthenware vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked <b>that went outside</b> the curtains and became ritually impure outside the curtains, one punctures the vessel to render it ritually pure, brings the vessel back into the courtyard, and breaks it there. The Gemara asks: Why is there a need to break the earthenware vessel after puncturing it? <b>The Merciful One states:</b> “The earthenware <b>vessel…</b>shall be broken” (Leviticus 6:21), <b>and,</b> once it is punctured, <b>it is not a vessel.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>When it is punctured</b> with a hole only the size <b>of a small root,</b> the earthenware vessel is purified from the ritual impurity it contracted, but it remains a vessel for other purposes, such as holding fruit.
The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>a copper vessel</b> in which a sin offering was cooked that went outside the curtains and became ritually impure outside the curtains, <b>one breaks</b> the vessel by boring a large hole in it to render it ritually pure, brings the vessel back into the courtyard, and scours and rinses it there. The Gemara asks: Why should the copper vessel be scoured and rinsed? After all, once the hole is bored, <b>this is not a vessel</b> anymore. The Gemara explains: <b>When he hammers</b> it and refashions it into a vessel, he must scour and rinse it.
§ Earlier (94b–95a), the Gemara discusses a garment upon which the blood of a sin offering has sprayed; if it has contracted ritual impurity outside of the Temple courtyard, it must be torn before it is brought back into the courtyard to be laundered. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> If the <b>robe</b> of the High Priest upon which the blood of a sin offering has sprayed <b>has contracted ritual impurity</b> outside of the Temple courtyard, one does not tear it; rather, <b>he brings it in</b> to the courtyard gradually, in portions <b>less than</b> the measure of a garment susceptible to impurity, which is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, <b>and</b> he <b>launders it</b> section by section as the robe crosses the threshold. The ritually impure robe must be brought into the courtyard in this manner <b>because it is stated</b> with regard to the High Priest’s robe: <b>“It shall not be torn”</b> (Exodus 28:32).
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raises an objection</b> based upon a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 28:8): <b>The</b> particularly <b>thick</b> garments <b>and the soft</b> garments <b>are not subject to</b> the standard measure of <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, with regard to determining their susceptibility to becoming ritually impure. Because of their particular qualities, such garments are useful only when they are larger and are not considered significant items when they measure three by three. Since the High Priest’s robe is a thick garment, why must one bring it into the courtyard only in portions of less than three by three?
The Gemara answers: With regard to the whole robe of the High Priest, which is a garment of particular significance, even the small portions of the robe <b>are significant due to their source</b> garment, and are susceptible to impurity in portions measuring three by three fingerbreadths.
§ The Gemara asks a fundamental question with regard to the procedure for laundering a garment upon which the blood of a sin offering has sprayed: <b>But isn’t</b> it so that laundering <b>requires seven</b> abrasive <b>substances? As Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: Blood of a sin offering</b> that has sprayed on a garment, <b>and shades of</b> leprous <b>marks</b> on garments, which are subject to laundering (see Leviticus 13:54), <b>require</b> the <b>seven</b> abrasive <b>substances</b> used as laundering agents; and these substances include urine (<i>Nidda</i> 61b). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>But urine is not brought into the Temple,</b> because it is inappropriate for the Temple, although urine is theoretically suitable for use in the preparation of the incense spices. Accordingly, how is a garment laundered in the Temple?

Daf 95b

The Gemara rejects a solution: <b>And if you would say that</b> the urine <b>is absorbed together with</b> the rest of the <b>seven</b> abrasive <b>substances</b> used as laundering agents, <b>and one applies all of them at once</b> to the garment, such that the urine is not discernable separately, that is difficult: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that this method is invalid? The mishna states (<i>Nidda</i> 62a): If one <b>applied them not according to their</b> prescribed <b>order, or</b> if one <b>applied all seven</b> substances <b>simultaneously, he has done nothing,</b> and the laundering has not been effective.
The Gemara rejects another solution: <b>And if you would say that</b> the urine <b>is absorbed together with</b> only <b>one of the</b> cleansing <b>substances,</b> that is difficult: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in that mishna: <b>One must rub</b> the garment <b>three times with each and every one</b> of those substances independently? The Gemara resolves: <b>Rather,</b> it must be explained <b>that</b> the urine <b>is absorbed in tasteless saliva,</b> which comes from one who has not eaten since waking; <b>as Reish Lakish says: Tasteless saliva must accompany each and every one</b> of the substances applied to the garment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Whether</b> with regard to a copper vessel <b>in which</b> one <b>cooked</b> the meat of an offering <b>or whether</b> with regard to one <b>into which</b> one <b>poured</b> the <b>boiling</b> meat of an offering, <b>whether</b> the meat is from <b>offerings of the most sacred order or whether</b> it is from <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> such vessels <b>require scouring and rinsing. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Vessels in which <b>offerings of lesser sanctity</b> were cooked or poured <b>do not require scouring and rinsing.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Concerning the statement in the mishna that these <i>halakhot</i> also apply to a vessel into which a boiling cooked dish was poured, the Gemara notes that <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a sin offering, the verse states: <b>“In which it is cooked”</b> (Leviticus 6:21). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only that</b> this applies to a vessel <b>in which</b> one <b>cooked</b> the sin offering. <b>From where</b> do I derive that it applies also to a vessel <b>into which</b> one <b>poured a boiling</b> cooked dish? <b>The verse states</b> more fully: <b>“But</b> the earthenware vessel <b>in which it is cooked shall be broken.”</b> Since the verse employs the phrase: “In which it is…shall be broken,” that teaches that if the hot meat is in the vessel, whether cooked or poured into the vessel, these <i>halakhot</i> apply to it, and if it is an earthenware vessel it must be broken.
§ <b>Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>suspended</b> the meat of a sin offering <b>in the airspace of</b> an earthenware <b>oven</b> in order to roast it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? When the verse requires the breaking of the earthenware vessel, <b>is it</b> only <b>with regard to</b> both <b>cooking and</b> the resultant <b>absorption</b> of the offering’s flavor into the vessel <b>that the Merciful One is particular?</b> If so, an oven would not need to be broken simply because an offering has been roasted within its airspace. <b>Or perhaps,</b> is the Merciful One particular even <b>about cooking</b> in the vessel <b>without absorption</b> of the flavor, and therefore, if meat is roasted while suspended in this oven, the vessel must still be broken?
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, deduced from the mishna: <b>Whether</b> with regard to a copper vessel <b>in which</b> one <b>cooked</b> the meat of an offering <b>or whether</b> with regard to one <b>into which</b> one <b>poured</b> the <b>boiling</b> meat of an offering, the earthenware vessel must be broken. Therefore, the vessel must be broken even if the meat was not cooked in it but only absorbed in its walls, indicating that even if cooking and absorption do not occur together, just one of the two should suffice to require the breaking of the vessel.
The Gemara rejects the proof: The <i>halakha</i> in a case of the <b>absorption</b> of flavor into an earthenware vessel <b>without cooking</b> the meat in that vessel, as in the case of pouring, <b>was not raised as a dilemma to us.</b> If the boiling offering has been poured into a vessel, the vessel certainly must be broken, since earthenware never fully emits all that it absorbed. <b>When</b> a scenario <b>was raised</b> as <b>a dilemma to us,</b> it was with regard to <b>cooking</b> meat in the vessel <b>without absorption</b> of the flavor by that vessel, as in the case of roasting suspended meat. In such a case, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, deduced from <b>that which Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: The oven of the Temple was</b> fashioned <b>of metal. And if it enters your mind</b> that with regard to <b>cooking</b> in a vessel <b>without absorption,</b> the Merciful One <b>is not particular</b> and does not require the breaking of a vessel used in such a fashion, then the oven <b>should be made of earthenware.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Since there are the remainders of meal offerings, whose baking</b> is performed <b>in the oven, and there is</b> both <b>cooking and absorption</b> into the oven, as the remains of the meal offerings would be baked directly on the walls of the oven, for this reason alone the oven would have to be broken if it were fashioned of earthenware. Consequently, <b>we fashion</b> it <b>of metal.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain oven that was smeared with</b> animal <b>fat</b> all over its walls and floor. <b>Rabba bar Ahilai prohibited eating bread</b> baked in that oven <b>forever, and</b> he prohibited <b>even</b> eating the bread <b>with salt</b> alone, <b>lest one come to eat it with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dish made from milk, water, salt, and bread crumbs. According to Rabba bar Ahilai, the oven will never fully eliminate the fat.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to baking bread, <b>one may not knead the dough with milk, and if one</b> nevertheless <b>kneaded</b> the dough with milk, <b>all of the bread</b> made from that dough is <b>forbidden, because</b> one might become <b>accustomed to sin.</b> As one habitually eats bread with meat, he might also eat this bread with meat and unwittingly transgress the prohibition against eating meat with milk.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Similarly,</b> one may <b>not smear [<i>tashin</i>] the</b> inside of <b>an oven with</b> the fat of a sheep’s <b>tail,</b> because the fat of the tail has the <i>halakha</i> of meat. <b>And if</b> one nevertheless <b>smeared</b> the oven with the fat of the tail, <b>all of the bread</b> baked in it is <b>forbidden, until</b> one <b>kindles the oven</b> and burns off this fat. Evidently, the bread baked after the oven is kindled again is permitted, because the oven is considered cleansed of the meat fat. Therefore, <b>the refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rava bar Ahilai,</b> who says that the oven never fully eliminates the fat, is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Since</b> the statement of <b>Rava bar Ahilai was conclusively refuted, why does Rav say</b> that <b>pots</b> that were used for leavened bread <b>must be broken</b> before <b>Passover?</b> Presumably, the leavened bread could be burned out of them through kindling instead. Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Rav construes that</b> ruling of the <i>baraita</i>, according to which the fat can be burned out of the oven, as referring <b>to</b> an oven fashioned <b>of metal,</b> which cleanses the fat when kindled. In the case of earthenware vessels, additional kindling is insufficient, because the flavor absorbed within it cannot be cleansed by fire.
<b>Or if you wish, say</b> instead that the <i>baraita</i> is also referring <b>to an earthenware oven,</b> and there is another distinction. <b>This</b> oven <b>is kindled from the inside,</b> and a fire kindled inside the oven suffices to cleanse absorbed flavor. <b>But that</b> pot <b>is kindled from the outside</b> while it rests on the stove, and the heat absorbed in that manner is insufficient to cleanse absorbed flavor.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let us</b> also <b>perform</b> the <b>kindling</b> of the pot <b>from the inside,</b> in order to cleanse that which has been absorbed. The Gemara answers: This solution is not feasible; the owners of such pots might be <b>concerned for them, as they</b> are apt to <b>break</b> if the heat becomes too great. Consequently, the owners will not apply sufficient heat to ensure that the absorbed flavor will be completely cleansed. The Gemara concludes: <b>Therefore,</b> with regard to <b>this earthenware tile [<i>kuvya</i>],</b> which is used on the fire as a baking pan and <b>its kindling is from the outside,</b> it becomes <b>prohibited</b> for subsequent use by the flavors absorbed within, which cannot be cleansed.

Daf 96a

The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> according to the opinion that earthenware vessels can be cleansed of their absorbed substances by the process of kindling, with regard to <b>pots</b> used in <b>the Temple, why does the Merciful One state</b> in the Torah that <b>they should be broken? Let us</b> simply <b>return them to</b> the <b>kilns</b> in which pots are made to be sure that the pots will be cleansed by the extreme heat of the kilns. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The pots cannot be returned to kilns <b>because,</b> as taught in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Bava Kamma</i> 82b), <b>kilns are not built in Jerusalem</b> because of the great quantity of smoke they produce.
The Gemara presents an objection to Rabbi Zeira’s answer. <b>Abaye said: But</b> if, as the <i>baraita</i> teaches, there are no kilns in Jerusalem, <b>are scrap heaps</b> of earthenware <b>assembled in the Temple courtyard?</b> The same <i>baraita</i> also teaches that there are no scrap heaps in Jerusalem. What, then, is done with the shards of earthenware vessels that must be broken in the courtyard? The Gemara dismisses the question: Abaye raised that objection only because <b>that which Shemaya taught in Kalnevo escaped him;</b> Shemaya taught there: In the Temple, <b>shards of earthenware vessels were</b> miraculously <b>absorbed in their place.</b>
The Gemara returns to the topic of kindling earthenware vessels and asks: <b>But</b> if kindling from within cleanses everything absorbed in an earthenware oven, what is the reason for <b>that which Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: The oven in the Temple was</b> fashioned <b>of metal? Let us fashion</b> it <b>of earthenware, as</b> an oven’s <b>kindling is from the inside,</b> and, accordingly, it would be possible to cleanse it?
The Gemara answers: The reason the oven must be fashioned of metal is <b>because there are the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering on <i>Shavuot</i> of two loaves from the new wheat, <b>and the shewbread,</b> i.e., the bread baked each week in a special form and displayed for the duration of one whole week on the table in the Sanctuary, <b>whose baking is</b> done <b>in the oven, and</b> also <b>whose sanctification</b> occurs <b>in the oven.</b> Because these offerings are not kneaded in a service vessel, they are sanctified only by being placed in the oven, and therefore the oven <b>is a service vessel; and we do not make a service vessel of earthenware.</b>

Daf 96b

<b>And even Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says only</b> that a service vessel may be fashioned <b>of wood,</b> which is a somewhat significant material, <b>but</b> with regard to a service vessel fashioned <b>of earthenware,</b> he holds that this is <b>not</b> valid.
§ The Gemara relates an incident related to the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yehuda was</b> initially <b>accustomed</b> to study Torah <b>before Rami bar Ḥama.</b> After some time, <b>he left him and went to</b> study before <b>Rav Sheshet. One day</b> Rami bar Ḥama <b>met him</b> and <b>said to him</b> colloquially: Did you assume, as many do, that when <b>the chief of taxes [<i>alkafta</i>] grasped me</b> by the hand, <b>the fragrance</b> of his hand <b>came to</b> my <b>hand?</b> Do you think that <b>because you went</b> away from me in order to study <b>before Rav Sheshet, have you become like Rav Sheshet</b> merely by association?
Rav Yitzḥak bar Yehuda <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>not due to that</b> reason that I went to study before Rav Sheshet, but for another reason. As for you, <b>Master, when I ask</b> with regard to any <b>matter,</b> Master <b>resolves</b> the question <b>for me through reasoning.</b> Consequently, <b>when I find a mishna</b> that opposes that reasoning, it <b>refutes</b> Master’s proposed resolution. As for <b>Rav Sheshet, when I ask of him</b> a question concerning any <b>matter,</b> he <b>resolves</b> the question <b>for me by</b> citing <b>a mishna.</b> Consequently, <b>when I also find a mishna, and</b> that mishna <b>refutes</b> the proposed resolution, <b>it is</b> a dispute between one <b>mishna and</b> another <b>mishna,</b> which does not necessarily refute the mishna that he cited.
Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to him: Ask me</b> about <b>a matter, which I</b> will <b>resolve for you in accordance with a mishna.</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Yehuda <b>asked him:</b> If one <b>cooked</b> a sin offering <b>in</b> only <b>part of a vessel, does</b> the entire vessel <b>require scouring and rinsing, or does it not require</b> scouring and rinsing? Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to him:</b> The entire vessel <b>does not require</b> scouring and rinsing, <b>just as it is</b> taught concerning <b>sprinkling</b> the blood of a sin offering upon a garment. In the latter case, the mishna teaches (93b) that one must launder only the part of the garment on which the blood sprayed.
Rav Yitzḥak bar Yehuda replied: <b>But the <i>tanna</i> does not teach this</b> explicitly. Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to him:</b> Nevertheless, <b>it stands to reason</b> that the scouring and rinsing of a vessel in which sacred meat was cooked should be <b>like</b> the laundering of <b>a garment,</b> as follows: <b>Just as a garment requires laundering only</b> in the <b>place</b> where <b>the blood</b> was sprayed, <b>so too,</b> it must be that <b>a vessel requires scouring and rinsing only in the place</b> where the meat underwent the process of <b>cooking.</b>
Rav Yitzḥak bar Yehuda <b>said to him: Are</b> the situations <b>comparable? Blood does not spread</b> and penetrate all parts of the garment, but in the case of <b>cooking,</b> the flavor of the meat <b>spreads</b> throughout the entire vessel. <b>Additionally,</b> your reasoning opposes that which <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 10:15): A certain <b>stringency</b> applies <b>to sprinkling</b> more <b>than</b> it applies to <b>scouring and rinsing; and</b> a certain <b>stringency</b> applies <b>to scouring and rinsing</b> more <b>than</b> it applies to <b>sprinkling.</b>
