The <i>baraita</i> continues: The <b>stringency</b> that applies <b>to sprinkling</b> is <b>that</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>sprinkling</b> of blood on a garment <b>applies to external sin offerings,</b> brought on the altar in the Temple courtyard, <b>and to internal sin offerings,</b> whose blood is sprinkled on the altar in the Sanctuary; <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> of blood sprayed onto a garment <b>applies</b> if it sprays <b>before</b> the required <b>sprinkling</b> of the offering’s blood on the altar; <b>which is not so in</b> the case of <b>scouring and rinsing.</b> Scouring and rinsing are required only for external sin offerings, whose meat is eaten and therefore cooked; and it applies only after the sprinkling of blood on the altar, after which the meat may be eaten.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The <b>stringency</b> that applies <b>to scouring and rinsing</b> is <b>that the scouring and rinsing</b> of vessels <b>is practiced both for offerings of the most sacred order and for offerings of lesser sanctity;</b> and even if one <b>cooked in</b> only <b>part of the vessel, the entire vessel requires scouring and rinsing, which is not so in</b> the case of errantly <b>sprinkling</b> blood onto a garment, for which one must launder only the place on which the blood sprayed.
Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to him: If</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught,</b> and I cannot take issue with it. The Gemara then clarifies: <b>And what is the reason</b> that an entire vessel requires scouring and rinsing even if one cooked the meat of an offering in only part of the vessel? The reason is that <b>the verse states: “And if it be cooked in a copper vessel,</b> it shall be scoured and rinsed in water” (Leviticus 6:21). From the phrase “in a copper vessel” it is derived that <b>even</b> if the meat is cooked <b>in</b> only <b>part of a vessel,</b> the entire vessel must be scoured and rinsed.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Whether</b> the meat is from <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> or whether it is from offerings of lesser sanctity, the vessels in which it is cooked must be scoured and rinsed. The Gemara cites a related <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Sages taught:</b> The Torah introduces the mitzva of scouring and rinsing with the qualifying statement: “This is the law of the <b>sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:18). From this verse <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to scouring and rinsing applies to vessels in which <b>a sin offering</b> was cooked. <b>From where</b> do I derive that this <i>halakha</i> applies to vessels used for <b>all sacrificial</b> meat? <b>The verse states:</b> “Every male among the priests may eat of it; <b>it is most sacred”</b> (Leviticus 6:22), to teach that this <i>halakha</i> applies to vessels used for all of the sacrificial meat that the priests eat.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include</b> vessels used for cooking <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, as well, as it is also sacred and may be eaten only by a priest (see Leviticus 22:14). To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “Every male among the priests may eat <b>of it;</b> it is most sacred” (Leviticus 6:22). The emphatic qualifier “of it” <b>excludes <i>teruma</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: Offerings of the most sacred order require scouring and rinsing,</b> but <b>offerings of lesser sanctity do not require scouring and rinsing, as it is written: “Most sacred.”</b> Accordingly, with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, yes,</b> scouring and rinsing is required; but for <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, no,</b> it is not required.
The Gemara asks: The <i>baraita</i> explains Rabbi Shimon’s reasoning; <b>what is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the qualifying term <b>“of it” was necessary to exclude <i>teruma</i>, by inference,</b> it must be <b>that</b> vessels used for <b>offerings of lesser sanctity require scouring and rinsing.</b> If even offerings of lesser sanctity are excluded from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, it would be self-evident that the vessel used for <i>teruma</i> is exempt from scouring and rinsing. Accordingly, the direct exclusion of <i>teruma</i> indicates that the vessels used for offerings of lesser sanctity are not excluded. <b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> The term <b>“of it”</b> teaches a different <i>halakha</i> and excludes a disqualified sin offering from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, <b>as we say</b> earlier in this chapter (93a).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it correct that with regard to a copper vessel used to cook <b><i>teruma</i>, it does not require rinsing and scouring? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 8:16): With regard to <b>a pot in which</b> one <b>cooked meat,</b> one <b>may not cook milk in it; and if</b> one <b>cooked</b> milk in it, the meat absorbed in the pot renders the milk forbidden if it <b>imparts flavor</b> to it. Similarly, if one cooked <b><i>teruma</i></b> in a pot, one <b>may not cook non-sacred</b> food <b>in it; and if</b> one <b>cooked</b> non-sacred food in it, the absorbed <i>teruma</i> renders the mixture sacred if it <b>imparts flavor</b> to it. Therefore, a pot requires purging with boiling liquid in order to expel the flavor of <i>teruma</i> from it.
Three <i>amora’im</i> address the apparent inconsistency that while the Torah excludes vessels used for <i>teruma</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that these vessels must be purged. <b>Abaye said:</b> When the verse excludes <i>teruma</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, this <b>is necessary only for</b> that <b>which the Master said:</b> If one <b>cooked in</b> only <b>part of</b> the <b>vessel, the entire vessel requires scouring and rinsing.</b> By contrast, in <b>this</b> case, if <b><i>teruma</i></b> was cooked in only part of a vessel, one <b>must</b> perform scouring and rinsing <b>only</b> in <b>the place of</b> the <b>cooking,</b> and not in the whole vessel.
<b>Rava said:</b> When the verse excludes <i>teruma</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, that <b>is necessary only for</b> that <b>which the Master said:</b> The verse specifies: “It shall be scoured and rinsed <b>in water”</b> (Leviticus 6:21), <b>but</b> the vessel is <b>not</b> to be scoured and rinsed <b>in wine.</b> It must be scoured and rinsed <b>“in water,” but not in diluted</b> wine. By contrast, in <b>this</b> case, i.e., the vessel in which <i>teruma</i> was cooked, it may be scoured and rinsed <b>even in wine, and even in diluted</b> wine.
<b>Rabba bar Ulla said:</b> When the verse excludes <i>teruma</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of scouring and rinsing, this <b>is necessary only for</b> that <b>which the Master said:</b> One must perform <b>scouring and rinsing with cold</b> water, in addition to purging a vessel of its absorbed flavors with boiling water. By contrast, in <b>this</b> case, i.e., with regard to the vessel in which <i>teruma</i> was cooked, one may cleanse the vessel <b>even</b> by performing only the purging <b>with boiling</b> water, which removes the residue of the forbidden food, and omitting the cold water processes entirely.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>scouring and rinsing</b> are performed <b>with cold</b> water; <b>but according to the one who says</b> that <b>scouring</b> is done by purging <b>with hot</b> water, <b>and rinsing</b> is a different procedure performed <b>with cold</b> water, <b>what can be said?</b> According to this opinion, the verse is also referring to purging; and if the verse excludes vessels used for <i>teruma</i>, how does the <i>baraita</i> teach that such vessels much be purged? The Gemara answers: According to the opinion that differentiates scouring, which is done with boiling water, from rinsing, which is done with cold water, the Torah excludes vessels used for <i>teruma</i> only from <b>the additional rinsing</b> that the Torah requires after the scouring.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Tarfon says:</b> If one <b>cooked</b> a sin offering in a copper vessel <b>from the beginning of the</b> pilgrimage <b>Festival,</b> one <b>may cook in it</b> for <b>the entire</b> pilgrimage <b>Festival;</b> he need not scour and rinse the vessel after every use. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One may not continue using it in this manner; rather, one must perform <b>scouring and rinsing before</b> the end of the <b>period</b> during which <b>partaking</b> of the particular cooked offering is permitted. <b>Scouring</b> is <b>like the scouring of</b> the inside of <b>a cup,</b> the cleaning done when wine sticks to the cup, <b>and rinsing</b> is <b>like the rinsing of</b> the outside of <b>a cup. Scouring and rinsing</b> are both performed <b>with cold</b> water.

Daf 97a

With regard to <b>the spit and the</b> metal <b>grill [<i>askela</i>],</b> one <b>purges them in hot water.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that Rabbi Tarfon says: If one cooked a sin offering in a vessel from the beginning of the Festival, one may cook in it for the entire Festival without scouring and rinsing the vessel after every use and without being concerned that he is eating forbidden leftover meat. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Tarfon?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>as the verse states</b> with regard to the Paschal offering: “And you shall roast and eat it in the place that the Lord your God shall choose; <b>and you shall turn in the morning, and go to your tents”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:7). Although one does not leave Jerusalem on the first morning of Passover, <b>the verse has rendered all of those</b> days over which one remains there equal to <b>one morning.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami objects to this:</b> Can it be that all of the days of the Festival are considered a single day? <b>But is there no</b> prohibition against bringing <b>an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its appointed time [<i>piggul</i>] during a pilgrimage Festival? And is there no</b> prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>,</b> consuming sacrificial meat beyond its appointed time, <b>during a pilgrimage Festival?</b> Both these prohibitions are based on the premise that each offering may be eaten over a limited time far less than the duration of the entire Festival.
<b>And if you would say: Indeed,</b> neither <i>piggul</i> nor <i>notar</i> apply during a Festival, that is difficult: <b>But it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: Rabbi Tarfon said</b> that an entire Festival is considered a single day <b>only</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of scouring and rinsing, <b>alone,</b> and not with regard to other <i>halakhot</i>, including <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i>. Evidently, his opinion is not based on the cited verse.
The Gemara continues: <b>Rather,</b> one must explain that Rabbi Tarfon’s opinion accords <b>with that which Rav Naḥman says</b> citing <b>Rabba bar Avuh. As Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> Scouring and rinsing does not need to be done every day in order to avoid eating the taste of forbidden leftover meat, because while the vessels are used for repeatedly cooking various types of sacrificial meat, the meat of <b>each and every day becomes a purging agent for the other</b> food, that which is already absorbed in the vessel from the prior day. Therefore, only after the Festival, when the vessel is not being used, must the pot be scoured and rinsed.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One may not continue using it in this manner; rather, one must perform scouring and rinsing <b>before</b> the end of the <b>period</b> during which <b>partaking</b> of the particular cooked offering is permitted. <b>What</b> is the mishna <b>saying? Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: One waits for</b> the copper vessel <b>so long as</b> it remains <b>the period of partaking, and then</b> he <b>performs scouring and rinsing on it.</b>
<b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Abba Yosei bar Abba: It is written</b> about a copper vessel in which a sin offering was cooked: <b>“It shall be scoured and rinsed</b> in water” (Leviticus 6:21); <b>and it is written</b> in the following verse: <b>“Every male among the priests may eat</b> it.” <b>How so,</b> i.e., what are the verses teaching through this juxtaposition? One <b>waits with it until</b> the end of <b>the period of partaking and then performs scouring and rinsing on it.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Scouring</b> is <b>like the scouring of a cup,</b> and <b>rinsing</b> is <b>like the rinsing of a cup;</b> and scouring and rinsing are both performed with cold water. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Scouring and rinsing</b> are both performed <b>with cold</b> water; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: Scouring</b> is performed <b>with hot</b> water, <b>and rinsing</b> is performed <b>with cold</b> water.
<b>What is the reasoning of the Rabbis?</b> They hold that this <i>halakha</i> is <b>just as it is with</b> regard to <b>purging</b> the used vessels acquired from <b>gentiles,</b> for which purging the forbidden absorptions must be performed with hot water. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi could have <b>said to you: I do not say</b> this statement about <b>purging,</b> which must certainly be performed with hot water. Rather, <b>when I say</b> my opinion, it is <b>with regard to</b> the mitzva of <b>scouring and rinsing, which is</b> performed <b>after purging.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis</b> could reply: <b>If so,</b> that scouring and rinsing are both performed in the same manner, <b>let the verse write</b> the same verb to describe both processes, namely <b>either:</b> It shall be <b>scoured</b> and <b>scoured</b> in water, <b>or:</b> It shall be <b>rinsed</b> and <b>rinsed</b> in water. <b>What</b> is meant by the formula: <b>“It shall be scoured and rinsed</b> in water”? <b>Conclude from</b> the use of two verbs that <b>scouring</b> is performed <b>with hot</b> water, <b>and rinsing</b> is performed <b>with cold</b> water.
<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi could reply: <b>If it were written: It shall be scoured</b> and <b>scoured,</b> or: It shall be rinsed and rinsed, <b>I would say</b> that the vessel must be <b>scoured two times, or</b> that it must be <b>rinsed two times. Therefore, it is written: “It shall be scoured and rinsed,” to tell you</b> that even if both are performed with cold water, there are two distinct actions: <b>Scouring</b> is <b>like the scouring of</b> the inside of <b>a cup,</b> and <b>rinsing</b> is <b>like the rinsing of</b> the outside of <b>a cup.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <b>cooked in</b> one vessel <b>sacrificial</b> meat <b>and non-sacred</b> meat, <b>or</b> the meat of <b>offerings of the most sacred order and</b> the meat of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> the status of the food depends upon the taste of the stringent substance. <b>If there is</b> enough <b>of</b> the more sacred meat <b>to impart flavor</b> to the less sacred or non-sacred meat, then <b>the lenient</b> components of the mixtures must <b>be eaten in accordance with</b> the restrictions of <b>the stringent</b> components <b>therein,</b> insofar as who may partake of them, as well as the time when and the place where they may be eaten. <b>And</b> the copper vessels in which the lenient components were cooked <b>do not require scouring and rinsing, and</b> the lenient components <b>do not disqualify</b> pieces of meat <b>through contact.</b> With regard to these principles, the lenient components do not assume the status of the stringent components.
In the case of a fit <b>wafer that touched</b> an unfit <b>wafer or a piece</b> of sacrificial meat that touched an unfit <b>piece</b> of sacrificial meat, <b>neither all the wafers nor all the pieces</b> of meat <b>are forbidden. No</b> part is <b>forbidden other than</b> that which is <b>in the place where</b> the item <b>absorbed</b> taste from the unfit wafers or pieces.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> According to the mishna, if the more sacred meat imparts flavor to the less sacred or non-sacred meat, then the lenient meat is to be treated in the same manner as the more sacred meat. Concurrently, their vessels do not require scouring and rinsing, and the lenient components do not disqualify pieces of meat through contact. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the mishna <b>saying?</b> Is this not inconsistent? The Gemara answers: The mishna must be understood otherwise: <b>If there is</b> enough <b>of</b> the more sacred meat <b>to impart flavor</b> to the less sacred or non-sacred meat, then <b>the lenient</b> components of the mixtures must <b>be eaten in accordance with</b> the restrictions of <b>the stringent</b> components. Moreover, the copper vessels in which the lenient components were cooked do <b>require scouring and rinsing, and</b> the lenient components do <b>disqualify</b> pieces of meat <b>through contact.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>If</b> the more sacred meat <b>is not sufficient to impart flavor</b> to the less sacred or non-sacred meat, then <b>the lenient</b> components of the mixtures <b>are not eaten in accordance with</b> the restrictions of <b>the stringent</b> components. Moreover, the copper vessels in which the lenient components were cooked <b>do not require scouring and rinsing, and</b> the lenient components <b>do not disqualify</b> pieces of meat <b>through contact.</b>
The Gemara asks: If the offerings of the most sacred order do not impart taste to the offerings of lesser sanctity, <b>granted,</b> the vessels <b>do not require</b> scouring and rinsing commensurate with vessels used to cook <b>offerings of the most sacred order.</b> But isn’t it so that the vessels <b>should</b> nevertheless <b>require</b> scouring and rinsing by virtue of having been used for <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b>
<b>Abaye said: What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Do not require, which</b> the mishna <b>states?</b> It means only that the vessels do not require scouring and rinsing commensurate with vessels used to cook <b>offerings of the most sacred order, but</b> they <b>do require</b> scouring and rinsing as vessels used to cook <b>offerings of lesser sanctity. Rava said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says:</b> Vessels used to cook <b>offerings of lesser sanctity do not require scouring and rinsing</b> at all.
The Gemara analyzes: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If one cooked in one vessel sacrificial meat and non-sacred meat, <b>or</b> the meat of <b>offerings of the most sacred order and</b> the meat of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> The mishna provides a second scenario in order to teach that vessels used to cook offerings of lesser sanctity do not require scouring and rinsing, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>But</b> according <b>to Abaye, why do I</b> need <b>two</b> cases to teach the single principle that a substance is nullified if its presence is insufficient to impart flavor?
The Gemara answers: Even according to Abaye, both cases <b>are necessary,</b> in order to teach a <i>halakha</i> with regard to nullification. <b>As, had</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> only the case of <b>sacrificial</b> meat <b>and non-sacred</b> meat, <b>I would say</b> that <b>it is non-sacred</b> meat <b>that can nullify sacrificial</b> meat, <b>as</b> sacrificial meat is <b>not its type. But</b> with regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order and offerings of lesser sanctity, I would say:</b> The offerings of lesser sanctity do <b>not</b> nullify those other offerings, because they are of the same type.
<b>And had</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> only the case of <b>offerings of the most sacred order and offerings of lesser sanctity, I would say</b> that <b>it is sacrificial</b> meat <b>that is strong</b> enough <b>to nullify</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>non-sacred</b> meat, <b>I would say:</b> It is <b>not</b> strong enough to nullify sacrificial meat. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both cases.
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of a fit <b>wafer that reached</b> an unfit <b>wafer</b> or a piece of sacrificial meat that touched an unfit piece of sacrificial meat, neither all the wafers nor all the pieces are forbidden. No part is forbidden other than that which is in the place where the item absorbed taste from the unfit wafers or pieces. In relation to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a sin offering, the verse states: <b>“Whatever shall touch</b> its flesh shall be sacred” (Leviticus 6:20). One <b>might</b> have thought that this applies to all contact, <b>even</b> if the other piece <b>did not absorb</b> any flavor from the meat of the sin offering. To counter this, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states: “With its flesh [<i>bivsarah</i>]”</b> which can also be translated: In its flesh.

Daf 97b

This teaches that this <i>halakha</i> does not apply <b>unless</b> the other food <b>absorbs</b> something of the sin offering <b>into its meat.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>if</b> the sin offering <b>touched part of a piece</b> of something that absorbed flavor from the sin offering, <b>the entire</b> piece <b>should become disqualified.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “Whatever <b>shall touch</b> its flesh shall be sacred” (Leviticus 6:20), to teach that only the section <b>that touches</b> the sin offering is <b>disqualified. How so?</b> What can be done with an item when a section of it is disqualified? <b>One slices off the section</b> of the piece <b>that absorbed</b> the disqualified matter. Additionally, the verse states: “Whatever shall touch <b>its flesh,” but</b> an item is <b>not</b> disqualified if it touches the sin offering’s <b>sinews, nor</b> its <b>bones, nor</b> its <b>horns, nor</b> its <b>hooves.</b>
§ The <i>baraita</i> continues to interpret the same verse. “Whatever shall touch its flesh <b>shall be sacred,”</b> teaches: Whatever touches it <b>becomes like it,</b> with regard to its status. <b>How so? If</b> the sin offering <b>is disqualified,</b> due to any disqualification, whatever touches it <b>becomes disqualified. And if it is fit,</b> whatever touches it must <b>be eaten in accordance with the stringent</b> regulations <b>that</b> apply <b>to</b> the sin offering. Therefore, a piece of meat that touches the meat of a sin offering may be eaten only in accordance with the terms of the consumption of a sin offering, e.g., it may be eaten only by male priests, and only for one day and one night.
The Gemara asks: If sacrificial meat touched the meat of a disqualified sin offering, <b>why</b> should the sacrificial meat become forbidden? <b>Should</b> not the <b>positive mitzva</b> of eating the sacrificial meat <b>come and override</b> the <b>prohibition</b> against eating the disqualified substance that was absorbed in it? <b>Rava said: A positive mitzva does not override a prohibition that</b> relates <b>to the Temple.</b>
Rav’s opinion relates to that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>As it is stated</b> in a verse concerning the Paschal offering: <b>“Nor shall you break a bone of it”</b> (Exodus 12:46). <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: Both a bone that contains marrow and a bone that does not contain marrow</b> are included in the prohibition. This statement is analyzed: If one means to break a bone in order to eat its marrow, <b>why</b> would that be prohibited? <b>Should</b> not the <b>positive mitzva</b> of eating the edible parts of the offering, including the marrow, <b>come and override</b> the <b>prohibition</b> of not breaking a bone of the Paschal offering? <b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>a positive mitzva does not override a prohibition that</b> relates <b>to the Temple.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> If sacrificial meat touches a disqualified sin offering, this is not simply a case of a positive mitzva in conflict with a prohibition. Because the verse states: “Whatever shall touch its flesh <b>shall be sacred”</b> (Leviticus 6:20), treating the item as consecrated <b>is</b> itself <b>a positive mitzva.</b> Consequently, both a positive mitzva and a prohibition stand in opposition to eating that sacrificial meat, <b>and a positive mitzva does not override</b> both <b>a prohibition and a positive mitzva.</b>
§ With regard to a sin offering, the verse states: “Whatever shall touch its flesh shall be sacred.” The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source teaching <b>that</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> whatever it touches <b>becomes sanctified through that which is absorbed</b> from the sin offering. <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is also the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>the rest of the sacred</b> offerings? <b>Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> It is stated: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the inauguration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings”</b> (Leviticus 7:37). This verse connects all of the specified offerings, such that individual aspects of each offering are applicable to all of the offerings.
The Gemara details these aspects. The verse states <b>“of the burnt offering”</b> to teach that all of the offerings are <b>like a burnt offering</b> in that <b>just as a burnt offering requires a utensil</b> in its preparation, <b>so too do all</b> animal offerings <b>require a utensil. What</b> is the <b>utensil? If we say</b> it is <b>a bowl,</b> a utensil used for collecting the blood, as were used in the burnt offerings that were sacrificed at Mount Sinai, that cannot be correct, since the source for a vessel for collecting blood does not need to be derived from the use of one in a burnt offering. <b>With regard to communal peace offerings it is also written of them:</b> “And they offered burnt offerings, and they sacrificed peace offerings…<b>And Moses took half of the blood, and put it in basins”</b> (Exodus 24:5–6).
<b>Rather,</b> the term: Utensil, must be stated <b>of a knife,</b> as the slaughtering may be performed only with a knife and not with a sharp stone or reed. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering itself, from where do we</b> derive that it must be slaughtered with a knife? This is learned from <b>that which is written: “And Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife</b> to slaughter his son” (Genesis 22:10); <b>and there,</b> Abraham was offering <b>a burnt offering, as it is written: “And offered it up for a burnt offering instead of his son”</b> (Genesis 22:13).
The Gemara continues to expound the aforementioned verse (Leviticus 7:37). When the verse mentions <b>a meal offering,</b> it teaches that <b>just as a meal offering is eaten only by males of</b> the <b>priesthood</b> (see Leviticus 6:9–11), <b>so too are all</b> of the offerings mentioned in this verse <b>eaten only by males of</b> the <b>priesthood.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>what</b> offering <b>is it</b> that this <i>halakha</i> must be derived? <b>If</b> one suggests it is with regard to the <b>sin offering and</b> the <b>guilt offering,</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is explicitly written of them.</b> With regard to the sin offering, it is stated: “Every male among the priests may eat it” (Leviticus 6:22); and with regard to the guilt offering, it is stated: <b>“Every male among the priests may eat of it”</b> (Leviticus 7:6).
<b>And if</b> one suggests that the <i>halakha</i> must be derived with regard to <b>communal peace offerings,</b> i.e., the two lambs that were sacrificed as communal offerings on <i>Shavuot</i> together with the offering of the two loaves (see Leviticus 23:19), this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> the <b>amplification of the verse</b> that is stated with regard to meal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings. The verse states: <b>“In a most sacred place shall you eat of it; every male may eat it”</b> (Numbers 18:10), and it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse <b>teaches with regard to communal peace offerings that they are eaten only by males of priestly</b> families.
The Gemara explains: <b>It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>

Daf 98a

<b>There is</b> one <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives it,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that only males of priestly families may eat of the communal peace offering, <b>from here,</b> i.e., the precedent mentioned explicitly with regard to the meal offering; <b>and there is</b> one <i>tanna</i> <b>who derives it from there,</b> i.e., the amplification of the verse stated with regard to meal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings.
The Gemara continues expounding the verse: “This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the inauguration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings.” <b>“Sin offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> whatever it touches <b>is sanctified through</b> the substance that becomes <b>absorbed, so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, whatever they touch <b>is sanctified through</b> the <b>absorbed</b> portions.
<b>“Guilt offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, a fetal sac and a placenta are not sacred within it,</b> because a guilt offering is always male and as such never holds a fetal sac or a placenta, <b>so too</b> for <b>any</b> of the offerings mentioned in the verse, <b>a fetal sac and a placenta are not sacred</b> if found <b>within it.</b> The Gemara notes: Evidently, this <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that with regard to the <b>offspring of sacrificial</b> animals, <b>they are sanctified</b> only <b>as they are</b> from the moments of their births, but not in utero. <b>And</b> he also holds that <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> so that the <i>halakha</i> of a fetal sac and of a placenta concerning female animals may be derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a male animal.
<b>“Inauguration offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>inauguration offering,</b> the rams and the bread of that offering, which were brought during the seven days of inauguration of the Tabernacle and which the priests ate, <b>their leftovers</b> were disposed of <b>by incineration,</b> as is stated: “And if any of the flesh of the inauguration offering, or of the bread, remain until the morning, then you shall burn the remainder with fire” (Exodus 29:34), <b>and no living animals</b> were <b>among their leftovers</b> designated for incineration; <b>so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned, <b>their leftovers are</b> disposed of <b>by incineration, and there are no living animals</b> counted <b>among their leftovers</b> to be incinerated. Accordingly, if one sanctifies two animals so that either one may be brought if the other is lost, when one animal is sacrificed, the surviving animal is not killed and incinerated.
<b>“Peace offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>peace offer-ing,</b> its components can <b>render</b> an animal disqualified as <b>an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its appointed time [<i>piggul</i>] and</b> can be <b>rendered <i>piggul</i>; so too</b> with regard to <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, their components <b>render</b> an animal disqualified as <b><i>piggul</i> and</b> can be <b>rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b>
§ With regard to the verse at the center of the prior exchange (Leviticus 7:37), the Gemara states: <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> in the name of Rabbi Akiva:</b> From the term <b>“meal offering,”</b> it is derived: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering,</b> whatever it touches <b>is sanctified through</b> the substance that becomes <b>absorbed,</b> as it is stated: “Whatever shall touch them shall be sacred” (Leviticus 6:11); <b>so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, whatever they touch <b>is sanctified through</b> the <b>absorbed</b> portions.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it was necessary to write</b> the <i>halakha</i> of absorption with regard to <b>a meal offering, and it was necessary to write</b> the <i>halakha</i> of absorption with regard to <b>a sin offering. As, had</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a meal offering,</b> I would say <b>that since it is soft, it is absorbed</b> and, therefore it sanctifies what it touches. <b>But</b> with regard to the meat of <b>a sin offering, I would say</b> that it does <b>not</b> sanctify what it touches. <b>And had it</b> had <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> I would say that <b>because,</b> on account of its fattiness, it <b>oozes</b> into whatever it touches, it sanctifies it. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering, I would say</b> that it does <b>not</b> sanctify what it touches. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to write both.
The cited <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>“Sin offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as a sin offering is brought only from non-sacred</b> animals <b>and</b> is sacrificed specifically <b>in the daytime, and</b> its service must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand; so too all</b> offerings mentioned <b>are brought only from non-sacred</b> animals, <b>and</b> are sacrificed specifically <b>in the daytime, and</b> each one’s service must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand. And</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering, from where do we</b> derive that it is brought only from non-sacred animals? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: The verse states: “And Aaron shall present the bull of the sin offering, which is his”</b> (Leviticus 16:11). This teaches that the animal must come <b>from his</b> cattle, <b>and not from communal</b> property, <b>and not from</b> money upon which the second <b>tithe</b> has been redeemed.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to derive from the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering that an offering is sacrificed <b>in the daytime?</b> Is this principle not <b>derived from</b> the conspicuous expression: <b>“On the day of His commanding”</b> (Leviticus 7:38), which is understood to be referring to all offerings? The Gemara answers: Indeed, the <i>baraita</i> <b>cited</b> the principle from the model of a sin offering <b>for no reason [<i>kedi</i>],</b> and it was mentioned here on account of the other principles.
The Gemara asks: Why must the <i>baraita</i> teach that <i>halakha</i> of the sin offering teaches that the rites of an offering must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand?</b> Is this not <b>derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabba bar bar Ḥana? As Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> In <b>any place</b> in the Torah <b>that it is stated</b> that an action is performed with <b>a finger, or</b> that it is performed by <b>priesthood,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the rite is performed <b>only</b> with the <b>right</b> hand. This is derived from the Torah’s statement with regard to the leper: “And the priest shall dip his right finger” (Leviticus 14:16). The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>cited</b> the principle from the model of a sin offering <b>for no reason,</b> since it is actually derived from Rabba bar bar Ḥana’s statement.
The Gemara suggest: <b>And if you wish, say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says:</b> Where the verse mentions <b>a finger,</b> it <b>is not necessary</b> for the verse to mention <b>priesthood;</b> but where it mentions <b>priesthood,</b> it <b>is necessary</b> for the verse to mention <b>a finger,</b> in order to teach that the rite must be performed with the right hand, which is not self-evident. With regard to the assorted offerings itemized in the verse (Leviticus 7:37), the Torah does not mention a finger; therefore, they must be derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering.
The cited <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>“Guilt offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, its bones</b> have no sanctity and <b>are permitted</b> for any use, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b>any</b> mentioned offering, <b>its bones are permitted.</b>
§ <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that

Daf 98b

when the <b>blood of a sin offering is below and</b> the <b>blood of a burnt offering is above,</b> in a case in which the blood of a burnt offering is sprayed as a second layer on top of the blood of a sin offering that has already been sprayed and absorbed into a garment, the garment <b>requires laundering.</b>
<b>Rava asks:</b> When the <b>blood of a burnt offering is below and</b> the <b>blood of a sin offering is above, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is</b> one required to launder a garment to remove the blood of a sin offering <b>because</b> the blood <b>touches</b> his garment, <b>and</b> in this case, <b>this</b> blood <b>is touching</b> the garment? <b>Or perhaps is</b> one required to launder it <b>because of</b> the <b>absorption</b> of the blood into the garment, <b>and,</b> in this case, since the garment has already absorbed the other blood, <b>this</b> garment <b>did not absorb</b> the blood? Rava <b>then resolves</b> his dilemma, ruling <b>that</b> such garments <b>do not require laundering.</b>
§ In a similar manner, with regard to the immersion of a garment that has become impure, <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that if there is <b>blood on</b> one’s <b>garment,</b> it <b>interposes</b> between the water of immersion and the garment, such that the immersion is ineffective. <b>But if he is a butcher,</b> used to having blood on his garments, a bloodstain <b>does not interpose,</b> and the immersion is effective, since a substance is not considered an interposition if the one immersing is not particular about it. Similarly, if there is a stain of <b>fat [<i>revav</i>] on one’s garment,</b> it <b>interposes. But if he is a fat seller,</b> such a stain <b>does not interpose. Rava asks:</b> If there is both <b>blood and fat on</b> one’s <b>garment</b> when he immerses it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara challenges the question: <b>If he is a butcher, let me derive</b> that the stain interposes <b>due to</b> the <b>fat</b> that he is not used to having on his garments; <b>and</b> conversely, <b>if he is a fat seller, let me derive</b> that the stain interposes <b>due to</b> the stain of <b>blood</b> that he is not used to having on his garments. The Gemara explains: <b>No,</b> this question is not superfluous; it is <b>necessary</b> with regard to a person <b>who works</b> both as <b>this,</b> a butcher, <b>and</b> as <b>that,</b> a fat seller. In such a case, the question is: Is it that <b>he is not particular with regard to one</b> stain, but <b>he is particular with regard to two</b> stains, so that the immersion is ineffective? <b>Or, perhaps,</b> is it that he is <b>not particular</b> even with regard <b>to two</b> stains, as neither is unusual for him? The Gemara provides no answer, and the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A priest who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed, <b>and</b> a priest <b>who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering to complete the purification process, e.g., a <i>zav</i> and a leper who did not bring their requisite atonement offerings, who are not yet permitted to partake of sacrificial meat, <b>do not receive a share of sacrificial</b> meat along with the other members of the patrilineal priestly family serving in the Temple that day, in order <b>to partake</b> of it <b>in the evening</b> after the offerings were sacrificed, even though after nightfall he would be permitted to partake of the offerings.
A priest who is <b>an acute mourner,</b> i.e., if one of his relatives for whom he is obligated to mourn died that day, is permitted to <b>touch</b> sacrificial meat, as he is not ritually impure. <b>But he may not sacrifice</b> offerings, <b>and he does not receive a share</b> of sacrificial meat in order <b>to partake</b> of it <b>in the evening.</b>
<b>Blemished</b> priests, <b>whether</b> they are <b>temporarily blemished</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>permanently blemished, receive a share and partake</b> of the offerings with their priestly brethren, <b>but do not sacrifice</b> the offerings.
The principle is: <b>Any</b> priest <b>who is unfit for the service</b> that specific day <b>does not receive a share of the</b> sacrificial <b>meat, and anyone who has no</b> share <b>of the meat has no</b> share <b>in the hides</b> of the animals, to which the priests are entitled as well.
<b>Even</b> if the priest was <b>ritually impure</b> only <b>at the time of the sprinkling of the blood</b> of the offering <b>and</b> he was <b>pure at the time of the burning of</b> the <b>fats</b> of that offering, he still <b>does not receive a share of the meat, as it is stated: “He that sacrifices the blood of the peace offerings and the fat, from among the sons of Aaron, shall have the right thigh for a portion”</b> (Leviticus 7:33). One who cannot sprinkle the blood does not receive a share in the meat.

Daf 99a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a priest who is unfit for the Temple service does not receive a share of the sacrificial meat. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states</b> about a sin offering: <b>“The priest who effects atonement shall eat it;</b> in a sacred place shall it be eaten, in the court of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 6:19). This teaches that only <b>a priest who effects atonement</b> by performing the rites of the offering <b>shall partake</b> of its meat, but a priest <b>who does not effect atonement does not partake</b> of its meat.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And is</b> this an established <b>principle? But</b> there are <b>all the</b> priests of the <b>priestly watch</b> of that week in the Temple, <b>who do not effect atonement</b> for that offering, because the blood of a specific sin offering is presented by just one priest, <b>and</b> yet they all <b>partake</b> of its meat. The Gemara explains: <b>We</b> mean to <b>say</b> that any priest who is <b>fit for effecting atonement</b> may partake of it, even one who did not participate in the service.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> there is the case of <b>a minor, who is unfit for effecting atonement, and</b> who nevertheless <b>partakes</b> of sacrificial meat. The Gemara explains: <b>Rather, what</b> is meant by the term: <b>“Shall eat it”?</b> It means that he <b>shall receive a share of it.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is therefore that a priest who is <b>fit for effecting atonement receives a share</b> of the meat, but a priest <b>who is unfit for effecting atonement does not receive a share</b> of the meat. Minors do not receive a share, though they may partake of meat given to them by others.
The Gemara objects: But there is <b>a blemished priest, who is unfit for effecting atonement, and</b> yet he <b>receives a share</b> of its meat. The Gemara replies: <b>The Merciful One included a blemished</b> priest as an exception, as the verse that states: <b>“Every male among the priests</b> shall eat it” (Leviticus 6:22), serves <b>to include a blemished</b> priest.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But say</b> that the phrase <b>“every male”</b> serves <b>to include one who immersed that day,</b> teaching that he may also receive a share in the sacrificial meat. Why should it be understood as referring specifically to a blemished priest? The Gemara replies: <b>It stands to reason</b> that the Torah <b>should include a blemished</b> priest for receiving his own share of the meat, <b>because</b> he may <b>partake</b> of sacrificial meat in any event. By contrast, one who immersed that day is impure and may not touch or partake of sacrificial meat.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary,</b> the Torah <b>should include one who immersed that day, because,</b> unlike a blemished priest, <b>in the evening he will be fit</b> to perform the service. The Gemara replies: <b>Now, in any event,</b> the one who immersed himself <b>is not fit.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> another explanation: <b>Now what</b> is meant by the term: <b>“Shall eat it”?</b> It means: He <b>shall receive a share of it.</b> But if so, <b>let the Merciful One write: Shall receive a share of it. What</b> is the reason for writing: <b>“Shall eat it”? Learn from it</b> that only a priest who is <b>fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat, which includes a blemished priest, <b>receives a share</b> in the meat; but a priest <b>who is not fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat, e.g., one who immersed that day, <b>does not</b> receive a <b>share</b> in the meat.
§ <b>Reish Lakish raises a dilemma:</b> If a priest is <b>blemished and he is impure, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Must the other priests <b>give him a share</b> of the meat? Perhaps we say that <b>since he is not fit</b> to perform the rite as a blemished priest <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>the Merciful One included him</b> to receive a share in the meat, there <b>is no difference: What</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> if he is <b>impure,</b> and <b>what</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> if he is only <b>blemished?</b> In any event he is not fit, yet the Torah allows him to receive a share in the meat. <b>Or perhaps</b> he may not receive a share in the meat, because only a priest who is <b>fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat <b>receives a share</b> of the meat, but a priest <b>who is not fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat <b>does not receive a share</b> of the meat.
<b>Rabba said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a High Priest</b> is serving in the Temple and one of his immediate relatives dies, <b>he sacrifices</b> offerings even as <b>an acute mourner. But he does not partake</b> of sacrificial meat, <b>and he does not receive a share to partake</b> of it <b>in the evening. Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that in order for the priest to receive a share in sacrificial meat, <b>we require</b> that he be <b>fit for partaking</b> of it, and accordingly, a blemished priest who is impure does not receive a share. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that this is so.
§ <b>Rav Oshaya raises a dilemma:</b> If a priest is <b>impure,</b> then <b>in</b> a case of <b>communal offerings,</b> which may be offered by an impure priest, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do the other priests <b>give him a share</b> of the meat, so that he may partake of it in the evening when he becomes pure? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “The priest <b>who effects atonement,” and</b> therefore any priest who is fit for effecting atonement receives a share, as derived earlier, and <b>this</b> priest <b>is also</b> one who may <b>effect atonement,</b> since this is a communal offering? <b>Or perhaps</b> he may not, due to the principle that only a priest who is <b>fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat <b>receives a share</b> of the meat, but a priest <b>who is unfit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat <b>does not receive a share.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a High Priest</b> is serving in the Temple and one of his relatives dies, <b>he sacrifices</b> offerings even as <b>an acute mourner, but he does not partake</b> of sacrificial meat <b>and he does not receive a share</b> of it <b>to partake in the evening. Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that in order for a priest to receive a share in sacrificial meat, <b>we require</b> that he be <b>fit for partaking</b> of it at the time of the service, without regard to whether he can perform the service. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches: A priest who is <b>an acute mourner</b> is permitted to <b>touch</b> sacrificial meat, <b>but he may not sacrifice</b> offerings. The Gemara asks: Is it in fact permitted for <b>an acute mourner</b> to <b>touch</b> sacrificial meat? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 21a): <b>An acute mourner and one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, even after their respective disqualifications have expired, <b>require immersion</b> in order <b>to</b> eat <b>sacrificial</b> food. According to that mishna, an acute mourner who did not immerse may not touch sacrificial meat.
<b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> the mourner <b>immersed</b> during his day of acute mourning. This is why he is permitted to touch the sacrificial meat. <b>There,</b> the ruling of the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i> is stated <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> the mourner <b>did not immerse.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> even <b>if</b> he <b>immersed, what of it? But</b> doesn’t his <b>acute mourning return to him? As Rabba, son of Rav Huna, says:</b> In a case of <b>an acute mourner who immersed</b> during his day of his acute mourning, <b>his acute mourning returns to him.</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. That</b> case, in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i>, is one <b>where he was distracted</b> from safeguarding his state of purity, so he may not touch sacrificial meat in the event that he is impure. <b>This</b> case, in the mishna here, is one <b>where he was not distracted.</b>
The Gemara counters: If the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i> is discussing a case of <b>distraction,</b> then his status is like that of one who contracted ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, who <b>requires</b> sprinkling with water of purification on the <b>third and seventh</b> days of his impurity. <b>As Rabbi Yustai, son of Rabbi Matun, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> One who experienced <b>a distraction requires sprinkling</b> with water of purification on the <b>third and seventh</b> days.
The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult. That</b> statement, that he requires sprinkling, is discussing a case <b>where he was distracted</b> and careless <b>about</b> contracting <b>impurity imparted by a corpse. This</b> mishna in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i>, stating that he requires immersion but not sprinkling, is discussing a case <b>where he was distracted</b> and careless <b>about</b> contracting <b>impurity imparted by</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal.</b>
The Gemara counters: One who was careless about becoming <b>impure due to</b> the carcass of <b>a creeping animal is fully impure,</b> and so he requires not only immersion to become pure, but he also <b>requires sunset. And furthermore,</b> if the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i> is discussing this case, the mourner should be prohibited from touching <b>even <i>teruma</i>,</b> not just sacrificial meat. Why does the mishna mention only the latter?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> The mishna is discussing a case <b>where he says: I safeguarded myself from anything that would render me impure,</b> so I am certain that I did not contract impurity that requires waiting until sunset; <b>but I did not safeguard my-self from anything that would render me unfit</b> for touching sacrificial meat.
The Gemara asks: <b>But is there</b> such a concept of <b>partial care,</b> that one can claim to have safeguarded himself from one form of impurity but not another? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one was carrying a basket, and <b>the basket was still on his head,</b>

Daf 99b

<b>and a shovel</b> was <b>in</b> the basket, <b>and he said: I am minding the basket,</b> that it not become impure, <b>but I am not minding the shovel,</b> then <b>the basket is pure, and the shovel is impure.</b>
The Gemara challenges the ruling of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But</b> wouldn’t <b>the shovel render the basket impure?</b> The Gemara answers: There is a principle that <b>a vessel does not render</b> another <b>vessel ritually impure.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> wouldn’t <b>the shovel render that which is in</b> the basket, e.g., figs, <b>impure? Rava said:</b> The case is <b>where he says: I safeguarded it,</b> the shovel, <b>from anything that</b> would allow it to <b>render</b> another item <b>impure, but I did not safeguard it from anything that would render it</b> itself <b>unfit,</b> i.e., impure.
The Gemara returns to discuss the contradiction between the mishna, which permits an acute mourner to touch sacrificial meat, and the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i>, which requires him to immerse. The Gemara relates: <b>The matter circulated and came before Rabbi Abba bar Memel. He said to</b> the Sages before him: <b>Have they not heard that which Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: One who partakes of <i>teruma</i></b> that has <b>third-</b>degree impurity, i.e., <i>teruma</i> disqualified through contact with an item with second-degree impurity, <b>is prohibited from partaking</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>but permitted to touch</b> <i>teruma</i>.
Rabbi Abba bar Memel continued: <b>Apparently, in</b> a case of <b>partaking, the Sages imposed a higher standard,</b> whereas <b>in</b> a case of <b>touching, the Sages did not impose a higher standard.</b> Similarly, in a case of an acute mourner, the Sages require him to immerse before he may partake of sacrificial meat, as taught in tractate <i>Ḥagiga</i>, but they do not impose this standard for touching the meat, as taught in the mishna here.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to an acute mourner: <b>And he does not receive a share</b> of sacrificial meat in order <b>to partake</b> of it in the evening. The Gemara comments: The mishna indicates only that <b>he may not receive a share</b> of the meat, <b>but when</b> other priests <b>invite him</b> to join in their portions, <b>he may partake</b> of them in the evening.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 91b): <b>An acute mourner immerses and partakes of his Paschal offering in the evening, but</b> he may <b>not</b> partake <b>of</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat.
<b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the first night of <b>Passover,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Pesaḥim</i>, the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to the rest of the days of the year.</b>
What is the reason for the distinction between the two? <b>On</b> the first night of <b>Passover, since he partakes of</b> the <b>Paschal offering, he may also partake of</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat. But <b>on the rest of the days of the year, when he is unfit</b> to partake of sacrificial meat, <b>he is unfit. And what</b> does the mishna in <i>Pesaḥim</i> mean when it states: <b>But</b> he may <b>not</b> partake <b>of</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat? It means: <b>But</b> he may <b>not</b> partake <b>of sacrificial</b> meat <b>of all</b> of the rest of <b>the year,</b> other than the first night of Passover.
<b>Rav Asi said</b> there is a different resolution to the contradiction between the <i>mishnayot</i>: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the ruling of the mishna in tractate <i>Pesaḥim</i>, which prohibits an acute mourner from partaking of sacrificial meat, it is referring to a case <b>where his</b> relative <b>died on the fourteenth</b> day of Nisan, <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> itself, in which case he is still considered an acute mourner by rabbinic law that evening. <b>There,</b> in the ruling of the mishna in this chapter, it is referring to a case <b>where his</b> relative <b>died on the thirteenth</b> of Nisan, <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan. The reason the mourner may partake is that since <b>the day of burial</b> is not the day of death, it <b>does not take hold of its</b> following <b>night by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that <b>acute mourning</b> the following <b>night</b> is <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as opposed to by Torah law? This <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Acute mourning at night is by Torah law;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> His status as <b>an acute mourner</b> at night <b>is not by Torah law, but by rabbinic law. Know</b> that this so, <b>as</b> the Sages <b>said: An acute mourner immerses and partakes of his Paschal offering in the evening, but</b> he may still <b>not</b> partake <b>of</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat. If acute mourning at night were by Torah law, he would not be permitted to partake of the Paschal offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Shimon hold</b> that <b>acute mourning at night is by rabbinic law</b> and that consequently an acute mourner partakes of his Paschal offering in the evening? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: An acute mourner does not send his offerings</b> to the Temple to be sacrificed? <b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>even to a Paschal offering?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to all offerings <b>other than a Paschal offering.</b>
The Gemara counters: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the verse: “And if his offering be a sacrifice of peace offerings [<i>shelamim</i>]” (Leviticus 3:1), <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The offering is called <b><i>shelamim</i></b> to teach that <b>when</b> a person <b>is whole [<i>shalem</i>],</b> i.e., in a state of contentment, <b>he brings</b> his offering, <b>but he does not bring</b> it <b>when he is an acute mourner. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> that an acute mourner does not bring even <b>a thanks offering? I include the thanks offering because it is consumed in</b> a state of <b>joy, like a peace offering.</b>
<b>From where</b> is it derived that the verse also serves <b>to include a burnt offering? I include the burnt offering because it comes as a vow</b> offering <b>and as a gift</b> offering, <b>like a peace offering. From where</b> is it derived that the verse also serves <b>to include a firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and a Paschal offering,</b> which are not brought voluntarily? <b>I include a firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> an animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and a Paschal offering, because they</b> too, like a peace offering, <b>do not come</b> to atone <b>for a sin. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include a sin offering and a guilt offering,</b> which atone for sins? <b>The verse states:</b> “And if his offering be <b>a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>]</b> of peace offerings,” which teaches that an acute mourner may not sacrifice any slaughtered offering [<i>zevaḥ</i>].
<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> even <b>the bird offerings, and the meal offerings, and the wine, and the wood, and the frankincense</b> brought for the Temple service? <b>The verse states:</b> “And if <b>his offering</b> be a sacrifice of <b>peace offerings [<i>shelamim korbano</i>],”</b> teaching that for <b>all offerings [<i>korbanot</i>] that</b> a person <b>brings, he brings</b> them <b>when he is whole [<i>shalem</i>], but he does not bring</b> them <b>when he is an acute mourner.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>In any event,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>teaches</b> that it is prohibited for an acute mourner to bring <b>a Paschal offering,</b> even though he will cease to be an acute mourner that night; this contradicts the first <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The latter <i>baraita</i> mentions <b>a Paschal offering for no purpose.</b> In other words, the <i>halakha</i> that an acute mourner does not bring an offering does not actually apply to a Paschal offering, and the <i>baraita</i> mentions it only out of habit, since a firstborn-animal offering, the animal tithe offering, and a Paschal offering are frequently mentioned together.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: What</b> is meant in this <i>baraita</i> by the term: <b>Paschal offering?</b> It is referring to <b>the peace offerings of Passover,</b> i.e., the peace offering that is sacrificed along with the Paschal offering. The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> that <b>is</b> the same as <b>a peace offering,</b> which Rabbi Shimon already mentioned. The Gemara answers: He <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>peace offerings that come on account of</b> the <b>Paschal offering, and</b> he <b>taught</b> separately the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>peace offerings that come on their own account.</b>
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Shimon needed to teach both cases explicitly, <b>because if he did not teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>peace offerings that come on account of</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> it would <b>enter your mind to say: Since they come on account of</b> the <b>Paschal offering, they are considered like</b> the <b>Paschal offering itself,</b> and the acute mourner offers them as well. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon <b>teaches us</b> that these peace offerings are also forbidden to an acute mourner.
<b>Rav Mari said</b> a different resolution to the contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Shimon:

Daf 100a

It is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> where Rabbi Shimon holds an acute mourner may not send a Paschal offering, since acute mourning at night is by Torah law, it is referring to a case <b>where his</b> relative <b>died on the fourteenth</b> day of Nisan <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> itself. <b>There,</b> the ruling in the mishna in tractate <i>Pesaḥim</i>, which teaches that an acute mourner immerses and partakes of the Paschal offering in the evening, since acute mourning at night is by rabbinic law, is referring to a case <b>where his</b> relative <b>died on the thirteenth</b> day of Nisan <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan.
Rav Mari explains: In a case where <b>his</b> relative <b>died on the fourteenth</b> day of Nisan <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> itself, his acute mourning is due to <b>the day of death</b> and is therefore by Torah law. Consequently, it <b>takes hold of its</b> following <b>night by Torah law,</b> and the mitzva of the Paschal offering does not override it. By contrast, in a case where <b>his</b> relative <b>died on the thirteenth</b> day of Nisan <b>and he buried him on the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, the fourteenth is only <b>the day of burial,</b> and his acute mourning is therefore <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Consequently, <b>it takes hold of its</b> following <b>night only by rabbinic law,</b> and the mitzva of the Paschal offering overrides it.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Mari: But</b> if so, it is difficult to understand <b>that which</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Rabbi Shimon said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>Know</b> that this so, <b>as</b> the Sages <b>said: An acute mourner immerses</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>and partakes of his Paschal offering</b> in the evening, <b>but</b> he may <b>not</b> partake <b>of</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> meat. According to your explanation of this statement, <b>let</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>say to</b> Rabbi Shimon that this is no proof: <b>I am telling you</b> a <i>halakha</i> about <b>the day of death,</b> when acute mourning is <b>by Torah law, and you tell me</b> that you have a proof from a mishna that deals with <b>the day of burial,</b> when acute mourning is <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara concludes: This indeed poses <b>a difficulty</b> for Rav Mari.
<b>Abaye said</b> a different resolution to the contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Shimon: It is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> where Rabbi Shimon holds that an acute mourner may not send a Paschal offering, it is referring to a case <b>where</b> his relative <b>died before midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan. <b>There,</b> the ruling in the mishna in tractate <i>Pesaḥim</i>, which teaches that an acute mourner immerses and partakes of the Paschal offering in the evening, it is a case <b>where</b> his relative <b>died after midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan. When his relative died <b>before midday,</b> in <b>which</b> case <b>he was not</b> ever <b>fit for</b> bringing <b>a Paschal offering</b> since the obligation begins at midday, the status of <b>acute mourning applies to him,</b> and it is prohibited for him to bring a Paschal offering. But if his relative dies <b>after midday, when he is</b> already <b>fit for</b> bringing <b>a Paschal offering,</b> the status of <b>acute mourning does not apply to him</b> with regard to this matter, so he may immerse and partake of the Paschal offering in the evening.
The Gemara explains: <b>And from where do you say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is different</b> depending on <b>whether</b> his relative died <b>before midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan or <b>whether</b> he died <b>after midday? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states with regard to a priest: “And for his sister a virgin, that is near unto him, that has had no husband, <b>for her may he become impure”</b> (Leviticus 21:3). From here it is derived that it is <b>a mitzva</b> for a priest to become impure in order to bury his deceased relatives, and if he <b>did not want</b> to do so, others must <b>render him impure against his will. And an incident</b> occurred <b>involving Yosef the priest, where his wife died on Passover eve, and he did not want to become impure,</b> as he wanted to offer the Paschal offering; <b>and his brethren the priests voted and rendered him impure against his will.</b>
<b>And</b> the Sages <b>raise a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> with regard to a nazirite: “He shall not become impure for his father, or for his mother, for his brother, <b>or for his sister</b> when they die; because his consecration unto God is upon his head” (Numbers 6:7)? If a nazirite <b>went to slaughter his Paschal offering or to circumcise his son,</b> mitzvot for which failure to fulfill them is punishable by <i>karet</i>, <b>and he heard that</b> a relative <b>of his died,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that he should <b>become impure</b> in order to bury his relative even if this will result in his not bringing the Paschal offering. <b>You</b> rather <b>say,</b> based on this verse, that <b>“he shall not become impure.”</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>just as he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>his sister, so too he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>a corpse with no one to bury it [<i>met mitzva</i>]. The verse states: “Or for his sister,”</b> teaching that <b>it is</b> only <b>to</b> bury <b>his sister that he may not become impure, but he does become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b>
In the first <i>baraita</i>, contracting impurity from a dead relative is obligatory, and in the second <i>baraita</i> it is forbidden. Do you <b>not learn from</b> this contradiction that there must be a distinction between the cases? <b>Here,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i> concerning a priest, it must be referring to a case where the relative died <b>before midday,</b> so he was obligated to become impure before the obligation for the Paschal offering took effect. <b>There,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i> concerning a nazirite, it must be referring to a case where the relative died <b>after midday.</b> This distinction, between death before and after midday, also applies to acute mourning.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>From where</b> do you infer that this is the resolution to the contradiction? <b>Actually, perhaps I will say to you:</b> Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are discussing deaths that occurred <b>after midday. And this</b> <i>baraita</i>, about a nazirite, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, and that</b> <i>baraita</i>, about Yosef the priest, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states with regard to a priest: “And for his sister a virgin, that is near unto him, that has had no husband, <b>for her may he become impure”</b> (Leviticus 21:3). This is <b>optional,</b> i.e., a priest is not obligated to become impure to bury his sister; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> It is <b>mandatory.</b>
The Gemara responds: This should <b>not enter your mind, because</b> it is <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> who <b>teaches the first clause of</b> the <i>baraita</i> about a nazirite. <b>As it is taught</b> in the full version of that <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states: “All the days that he consecrates himself unto the Lord he shall not come near to a dead body. He shall not become impure for his father, or for his mother, for his brother, or for his sister when they die; because his consecration unto God is upon his head” (Numbers 6:7). <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The term <b>“body [<i>nefesh</i>]”</b> is referring to <b>relatives.</b> The term <b>“dead [<i>met</i>]”</b> is referring to <b>non-relatives.</b>
The verse specifies: <b>“For his father,”</b> even though his father is included among his relatives, to teach that <b>he may not become impure</b> to bury his father, <b>but he does become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b> The verse states: <b>“For his mother,”</b> to teach that even if <b>he was a priest and he was a nazirite,</b> and therefore doubly prohibited from becoming impure, nevertheless, <b>he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>his mother but he does become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b> The verse states: <b>“For his brother,”</b> to teach <b>that</b> even <b>if he was a High Priest,</b> who may not become impure even for his relatives, <b>and he</b> was also <b>a nazirite,</b> nevertheless, <b>he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>his brother but he does become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b>
<b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Or for his sister”?</b> If a nazirite <b>went to slaughter his Paschal offering or to circumcise his son, and he heard that</b> a relative <b>of his died,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that he should <b>become impure. You</b> rather <b>say</b> that <b>he may not become impure.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>just as he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>his sister, so too he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>. The verse states: “Or for his sister,”</b> to teach that <b>he may not become impure to</b> bury <b>his sister but he does become impure to</b> bury <b>a <i>met mitzva</i>.</b> Consequently, the statement of the <i>baraita</i> concerning a nazirite represents the opinion of Rabbi Akiva.

Daf 100b

<b>Rava said</b> there is a different resolution to the contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Shimon. Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are discussing cases where the relative died <b>after midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and</b> still it is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> his relative died <b>before</b> the priests would have <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering <b>and sprinkled</b> its blood <b>on his account,</b> and he may not send the offering. <b>There,</b> the relative died <b>after</b> the priests <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering <b>and sprinkled</b> its blood <b>on his account.</b> Since acute mourning at night is by rabbinic law, it is suspended to allow him to consume an offering that was already sacrificed.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to Rava:</b> In a case where one’s relative died <b>after</b> the priests <b>slaughtered</b> the Paschal offering <b>and sprinkled its blood,</b> why should he be permitted to partake of the Paschal offering? <b>What was, was,</b> and although the offering was sacrificed, isn’t he still an acute mourner by rabbinic law? <b>Ravina said to</b> Rav Adda bar Mattana: <b>Partaking of</b> the <b>Paschal offering is indispensable</b> for the mitzva, as is seen <b>from that which Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> taught, as the Gemara will explain. Therefore, the Sages did not prohibit the acute mourner from partaking of the Paschal offering as they do for other offerings, for which consumption of the meat is dispensable. Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Adda bar Mattana: <b>Listen to what your master,</b> Ravina, <b>told you,</b> as his explanation is correct.
<b>What</b> is the statement <b>of Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> that teaches that partaking of the Paschal offering is indispensable? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The day</b> that a person receives <b>tidings</b> that his relative died is considered <b>as</b> if it were <b>the day of burial</b> with regard <b>to the mitzva of</b> the <b>seven</b>-day mourning period, when he may not bathe or wear shoes, <b>and</b> with regard to the <b>thirty</b>-day period when he may not wear ironed garments. <b>And with regard to partaking of</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> the day he receives the tidings is <b>like the day of the gathering of</b> the <b>bones</b> of the deceased after the flesh decomposed (see <i>Pesaḥim</i> 92a). In <b>both this and that</b> case, <b>he immerses and partakes of sacrificial</b> meat <b>in the evening.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself</b> is <b>difficult.</b> At first <b>you say: The day of tidings</b> is considered <b>as</b> if it were <b>the day of burial for the mitzva of</b> the <b>seven</b>-day <b>and thirty</b>-day mourning periods; <b>and with regard to partaking of</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> it is <b>like the day of the gathering of bones,</b> when one may immerse and partake of sacrificial meat in the evening. <b>By inference,</b> one concludes <b>that</b> on <b>the day of burial, he</b> may <b>not partake</b> of the Paschal offering <b>even in the evening,</b> and all the more so other sacrificial meat. <b>And then</b> it <b>is taught:</b> In <b>both this and that</b> case, i.e., on both the day of burial and the day of the gathering of bones, <b>he immerses and partakes of sacrificial</b> meat <b>in the evening.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> Whether it is permitted to partake of sacrificial meat the night after the day of burial <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the latter clause, where the <i>baraita</i> teaches that on both the day of burial and the day of the gathering of bones he immerses and partakes of sacrificial meat in the evening, it is referring to a case <b>where he heard tidings of his dead</b> relative <b>just before sunset, and likewise</b> a case <b>where they gathered</b> the <b>bones for him just before sunset, and likewise</b> a case <b>where his</b> relative <b>died and he buried him just before sunset. But there,</b> in the first clause, from which it is inferred that he may not consume any sacrificial meat the night after the day of burial, the burial occurred <b>after sunset,</b> i.e., on the night of the fifteenth of Nisan itself.
The Gemara objects: If so, why not say that even if he gathered bones <b>after sunset,</b> then <b>what was, was?</b> Why did the Sages permit him to partake of the Paschal offering, as opposed to other sacrificial meat? <b>Rather, learn from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that <b>partaking of</b> the <b>Paschal offering is indispensable</b> to fulfilling the obligation, and due to the severity of the mitzva, the Sages suspended their decree prohibiting one from partaking of it.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> there is another resolution to this question: <b>What</b> is meant by the latter clause in the <i>baraita</i>: In <b>both this and that</b> case? It does not mean both the day of burial and the day of the gathering of bones. Rather, <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Both</b> on <b>the day of tidings and</b> on <b>the day of</b> the <b>gathering</b> of bones, the mourner <b>immerses and partakes of sacrificial</b> meat <b>in the evening.</b> But after the day of burial, he may not partake of the Paschal offering, and all the more so of other sacrificial meat, as indicated in the first clause in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara notes: <b>And this</b> resolution <b>of Rav Ashi is a mistake, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> is already <b>discussing those</b> two cases and equating them. According to Rav Ashi’s resolution, it is extraneous to say: In both this and that case; the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> simply said: In <b>this and that</b> case. <b>Rather, learn from</b> the language of the <i>baraita</i> that Rav Ashi’s resolution <b>is a mistake.</b>
The Gemara returns to discuss Rav Ḥisda’s resolution: <b>And what</b> is the dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> with regard to the night following the day of burial? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until when</b> does a person <b>mourn acutely for</b> his relative, such that he is prohibited to partake of sacrificial meat? <b>The entire day. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: As long as</b> his relative <b>has not been buried.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> we are dealing <b>with the day of death, is there</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who does not hold that the day of death takes hold of its</b> following <b>night,</b> at least <b>by rabbinic law?</b> In accordance with whose opinion is the statement of the first <i>tanna</i>, who says that the acute mourning is only during the day, and not at night?
<b>And furthermore,</b> if we are dealing with the day of death, then when <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: As long as</b> his relative <b>has not been buried,</b> it indicates that <b>consequently,</b> once he <b>has buried him, it becomes permitted for him</b> to partake of sacrificial meat, even on the day of death itself. <b>But is there</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>who does not hold</b> that acute mourning extends for the entire day of death, even after burial? The verse states: “And I will turn your feasts into mourning, and all your songs into lamentation; and I will bring up sackcloth upon all loins, and baldness upon every head; and I will make it as the mourning for an only son, <b>and the end thereof as a bitter day”</b> (Amos 8:10).
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> is <b>discussing the day of burial</b> when it is not the day of death. The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree whether the acute mourning lasts only until the burial, or until the end of the day of burial.
