<b>Rav Yosef objects</b> to this: <b>But</b> there is <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who hears</b> tidings <b>of his dead</b> relative is considered <b>as one who gathers</b> his relative’s <b>bones,</b> in that he may <b>immerse and partake of sacrificial</b> meat <b>in the evening. By inference,</b> on <b>the day of burial he may not partake even in the evening.</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this?</b> This is the opinion of neither the first <i>tanna</i> nor Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rather,</b> one must <b>answer</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>Until when</b> does a person <b>mourn acutely for</b> his relative? <b>That entire day</b> of burial <b>and its</b> following <b>night. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> He continues into the night only <b>as long as</b> his relative <b>has not been buried; but</b> once he <b>is buried,</b> the acute mourning lasts only for the rest of the day, <b>without its night.</b>
The Sages <b>said this</b> statement of Rav Yosef <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said</b> in surprise: <b>Would a great man like Rav Yosef say this? Would he say</b> that the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi is the more <b>lenient</b> of the two? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until when</b> does a person <b>mourn acutely for</b> his relative? <b>As long as</b> his relative <b>has not been buried, even</b> if he remains unburied <b>from now until ten days</b> from now. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Sages say: He mourns acutely for</b> his relative <b>only on that</b> same <b>day.</b> The opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is more stringent than that of the Sages.
<b>Rather, answer like this: Until when</b> does a person <b>mourn acutely for</b> his relative? <b>That entire day</b> of burial, <b>without its night. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The acute mourning continues <b>as long as</b> his relative <b>has not been buried,</b> even for ten days, <b>and once he is buried,</b> that day <b>takes hold of its night.</b> This is the dispute to which Rav Ḥisda referred.
The Sages <b>said this</b> statement <b>before Rava.</b> Rava said: <b>Since Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that <b>the day of burial,</b> when acute mourning is by rabbinic law, <b>takes hold of its night by rabbinic law, by inference,</b> he must hold <b>that the day of death,</b> when acute mourning is by Torah law, <b>takes hold of its night by Torah law.</b> The Sages would not be more stringent with their ordinance than the parallel law of the Torah.
The Gemara objects: <b>And does Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>hold</b> that <b>acute mourning at night is by Torah law? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: On the last day of the inauguration of the Tabernacle, after two of Aaron’s sons died, Aaron said to Moses: <b>“Behold,</b> today…there have befallen me such things as these; and if I had consumed the sin offering today, would it have been good in the eyes of the Lord?” (Leviticus 10:19). The word “today” teaches that Aaron is saying: <b>I am prohibited</b> from partaking <b>today but permitted</b> to partake at <b>night; but for</b> future <b>generations,</b> an acute mourner is <b>prohibited</b> from partaking of sacrificial meat <b>whether during the day or at night.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> For future generations, <b>acute mourning at night is not by Torah law,</b> but <b>rather by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that acute mourning on the night after death <b>is by rabbinic law,</b> not Torah law.

Daf 101a

<b>And</b> the same holds for the night after the day of burial, even though the acute mourning of that day itself is by rabbinic law, because <b>the Sages reinforced their pronouncements with greater</b> severity <b>than Torah</b> law.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: On the eighth day of the inauguration of the Tabernacle, on which two of Aaron’s sons died, Moses spoke to Aaron and his sons using three different forms of the word command: <b>“For so I am commanded [<i>tzuveiti</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 10:13), <b>“as I commanded [<i>tziveiti</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 10:18), and <b>“as the Lord has commanded [<i>tziva</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 10:15). Moses said to Aaron: “And you shall eat it…<b>for so I am commanded,”</b> to teach that Aaron and his remaining sons <b>shall partake of</b> the offerings even <b>in acute mourning.</b> The statement: “You should certainly have eaten it…<b>as I commanded,”</b> Moses <b>said to them at the time of</b> the <b>incident,</b> when Aaron and his sons burned the sin offering for the New Moon. Moses said: <b>“As the Lord has commanded,”</b> to emphasize that it is <b>not of my own</b> initiative that <b>I say</b> this, but it is from the word of God.
<b>And</b> the Sages <b>raise a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: The sin offering <b>was burned due to</b> the <b>acute mourning</b> of Aaron and his sons, since they felt they could not partake of it. <b>Therefore,</b> it <b>is stated</b> in Aaron’s explanation: “There have befallen me such things <b>as these;</b> and if I had consumed the sin offering today, would it have been good in the eyes of the Lord?” (Leviticus 10:19). Moses conceded to Aaron that he was correct (see Leviticus 10:20), indicating that it was not permitted for Aaron to partake of the sin offering in acute mourning.
<b>Shmuel said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> first <i>baraita</i>, according to which Moses commanded Aaron and his sons to consume the sacrificial meat in acute mourning, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda;</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, according to which they acted properly in refraining from eating it, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Aaron and his sons <b>burned</b> the sin offering <b>due to</b> their <b>acute mourning. Therefore,</b> it <b>is stated: “As these”;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Neḥemya. Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon say:</b> The sin offering <b>was burned due to ritual impurity. As, if you say</b> that it <b>was burned due to acute mourning,</b> they <b>should have burned</b> all <b>three of</b> the sin offerings offered that day. <b>Alternatively,</b> if it was burned due to acute mourning, <b>they would have been fit to partake of</b> the sin offerings <b>in the evening,</b> and there would have been no need to burn them. <b>Alternatively,</b> if it was burned due to acute mourning, <b>wasn’t Pinehas,</b> son of Elazar the priest, <b>with them?</b> He was not in mourning, and he could have partaken of the sin offering.
<b>Rava said:</b> Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who holds that the sin offering was burned due to acute mourning. <b>And</b> this is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> according to which Moses commanded that Aaron and his sons partake of the offering as acute mourners is referring <b>to the offerings of</b> a particular <b>time,</b> i.e., the meal offering, which was unique to the inauguration ceremony. <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> according to which they rightly burned the sin offering, due to acute mourning, is referring <b>to the offerings of</b> all future <b>generations.</b> That sin offering was brought for the New Moon of Nisan, and such an offering would be brought at every New Moon from that day onward. Moses conceded that such offerings should not be consumed by acute mourners.
The Gemara asks: <b>How</b> would <b>Rabbi Neḥemya reconcile these</b> apparently contradictory <b>verses</b> about the sin offering, <b>and how</b> would <b>the Sages reconcile these verses</b> (see Leviticus 10:17–20)?
<b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> would <b>reconcile them like this:</b> When Moses asked: <b>“Why have you not eaten</b> the sin offering?” (Leviticus 10:17), this is what <b>Moses said to Aaron: Perhaps the blood of</b> this sin offering <b>entered the innermost sanctum,</b> thereby disqualifying it (see Leviticus 6:23). Is this why you burned it? Aaron <b>said to him: “Behold, the blood of it was not brought</b> into the Sanctuary within” (Leviticus 10:18). Moses then asked: <b>Perhaps it went outside its partition,</b> i.e., it exited the courtyard of the Tabernacle, and was thereby disqualified? Aaron <b>said to him: It was inside the sacred</b> area at all times.
Moses then suggested: <b>But perhaps you sacrificed it in acute mourning,</b> which is prohibited for ordinary priests, <b>and disqualified it.</b> Aaron <b>said to him: Moses, was it they,</b> i.e., my sons, <b>who sacrificed</b> the offering? <b>I sacrificed</b> the offering, and as High Priest, I may serve even as an acute mourner (see Leviticus 21:10–12). <b>And</b> Moses <b>said to him: “Behold, the blood of it was not brought</b> into the Sanctuary within,” <b>and it was inside the sacred</b> area at all times; therefore: <b>“You should certainly have consumed it</b> in the sacred area, <b>as I commanded”</b> (Leviticus 10:18), i.e., just as I commanded that the priests should <b>consume</b> today’s meal offering <b>in acute mourning.</b>
Aaron <b>said to him:</b> “Behold, today have they sacrificed their sin offering and their burnt offering before the Lord, <b>and there have befallen me such things as these; and if I had consumed the sin offering today, would it have been good in the eyes of the Lord?”</b> (Leviticus 10:19). <b>Perhaps you heard</b> the command to consume the offering <b>only with regard to offerings of</b> a particular <b>time,</b> i.e., the meal offering, which was unique to that day.
<b>As, if</b> you claim that it also applies <b>to the offerings of</b> all <b>generations,</b> then one can prove this is not so via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the second <b>tithe,</b> for <b>which</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> more <b>lenient</b> than for sacrificial meat: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the second <b>tithe,</b> for <b>which</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> more <b>lenient, the Torah stated: “I have not eaten thereof in my mourning [<i>ve’oni</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:14), teaching that an acute mourner [<i>onen</i>] is prohibited from partaking of it, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that <b>with regard to the offerings of</b> all <b>generations,</b> an acute mourner is prohibited from partaking of them?
Moses <b>immediately conceded</b> to Aaron, as the verse states: <b>“And Moses heard, and it was good in his eyes”</b> (Leviticus 10:20). <b>And Moses was not embarrassed</b> and did not attempt to justify himself <b>by saying: I did not hear</b> of this <i>halakha</i> until now. <b>Rather, he said: I heard</b> it, <b>and I forgot</b> it, as the verse indicates by stating: “Moses heard.”
The Gemara continues: <b>And how</b> would <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon,</b> who hold that the sin offering was burned due to ritual impurity, <b>reconcile those</b> verses? <b>They</b> would <b>reconcile them like this:</b> When Moses said to Aaron and his sons: <b>“Why have you not eaten the sin offering in the place of the Sanctuary?”</b> (Leviticus 10:17), he meant: <b>Perhaps its blood entered the innermost sanctum,</b> disqualifying the offering. Aaron <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>“Behold, the blood of it was not brought into the Sanctuary within”</b> (Leviticus 10:18).
Moses then asked: <b>Perhaps it went outside its partition,</b> i.e., the courtyard of the Tabernacle, and was thereby disqualified? Aaron <b>said to him: It was inside the sacred</b> area at all times. Moses then asked: <b>But perhaps you sacrificed it in acute mourning and disqualified it?</b> Aaron <b>said to him: Moses,</b> was it my sons who <b>sacrificed</b> the offering, <b>that</b> their <b>acute mourning</b> would <b>disqualify</b> the offering? <b>I,</b> the High Priest, <b>sacrificed</b> the offering, and I may serve even in acute mourning.
Moses then asked: <b>Or perhaps, due to your bitterness</b> in mourning, <b>were you neglectful of</b> the offering <b>and it became impure?</b> Aaron <b>said to him: Moses, am I in your eyes such</b> a person, <b>that I</b> would <b>treat</b> an offering <b>consecrated to Heaven with contempt? “There have befallen me such things as these”</b> (Leviticus 10:19), i.e., <b>even</b> if <b>these</b> tragedies <b>and</b> more <b>such as them</b> should befall me, <b>I</b> would <b>not treat</b> an offering <b>consecrated to Heaven with contempt.</b>
Moses <b>said to him:</b> If so, <b>and if,</b> as you say: <b>“Behold, the blood of it was not brought</b> into the Sanctuary within,” <b>and</b> it <b>was inside the sacred</b> area at all times, then: <b>“You should certainly have eaten it in the sacred area, as I commanded,”</b> i.e., as I commanded that the priests should <b>consume</b> the meal offering even <b>in acute mourning.</b>
Aaron <b>said to him: Perhaps you heard</b> the command to consume the offering <b>only with regard to the night</b> following the day of acute mourning, but during the day itself the prohibition stands. <b>As, if</b> you claim that it may be consumed <b>during the day</b> itself, I can prove that this is not so via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the second <b>tithe,</b> for <b>which</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> more <b>lenient</b> than for sacrificial meat: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the second <b>tithe,</b> for <b>which</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> more <b>lenient, the Torah stated: I have not eaten thereof in my mourning, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that in the <b>stringent</b> case of <b>sacrificial</b> meat, an acute mourner is prohibited from partaking of it?
Moses <b>immediately</b> conceded to Aaron, as the verse states: <b>“And Moses heard,</b>

Daf 101b

<b>and it was good in his eyes”</b> (Leviticus 10:20). <b>Moses was not embarrassed</b> and did not attempt to justify himself <b>by saying: I did not hear</b> this <i>halakha</i> until now. <b>Rather,</b> he said: <b>I heard</b> it, <b>and I forgot</b> it.
The Gemara asks: According to this opinion, why was the sin offering burned? <b>They should have delayed its</b> consumption <b>and consumed</b> it that <b>night.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Ritual impurity came</b> upon this sin offering <b>due to circumstances beyond</b> the priests’ <b>control,</b> and they were forced to burn it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, <b>this is as it is written:</b> “And if I had consumed the sin offering <b>today,</b> would it have been good in the eyes of the Lord”? The verse indicates that Aaron could have eaten it at night. <b>But according to Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who holds that Aaron distinguished between the offerings of that particular time and the offerings of all later generations, <b>what</b> did Aaron mean by the word <b>“today”?</b> The Gemara answers: He meant: And if I had eaten the sin offering of the New Moon, which is <b>today’s obligation,</b> would it have been good in the eyes of the Lord?
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Neḥemya, this is as it is written: “Behold, today</b> have they sacrificed their sin offering and their burnt offering before the Lord,” i.e., they offered it as the obligation of the day. <b>But according to the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, <b>what</b> did Aaron mean by the phrase “<b>behold [<i>hen</i>], today”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what Aaron <b>is saying: Did they [<i>hen</i>],</b> my sons, <b>sacrifice</b> the offering today, which would have been prohibited to them in acute mourning? No, <b>I sacrificed</b> the offering, and as High Priest, I may perform the service in acute mourning.
§ The Gemara continues to analyze the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master says:</b> If the sin offering was burned due to acute mourning, then the priests <b>should have burned</b> all <b>three of</b> the sin offerings offered that day. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: All <b>three of</b> the sin offerings?
The Gemara responds: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And Moses diligently inquired for the goat of the sin offering,</b> and behold, it was burned” (Leviticus 10:16). When the verse states: “The <b>goat,” this</b> is referring to <b>the goat of Nahshon,</b> son of Amminadav, the prince of the tribe of Judah, who brought the offering on the first day of the Tabernacle’s inauguration (see Numbers 7:12). When the verse states: “The <b>sin offering,” this</b> is referring to the <b>sin offering</b> that the people brought on the <b>eighth</b> day of the inauguration (see Leviticus 9:13). The term <b>“inquired”</b> is referring to the <b>goat</b> sacrificed at every <b>New Moon</b> (see Numbers 28:15). The Tabernacle was erected on the New Moon of Nisan (see Exodus 40:17). These are the three goats that were sacrificed that day.
One <b>might</b> have thought that all <b>three of them were burned.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And Moses diligently inquired for the goat of the sin offering, <b>and, behold, it was burned,”</b> to teach that <b>one</b> of the offerings <b>was burned, but not</b> all <b>three of them were burned.</b> The verse states: “And Moses <b>diligently inquired [<i>darosh darash</i>].” Why</b> were there <b>two inquiries?</b> Moses <b>said to them: For what</b> reason is <b>this sin offering burned, and</b> secondly, for what reason are <b>those left</b> unburned? The <i>baraita</i> comments: Still, <b>I do not know which of them</b> was burned. <b>When it states</b> with regard to the burned goat: <b>“And He has given it to you to bear the iniquity of the congregation”</b> (Leviticus 10:17), <b>you must say: This is the goat of the New Moon,</b> which atones for impurity in the Temple.
The Gemara comments: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <b>say well to</b> Rabbi Neḥemya; if the sin offering was burned due to acute mourning, then all three goats should have been burned. How would Rabbi Neḥemya respond? The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Acute mourning does not disqualify offerings of</b> a particular <b>time.</b> Therefore, they burned only the New Moon sin offering, which applies to future generations as well.
<b>The Master says</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: If the sin offering was burned due to acute mourning, why was it burned at all? <b>He should have eaten it in the evening.</b> The Gemara comments: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <b>say well to</b> Rabbi Neḥemya in posing this difficulty. How would he respond? The Gemara explains: He <b>holds</b> that <b>acute mourning in the evening</b> is <b>by Torah law,</b> and therefore the priests were not permitted to eat it even then.
Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon also stated: <b>Alternatively, wasn’t Pinehas,</b> son of Elazar the priest, <b>with them?</b> He was not an acute mourner. The Gemara comments: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <b>say well to</b> Rabbi Neḥemya. The Gemara explains: <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. As Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: Pinehas did not become a priest until he killed Zimri,</b> who had engaged in intercourse with a Midianite woman (see Numbers 25:6–8). <b>As it is written</b> only after that incident concerning Pinehas: <b>“And it shall be unto him and to his seed after him the covenant of an everlasting priesthood”</b> (Numbers 25:13). Before that incident, at the time of the inauguration of the Tabernacle, the only priests were Aaron and his sons.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Pinehas did not become a priest <b>until he made peace among the tribes</b> at the time of the conquest of Eretz Yisrael, when the tribes east of the Jordan River built their own altar and nearly provoked a civil war. Before this, Pinehas was always referred to as: Son of Elazar the priest, but during this incident he is himself referred to as a priest for the first time, <b>as it is stated: “And Pinehas the priest, and the princes of the congregation, and the heads of the thousands of Israel</b> that were with him, <b>heard</b> the words that the children of Reuben and the children of Gad and the children of Manasseh spoke, and it pleased them well” (Joshua 22:30).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> for <b>the other</b> Sage, Rav Ashi, <b>as well, isn’t it written: “And it shall be unto him, and to his seed after him,</b> the covenant of an everlasting priesthood”? Apparently, Pinehas became a priest after he killed Zimri. The Gemara responds: <b>When that</b> verse <b>is written,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>blessing that it is written,</b> that his descendants would always be priests. It did not indicate that Pinehas became a priest immediately.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> for <b>the other</b> Sages <b>as well,</b> who hold that Pinehas became a priest immediately after he killed Zimri, <b>isn’t it written: “And Pinehas the priest…heard”?</b> Apparently he became a priest only after the conquest of Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse serves <b>to entitle his descendants after him,</b> that they would continue as High Priests through his merit.
§ <b>Rav says: Moses, our teacher,</b> was <b>a High Priest and would receive a share of offerings</b> consecrated <b>to Heaven, as it is stated:</b> “And Moses took the breast, and waved it for a wave offering before the Lord; <b>it was Moses’ portion of the ram of inauguration,</b> as the Lord commanded Moses” (Leviticus 8:29).
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> In the <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon claim that acute mourning was not the reason the sin offering was burned by asking: <b>Wasn’t Pinehas with them? And if it is so</b> that Moses could partake of sacrificial meat, <b>let them say: Wasn’t Moses, our teacher, with them?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps Moses is different, since</b> as a prophet, <b>he was preoccupied with the Divine Presence,</b> and was not available. <b>As the Master says: Moses ascended</b> Mount Sinai <b>early in the morning, and</b> he <b>descended early in the morning.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s statement from another <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to a blemished priest: <b>“He may eat the bread of his God, both of the most sacred, and of the sacred”</b> (Leviticus 21:22). <b>If offerings of the most sacred order are stated,</b> that a blemished priest may eat them, then <b>why</b> are <b>offerings of lesser sanctity</b> also <b>stated? And if offerings of lesser sanctity are stated, why</b> are <b>offerings of the most sacred order stated?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Had offerings of lesser sanctity not been stated, I would have said: It is</b> only <b>offerings of the most sacred order that</b> a blemished priest <b>may eat, as they were permitted</b> both <b>to a non-priest and to</b> the priests, but a blemished priest <b>may not eat offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> which were not permitted to non-priests. <b>And had offerings of the most sacred order not been stated, I would have said:</b> A blemished priest <b>may eat offerings of lesser sanctity, as they are of lesser sanctity,</b> but <b>he may not eat of offerings of the most sacred order,</b> as they are of higher sanctity. <b>Therefore, offerings of the most sacred order are stated, and therefore, offerings of lesser sanctity</b> are <b>stated.</b>
The Gemara explains the objection: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: As they were permitted</b> both <b>to a non-priest and to</b> the priests. What non-priest is permitted to eat offerings of the most sacred order? Is this <b>not</b> referring to <b>Moses?</b> This indicates that Moses was not considered a High Priest, contrary to Rav’s statement. <b>Rav Sheshet said: No,</b> this is referring <b>to a non-priest</b> sacrificing <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> Once the Jewish people entered Eretz Yisrael, it was permitted for a time for them to build private altars, on which even non-priests could serve. <b>And</b> although only offerings of lesser sanctity were offered on private altars, this <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with the statement of the</b> Sage who <b>says: There is a meal offering</b> that may be offered <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> Meal offerings are of the most sacred order.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s statement: When <b>Miriam</b> became a leper (see Numbers 12:10), <b>who</b> diagnosed and <b>quarantined her? If you say</b> that <b>Moses quarantined her,</b> that is difficult, as <b>Moses</b> was <b>a non-priest,</b>

Daf 102a

<b>and a non-priest may not inspect the</b> shades of leprous <b>marks</b> to diagnose them. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>Aaron quarantined her,</b> that is difficult, as <b>Aaron</b> was <b>a relative,</b> Miriam’s brother, <b>and a relative may not inspect the</b> shades of leprous <b>marks. Rather, the Holy One, Blessed be He, bestowed a great honor on Miriam at that time,</b> and said: <b>I</b> Myself <b>am a priest, and I</b> will <b>quarantine her</b> for seven days to see if the shades of leprous marks persist, and <b>I</b> will <b>declare her</b> a leper if she is impure, <b>and I</b> will <b>exempt her</b> if she is not impure.
<b>In any event,</b> the midrash <b>teaches: Moses</b> was <b>a non-priest, and a non-priest may not inspect the</b> shades of leprous <b>marks,</b> which contradicts the statement of Rav that Moses was a priest.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of the examination of <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks are different, because</b> specifically <b>Aaron and his sons,</b> and not Moses, <b>are written in the passage</b> that discusses them: “Then he shall be brought unto Aaron the priest, or unto one of his sons the priests” (Leviticus 13:2). Therefore, there is no proof from this <i>baraita</i> that Moses was not a priest.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Elisheva,</b> the daughter of Amminadav and the wife of Aaron, <b>had five more</b> reasons for <b>joy than</b> the other <b>daughters of Israel</b> on the day the Tabernacle was dedicated: <b>Her brother-in-law,</b> Moses, was <b>a king; her husband,</b> Aaron, was the <b>High Priest; her son,</b> Elazar, was the <b>deputy</b> High Priest; <b>her son’s son,</b> Pinehas, was the priest <b>anointed for war,</b> who would lead the army out to battle; <b>and her brother,</b> Nahshon, son of Amminadav, was <b>the prince of</b> the <b>tribe</b> of Judah, who brought his offering on that day, as the first of all the princes. <b>But</b> on that same day of joy she was <b>in mourning for her two sons,</b> Nadav and Avihu, who died on that day.
<b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Her brother-in-law,</b> Moses, was <b>a king.</b> From this one can infer that <b>yes,</b> he was <b>a king,</b> but he was <b>not a High Priest,</b> contrary to Rav’s statement. The Gemara responds: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means: Moses was <b>a king as well,</b> in addition to being a High Priest.
The Gemara comments: The question of whether Moses was a High Priest is <b>subject to</b> a dispute among <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: When Moses was at the burning bush and expressed hesitation to deliver God’s message to Pharaoh, the verse states: <b>“And the anger of the Lord burned against Moses,</b> and He said: Is there not Aaron your brother the Levite? I know that he can speak well. And also, behold, he comes forth to meet you, and when he sees you, he will be glad in his heart” (Exodus 4:14). <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says:</b> For <b>every burning anger that</b> is stated <b>in the Torah, its effect is</b> also <b>stated,</b> i.e., the Torah records an action or pronouncement as a consequence of that anger, <b>but</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>no effect of</b> the anger <b>is stated.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: Even in this</b> case the anger’s <b>effect is stated, as it is stated</b> there: <b>“Is there not Aaron your brother the Levite?</b> I know that he can speak well.” <b>But isn’t</b> Aaron <b>a priest?</b> Why is he referred to as a Levite? <b>This</b> is what God <b>is saying</b> to Moses: <b>I</b> initially <b>said</b> that <b>you</b> would be the <b>priest and he</b> would be the <b>Levite; now he</b> will be the <b>priest and you</b> will be the <b>Levite.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Moses became a priest</b> for <b>the seven days of inauguration alone,</b> and after that his priesthood expired. <b>And some say:</b> The <b>priesthood expired only for the descendants of Moses,</b> but Moses himself remained a priest, <b>as it is stated: “But as for Moses the man of God, his sons are named among the tribe of Levi”</b> (I Chronicles 23:14). This verse indicates that it was his sons who were Levites, but he himself remained a priest. <b>And</b> so too the verse <b>states: “Moses and Aaron among His priests, and Samuel among them that call upon His name,</b> did call upon the Lord, and He answered them” (Psalms 99:6).
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>And</b> so too the verse <b>states?</b> Why did the <i>tanna</i> need to cite a second proof? The Gemara explains: <b>And if you would say</b> the first verse <b>is written only for</b> future <b>generations,</b> to include Moses’ descendants in the tribe of Levi but not to exclude him, then there is a second proof: <b>And</b> so too, the verse <b>states: “Moses and Aaron among His priests.”</b> The statement of Rav that Moses was a High Priest is in accordance with the opinion in this <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara challenges the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa: <b>And</b> is it true that for <b>every burning anger that</b> is stated <b>in the Torah, its effect is</b> also <b>stated? But isn’t it written</b> with regard to Moses: <b>“And he went out from Pharaoh in hot anger”</b> (Exodus 11:8)? <b>And</b> Moses <b>did not say anything to</b> Pharaoh. <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> Moses <b>slapped him and left.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And does Reish Lakish</b> actually <b>say this? But isn’t it written:</b> “Go unto Pharaoh in the morning; lo, he goes out unto the water; <b>and you shall stand by the river’s brink to meet him,</b> and the rod which was turned to a serpent shall you take in your hand” (Exodus 7:15); <b>and Reish Lakish says:</b> God meant: Pharaoh <b>is a king, and</b> so you should <b>be amiable toward him, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> God meant: Pharaoh <b>is wicked, and</b> so you should <b>be insolent toward him.</b> If according to Reish Lakish Moses was commanded to greet Pharaoh with respect, how could he say that Moses slapped Pharaoh? The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the names of the Sages in this dispute; it is Reish Lakish who says that Moses was commanded to be insolent.
With regard to the respect accorded to a king, <b>Rabbi Yannai says: Fear of</b> the <b>kingship should always be upon you,</b> even when the king does not deserve respect, <b>as it is written</b> that Moses said to Pharaoh: <b>“And all these your servants shall come down unto me</b> and bow down unto me, saying: Get you out, and all the people that follow you, and after that I will go out” (Exodus 11:8). He mentioned Pharaoh’s servants, <b>but he did not say</b> this <b>of</b> Pharaoh <b>himself,</b> even though this was the eventual outcome. Rather, he spoke to Pharaoh with the respect due to a king.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Derive the principle <b>from here: “And the hand of the Lord was on Elijah, and he girded up his loins and ran before Ahab</b> to the entrance of Jezreel” (I Kings 18:46). Elijah the prophet ran before the evil king Ahab out of respect.
The Gemara continues to discuss the roles of Moses: <b>Ulla says: Moses requested</b> that he be given the <b>kingship, but it was not given to him, as it is written: “Do not draw hither”</b> (Exodus 3:5); <b>and</b> the word <b>“hither”</b> refers to <b>nothing other than kingship, as it is stated:</b> “Then David the king went in and sat before the Lord, and he said: <b>Who am I, O Lord God,</b> and what is my house, <b>that You have brought me hither”?</b> (II Samuel 7:18).
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> from the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> Elisheva’s <b>brother-in-law,</b> Moses, was <b>a king.</b> This teaches that Moses was in fact granted kingship. <b>Rava said:</b> Ulla <b>is saying</b> that Moses did not receive kingship <b>for himself and for his descendants,</b> i.e., it was not bequeathed to his sons.
The Gemara counters: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>anywhere that it is written “hither”</b> the verse <b>is</b> referring to kingship <b>for</b> future <b>generations</b> as well? <b>But isn’t it written about</b> the kingship of <b>Saul:</b> “They asked of the Lord further: <b>Is there yet a man who comes hither”</b> (I Samuel 10:22), and Saul was <b>indeed</b> a king, but <b>his descendants</b> were <b>not.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If you wish, say: There was Ish-Bosheth,</b> Saul’s son, who was a king (see II Samuel 2:10), indicating that Saul’s kingship did pass to his son. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Saul is different, because</b> the kingship <b>did not stand even for himself,</b> and this is why it did not pass on to his descendants.
The second response is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> says that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: When greatness is apportioned to a person</b> in Heaven, it <b>is apportioned to him and to his descendants until the end of all generations, as it is stated: “He withdraws not His eyes from the righteous; but with kings upon the throne</b> He sets them forever, and they are exalted” (Job 36:7). <b>But if he</b> then <b>became arrogant, the Holy One, Blessed be He, humiliates him, as is stated</b> in the next verse: <b>“And if they be bound in fetters, and be held in cords of affliction”</b> (Job 36:8). This was the case with Saul.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Blemished</b> priests, <b>whether</b> they are temporarily <b>blemished</b> or permanently blemished, receive a share and partake of offerings, but do not sacrifice them. The Gemara explains: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the meal offering: <b>“Every male</b> among the sons of Aaron shall eat it” (Leviticus 6:11). The phrase “every male” serves <b>to include blemished</b> priests.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>For what</b> matter is this derivation necessary? <b>If</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>consumption, it is already stated</b> explicitly: “Any man of the seed of Aaron the priest who has a blemish…<b>He may eat the bread of his God, of the most sacred,</b> and of the sacred” (Leviticus 21:21–22). <b>Rather,</b> Leviticus 6:11 is necessary <b>for</b> the matter of <b>receiving a share,</b> teaching that blemished priests may do so along with the other priests. This is the source for the mishna’s statement.
It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sin offering: <b>“Every male</b> among the priests may eat thereof” (Leviticus 6:22). The phrase “every male” serves <b>to include blemished</b> priests. The Gemara explains: <b>For what</b> matter is this derivation necessary? <b>If</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>consumption, isn’t</b> that <b>already stated</b> in Leviticus, chapter 21? <b>If</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>receiving a share, isn’t</b> that <b>already stated</b> in verse 6:11? Rather, the verse is necessary <b>because</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a priest who was at first <b>unblemished and</b> later <b>became blemished. From where</b> is it derived that one <b>blemished from birth</b> also receives a share? <b>The verse states</b> here: <b>“Every male.”</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the guilt offering: <b>“Every male</b> among the priests may eat thereof” (Leviticus 7:6). The phrase “every male” serves <b>to include a blemished</b> priest. The Gemara explains: <b>For what</b> matter is this derivation necessary? <b>If</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>eating, isn’t</b> that <b>already stated? And if</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> the matter of <b>receiving a share, isn’t</b> that <b>already stated? And if</b> one suggests it is <b>for</b> a priest <b>blemished from birth, isn’t</b> that <b>already stated?</b> Rather, the verse is necessary <b>because</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a permanently blemished</b> priest. <b>From where</b> is it derived that a <b>temporarily blemished</b> priest also receives a share? <b>The verse states</b> here: <b>“Every male.”</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>Isn’t it the opposite [<i>kelapei layya</i>]?</b> Wouldn’t I have thought that a priest with a permanent blemish would be treated more stringently than one with a temporary blemish? <b>Rav Sheshet said: Reverse</b> the wording as follows: One might have thought that I have derived only the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a priest with a temporary blemish; from where is it derived that one with a permanent blemish also receives a share?
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually, do not reverse</b> the wording, <b>and</b> this is not difficult. It <b>was necessary</b> to teach that even a priest with a temporary blemish receives a share, because it might <b>enter your mind to say</b>

Daf 102b

that the <i>halakha</i> of this priest is <b>like</b> that of <b>a ritually impure</b> priest: <b>Just as an impure</b> priest <b>may not partake as long as he is not pure, so too, this</b> priest with a temporary blemish <b>may not partake as long as he does not become fit.</b> The verse therefore <b>teaches us</b> that he may receive a share even before his blemish heals.
§ The mishna teaches: The principle is: <b>Any</b> priest <b>who is unfit</b> for the service that day does not receive a share of the sacrificial meat. The Gemara objects: <b>But doesn’t</b> he? <b>Isn’t</b> there <b>a blemished</b> priest, <b>who is not fit for the service and</b> who nevertheless <b>receives a share</b> of the meat, as the mishna itself teaches? <b>And furthermore,</b> this principle indicates that only priests unfit for the service do not receive a share, <b>but</b> any priest who is <b>fit for the service</b> does <b>receive a share.</b> But <b>isn’t</b> there <b>an impure</b> priest, <b>who, with regard to offerings of the community, is fit for the service, and</b> who nevertheless <b>does not receive a share?</b>
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is saying</b> that any priest who is not <b>fit for partaking</b> of sacrificial meat does not receive a share. Blemished priests may partake of sacrificial meat, and impure priests may not.
The Gemara objects: This indicates that any priest who is fit to partake may receive a share. <b>But isn’t</b> there is a <b>minor, who is fit for partaking and</b> who <b>does not receive a share?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> inverse principle, that any priest who is fit to partake may receive a share, <b>is not taught.</b> The mishna means to teach only that any priest who is unfit does not receive a share.
The Gemara notes: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> conclusion, that the mishna’s statement only teaches what it says explicitly, one can say that the mishna <b>actually</b> means <b>what</b> the Gemara <b>said at the outset,</b> that no priest unfit for the service receives a share. <b>If</b> one raises an objection <b>with regard to an impure</b> priest, who is fit for the service of communal offerings but does not receive a share, answer that the mishna <b>does not teach</b> that every fit priest, even <b>an impure</b> one, receives a share, only the inverse. <b>And if</b> you raise an objection <b>with regard to a blemished</b> priest, who is unfit for the service but nevertheless receives a share, answer that <b>the Merciful One included him</b> as an exception by the phrase: Every male, as derived above (102a).
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Even</b> if the priest was <b>ritually impure</b> only <b>at the time of the sprinkling of the blood</b> of the offering, <b>and</b> he was <b>pure at the time of the burning of the fats,</b> he still <b>does not receive a share</b> of the meat. The Gemara notes: <b>Consequently,</b> one can infer that a priest who was <b>pure at the time of the sprinkling of the blood,</b> even one who was <b>impure at the time of the burning of the fats, does receive a share.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Shaul says:</b> A priest <b>never partakes,</b> i.e., receives a share, of sacrificial meat, <b>unless he is pure from the time of sprinkling until the time of the burning of the fats, as the verse states:</b> “He among the sons of Aaron <b>who sacrifices the blood of the peace offerings and the fat</b> shall have the right thigh for a portion” (Leviticus 7:33). The verse <b>requires</b> that the priest be pure <b>even</b> at the time of <b>the burning of the fats.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> According to the opinion of Abba Shaul, in a case where the priest <b>became impure between</b> the sprinkling of the blood and the burning of the fats but became pure again before the latter, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we require</b> only that he be pure both <b>at the time of sprinkling and at the time of</b> the <b>burning</b> of the fats, <b>and there is</b> purity at these times? <b>Or perhaps</b> Abba Shaul meant that the priest may not receive a share in the meat <b>unless he is pure from the time of sprinkling until the time of the burning of the fats,</b> without interruption. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that an impure priest who immersed that day, such that he will not be pure until sunset, and likewise an acute mourner and one who has not yet brought an atonement offering, do not receive a share of sacrificial meat in order to partake of it in the evening. <b>Rava says: I learned this <i>halakha</i> from Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who said in the bathroom: You</b> can <b>contend</b> by way of a story: A priest <b>who immersed that day came and said</b> to a pure priest of the same patrilineal priestly family serving in the Temple that day, who was apportioning the sacrificial food: <b>Give me</b> a share <b>of a meal offering, and I will partake</b> of it in the evening.
The pure priest <b>said</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>to him: Just as with regard to</b> a matter <b>where your right is superior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>your</b> own <b>sin offering,</b> to which you have a right even when your family is not serving in the Temple, <b>I</b> can nevertheless <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite</b> because you immersed today; <b>is it not logical that</b> with regard to a matter <b>where your right is inferior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>your</b> own <b>meal offering,</b> as the meal offering of a priest is not eaten at all, that <b>I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the meal offering of an Israelite?</b>
The priest who immersed that day responded: <b>But</b> even <b>if you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite</b> on the day I immersed, perhaps this is <b>since just as my right is superior</b> in the case of my own sin offering, <b>so too, your right is superior</b> in the case of your own sin offering. If so, is it necessarily so that <b>you</b> can <b>refuse me</b> a share <b>of</b> the <b>meal offering</b> of an Israelite, <b>where just as my right is inferior, so your right is inferior,</b> as neither of us may eat from our own meal offerings?
The pure priest responded: The verse <b>states:</b> “And every meal offering that is baked in the oven, and all that is dressed in the stewing pan, and on the griddle, <b>shall be the priest’s that offers it”</b> (Leviticus 7:9). If you wish to receive a share of a meal offering, <b>come sacrifice and partake</b> of one. Since you cannot sacrifice a meal offering, having immersed only today, neither can you receive a share.
The priest who immersed that day made another demand: <b>Give me</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite, and I will partake</b> of it in the evening when I am pure.
The pure priest <b>said to him: Just as with regard to</b> a matter <b>where my right is inferior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>my</b> own <b>meal offering,</b> which is not eaten, <b>I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the meal offering of an Israelite,</b> as I explained; so too, <b>is it not logical that</b> with regard to a matter <b>where my right is superior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>my</b> own <b>sin offering,</b> to which I have a right even when my family is not serving in the Temple, <b>I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite?</b>
The priest who immersed that day <b>said to him: But if you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of the meal offering of an Israelite, where just as your right is inferior, so too my right is inferior,</b> is it necessarily so that <b>you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite, where just as your right is superior</b> in the case of your own sin offering, <b>so too my right is superior</b> in the case of my own sin offering?
The pure priest responded: The verse <b>states</b> with regard to the sin offering: <b>“The priest who effects atonement shall eat it”</b> (Leviticus 6:19). If you wish to receive a share of a sin offering, <b>come effect atonement and partake</b> of one. Since you cannot perform the service of a sin offering, having immersed only today, you cannot receive a share in its meat either.
The priest who immersed that day made another demand, and <b>said to him: Give me</b> a share <b>of</b> the <b>breast and thigh,</b> the portions that priests receive of peace offerings, <b>and I will partake</b> of it in the evening when I am pure.
The pure priest <b>said to him: Just as with regard to</b> a matter <b>where your right is superior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>your</b> own <b>sin offering,</b> to which you have a right to its meat in its entirety, <b>I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite,</b> as I explained, so too <b>is it not logical that</b> with regard to a matter <b>where your right is inferior,</b> i.e., <b>in</b> the case of <b>a peace offering, of which you have only</b> the right to a share of the <b>breast and thigh, I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share?
The priest who immersed that day responded: But <b>if you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of a sin offering, where my right is inferior with regard to my wives and my slaves,</b> as a sin offering can be consumed only by male priests, is it necessarily so that <b>you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of</b> the <b>breast and thigh</b> of a peace offering, <b>where my right is superior with regard to my wives and my slaves,</b> who may also partake of them?
The pure priest responded: The verse <b>states</b> with regard to the peace offering: <b>“It shall be the priest’s that sprinkles the blood of the peace offerings</b> against the altar” (Leviticus 7:14). If you wish to partake of a peace offering, <b>come sprinkle</b> its blood <b>and partake</b> of it. Since you cannot perform this service, having immersed only today, you cannot receive a share of its meat either.
The story concludes: The priest <b>who immersed that day left</b> in disappointment, with <b>his <i>a fortiori</i></b> inferences <b>upon his head,</b> as they did not help him. And along with him walked <b>an acute mourner on his right</b> and a priest <b>who had not yet</b> brought an <b>atonement</b> offering <b>on his left.</b> They too were denied shares, because they were unfit for the Temple service.
<b>Rav Aḥai refutes</b> this: Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, could have added to the contentions described in the story. <b>Let</b> the priest who immersed that day <b>say to</b> the pure priest: <b>Give me</b> a share <b>of a firstborn</b> offering, <b>and I will partake</b> of it in the evening.
Perhaps it is <b>because</b> the pure priest could <b>say to him: Just as with regard to a sin offering, where my right is inferior with regard to my wives and my slaves,</b> since it may be eaten only by male priests, <b>I</b> can nevertheless <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of the sin offering of an Israelite,</b> as I explained; so too <b>is it not logical that with regard to a first-born, where my right is superior because all of</b> its meat <b>is mine,</b> as firstborn offerings are given to a specific priest, <b>I</b> can <b>deny you</b> a share <b>of it?</b>
But the priest who immersed that day could respond: <b>But if you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of a sin offering, where just as your right is inferior, so is my right inferior;</b> is it necessarily so that <b>you</b> can <b>deny me</b> a share <b>of a firstborn</b> offering, <b>where just as your right is superior, so my right is superior?</b>
The pure priest could respond: The verse <b>says</b> with regard to a firstborn offering: <b>“You shall sprinkle their blood on the altar and shall make their fat smoke</b> for an offering made by fire, for a pleasing aroma to the Lord. <b>And the flesh of them shall be yours,</b> as the breast and as the thigh, it shall be yours” (Numbers 18:17–18). If you wish to receive a share in the meat of a firstborn, <b>come sprinkle</b> its blood <b>and partake</b> of it. Why did Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, not include this exchange as another stage in his story?
The Gemara responds: <b>But the other</b> priest, the one who immersed that day, could <b>refute</b> this proof: <b>Is it written: And the flesh of them shall be for the priest who sprinkles,</b> as is written with regard to a meal offering, a sin offering, and a peace offering? Rather, it <b>is written: “And the flesh of them shall be yours,”</b> indicating that it can be given <b>even to a priest other</b> than the one who sacrificed it. This is why Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, did not include this exchange in his story.
The Gemara returns to Rava’s statement that Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, taught this <i>halakha</i> in the bathroom. <b>And how did</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>do this? But doesn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>permitted to contemplate</b> matters of Torah <b>in all places except the bathhouse and the bathroom?</b> The Gemara answers: A case where the matter was <b>involuntary is different.</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, was so preoccupied by the issue that he taught it even though he was in the bathroom.

Daf 103a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>any</b> burnt offering <b>for which the altar did not acquire its flesh,</b> e.g., if it was disqualified prior to the sprinkling of its blood, the <b>priests did not acquire its hide, as it is stated</b> with regard to the burnt offering: “And the priest that sacrifices <b>a man’s burnt offering,</b> the priest shall have to himself the hide of the burnt offering that he has sacrificed” (Leviticus 7:8), indicating that the priest acquires only the hide of <b>a burnt offering that satisfied</b> the obligation <b>of a man.</b>
Nevertheless, in a case of <b>a burnt offering that was slaughtered not for its sake</b> but for the sake of another offering, <b>although it did not satisfy</b> the obligation <b>of the owner, its hide</b> goes <b>to the priests.</b> In addition, although the verse states: “A man’s burnt offering,” in the case of <b>both the burnt offering of a man and the burnt offering of a woman, their hides</b> go <b>to the priests.</b>
<b>The hides of offerings of lesser sanctity</b> belong <b>to the owners; the hides of offerings of the most sacred order</b> belong <b>to the priests.</b> The right of priests to hides of offerings of the most sacred order is derived via <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> for <b>a burnt offering, for which</b> the priests <b>do not acquire its flesh,</b> as it is burned in its entirety, <b>they acquire its hide,</b> then for other <b>offerings of the most sacred order, for which</b> the priests <b>acquire its flesh, is it not right that they should acquire its hide?</b> And <b>there is no</b> room to contend that the <b>altar will prove</b> that this is not a valid inference, as it acquires the flesh of a burnt offering but not its hide, <b>since it does not have</b> the right to the <b>hide</b> of an offering <b>in any place.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>“a man’s burnt offering”</b> in the verse mentioned above serves <b>to exclude the burnt offering of consecrated</b> property, meaning that the priests do not acquire the hides of such offerings. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> The phrase serves <b>to exclude the burnt offering of converts.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> does Rabbi Yehuda mean when he says that the phrase serves <b>to exclude the burnt offering of consecrated</b> property? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says:</b> He means it serves <b>to exclude a burnt offering that comes from</b> property that was <b>left over.</b> For example, if an animal consecrated as a guilt offering remains alive after its owner has achieved atonement by sacrificing another animal, the owner must wait until it acquires a blemish and then sell it. The proceeds are used to purchase a communal gift offering, which is sacrificed when there are no other offerings to be burned on the altar (see <i>Temura</i> 20b). Because it is a communal offering, it is not considered a man’s burnt offering, and the priests therefore have no right to the hide.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says: Leftover</b> consecrated property <b>goes toward communal gift</b> offerings. <b>But according to the one who says: Leftover</b> consecrated property <b>goes toward an individual’s gift</b> offering, <b>what can be said?</b> As this is a man’s burnt offering, the priests should have a right to the hides.
The Gemara answers: According to that opinion, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>as Rava says:</b> The verse states: “And the priest shall kindle wood on it every morning; and he shall lay <b>the burnt offering</b> in order upon it” (Leviticus 6:5). The verse states: “The burnt offering,” with the definite article, to teach that the daily burnt offering is the <b>first burnt offering</b> sacrificed each day in the Temple. <b>Here too,</b> the verse states: “The priest shall have to himself the hide of <b>the burnt offering</b> which he has offered,” to teach that the priest acquires the hide of <b>a first burnt offering,</b> i.e., an animal that was initially designated as a burnt offering, but not of a burnt offering purchased from proceeds left over from another offering.
<b>Rabbi Aivu</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> Rabbi Yehuda’s statement can be interpreted differently. The phrase “a man’s burnt offering” serves <b>to exclude</b> a case of <b>one who consecrates a burnt offering for Temple maintenance.</b> Since the owner seeks to shift its ownership to the Temple, the priests have no right to its hides.
The Gemara comments: <b>It is not necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>according to the one who says</b> that <b>consecration for Temple maintenance applies by Torah law</b> to offerings already consecrated to the altar, as the animal in fact ceases to belong to the individual, and the priests clearly have no claim to its hide. <b>Rather, even according to the one who says</b> that it <b>does not apply</b> by Torah law, because the offering is already consecrated for the altar, <b>this matter</b> applies only to the <b>meat; but</b> as for the <b>hide,</b> the consecration for Temple maintenance <b>applies</b> and nullifies the priests’ claim to it.
The Gemara returns to the explanation of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef and comments: <b>And so says Rav Naḥman</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The phrase “a man’s burnt offering” serves <b>to exclude a burnt offering that comes from</b> property that was <b>left over.</b>
<b>Rav Hamnuna said to Rav Naḥman: In accordance with whose</b> statement is your opinion? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> But <b>didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>retract</b> this statement? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mishna in tractate <i>Shekalim</i> (6:5) states that the Temple had <b>six</b> collection boxes shaped like horns, <b>for</b> communal <b>gift</b> offerings. These funds would go <b>toward burnt offerings that come from</b> money that was <b>left over.</b> For example, if someone dedicated money to purchasing an offering, and after his purchase some of the sum remained, he would put it in these boxes. The <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the priests have no right to the hide of</b> such an offering. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Neḥemya said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> said to him: <b>If so, you have nullified the interpretation of Jehoiada the priest. As it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 6:6) that <b>Jehoiada the priest taught this interpretation:</b> The verse states: <b>“It is a guilt offering; he is certainly guilty before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 5:19). The phrase “before the Lord” teaches that if <b>any</b> money <b>comes on account of a sin offering or on account of a guilt offering,</b> i.e., it is left over after their purchase, <b>burnt offerings must be purchased with it,</b> and their <b>flesh</b> must be burned on the altar <b>to the Lord.</b> But <b>its hide</b> shall go <b>to the priests.</b> Rabbi Yehuda did not respond, indicating that he conceded that the hides of such offerings go to the priests.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rav Hamnuna: <b>But how does the Master interpret</b> the phrase: “A man’s burnt offering,” as meaning? Rav Hamnuna <b>said to him: I interpret it</b> as referring <b>to one who consecrates</b> all <b>his property,</b> including animals fit for burnt offerings. If these animals are later sacrificed as burnt offerings, the priests do not acquire the hides, since the offerings are consecrated property.
<b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 4:7): If <b>one consecrates his property</b> without specifying the purpose, generally speaking, it goes toward Temple maintenance. <b>But</b> if <b>among it were animals fit to</b> be sacrificed on the <b>altar,</b> either <b>male or female,</b> then <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Animals that are fit for offerings must be sacrificed. Therefore, the <b>male</b> animals <b>shall be sold for the purpose of burnt offerings</b> to those who need to bring such offerings, and the <b>female</b> animals, which cannot be brought as burnt offerings, <b>shall be sold for the purpose of peace offerings</b> to those who need to bring such offerings. <b>And</b> because they were consecrated for Temple maintenance, <b>their proceeds shall be allocated with the rest of</b> the person’s <b>property for Temple maintenance.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The donor intended that all animals fit for sacrifice be brought as burnt offerings, and the rest of his property be given for Temple maintenance. Therefore, the <b>males shall be sacrificed themselves</b> as <b>burnt offerings; and</b> the <b>females shall be sold for the purpose of</b> being sacrificed as <b>peace offerings, and he shall bring burnt offerings with their proceeds; and the rest of</b> his <b>property shall be allocated for Temple maintenance.</b>
Rav Hamnuna explains: <b>And even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who says</b> that <b>a person divides his consecrated</b> property, as he rules that the animals are themselves sacrificed while the other property is given for Temple maintenance, <b>this statement</b> applies specifically to the <b>flesh,</b> which is fit to be burned on the altar; <b>but</b> as for the <b>hide,</b> which is not, the fund for Temple maintenance <b>acquires</b> it from the outset, and the priests therefore have no right to it. This is the <i>halakha</i> that Rabbi Yehuda derives from the phrase “a man’s burnt offering.”
The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> The phrase “a man’s burnt offering” serves <b>to exclude the burnt offering of converts.</b> The priests do not acquire the hides of such offerings. <b>Rav Simai bar Ḥilkai said to Ravina: Is that to say</b> that <b>a convert is not</b> included in the category of <b>a man?</b> Ravina <b>said to him:</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, meant that the verse serves <b>to exclude</b> the burnt offering of <b>a convert who died and has no heirs.</b> The offering has no owner, and therefore the priests do not acquire its hide.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And the priest that offers <b>a man’s burnt offering,</b> the priest shall have to himself the hide of the burnt offering that he has sacrificed” (Leviticus 7:8). From this verse <b>I have</b> derived the <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a man’s burnt offering,</b> i.e., that of a born-Jewish male. <b>From where</b> is the same derived with regard to <b>the burnt offering of converts, women, or</b> Canaanite <b>slaves? The verse states: “The hide of the burnt offering,”</b> and it thereby <b>included</b> these as well.
<b>And if so, why</b> must <b>the verse state: “A man’s burnt offering”?</b> It serves to teach that the priests acquire the hide only of <b>a burnt offering that satisfied</b> the obligation <b>of a man,</b> i.e., <b>to exclude</b> a burnt offering <b>that was slaughtered</b> with the intention of consuming it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> and was thereby disqualified. The verse teaches <b>that the priests have no right to the hide of</b> such an offering.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I include</b> a burnt offering <b>that was not slaughtered for its own sake</b> but for the sake of another offering. <b>Since it does not satisfy</b> the obligation <b>of the owner,</b>

Daf 103b

I might have thought that <b>the priests have no right to its hide.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “The hide of the burnt offering,”</b> to teach that <b>in any case</b> where the offering is not disqualified, the priests acquire its hide, even if it did not satisfy the owner’s obligation.
And from the phrase <b>“the hide of the burnt offering” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the priests acquire <b>the hide of the burnt offering. From where</b> do I derive that they acquire <b>the hides of</b> all <b>offerings of the most sacred order? The verse states: “The hide of the burnt offering which he has offered,”</b> which serves to include any offering that the priests sacrifice. If so, one <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I include even offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Burnt offering,”</b> and not simply: Offering, to teach that <b>just as a burnt offering is an offering of the most sacred order, so too</b> the priests acquire the hides only of <b>all offerings of the most sacred order;</b> they do not acquire the hides of offerings of lesser sanctity.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says</b> there is a different derivation. From the phrase <b>“the hide of the burnt offering,” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the priests acquire the hide of <b>the burnt offering. From where</b> is it derived that they acquire <b>the hides of</b> all <b>offerings of the most sacred order? It is</b> based on <b>a logical inference: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a burnt offering, for which</b> the priests <b>do not acquire its meat,</b> the priests nevertheless <b>acquire its hide,</b> then in the case of <b>offerings of the most sacred order, for which</b> the priests <b>do acquire its meat, is it not logical that</b> they <b>acquire their hides?</b>
One may counter: Let the <b>altar prove</b> that this is not a valid <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as it acquires the meat, and</b> still <b>it does not acquire the hide.</b> One may respond: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about the altar?</b> It is notable <b>in that it does not acquire</b> hides <b>in any</b> instance. <b>Will you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the altar should teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>concerning</b> the <b>priests, who acquire</b> hides of <b>some of</b> the offerings, as the Torah explicitly grants them the hides of burnt offerings? Rather say: <b>Since</b> the priests <b>acquire</b> hides of <b>some of</b> the offerings, <b>they acquire</b> the hides of <b>all</b> offerings of the most sacred order.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> There is no need to derive that hides of offerings of the most sacred order go to the priests. <b>We need</b> the verse <b>itself only to</b> teach that this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the hide of the burnt offering. As</b> the Torah does not generally require that an offering be flayed, <b>in all</b> other <b>cases the hide</b> of the offering <b>follows the flesh</b> of the offering.
For example, <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> must be burned <b>themselves, and their hides burned with them,</b> as the Torah states explicitly (see Leviticus 4:11–12). <b>A sin offering, and a guilt offering, and a communal peace offering</b> are given as <b>a gift to the priest</b> (see Leviticus 7:7); if the priests <b>want,</b> they may <b>flay them</b> and use the hides, and if they <b>do not want</b> to use the hides, they may <b>eat</b> the offerings <b>together with their hides. Offerings of lesser sanctity</b> are given <b>to the owners;</b> if they <b>want,</b> they may <b>flay them</b> and use the hides, and if they <b>want,</b> they may <b>eat</b> the offerings <b>together with their hides.</b>
<b>But with regard to a burnt offering it is stated: “And he shall flay the burnt offering, and cut it into its pieces”</b> (Leviticus 1:6). One <b>might</b> have thought that, because all the flesh of the burnt offering is burned on the altar, <b>the priests have no right to its hide.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “The priest shall have to himself <b>the hide of the burnt offering that he has sacrificed”</b> (Leviticus 7:8).
The phrase “the priest <b>shall have to himself”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> a priest <b>who immersed that day and</b> a priest <b>who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>and an acute mourner,</b> i.e., meaning that they do not receive a share of the hides, just as they do not receive a share of the meat. <b>As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that although these priests <b>will not acquire the meat,</b> this is <b>because it is for consumption,</b> and they are not permitted to partake of it; but <b>they will acquire the hide, because it is not for consumption.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Shall have to himself,” to exclude</b> a priest <b>who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>and</b> a priest <b>who immersed that day, and an acute mourner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But let the first <i>tanna</i> also derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>logically,</b> as Rabbi Yishmael did. Why did he cite a verse? The Gemara answers: Often when there is <b>a matter that can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, the <b>verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly.
<b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael, what does he do with this</b> phrase: “The hide of the burnt offering <b>that he has sacrificed,”</b> from which the first <i>tanna</i> derives the <i>halakha</i>? He holds that it serves <b>to exclude</b> a priest <b>who immersed that day, and</b> a priest <b>who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>and an acute mourner,</b> who do not receive a share in the hides.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the phrase: <b>“Shall have to himself,”</b> as does Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> that the phrase teaches a different <i>halakha</i>. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> It <b>is stated: “Shall have to himself”</b> (Leviticus 7:8), <b>with regard to a burnt offering, and</b> it <b>is stated:</b> “The priest that makes atonement, <b>he shall have to himself”</b> (Leviticus 7:7), <b>with regard to a guilt offering.</b> The following verbal analogy is derived from here: <b>Just as there,</b> after the blood of a guilt offering is presented, <b>its bones</b> become <b>permitted</b> to the priest for any use, since only the portions intended for consumption on the altar are sacrificed whereas the rest of the animal is given to the priests, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to a burnt offering, <b>its bones</b> that are not attached to the flesh and are therefore not intended for the altar <b>are permitted.</b>
With regard to this verbal analogy the Gemara comments: It must be that those terms <b>are free,</b> i.e., superfluous in their context and therefore available for the purpose of establishing a verbal analogy. <b>As, if they are not free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that its meat is permitted</b> to the priests, unlike the flesh of a burnt offering, which is burned upon the altar, and perhaps this is why the bones of a guilt offering are also permitted. Since the phrase: <b>“Shall have it to himself,” is a superfluous</b> term in each <b>verse,</b> the analogy stands, because a verbal analogy based on free terms cannot be refuted logically.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>any offerings</b> of the most sacred order <b>were disqualified prior to their flaying, their hides do not</b> go <b>to the priests;</b> rather, they are burned together with the flesh in the place of burning. If they were disqualified <b>after their flaying, their hides</b> go <b>to the priests. Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, said: In</b> all <b>my days, I never saw a hide going out to the place of burning.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva said: From the statement of</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, <b>we learned that</b> in a case where <b>one flays the firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> the animal is later <b>discovered to have a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the priests may derive benefit [<i>sheye’otu</i>] from its hide. And the Rabbis say:</b> The claim: <b>We did not see, is no proof; rather,</b> if after flaying it is discovered that the animal was unfit before it was flayed, the hide <b>goes out to the place of burning.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The previous mishna (103a) teaches: In the case of <b>any</b> burnt offering <b>for which the altar did not acquire its flesh,</b> e.g., if it was disqualified prior to the sprinkling of its blood, <b>the priests did not acquire its hide.</b> The mishna does not state any qualification, indicating that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even if</b> the priest <b>flayed the hide before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood on the altar. The Gemara posits: <b>Whose</b> opinion is this? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says: The blood does not effect acceptance of the hide by itself;</b> i.e., it effects acceptance of the hide only together with the flesh. Since the flesh is disqualified and the sprinkling does not effect its acceptance, the sprinkling does not effect acceptance for the hide either.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Say the latter clause,</b> i.e., the mishna here: If <b>any offerings</b> of the most sacred order <b>were disqualified prior to their flaying, their hides do not</b> go <b>to the priests.</b> If they were disqualified <b>after their flaying, their hides</b> go <b>to the priests.</b> This indicates that once the hides are flayed, they go to the priests even if the flesh was disqualified before the sprinkling of the blood. If so, <b>we arrive at</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says: The blood effects acceptance of the hide,</b> i.e., renders the hide permitted to the priests, <b>by itself.</b> Can it be that <b>the former clause</b> of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> and <b>the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi?
<b>Abaye said: Since the latter clause</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, it must be that <b>the former clause is also</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And</b> although Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that in principle the priests should acquire the hides if they are removed before the flesh is disqualified, in any case <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes that</b> the <b>flaying is not</b> done <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling.</b> Since the offering cannot be disqualified before the hide is removed, practically speaking, the priests will never acquire the hides unless the altar acquires the flesh, as taught in the former clause.
<b>Rava said:</b> On the contrary, <b>since the former clause</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> it must be that <b>the latter clause is also</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.</b> When the mishna states that the priests acquire the hides if the flesh was disqualified after the flaying, it must mean that the flesh was disqualified after the sprinkling. Therefore, <b>what</b> does the mishna mean by the phrase: <b>Before flaying,</b>

Daf 104a

<b>and what</b> does it mean by the phrase: <b>After flaying?</b> It means <b>before</b> the moment the offerings <b>became fit for flaying,</b> and <b>after</b> the moment <b>they became fit for flaying,</b> i.e., before and after the sprinkling of the blood.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and what</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon?</b> Their opinions are <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The blood effects acceptance of the hide by itself,</b> after it has been flayed, even if the flesh is disqualified. <b>And</b> if, <b>when</b> the hide <b>is</b> still <b>with the flesh, a disqualification appears on</b> the flesh, <b>whether before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>or after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, then the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the hide <b>is parallel to</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the flesh: Both are burned.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: The blood does not effect acceptance of the hide by itself. And</b> if, <b>when</b> the hide <b>is</b> still <b>with the flesh, a disqualification appears on</b> the flesh <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, then the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the hide <b>is parallel to</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the flesh: Both are burned. If a disqualification develops on the flesh <b>after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, the <b>flesh was</b> already <b>accepted for a time.</b> Therefore, even though the flesh is disqualified, the priest <b>may flay</b> the animal before it is burned, <b>and its hide</b> goes <b>to the priests.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Elazar <b>disagree about</b> the same principle as do <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua?</b> As it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood,</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27). <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The verse teaches that <b>if there is no blood</b> sprinkled on the altar, <b>no flesh</b> may be burned on the altar, and <b>if there is no flesh</b> to be burned on the altar, <b>no blood</b> may be sprinkled on the altar.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The <b>blood</b> must be sprinkled <b>even if there is no flesh, as it is stated</b> in the continuation of the verse: <b>“And the blood of your sacrifices shall be poured out</b> against the altar of the Lord your God, and you shall eat the flesh.” <b>If so, what</b> is taught when <b>the verse states: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood”?</b> It is stated <b>to tell you: Just as blood</b> is placed on the altar <b>by sprinkling, so too,</b> the <b>flesh</b> is placed on the altar <b>by tossing. Consequently, you learn that there is a space between</b> the <b>ramp and the altar,</b> such that the priest must toss the flesh from the edge of the ramp.
The Gemara explains: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>the one who says</b> that the hide <b>is accepted</b> independent of the flesh holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> that the blood is sprinkled independent of the flesh, <b>and the one who says</b> that the hide <b>is not accepted</b> independent of the flesh holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> that if there is no flesh then the blood is not sprinkled?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that the blood may be sprinkled even if the flesh is disqualified, <b>everyone agrees</b> that this sprinkling effects acceptance of the hide. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>The one who says</b> that the hide <b>is not accepted</b> independently, i.e., Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the straightforward meaning of the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua;</b> once the flesh is disqualified, the blood cannot be sprinkled and does not effect acceptance of the hide. <b>The one who says</b> that the hide <b>is accepted,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, could <b>say to you: Rabbi Yehoshua says only there</b> that the blood may not be sprinkled <b>in</b> a case where nothing but the <b>flesh</b> was at stake, <b>where there is no loss for the priests,</b> who never receive meat from burnt offerings. <b>But</b> in cases where the <b>hide</b> would go to waste, <b>where there is a loss for the priests,</b> perhaps <b>even Rabbi Yehoshua concedes</b> that the blood effects acceptance.
This latter interpretation of Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion with regard to the hides is <b>just as it is with regard to</b> disqualified flesh <b>after the fact.
