As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the <b>flesh contracted ritual impurity or was disqualified, or</b> if it <b>emerged beyond the curtains</b> delineating its designated area, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest must nevertheless <b>sprinkle</b> the blood on the altar. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The priest <b>may not sprinkle</b> the blood on the altar. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that if</b> the priest nevertheless <b>sprinkled</b> the blood, the offering <b>is accepted</b> after the fact. Apparently, the sprinkling is sufficiently valid to effect acceptance of the hide.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, said:</b> In all my days, I never saw a hide going out to the place of burning. The Gemara challenges: <b>And</b> is it so that he did <b>not</b> see? <b>Aren’t there bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> together with their hides as a matter of course?
The Gemara answers: <b>We are not saying</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina never saw hides go out to be burned <b>in accordance with their mitzva;</b> he certainly did. Rather, he never saw hides being burned because the offering was disqualified.
The Gemara challenges: But <b>isn’t there</b> a case where an offering is disqualified <b>before flaying and before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, in which case all agree that the animal is burned with its hide? The Gemara answers: <b>We are saying</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina never saw a hide go out <b>stripped</b> from its flesh.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t there</b> a case where an offering is disqualified <b>after</b> the <b>flaying</b> of the hide <b>and before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, in which case the hide is burned <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who says: The blood does not effect acceptance of the hide by itself?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, that the blood does effect acceptance of the hide in such a case, and so it would not be burned. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that you can <b>even interpret</b> the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> as <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes that</b> the <b>flaying is not</b> done <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling,</b> and so in practice Rabbi Ḥanina never saw a hide that was flayed before the offering was disqualified.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t there</b> the case of an animal that, after the hide was flayed and the blood was sprinkled, <b>was found</b> to have a wound <b>in</b> its <b>intestines</b> rendering it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> in which case the offering was already disqualified when the blood was sprinkled?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ḥanina <b>holds</b> that in the case of an animal that <b>was found</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> due to a wound <b>in</b> its <b>intestines,</b> the sprinkling of the blood nevertheless <b>effects acceptance,</b> because the wound was unknown at the time of the sprinkling. The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Rabbi Akiva said: From the statement of</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, <b>we learned that</b> in a case where <b>one flays the firstborn</b> offering, <b>and</b> the animal is later <b>discovered</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the priests may derive benefit from its hide.</b> This indicates that the sprinkling of the blood effects acceptance if the wound was unknown. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>learn from</b> the mishna that this is so.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if this is what Rabbi Ḥanina meant, then <b>what is Rabbi Akiva teaching us?</b> His statement seems unnecessary. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what Rabbi Akiva is <b>teaching us:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies not just in the Temple but <b>even in the outlying areas,</b> e.g., with regard to a blemished firstborn animal, which is slaughtered outside the Temple. If it is discovered to be a <i>tereifa</i> before its slaughter, it must be buried with its hide, but if it is slaughtered and later discovered to be a <i>tereifa</i>, then its slaughter renders the hide permitted to the priests, just as the sprinkling of the blood renders the hide permitted in the Temple.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And even Rabbi Akiva said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where an expert</b> verified the firstborn animal’s blemish and <b>permitted it</b> to be slaughtered. <b>But</b> if <b>an expert did not permit it,</b> then its slaughter does <b>not</b> render the hide permitted to the priest.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis,</b> not Rabbi Akiva. Therefore, the <b>flesh</b> is discarded <b>by burial and the hide by burning.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>bulls that are burned,</b> i.e., the bull of Yom Kippur, the bull of the anointed priest, and the bull brought for an unwitting communal sin, which are burned after their blood is sprinkled and their sacrificial portions burned on the altar, <b>and goats that are burned,</b> i.e., the goat of Yom Kippur and the goat brought for the unwitting communal transgression of the prohibition against idol worship, <b>when they are burned in accordance with their mitzva, they are burned in the place of the ashes</b> (see Leviticus 4:12) outside of Jerusalem, <b>and they render</b> the <b>garments</b> of the priests who tend to their burning <b>impure</b> (see Leviticus 4:25). <b>And if</b> these offerings <b>are not burned in accordance with their mitzva</b> because they were disqualified, and offerings that are disqualified are also burned, <b>they are burned in the place of</b> burning in <b>the <i>bira</i>, and they do not render</b> the <b>garments</b> of the priests who tend to their burning <b>impure.</b>

Daf 104b

The priests <b>would carry</b> the bulls and the goats that are burned suspended <b>on poles.</b> When <b>the first</b> priests, carrying the front of the pole, <b>emerged outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and the latter</b> priests <b>did not</b> yet <b>emerge, the first</b> priests <b>render</b> their <b>garments impure, and the latter</b> priests <b>do not render</b> their <b>garments impure until they emerge.</b> When both <b>these and those</b> priests <b>emerged, they render</b> their <b>garments impure. Rabbi Shimon says: They do not render</b> their <b>garments impure,</b> as this <i>halakha</i> applies only to those who burn the offerings. And even then their garments do not become ritually impure <b>until the fire is ignited in the majority of</b> the offerings. Once <b>the flesh is</b> completely <b>scorched,</b> with no moisture remaining, <b>one who</b> then <b>burns</b> the remains <b>does not render</b> his <b>garments impure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if offerings of a type that are burned were disqualified, they are burned in a place of burning called the <i>bira</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <b><i>bira</i>? Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is a place on the Temple Mount, and its name is <i>bira</i>,</b> and this is where they would burn these offerings. <b>And Reish Lakish says: The entire Temple is called</b> the <b><i>bira</i>, as it is stated</b> in the prayer of David: “And give unto Solomon my son a whole heart, to keep Your commandments, Your testimonies, and Your statutes, and to do all this, and to build <b>the Temple [<i>bira</i>] for which I have made provision”</b> (I Chronicles 29:19).
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: There are three places of the ashes.</b> First was the <b>great place of the ashes</b> that <b>was in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, where</b> the priests would <b>burn the disqualified offerings of the most sacred order, and the</b> disqualified <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity, and bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> if <b>they were disqualified prior to</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood.
<b>And there was another place of the ashes on the Temple Mount, where</b> the priests would <b>burn bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> if <b>they were disqualified after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood. <b>And</b> the third place of the ashes was for the bulls and goats that were burned <b>in accordance with their mitzva, outside</b> the <b>three camps,</b> i.e., outside the walls of Jerusalem.
<b>Levi teaches</b> a different version of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>There are three places of the ashes.</b> First was the <b>great place of the ashes</b> that <b>was in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, where</b> the priests would <b>burn the disqualified offerings of the most sacred order, and the</b> disqualified <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity, and bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> if <b>they were disqualified, whether prior to</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>or after</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood. <b>And there was another place of the ashes on the Temple Mount, where</b> the priests would <b>burn bulls that are burned and goats that are burned</b> if <b>they were disqualified upon emerging</b> from the Temple courtyard. <b>And</b> the third was for bulls and goats burned <b>in accordance with their mitzva, outside</b> the <b>three camps.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> The flesh of most offerings is disqualified by being left overnight. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>being left overnight is effective to</b> disqualify <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned?</b> Given that their flesh is neither eaten nor burned on the altar, <b>do we say: When being left overnight is effective</b> to disqualify flesh, this is only <b>in</b> a case of <b>flesh that is fit for consumption,</b> either by the altar or by human beings; <b>but</b> in the case of <b>these</b> bulls and goats that are burned, <b>which are not fit for consumption,</b> being left overnight does <b>not</b> disqualify the flesh? <b>Or perhaps</b> this case <b>is no different,</b> and being left overnight disqualifies the flesh.
<b>Rava said: This matter,</b> Rabbi Yirmeya’s <b>dilemma, was raised by Abaye, and I resolved it from this</b> <i>baraita</i>: The mishna (43a) records a dispute as to whether the sacrificial portions of bulls that are burned are subject to disqualification by intent to burn them beyond their designated time [<i>piggul</i>]. <b>But</b> the disputants <b>agree that if</b> the priest <b>intended for the consumption of</b> the <b>bulls’</b> meat <b>and their burning</b> to be beyond their designated time, <b>he did nothing,</b> as <i>piggul</i> applies only to flesh consumed by human beings or the altar. <b>What, is it not</b> the case that <b>since</b> the <b>intention</b> of burning after the designated time <b>does not disqualify</b> bulls that are burned, one can infer that <b>being left overnight also does not disqualify</b> bulls that are burned?
The Gemara responds: <b>But perhaps it is</b> only improper <b>intention that does not disqualify</b> such offerings, <b>but being left overnight does disqualify</b> them.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 9a): With regard to <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned,</b> one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>from</b> the time <b>that they were consecrated.</b> Once <b>they have been slaughtered, they are susceptible to be rendered disqualified</b> for sacrifice <b>through</b> contact with <b>one who immersed that day, and through</b> contact with <b>one who has not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering, <b>and through</b> being <b>left overnight</b> without the requirements of the offering having been fulfilled. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to the <b>flesh</b> of bulls, indicating that the flesh is disqualified if <b>left overnight?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the mishna indicates only that the offerings’ <b>sacrificial portions</b> are disqualified if <b>left overnight,</b> since they must be burned on the altar.
The Gemara responds: <b>But</b> evidence to the contrary can be ad-duced <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches:</b> In <b>all of those</b> cases, one who benefits <b>from them</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property if he derives benefit while they are burned <b>in the place of the ashes, until the flesh is</b> completely <b>incinerated.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> is discussing <b>flesh,</b> infer that <b>the first clause also</b> discusses <b>flesh,</b> and not the sacrificial portions. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Are the cases comparable? The latter clause</b> discusses <b>flesh,</b> and <b>the first clause</b> discusses <b>sacrificial portions.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>which Levi teaches</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: There was another place of the ashes on the Temple Mount, where the priests would burn bulls that are burned and goats that are burned if they were <b>disqualified upon emerging</b> from the Temple courtyard. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to offerings disqualified by being <b>left overnight?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>disqualification by</b> contracting <b>ritual impurity or disqualification by leaving</b> the courtyard before the blood was sprinkled on the altar. The dilemma of Rabbi Yirmeya stands unresolved.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar raises a dilemma:</b> In general, the flesh of offer-ings is disqualified by leaving the Temple courtyard. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to whether <b>leaving is effective to</b> disqualify <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the dilemma he is raising?</b> Here it is a mitzva to burn the flesh of these offerings outside the Temple courtyard. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said:</b> Rabbi Elazar raises his dilemma <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the one who says:</b> With regard to offerings of lesser sanctity, even though the flesh may be consumed anywhere in Jerusalem, nevertheless, if it emerges from the Temple courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood, it is disqualified, because <b>its time to leave</b> from the Temple courtyard <b>has not yet arrived.</b> Perhaps the same <i>halakha</i> applies to bulls and goats that are burned: Even though the flesh must eventually leave the Temple, if it leaves before its designated time, it is disqualified.
The dilemma is: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>this matter,</b> disqualification by leaving the Temple courtyard prematurely, applies only to <b>flesh that need not eventually leave</b> due to an <b>obligation?</b> One may consume the meat of offerings of lesser sanctity in the Temple courtyard if he wishes. <b>But</b> perhaps <b>these</b> bulls and goats that are burned, <b>which</b> must <b>eventually leave</b> due to an <b>obligation,</b> are <b>not</b> disqualified by emerging prematurely. <b>Or perhaps here too</b> the flesh is disqualified if <b>its time to leave has not</b> yet <b>arrived.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>which Levi teaches</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: There was another place of the ashes on the Temple Mount, where the priests would burn bulls that are burned and goats that are burned if <b>they were disqualified upon emerging</b> from the Temple courtyard. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to <b>disqualification by leaving</b> the Temple courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>disqualification by</b> contracting <b>ritual impurity or disqualification by being left overnight.</b> The dilemma of Rabbi Elazar stands unresolved.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar raises</b> another <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>bulls that are burned and goats that are burned,</b> if <b>the majority of</b> the animal’s body <b>emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard, but it consists of a majority only <b>by</b> inclusion of <b>the minority of a limb,</b> the majority of which remains inside the courtyard, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we</b> determine the status of <b>this minority of a limb</b> by <b>casting it after the majority</b> of that limb, <b>and</b> the majority of <b>that</b> limb <b>did not leave? Or perhaps we</b> determine its status by <b>casting</b> it <b>after the majority of</b> the <b>animal,</b> and therefore a majority of the animal has left?
The Gemara clarifies: Isn’t it <b>obvious that we do not disregard the majority of the animal and</b> instead <b>follow the majority of the limbs? Rather,</b> Rabbi Elazar’s dilemma must be as follows: In a case <b>where half of</b> the animal <b>emerged</b> from the courtyard such that <b>the majority of</b> a certain <b>limb</b> emerged, but a minority of the limb remained inside, what is the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we</b> determine the status of <b>this minority of a limb</b>

Daf 105a

by <b>casting it after the majority of</b> that <b>limb, and</b> the majority of <b>that</b> limb <b>did leave? Or perhaps we</b> determine its status by <b>casting it after</b> the half of <b>the animal,</b> which did not leave the courtyard. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma of Rabbi Elazar <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna teaches this</b> dilemma <b>with regard to people: In</b> a case where <b>five people are handling</b> an offering and carrying it out to be burned, <b>and three</b> of them <b>emerged and two of them remained</b> in the Temple courtyard, such that the animal is partly inside and partly outside, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we follow the majority of the people handling</b> the offering, who have left the courtyard, <b>or</b> do <b>we follow</b> the <b>animal,</b> the majority of which did not yet leave? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raises</b> another <b>dilemma:</b> If <b>bulls and goats that are burned left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and returned, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the garments of those who carry them inside the courtyard? <b>Do we say: Once they left, they became impure? Or perhaps once they return, they return</b> and do not render garments impure?
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel says: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the mishna: <b>They would carry</b> the bulls and the goats that are burned suspended <b>on poles.</b> When <b>the first</b> priests, carrying the front of the pole, <b>emerged beyond the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and the latter</b> ones <b>did not</b> yet <b>emerge, the first</b> ones, <b>who emerged beyond the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, render</b> their <b>garments impure, but the latter</b> ones <b>do not render</b> their <b>garments impure until they emerge.</b> Rabbi Abba bar Memel explains: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>once they leave, they become impure, these</b> latter ones mentioned in the mishna <b>who are</b> still <b>inside should be rendered impure,</b> since the offering itself has emerged. It follows that if the offering returns, their garments are not rendered impure.
<b>Ravina said: And can you understand</b> this as a proof? The reason that the latter ones’ garments are not rendered impure is that <b>I require</b> the fulfillment of the verse: “And he who burns them shall wash his garments, and bathe his flesh in water, <b>and afterward he may come into the camp”</b> (Leviticus 16:28). <b>And</b> since they have <b>not</b> yet left the camp, they cannot come into it, and therefore they do not contract the impurity described in the verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if they can become impure only after they leave, <b>how did Rabbi Elazar raise this dilemma?</b> The Gemara answers: He raised the dilemma with regard to a case <b>where they take</b> the offering <b>with staffs [<i>bevakulsei</i>],</b> i.e., after the offering is returned to the Temple courtyard, other people stand outside the courtyard and bring it out again using staffs. Does the offering render these people impure, even though they are standing outside the courtyard? The dilemma of Rabbi Elazar remains unresolved.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>bulls</b> that are burned, <b>and</b> a red <b>heifer, and the scapegoat</b> of the Yom Kippur service, <b>the one who sends</b> them, <b>the one who burns them, and the one who takes them out</b> of the Temple courtyard <b>render</b> their <b>garments impure. And</b> the animals <b>themselves,</b> after they emerge from the Temple courtyard, <b>do not render garments</b> that they touch <b>impure, but they render food and drink</b> that they touch <b>impure.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> A red <b>heifer and bulls</b> that are burned <b>render food and drink impure,</b> but <b>the scapegoat does not transmit impurity</b> at all, <b>as it is</b> still <b>alive</b> when it leaves the Temple, <b>and a living being does not render food and drink impure.</b>
The Gemara comments. <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Meir</b> there is no difficulty, as his opinion is <b>in accordance with</b> that <b>which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states that seeds can contract impurity from the carcass of a creeping animal only if they first come in contact with water: “And if any part of their carcass fall <b>upon any sowing seed</b> which is to be sown, it is pure. But if water be put upon the seed, and any part of their carcass fall thereon, it is impure unto you” (Leviticus 11:37–38).
<b>Just as</b> is the case for <b>seeds, which,</b> like any food, <b>can never contract impurity severe</b> enough to transmit it to human beings, <b>and they need</b> exposure to liquid to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to their less severe level of impurity, <b>so too, all</b> items <b>that can never contract impurity severe</b> enough to transmit it to human beings <b>need</b> exposure to liquid to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to their less severe level of impurity and to transmit it. This serves to <b>exclude the carcass of a kosher bird, which can contract impurity severe</b> enough to be transmitted to a human being who swallows it, <b>and</b> therefore <b>does not need</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity in order to transmit ritual impurity. According to this <i>baraita</i>, bulls that are burned, a red heifer, and a scapegoat, which are all sources of impurity for human beings, are able to transmit impurity to food and drink on their own, even if they have not been exposed to liquid and have not come in contact with any source of impurity. Rabbi Meir’s opinion accords with this principle.
<b>But for</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Meir and say that a scapegoat does not transmit impurity to food and drink, this is difficult. <b>If they accept</b> that <b>which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught,</b> then <b>even the scapegoat</b> should transmit impurity to food and drink. And <b>if they do not accept</b> that statement, then <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>even</b> a red <b>heifer and bulls</b> that are burned transmit impurity to food and drink?
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael he <b>said:</b> The Sages <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>say:</b> The opinion of the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Meir is that bulls that are burned and a red heifer <b>need</b> to <b>contract impurity from somewhere else</b> to be able to transmit impurity to foods. Since the scapegoat cannot contract impurity, as it is alive, it cannot transmit impurity.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>bulls and goats that are burned, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to <b>whether they can transmit impurity to food and drink inside</b> the Temple courtyard, before they leave, <b>as</b> they do <b>outside</b> afterward? Is an offering <b>that has not yet left</b> the Temple <b>considered as</b> if it were an item for which a necessary <b>action has not yet</b> been performed, i.e., because it has not yet become a source of impurity to those who carry it, it also does not transmit impurity to food without being rendered susceptible by coming into contact with a liquid and then coming into contact with a source of impurity? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>no,</b> because the offering will become a source of impurity to those who carry it once it leaves the Temple courtyard, it already transmits impurity to food without being rendered susceptible.
<b>After</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>raised the dilemma, he then resolved it:</b> An offering <b>that has not yet left is considered as</b> if it were an item for which a necessary <b>action has not yet</b> been performed, and it does not transmit impurity to food without being rendered susceptible.
§ <b>Rabbi Abba bar Shmuel posed</b> another <b>dilemma to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba:</b> Food transmits impurity to other food or drink only if it is the volume of at least one egg-bulk and it is first rendered susceptible to impurity. The carcass of a kosher bird transmits impurity to a person who swallows it even if it is of the volume of at least one olive-bulk, and even if it has not been rendered susceptible to impurity. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that the carcass of a kosher bird transmits impurity to other food without first being rendered susceptible to impurity, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as to the requisite measure? Does <b>the carcass of a kosher bird transmit impurity</b> to food even if it is of the volume of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> as it would to a person?
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Do not raise the dilemma</b> in a case <b>where</b> the carcass <b>lies on the ground,</b> as in that case it certainly must be of the volume of an egg-bulk, like any other impure food. And <b>do not raise the dilemma</b> in a case <b>where</b> a person <b>holds</b> the bird’s flesh <b>in his mouth,</b> as it may be swallowed and transmit impurity to him even if it is of the volume of only an olive-bulk; in this case it certainly transmits impurity to food in the same measure. <b>When you raise the dilemma,</b> raise it in a case <b>where he holds</b> the bird’s flesh <b>in his hand.</b> When the flesh <b>has not yet been brought close</b> to being swallowed, is it <b>considered</b> to be <b>like</b> an item for which a necessary <b>action has not yet</b> been performed, in which case it is considered a normal food and must be of the volume of an egg-bulk, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>not?</b>
<b>After</b> Abba bar Shmuel <b>raised the dilemma, he then resolved it:</b>

Daf 105b

Even if the carcass of a kosher bird <b>has not yet been brought close</b> to being swallowed, it is still <b>not considered as</b> if a necessary <b>action has not yet</b> been performed, and an olive-bulk is sufficient to transmit impurity to food and drink.
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabbi Abba bar Shmuel, based on a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 1:1): <b>Thirteen matters were stated with regard to the carcass of a kosher bird, and this is one of them:</b> In order to be susceptible to impurity as a food, it <b>requires</b> a person’s <b>intention</b> that it be eaten; <b>and it does not need</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to such impurity by contact with liquid; <b>and it transmits ritual impurity of food in</b> the amount of <b>an egg-bulk.</b> In accordance with whose opinion is this mishna? <b>What, is it not</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir?</b> If so, he holds that an egg-bulk of a carcass of a kosher bird is necessary to transmit impurity.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the mishna <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But the first clause</b> of that mishna <b>teaches:</b> In order to be susceptible to impurity as a food, it <b>requires</b> a person’s <b>intention</b> that it be eaten <b>and it does not need</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> by contact with liquid. <b>And</b> from <b>whom do you learn this reasoning?</b> From <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> as was taught in the <i>baraita</i> (105a). <b>And since the first clause</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it follows that <b>the latter clause</b> is <b>also</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Are the cases comparable?</b> Must both clauses be the opinion of the same <i>tanna</i>? <b>This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> one can still infer this <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of that mishna <b>teaches: The slaughter or the pinching</b> of the nape <b>of</b> a bird offering <b>purifies it from its impurity,</b> i.e., prevents it from assuming the impure status of a carcass, even if it is found to <b>have a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>].</b> And from <b>whom did you learn this reasoning?</b> From <b>Rabbi Meir</b> (see 67a). Could it be that <b>the first clause and the last clause</b> represent the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and the middle clause</b> represents the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Yes, the first clause and the last clause</b> represent the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and the middle clause</b> represents the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
§ <b>Rav Hamnuna said to Rabbi Zeira: Do not sit down until you tell me</b> the resolution of <b>this matter:</b> In general, when a food touches a primary source of ritual impurity after having been rendered susceptible to impurity by contact with a liquid, it contracts first-degree impurity. If it then touches another food, it imparts to it second-degree impurity. <b>The carcass of a kosher bird, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> transmits impurity to food without being rendered susceptible. Does one <b>count its first and second</b> degrees of impurity when it touches food or drink, treating it like a primary source of impurity? <b>Or</b> perhaps one <b>does not count first and second</b> degrees of impurity, but rather treats it as a food with first-degree impurity, which imparts second-degree impurity?
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Wherever</b> an item <b>can render a person impure through contact,</b> it is considered a primary source of impurity, and one <b>counts its first and second</b> degrees of impurity. And <b>wherever it cannot render a person impure through contact,</b> one <b>does not count its first and second</b> degrees of impu-rity. Since the carcass of a kosher bird does not render a person impure through contact, but only by being swallowed, it is treated as a food with first-degree impurity.
<b>Rabbi Zeira posed a dilemma to Rabbi Ami bar Ḥiyya, and some say to Rabbi Avin bar Kahana</b> concerning <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 8:8): <b>Connections between foods by liquid,</b> i.e., liquids in contact with two foods, a situation that causes the impurity of one food to be transmitted to the other and their sizes to be combined toward the minimum measure for transmitting impurity, are considered <b>a connection for</b> the <b>lenient impurity</b> of foods, <b>but</b> are <b>not</b> considered <b>a connection for impurity severe</b> enough to be transmitted to a human being. If two pieces of animal carcass are connected by a liquid, they do not combine to form the minimum measure for transmitting their impurity to a person, but they can transmit impurity to food.
Rabbi Zeira asks: If these two pieces of animal carcass come in contact with food, does one <b>count its first and second</b> degrees of impurity and treat the pieces as a primary source of impurity, such that the food will impart second-degree impurity to other food? <b>Or</b> does one <b>not count its first and second</b> degrees of impurity, and treat the animal carcass as food with first-degree impurity?
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Wherever</b> an item <b>can render a person impure,</b> one <b>counts its first and second</b> degrees of impurity. And wherever it <b>cannot render a person impure,</b> one <b>does not count its first and second</b> degrees of impurity. Since the pieces of carcass cannot transmit their impurity to a person, they are treated as food with first-degree impurity.
§ The mishna teaches: When both <b>these</b> priests <b>and those</b> priests <b>emerged,</b> all of their garments were rendered ritually impure. The Gemara explains: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the bull and goat that are burned on Yom Kippur: “They shall be carried forth outside the camp” (Leviticus 16:27). <b>There,</b> elsewhere, the verse <b>states</b> that such bulls and goats are burned <b>outside three camps,</b> those of the Tabernacle, the Levites, and the Israelites, whereas <b>here,</b> the verse states only that they are taken outside <b>one camp,</b> i.e., the Tabernacle. This serves <b>to tell you: Once</b> the offering <b>emerges beyond one camp,</b> one who carries it <b>renders</b> his <b>garments impure,</b> as the next verse states: “And he who burns them shall wash his garments” (Leviticus 16:28).
The Gemara explains further: <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>itself,</b> that the bulls and goats are burned outside the three camps? <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is stated about the bull brought as a sin offering of the High Priest: <b>“Even the whole bull shall he carry outside the camp</b> unto a pure place, where the ashes are poured out, and burn it” (Leviticus 4:12), meaning that he should take it <b>outside</b> the <b>three camps. Do you say</b> that he takes it <b>outside</b> the <b>three camps, or</b> is he required to take it outside <b>only one camp?</b>
<b>When</b> the verse <b>states with regard to the bull</b> brought as <b>a communal</b> sin offering: “He shall carry the bull <b>outside the camp,</b> and burn it as he burned the first bull” (Leviticus 4:21), it requires explanation, <b>as there is no need</b> for the verse <b>to state</b> “outside the camp,” <b>since it is already stated</b> at the end of that same verse: <b>“And burn it as he burned the first bull,”</b> which indicates that all the <i>halakhot</i> of the bull brought as a sin offering of a High Priest apply to the bull brought as a communal sin offering. What then does the verse mean when it states “outside the camp”? <b>To give it a second camp,</b> i.e., it indicates that it must be removed not only from the camp of the Divine Presence, corresponding to the Temple, but also from the Levite camp, corresponding to the Temple Mount.
And <b>when</b> another verse <b>states with regard to</b> the removal of <b>the ash:</b> “And he shall put off his garments, and put on other garments, and carry forth the ashes <b>outside the camp</b> to a pure place” (Leviticus 6:4), that verse also requires an explanation, <b>as there is no need</b> for the verse <b>to state</b> this, <b>since it is already stated</b> with regard to the bull brought as a sin offering of a High Priest: “Even the whole bull shall he carry outside the camp to a pure place, where the ashes are poured out, and burn it on wood with fire; <b>where the ashes are poured out shall it be burned”</b> (Leviticus 4:12). The repetition of “outside the camp” indicates that he is required <b>to give it a third camp,</b> i.e., teaching that it is burned when outside the Israelite camp, corresponding to the land outside the walls of Jerusalem.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Shimon do with this</b> phrase, stated with regard to the bull and goat of Yom Kippur: <b>“Outside the camp”</b> (Leviticus 16:27), given that he holds that the garments do not become impure until the offering is burning? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for</b> that <b>which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: It is stated here: “Outside the camp,” and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the red heifer: “He shall bring it <b>outside the camp”</b> (Numbers 19:3). <b>Just as here,</b> the bull and goat of Yom Kippur are burned <b>outside three camps, so too there,</b> the red heifer is burned <b>outside three camps. And just as there,</b> the red heifer is burned <b>east of Jerusalem,</b> since it must be burned “toward the front of the Tent of Meeting” (Numbers 19:4), opposite the entrance of the Temple, which is to its east,

Daf 106a

<b>so too here,</b> the bull and goat of Yom Kippur are burned <b>east of Jerusalem.</b>
<b>But according to the Rabbis,</b> then, <b>where</b> outside Jerusalem <b>do they burn them?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Where are</b> the bulls and goats <b>burned?</b> They are burned <b>north of Jerusalem, outside of</b> the <b>three camps. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: They are burned on the place of the ashes,</b> where the ashes from the altar were poured.
<b>Rava said: Who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? It is Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to bulls that are burned: <b>“Where the ashes are poured out [<i>shefekh hadeshen</i>] shall it be burned”</b> (Leviticus 4:12). This teaches <b>that ashes must be there</b> already when the bulls are burned. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says:</b> This verse teaches <b>that its place should slope [<i>meshupakh</i>]</b> downward so that ashes from the burning will slide downhill.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>Perhaps they disagree</b> only <b>about</b> whether <b>the place must slope,</b> but Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov agrees that it must be the place where the ashes from the altar were deposited.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the bull and goat of Yom Kippur: “And he who burns them shall wash his garments” (Leviticus 16:28). This teaches that only <b>the one who burns</b> them <b>renders</b> his <b>garments impure, but the one who kindles the fire does not render</b> his <b>garments impure, and the one who sets up the arrangement</b> of wood <b>does not render</b> his <b>garments impure. And who is</b> considered <b>the one who burns? One who assists at the</b> actual <b>time of burning.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that this priest <b>renders</b> his <b>garments impure even after</b> the bull and goat <b>become ash.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And he who burns <b>them”</b> (Leviticus 16:28), teaching that <b>they,</b> the whole bull and goat, <b>render garments impure, but they do not render garments impure once they become ash. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The word “them” teaches that <b>they render garments impure,</b> but once <b>the flesh is incinerated they do not render garments impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> and the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? <b>Rava said:</b> The difference <b>between them is when he turned it into a charred</b> mass, and the form of the animal has become distorted, but has not actually become ash. The first <i>tanna</i> holds that at this stage the offering still transmits impurity, whereas Rabbi Shimon holds that it does not.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who slaughters</b> an offering outside the Temple courtyard <b>and one who offers</b> it <b>up outside</b> the Temple courtyard is <b>liable for the slaughter and liable for</b> the <b>offering up,</b> as each act involves an independent prohibition. If done intentionally, he is liable to receive excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>] for each act, and if done unwittingly, he is liable to bring a sin offering for each act.
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> If <b>he slaughtered</b> an offering <b>inside</b> the courtyard <b>and</b> then <b>offered</b> it <b>up outside</b> the courtyard, he is liable. But if <b>he slaughtered</b> it <b>outside,</b> thereby rendering it unfit, <b>and</b> then <b>he offered</b> it <b>up outside,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> for the offering up, <b>as he offered up only an item</b> that is <b>unfit,</b> and one is liable only for offering up an item that is fit to be offered up inside the Temple. The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> According to your reasoning, <b>even</b> in a case where <b>he slaughters</b> it <b>inside and offers</b> it <b>up outside,</b> he should be exempt, <b>since</b> the moment <b>that he took it outside</b> the courtyard, he thereby <b>rendered it unfit.</b> Yet, in such a case, he is certainly liable for offering it up. So too, one who slaughters an offering outside and then offers it up outside is liable.
<b>One who is ritually impure who ate</b> sacrificial food, <b>whether</b> it was <b>ritually impure sacrificial</b> food <b>or ritually pure sacrificial</b> food, is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> if he did so intentionally and to bring a sliding-scale offering if he did so unwittingly. <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: An impure</b> person <b>who ate pure</b> sacrificial food is <b>liable. But an impure</b> person <b>who ate impure</b> sacrificial food is <b>exempt, as he merely ate an impure item,</b> and the prohibition against eating sacrificial food while one is impure applies only to pure sacrificial food. The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> According to your logic, this <i>halakha</i> would apply <b>even</b> in a case of <b>an impure</b> person <b>who ate</b> what had been <b>pure</b> sacrificial food, because <b>once he touched it, he</b> thereby <b>rendered it ritually impure.</b> Yet, in such a case, he is certainly liable for eating it. So too, an impure person who ate impure sacrificial food is liable.
<b>And a pure</b> person <b>who ate impure</b> sacrificial food is <b>exempt, as</b> one is <b>liable</b> for eating sacrificial food in impurity <b>only due to</b> the <b>impurity of</b> one’s <b>body,</b> but not due to the impurity of the food.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one both slaughters and offers up an offering outside the Temple courtyard, he is liable for each act, as they are independent prohibitions. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted</b> that one is liable for the <b>offering up,</b> as the <b>punishment</b> for this act <b>is written</b> in the Torah <b>and</b> the <b>prohibition</b> concerning this act <b>is</b> also <b>written</b> in the Torah. The <b>punishment</b> is <b>as it is written:</b> “Any man…that offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice, <b>and will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,</b> to sacrifice it to the Lord, and that man shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 17:8–9). The <b>prohibition</b> is <b>as it is written: “Take heed to yourself lest you offer up your burnt offerings</b> in every place that you see” (Deuteronomy 12:13). <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with that which Rabbi Avin says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Wherever it is stated</b> in the Torah: <b>Observe,</b> or: <b>Lest, or: Do not, it is nothing other than a prohibition.</b> Accordingly, the verse in Deuteronomy is understood as issuing a prohibition.
<b>But</b> for the <b>slaughtering,</b> why is one liable? <b>Granted</b> that the <b>punishment</b> is stated in the Torah, <b>as it is written:</b> “Any man…that slaughters it outside the camp, <b>and he did not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,</b> to sacrifice an offering to the Lord, before the Tabernacle of the Lord…that man shall be cut off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:3–4). <b>But from where do we</b> derive its <b>prohibition?</b> One is liable only in a case where the Torah specifies both the prohibition and the punishment. The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states</b> in the continuation of that passage: <b>“And they shall not slaughter anymore</b> their offerings to the <i>se’irim</i> after whom they go astray” (Leviticus 17:7).
The Gemara questions the use of this verse as a source: But <b>this</b> verse is <b>necessary for</b> the purpose of expounding <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar, as he says: From where</b> is it derived with regard to <b>one who slaughters an animal</b> as an offering <b>to Mercury,</b> a pagan deity, <b>that he is liable</b> even though this is not the established manner in which that deity is worshipped? <b>As it is written:</b> “And <b>they shall not slaughter anymore their offerings</b> to the <i>se’irim</i>.” <b>If</b> the verse <b>is not</b> needed to teach the <b>matter of</b> worshipping a deity <b>in accordance with its established manner,</b> as it is already taught that one is liable for this, <b>as it is written:</b> “Take heed to yourself…lest you inquire after their gods, saying: <b>How do these</b> nations <b>serve</b> their gods, so too will I do likewise” (Deuteronomy 12:30), then <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of</b> worshipping a deity in a way <b>that</b> is <b>not in accordance with its established manner.</b>
<b>Rabba said:</b> Both <i>halakhot</i> can be derived from the same verse. <b>Read into</b> the verse as though it stops after the phrase: <b>“And they shall not slaughter”</b> (Leviticus 17:7), and relates to the prohibition against slaughtering outside the Temple courtyard, which was mentioned in the previous verses. <b>And</b> also <b>read into</b> the verse as relating to the verse’s continuation: <b>And not anymore</b> their offerings to the <i>se’irim</i>, which serves as the source for the prohibition against sacrificing offerings to false deities.
The Gemara challenges: But the verse is <b>still necessary for</b> the purpose of expounding <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “Any man…that slaughters it outside the camp, and he did not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, to sacrifice an offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 17:3–4). <b>Until this point,</b> the verse is <b>speaking about sacrificial</b> animals <b>that one consecrated during a period when the prohibition against</b> sacrificing on private <b>altars</b> was in effect, i.e., after the Tabernacle was erected, <b>and</b> then he also <b>sacrificed them during a period when the prohibition against</b> sacrificing on private <b>altars</b> was in effect.

Daf 106b

This is apparent, <b>as the punishment for</b> sacrificing <b>them is stated</b> in this verse: <b>“And</b> he did not bring it <b>to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,</b> to sacrifice an offering to the Lord, before the Tabernacle of the Lord…that man shall be cut off from among his people.” The <b>prohibition</b> is also explicit, <b>as it is written: “Take heed to yourself lest you offer up your burnt offerings</b> in every place that you see” (Deuteronomy 12:13).
<b>From that</b> point <b>onward,</b> the verse is speaking <b>about sacrificial</b> animals <b>that one consecrated during a period when</b> there was <b>permission</b> to sacrifice offerings on private <b>altars,</b> i.e., before the Tabernacle was erected, <b>and</b> then <b>he sacrificed them</b> outside the Tabernacle <b>during a period when the prohibition against</b> sacrificing on private <b>altars</b> was in effect.
This is apparent, <b>as it is stated: “In order that the children of Israel shall bring their sacrifices, which they slaughter</b> upon the open field, that they shall bring them to the Lord, to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 17:5). The phrase “their sacrifices, which they slaughter” is interpreted as referring to <b>offerings that I have previously permitted for you</b> to slaughter on private altars. This verse teaches that those offerings may now be sacrificed only inside the Tabernacle. The phrase <b>“upon the open field” tells you</b> that in the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> an offering on a private altar <b>during a period when the prohibition against</b> sacrificing on private <b>altars</b> is in effect, even if he sacrifices the offering to God, <b>the verse ascribes him</b> blame <b>as if he sacrificed</b> it <b>upon the open field</b> in idolatrous worship.
The verse continues: <b>“That they shall bring them to the Lord.” This</b> is <b>a positive mitzva</b> to sacrifice in the Tabernacle even offerings that were consecrated before the Tabernacle was erected. <b>From where</b> is it derived that there is <b>a prohibition</b> against sacrificing them outside the Tabernacle? <b>The verse states: “And they shall not slaughter anymore</b> their offerings to the <i>se’irim</i> after whom they go astray; this shall be to them an eternal statute, throughout their generations” (Leviticus 17:7).
One <b>might</b> have thought that sacrificing these offerings outside the Tabernacle <b>would be punishable</b> by <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to offerings consecrated after the Tabernacle was erected. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This shall be to them an eternal statute, throughout their generations”</b> (Leviticus 17:7). One can infer from this verse that <b>this,</b> the punishment for transgressing a positive mitzva and a prohibition, applies <b>to them, but no other</b> punishment applies <b>to them.</b> It is clear from this <i>baraita</i> that the verse “And they shall not slaughter anymore” is used to teach about the prohibition against sacrificing outside the Tabernacle those offerings that were consecrated while there was permission to sacrifice on private altars, and not those offerings that were consecrated while it was prohibited to sacrifice on private altars.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Avin says:</b> The prohibition against slaughtering an offering outside the Temple is derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as in a case</b> in <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment</b> for a certain action, it nevertheless <b>prohibited</b> it, as is the case with regard to sacrificing outside the Temple an offering consecrated while there was permission to sacrifice on private altars, so too, in <b>a case</b> in <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did prescribe punishment</b> for a certain action, as is the case with regard to slaughtering outside the Temple an offering consecrated while it was prohibited to sacrifice on private altars, <b>is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>prohibited</b> the action?
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: If so,</b> that whenever the Torah states a punishment for a certain action, there is no need for it to state the prohibition, then <b>let</b> the Torah <b>not state a prohibition with regard to</b> eating forbidden <b>fat</b> of a kosher animal, <b>and</b> then <b>derive</b> the fact that it is prohibited through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the prohibition against eating <b>an unslaughtered animal carcass: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a carcass,</b> even though the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment</b> for consuming it, it nevertheless <b>prohibited</b> consuming it, so too, with regard to animal <b>fat,</b> for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did prescribe punishment, is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>prohibited</b> its consumption?
Rav Ashi <b>came before Rava</b> and <b>said to him:</b> The prohibition against eating animal fat <b>can also not be derived from</b> the prohibition of <b>a carcass, as</b> the <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a carcass?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it <b>renders</b> other items <b>ritually impure</b> through contact with it. Forbidden fat does not share this stringency. The existence of a unique stringency undermines the possibility of using an <i>a fortiori</i> inference.
Rav Ashi raises the possibility of deriving the prohibition against eating forbidden fat through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from various other prohibitions that, like forbidden fat, do not carry the stringency of being punishable by <i>karet</i>, and Rava rejects each one. Can one derive the prohibition against eating forbidden fat <b>from</b> the prohibition against eating carcasses of <b>ritually impure creeping animals</b> (see Leviticus 11:41)? One cannot, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about ritually impure creeping animals?</b> They are notable in <b>that they render</b> other items <b>ritually impure though</b> contact with <b>any amount</b> of them. Forbidden fat does not share this stringency.
Can one derive it <b>from</b> the prohibition against eating the carcasses of <b>ritually pure creeping animals</b> (see Leviticus 11:41), which do not have the capacity to render other items ritually impure? One cannot, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about ritually pure creeping animals?</b> They are notable in <b>that</b> with regard to <b>their prohibition</b> there is liability <b>for</b> consuming <b>any amount</b> of them. Forbidden fat does not share this stringency, as one is liable only if he eats an olive-bulk of it.
Can one derive it <b>from</b> the prohibition against eating <b>the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [<i>orla</i>] or</b> from the prohibition against eating <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard,</b> for which one is liable only if he eats an olive-bulk of them, just like with regard to animal fat? One cannot, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about <i>orla</i> and diverse kinds in a vineyard?</b> They are notable <b>in that they are items from which</b> deriving <b>benefit is prohibited.</b> Forbidden fat does not share this stringency.
Can one derive it <b>from</b> the prohibition against eating <b>Sabbatical</b> Year produce, from which benefit is permitted just like with regard to animal fat? One cannot, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about Sabbatical</b> Year produce? It is notable <b>in that it transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is purchased. Forbidden fat does not share this stringency.
Can one derive it <b>from</b> the prohibition of a non-priest partaking of <b>the portion of the produce that is designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>]?</b> One cannot, <b>as</b> in the case of <i>teruma</i> there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>its general prohibition was permitted.</b> The prohibition concerning <i>teruma</i> applies broadly, unlike in the case of forbidden fat, where the prohibition applies only to the fat of domesticated animals but not to the fat of undomesticated animals. Rava notes that the possibility of deriving the prohibition against eating forbidden fat <b>from all of those</b> prohibitions can <b>also</b> be refuted based on this claim, <b>as</b> in those cases, too, there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>their general prohibition was permitted.</b>
<b>Rava said: If</b> there is <b>a difficulty for me</b> in accepting Rabbi Avin’s claim that the prohibition against slaughtering an offering outside the Temple can be derived via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>this</b> is <b>difficult for me: That which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Karetot</i> 2a), which enumerates the thirty-six cases for which one is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. The end of that mishna lists: One who neglects sacrificing the <b>Paschal offering and</b> one who does not undergo <b>circumcision,</b> which are <b>positive mitzvot,</b> unlike the other cases enumerated in the mishna, which are all prohibitions.
Rava explains his difficulty: If Rabbi Avin is correct, <b>derive</b> that there is a prohibition against neglecting the sacrifice of the Paschal offering and not undergoing circumcision <b>via an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>one who leaves over</b> sacrificial meat beyond the allotted period for its consumption (see Leviticus 22:30): <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>one who leaves over</b> sacrificial meat, <b>where</b> the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment</b> but nevertheless <b>prohibited</b> this act, so too, with regard to neglecting the sacrifice of the Paschal offering and not undergoing circumcision, for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did prescribe punishment, is it not logical that</b> the Torah actually <b>prohibited</b> neglecting them as well?
<b>Rav Ashi said: I stated this</b> very <b>discussion before Rav Kahana, and he said to me: One cannot derive</b> a prohibition against neglecting the sacrifice of the Paschal offering <b>from</b> the case of <b>one who leaves over</b> sacrificial meat via an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as it can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about one who leaves over</b> sacrificial meat? He is notable <b>in that there is no remedy</b> once the prohibition has been violated. <b>Shall you say</b> the same about the neglect of the <b>Paschal offering,</b> for which <b>there is a remedy?</b> One who fails to bring it on the first <i>Pesaḥ</i> must bring it on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The Gemara challenges the very premise of Rabbi Avin’s claim: <b>But can one</b> derive that the Torah <b>prohibits</b> an action <b>via</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference? Even the one who says</b> that the court <b>administers punishment</b> based <b>on</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> concedes that <b>one does not</b> derive <b>a prohibition from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Avin’s claim is refuted.
<b>Rather,</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an offering outside the Temple courtyard can be derived <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says:</b> It is <b>derived</b> from the prohibition against offering up outside the Temple through a verbal analogy between the reference to <b>bringing</b> stated with regard to slaughtering outside the Temple, and the reference to <b>bringing</b> stated with regard to offering up outside the Temple.
With regard to slaughtering, it is stated: “Or that slaughters it outside the camp, and he did not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 17:3–4), and with regard to offering up, it is stated: “That offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice, and he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 17:8–9). The verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to offering up, the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment</b> for an action <b>unless</b> it also explicitly <b>prohibited</b> the action, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to slaughtering, the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment unless it</b> also <b>prohibited</b> it. Therefore, even though the Torah does not explicitly state the prohibition, it is evident that it is prohibited.

Daf 107a

<b>Rava said:</b> The prohibition can be derived <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yona, as Rabbi Yona says:</b> It is <b>derived</b> from the verse: “But in the place that the Lord will choose in one of your tribes, there you shall offer up your burnt offerings and there you shall do all that I command you” (Deuteronomy 12:14), through the juxtaposition of the word <b>“there”</b> in the first part of the verse to the word <b>“there”</b> in the second part of the verse. This serves to juxtapose the offering up, mentioned in the first part, to the sacrifice of an offering, mentioned in the second part, which includes slaughtering it. Accordingly, it teaches that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to offering up, the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment unless</b> it also <b>prohibited</b> it, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to slaughtering, the Torah <b>did not prescribe punishment unless</b> it also <b>prohibited</b> it. Therefore, even though the Torah does not explicitly state the prohibition, it is evident that it is prohibited.
§ The Gemara (106a) states that the source for the liability for offering up outside the Temple is the verse: “Any man…that offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice, and he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, to sacrifice it to the Lord, and that man shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 17:8–9). The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> that one is liable only for offerings that are fit to be <b>burned inside</b> the Temple courtyard, having been appropriately slaughtered inside the Temple courtyard, <b>which</b> one then <b>offered up outside</b> the courtyard. The verse states: “He will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting,” which indicates that they were fit to be brought to the Temple. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one is also liable with regard to offerings that are unfit and are to be <b>burned outside</b> the Temple as they were unlawfully slaughtered outside the Temple courtyard, <b>that</b> one then <b>offered up outside?</b>
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The beginning of that <b>verse states: “And to them [<i>va’alehem</i>] you shall say”</b> (Leviticus 17:8). The term “<i>alehem</i>,” to them, written with the letter <i>alef</i>, is phonetically similar to the term <i>alehem</i>, about them, written with the letter <i>ayin</i>. Therefore, the verse can be understood as saying: <b>About that which is</b> written in the <b>adjacent</b> passage <b>you shall say.</b> The preceding passage discusses offerings that were slaughtered outside the Temple, so the liability for offering up outside the Temple mentioned in this verse is also referring to those offerings.
<b>Rava objects to this: Is it written: And about them? “And to them” is written,</b> and it means that the command should be relayed to Aaron, his sons, and the Jewish people, who are mentioned in the beginning of the passage. <b>Rather,</b> liability in this case is derived <b>as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The opening phrase: <b>“And to them you shall say,”</b> starts with the conjunction “and” <b>to mix</b> the <b>passages</b> of slaughtering outside the Temple and offering up outside the Temple, in order to teach that one is liable for the latter even after having done the former.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Liability in this case <b>is derived</b> through a verbal analogy between the reference to <b>bringing</b> stated with regard to slaughtering (see Leviticus 17:4), and the reference to <b>bringing</b> stated with regard to offering up (see Leviticus 17:9). The verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to slaughtering, one is liable for offerings that are going to be <b>burned outside</b> the Temple, since one slaughtered them there, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to offering up, one is liable even for offerings that are unfit and so will be <b>burned outside</b> the Temple, having been slaughtered there.
<b>Rav Beivai objects to</b> these suggestions: But what about <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Karetot</i> 2a): There are <b>thirty-six</b> cases <b>in the Torah</b> for which one is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> The mishna enumerates all thirty-six, and offering up outside the Temple is counted as only one of them. According to these suggestions, <b>there are thirty-seven, as there is</b> one case of <b>one who offers up</b> an offering that was slaughtered inside the Temple, <b>and</b> the other case of <b>one who offers up</b> an offering that was slaughtered outside the Temple, which are considered two independent prohibitions. The Gemara concedes: This is <b>difficult.</b>
§ The Gemara considers the source for other prohibitions. <b>And</b> concerning <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (110a): <b>One who sprinkles part of</b> the <b>blood</b> of an offering, e.g., if he sprinkles one sprinkling instead of four, <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, is <b>liable; from where do we</b> derive this? The <i>tanna</i> <b>derives it from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to one who slaughters outside the Temple courtyard: <b>“Blood shall be imputed</b> to that man, he has shed blood, and that man shall be cut off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:4). This serves <b>to include</b> liability for <b>one who sprinkles</b> sacrificial blood outside the Temple courtyard; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> It is derived from the verse: “Any man…that offers up a burnt offering <b>or sacrifice”</b> (Leviticus 17:8). The term “or” serves <b>to include</b> liability for <b>one who sprinkles</b> blood outside the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael, what does he do with this</b> term “or” in “a burnt offering <b>or sacrifice”?</b> It serves <b>to divide</b> them into two independent cases, such that liability is incurred even if one offered up only one of them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva, from where does he</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>to divide</b> them into two cases? <b>He derives it from</b> the next verse: “And <b>he will not bring it</b> to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 17:9). The term “it” is written in the singular to indicate that one is liable even if he offered up only one of them.
<b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> why does he not derive that <i>halakha</i> from the term “it”? The Gemara answers: According to him, <b>that</b> term <b>is necessary</b> as the source for the <i>halakha</i> that one <b>is liable for</b> offering up <b>a complete</b> animal, <b>but</b> one <b>is not liable for</b> offering up <b>an incomplete</b> animal. The term “it” indicates an animal in its entirety. <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva, he derives</b> this <b>from</b> the repetition of “it” in the continuation of the verse: “He will not bring it…<b>to sacrifice it</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 17:9).
<b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> how does he explain the repetition of “it”? He holds that each mention teaches about a different case: <b>One</b> is referring <b>to</b> offerings that are fit to be <b>burned inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>that became incomplete and were</b> then <b>offered up outside. And</b> the other <b>one</b> is referring <b>to</b> offerings that are unfit and so will be <b>burned outside</b> the Temple as they were unlawfully slaughtered outside the Temple courtyard, <b>that became incomplete and were offered up outside.</b> In both cases one is exempt. <b>And so it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that with regard to offerings that were fit to be <b>burned inside</b> the Temple courtyard and <b>that became incomplete and were</b> instead <b>offered up outside,</b> one would be <b>liable.</b> To dispel this notion, <b>the verse states: “To sacrifice it,”</b> which indicates that <b>for</b> offering up <b>a complete</b> animal one is <b>liable, but</b> one is <b>not liable for an incomplete</b> animal.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva,</b> who has already expounded both mentions of “it,” disagrees with Rabbi Yishmael and holds that one is <b>liable</b> for offerings that are fit to be <b>burned inside that became incomplete and were</b> instead <b>offered up outside.</b>
Rabbi Yishmael derives the liability for sprinkling part of the blood of an offering outside the Temple courtyard from the verse “Blood shall be imputed to that man.” The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva, what does he do with this</b> verse: <b>“Blood shall be imputed</b> to that man”? He expounds it <b>to include</b> liability for the <b>slaughter of a bird</b> offering outside the courtyard. One is liable despite the fact that inside the Temple, a bird is sacrificed by pinching the nape of its neck, not by slaughtering it. <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael, he derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from: “Or that slaughters</b> it outside the camp” (Leviticus 17:3).
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that he does not derive it from <b>that</b> verse, as he holds that it is <b>necessary to</b> teach that only <b>one who slaughters</b> a bird offering outside <b>is liable, but</b> one is <b>not liable for pinching its nape</b> outside. <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> from where does he derive that one is exempt if he pinches? <b>He derives it from</b> the phrase at the beginning of the passage about slaughtering outside: <b>“This is the matter”</b> (Leviticus 17:2), which indicates that one is liable only for slaughtering and not for any other method of killing.
Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “Any man of the house of Israel <b>that slaughters</b> an ox, or lamb, or goat, in the camp, or that slaughters it outside the camp” (Leviticus 17:3). From this verse <b>I have</b> derived liability <b>only</b> for one who <b>slaughters an animal</b> offering outside; <b>from where do we</b> derive that one is liable if he <b>slaughtered a bird</b> offering outside? <b>The verse states: “Or that slaughters,”</b> to include liability for slaughtering a bird.
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even one who pinches</b> the nape of a bird offering outside would be liable. <b>And</b> there <b>is a logical inference</b> to support this: <b>If</b> with regard to the <b>slaughter</b> of a bird offering, <b>which is not</b> the valid <b>method of preparation inside</b> the Temple, one is nevertheless <b>liable</b> if he did it outside, then with regard to <b>pinching</b> the nape of a bird offering, <b>which is</b> the valid <b>method of preparation inside</b> the Temple, <b>is it not logical that</b> one <b>is liable</b> if he did it outside? To counter this, <b>the verse states: “This is the matter”</b> (Leviticus 17:2), which indicates one is liable only for slaughtering, not for any other method of killing.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that he does not derive it from <b>that</b> verse, as he holds that it is <b>necessary for</b> expounding as part of <b>a verbal analogy</b> with the passage with regard to vows, where it is written: “This is the matter that the Lord has commanded” (Numbers 30:2).
§ The Gemara considers the source for other prohibitions. <b>And</b> concerning <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (112b): <b>One who takes a handful</b> from a meal offering outside the Temple courtyard but does not burn it, <b>and one who collects</b> the <b>blood</b> of an offering in a vessel <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard but does not sprinkle it on an altar, he is <b>exempt; from where do we</b> derive this, that one is not liable unless he also completes the subsequent sacrificial rites? The Gemara is surprised by the question: <b>But from where would</b> it <b>be derived that</b> one is <b>liable</b> for these acts, necessitating a source for the fact that he is exempt?
The Gemara demonstrates that there is no reason to have assumed that one would be liable: If you suggest <b>deriving</b> it <b>through</b> a comparison to <b>slaughtering</b> outside the Temple, where one is liable even if he does not perform the subsequent sacrificial rites, this can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about slaughtering?</b> It is notable <b>in that with regard to a Paschal offering,</b> if one slaughters it with the intent that it be <b>for</b> the sake of <b>those who cannot eat</b> it, it is thereby <b>disqualified.</b> The cases in the mishna do not share this stringency.
And if you suggest <b>deriving</b> it <b>through</b> a comparison to <b>sprinkling</b> blood outside the Temple, as one is liable for sprinkling the blood even though it is only one of the sacrificial rites of the offering that should have been performed inside the Temple, this can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about sprinkling?</b> It is notable <b>in that a non-priest</b> who sprinkles blood in the Temple is <b>liable</b> to be punished with <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> this act. The cases in the mishna do not share this stringency.

Daf 107b

Given that each suggestion has a different refutation, the Gemara suggests: <b>Derive</b> it <b>through</b> a comparison to <b>the common element</b> shared by these two cases. Slaughtering and sprinkling are each just one of the sacrificial rites that are performed with an offering, and yet one is liable for performing them outside the Temple. Since the derivation is based on a comparison to both cases, the refutations offered for each individual case are no longer relevant.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>If</b> that were <b>so,</b> and one can derive liability for one rite through a comparison to the common element shared by two other rites, then <b>let</b> the Torah <b>not state</b> that one is liable <b>for sprinkling</b> blood outside the Temple, <b>and</b> instead <b>derive</b> it <b>from the common element</b> shared by slaughtering and offering up outside the Temple.
The derivation would be as follows: <b>And</b> if you suggest <b>deriving</b> liability for sprinkling <b>from</b> the liability for <b>slaughtering,</b> that could be refuted. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about slaughtering?</b> It is notable <b>in that, with regard to a Paschal offering,</b> if one slaughters it with the intent that it be <b>for the sake of those who cannot eat,</b> it is thereby <b>disqualified.</b> Sprinkling does not share this stringency. And if you suggest <b>deriving</b> liability for sprinkling <b>from</b> the liability for <b>offering up,</b> that could also be refuted. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about offering up?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> liability for offering up also <b>exists with regard to a meal offering.</b> Sprinkling does not share this stringency. <b>But</b> it should still be possible to <b>derive</b> liability for sprinkling <b>from the common element</b> shared by the two cases. Since the derivation is based on a comparison to both cases, the refutations offered above for each individual case are no longer relevant.
The Gemara explains: It is <b>for this</b> very reason that <b>a verse is written</b> to teach the liability for sprinkling outside the Temple, <b>to say</b> to you <b>that</b> liability for performing sacrificial rites outside the Temple <b>cannot be derived from the common element</b> shared by two other cases; rather, it must be directly derived from a verse. Accordingly, the Gemara has demonstrated that there is no basis to have assumed that one who takes a handful from a meal offering, or collects blood, outside the Temple is liable.
§ The Gemara cited a dispute concerning the source for the liability for sprinkling part of the blood of an offering outside the Temple courtyard. According to Rabbi Yishmael, it is derived from the verse in the passage about slaughtering outside the Temple: “Blood shall be imputed to that man” (Leviticus 17:4). According to Rabbi Akiva, it is derived from the verse in the passage about offering up outside the Temple: “Any man…that offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice” (Leviticus 17:8). <b>Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> One who <b>slaughtered</b> an offering <b>and sprinkled</b> its blood outside the Temple in a single lapse of awareness, <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Yishmael,</b> is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>one</b> sin offering, as liability for each transgression is derived from the same passage and they are subcategories of the same prohibition. <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin offerings, as the liability for each transgression is derived from a different passage and they are considered independent prohibitions.
<b>Abaye said: Even according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering, <b>as the verse states</b> with regard to performing sacrificial rites outside the Temple courtyard: “But in the place that the Lord will choose in one of your tribes, there you shall offer up your burnt offerings, and <b>there you shall do</b> all that I command you” (Deuteronomy 12:14). Since the first part of the verse makes reference to offering up, by inference, the term “you shall do” in the second part must be referring to all the other sacrificial rites. Therefore, <b>the verse has regarded all of</b> the sacrificial rites apart from offering up as <b>one rite</b> with regard to the prohibition against performing them outside the Temple courtyard.
Rabbi Abbahu also said: One who <b>sprinkled</b> the blood of an offering <b>and offered</b> it <b>up</b> outside, in a single lapse of awareness, <b>according to the statement of Rabbi Yishmael</b> is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin offerings. <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering.
<b>Abaye said: Even according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin offerings, as it is <b>for this</b> reason that <b>the verse differentiated</b> between the offering up and the slaughtering, as it states: <b>“There you shall offer up</b> your burnt offerings, <b>and there you shall do,”</b> in order to teach that one who performs both is liable for each one.
Finally, Rabbi Abbahu adds the logical conclusion that with regard to one who <b>slaughtered</b> an offering <b>and sprinkled</b> its blood <b>and offered</b> it <b>up</b> outside, in a single lapse of awareness, <b>all agree</b> that he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin offerings.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “Any man of the house of Israel that slaughters an ox, or lamb, or goat, in the camp, or that slaughters it outside the camp” (Leviticus 17:3). Based on the first part of the verse: “That slaughters…<b>in the camp,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who slaughters a burnt offering in the south</b> of the courtyard, instead of in the north, where it should be slaughtered, <b>will be liable,</b> as he has slaughtered it outside the area in which it should be slaughtered. To counter this, <b>the</b> next part of the <b>verse states:</b> “That slaughters it <b>outside the camp,”</b> indicating that liability is incurred only for slaughtering an offering outside the Temple courtyard.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Three concentric areas, so-called camps, arranged according to decreasing level of sanctity, encompassed the Tabernacle and Temple: The camp of the Divine Presence comprised the courtyard of the Tabernacle, and later on, of the Temple. Surrounding that was the Levite camp and then the Israelite camp. If the verse had stated only: “That slaughters it outside the camp,” one <b>might</b> have thought that a person would be liable only for slaughtering an offering <b>outside</b> all <b>three</b> of the <b>camps.</b> To dispel this notion, the first part of <b>the verse states:</b> “That slaughters an ox, or lamb, <b>or goat, in the camp,”</b> which indicates that liability is incurred even for slaughtering inside these camps. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one is liable <b>even</b> if he slaughters <b>inside the Levite camp? The verse states:</b> “That slaughters…<b>in the camp,”</b> which indicates that liability is incurred even for slaughtering inside the three camps.
