<b>If</b> the verse stated only the term <b>“in the camp,”</b> which indicates that one is liable even for slaughtering inside the three camps, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who slaughters a burnt offering in the south</b> of the courtyard, which is regarded as being outside of the holier northern section of the courtyard, where such an offering should be slaughtered, <b>will</b> also <b>be liable.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “Or</b> that slaughters it <b>outside the camp.”</b>
This indicates that <b>just as</b> the phrase <b>“outside the camp”</b> is <b>distinctive</b> in that it is referring to an area <b>that is not fit for slaughtering offerings</b> of the most sacred order <b>or for slaughtering any</b> other type of <b>offering,</b> so too, the term “in the camp” is referring to an area unfit for the slaughter of any offering. This <b>excludes</b> the <b>south</b> of the courtyard, <b>as even though</b> it is an area that is <b>not fit for slaughtering offerings of the most sacred order,</b> it is <b>fit for slaughtering offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> Therefore, no liability is incurred for slaughtering an offering in the south of the courtyard, even if it should have been slaughtered in the north.
Based on this <i>baraita</i>, <b>Ulla says: One who slaughters</b> an offering <b>on the roof of</b> the <b>Sanctuary</b> is <b>liable</b> for slaughtering outside the Temple courtyard, <b>since</b> the roof is an area that is <b>not fit for the slaughter of any offering. Rava objects to this: If so, let the verse write</b> only: “Or that slaughters it <b>outside the camp,” and</b> it would <b>not</b> be <b>necessary</b> to write: “And he did not bring it <b>to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 17:4). <b>Why do I</b> need the verse to also write: “And he did not bring it <b>to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”?</b> Is it <b>not to exclude the roof of</b> the Sanctuary, as in the Temple the Sanctuary corresponded to the Tent of Meeting? Although the roof is an area that is not fit for slaughtering any offering, one should not be liable for slaughtering there since the offering was nevertheless brought to the Tent of Meeting.
The Gemara questions Rava’s claim: <b>But according to Rava, if</b> that is <b>so</b> and one is exempt if he slaughtered on the roof of the Sanctuary as ultimately the offering was brought to the Tent of Meeting, then <b>let</b> the verse <b>write</b> only: <b>“And</b> he did not bring it <b>to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.” Why do I</b> need the verse to also write <b>“in the camp”</b> and <b>“outside the camp”?</b> Is it <b>not</b> that the term “in the camp” indicates that there is a case where one is liable even when slaughtering inside the courtyard, which serves <b>to include</b> liability for slaughtering on <b>the roof of</b> the Sanctuary? According to this, the term “outside the camp” would then be necessary to exclude liability for slaughtering a burnt offering in the south of the courtyard.
<b>Rav Mari said</b> in defense of Rava: No, the term “in the camp” is written <b>to include</b> liability for slaughtering an offering in a case where <b>its</b> body is <b>entirely inside</b> the courtyard <b>but its neck</b> is <b>outside</b> the courtyard.
The Gemara modifies Rav Mari’s statement: If <b>its neck</b> is <b>outside</b> the courtyard, it is <b>obvious</b> that one is liable, as <b>about what</b> is <b>the Merciful One particular?</b> The Merciful One is particular <b>about</b> the <b>slaughter. And</b> in this case, the <b>slaughter is</b> done <b>out-side</b> the courtyard. <b>Rather,</b> say instead that the term “in the camp” is written <b>to include</b> liability for slaughtering an offering where <b>its</b> body is <b>entirely outside</b> the courtyard <b>but its neck</b> is <b>inside</b> the courtyard.
§ An amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to <b>one who offers up</b> an offering outside the courtyard <b>today,</b> when there is no Temple: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable. Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that he is <b>liable,</b> as he holds that the <b>initial consecration</b> of the Temple <b>sanctified</b> it <b>for its time and sanctified</b> it <b>forever,</b> and the location of the Temple remains sacred even after the Temple was destroyed. Accordingly, it is still possible now to build an altar there and bring offerings upon it; therefore, one is liable if he instead offers up an offering outside the Temple courtyard area. <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>exempt,</b> as he holds that the <b>initial consecration</b> of the Temple <b>sanctified</b> it <b>for its time but did not sanctify</b> it <b>forever.</b> Accordingly, one can no longer bring offerings there; therefore, one is not liable for offering up outside that area.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 8:6): <b>Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> I heard that <b>when they were building the Sanctuary</b> in the Second Temple, <b>they would fashion</b> temporary <b>curtains for the Sanctuary</b> and temporary <b>curtains for the courtyards</b> to serve as partitions until the construction of the stone walls was completed. The difference was <b>only that in the Sanctuary,</b> the workers <b>built</b> the walls <b>outside</b> the curtains, without entering, <b>and in the courtyards,</b> the workers <b>built</b> the walls <b>within</b> the curtains.
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: I heard that one sacrifices</b> offerings on the altar <b>even if there is no Temple, and one partakes of offerings of the most sacred order</b> in the Temple courtyard <b>even if there are no curtains, and</b> one partakes of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity and second-tithe</b> produce in Jerusalem <b>even if there is no wall</b> surrounding the city. This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>initial consecration sanctified</b> the Temple and Jerusalem <b>for their time and</b> also <b>sanctified</b> them <b>forever.</b>
The Gemara concludes: From the fact that Rabbi Yehoshua based his opinion on the principle that the initial consecration sanctified the Temple and Jerusalem forever, can one <b>not</b> learn <b>by inference</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer maintains</b> that <b>it did not sanctify</b> them for-ever? The dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish would then directly parallel the dispute between Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: From where</b> do you draw this inference? <b>Perhaps everyone</b> maintains that the <b>initial consecration sanctified</b> the Temple and Jerusalem <b>for their time and</b> also <b>sanctified</b> them <b>forever. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>stated that</b> tradition, <b>which he heard</b> from his teachers, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>stated that</b> tradition, <b>which he heard</b> from his teachers, and there is no dispute between them. <b>And if you would say: Why do I</b> need <b>curtains</b> at all <b>according to Rabbi Eliezer?</b> The original sanctity remained when Jerusalem was not surrounded by walls, and similarly, the presence or absence of curtains is irrelevant to the sanctity of the Temple area as well. The Gemara answers: The curtains were established <b>merely for seclusion,</b> as it would have been unbecoming for the activity in this most sacred venue to have been visible to all.
§ An amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to <b>one who offers up</b> outside the Temple a limb of an offering <b>and</b> it <b>does not have</b> on it <b>an olive-bulk</b> of flesh, <b>but</b> the <b>bone completes</b> the measure <b>to</b> make <b>an olive-bulk. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable. Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that he is <b>liable,</b> as he holds that an item <b>attached to</b> flesh that must be <b>offered up</b> on the altar, e.g., a bone attached to sacrificial flesh, is also regarded <b>as</b> an item that must be <b>offered up</b> on the altar. Even though if it were to become detached, there would be no requirement to offer it up, nevertheless, as long as it is attached it is considered part of the flesh and it contributes to the required measure of an olive-bulk. <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>exempt,</b> as he holds that an item <b>attached to</b> flesh that must be <b>offered up</b> on the altar is <b>not</b> regarded <b>as</b> an item that must be <b>offered up</b> on the altar.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>one who offers up</b> outside the Temple courtyard

Daf 108a

the <b>head of a pigeon</b> burnt offering <b>that does not have</b> on it <b>an olive-bulk</b> of flesh, <b>but</b> the <b>salt</b> that adheres to it, after it was salted in accordance with the requirement to salt it (see Leviticus 2:13), <b>completes</b> the measure <b>to</b> make <b>an olive-bulk, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is one liable for offering it up outside?
<b>Rava from Parzakya said to Rav Ashi: Is this not</b> identical to <b>the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish</b> with regard to a bone attached to sacrificial flesh? Rav Ashi responded: No. <b>The dilemma can be raised according to Rabbi Yoḥanan and the dilemma can be raised according to Reish Lakish.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The dilemma can be raised according to Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> Perhaps <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan states</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> with regard to <b>a bone,</b> claiming that it contributes to the measure of an olive-bulk <b>as it is</b> of <b>the</b> same <b>kind that flesh</b> is, i.e., they are both animal parts. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>salt, which is not</b> of <b>the</b> same <b>kind as a pigeon,</b> perhaps it would <b>not</b> contribute to the measure. And <b>the dilemma can</b> also <b>be raised according to Reish Lakish:</b> Perhaps <b>Reish Lakish states</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> with regard to a bone, claiming that it does not contribute to the measure of an olive-bulk, <b>as if</b> the bone <b>separates from</b> the flesh, there is <b>no mitzva to offer</b> the bone <b>up</b> on the altar. <b>But here,</b> with regard to salt, concerning <b>which if it separates</b> from the pigeon there is <b>a mitzva to offer</b> it <b>up,</b> he would <b>not</b> rule as he does concerning a bone attached to flesh. <b>Or perhaps</b> there <b>is no difference</b> between the cases.
The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> If he slaughtered an offering inside the courtyard and then offered it up outside the courtyard, he is liable. But if he slaughtered it outside, thereby rendering it unfit, and then he offered it up outside, he is exempt for the offering up, as he offered up only an item that is unfit, and one is liable only for offering up an item that is fit to be offered up inside the Temple. The Rabbis said to him: According to your reasoning, even in a case where he slaughters it inside and offers it up outside, he should be exempt, since he rendered it unfit the moment that he took it outside the courtyard. Yet, in such a case, he is certainly liable for offering it up. So too, one who slaughters an offering outside and then offers it up outside is liable.
While a defense of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion is not presented in the mishna, various possibilities are recorded in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>responded</b> to this challenge <b>on behalf of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: What</b> is notable <b>about slaughtering</b> an offering <b>inside</b> the courtyard <b>and</b> then <b>offering</b> it <b>up outside?</b> It is notable in <b>that</b> the offering <b>had a period of fitness. Can you say</b> the same <b>about slaughtering</b> an offering <b>outside and</b> then <b>offering</b> it <b>up outside, where</b> the offering <b>never had a period of fitness?</b> It was disqualified as soon as it was slaughtered and so it is reasonable that one is not liable for offering it up.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, responded</b> to this challenge <b>on behalf of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili: What</b> is notable <b>about slaughtering</b> an offering <b>inside</b> the courtyard <b>and</b> then <b>offering</b> it <b>up outside?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> even though the offering was taken outside the courtyard and thereby disqualified, if it is, albeit unlawfully, placed on the altar, the <b>sanctity</b> of the altar <b>renders</b> the offering <b>acceptable</b> and it should not be removed from the altar because the disqualification occurred in sanctity, i.e., during the course of the Temple service (see 84a). <b>Can you say</b> the same <b>about slaughtering</b> an offering <b>outside</b> and then offering it up outside, <b>where</b> the disqualification did not occur in sanctity and so the <b>sanctity</b> of the altar <b>does not render</b> the offering <b>acceptable?</b> Therefore, even if it were placed there, it must be removed.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the practical difference <b>between these</b> two responses? <b>Ze’eiri said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them is</b> a case of <b>slaughtering</b> an offering <b>at night</b> inside the courtyard and then offering it up outside. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s response, one would be exempt, as slaughtering at night disqualifies the offering from its very outset; whereas according to the response of Rabbi Elazar, one would be liable as this is a disqualification that occurs in sanctity.
<b>Rabba said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them is</b> a case in which, after slaughtering the offering in the courtyard, the <b>collection</b> of the blood was done there <b>in a non-sacred vessel</b> and then the animal was offered up outside the courtyard. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s defense, one would be exempt, as collecting the blood in a non-sacred vessel disqualifies the offering from its very outset; whereas according to the response of Rabbi Elazar, one would be liable as this is a disqualification that occurs in sanctity.
§ The mishna teaches: One who is <b>ritually impure who ate</b> sacrificial food, <b>whether</b> it was ritually impure <b>sacrificial</b> food or ritually pure sacrificial food, is liable to receive <i>karet</i> if he did so intentionally, and to bring a sliding-scale offering if he did so unwittingly. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: An impure person who ate pure sacrificial food is liable. But an impure person who ate impure sacrificial food is exempt, as he merely ate an impure item, and the prohibition against eating sacrificial food while one is impure applies only to pure sacrificial food. The Rabbis said to him: According to your logic, even in a case of an impure person who ate what had been pure sacrificial food, once he has touched it, he has thereby rendered it ritually impure. Yet, in such a case, he is certainly liable for eating it. So too, an impure person who ate impure sacrificial food is liable.
The Gemara notes: <b>The Rabbis are saying well to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili;</b> why does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili disagree?
<b>Rava said</b> in elaboration of the dispute: <b>Wherever</b> one is first <b>rendered impure</b> with <b>impurity of the body and</b> then <b>afterward</b> the sacrificial <b>meat is rendered impure, everyone agrees that</b> he is <b>liable</b> if he eats the meat. This is <b>because</b> the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of</b> one’s <b>body,</b> which carries the punishment <b>of <i>karet</i>,</b> took effect while the meat was still ritually pure, and so this prohibition is not abrogated even when the meat is later rendered impure.
<b>When they disagree</b> is in a case where first the <b>meat is rendered impure and</b> then <b>afterward the</b> person’s <b>body is rendered impure.</b> In general, once an item has become subject to a prohibition, it cannot then become subject to an additional prohibition. In this case, once the meat is rendered impure, it is prohibited for anyone to eat it, even if that person is ritually pure. If that person is later rendered impure, the meat should not become subject to the additional prohibition against a ritually impure person eating sacrificial meat.
Rava explains that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and the Rabbis disagree as to whether this case is an exception to that principle, <b>as the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we say</b> that <b>since</b> the prohibition due to the ritual impurity of one’s body is a more inclusive prohibition, as it prohibits that person from eating all sacrificial meat, both pure and impure, it therefore takes effect also with regard to this meat, even though it was already rendered impure before the person was. <b>And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>since</b> it is a more inclusive prohibition, it takes effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> even according to <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> HaGelili, <b>granted that we do not say</b> that <b>since</b> it is a more inclusive prohibition it will take effect. But still, the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of</b> a person’s <b>body, which</b> is <b>a more stringent</b> prohibition as it carries the punishment of <i>karet</i>, <b>should come and take effect upon</b> the prohibition due to the <b>ritual impurity</b> of the <b>meat</b> itself, as that prohibition is less stringent as it carries only the punishment of lashes. One exception to the principle that a second prohibition does not take effect is that even if an item or person is already subject to a prohibition, a more stringent prohibition will still take effect with regard to it.
<b>Rav Ashi said: From where</b> is it apparent <b>that</b> the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of the</b> person’s <b>body is more stringent? Perhaps</b> the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of</b> the <b>meat is more stringent, as</b> impure meat <b>does not have</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath,</b> whereas a ritually impure person does. Since the prohibition due to the person’s impurity is not more stringent in every regard, it cannot take effect upon meat that is already prohibited due to its own impurity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There is <b>a greater stringency with regard to slaughtering</b> outside the Temple courtyard <b>than with regard to offering up</b> outside, <b>and</b> there is a greater stringency <b>with regard to offering up</b> outside <b>than with regard to slaughtering</b> outside.
The mishna elaborates: The <b>greater stringency with regard to slaughtering</b> outside is <b>that one who slaughters</b> an offering outside the Temple courtyard even <b>for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose, not for the sake of God, is <b>liable. But one who offers up</b> an offering outside the courtyard <b>for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose is <b>exempt.</b> The <b>greater stringency with regard to offering up</b> outside is that <b>two</b> people <b>who grasped a knife and</b> together <b>slaughtered</b> an offering outside the courtyard are <b>exempt.</b> But if two <b>grasped a limb</b> from an offering <b>and</b> together <b>offered</b> it <b>up</b> outside, they are <b>liable.</b>
If one unwittingly <b>offered up</b> part of an offering outside the courtyard <b>and then</b> in a different lapse of awareness <b>offered up</b> other parts of that offering <b>and then</b> again, in another lapse of awareness, <b>offered up</b> yet other parts, he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sin offering <b>for each</b> act of <b>offering up;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering.
Rabbi Yosei adds: <b>And</b> one is <b>liable</b> for offering up an offering outside the courtyard <b>only once he offers</b> it <b>up at the top of an altar</b> that was erected there. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even</b> if <b>he offered</b> it <b>up on a rock or on a stone,</b> not an altar, he is <b>liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara analyzes the first <i>halakha</i> of the mishna: <b>What is different</b> about <b>one who offers up</b> outside <b>for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose, <b>that he is exempt? As it is written:</b> “And he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, to sacrifice it <b>to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 17:9), which indicates that the liability applies only to offering up for the sake of the Lord. The Gemara questions this: But <b>with regard to slaughtering, isn’t it also written:</b> “Or that slaughters it outside the camp, and he did not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to sacrifice an offering <b>to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 17:3–4)?
The Gemara explains: It <b>is different there,</b> with regard to slaughtering, <b>as the verse states: “Any man [<i>ish ish</i>]</b> of the house of Israel…that slaughters it outside the camp” (Leviticus 17:3). The amplification indicated by the phrase “<i>ish ish</i>” teaches that one is liable even for slaughtering for the sake of an ordinary purpose. The Gemara challenges: But <b>also with regard to offering up it is written: “Any man [<i>ish ish</i>]</b> of the house of Israel…that offers up a burnt offering” (Leviticus 17:8). The Gemara explains: <b>That</b> amplification <b>is necessary to</b> teach that <b>two people who offered up a limb</b> of an offering together outside the courtyard are <b>liable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, here too,</b> with regard to slaughtering, the phrase “<i>ish ish</i>” <b>should be</b> used <b>to</b> teach that <b>two</b> people <b>who grasped a knife and</b> together <b>slaughtered</b> an offering outside the courtyard are <b>liable,</b> contrary to the ruling of the mishna. Why are the two parallel phrases expounded in different ways? The Gemara explains: <b>It is different there,</b> with regard to slaughtering, <b>as the verse states:</b> “And <b>that</b> man shall be cut off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:4). The term “that man,” which is in the singular, indicates that only <b>one</b> who acts alone is liable, <b>but not two</b> who act together.
The Gemara challenges: But <b>if so, also with regard to offering up, isn’t it written: “That</b> man shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 17:9)? Why isn’t that term also expounded to teach that only one who acts alone is liable? The Gemara explains: <b>That</b> term <b>is necessary</b>

Daf 108b

<b>to exclude</b> from the liability for <i>karet</i> one whose violation was <b>unwitting,</b> or who was <b>compelled to act, or</b> who was <b>mistaken.</b> The term “that man” teaches that only one who offered up with intent is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, here too,</b> with regard to slaughtering outside, the term is <b>necessary to exclude</b> one whose violation was <b>unwitting,</b> or who was <b>compelled to act, or</b> who was <b>mistaken.</b> How can the term be used to teach that only one who acts alone is liable?
The Gemara explains: With regard to slaughtering outside, <b>two</b> instances of the term <b>“that</b> man” <b>are written:</b> “Blood shall be imputed to that man, he has shed blood, and that man shall be cut off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:4). One instance teaches that only one who acts with intent is liable to receive <i>karet</i>, and the other teaches that only one who acts alone is liable.
The Gemara has now justified its claim that the liability of one who slaughters an offering outside for the sake of an ordinary purpose is derived from the phrase “<i>ish ish</i>.” Accordingly, the Gemara asks: <b>But why do I</b> need the term <b>“to the Lord”?</b> The Gemara explains: It is written <b>to exclude</b> from liability one who slaughters the Yom Kippur <b>scapegoat</b> outside the courtyard.
§ The mishna teaches: The <b>greater stringency</b> with regard to <b>offering up</b> outside is that two people who grasped a knife and together slaughtered an offering outside the courtyard are exempt. But if two grasped a limb from an offering and together offered it up outside, they are liable.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> <i>halakha</i> is alluded to when <b>the verse states: “Any man [<i>ish ish</i>]…</b>that offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice” (Leviticus 17:8)? The verse teaches that <b>two people who grasped a limb</b> of an offering <b>and offered</b> it <b>up</b> together outside the courtyard are <b>liable.</b> It is necessary for the verse to teach this, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought to say: <b>Could this not be</b> derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: If</b> with regard to slaughtering outside the courtyard, <b>one who slaughters for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose is <b>liable,</b> and nevertheless, <b>two who grasped a knife and</b> together <b>slaughtered</b> an offering are <b>exempt,</b> then with regard to offering up outside the courtyard, where <b>one who offers up for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose is <b>exempt, is it not logical that two who grasped</b> a limb and offered it up will also be <b>exempt?</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states “<i>ish ish</i>”</b> to teach that they are liable for offering up together; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that the <i>halakha</i> concerning this case is derived from a different verse. The term <b>“that [<i>hahu</i>]</b> man” (Leviticus 17:9), which is in the singular, indicates that only <b>one</b> who acts alone is liable, <b>but not two</b> who act together. The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>If so, what</b> <i>halakha</i> is alluded to when <b>the verse states “<i>ish ish</i>”?</b> The <i>baraita</i> explains: Rabbi Yosei holds that the reason the Torah uses the doubled term “<i>ish ish</i>” is that <b>the Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> and no <i>halakhot</i> are to be derived from it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon,</b> what does he derive from the term “that man”? The Gemara explains: <b>This</b> term: <b>“That</b> man,” <b>is necessary to exclude</b> from liability one whose violation was <b>unwitting,</b> or who was <b>compelled to act, or</b> who was <b>mistaken.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And Rabbi Yosei</b> derives that <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the fact that the verse could have stated <b><i>hu</i></b> and instead stated <b>“<i>hahu</i>.”</b> The Hebrew word for: That, <i>hahu</i>, is formed of the definite article <i>ha</i> and the pronoun <i>hu</i>. <b>And Rabbi Shimon does not expound</b> any <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> the fact that the verse could have stated <b><i>hu</i></b> and instead stated <b>“<i>hahu</i>.”</b> He holds that the expanded form is used because the Torah spoke in the language of people.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yosei, from</b> the fact <b>that</b> he holds that nothing is to be derived from the phrase <b>“<i>ish ish</i>”</b> written with regard to offering up, as he holds that <b>the Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> then <b>also</b> with regard to <b>that</b> phrase: <b>“Any man [<i>ish ish</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 17:3), written with regard to slaughtering, since he holds that <b>the Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> he should not derive any <i>halakhot</i> from it. <b>But</b> if so, <b>from where</b> does he derive <b>that one who slaughters</b> outside <b>for</b> the sake of <b>an ordinary</b> purpose is <b>liable?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the verse: <b>“Blood shall be imputed to that man; he has shed blood”</b> (Leviticus 17:4), which teaches that <b>even one who slaughters for</b> the sake of an ordinary <b>man</b> is liable.
§ The mishna teaches: If one unwittingly <b>offered up</b> part of an offering outside the courtyard <b>and then</b> in a different lapse of awareness <b>offered up</b> other parts of that offering and then again, in another lapse of awareness, offered up yet other parts, he is liable to bring a sin offering for each act of offering up; this is the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Yosei says: He is liable to bring only one sin offering.
The Gemara cites two opinions concerning the case under dispute. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> in the mishna <b>concerns four or five limbs</b> that were offered up in different lapses of awareness. <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds: When it is written: “To sacrifice it”</b> (Leviticus 17:9), which teaches the <i>halakha</i> that <b>for</b> offering up <b>a complete</b> item one is <b>liable but</b> that one is <b>not liable for</b> offering up <b>an incomplete</b> item, <b>it is written with regard to a whole animal.</b> Accordingly, liability to bring a sin offering is incurred only once one offers up the entire animal, even if that was done limb by limb. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that that verse <b>is written with regard to each and every limb</b> of an animal. Accordingly, one is liable for each limb he offered up. <b>But</b> with regard to the offering up of <b>one limb</b> in parts, <b>everyone agrees</b> that a person is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering. According to Rabbi Shimon this would apply even if that were the only limb that was offered up; according to Rabbi Yosei this would apply only if the rest of the animal had already been offered up.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Everyone agrees that one is liable even for offering up a single limb. Furthermore, if an offering is slaughtered outside the courtyard, everyone agrees that one is liable only once an entire limb has been offered up. The <b>dispute</b> in the mishna <b>concerns one limb</b> from an offering that was slaughtered inside the courtyard that was then taken outside and offered up in parts, during different lapses of awareness. <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that for offerings <b>that are</b> fit to be <b>burned inside</b> the Temple, <b>that became incomplete and were</b> instead <b>offered up outside</b> the Temple, one is <b>liable.</b> Accordingly, one is liable for each part of the limb. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>exempt</b> for offering up part of a limb outside the courtyard. Accordingly, liability is incurred only once all the parts of the limb have been offered up. <b>But with regard to</b> offering up <b>four or five limbs, everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>liable for each and every limb,</b> as they understand that the phrase “to sacrifice it” is written with regard to each and every limb.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion <b>of Ulla, as Ulla says: Everyone</b> in the mishna <b>concedes with regard to</b> offerings <b>that are</b> fit to be <b>burned inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>that became incomplete and were</b> instead <b>offered up outside</b> the courtyard, <b>that</b> one is <b>liable. They disagree only with regard to</b> offerings that, having been slaughtered outside <b>are</b> unfit and so will be <b>burned outside, that became incomplete and were offered up outside. As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>exempt, and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>liable.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> there is a different version of Ulla’s statement, according to which he agrees with his teacher, Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>Ulla says: Everyone</b> in the mishna <b>concedes with regard to</b> offerings that, having been slaughtered outside the Temple <b>are</b> unfit and so will be <b>burned outside, that became incomplete and were offered up outside, that one is exempt. They disagree only with regard to</b> offerings <b>that are</b> fit to be <b>burned inside that became incomplete and were</b> instead <b>offered up outside. As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>exempt, and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>liable.</b>
<b>And</b> the statement <b>of Shmuel’s father disagrees with the first version of Ulla’s</b> statement, <b>as Shmuel’s father says: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do we restore</b> limbs <b>that were dislodged</b> from upon the altar <b>to the altar? In accordance with whose</b> opinion? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> recorded in the mishna. Shmuel’s father assumes that Rabbi Yosei holds that incomplete limbs are never offered up on the altar, even if they were dislodged from the altar. Accordingly, he holds that one is not liable for offering them up outside the Temple courtyard. This is contrary to the first version of Ulla’s opinion, according to which one is liable for offering up incomplete offerings that were slaughtered inside the courtyard. Evidently, Ulla holds that an incomplete limb that was dislodged from the altar is to be restored to the altar.
§ The mishna teaches: Rabbi Yosei says: <b>And</b> one is <b>liable</b> for offering up an offering outside the courtyard <b>only once he offers</b> it <b>up</b> upon the top of an altar that was erected there. Rabbi Shimon says: Even if he offered it up on a rock or on a stone, not an altar, he is liable. <b>Rav Huna says: What is the reason of Rabbi Yosei? As it is written: “And Noah built an altar to the Lord,</b> and took of every pure animal, and of every pure bird, and offered up burnt offerings on the altar” (Genesis 8:20). Noah was particular to use an altar rather than one of the available rocks. Apparently, this was because placing an item upon an altar is the only act that can be considered offering up.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the reason of Rabbi Shimon? As it is written: “And Manoah took the kid with the meal offering, and offered it up upon the rock, to the Lord”</b> (Judges 13:19). Evidently, even placing an offering upon a rock is considered an act of offering up.
The Gemara explains how each <i>tanna</i> interprets the verse that supports the other. <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> opinion, Rabbi Shimon’s, <b>isn’t it written: “And</b> Noah <b>built an altar to the Lord”?</b> How does he explain that verse? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse is referring <b>merely</b> to <b>an elevated place</b> and not specifically to an altar. <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> opinion, Rabbi Yosei’s, <b>isn’t it written: “And Manoah took</b>…and offered it up upon the rock”? How does he explain that verse? The Gemara answers: The use of a rock in <b>that</b> case <b>was a provisional edict</b> issued in exigent circumstances, by the angel who visited Manoah, and so one cannot derive normative <i>halakha</i> from it.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>the reason of Rabbi Shimon is as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the verse states: “And the priest shall sprinkle the blood upon the <b>altar</b> of the Lord <b>at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 17:6). From here it is apparent that only in the Sanctuary is there a requirement for an altar, <b>but</b> a specifically erected <b>altar is not</b> required in order to offer up <b>on</b> a private <b>altar</b> during periods when it is permitted to do so. <b>Therefore, one who offered up</b> outside the courtyard <b>on a rock or on a stone</b> is <b>liable.</b>
The Gemara questions the formulation of the <i>baraita</i>: If the <i>baraita</i> was referring to offering up during a period when the use of private altars is permitted, it <b>should have</b> concluded: One who offered up outside on a rock or on a stone has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. Why does it state instead that he is liable? The Gemara explains: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> Since there is no requirement for a specifically erected altar during a period when private altars are permitted, <b>therefore, during a period when</b> the use of private <b>altars is prohibited,</b> one who <b>offers up</b> outside <b>on a rock or on a stone</b> is <b>liable.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, raises a dilemma:</b> Features that are indispensable with regard to the altar in the Temple are the <b>corner,</b> the <b>ramp</b> leading to the altar, the <b>base</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> the <b>square shape. What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>whether they are</b> also <b>indispensable for</b> the validity of a private <b>altar</b> during a period when it is permitted to use private altars?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>corner,</b> the <b>ramp,</b> the <b>base, and</b> the <b>square shape are</b> all <b>indispensable for</b> the validity of <b>a great</b> public <b>altar, but they are not indispensable for</b> the validity of <b>a small</b> private <b>altar.</b>

Daf 109a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>both fit sacrificial</b> animals, <b>and unfit sacrificial</b> animals <b>whose disqualification occurred in sanctity,</b> i.e., in the course of the Temple service, <b>and one sacrificed them outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>liable.</b>
<b>One who offers up outside</b> the courtyard <b>an olive-bulk</b> made up <b>of</b> the flesh of <b>a burnt offering and of</b> its <b>sacrificial portions</b> is <b>liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to offering up outside the courtyard: <b>“That offers up a burnt offering or sacrifice,</b> and he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, to sacrifice it to the Lord” (Leviticus 17:8–9). From the term “burnt offering” <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that one is liable for offering up <b>a burnt offering,</b> which is burned entirely on the altar. <b>From where</b> do I derive <b>to include</b> that one is liable for offering up outside the courtyard <b>the sacrificial portions of a guilt offering, the sacrificial portions of a sin offering, the sacrificial portions of offerings of the most sacred order, or the sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity? The verse states: “Sacrifice,”</b> which includes the sacrificial portions of all other offerings that are to be burned on the altar.
<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> that one is liable for offering up outside the courtyard <b>the handful</b> taken from a meal offering; <b>the frankincense</b> that was to be offered with it; <b>the incense,</b> which was offered each day in the Sanctuary; <b>the meal offering of priests; the meal offering of the anointed priest,</b> i.e., the High Priest, which he offered daily; <b>and</b> to include as liable <b>one who pours as a libation three <i>log</i> of wine,</b> which is the volume of the smallest wine libation used in the Temple; <b>or</b> one who pours as a libation <b>three <i>log</i> of water</b> that was consecrated to be used as a libation during the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>? <b>The verse states: “And he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 17:9), which indicates that with regard to <b>any</b> offering that is fit to be <b>brought to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting</b> to be offered there upon the altar, one is <b>liable for</b> offering it up <b>outside</b> the courtyard.
<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that one is liable for offering up <b>fit offerings; from where</b> do I derive <b>to</b> also <b>include</b> liability for <b>unfit</b> offerings whose disqualification occurred in sanctity?
<b>For example:</b> Sacrificial meat <b>that was left overnight, or</b> an offering <b>that went outside</b> the courtyard, <b>or</b> an offering <b>that</b> is <b>impure, or</b> an offering <b>that was slaughtered</b> with intent to consume it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, or</b> an offering <b>that an unfit</b> person <b>collected and sprinkled its blood, or</b> if <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed above</b> the red line encircling the altar <b>below</b> it, <b>or</b> if <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed below</b> the red line <b>above</b> it, <b>or</b> if <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>outside</b> on the external altar, <b>or</b> if <b>one placed</b> the blood <b>that is</b> to be <b>placed outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>inside</b> it, <b>or a Paschal offering or sin offering whose</b> blood <b>was placed not for their sake?</b>
Since the disqualification of these offerings occurred in sanctity, if they were to be, albeit unlawfully, placed upon the altar, the altar would render them acceptable such that they should not be removed from upon it. <b>From where</b> is it derived to also include liability for these unfit offerings? <b>The verse states:</b> “And <b>he will not bring it</b> to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, <b>to sacrifice</b> it to the Lord,” which indicates that with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that is</b> rendered <b>acceptable</b> upon the altar <b>at</b> the <b>entrance of the Tent of Meeting,</b> even if it should not have been brought there <i>ab initio</i>, one is <b>liable for</b> offering <b>it</b> up <b>outside</b> the courtyard.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>One who offers up outside</b> the courtyard <b>an olive-bulk</b> made up <b>of</b> the flesh of <b>a burnt offering</b> and of its sacrificial portions is liable. The Gemara infers: The mishna states that for an olive-bulk combined of the flesh of <b>a burnt offering and</b> of <b>its sacrificial portions, yes,</b> one is liable. By inference, for an olive-bulk combined of the meat of <b>a peace offering and</b> of <b>its sacrificial portions,</b> one is <b>not</b> liable, because its meat is eaten, not burned on the altar.
<b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Me’ila</i> 1:28): The flesh of <b>a burnt offering and its sacrificial portions combine to</b> form the minimum measure, of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> to render one liable <b>for offering them up outside</b> the courtyard, <b>and to render</b> one <b>liable for</b> eating <b>them due to <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., if the sacrificial rites were performed with the intent of sacrificing the offering after its designated time; <b><i>notar</i>,</b> i.e., if its flesh remained after the period in which it was permitted to sacrifice it; <b>or</b> for eating them while he was <b>ritually impure.</b> This <i>baraita</i>, too, states that only the flesh and sacrificial portions of a burnt offering combine. This indicates that the meat and sacrificial portions of a peace offering do not combine.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>offering up</b> outside the courtyard, it is logical that for <b>a burnt offering, which is</b> entirely <b>consumed</b> upon the altar, that <b>yes,</b> everything will combine, and that for <b>peace offerings,</b> whose meat is not burned on the altar, the meat and sacrificial portions will <b>not</b> combine. <b>But</b> with regard to liability for <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, and</b> eating while <b>ritually impure, what is the reason</b> that the <i>baraita</i> differentiates between a burnt offering and a peace offering?
The Gemara compounds its questions: <b>And didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 15a): <b>Anything that is <i>piggul</i> combines</b> together, <b>and anything that is <i>notar</i> combines</b> together, to form the measure of an olive-bulk to render one liable? The mishna indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies to all types of offerings. Accordingly, the Gemara notes: The ruling about <b><i>piggul</i></b> in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult,</b> as it is contradicted <b>by</b> the ruling about <b><i>piggul</i></b> in the mishna, and the ruling about <b><i>notar</i></b> in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult,</b> as it is contradicted <b>by</b> the ruling about <b><i>notar</i></b> in the mishna.
The Gemara resolves the difficulties: That the ruling about <b><i>piggul</i></b> in the <i>baraita</i> is contradicted <b>by</b> the ruling about <b><i>piggul</i></b> in the mishna is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the mishna, the ruling that they combine <b>concerns</b> liability for eating <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, the ruling that only the parts of a burnt offering combine <b>concerns <i>piggul</i> intention.</b> An offering is rendered <i>piggul</i> only if one intends to eat an olive-bulk of it after the designated time for eating it or to sacrifice an olive-bulk of it after the designated time for sacrificing it. The <i>baraita</i> rules that for a burnt offering, if one has such intention for both half an olive-bulk of its meat and half an olive-bulk of its sacrificial portions, that is sufficient for the entire offering to be rendered <i>piggul</i>. For a peace offering, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i> only if one has such intention about an olive-bulk comprised only of meat or only of sacrificial portions.
The Gemara resolves the second difficulty: That the ruling about <b><i>notar</i></b> in the <i>baraita</i> is contradicted <b>by</b> the ruling about <b><i>notar</i></b> in the mishna is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the mishna, the ruling that they combine <b>concerns</b> liability for eating <b><i>notar</i>,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, the ruling that only the parts of a burnt offering combine <b>concerns</b> a case in <b>which</b> only an olive-bulk combined of both the flesh and the sacrificial portions <b>remained</b> from the offering, the rest having been destroyed, <b>before</b> its <b>blood was sprinkled.</b> Blood may not be sprinkled unless an olive-bulk of the offering remains. And if the blood is not sprinkled, the offering will never be rendered <i>notar</i>. The <i>baraita</i> rules that in the case of a burnt offering, the different parts of it combine to form an olive-bulk to permit the sprinkling of the blood. This does not apply to a peace offering, for which an olive-bulk of only meat or of only sacrificial portions must remain in order to permit the sprinkling of the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And whose</b> opinion is expressed by the <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>all the offerings that</b> are mentioned <b>in the Torah from which there remains</b> only <b>an olive-bulk of meat,</b> the rest having been destroyed or rendered impure,

Daf 109b

<b>or</b> from which there remains only <b>an olive-bulk of</b> sacrificial portions, e.g., <b>fat</b> to be burned on the altar, one still <b>sprinkles the blood</b> of the offering on the altar and one thereby fulfills his obligation.
But if all that remains is <b>half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of fat, one may not sprinkle the blood,</b> as since the meat and the sacrificial portions are used differently, the former being eaten and the latter being burned on the altar, they cannot combine to form the minimum requirement of an olive-bulk. This applies only to offerings whose meat is eaten. <b>But for a burnt offering,</b> even if all that remains is <b>half an olive-bulk of flesh and half an olive-bulk of fat, one sprinkles the blood, because</b> since the offering is <b>consumed</b> upon the altar <b>in its entirety,</b> all of its parts combine together. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering, even if all of it</b> still <b>exists, one does not sprinkle</b> the blood. It is apparent that Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion in this <i>baraita</i> is the one expressed in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara clarifies the final clause of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the relevance of a meal offering</b> to the sprinkling of blood? In a meal offering there is no blood at all. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations that accompany</b> an animal <b>offering.</b> If the entire body of the offering was destroyed but the meal offering that accompanied it remains, one might have thought that it would be sufficient to allow for the sprinkling of the blood. The <i>baraita</i> teaches that this is incorrect.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the handful</b> of a meal offering, <b>the frankincense, the incense, the meal offering of priests, the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, and the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings, in a case <b>where one sacrificed</b> even <b>an olive-bulk from</b> any <b>one of these,</b> which should be sacrificed on the altar, <b>outside</b> the Temple, he is <b>liable,</b> as the burning of an olive-bulk is considered a proper burning. <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>exempt unless he sacrifices the whole of</b> any one of these items outside the Temple. <b>But</b> Rabbi Eliezer concedes that with regard to <b>any of them that one sacrificed inside</b> the courtyard <b>but left over an olive-bulk from them and</b> then <b>sacrificed that</b> olive-bulk <b>outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>liable.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>any of these</b> offerings <b>that were lacking any amount,</b> if <b>one sacrifices it outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>exempt.</b>
<b>One who sacrifices sacrificial</b> meat, which is eaten, <b>and sacrificial portions,</b> i.e., those that are to be burned on the altar, <b>outside</b> the courtyard, is <b>liable</b> for the sacrifice of the sacrificial portions. But he is not liable for sacrificing the meat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Each morning and afternoon, a <i>peras</i>, i.e., half a <i>maneh</i>, of incense must be burned in the Sanctuary. Nevertheless, <b>one who burns</b> only <b>an olive-bulk</b> of incense <b>outside</b> the courtyard is <b>liable.</b> If one burns <b>half a <i>peras</i> inside</b> the Temple, he is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara addresses the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>It enters our mind</b> to explain: <b>What</b> is meant by: He is <b>exempt?</b> It means that <b>a non-priest,</b> for whom it is prohibited to perform the sacrificial rites in the Temple, is <b>exempt</b> if he burns incense inside the Temple. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Why</b> should he be exempt; this <b>is</b> an act of <b>sacrificial burning?</b> Even though he burned less than a <i>peras</i>, it is apparent from the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> that burning even an olive-bulk is considered an act of sacrificial burning.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya, son of Abba, said</b> that <b>Rav said: What</b> is meant by: He is <b>exempt?</b> It means that if a priest burns half a <i>peras</i> inside the Temple, the <b>community</b> is thereby <b>exempt</b> from its obligation to burn incense despite the fact that less than the required amount was burned.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: If</b> there is something <b>difficult for me</b> with regard to this <i>baraita</i>, <b>this</b> is <b>difficult for me: That which Rav said concerning</b> this <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that if a priest burns less than a <i>peras</i> of incense the community fulfills its obligation, <b>even Rabbi Eliezer concedes.</b> Rabbi Zeira explains: This is difficult for me <b>as Rabbi Eliezer</b> rules in the mishna that one who burns an olive-bulk of incense outside is exempt. Effectively, he is <b>saying</b> that burning less than the required amount <b>is not</b> an act of <b>sacrificial burning.</b> How then can he hold that the community fulfills its obligation by the burning of less than a <i>peras</i>?
<b>Rabba said: With regard to</b> the <b>burning of</b> incense designated to be burned in the <b>Sanctuary</b> upon the golden altar, <b>everyone,</b> i.e., the Rabbis and Rabbi Eliezer, <b>agrees</b> that the Torah does not specify the amount to be burned; the requirement to burn a <i>peras</i> is rabbinic. Accordingly, the obligation is fulfilled even if only an olive-bulk of incense is burned there, as the <i>baraita</i> states, and one who burns an olive-bulk of that incense outside the Temple is liable.
<b>When they disagree</b> in the mishna, it is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>burning of</b> incense in the <b>inner</b> sanctum, i.e., in the Holy of Holies, on Yom Kippur. Concerning that obligation, the verse states: “And he shall take…his handful of sweet incense, beaten small, and bring it within the Curtain” (Leviticus 16:12). <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>“his handful”</b> indicates that <b>specifically</b> that measure must be burned in order to fulfill the obligation. Accordingly, he also holds that one who burns only an olive-bulk of that incense outside the courtyard is exempt. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>“his handful”</b> does <b>not</b> indicate that <b>specifically</b> that measure must be burned, and the obligation can be fulfilled even with a lesser amount. Accordingly, they also hold that one who burns even an olive-bulk of that incense outside the courtyard is liable.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>But when</b> the term <b>“statute” is written</b> with regard to the Yom Kippur Temple service (see Leviticus 16:29), <b>it is</b> also <b>written with regard to</b> the <b>burning of</b> incense in the <b>inner</b> sanctum. The term “statute” stated with regard to a rite indicates that it is valid only if performed precisely in accordance with all the details mentioned in the Torah concerning it. Accordingly, the term “his handful” must be specific.
<b>Rather, Abaye said: With regard to</b> the <b>burning</b> of incense <b>in</b> the <b>inner</b> sanctum, i.e., in the Holy of Holies, on Yom Kippur, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the obligation is only fulfilled if a handful of incense is burned. Also, everyone agrees with regard to burning incense in the Sanctuary that the obligation is fulfilled even with an olive-bulk, as the <i>baraita</i> states, and one who burns an olive-bulk of incense outside the Temple is liable.
<b>When they disagree</b> in the mishna, it is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>burning of</b> incense of the Holy of Holies <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard. One <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>we derive</b> the measure for liability for incense of the <b>inner</b> sanctum <b>from</b> incense of the <b>outer</b> sanctum, i.e., the Sanctuary. Just as for the latter one is liable for an olive-bulk, so too, for the former one is liable for an olive-bulk. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not derive</b> one from the other. Rather, since the obligation inside the Holy of Holies is fulfilled only with a handful of incense, one is liable for burning that incense outside the Temple only if he burns that amount.
<b>Rava said</b> in rejection of Abaye’s understanding: <b>Now,</b> if <b>the Rabbis do not derive</b> the measure for liability for offering up outside the Temple courtyard, with regard to other rites performed in the <b>outer</b> sanctum, <b>from</b> incense of the <b>outer</b> sanctum, is it <b>necessary</b> to question whether they would derive the measure for liability for incense of the <b>inner</b> sanctum <b>from</b> incense of the <b>outer</b> sanctum? Certainly, they would not.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the rite that Rava is referring to in his response to Abaye? It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who offers up</b> outside the courtyard <b>less than an olive-bulk of</b> the <b>handful</b> taken from a meal offering <b>or less than an olive-bulk of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions, or who pours as a libation</b> outside the courtyard <b>less than three <i>log</i> of wine</b> or who pours as a libation on <i>Sukkot</i> <b>less than three <i>log</i> of water,</b> that <b>he would be liable.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “And he will not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, <b>to sacrifice</b> it” (Leviticus 17:9). The term “to sacrifice it” indicates that one is <b>liable for the</b> sacrifice of <b>a complete</b> offering outside the courtyard <b>but one is not liable for the</b> sacrifice of <b>an incomplete</b> offering outside.
The Gemara explains Rava’s inference: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> states that for a libation of <b>less than three <i>log</i></b> outside the courtyard one is exempt despite the fact <b>that</b> the libation still <b>contains a few olive-bulks. And</b> it is apparent then, that <b>the Rabbis do not derive</b> the measure for liability for the rite of libation that should be performed in the <b>outer</b> sanctum <b>from</b> incense that should be burned in the <b>outer</b> sanctum. Certainly then, they would not derive the measure for liability for incense of the inner sanctum from incense of the outer sanctum.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> to resolve Rabbi Zeira’s difficulty: Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis agree with regard to the incense of the Sanctuary, that the Torah does not specify an amount to be burned, and the community fulfills its obligation even if only an olive-bulk is burned, as is taught in the <i>baraita</i>. When they disagree in the mishna, it is in a case <b>where, for example, one designated two half-<i>peras</i></b> portions of incense, in accordance with the rabbinic requirement to burn one <i>peras</i>,

Daf 110a

by placing them <b>in a vessel.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that the <b>designation of</b> a measure of incense larger than an olive-bulk by placing it in <b>a vessel is</b> a significant <b>matter</b> that renders one obligated to burn all the incense that was placed there. Therefore, one who then burned only an olive-bulk of that incense outside the courtyard is exempt. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that it <b>is nothing</b> and does not render one obligated to burn all the incense that was placed in the vessel. Therefore, one who then burned an olive-bulk of that incense outside the courtyard is liable.
<b>Rava said: Now, according to the one who says</b> that <b>designation</b> by placing in a <b>vessel is nothing,</b> if <b>one designated</b> in a vessel <b>six</b> <i>log</i> of wine <b>as</b> a libation to accompany the sacrificing of <b>a bull,</b> which is the required amount, <b>and</b> then <b>removed four</b> <i>log</i> <b>from</b> it <b>and brought those</b> four <i>log</i> as a libation <b>outside</b> the courtyard, he would be <b>liable, as</b> a libation of four <i>log</i> of wine is <b>fit for</b> the sacrificing of <b>a ram</b> (see Numbers 28:14).
Similarly, if one <b>designated</b> by placing in a vessel <b>four</b> <i>log</i> of wine <b>for</b> a libation to accompany the sacrificing of <b>a ram and</b> then <b>removed three</b> <i>log</i> <b>of</b> wine from it <b>and brought those</b> three <i>log</i> as a libation <b>outside</b> the courtyard, he would be <b>liable, as</b> three <i>log</i> of wine is a <b>fit</b> libation <b>for</b> the sacrificing of <b>a lamb</b> (see Numbers 28:14).
But if those three <i>log</i> <b>were lacking any amount, and one brought them</b> as a libation <b>outside</b> the courtyard, he would be <b>exempt</b> because less than three <i>log</i> of wine is never a fit libation.
Rava inferred from the <i>baraita</i> that the Rabbis do not derive the measure for liability for a rite performed in the outer sanctum, i.e., the pouring of a libation, from one performed in the outer sanctum, i.e., the burning of incense. From that he concluded that the Rabbis would certainly not derive the measure for liability for a rite performed in the inner sanctum from a rite performed in the outer sanctum. This refuted Abaye’s claim that the Rabbis derive the measure for liability for burning outside the incense of the inner sanctum from the measure for liability for burning outside the incense of the outer sanctum. <b>Rav Ashi said</b> in defense of Abaye’s opinion: Indeed, as is indicated by the <i>baraita</i>, <b>the Rabbis do not derive</b> the measure for liability for <b>pouring a libation</b> outside the courtyard <b>from</b> the measure for liability for <b>burning</b> incense, which are two different rites performed in the outer sanctum.
Rav Ashi continues: <b>Even though</b> the Rabbis <b>do not derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a rite performed in the <b>outer</b> sanctum <b>from</b> a different rite performed in the <b>outer</b> sanctum, <b>they do derive</b> the measure for liability for <b>burning</b> the incense of the outer sanctum <b>from</b> the identical rite of <b>burning</b> of the incense of the inner sanctum, <b>even though</b> it involves deriving the <i>halakhot</i> of a rite performed in the <b>outer</b> sanctum <b>from</b> one performed in the <b>inner</b> sanctum.
§ After enumerating various items that are burned entirely on the altar, the mishna states: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>any of these</b> offerings <b>that were lacking</b> any amount, if one sacrifices it outside the courtyard, he is exempt. Concerning this ruling, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is <b>a lack that</b> occurs to an offering <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>considered a lack</b> in order to exempt one who sacrifices the remainder outside the courtyard? <b>Or</b> is it <b>not considered a lack?</b>
<b>Do we say</b> that <b>once</b> an offering <b>emerges</b> from the courtyard <b>it is</b> in any event <b>disqualified,</b> and yet the Torah deems one liable for offering it there, so <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if there is an additional disqualification of being <b>lacking</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if it is still <b>complete? Or perhaps</b> it is only with regard to <b>emerging</b> from the courtyard, <b>where it is</b> still <b>in its original state,</b> that <b>yes,</b> one is liable despite the fact that it was disqualified by emerging from the courtyard, but where it is <b>not in its original state,</b> one would <b>not</b> be liable.
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from the mishna: <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>exempt unless he sacrifices the whole of</b> any one of these items outside the Temple. It is apparent then that the offering must remain complete.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye:</b> Can the <b>Master resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer?</b> The Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer, and hold that one is liable for sacrificing even an olive-bulk, and the dilemma was raised according to their opinion.
Abaye <b>said to him: I heard explicitly from Rav</b> that <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer only where</b> the offering <b>is</b> still <b>in its original form,</b> i.e., complete. <b>But where</b> it is <b>lacking, they concede to him</b> that one is not liable. The Gemara attempts to bring a proof from here: Was Rav <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where it became lacking outside</b> the courtyard? If so, it is evident that even according to the Rabbis a lack that occurs outside is considered a lack. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> he was referring to a case <b>where it became lacking inside</b> the courtyard. Accordingly, this mishna cannot serve as a proof.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from the continuation of the mishna: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>any of these</b> offerings <b>that were lacking</b> any amount, if <b>one sacrifices them outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>exempt.</b> The Gemara attempts to bring a proof from here: Is the mishna <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where it became lacking outside</b> the courtyard? If so, it is evident that even a lack that occurs outside is considered a lack. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where it became lacking inside</b> the courtyard. Accordingly, this cannot serve as a proof.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>One who sacrifices sacrificial</b> meat, which is eaten, and sacrificial portions, i.e., those that are to be burned on the altar, outside the courtyard, is liable for the sacrifice of the sacrificial portions, but not for the meat. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is he liable? If the meat is placed directly on the altar’s fire and then the sacrificial portions are placed upon the meat, <b>isn’t there an interposition</b> between the altar and the sacrificial portions? Since if they were offered in the Temple in that manner, one would not have fulfilled the obligation, one should not be liable if he offers them up in this manner outside the Temple.
<b>Shmuel said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where he turned them over</b> and the sacrificial portions lay directly on the altar’s fire.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> there is another explanation: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where they did not turn them over. And</b> in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? It <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> (108a) that <b>even if one offered it up on a rock</b> he is <b>liable.</b> According to him, it is clear that in order for one to be liable, the mode of offering up performed outside the Temple does not need to entirely parallel the mode of offering up in the Temple.
<b>Rav said</b> there is another explanation: Even in the Temple, burning the sacrificial meat and sacrificial portions in this manner would be valid as both items are from the same animal, and <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance does not interpose.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <b>a meal offering</b> from <b>which a handful was not removed, and one sacrificed it outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>exempt</b> from liability, because until the handful is actually removed it is not fit to be burned on the altar inside the Temple. But if a priest <b>took a handful from it and</b> then <b>returned its handful into</b> the remainder of the meal offering, <b>and one sacrificed</b> the entire mixture <b>outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>liable,</b> as once the handful has been removed it is fit to be burned on the altar inside the Temple, and one is liable for offering it up outside even though it is mixed into the remainder.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks about the final clause: <b>But why</b> is he liable? <b>Let</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering, which is certainly the majority of the mixture, <b>nullify the handful.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> A term of <b>burning is stated with regard to the handful</b> removed from the meal offering, <b>and</b> a term of <b>burning is stated with regard to the remainder</b> of the meal offering. With regard to the handful, referred to by the Torah as “the memorial part,” it is written: “And the priest shall burn the memorial part upon the altar” (Leviticus 2:2), and with regard to the remainder of the meal offering it is written: “Do not burn it as a fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11). This provides a verbal analogy that teaches that <b>just as</b> with regard to the <b>burning of</b> the <b>handful,</b> if two handfuls are mixed together one <b>handful does not nullify another, so too,</b> with regard to the <b>burning of</b> the <b>remainder,</b> if the remainder and the handful are mixed together, the <b>remainder does not nullify</b> the <b>handful.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The burning of both the handful and the frankincense permits the consumption of the remainder of the meal offering by the priests. With regard to <b>the handful and the frankincense,</b> in a case <b>where one sacrificed</b> only <b>one of them outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>liable. Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> from liability one who burns only one of them <b>until he</b> also <b>sacrifices the second.</b> Since the remainder of the meal offering becomes permitted only once both have been burned, he considers each one alone to be an incomplete offering, and he holds one is not liable for sacrificing only one of them. Rabbi Eliezer concedes that if one sacrificed <b>one inside</b> the courtyard <b>and one outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>liable.</b>
The burning of two bowls of frankincense permits the consumption of the shewbread. With regard to the <b>two bowls of frankincense,</b> in a case <b>where one sacrificed</b> only <b>one of them outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>liable. Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> from liability one who burns only one of them <b>until he</b> also <b>sacrifices the second,</b> since the shewbread becomes permitted only once both bowls of frankincense are burned. Rabbi Eliezer concedes that if one sacrificed <b>one inside</b> the courtyard <b>and one outside</b> the courtyard, he is <b>liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna is based on the fact that it is permitted for the priests to consume the remainder of the meal offering only once both the handful and the frankincense have been burned. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa raises a dilemma:</b> If one burned the <b>handful</b> but not the frankincense, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>whether</b> this <b>will permit</b> the consumption of <b>the corresponding</b> half <b>of the remainder?</b> Since the burning of both the handful and the frankincense permits the entire remainder, it seems that each one of them affects half of the remainder. Accordingly, it is unclear whether burning one of them will entirely <b>permit</b> half of the remainder, <b>or</b> whether it will merely <b>weaken</b> the prohibition concerning the remainder, and it will still be prohibited to eat any of it.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa raise this dilemma? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir, who says: One can render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> by having <i>piggul</i> intention <b>during half</b> of two acts that together <b>permit</b> the offering for consumption, i.e., during either one of them, then it should be obvious that the offering of the handful alone should entirely <b>permit</b> half of the remainder. The fact that Rabbi Meir holds that intention during just one of the acts can render the offering <i>piggul</i> demonstrates that he holds that each act alone has the power to permit part of the offering. It is apparent, then, the dilemma was not raised according to Rabbi Meir’s opinion.
<b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis, who say: One cannot render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> by having <i>piggul</i> intention <b>during half</b> of two acts that together <b>permit</b> the offering for consumption; rather, one must have <i>piggul</i> intention during both acts, then it is evident that neither act alone has the power to affect the offering, and so the burning of the handful alone should <b>neither permit</b> any of the remainder <b>nor weaken</b> the prohibition that applies to it. It is apparent, then, the dilemma was not raised according to the Rabbis’ opinion.
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma was raised <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> as taught in the mishna. Rabbi Eliezer rules that one who sacrifices outside only the handful or the frankincense is not liable. Evidently, he holds that neither of these alone can permit the consumption of the meal offering. The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: One cannot render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> by having <i>piggul</i> intention <b>during half</b> of two acts that together <b>permit</b> the offering for consumption. Accordingly, he would hold that the offering of only the handful neither permits any of the remainder, nor weakens the prohibition concerning it, and it would not make sense to raise the dilemma according to him.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that the dilemma was raised <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis that</b> is taught <b>here</b> in the mishna. They hold that one is liable even for sacrificing outside only the handful or only the frankincense. Evidently, they hold that each one alone has the power to affect the status of the remainder. Accordingly, Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa asked concerning a case where one of them is burned on the altar in the Temple, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Does it entirely <b>permit</b> half of the remainder, <b>or</b> does it <b>weaken</b> the prohibition concerning the entire remainder?
The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who sprinkles part of</b> the <b>blood</b> of an offering, e.g., one sprinkling instead of four, <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard

Daf 110b

is <b>liable. Rabbi Elazar says: So too, one who pours as a libation water</b> consecrated for the libation <b>of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>during the Festival, outside</b> the courtyard, is <b>liable. Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> For the <b>remainder of the blood</b> of an offering that was supposed to be poured at the base of the altar and <b>that</b> instead <b>one sacrificed outside</b> the courtyard, one is <b>liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava says:</b> Rabbi Elazar generally holds that one is liable for sacrificing outside only when he sacrifices a complete offering, <b>but Rabbi Elazar concedes with regard to</b> the sprinkling of the <b>blood</b> of an offering, that one is liable for sprinkling outside even part of the blood, e.g., one sprinkling instead of four. This is clearly the <i>halakha</i> with regard to offerings whose blood is sprinkled on the external altar, as a single sprinkling renders such an offering valid (see 36b), and it can be regarded as a complete offering. Rabbi Elazar concedes that this is the <i>halakha</i> even with regard to offerings whose blood is sprinkled on the inner altar, despite the fact that such offerings are valid only once all the sprinklings have been completed.
The fact that Rabbi Elazar concedes this point is apparent from that <b>which is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 60a) with regard to the numerous sprinklings of blood performed in the Holy of Holies, upon the Curtain, and on the inner altar, as part of the Yom Kippur Temple service: If during the sprinklings the blood spills and it is necessary to bring the blood of a second animal in order to complete them, <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon say: From the place that</b> the High Priest <b>stopped</b> sprinkling the blood of the first animal, there <b>he begins</b> to sprinkle the blood of the second animal; it is unnecessary to repeat any of the sprinklings that have already been performed. From this ruling it is apparent that each sprinkling is considered an independent and complete act of service, and one will be liable for even a single act of sprinkling done outside the Temple.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Elazar says: So too, one who pours as a libation water</b> consecrated for the libation <b>of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>during the Festival, outside</b> the courtyard, is liable. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Menaḥem Yodfa’a: Rabbi Elazar said that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, his teacher, who says: The water libation</b> on <i>Sukkot</i> is a mitzva <b>by Torah law. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> concerning the verse: “Beside the daily burnt offering, its meal offering, <b>and its libations”</b> (Numbers 29:31), the fact that the Torah makes reference to “libations” in the plural indicates that <b>the verse is speaking of two</b> types of <b>libations. One</b> is <b>the water libation,</b> which is unique to the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>; <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> is <b>the wine libation,</b> which always accompanies the daily offering. If the water libation was not a mitzva by Torah law, one would not be liable for pouring it as a libation outside the Temple courtyard.
<b>Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: If</b> Rabbi Elazar derives the mitzva of the water libation through the derivation taught by Rabbi Akiva, according to which both the wine libation and water libation are derived from the same word, then he should hold that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to wine, one is liable only if he pours <b>three <i>log</i>, so too here,</b> with regard to water, one should be liable only if he pours <b>three <i>log</i>. But</b> in the mishna, <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> simply: <b>Water of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, which seems to include any amount. Furthermore, he should hold that <b>just as</b> with regard to pouring a libation of wine outside the Temple, one is liable for pouring a libation <b>during the rest of the days of the year</b> and not only on <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>so too,</b> with regard to pouring a libation of water, one should be liable for pouring a libation <b>during the rest of the days of the year. But</b> in the mishna <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that one is liable only if he pours the water libation <b>during the Festival.</b> It is apparent that Rabbi Elazar derived the mitzva of the water libation from a different source.
<b>That which Rabbi Asi says escaped him, as Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Neḥunya, a man of the valley of Beit Ḥortan:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>ten saplings,</b> the practice of taking <b>a willow</b> in the Temple during <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>and</b> the obligation to perform <b>the water libation</b> during <i>Sukkot</i>, each of these is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b> According to Rabbi Asi, the mitzva of the water libation is not derived from the same source as the wine libation, and it is possible that there will be differences in the <i>halakhot</i> that apply to them.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who pours as a libation three <i>log</i> of water during the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>outside</b> the courtyard is <b>liable. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: If he filled</b> a service vessel with the three <i>log</i> in order to consecrate <b>them for the sake of</b> the <b>Festival,</b> he is <b>liable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> these two opinions? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: They disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>there is</b> a precise <b>measure of water</b> that can be consecrated as a libation. The first <i>tanna</i> holds that even if one fills a service vessel with more than three <i>log</i>, the water is thereby consecrated. Therefore, if one then pours at least three <i>log</i> of that water outside the courtyard, he is liable. Rabbi Elazar holds that if one attempts to consecrate more than three <i>log</i>, the consecration of the water is ineffective. Therefore, if one then pours three <i>log</i> of that water as a libation outside the courtyard, he is not liable.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b>

Daf 111a

<b>They disagree</b> with regard to whether one is liable for pouring a libation outside the courtyard that was not first consecrated in a service vessel.
