<b>Rabba said: The reason of Rabbi Shimon</b> is not based upon: “You shall not do,” as Reish Lakish claims, but upon another verse. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who slaughters</b> his <b>Paschal offering on a private altar at a time</b> when it is <b>prohibited</b> to sacrifice offerings on private <b>altars</b> violates <b>a prohibition? The verse states: “You may not sacrifice the Paschal offering</b> within any of your gates; but at the place that the Lord your God shall choose to cause His name to dwell in, there you shall sacrifice the Paschal offering” (Deuteronomy 16:5–6).
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even at a time</b> when it is <b>permitted</b> to sacrifice offerings on private <b>altars</b> this is <b>so.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Within any [<i>be’aḥad</i>] of your gates,”</b> which indicates that <b>I said</b> this prohibition <b>to you only when all of the Jewish people enter</b> the Temple <b>through one [<i>eḥad</i>] gate</b> in order to sacrifice their offerings. When there is no permanent communal altar, it is permitted to slaughter the Paschal offering on a private altar.
Rabba analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>When</b> was this Paschal offering, for which one violates a prohibition for slaughtering it during a time when it is forbidden to sacrifice on private altars, slaughtered? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>after midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, which is the proper time for sacrificing the Paschal offering in the Temple, then one who sacrifices it then violates not only a prohibition, he should also <b>be deemed liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> as well,</b> as would anyone who slaughters a fit offering outside the Temple courtyard. <b>Rather, is it not</b> discussing one who slaughtered the Paschal offering on a private altar on the fourteenth of Nisan <b>before midday,</b> when its time had not yet arrived?
The Gemara rejects Rabba’s explanation: <b>Actually,</b> the Paschal offering may have been sacrificed on a private altar <b>after midday</b> of the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>and</b> it is <b>referring to a time</b> when it is <b>permitted</b> to sacrifice on private <b>altars,</b> i.e., the periods of Gilgal, Nov, and Gibeon. The verse teaches that although it was permitted to sacrifice voluntary vow offerings and gift offerings on a private altar, the Paschal offering may be sacrificed only on a great public altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>state: At a time</b> when it is <b>prohibited</b> to sacrifice offerings on private <b>altars?</b> The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> means that it is <b>prohibited for</b> one to sacrifice the Paschal offering on a private <b>altar,</b> but it is <b>permitted</b> to use a private <b>altar for another</b> offering, i.e., a voluntary vow offering or gift offering.
§ The mishna teaches that with regard to an offering <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived because it is premature for its owner, one who sacrifices it outside the Temple courtyard is exempt. This category includes a <i>zav</i>, a <i>zava</i>, and a woman after childbirth, any of whom sacrificed a sin offering or guilt offering outside the Temple courtyard during the days that they are counting toward purification. The Gemara asks: <b>And are these</b> individuals <b>subject to</b> the obligation to bring <b>guilt offerings? Ze’eiri said:</b> The text of the mishna should <b>teach: Leper, together with</b> the <i>zav</i>, <i>zava</i>, and woman after childbirth. A leper brings a guilt offering as part of his purification process.
The mishna also teaches that if those whose time has not yet arrived sacrifice <b>their burnt offerings or their peace offerings</b> outside the Temple courtyard, they are liable. The Gemara asks: <b>And are these</b> individuals <b>subject to</b> the obligation to bring <b>peace offerings? Rav Sheshet said: Teach</b> the case of <b>a Nazirite</b> as part of the list in the mishna. A nazirite brings a peace offering at the conclusion of his term of naziriteship. The Gemara notes that the addition <b>of Ze’eiri</b> to the text of the mishna, i.e., the case of a leper, was <b>fixed</b> by <b>the <i>tanna’im</i></b> in the version of the mishna that they would teach, while the addition <b>of Rav Sheshet,</b> i.e., the case of a nazirite, was <b>not fixed</b> by <b>the <i>tanna’im</i></b> in the mishna that they would teach.
§ The mishna teaches that if one whose days of purification are not complete, e.g., a leper, slaughters his guilt offering outside the courtyard, he is exempt, since the offering is not fit for sacrifice at that time. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Ḥilkiya,</b> a Sage <b>from the school of Rav Tovi, says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to one who slaughters a guilt offering outside the Temple courtyard <b>for its own sake. But</b> if he slaughtered it outside the Temple courtyard <b>not for its own sake</b> but for the sake of a different offering, he is <b>liable</b> for having sacrificed outside the courtyard. This is <b>because</b> it was <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed <b>not for its own sake inside</b> the Temple courtyard, as a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its own sake is fit for sacrifice (see 2a).
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> one who slaughtered the guilt offering <b>for its own sake should also be liable</b> for having slaughtered it outside the Temple courtyard, <b>since</b> it was <b>fit</b> to be slaughtered <b>not for its sake inside</b> the Temple courtyard. The Gemara answers: In order for a guilt offering that was slaughtered outside the Temple courtyard to be considered fit to be sacrificed inside it, it first <b>requires uprooting</b> of its status, i.e., the one who slaughters it should intend explicitly that it be a different sacrifice. If its status as a guilt offering has not been uprooted, it is not considered fit to be sacrificed inside.
<b>Rav Huna objects to</b> Rabbi Ḥilkiya’s statement that a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived is fit to be sacrificed inside if it is slaughtered not for its own sake: <b>And is there anything that is not fit</b> if its action is performed <b>for its own sake, but is fit</b> if its action is performed <b>not for its sake?</b> The Gemara replies: <b>And</b> is there <b>not? But</b> there is

Daf 115a

the <b>Paschal offering during the rest of the days of the year,</b> i.e., not on the fourteenth of Nisan after midday, when it is fit to be sacrificed, <b>which is not fit</b> if it was sacrificed <b>for its sake, but is fit</b> if it was sacrificed <b>not for its sake.</b> The Gemara responds: The <b>Paschal offering during the rest of the days of the year is</b> considered to be <b>a peace offering,</b> not a Paschal offering that was slaughtered not for its sake.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya, who holds that one who slaughters a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived, outside the courtyard, not for its own sake, is liable: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I exclude</b> from the category of those who are liable for slaughtering outside the courtyard <b>even</b> one who slaughters <b>a burnt offering whose time has not yet</b> arrived <b>due to</b> its being premature <b>for its owner,</b> e.g., a woman after childbirth whose term of impurity is not yet finished, <b>and</b> one who slaughters <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper</b> before they are fit to sacrifice their offerings.
To counter this, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to slaughter outside the courtyard: “Whatever person there be of the house of Israel that slaughters an ox, or lamb, or goat, in the camp, or that slaughters it outside the camp” (Leviticus 17:3). <b>“Ox”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of an ox, <b>“lamb”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of a lamb, and <b>“goat”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of a goat, that one is liable for slaughtering them outside the courtyard; <b>while a sin offering</b> was <b>omitted</b> from the cases in the <i>baraita</i> where one who slaughters the offering outside the courtyard is liable.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are we dealing with</b> in this <i>baraita</i> when it discusses the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper? <b>If we say</b> that it is dealing with a guilt offering that was slaughtered outside the courtyard <b>at its</b> proper <b>time, why</b> state that one is liable <b>specifically</b> for <b>a guilt offering?</b> One would be liable for slaughtering <b>a sin offering</b> outside the courtyard at its time <b>as well. Rather,</b> it is discussing a guilt offering that was slaughtered <b>not at its time,</b> i.e., when the nazirite or leper’s time had not yet arrived.
The Gemara explains: <b>And what</b> is the <i>baraita</i> dealing <b>with? If we say</b> that it is dealing with one who slaughtered it <b>for its sake, why</b> would he be <b>liable</b> for <b>a guilt offering</b> that was slaughtered outside the courtyard if it is not fit for sacrifice? <b>Rather, is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> dealing with one who slaughtered it <b>not for its sake,</b> and the <i>baraita</i> states that one would be liable, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya? The Gemara rejects this: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with one who slaughtered a guilt offering outside the courtyard <b>at its</b> proper <b>time and not for its sake.</b>
<b>And</b> although there is ostensibly no need for an additional verse from which to derive the <i>halakha</i> in this case, as a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its sake inside the courtyard is fit for sacrifice, the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says: We juxtapose a guilt offering with a sin offering</b> in the verse: “As is the sin offering, so is the guilt offering; there is one law for them” (Leviticus 7:7), from which it may be derived that they have equivalent halakhic status. Therefore, a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its sake is disqualified, and consequently one might say that one who slaughters a guilt offering not for its sake outside the Temple courtyard is exempt, as it is not fit for sacrifice. Therefore, the derivation from the verse is necessary.
<b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught:</b> Guilt offering, which, in this context, is <b>secondary</b> to the sin offering, as it is derived from the latter. <b>But the same is true</b> of the <b>primary,</b> i.e., the sin offering: One who slaughters it outside the courtyard not for its sake is liable.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> in support of Rabbi Ḥilkiya: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I include</b> in liability even one who slaughters <b>a burnt offering whose time has not yet</b> arrived because it is <b>intrinsically</b> lacking, i.e., eight days have not yet passed; <b>and</b> one who slaughters <b>a sin offering</b> whose time has not yet arrived, <b>whether</b> because it is <b>intrinsically</b> lacking <b>or</b> because it is premature for <b>the owner.</b>
To counter this, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to one who slaughters outside the courtyard: <b>“And</b> has not brought it <b>to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 17:4), which teaches that for <b>any</b> sacrifice <b>that is unfit to be brought to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, one is not liable for</b> slaughtering it outside the courtyard. <b>But a guilt offering</b> whose time has not yet arrived was <b>omitted</b> by the <i>tanna</i>, from which it can be inferred that one who slaughters a guilt offering outside the courtyard is liable.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a case where one slaughtered a sin offering whose time has not yet arrived, outside the courtyard <b>for its sake,</b> then one who slaughters <b>a guilt offering should also be exempt,</b> as it is an offering whose time has not yet arrived. <b>Rather, is it not</b> dealing with a case of one who slaughtered a sin offering whose time has not yet arrived, outside the courtyard <b>not for its sake?</b> In this case, one would be exempt for slaughtering it outside the courtyard, as if it is slaughtered inside the courtyard not for its sake it is disqualified. But in the case of a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived one would be liable, since it is fit for sacrifice, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya.
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with one who slaughtered a sin offering whose time has not yet arrived, outside the courtyard <b>not for its sake. And</b> nevertheless, it may not be inferred that in the case of a guilt offering one would be liable, as this <i>baraita</i> may <b>be</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who juxtaposes a guilt offering with a sin offering;</b> and one who slaughters a guilt offering is also exempt. The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> omitted mention of a guilt offering because he <b>taught:</b> Sin offering, which is the <b>primary</b> case of the disqualification of an offering slaughtered not for its sake, <b>and all the more so</b> it applies <b>to</b> the <b>secondary</b> case, i.e., the guilt offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof for the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>the school of Rabbi Livai taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I exclude</b> from the category of those who are liable for slaughtering offerings outside the Temple courtyard <b>even</b> one who slaughters <b>a burnt offering whose time has not yet</b> arrived <b>due to</b> its being premature <b>for its owner,</b> or who slaughters <b>a guilt offering of a nazirite or the guilt offering of a leper</b> whose time has not yet arrived due to its being premature for its owner. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one is liable for doing so? Rav Dimi added: <b>And</b> the Sages <b>brought a derivation</b> from a verse to prove that one is <b>liable, but I do not know what</b> the derivation <b>is.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation? Ravina said</b> that it is derived from the verse cited above with regard to offerings that are slaughtered outside the courtyard, where <b>“ox”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of an ox, <b>“lamb”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of a lamb, and <b>“goat”</b> indicates <b>in any case</b> of a goat. This supports the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya, as the <i>baraita</i> is discussing a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived that is slaughtered not for its sake, and contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna. The Gemara asks: <b>What contradiction</b> is <b>this?</b> It can be resolved <b>as you stated</b> earlier: That the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its sake at the proper time, and is accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that according to the opinion of Rav Dimi, the <i>baraita</i> cannot be interpreted as dealing with a guilt offering that was slaughtered at its proper time, <b>because he raises a contradiction between</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>that the school of Rabbi Livai taught</b> and a <i>baraita</i> <b>that Levi taught: The guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper that one slaughtered not for their sakes are fit, but they do not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b>
If one <b>slaughtered them</b> in a case where the offering was <b>premature due to its owner, or</b> if the lambs <b>were in their second year</b> when one <b>slaughtered them,</b> and not in their first year as required, they <b>are disqualified,</b> and one who slaughters them outside the Temple courtyard is not liable. This contradicts the <i>baraita</i> taught by the school of Rabbi Livai.
<b>And Rav Dimi answers:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that states that one who slaughters outside the courtyard is exempt, it is referring to a case where the animal whose time has not yet arrived was slaughtered <b>for its sake; there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that teaches that one who slaughters outside the courtyard is liable, it is referring to a case where the offering was slaughtered <b>not for its sake.</b>
Likewise, <b>Rav Ashi raises a contradiction between the mishna,</b> which teaches that one who slaughters a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived outside the courtyard is exempt, <b>and the <i>baraita</i>,</b> which teaches that one who does so is liable. <b>And</b> Rav Ashi <b>answers: Here,</b> the mishna that teaches that one is exempt is referring to a case where the offering was slaughtered <b>for its sake. And there,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that teaches that one is liable is referring to a case where the offering was slaughtered <b>not for its sake,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Ḥilkiya.
The Gemara says: If so, <b>shall we say</b> that this <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Huna,</b> who holds that one who slaughters a guilt offering whose time has not yet arrived not for its sake outside the courtyard is exempt?
The Gemara replies that <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: What are we dealing with here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that deems one liable for a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its sake? We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> one <b>separated two guilt offerings as a guarantee,</b> so that atonement would be achieved through the sacrifice of the second if the first was lost, but before the proper time arrived he slaughtered one of them as a burnt offering rather than as a guilt offering. In this case there would be liability for slaughtering outside the courtyard, as is the case with one who slaughters a burnt offering outside the courtyard, <b>since one of them,</b> i.e., the one that will not effect atonement, <b>is a burnt offering from the outset.</b>

Daf 115b

This is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement that <b>Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says. As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a guilt offering</b> whose owner died or achieved atonement through a different guilt offering and which <b>was consigned to grazing</b> in the field until it develops a blemish, <b>and</b> prior to its being consigned one <b>slaughtered it without specification</b> of its purpose, it is <b>fit as a burnt offering.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>One who offers up</b> outside the Temple courtyard a portion <b>of the meat of a sin offering</b> that is eaten, or who offers up a portion of several other items, is exempt. With regard to the reasoning behind this <i>halakha</i>, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who offers up</b> outside the Temple courtyard a portion <b>of the meat of a sin offering, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of a guilt offering, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of offerings of the most sacred order, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of offerings of lesser sanctity, or</b> a portion <b>of the surplus of the <i>omer</i> offering, or the two loaves, or the shewbread, or the remainder of meal offerings</b> is <b>exempt,</b> as all these are eaten by the priests and not sacrificed on the altar?
<b>The verse states</b> with regard to the prohibition against sacrificing outside the Temple courtyard: “Whatever man…that sacrifices <b>a burnt offering</b> or sacrifice, and brings it not to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, to sacrifice it to the Lord, that man shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 17:8–9). The term “burnt offering” teaches: <b>Just as a burnt offering is fit for offering up</b> upon the altar, <b>so too, anything that is fit for offering up</b> is included in the prohibition. All of the offerings listed in the <i>baraita</i> are not sacrificed upon the altar but given to the priests.
<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that even</b> with regard to <b>one who pours</b> oil onto the meal offering, <b>and one who mixes</b> the oil into the flour of the meal offering, <b>and one who breaks</b> the loaves of the meal offering into pieces, <b>and one who salts</b> the meal offering or other offerings, <b>and one who waves</b> the meal offering, <b>and one who brings</b> the meal offering to the corner of an altar that he constructs outside the courtyard, <b>and one who arranges</b> the shewbread on <b>the table</b> outside the Sanctuary, <b>and one who removes the ashes</b> from <b>the lamps</b> of the Candelabrum, <b>and one who removes a handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>and one who collects the blood</b> of an offering in a vessel, if he did so <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard he is <b>exempt.</b>
<b>The verse states: “That sacrifices a burnt offering or sacrifice”</b> (Leviticus 17:8). <b>Just as sacrificing is the conclusion of</b> the sacri-ficial <b>service, so too, any</b> rite <b>that is the conclusion of</b> a sacrificial <b>service</b> is included. All of these are excluded from the prohibition, as there are rites that follow them.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Until the Tabernacle was established,</b> private altars were permitted and the sacrificial service was performed by the firstborn. The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Huna bar Rav Ketina was sitting before Rav Ḥisda and was reading</b> this verse with regard to the revelation at Sinai: <b>“And he sent the young men of the children of Israel,</b> who offered burnt offerings and sacrificed peace offerings of oxen to the Lord” (Exodus 24:5). The young men referred to in the verse were the firstborn of the Jewish people. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rabbi Asi said: They sacrificed</b> the offerings <b>and</b> then <b>ceased</b> to serve; after that day, the firstborn no longer performed the sacrificial service.
Rav Huna <b>thought to raise a contradiction from the mishna,</b> which states that the firstborn performed not only the sacrificial service on that day, but also did so until the Tabernacle was established the following year. In the meanwhile, <b>he heard</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>say in the name of Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> that the <b>burnt offering that the</b> children of <b>Israel sacrificed in the wilderness</b> before the establishment of the Tabernacle <b>did not require flaying</b> of the skin <b>and cutting</b> into pieces; it was sacrificed as it was. He therefore <b>raised the contradiction</b> from <b>a <i>baraita</i> that is equal with regard to both of them,</b> i.e., from which Rav Huna could raise a contradiction to both of Rav Ḥisda’s statements.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until the Tabernacle was established,</b> private <b>altars</b> were <b>permitted, the</b> sacrificial <b>service</b> was performed <b>by the firstborn, and all</b> animals were <b>fit to be sacrificed: A domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird; males and females; unblemished and blemished</b> animals. All animal sacrifices were brought from animals and birds that were <b>kosher, but not</b> from <b>non-kosher</b> species.
<b>And all</b> offerings brought before the construction of the Tabernacle were <b>sacrificed</b> as <b>burnt offerings. And</b> the <b>burnt offering that the Jewish people sacrificed in the wilderness</b> before the Tabernacle was established <b>required flaying</b> of the skin <b>and cutting</b> into pieces. <b>And today, gentiles are permitted to</b> sacrifice offerings on private altars. The <i>baraita</i> states explicitly that until the Tabernacle was constructed, the sacrificial service was performed by the firstborn, and the burnt offering required flaying and cutting.
Rav Ḥisda replied that with regard to the firstborn, it <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: God said to Moses on Mount Sinai: <b>“And let the priests also that come near to the Lord sanctify themselves,</b> lest the Lord break forth upon them” (Exodus 19:22). In other words, they should separate themselves and not approach the mountain. This command was given one day after the burnt offerings and peace offerings were sacrificed in anticipation of the revelation at Sinai. With regard to this command, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says: This</b> command is a reference to <b>the separation of</b> the <b>firstborn,</b> as they functioned as priests. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: This</b> command is a reference to <b>the separation of Nadav and Avihu,</b> who were priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the command for the priests to sanctify themselves is referring to <b>the separation of Nadav and Avihu, this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> after their death on the eighth day of the inauguration of the Tabernacle: “Then Moses said to Aaron: <b>This is it that the Lord spoke, saying: Through them that are near to Me I will be sanctified…</b>and Aaron held his peace” (Leviticus 10:3). Nadav and Avihu had already been warned not to draw too close: “Lest the Lord break forth upon them.”
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that the command for the priests to sanctify themselves is referring to <b>the separation of</b> the <b>firstborn, where is the allusion</b> to the fact that God would be sanctified through Nadav and Avihu? The Gemara replies: <b>As it is written: “And there I will meet with the children of Israel; and it shall be sanctified by My glory”</b> (Exodus 29:43). <b>Do not read</b> it as <b>“by My glory [<i>bikhvodi</i>]”; rather,</b> read it as: <b>By My honored ones [<i>bimekhubadai</i>].</b> God will be sanctified by those considered honored by God when He reveals Himself in the Tabernacle.
<b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said this statement to Moses, but</b> Moses <b>did not know</b> its meaning <b>until the sons of Aaron died. Once the sons of Aaron died,</b> Moses <b>said to him: Aaron, my brother, your sons died only to sanctify the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He. When Aaron knew that his sons were beloved by the Omnipresent, he was silent and received a reward, as it is stated: “And Aaron held his peace [<i>vayidom</i>].”</b>
<b>And likewise in</b> a verse written by <b>David</b> it <b>states: “Resign yourself [<i>dom</i>] to the Lord, and wait patiently [<i>vehitḥolel</i>] for Him”</b> (Psalms 37:7). <b>Although He strikes down many corpses [<i>ḥalalim</i>]</b> around <b>you, you be silent</b> and do not complain. <b>And likewise in</b> a verse written by <b>Solomon</b> it <b>states: “A time to keep silence, and a time to speak”</b> (Ecclesiastes 3:7). There are <b>times that</b> one <b>is silent and receives reward for the silence,</b> and at <b>times</b> one <b>speaks and receives reward for the speech.</b>
<b>And this is what Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Awesome is God out of your holy places”</b> (Psalms 68:36)? <b>Do not read</b> it as: <b>“From your holy places [<i>mimikdashekha</i>]”; rather,</b> read it as: <b>From your holy ones [<i>mimekudashekha</i>]. When the Holy One, Blessed be He, carries out judgment upon His holy ones, He is feared, and exalted, and praised</b> by all. In any event, there is no contradiction from the <i>baraita</i> which teaches that the first-born performed the sacrificial service before the Tabernacle was established, as this matter is the subject of a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>.
<b>But</b> there is still <b>a difficulty</b> with regard to the <b>burnt offering,</b> as it was stated in the name of Rav Adda bar Ahava that the burnt offering that the Jewish people sacrificed in the wilderness did not require flaying of the skin or cutting into pieces, while the <i>baraita</i> states that it did. The Gemara replies: This <b>is</b> a dispute between the opinions of <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> The <b>general statements,</b> i.e., the principles of the Torah, <b>were said at Sinai, and</b> the <b>details</b> of the mitzvot that are explicated in Leviticus were said to Moses <b>in the Tent of Meeting.</b> This includes the <i>halakha</i> that the burnt offering must be flayed and cut into pieces. Consequently, it could not have been in effect before the construction of the Tabernacle.
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Both <b>general statements and</b> the <b>details</b> of mitzvot <b>were said at Sinai and</b> later <b>taught again in the Tent of Meeting, and</b> taught <b>a third time</b> by Moses to the Jewish people <b>in the plains of Moab,</b> when he taught the Torah to the people (see Deuteronomy 1:1). According to Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, the <i>halakha</i> of flaying and cutting into pieces was in effect when the Torah was given, even before the construction of the Tabernacle.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: Before the Tabernacle was established, <b>all</b> animals were <b>fit to be sacrificed:</b> A domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Huna said: As the verse states</b> with regard to the offering that was sacrificed after the flood: <b>“And Noah built an altar to the Lord, and took of every pure animal, and of every pure fowl,</b> and offered burnt offerings on the altar” (Genesis 8:20). The Gemara explains: <b>“Animal [<i>behema</i>],”</b> is understood <b>in accordance with its plain meaning,</b> a domesticated animal, and the same is true of fowl; <b>an undomesticated animal [<i>ḥayya</i>]</b> is <b>included in</b> the term <b>“<i>behema</i>”</b> that is stated in the verse.

Daf 116a

That which was taught in the <i>baraita</i>: All animals were fit to be sacrificed: <b>Males and females, unblemished and blemished</b> animals, pertains to <b>that</b> which <b>the Master said</b> as a principle concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of sacrifices: The requirements that an offering must have <b>unblemished status and</b> that a burnt offering must have <b>male status</b> apply <b>to animal</b> offerings, <b>but</b> the requirements of <b>unblemished status and male status</b> do <b>not</b> apply <b>to birds.</b>
<b>And</b> in the verses that recount Noah’s sacrifices upon exiting the ark, <b>a domesticated animal is juxtaposed with a bird,</b> in the verse: “Of every pure animal, and of every pure fowl” (Genesis 8:20), which teaches that kosher animals had a status identical to that of birds, and could be sacrificed whether male or female, unblemished or blemished.
The Gemara adds: That which was taught in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Unblemished and blemished</b> animals, serves <b>to exclude</b> animals that are <b>lacking a limb, which</b> were <b>not</b> fit for sacrifice. As <b>Rabbi Elazar says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> an animal that is <b>lacking a limb is forbidden to the descendants of Noah,</b> i.e., gentiles, to be used as a sacrifice? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to Noah: <b>“And of every living being of all flesh,</b> two of every sort shall you bring into the ark” (Genesis 6:19). With regard to the phrase: “And of every living being,” which is superfluous, <b>the Torah stated: Bring an animal whose limbs are</b> all <b>living,</b> not one lacking a limb, as that animal is disqualified from sacrifice.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> this phrase: “And of every living being,” serves <b>to exclude an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]</b> from being fit as a sacrifice. The Gemara explains: The disqualification of a <i>tereifa</i> <b>is derived from</b> the phrase: <b>“To keep seed alive”</b> (Genesis 7:3), as a <i>tereifa</i> cannot propagate.
The Gemara challenges: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> cannot give birth.</b> In this case the disqualification of the <i>tereifa</i> is derived from the verse: “To keep seed alive,” while the disqualification of the animal lacking a limb is derived from the verse: “And of every living being.” <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can give birth, what can be said?</b> According to this opinion, a <i>tereifa</i> cannot be excluded by the phrase: “To keep seed alive.” The Gemara explains: <b>Doesn’t the verse state</b> with regard to the animals that were brought by Noah into the ark: “You shall bring into the ark, to keep them alive <b>with you”</b> (Genesis 6:19)? The term “with you” indicates that the verse is stated <b>with regard to</b> animals that are <b>similar to you,</b> not a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps Noah himself was a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> If so, one cannot exclude a <i>tereifa</i> from the comparison of animals to Noah. The Gemara answers: <b>It is written about</b> Noah that he was <b>“complete”</b> (Genesis 6:9), which indicates that he was physically whole and unblemished. The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> the verse means that <b>his ways were complete,</b> and it is not referring to Noah’s physical attributes. The Gemara explains: <b>It is</b> already <b>written about him</b> that he was <b>“righteous”</b> (Genesis 6:9), which means that his actions were perfect. Consequently, when the verse says that he was also complete, it must be referring to his body.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> the verse means that Noah was <b>complete in his manner,</b> and he was <b>righteous in his</b> good <b>deeds.</b> Accordingly, the verse would not exclude the possibility that Noah himself was a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>If it enters your mind</b> to say <b>that Noah himself was a <i>tereifa</i>, would the Merciful One have said to him: Bring in</b> <i>tereifot</i> <b>like you</b> to the ark, but <b>do not bring in whole</b> and perfect animals? It is not reasonable to say that there would be a preference for him to bring <i>tereifot</i>. Rather, Noah was certainly not a <i>tereifa</i>, and the fact that a <i>tereifa</i> is disqualified for sacrifice is derived from “with you.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And once we derive</b> the disqualification of a <i>tereifa</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>“with you,” why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“to keep seed alive”?</b> The Gemara answers: If one could derive only from <b>“with you,” you would say</b> that Noah brought the animals to the ark <b>only for</b> the purpose of <b>companionship,</b> and therefore <b>even</b> an animal that is <b>old</b> or <b>even one who is castrated</b> can come into the ark, provided that it is not a <i>tereifa</i>. Therefore, the Merciful One writes: “To keep seed alive,” which <b>teaches us</b> that only animals that can bear offspring were allowed to be brought into the ark.
§ The <i>baraita</i> also teaches that before the Tabernacle was constructed, sacrifices were brought from animals and birds that were <b>kosher, but not</b> from <b>non-kosher</b> species. This is based on the verse that describes what Noah sacrificed when he exited the ark: “And he took of every pure animal and of every pure fowl and offered burnt offerings on the altar” (Genesis 8:20). The Gemara asks: <b>And were there pure and impure</b> species <b>at that time,</b> during the period of Noah? The distinction between pure, i.e., kosher species, and impure, i.e., non-kosher species, was introduced only after the Torah was given (see Leviticus, chapter 11). <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> The pure animals that Noah took were <b>from those that had not been used in the performance of sin.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where did</b> Noah and his sons <b>know</b> which animals had been used in the performance of a sin, in order to prevent them from entering the ark? The Gemara answers that it is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda. As Rav Ḥisda says:</b> Noah caused all of the animals to <b>pass before the ark. All</b> animals <b>that the ark accepted,</b> i.e., drew in, was <b>known to be pure;</b> if <b>the ark did not accept them,</b> it was <b>known that they</b> were <b>impure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> there is a different explanation as to how Noah knew which animals were pure or impure. <b>The verse states: “And they that went in,</b> went in <b>male and female</b> of all flesh” (Genesis 7:16), which means: Those <b>that went in on their own.</b> Consequently, Noah did not need to distinguish between pure and impure animals, as only the pure ones approached.
§ In describing the sacrificial service before the Tabernacle was constructed, <b>the Master said: And all</b> offerings brought before the construction of the Tabernacle were <b>sacrificed</b> as <b>burnt offerings.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Burnt offerings, yes,</b> were sacrificed, but <b>peace offerings</b> were <b>not</b> sacrificed. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> with regard to the offerings that were sacrificed at Mount Sinai at the time of the giving of the Torah, <b>it is written:</b> “And they offered burnt offerings, <b>and sacrificed peace offerings of oxen to the Lord”</b> (Exodus 24:5). This event occurred prior to the construction of the Tabernacle. <b>Rather, say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>All</b> offerings <b>sacrificed</b> were either <b>burnt offerings or peace offerings.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And isn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>But peace offerings</b> were <b>not</b> sacrificed before the construction of the Tabernacle; <b>rather, only burnt offerings</b> were sacrificed? Clearly, <b>burnt offerings, yes,</b> were sacrificed, but <b>peace offerings</b> were <b>not</b> sacrificed. The Gemara answers that this <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that <b>peace offerings were not sacrificed</b> by the <b>descendants of Noah. As it was stated</b> that there is a dispute between <b>Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina</b> with regard to this: <b>One says</b> that <b>the descendants of Noah sacrificed peace offerings, and one says</b> that <b>they did not sacrifice</b> peace offerings.
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>What is the reasoning of the one who says</b> that <b>the descendants of Noah sacrificed peace offerings? As it is written: “And Abel, he also brought of the firstborn of his flock and of the fat thereof”</b> (Genesis 4:4). Abel, like all gentiles, is categorized as a descendant of Noah. The verse emphasizes that the fat was sacrificed. The Gemara analyzes: <b>What is an item,</b> i.e., an offering, <b>the fat of which is sacrificed upon the altar, but</b> that <b>is not sacrificed in its entirety upon the altar? You must say: This is the peace offering,</b> the meat of which is consumed.
<b>What is the reasoning of the one who says</b> that <b>they did not sacrifice</b> peace offerings? <b>As it is written: “Awake [<i>uri</i>], O north; and come, south…</b>Let my beloved come into his garden, and eat his precious fruits” (Song of Songs 4:16). The Gemara interprets this homiletically: The <b>nation,</b> i.e., the nations of the world, who are the descendants of Noah, <b>whose acts,</b> i.e., sacrifices, are only <b>in the north,</b> i.e., they sacrifice only burnt offerings, which are slaughtered and their blood collected in the north of the Temple courtyard, <b>shall be removed [<i>titna’er</i>], and</b> in its place <b>shall come</b> the Jewish <b>nation, whose acts,</b> i.e., sacrifices, are <b>in the north and in the south,</b> as they sacrifice burnt offerings, whose rites are performed in the north, and peace offerings, whose rites may also be performed in the south, as the entire courtyard is fit for their rites.
The Gemara asks: <b>And also</b> according to <b>the Master</b> who holds that the descendants of Noah did not sacrifice peace offerings, <b>isn’t it written: “And of the fat thereof,”</b> from which it may be derived that Abel sacrificed a peace offering? The Gemara answers: “The fat thereof,” does not mean that Abel sacrificed only the fats of his offerings; rather, it means that he sacrificed <b>the fattest of them,</b> i.e., the fattest and choicest of his animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>And also</b> according to <b>the Master</b> who holds that the descendants of Noah did sacrifice peace offerings, <b>isn’t it written: “Awake, O north,”</b> from which it may be derived that the nations of the world do not sacrifice peace offerings? The Gemara answers: In his opinion, <b>that</b> verse <b>is written with regard to the ingathering of the exiles,</b> i.e., the Jewish exiles will come from the north and the south.
With regard to the opinion that the descendants of Noah did not sacrifice peace offerings, the Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written: “And Moses said: You must also give into our hand sacrifices [<i>zevaḥim</i>] and burnt offerings, that we may sacrifice to the Lord our God”</b> (Exodus 10:25)? This indicates that sacrifices [<i>zevaḥim</i>], i.e., peace offerings, were sacrificed before the Torah was given. The Gemara answers: In this context, <b>“<i>zevaḥim</i>”</b> is referring to animals to be used <b>for consumption,</b> as the word <i>zevaḥ</i> can also be translated as an animal for slaughter, <b>and “burnt offerings”</b> is referring to animals to be used <b>for sacrifice.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> before the giving of the Torah: <b>“And Yitro, Moses’ father-in-law, took a burnt offering and sacrifices [<i>zevaḥim</i>]</b> for God” (Exodus 18:12)? Since the word <i>zevaḥim</i> there is referring to sacrifices, as the verse clearly states that Yitro took them for God, evidently peace offerings were sacrificed before the giving of the Torah. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>was written</b> with regard to the period <b>after the giving of the Torah,</b> when the Jewish people were permitted to sacrifice peace offerings.
The Gemara notes: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that the episode with <b>Yitro was after the giving of the Torah. But according to the one who says</b> that the episode with <b>Yitro was before the giving of the Torah, what can be said? As it was stated: The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> engage in a dispute concerning this issue. <b>One says</b> that the episode with <b>Yitro was before the giving of the Torah, and one says</b> that the episode with <b>Yitro was after the giving of the Torah.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The one who says</b> that the episode with <b>Yitro was before the giving of the Torah maintains</b> that <b>the descendants of Noah did sacrifice peace offerings.</b>
§ The Gemara notes that the disagreement between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to when Yitro came to Mount Sinai is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b> The Torah states with regard to Yitro, before he came to Mount Sinai: <b>“Now Yitro, the priest of Midian, Moses’ father-in-law, heard</b> of all that God had done for Moses, and for Israel His people, how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt” (Exodus 18:1). <b>What tiding did he hear that he came and converted? Rabbi Yehoshua says: He heard</b> about <b>the war with Amalek, as it is written adjacent to</b> the verses that state that Yitro came: <b>“And Joshua weakened Amalek and his people with the edge of the sword”</b> (Exodus 17:13).
<b>Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i says: He heard</b> about <b>the giving of the Torah and came. As when the Torah was given to the Jewish people, the voice of</b> the Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>went from</b> one <b>end of the world to the</b> other <b>end, and all of the kings of the nations of the world were overcome with trembling in their palaces and recited a song</b> of praise, <b>as it is stated:</b> “The voice of the Lord makes the hinds to calve…<b>and in his palace all say: Glory”</b> (Psalms 29:9), i.e., each king in his own palace recited songs of praise to God.
At that time, <b>all of</b> the kings <b>gathered around Balaam the wicked,</b> who was the greatest gentile prophet, <b>and said to him: What is the tumultuous sound,</b> i.e., the loud noise, <b>that we have heard? Perhaps a flood is coming to</b> destroy <b>the world, as it is stated: “The Lord sat enthroned at the flood”</b> (Psalms 29:10)? Balaam <b>said to them: “The Lord sits as King forever”</b> (Psalms 29:10), which means that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, already took an oath</b> after the flood <b>never to bring a flood to the world,</b> as it is stated: “And the waters shall no more become a flood” (Genesis 9:15).
The kings <b>said to him: He will not bring a flood of water,</b> as he vowed, <b>but</b> perhaps <b>He will bring a flood of fire,</b> as in the future the Lord will punish the nations with fire, <b>as it is stated: “For by fire will the Lord contend,</b> and by His sword with all flesh; and the slain of the Lord shall be many” (Isaiah 66:16). Balaam <b>said to them: He already took an oath that He will not destroy all flesh</b> in any manner, as it is stated: “To destroy all flesh” (Genesis 9:15). Therefore, there will not be a flood of fire.
They asked: <b>And</b> if so, <b>what is this tumultuous sound that we have heard?</b> Balaam <b>said to them: He has a good</b> and <b>precious item in His treasury, that was hidden away with Him</b> for <b>974 generations before the world was created, and He seeks to give it to his children, as it is stated: “The Lord will give strength to His people”</b> (Psalms 29:11). “Strength” is a reference to the Torah, which is the strength of the Jewish people. <b>Immediately, they all began to say: “The Lord will bless His people with peace”</b> (Psalms 29:11).
The Gemara offers another explanation of what Yitro heard: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He heard</b> about <b>the splitting of the Red Sea and came, as it is stated</b> in a similar context with regard to the splitting of the Jordan in the days of Joshua: <b>“And it came to pass, when all the kings of the Amorites,</b> that were beyond the Jordan westward, and all the kings of the Canaanites, that were by the sea, <b>heard</b> how that the Lord had dried up the waters of the Jordan from before the children of Israel, until they were passed over, that their heart melted, neither was there spirit in them anymore, because of the children of Israel” (Joshua 5:1). <b>And even Rahab the prostitute said to Joshua’s messengers: “For we have heard how the Lord dried up the water of the Red Sea</b> before you” (Joshua 2:10).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different there,</b> i.e., with regard to the splitting of the Jordan, <b>where</b> the verse <b>states: “Neither was there spirit in them anymore,” and what is different here,</b> i.e., in the statement of Rahab, <b>where</b> the verse <b>states: “Neither did there remain [<i>kama</i>] any more spirit in any man”</b> (Joshua 2:11)?

Daf 116b

The Gemara replies that Rahab used this phrase euphemistically, to say that their fear was so great <b>that</b> their male organs <b>were not even</b> able to <b>become erect,</b> as “<i>kama</i>” also means rise. The Gemara asks: <b>And how did</b> Rahab <b>know</b> this? The Gemara replies: <b>As the Master said: You do not have any prince or ruler</b> at that time <b>who did not engage in intercourse with Rahab the prostitute.</b>
The Gemara adds that the Sages <b>said</b> with regard to Rahab: <b>She was ten years old when the Jewish people left Egypt, and she engaged in prostitution all forty years that the Jewish people were in the wilderness. After</b> that, when she was <b>fifty years</b> old, she <b>converted</b> when the two spies visited her. <b>She said: May</b> all of my sins of prostitution <b>be forgiven me as a reward</b> for having endangered myself with the <b>rope, window, and flax,</b> by means of which I saved Joshua’s two spies. Rahab first concealed the spies in stalks of flax, and later assisted them in exiting her home by lowering them from the window with a rope (see Joshua 2:6 and 2:15).
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that discussed the sacrifice of offerings before the construction of the Tabernacle: <b>And today gentiles are permitted to do so,</b> i.e., to sacrifice offerings outside the Temple courtyard, despite the fact that this is forbidden for the Jews. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught</b> with regard to the verses that prohibit the slaughter of offerings outside the Temple: <b>“Speak</b> to Aaron, and to his sons, and <b>to</b> all <b>the children of Israel”</b> (Leviticus 17:2). This indicates that only <b>Jews are commanded with regard to</b> offerings <b>slaughtered outside</b> the Temple, <b>but gentiles are not commanded with regard to</b> offerings <b>slaughtered outside</b> the Temple.
<b>Therefore, each and every</b> gentile may, if he desires, <b>construct</b> a private <b>altar for himself, and sacrifice upon it whatever he desires. Rabbi Ya’akov bar Aḥa says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says:</b> Although it is permitted for gentiles to sacrifice offerings outside the Temple courtyard, it is <b>prohibited</b> for a Jew <b>to assist them or to fulfill their agency</b> in this matter, as sacrificing in this manner is forbidden for a Jew. <b>Rabba said: But to instruct them</b> how to sacrifice outside the Temple is <b>permitted.</b>
This is <b>similar to that</b> incident in <b>which Ifera Hurmiz, the mother of King Shapur</b> of Persia, <b>sent an offering to Rava,</b> with which <b>she sent</b> this message <b>to him: Sacrifice this for me, for the sake of Heaven.</b> Rava <b>said to Rav Safra and to Rav Aḥa bar Huna: Go, take two</b> gentile <b>youths of the same age,</b> i.e., similar to one another, so that the sacrifice will be performed with maximal beauty, <b>and see where the sea</b> currently <b>raises silt [<i>sirton</i>],</b> which is a place that no one has used before. <b>And take new wood and bring out fire from new vessels, and</b> the two youths will <b>sacrifice</b> the offering <b>for her, for the sake of Heaven.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was the instruction to sacrifice exclusively with new wood? Was it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua says: Just as</b> the <b>altar</b> is a place <b>that is not used by an ordinary</b> person, <b>so too,</b> the <b>wood</b> that will be used <b>must not be used by an ordinary</b> person. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua concede</b> that <b>in</b> the case of a private <b>altar</b> the wood need not be new?
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to David’s purchase of the site of the Temple, when he wished to build an altar there at God’s instruction, <b>one verse states: “So David gave to Ornan for the place six hundred shekels of gold by weight.</b> And David built there an altar to the Lord, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings” (I Chronicles 21:25–26). <b>And it is written</b> elsewhere: <b>“So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.</b> And David built there an altar to the Lord, and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings” (II Samuel 24:24–25). <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled?
David would <b>collect from each tribe</b> of the twelve tribes <b>fifty</b> shekels, <b>which are</b> a sum of <b>six hundred</b> shekels. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says in the name of Abba Yosei ben Dostai</b> that there is another explanation: David purchased the <b>cattle and</b> the <b>wood and the site of</b> the <b>altar for fifty</b> shekels, <b>and</b> he purchased the site of <b>the entire Temple for six hundred</b> shekels.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua says</b> likewise: David purchased the <b>cattle and</b> the <b>wood and the site of</b> the <b>altar for fifty</b> shekels, <b>and</b> the site of <b>the entire Temple for six hundred</b> shekels, <b>as it is written: “And Araunah said to David: Let my lord the king take and offer that which is good in his eyes; see the cattle for the burnt offering, and the threshing tools, and the implements of the cattle for the wood”</b> (II Samuel 24:22), to which David replied: “No, but I will buy it from you at a price” (II Samuel 24:24). Consequently, according to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua, David purchased the threshing instruments and the furniture of the oxen for use as wood. <b>And Rava</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response: <b>There too,</b> in the case of David, the verse is dealing <b>with new</b> vessels that had not yet been used.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> are <b>“the threshing instruments [<i>morigim</i>]”</b> mentioned in the verse? <b>Ulla said:</b> It is <b>a <i>turbal</i> bed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is <b>a <i>turbal</i> bed? Abaye said:</b> It is <b>a heavy, serrated board [<i>dekurkesa</i>],</b> used <b>for threshing. Abaye said: What is the verse</b> from which the meaning of <i>morigim</i> is derived? <b>“Behold, I have made you a new threshing board [<i>morag</i>] having sharp teeth; you shall thresh the mountains, and beat them small, and shall make the hills as chaff”</b> (Isaiah 41:15). This verse indicates that a <i>morag</i> has grooves and teeth, and is used for threshing.
With regard to the contradiction between the verses that relate the sum of shekels paid by David, the Gemara says that <b>Rava</b> was <b>teaching</b> these verses <b>to his son, and raised a contradiction between verses: It is written: “So David gave to Ornan…</b>six hundred shekels of gold by weight” (I Chronicles 21:25), <b>and it is written: “So David bought…</b>fifty shekels of silver” (II Samuel 24:24). <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? David would <b>collect from each tribe</b> of the twelve tribes <b>fifty</b> shekels, <b>which are</b> a sum of <b>six hundred</b> shekels.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> these verses <b>are still difficult,</b> as they contradict <b>one another,</b> since <b>there</b> in the book of Samuel it is stated that David paid <b>silver</b> shekels, while <b>here</b> in Chronicles it is stated that he paid <b>gold</b> shekels. The Gemara replies: <b>Rather, this</b> is what the verses are <b>saying:</b> David would <b>collect</b> from each tribe <b>silver</b> shekels that had the value of fifty gold shekels in weight, so that the value of the final sum was equal to <b>six hundred gold</b> shekels.
§ The mishna teaches that once the Tabernacle was established in the wilderness, <b>offerings of lesser sanctity</b> were <b>eaten throughout the camp of Israel. Rav Huna says:</b> This means that offerings of lesser sanctity were eaten <b>in any</b> of the <b>places</b> that <b>an Israelite</b> would be found. <b>But there was no</b> actual <b>camp,</b> outside of which it was prohibited to eat the offerings.
<b>Rav Naḥman raised an objection to Rav Huna: And were there not camps</b> when the Jews were <b>in the wilderness? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Kelim Bava Kamma</i> 1:12): <b>Just as</b> there was <b>a camp in the wilderness</b> that was divided into different sections, with each section having particular <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to the consumption of offerings and to the ritually impure individuals who were prohibited from entering there, <b>so too,</b> there is a corresponding <b>camp in Jerusalem:</b> The area <b>from</b> the walls of <b>Jerusalem to the Temple Mount</b> has the status of <b>the Israelite camp.</b> The area <b>from the Temple Mount to Nicanor’s Gate</b> at the entrance to the Temple courtyard has the status of <b>the Levite camp.</b>
<b>From that</b> point <b>onward,</b> i.e., from the entrance to the Temple courtyard, the area has the status of <b>the camp of the Divine Presence; and</b> the Temple courtyard has the same status as the area within <b>the curtains</b> surrounding the courtyard of the Tabernacle <b>in the wilderness.</b>
The Gemara replies: <b>Rather, say</b> that Rav Huna meant that when the Tabernacle was in the wilderness, offerings of lesser sanctity could be consumed <b>wherever the Israelite camp</b> was located. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious?</b> Wherever the Jews were located in the wilderness was where the Israelite camp was. The Gemara responds: <b>Lest you say</b> that during the periods of travel between encampments the offerings were taken outside the Israelite camp, and <b>were</b> thereby <b>disqualified due to</b> the meat’s <b>leaving</b> the area within the partitions, Rav Huna <b>teaches us</b> that the meat is not disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that this is <b>indeed so,</b> i.e., that the meat is disqualified because it left the camp? The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “Then the Tent of Meeting,</b> with the camp of the Levites, <b>shall travel</b> in the midst of the camps; as they encamp, so shall they travel” (Numbers 2:17), which indicates that <b>although it traveled</b> from its place <b>it is</b> still <b>the Tent of Meeting.</b> Similarly, the Israelite camp retains its status even while traveling.
§ With regard to the division of Jerusalem into three camps, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: There was an additional</b> camp in Jerusalem, within the area of the Temple Mount, <b>and it</b> was <b>the rampart of the women’s courtyard.</b> The Sages rendered it prohibited for certain ritually impure individuals to enter that area, <b>but they would not punish</b> them <b>for</b> entering <b>it,</b> as by Torah law it does not constitute a distinct section of the Temple Mount but has the status of the Levite camp. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And</b> when the Tabernacle was <b>in Shiloh there were only two camps.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which of</b> the three camps that were present in the wilderness <b>was not</b> present in Shiloh? <b>Rabba said: It stands to reason that the Levite camp was</b> present, but the Israelite camp was not. <b>As, if it enters your mind to say</b> that <b>the Levite camp was not</b> present in Shiloh,

Daf 117a

it would consequently be <b>found</b> that both <b><i>zavim</i> and</b> those who are <b>ritually impure</b> from impurity imparted by <b>a corpse are sent out of one camp,</b> i.e., the camp of the Divine Presence, and both are permitted in the Israelite camp. <b>But the Torah said</b> with regard to sending the ritually impure out of the camp: “Outside the camp you shall put them; <b>that they will not defile their camps”</b> (Numbers 5:3).
The use of the plural “camps” indicates: <b>Give</b> a specific <b>camp to this</b> group, i.e., those who are ritually impure from impurity imparted by a corpse, who may enter the Levite camp but are forbidden to enter the camp of the Divine Presence, <b>and</b> give a specific <b>camp to this</b> group, i.e., those who are <i>zavim</i>, who may enter the Israelite camp but are forbidden to enter the camp of the Divine presence or the Levite camp. If there were no Levite camp in Shiloh, it would follow that both a <i>zav</i> and one who is ritually impure from the impurity imparted by a corpse are sent out of only one camp, and there is no distinction between them.
<b>Rava said to him: Rather, what</b> would you say instead? Would you say that <b>the Israelite camp was not</b> present in Shiloh? If so, it would be <b>found</b> that <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers are</b> both <b>sent to one place,</b> i.e., outside the Levite camp. <b>But the Torah said</b> with regard to the leper: <b>“He shall dwell alone;</b> outside the camp shall his dwelling be” (Leviticus 13:46). The word “alone” teaches <b>that another ritually impure person should not dwell with him.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>actually, all three</b> camps <b>were</b> present in Shiloh, <b>and what</b> is the meaning of that which was taught with regard to Shiloh: <b>There were only two camps?</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the fact that the Levite camp did not provide <b>refuge</b> to one who unintentionally killed another. The Gemara asks: <b>By inference,</b> does this mean <b>that in the wilderness the Levite camp did provide refuge</b> to those who unintentionally killed others?
The Gemara replies: <b>Yes, and so it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse concerning the cities of refuge. The verse states: “And one who did not lie in wait…<b>and I will appoint for you a place</b> where he may flee” (Exodus 21:13). The phrase “I will appoint for you” teaches that God said to Moses: There will be a place that provides refuge for unintentional murderers even <b>during your lifetime.</b> The term <b>“a place”</b> means that it will be from <b>your place,</b> meaning the Levite camp served as the place that provided refuge in the wilderness. <b>“Where he may flee” teaches that</b> the Jews <b>would exile</b> unintentional murderers <b>in the wilderness</b> as well, before they entered the land. <b>To where did they exile</b> unintentional murderers when they were in the wilderness? They exiled them <b>to the Levite camp,</b> which provided refuge.
<b>From here</b> the Sages <b>said: A Levite who killed</b> unintentionally <b>is exiled from</b> one Levite <b>city to</b> another Levite <b>city. And if he was exiled to</b> another area within <b>his city, he is admitted to his city,</b> i.e., it provides him with refuge.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the verse</b> from which the principle is derived that one who was already exiled to a city of refuge and who then killed another person is exiled to another area in that same city? <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, says</b> that the verse: <b>“For in his city of refuge he shall dwell”</b> (Numbers 35:28), indicates that he can be exiled to <b>a city in which he was already admitted,</b> as the verse is referring to it as his city, and he shall continue to reside there.
§ The mishna teaches that when the Jewish people <b>arrived at Gilgal</b> private altars were permitted. The Gemara elaborates: <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Any</b> offering that was brought due to <b>a vow, or contributed</b> voluntarily, <b>was sacrificed on</b> a private <b>altar;</b> and <b>any</b> offering <b>that is neither</b> brought due to <b>a vow nor contributed</b> voluntarily, but rather is compulsory, was <b>not sacrificed on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> Therefore, <b>a meal offering,</b> which is generally brought voluntarily, <b>and</b> offerings of <b>a nazirite,</b> which have the status of vow offerings as no one is compelled to become a nazirite, were <b>sacrificed upon</b> a private <b>altar.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Only burnt offerings and peace offerings were sacrificed</b> upon <b>a private</b> altar, not meal offerings or offerings of a nazirite.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Any</b> offering <b>that the public or an individual</b> could <b>sacrifice in the Tent of Meeting in the wilderness</b> could also be <b>sacrificed in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal. What,</b> then, is the difference <b>between the Tent of Meeting in the wilderness and the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal?</b> During the period of <b>the Tent of Meeting in the wilderness</b> private <b>altars were not permitted</b> and offerings could be sacrificed only in the Tabernacle, while during the period of <b>the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal</b> private <b>altars were permitted. But</b> even if one desired to sacrifice an offering upon <b>his</b> private <b>altar on his roof,</b> he could still <b>sacrifice upon it only burnt offerings and peace offerings.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Any</b> offering <b>that the public</b> could <b>sacrifice in the Tent of Meeting in the wilderness</b> could also be <b>sacrificed in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal, and here,</b> in the Tabernacle in Gilgal, <b>and there,</b> upon private altars, <b>only burnt offerings and peace offerings were sacrificed</b> for <b>an individual. Rabbi Shimon says: Even</b> the <b>public</b> did not sacrifice every type of offering in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal; they <b>sacrificed only Paschal offerings</b>

Daf 117b

<b>and compulsory</b> public offerings <b>that have a set time</b> to be sacrificed, e.g., daily offerings and additional offerings. Public offerings that do not have a set time were not sacrificed upon the great public altar in Gilgal.
§ The Gemara explains the various opinions cited in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> that only vow offerings and gift offerings, such as nazirite offerings and meal offerings, were sacrificed upon a private altar during the period of Gilgal? It is <b>as the verse states: “You shall not do all that we do here this day,</b> every man whatsoever is fitting in his own eyes. For you have not as yet come to the rest and to the inheritance” (Deuteronomy 12:8–9).
<b>Moses said</b> the following <b>to the Jewish people: When you enter Eretz</b> Yisrael but have not yet arrived at Shiloh or Jerusalem and are therefore permitted to sacrifice upon private altars, you may not sacrifice whatever has been sacrificed in the wilderness, i.e., both obligatory offerings and gift offerings. Rather, the phrase “every man whatsoever is fitting [<i>hayashar</i>] in his own eyes,” means that <b>fitting</b> offerings [<b><i>yesharot</i></b>], i.e., offerings that are fitting in one’s eyes and are brought due to one’s own benevolence, <b>you may sacrifice,</b> but <b>you may not sacrifice obligatory</b> offerings. <b>Meal offerings and</b> offerings of <b>a nazirite are</b> included in the category of <b>fitting</b> offerings: Meal offerings are sacrificed as vow offerings or gift offerings while offerings of a nazirite are considered a vow offering, as becoming a nazirite is not compulsory.
<b>And</b> what is the reason that <b>the Rabbis</b> disagree with Rabbi Meir and state that meal offerings and offerings of a nazirite were not sacrificed on a private altar? They hold that <b>a meal offering is not</b> ever sacrificed <b>upon</b> a private <b>altar</b> and that offerings of <b>a nazirite are</b> considered <b>compulsory.</b> While one assumes the status of a nazirite voluntarily, once he has become a nazirite he is required to bring the offering.
With regard to this, <b>Shmuel says</b> that <b>the disagreement</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis pertains only <b>to the sin offering and the guilt offering</b> brought by the nazirite. <b>But with regard to the burnt offering and the peace offering</b> that the nazirite brings, <b>all agree</b> that <b>they are</b> considered offerings that one deems <b>fitting</b> to sacrifice <b>and are</b> therefore <b>sacrificed</b> on a private altar.
<b>Rabba raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>the breast and thigh</b> portions of peace offerings, which are given to the priests (see Leviticus 7:34), <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering,</b> i.e., the bread that was given to the priests from each of the four types of loaves that were brought with the thanks offering (see Leviticus 7:14), <b>apply</b> only <b>with regard to a great</b> public <b>altar, and do not apply with regard to a small</b> private <b>altar.</b> Rabba comments: <b>By contrast,</b> another of the priestly gifts, <b>the cooked foreleg</b> of the nazirite’s ram (see Numbers 6:19–20) was <b>omitted</b> by the <i>tanna</i>.
Rabba notes: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> even <b>with regard to</b> whether <b>a burnt offering and peace offering</b> of a nazirite may be sacrificed upon a private altar, then in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i> that omits the nazirite’s ram? It <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the peace offering of the nazirite was not sacrificed upon a private altar. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>they disagree</b> only <b>with regard to a sin offering and guilt offering,</b> while the Rabbis agree that the peace offering and burnt offering of a nazirite were sacrificed on a private altar, then in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>?
<b>Rather, if</b> this <b>was stated,</b> it <b>was stated like this: Shmuel said</b> that the <b>disagreement</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis pertains only <b>to</b> the <b>burnt offering and peace offering</b> that were brought by the nazirite. <b>But with regard to</b> the <b>sin offering and guilt offering, all agree that they are compulsory, and</b> even according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir they <b>are not sacrificed</b> upon a private altar.
§ The Gemara continues to clarify the opinions in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda, <b>said</b> that any offering that the public or an individual could sacrifice in the Tent of Meeting in the wilderness, including vow offerings, gift offerings, and compulsory offerings, could also be sacrificed in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal. It was only on a private altar that the individual was limited to sacrificing burnt offerings and peace offerings. <b>And the Rabbis say: Any</b> offering <b>that the public</b> could <b>sacrifice in the Tent</b> of Meeting in the wilderness could also be sacrificed in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal. An individual could sacrifice only burnt offerings and peace offerings, whether on a great public altar or on a private altar.
The Gemara clarifies the two opinions: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> that only the public could sacrifice compulsory offerings on a great public altar? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the period in which private altars were permitted: “You shall not do all that we do here this day, every <b>man whatsoever is fitting in his own eyes”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:8). This indicates that it is <b>“a man,”</b> i.e., an individual, <b>who may sacrifice only</b> offerings that he deems <b>“fitting,”</b> i.e., voluntary offerings, but <b>may not sacrifice compulsory</b> offerings. <b>But</b> the <b>public may sacrifice even compulsory</b> offerings.

Daf 118a

<b>And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that an individual may also sacrifice compulsory offerings on a great public altar, could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>when</b> the phrase “whatsoever <b>is fitting” is written,</b> indicating that individuals may sacrifice only vow offerings and gift offerings, <b>it is</b> with regard to <b>“in his own eyes” that it is written.</b> In other words, it is referring to a location that is fitting in his eyes for sacrifice, i.e., a private altar. <b>But on a great</b> public <b>altar, even compulsory</b> offerings <b>may be sacrificed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> even if that derivation is correct, <b>isn’t “man” written</b> in that verse? <b>Isn’t that to say that</b> with regard to <b>“a man,”</b> i.e., an individual, <b>only</b> offerings that one deems <b>fitting</b> to sacrifice <b>may be sacrificed, but compulsory</b> offerings <b>may not be sacrificed?</b> The Gemara replies: <b>When “man” is written</b> in this verse, it is <b>to qualify a non-priest</b> to perform the sacrificial service on a private altar.
The Gemara challenges: But the fact that <b>a non-priest</b> is qualified to perform the sacrificial service on a private altar is <b>derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And the priest shall dash the blood against the altar of the Lord</b> at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting” (Leviticus 17:6). The verse indicates that service at a great public altar may be performed only by a priest, from which it is inferred that the service on a private altar may be performed by a non-priest as well.
The Gemara replies: <b>Lest you say</b> that whereas that verse indicates it is not required that the service on a private altar be performed by a priest, nevertheless <b>consecration of</b> the <b>firstborn</b> is <b>required</b> for this purpose, <b>as</b> was the case <b>initially,</b> i.e., before the Tabernacle was constructed. Perhaps the only non-priests who may perform the service on private altars are the firstborn sons. Therefore, the verse states: “Every man whatsoever is fitting in his own eyes,” which <b>teaches us</b> that with regard to private altars, each person may sacrifice his own offerings.
§ The Gemara clarifies the opinion of the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda, by questioning: But the statement of <b>the Rabbis is</b> identical to the statement of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis cited at the beginning of the <i>baraita</i>, who say that on a private altar an individual sacrificed only burnt offerings and peace offerings. What is the difference between the first <i>tanna</i> and the Rabbis?
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> is whether <b>libations were offered in the wilderness</b> along with burnt offerings and peace offerings. According to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, libations were not offered in the wilderness, nor were they offered in Eretz Yisrael during the period of Gilgal. According to the Rabbis in the latter section of the <i>baraita</i>, libations were offered in the wilderness and in Gilgal.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that even the public did not sacrifice all offerings in the Tent of Meeting in Gilgal; they sacrificed only Paschal offerings and compulsory public offerings that have a set time. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon? As it is written: “And the children of Israel</b> encamped <b>in Gilgal;</b> and <b>they kept the Passover</b> on the fourteenth day of the month at evening in the plains of Jericho” (Joshua 5:10).
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that they brought the Paschal offering? The Paschal offering is compulsory. <b>Rather, this</b> verse <b>teaches us that</b> in Gilgal, <b>only compulsory</b> offerings <b>similar to</b> the <b>Paschal</b> offering, i.e., that have a set time, <b>were sacrificed, but</b> offerings that are <b>not similar to</b> the <b>Paschal</b> offering <b>were not sacrificed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, i.e., the Rabbis who disagree with Rabbi Shimon and hold that during the period of Gilgal other offerings were sacrificed by the public, interpret the verse?
The Gemara responds: <b>It is necessary for</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> was taught <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan. As Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Bena’a:</b> If <b>an uncircumcised</b> Jew contracted ritual impurity from a corpse, he <b>may receive sprinkling</b> of the water containing the ashes of the red heifer on the third and seventh days of his purification, despite the fact that he is uncircumcised. In the time of Joshua, the Jewish people became circumcised after they were purified from impurity imparted by a corpse.
§ With regard to the Paschal offering and compulsory public offerings that have a set time mentioned by Rabbi Shimon, the Gemara relates that <b>a <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the presence of Rav Adda bar Ahava: The difference between a great</b> public <b>altar,</b> e.g., the altar in Gilgal, <b>and a small</b> private <b>altar is only</b> that the <b>Paschal offering and compulsory</b> offerings <b>that have a set time</b> may be sacrificed upon a great public altar, but not upon a private altar. Rav Adda bar Ahava <b>said to him: From where</b> would <b>an individual</b> sacrifice <b>compulsory</b> offerings <b>that have a set time?</b> There is no such offering brought by an individual. It was therefore unnecessary for the <i>tanna</i> to state that this type of offering is not sacrificed on a private altar.
The <i>tanna</i> <b>said to him:</b> If so, <b>shall I remove it</b> from the text of the mishna, and teach only: Paschal offerings? Rav Adda bar Ahava <b>said to him:</b> That is not necessary; <b>interpret your mishna</b> as referring <b>to a compulsory burnt offering,</b> i.e., the burnt offering of appearance brought on the pilgrimage Festivals by every individual, which is not sacrificed on a private altar, <b>as there is,</b> conversely, <b>a voluntary burnt offering</b> that may be sacrificed on a private altar. This <i>baraita</i> must be discussing a burnt offering brought by an individual, <b>as if it is</b> referring to <b>a sin offering</b> brought by <b>an individual, are there compulsory</b> sin offerings <b>that have a set time?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him establish</b> the <i>baraita</i> as referring <b>to</b> the <b>compulsory meal offering</b> of an individual, which has a set time, <b>as there is</b> the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering that the High Priest was obligated to sacrifice every day and that may be sacrificed only upon a great public altar, not upon a private altar. The Gemara replies: Rav Adda bar Ahava <b>holds</b> that <b>there is no meal offering</b> sacrificed <b>upon an altar</b> outside the Temple, even a great public altar.
§ The mishna teaches that when <b>they arrived at Shiloh,</b> private altars were prohibited. There was no roof of wood or stone in the Tabernacle in Shiloh; there was only a building of stone below, and the curtains of the roof of the Tabernacle were spread above it. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One verse states,</b> with regard to Hannah bringing Samuel to the Tabernacle: <b>“And she brought him to the house of the Lord in Shiloh”</b> (I Samuel 1:24), <b>and one verse states: “And He forsook the Tabernacle of Shiloh, the tent that He had made to dwell among men”</b> (Psalms 78:60). <b>And</b> in addition, <b>it is written: “Moreover he abhorred the tent of Joseph and chose not the tribe of Ephraim”</b> (Psalms 78:67).
One verse describes the Tabernacle in Shiloh as a house, while the other describes it as a tent. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? As the mishna states: <b>There was no roof</b>  of wood or stone <b>there; rather,</b> there was <b>stone below,</b> and it was therefore described as a house, <b>and</b> the <b>curtains</b> of the Tabernacle were spread <b>above it,</b> and it was therefore described as a tent. <b>And</b> the period that the Tabernacle was in Shiloh <b>was</b> characterized in the Torah as <b>“rest”</b> in the verse: “For you have not as yet come to the rest and to the inheritance, which the Lord your God has given you” (Deuteronomy 12:9).
§ The mishna teaches that during the period of Shiloh, <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> were eaten within the curtains, and offerings of lesser sanctity and second tithe were eaten in any place that overlooks Shiloh. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Oshaya said: As</b> in the context of the prohibition against sacrificing outside the Tabernacle, <b>the verse states: “Take heed to yourself that you do not offer your burnt offerings in every place that you see”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:13), from which it may be inferred: <b>You may not offer up in every place that you see, but you may eat</b> the offerings <b>in every place that you see.</b>
